query: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon provide us with sage advice.
comments: ['What a great quote. Is it possible that Steve Irwin read most of this but stopped right before the last part, beginning "and avoid...."', 'Why is the Spelling Bee link not working?', 'Did you get an answer? I have been trying to access spelling bee for three weeks now with no success.', 'Terrific puzzle!  (No surprise there.  it\'s EC & HR.) My only for-sure gimmes were ABBOTT and ANTIGONE, but I had a lot of maybes, and when I tried them out they were almost all right. I had a co-worker once who was a big TINTIN fan and had the comics pinned up all over his cubicle, so that was a leg up for me.  My first thought re "Din" was indeed KIPLING, but I held off, thinking they wouldn\'t dare.  Hah!  KLINGONS were an early thought too, but I was sure there were other HIGH-BROWed aliens. With a few letters, I took a chance on LOT\'S WIFE as sounding appropriately Biblical, especially with Mount Sodom. Dredged up memories of COUSTEAU and HERZOG from the clues!  Forget ESPOSITO; needed all but one letter, and then took a chance. One mistake:  The only Gourmets I remembered were the Galloping and the Frugal.  So I guessed and put in HAPPY, which of course had me grasping my STING RAY by its SPARACLES.  Well, at least I knew where to look for my error when the music didn\'t come. Hardest clue/word:  SKI SUIT.  Now to go look up "salopette" and see if I\'ve ever seen one. Thanks for the fun to my two favorite SLYBOOTS.', "ABBOTT and NARNIA were about it for me where gimmes were concerned.  I had LASERS in and took it out several times.  I have heard of Drake, so I tried RAPPING, and after a little thought came up with KLINGONS.  I saw spiracles but wasn't sure it was real.", "Started out nicely with COUSTEAU, ABBOTT, NARNIA, HERZOG, and KLINGONS. Thought of LASERS, but for some reason was hesitant to put it in. But I had enough to dig right in to the quote. I guessed a bit on You can... up a good-... and your, and soon had ...is the best way to lift... I looked up LOTS WIFE and ESPOSITO. Then I took a side trip to remember the Galloping Gourmet, which I used to watch a lot. Didn't know of the HIPPY, YCLEPT or SLYBOOTS. Finally thought of TINTIN when I got the Ts, but Gunga Din really tricked me. Good one! I was thinking of unruly children. Loved the part about the bowling ball. It's tempting to try it out, but they would probably get mad at me over at the Academy of Sciences.  P.S. Probably best not to refer to Tintin as French lit to a Belgian.", "As always, we enjoy a good Acrostic! Alas, though, it fell too quickly due to repeated words in the quotation. (But without them we'd never have gotten some of those words -- for example, RAPPERS, KLINGONS, and SKISUIT. So we shouldn't complain.)", 'I had a bunch of gimmes for this one--LOT’S WIFE, YCLEPT, ABBOTT, NARNIA, DAY LILY, RAPPING, ANTIGONE. Also a couple of guesses that turned out to be wrong and led me into fruitless paths--ROBOTS for LASERS and STIFFENS for RIGIDIFIES. For the third word, I had PI-- and tried various letters for the 4th space. K gave me KIPLING immediately, with a groan (my first thought for "Din creator" was TODDLER). SKI SUIT and COUSTEAU appeared once I had a few letters of those words. Democritus was the only early Greek atom guy I could think of and I couldn\'t even really think of his name (I thought it started with a D) but since he was the wrong guy it ended up not mattering at all. Once I had filled in "spiracles" I did look it up to make sure it was actually a word. "Good-sized" was the absolute last thing I filled in--had no idea what that hyphenated word was going to be. But I solved it, so it was fun!', "Alors, Deb, Tintin il est personnage Belge! It's like confusing Klingons and Romulans... hee hee", "Oh right, DC.  I suppose next you'll say that Poirot wasn't French either.", 'Or telling us he was a leek.', "I only had one gimme, ANTIGONE, but was pretty sure of LASER.  Not exactly enough to start working from the quote, so did some googling.  Even when I had quite a few answers I had more trouble than usual getting word in the quote as nothing was making much sense to me.  The breakthrough came when I finally got STING RAY (I always thought that was one word). Then that fun toggle back and forth bit came quite quickly. Favourite misdirection was Din creator which fooled me completely.   Good fun as always My print has suddenly changed to italics, don't know why, don't know if it will look like that in the comments and don't know how to change it back.  No italics here anyway.", 'ABBOTT was my only gimme, which was my excuse for using Google far earlier than I usually allow. Very difficult but not unfair. Is RIGIDIFY a real word?', 'Rigidify reminded me of this video about Gaussian curvature - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gi-TBlh44gY Plus: pizza.', 'The Acrostic made my day when my memory dredged up YCLEPT.  EC & HR are marvelous constructors.', 'I learned "yclept" from Deacon Mushrat in the old Pogo cartoons. Walt Kelly learnt me a lot of good ol\' words!', 'Common Sense was a nice new kind of “middle” puzzle, but it could have been a bit more challenging. Very seldom do I get the feeling that there were too many gimmes in a puzzle, but this time I did.', 'This was the third Thursday night in a row when the links to the weekend puzzles did not come up. And again at least I was lucky enough to remember that trick about changing the date in the Web address of the previous one. Anyway, this Acrostic was on the difficult side, with quite a few answers that I had to search for. [SPOILER ALERT] My only absolute gimmes were ABBOTT and YCLEPT. Having one or two letters gave me TAUNTS and LASERS. After a while I suddenly realized ANTIPODES. There is always at least one trick. Yes, KIPLING created Gunga “Din”, alright!', 'P.S. To Deb: That "Constructors\'s Notes" is still there. Was that ridiculous-looking typo pointed out to the Times?', "Hi Jerrold, How late would you say it is? I've reported it, but am waiting to hear back.", 'The links must have come up sometime during the post-midnight hours. They were finally there when I got up Friday morning.']
summary: Many of the commenters discuss the crossword puzzle provided in the article. Several of them talk about the "gimmes" the puzzle had. A few commenters discussed how difficult the puzzle was, with one commenter stating it was "very difficult but not unfair." A few of the commenters discussed that some of the links in the puzzle were not working properly, with one commenter stating this was the "third Thursday night" in a row that the links haven't been working.
short_title: Headline: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles; Acrostic Puzzles   Snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon provide us with sage advice.
short_question: ['Variety Puzzle: Acrostic  ']

query: C-sections can be lifesaving, but they increase the risk of subsequent miscarriages and other problems.
comments: ['1st child was a csection due to decelerating heart rate 2nd & 3rd were scheduled csections.   Never went into natural labor w all 3. A necessary breast reduction prevented breastfeeding (this was in late teens) All 3 kids are healthy & thin build Rarely an ear infection Eczema has cleared—2 had it when younger', "I had two vaginal births followed by hemorrhages, and one scheduled c-section for a stubborn left-handed breech baby. The c-section was the easiest recovery of the three. I was so freaked out about the c-section that I might have tried a vaginal delivery with that baby, too, if I had been able to find a doctor who would let me attempt a vaginal breech delivery. There weren't any. As my husband said, there is probably a reason for that. Like antibiotics, c-sections save lives. We should use them when they're needed and not when they're not.", "My 92 year old mother had 9 C-sections... she is healthy for her age as are all 9 of us.  Perhaps something has changed in the process in the last 50+ years since her last one... or maybe there are just too many variables in our lives and C-section procedures for science to isolate one as the cause of any particular problem.  The percentages mentioned are increases in probabilities, but no mention of whether that's a 17% increase in a .000001% chance?  Poorly written at best.", 'It\'s infuriating when people assume that c-section moms feel like they have failed. I promise I have no regrets about being alive and having two healthy babies. I did not "miss out" on the birth experiences. I had two birth experiences.', 'My first son was delivered by an unnecessary C-section. I was able to breast-feed. He developed just fine, did not not get asthma, and is nowhere near obese. I healed up ok from the operation, but I was disappointed not to have given birth vaginally. My second child was born vaginally. The doctor gave me an episiotomy, but I also tore. Of course I required quite a lot of stitches and it made for an uncomfortable recovery, to say the least. My baby, completely breast-fed, developed an eczema that wouldn\'t quit, which finally sort of cleared, only to be replaced by asthma. And don\'t even get me started on the food allergies. And now, twenty years later, I have a rectocele, a cystocele, and a gradually falling uterus. I get up about 2-3 times in the night to go to the loo. Which is not to say those anatomical things wouldn\'t have happened anyway, but the vaginal birth experience surely hastened them along. This little "article" on the "risks"  of c-sections is nothing but click bait.', 'Did they factor into the risk for the outcome the reasons for the c-section in the first place?  There are built in medical reasons for a lot of c sections that affect the health of the mother and child after birth.', 'I read this article twice and could not find any "long term risks to the mother" mentioned at all, unless she pursues future pregnancies. Instead, it starts off by citing several long-term BENEFITS of C-sections. Maybe that would have been a better title: "Cesarean Delivery Can Have Long Term Benefits to Mother, But Theoretical Risks for Child."  You could also publish an article: "Vaginal Delivery Can Pose Long-Term Risks to Mother And Child" and it would be equally true. But they wouldn\'t publish that because C-sections are supposed to be evil and we\'re supposed to hate them, and vaginal births are supposed to make all our kids skinny, perfectly healthy geniuses. Personally, I loved my scheduled C-section. I didn\'t take longer to heal, certainly not nearly as long as my friends who tore pushing for many hours. I sleep 8 straight hours without ever having to get up to go to the bathroom and have never had a second\'s incontinence, ever. My child is skinny and perfectly healthy with no allergies and a wonderful appetite. So are both my parents in their 70s/80s, who were fed exclusively with whatever formula was available in 1940. I\'m tired of these articles that push public health propaganda and stigmatize women who — often very reasonably, often because it is the only option — have C-sections and use baby formula.', "This article is a very short synopsis to a complicated medical issue. Pregnancy is a very complex human condition. During pregnancy there are multiple changes in a woman's body that increase the chance of blood clots, hemorrhage, hypertension, diabetes, gall bladder disease, kidney problems and more. In general it is better to avoid surgery whenever possible because of the risks of anesthesia, bleeding and infection. However, every situation is specific to the patient and her condition. The goal with every pregnancy should be healthy mom and baby.", "I wanted a healthy baby and my giant baby was not coming out except by c-section.  We both did well. I did not have a subsequent pregnancy, but if I had, I would have had prenatal care to ensure the best possible outcome. Stop scaring people!  Most women want a BABY, and they will accept it however it arrives.  My doctor stayed up all night with me, hoping that my son would emerge vaginally, but when he did not, he was ready to perform the c-section that saved my son's life. I was grateful then, grateful now and would do it again if I had to.", 'I requested a c-section because I was young and terrified.  Thankfully, my doctor reassured me and I had a wonderful birth experience.  Several friends have had c-sections for various medically necessary reasons.  Though they did have longer slower recoveries their children are healthy.  Well, there are risks either way we are so fortunate to have so many relatively safe birthing options.', 'C-sections are often life saving. However, we certainly do too many of them these days. They are harder to recover from and carry the risk of more complications. Part of the issue is unnecessary inductions of first time moms that often fail and end in c-section. These moms will then usually have a repeat c-section with the next baby. C-sections can delay breast milk production and lead to more failure of breast feeding especially in first time moms. These are issues that we can work to improve in obstetrics.', "My 32 year old daughter just requested her birth certificate to get the exact time she was born because she wanted her astrology chart read. I knew the time was somewhere between 6pm and 9pm-ish but wasn't certain. That's because at about 5:30pm, after 24 hours in a labor that never progressed, her heart monitor strip showed heart deceleration - signs that she was in distress. As a medical student in labor, I went 'deer in the headlights' and time froze as they prepped us for c-section. She just told me that her birth certificate said she was born at 6:02pm. We must have been rushed to c-section. She was born a tired but healthy baby, and in my opinion, has grown to be a brilliant young woman.  Apparently, my pelvis has bony projections that prevent a normal sized fetus from exiting. My second child was a scheduled section, during which the anesthesia almost killed me. Still, I am grateful for two normal and lovely adult children and 32 years as their mother. I know that would have not been how things played out if my daugher and I had lacked access to a c-section.  Yes I would have preferred a successful vaginal delivery. Yes, she had a lot of ear infections as a young child (perhaps maternal vaginal microbiome deficit??). Yes, my lower abdominal muscles are weak and weird from the two surgeries - but I don't think either of us would have made it well through the first delivery.", 'I had 2 vaginal deliveries AND was a full-time, stay-at-home, breastfeeding mom. My kids were constantly sick; the younger one had to have tubes in her ears at 13 months after both eardrums burst. I think the microbiome thing is overhyped.', 'I had 3 c sections, I have no problems and I have three healthy thin adult children, no asthma. I really think it depends on the individual.', "You need to separate out scheduled c-sections, including for maternal request, from those that are done when a vaginal birth goes wrong--when much of the long-term damage has already occurred. Then you need to compare the statistics for scheduled c-sections against those of all vaginal deliveries. Scheduled c-section have their risks, but one of them is not the tremendous pressure on a woman's delicate nerves and muscles that may never heal well, if at all. Or the tremendous pain often produced by vaginal delivery. To be honest, we need to focus on the health of the woman, physical and psychological, a lot more than the health of her baby--she grows it from nothing but her blood and her bones, then gives it life at risk of her own.  Obstetrics needs to treat women like the creators and life-givers that they are.", "Rates of maternal death in the US are like third world countries because we do not provide prenatal health services to women (mostly poor women). It's disgusting and disturbing since men make the rules. I guess they forgot they had a mother.", 'So many of us have been encouraged to have c-sections because it is quicker and easier for the doctors. It is a shame that the ob/gyns do not take these serious effects into account.', 'I requested a c-section because I was terrified of a vaginal delivery.  Thankfully my doctor calmed my fears and stressed that the safest option for both myself and my baby.  I was still terrified when the time came but actually had a wonderful birthing experience.', 'Oh please! And what are the long-term risks of vaginal delivery? Let me think...hm...incontinence for Mom and disability for the child. I had two c-sections and no regrets.', 'With respect to the link to obesity, asthma, still birth and miscarriage, did they control for maternal characteristics like socioeconomic status, obesity, diabetes, maternal asthma, etc?  If so, this is interesting.  If not, then it’s silly to publish this and suggest a causal relationship.  The placenta accreta link I bet is causal, but the rest I doubt unless they controlled for these factors.', "Sigh. Is it really any surprise that woman who had to have a C-section the first time went on to have subsequent pregnancy problems? It seems like there is a confusion between cause and effect to me. The first C-section was a symptom (effect) and the subsequent problems are a symptom (effect). Also, you are always (100% of the time) older with a second or third pregnancy; if you initially had problems, they're not going to get better with time.", "I nearly died after my second cesarean.  My OB told me the previous scar hadn't let my uterus stretch properly and it was as much thinner than normal for full-term as saran wrap is thinner than a styrofoam cup.  Took them more than two hours to sew me back up because I wouldn't stop bleeding and tearing.  Strange thing is that I had a VBAC between the two.", 'This is devastating for the one-third of US women who undergo a cesarean. They will blame themselves. However, it is lack of access to and support for vaginal birth after cesareans that keeps our cesarean rate going up and up not the failure of women. We need health policy that addresses this as the crisis it is.', "Disagree that this is devastating for those of us who have had C-sections. It  may  be for some but please do not lump us all into one category.  It is not a personal failure on our parts nor something to blame a competent physician for.  Each case is individual and unique.   I would also like to read the specifics of this study and see it replicated before I get too worked up about it's findings.", 'I think that one of the problems is that not every case is individual and unique, that a certain percentage of women choose c-sections just because it sounds more doable, when they could probably deliver naturally with no complications.']
summary: Almost every single commenter has a negative view of this article. Many commenters give their personal experiences with c-sections and the current health of their children born via c-section. Some commenters want to know if the article's author controlled for either existing conditions in the mother's health or medically required c-sections versus elective c-sections.
short_title: Headline: Parenting: Long-Term Cesarean Risks   Keywords: Pregnancy and Childbirth; Caesarean Section; Miscarriages; Children and Childhood; Asthma; Obesity   Snippet: C-sections can be lifesaving, but they increase the risk of subsequent miscarriages and other problems.
short_question: ['Parenting: Long-Term Cesarean Risks  ']

query: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles, including the Spelling Bee.
comments: ['Spelling Bee is my absolute favorite. NEVER  drop it. I head for it as soon as I get  the Sunday NYT...it is SO MUCH FUN.  ITs the ONLY time that I can somtimes call myself a GENIUS.   Cami', "We live for the Spelling Bee, too! So sorry to see we came too late to this forum. Bring the 'A Little Variety' posting back. All the smaller puzzles are so delightful to do in between the others, that's when the answers come rushing in.", "I live for the Spelling Bee.   Don't compound the bad decision to hire Bret Stephens!  This may change my mind about subscribing.", "Keep Spelling Bee   and publish the answers for previous week.  Don't betray your subscribers !!!!", "Keep the Spelling Bee. It's my favorite!", "Hi. I just found this!!! Don't discontinue it!  Promote it on the crossword page. All I see there is the wordplay blog", 'Could an online feature be added for people to submit brief pieces using the words they discovered in the Spelling Bee? Using the puzzle from this past weekend as an example: His reaction to the meter in the piece he was reading was more of a mixer. He didn’t have the temerity to critique the writing to the extreme. The effort would have been akin to rowing a trireme by oneself. However, he was feeling merry as he composed the thoughts he would remit. The verse was old-timey and a bit rimey but not entirely without merit, although reading some parts was like taking emery to an extremity. With his editor’s mitre, or miter, firmly in place, he began his task.', 'I should have added this to my previous post: can some kind soul tell me the Spelling Bee puzzle (and maybe provide the answer list)?  I would thank you profusely.', "So what do I do when the NYT Sunday doesn't get delivered to my home (which happens about 1/3 of the time these days) and I have to look online for the Spelling Bee?  Where will it be then?  Please help.", "Waiting for an answer, someone often steals my magazine from my paper and I can't find the spelling bee online or on my digital subscription.", 'I access it from the press reader app. Hope that helps.', "Please don't eliminate Spelling Bee!  I look forward to this puzzle every week.  I just switched from home delivery to online delivery and I will be very disappointed if I don't have my puzzles to keep my brain in gear.  Also, please make them easier to find.", "I do hope that you will continue to include on line Frank Longo's puzzle, Spelling Bee, under another title than A Little Variety. It is a great puzzle and I look forward to it each week. Thanks", 'Spoiler alert: Anyone else enter COOCOO?  How about ATAXIC? And what is COMMIX?  I thought of it but decided it was not a word.', "Where do I find the mysterious Variety page?  One reason we don't post often is that one must hunt down the post, buried back in WordPlay someplace...  There should be a place for commentary (especially since I often have words that are not on the Longo List) so I hope you can steer me to this other location for commentary.", 'I look forward to the Spelling Bee all week. Please please please keep publishing it online!', 'I love the Spelling Bee. It is the first thing I reach for in The NY Times on Sunday. I wish you would continue it.', 'Good for you.', 'Thank you so much!! :)', "Spelling Bee is likewise the first thing I reach for in the Sunday Times, too. Thank the Word Gods that Spelling Bee will continue, even if this forum won't.", 'Thanks for the heads-up, Deb. As others noted, ALV puzzles, while beloved, don\'t lend themselves to much blog-worthy chat. I hope the PTB won\'t confuse the comparatively lower traffic here for low interest in ALV...which for me, is the first thing I do with my Saturday paper delivery, over coffee. Scrubs my brain from the week\'s overload. I hit the Spelling Bee even before sports or op-ed, which says a lot! And this might be my last chance to have a "private forum" to say: Bring back 3-D Word Hunt! :-) See you on the other side.', "It may be that there are limits to what one can say about these puzzles. The middle one is most conducive to comments, and most of us agree that Patrick Berry's offerings are tasty morsels.  Capsules can be made more difficult at times, but the strategy doesn't really change.  Spelling Bee is fine, and yet it doesn't lead to a larger discussion of its merits.  If one can occasionally refer to a particularly fine example in the regular Variety discussion, that seems appropriate to me.  Thanks for giving it a try.", "I definitely understand that it's more trouble than it's worth. Maybe we can all agree to discuss these puzzles in the comments thread for the week's regular variety puzzle? 3-pointer popped right out, and it went quickly again this week.", 'Hi, Deb, I agree with the basic decision about discontinuing the separate page for A Little Variety, but hope that the Powers will agree that solvers would appreciate (see notes already posted here): --continuing to post a link (on the Variety post page) to the Spelling Bee answer list; --continuing to post the Spelling Bee letters as you have been (required letter, plus alphabetical list of other letters); and --adding the points breakdown for the Spelling Bee, which I and others have been adding weekly. In the olden days, we always felt bad about OT posts regarding Variety puzzles on the Sunday puzzle page - so continuing to have a home on the Variety page will be nice. But it has been a small club. Thanks for your curatorial work!', '“For Starters” has come to be one of my favorite “middle” puzzles. [MAJOR SPOILER ALERT] BOTTOM was such a gimme that I initially wondered if it could be wrong. TORERO was my other gimme. I first thought that the third horizontal word would be SUPPLE, but that was quickly disproved because I already had GROTTO going downward. I got ORTEGA only from the crossings.', 'P.S. I am disappointed to learn of the decision that was made regarding the discontinuation.', ". I respectfully dissent. Deb still has to write 8 blogs a week, solve puzzles live on facebook, cajole celebrities to construct puzzles, code the puzzles for all the different platforms, monitor the Comments for sourpusses, etc.  As long as she still gets the medium-sized bucks, the decision is fine. In all frankness, the readership was advised that this was an experiment; yet I never noticed a spontaneous uprising demanding that the 9 a.m. post become a fixture on the site. I had the National Park Service photograph the attendance at the pro-LVblog Rally and at the anti-LVblog Rally. Melissa McCarthy has declared that attendance at the anti-blog Rally was far larger than at the other one. It's unclear if the President forced the Service to then destroy the photographic evidence. The people have spoken! So have Deb's bosses, I presume.", 'Please continue providing the Spelling Bee answers as they appear in the Magazine? Thanks.', 'Genius Points?']
summary: The overwhelming majority of commentators want to keep the Spelling Bee puzzle, with some sharing experiences such as skipping everything else to do that puzzle first. A few commentators like the puzzle but see the difficulty of blog commentary on it and are willing to adjust the format. A few other commentators have trouble finding the puzzles online and want directions.
short_title: Headline: A Little Variety   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles, including the Spelling Bee.
short_question: ['A Little Variety  ']

query: Paulo Dybala of Juventus will face off against Barcelona’s Lionel Messi on Tuesday — a chance to see how close the resemblance between the two Argentines has become.
comments: ["The young man scored 2 exquisite goals for Juve against the Catalans today. He is gifted with a great sense of position and lethal right foot. Will he be the new Messi? I don' think so. I don't think he has the flare and ball control the way Messi does. And he is 23, not 18 years old.", "My apologies to Mr. or Ms. Smith, but this article is puzzling. I'm tempted to be quite rude about it, but will bite my tongue. The article says nothing about Dybala's play, nothing about his skills, nothing about goals scored or chances created. Nothing about how his play does or doesn't parallel Messi's. A silly, People Magazine level, article.", 'JPL, NYT for all its wonderful articles and information still views "the beautiful game" through the lens of a news (not a sports) site. So the article is entirely on point through that lens. If you wish analysis of the athlete in question, you should read elsewhere.', "I disagree. Some description of how they are similar, and different,  as players seems appropriate for an article such as this one. I'm not suggesting in depth technical analysis, but this article gives virtually no sense of how Dybala might be the new Messi except that he's young, and people say so. Is that news? What I think is missing is some description of what it is that he does that brings people to make the  comparison. That doesn't seem to me to ask the Times to go beyond its ken and  into the realm of specialty sports coverage coverage.", "In my opinion there are only one best player in the world and this is Lionel Messi. His game is fantastic and his definition it's perfect, and this it can not be equaled. Maybe Paulo Dybala is promissing to be a very good player but I doubt that he will become a player as good as Messi.", 'To get a red card is to be a star? Going back to 1966 and Argentina\'s captain Rattin being expelled against England and refusing to leave the field. It led to the English calling the Argentines "animals," and decades of ill will. I saw Maradona sent off in the fifth, and last, match of his first World Cup, in 1982 v. Brazil. Upset at rough treatment (Claudio Gentile was far worse on him the previous match), he took it out on Brazilian sub Batista by kneeing him in the groin. Batista came on to protect/relieve Zico in the 83rd, with Argentina trailing 3-0. Then Maradona kneed him. An ill tempered match, Ossie Ardiles ended the match with his shirt torn down to his navel. But what Maradona did hardly confirmed his star status.']
summary: Commentators say they think Paulo Dybala is a good player but do not believe he matches Lionel Messi. Another commentator did not like the article, said he was not addressed about Dybala's game, his skills, or his goals scored, and he did not make a comparison between him and Messi.  A commentator says that a star cannot receive a red card and cites other important players who were expelled from the games and that, in his opinion, this did not confirm his star status.
short_title: Headline: The Next Messi? A Young Argentine Turns Heads   Keywords: Soccer; World Cup (Soccer); Dybala, Paulo (1993- ); Messi, Lionel   Snippet: Paulo Dybala of Juventus will face off against Barcelona’s Lionel Messi on Tuesday — a chance to see how close the resemblance between the two Argentines has become.
short_question: ['The Next Messi? A Young Argentine Turns Heads  ']

query: What professions would you like to see featured in a day-in-the-life article and video?
comments: ['It takes a lot to be a professional ballet dancer, however I wasn’t really surprised at how much it takes to be one. I myself am a dancer but nowhere near the level of a ballet dancer, and even being just a high school dance team dancer it takes a lot. I was surprised to read that they have twelve hour days, and they are on their feet for the most part of the day. I would find the costumes and the makeup most appealing, because they are just so beautiful and almost dream-like. The jobs I am most interested is a dermatologist and a lawyer. I would like to see these, because as a teenager I am really not able to truly get a feel as to what the professions are. If they were a day-in-the-life-video out there about these careers it could help me make a life changing decision.', "One job I'm interested in is Game Development. What is it like to be a game developer? Is it just like any other job? What about one person development. I've seen many Indie games that had one developer do great. What would their daily life be? I'm already learning programming and I could already make a game, but I'm just wondering if I would want to continue on this path, or move on to a different one. Is a life of a single developer fun?", "One job that I am interested in is being a forensic scientist. I've always loved science courses throughout school and I was very intrigued with the small forensic unit in Biology. I think it would be cool to work in law enforcement and to use science methods to investigate crime scenes and analyze evidence gathered at the scene of the crime. This job is very important because it is very important that crimes committed by people be punished for their actions and using modern technology we can do this much more reliably.", 'A job i am intrested in right now is the role of being a dancer. It takes a lot of time and effort to be a dancer and it is a job where you are constantly learning new things.The thing I love most abput being a dancer is that there is no perfection. No one could ever say "I am a perfect dancer" because there will always be things that you wont know. I like a challenge and being a dancer is certainly a BIG challenge. I aspire to be a professional dancer when i get out of high school.', 'The job I am currently most interested about has to be the job of being a manga artist. One must have a lot of creativity and skill in order to make a story that draws people from many different backgrounds in with the addition of wonderful art that helps keep the story flowing correctly. I have always been interested in how manga artists use panels and white space to help their story flow as well. They are entertainers that tell stories through art. That in itself is fascinating to me.', "I personally was very surprised by the life of a professional ballet dancer. I knew that ballet dancers were constantly playing roles in various shows but I didn't expect for them to be cramming 7 shows in one day!  I would love being on stage all the time but constantly running from place to place and never getting a chance to to take a break and breathe is what I think is the least deseriabke aspects of the job. I career that I am very curious about is a psychologist. Psychology to me is very interesting. The way that someone just know how the mind is working and can help others through that is absolutely amazing. Furthermore, just the satisfaction of helping someone cope with their problems or just letting them have the chance to talk to someone is enough.", 'The job I am most interested in has to be a fire fighter. The way they have to plow through walls and doors like a bull. The things they have to got through physically and emotionally is amazing. They also have like super-hero powers. They are always there to save the day. Even if they have a life of their own they are always there to help other people.', "The job I am most curious about is the fire department. I know what they do requires a high physical demand, it also takes someone who cares a lot about everything they do, you have to be motivated to help people knowing you are risking your own life to help someone that needs help. I would like a video that shows what they do everyday for the people that they don't even know. They carry 60-80 pounds of extra gear, they do drills when they aren't busy to help practice there skills so they can help us when the time comes. They do this job so you don't have to.", 'A job that I am most curious about is a psychologist. I like the idea of working in the field of psychology because I really find pleasure in helping people deal with their mental or emotional issues. It is a great feeling knowing you are doing something worth wild that helps someone else out and makes their life even the slightest bit easier. Additionally, I find it interesting and beneficial to listen to and take someones problems about topics such as relationship problems, family issues, eating disorders, and learning problems into consideration. Not only does it help the person to cope with their issue, but it could also give the psychologist an idea of how to lead an optimistic path for their own life.', "I am most curious in the job of professional crime scene cleaners. I believe it is a very hard job that only very few are able to do because it requires a hard stomach and a non-emotional attachment to the scene. I would like to see crime scene cleaners and detectives in an article. I believe these jobs don't get enough recognition considering how hard and gut-wrenching they can be. The people that occupy these jobs are amazing and deserve for their stories to be told."]
summary: A good number of commentators want more info about police and fire department jobs, such as a firefighter and a forensic scientist. Several commentators are interested in types of dancers, especially ballet. One commentator wants to know about manga artists, another about game developers, and another about psychologists.
short_title: Headline: What Jobs Are You Most Curious About?   Keywords:    Snippet: What professions would you like to see featured in a day-in-the-life article and video?
short_question: ['What Jobs Are You Most Curious About?  ']

query: Subway riders look on as a foam container balances uneasily on a sleeping man’s hand.
comments: ["That is my pet peeve (an old-fashioned expression I find appropriate here).  I hate when people get on a rush hour subway and eat a full course meal like they're in a restaurant, especially in the morning.", 'Lovely, so his mess was left on the floor. When did the subway turn into a buffet line?', 'Oh, for some of those big, juicy pieces of meat! What is the rule (in seconds) for eating something that falls on the subway floor? Zero, obviously. A friend passed me a wrapped root beer candy in the subway the other day, ate his, and watched me fumble and drop the candy on the 1 train. The three second rule did not apply, so I picked the candy from the floor, and placed it in my jacket pocket for disposal later. (It did get thrown away, I promise.) Some passengers on the train with me had a discussion about the seconds rule. At home, I told them jokingly, I have a three week rule. "You must have a clean floor!" one of them explained. "No," I said, "I have a lot of candy on my floor. Look!" I pointed across the car. "An M&M!"', "I would be embarrassed to write this diary entry. No one thought to help out a guy who was losing his meal and soiling the subway floor? The description of the man's attire was very detailed, was his appearance a factor? I'd rather people didn't carry open food containers with pungent aromas into the subway in the first place, but would it have hurt to give this man a heads up?", 'It is amazing the urban talents we develop over time. Nope, it is no accident that he entire container contents did not fall to the floor. When we nod off we retain a level of consciousness concerning our surroundings. It is our version of a cat nap.  I could always nod off and not miss my station. A tourist might end up in New Lots, but not a native.']
summary: The commenters each react differently to this article. Multiple commenters share their own experiences of people's behavior on the subway. One disagrees that people act in this way on a subway while another shares their distaste for subway passengers' hurried behavior. One commenter shares an experience of dropping food on the subway and being sure not to pick it up. Another commenter states information about our awareness when we sleep, which is why the person from the article did not drop their food container.
short_title: Headline: Watching a Box of Takeout Teeter on the Edge   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Subway riders look on as a foam container balances uneasily on a sleeping man’s hand.
short_question: ['Watching a Box of Takeout Teeter on the Edge  ']

query: New York counties that banned trans fats in foods showed steeper declines in heart disease than those that didn’t have trans fat restrictions.
comments: ['Something along this line should happen with high fructose corn syrup. Of course, you have to fight with the agriculture industry.', 'There is significant momentum across the Region to take action on trans fats. Denmark, Austria, Hungary, Iceland, Norway and Switzerland have set similar limits that virtually ban trans fats from food products, but consumption remains high where no policies are in place. For example, a recent study revealed that people could consume as much as 30 g trans fat per day in some eastern countries in the Region.  This is a concern, as consumption of only 5 g per day is associated with a 23% increase in the risk of coronary heart disease.  Even in European Union countries, high levels of trans fats can still be found in some food categories, and there is some evidence of higher consumption in low socioeconomic groups.*  Denmark has seen several benefits from virtually banning trans fats. •Intake decreased among all age groups, and is now one tenth of the level when the ban was adopted. •Within one year, most products on the Danish market were able to comply with the new limit of 2 g trans fat per 100 g fat. •The overall nutritional profile of food products could improve, including increases in use of healthier fats (such as monounsaturated or polyunsaturated fats), according to the Danish Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fisheries. •The drop in trans-fat consumption may partly account for the significant decrease in mortality from cardiovascular diseases recently experienced in Denmark.', "Amazing how common sense and taking care of one's self can be so successful in leading to better health and happiness. And it can be done without taking useless pills and crash diets.", 'Trans fats were banned in my family since my parents were in their early 30s. Becoming an M.D. Ph.D. I saw the difference that makes an everyday diet without trans fats. The chairman of nephrology, Pr Lagrue, did an extensive study, in France that was not accepted in the 70s by the international peer reviewed journals. He showed that trans fats, starting after the great depression were as bad as Tobacco for human health. I campaigned since against trans fats, added sugar, GMO, and tobacco. These simple measures can prevent more than 60% of chronic diseases and light up health care bills.', 'Trans fats are likely deadlier than cigarettes, alcohol and illicit drugs.  They should be reclassified as a poison and taken out of our food supply.', 'Would be helpful if your article explained what is a trans fat for those of us who are ignorant about this subject.', 'When trans fat is banned, what substitutes do food manufacturers, restaurants and bakeries use in its place?  This is a good opportunity to identify suitable replacement fats have the taste, presentation and chemical properties acceptable to the food industry.', "People at home can use lard.  It sounds icky, but you can buy it in squares like margarine, and it can be used to make baked goods.  I don't know about food manufacturers, though.", 'It is true that most people do not know what a trans fat is, how it is manufactured, how it behaves in the body, and why it is dangerous to our health. Most people think a trans fat is just vegetable oil. It is not. It is a mutation of the atoms in vegetable oil by the process of putting oil under high heat and pressure in the presence of nickel. This results in an oil that has a very long shelf life, but that the mitochondria in our bodies cannot metabolize well, resulting in storing the fat (which is chemically like wax) in our arteries. If you do not read labels for trans fats, or hydrogenated vegetable oil, or partially hydrogenated vegetable oil, you will not know if you are eating it or not. Our government and the industries that put this in our food, resulting in heart attacks and death since WW11 should be sued. But they will not. They will skate off into the sunset with their profits, meanwhile, saying, "More research needs to be done." Before the invention of this fake oil, heart attacks were almost unheard of. But there is plenty on the web about it, if one cares to look into it.', '"Before the invention of this fake oil, heart attacks were almost unheard of." How do we know that? If you would, kindly supply a source for that info.', 'The study looked at hospital admissions. A patient could be in a hospital for observation without being formally admitted.  https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/19/your-money/when-a-hospital-stay-is-no... https://newoldage.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/29/two-kinds-of-hospital-pat... https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/07/us/politics/new-medicare-law-to-notif...', 'How did they control for travel outside those counties? Surely some of the people lived near county borders and ate food in public places in counties where trans fats were not banned? And conversely, what of people who lived in the trans fat counties but near the border of a non-trans fat county. There should have been some reduction, though lower than that of people living in the center of the non-trans-fat county, in both groups.', 'Or is it possible that those counties that banned trans fats have a better-educated and wealthier populace, who was also more likely to be following other health guidelines such as exercising and not smoking?', 'Very good points !!  This study is encouraging however we now need a prospective study which as Caring Feminist mentioned, taking into consideration: education, income, ethnicity and cultural influence, diet such as intake of sugared beverages and high refined carbohydrates, smoking , exercise, etc.. Hopefully the study is on tract to support the positive effects of  government regulation to help improve health. Yes there will be backlash against the "nanny state" but "nanny" seat belt regulations have prevented many injuries and deaths.', 'One does not need to do such a time and money costing analysis.  One only has to do a comparison of the counties before the ban.  If the counties had a similar heart attack figures before, and different after the ban such a cost of time and money is not worth while.  Also, any eating out of borders would decrease the effect of the ban, not increase it.  And even if the counties with the ban were more educated, they were more educated before the ban too, and the ban reduced heart attacks. This information is both important and priceless. - a retired epidemiologist.', 'This is a good example of how government agencies can make changes to improve public health. Unfortunately, government agencies are often more influenced by industry lobbyists than by serving as the guardians of public health. To make matters worse, industry officials are often recruited to lead government agencies. We are caught in a political predicament that resists rational attempts to prioritize the public interest.', 'It is our good fortune we read, we can teach our children to read labels at a much earlier age.  To teach the great human ritual of making choices and how those choices affect how we feel and function.   The government has nothing to do with how we make nutritional decisions.  Poor DC.  In one corner you have the nutrition pyramid, the other corner there are the junk food lobbyists, the sugar mongers and capitalist\'s dumping who know\'s what into our drinking water.   Common sense is only recognized when it is a " well-planned and well- executed public policy " paid for by the public who actually pay taxes. You can choose to be despondent or you can enjoy diving headfirst into growing and making your own food.  Parents have a lot on their plate and it better be homemade!', 'A win for evidence based public health!']
summary: Many commenters agree that trans fats can cause serious health complications, and their intake should be reduced. They lament that there is not more policy towards reducing these fats, and some argue that the private industry is having too much impact on policy. Some commenters argue that the study may not be completely accurate because of other factors like people leaving counties or differences in education and exercise.
short_title: Headline: Eat: Trans Fat Bans Help Hearts   Keywords: Trans Fatty Acids; Recalls and Bans of Products; Heart; Stroke   Snippet: New York counties that banned trans fats in foods showed steeper declines in heart disease than those that didn’t have trans fat restrictions.
subreddit: ['Trans Fatty Acids', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Heart', 'Stroke']
short_question: ['Eat: Trans Fat Bans Help Hearts  ']

query: Copper & Kings, in Kentucky, is just one of many distillers, large and small, betting that brandy will be the next big brown liquor.
comments: ['"Julia Momose, a cocktail consultant." Puhleeze.', 'Not much different than a perfumer.', 'Here in Wisconsin, we know the secret to picking a fine brandy. What Is the case price?', 'Too much emphasis on grapes.  Lairds Apple Jack has been producing a good apple jack for years.  Not as good as real Calvados, but the flavor is good and the savings are enormous.', 'Vivacity Spirits in Corvallis, OR has just released their first Brandy.  It is a single vineyard, pinot noir grown in the Willamette Valley, aged 2 years in pinot noir barrels.  So very very good! I suggest you check it out, it will be available here soon.    https://crafted-life.passionspirits.com/vivacity.html', 'RMS  Brandy was very very good.  Better then  Remy France', 'any one notice a common thread ; lot of immigrants, no brandy without them...', "I'd let the products speak for themselves, but it seems a large part of Mr. Heron's promo is trying to convince people to at least try it.  I'm all for someone being proud of their work, but not everyone is going to like the 'craft beer' approach to such traditionally elegant products.  I'm thinking an asterisk or some such next to the name will alert those who are looking for a traditional taste that they should seek out a taste at their local bar before jumping in and buying a case.", 'When making brandy based Sidecars, I use good old Presidente.', "When did Chip Tate start distilling again? We tried to visit his new distillery a month ago and it was just a construction site. Didn't look like they were anywhere close to making anything at that point", 'I think we should boycott products from Kentucky. especially McConnell.', "Brandy, at it's best, is a true and faithful representation of the very spirit of its source fruit. In South Florida, hundreds of exotic fruits from around the world are grown and many are made into wines. The potential of extracting, concentrating, preserving and delivering these exotic spirits is tremendous for those that know how to blend great cocktails, as well as sippers of fine spirits. The noble grape is king of brandy, but many other delicious fruits can be wined and distilled into marvelous spirits for the expanded enjoyment of their essence. The door is now open for exploring high quality expressions of many delicious fruits.", "I agree with Ron: you can't talk about American bandy without mentioning Laird's Bonded and the long history of apple brandy alongside rye whiskey in the original colonies. On the other hand, while I welcome new market entrants, I'm not looking forward to the 50-100% price increases and diminution in quality we've endured with rye.", "I am also a fan of Laird's. The 8 year old is good but I really like the 12 year version. Laird taught George Washington how to make it. They to this day have US liquor Lic. #1. Now live in NJ so I guess I am partial. They have been making it here longer than anyone else.", 'I\'m looking forward to tasting the picks on this article. Besides the superb Germain-Robin selections, I\'m not very familiar with American brandy.  As a 10 year Cognac drinker, I take issue with the "...in contrast to the muted elegance of Cognac" definition. Great Cognac (and Armagnac), especially those coming from the smaller distilleries, can be tremendously flavorful. And great French brandies can be difficult to locate here in LA.', "In my opinion Cognac/Armagnac/Calvados should be subtle and complex. They are delightful little sippers. But like wines made in the US, these brandies are brash (fruit forward, hot). I'll pass for now, but I have hope that the producers will mature and eventually start making a more complex product.", "I am surprised by your putting in the same basket Cognac/Armagnac/Calvados: cognac is double distilled. There used to be rare, lower-alcohol varieties of cognac (made, if I am not mistaken, by the family D'Or) that fill one with warmth and lift the spirit without scratching the throat.", "You're wrong. Armagnac & Calvados is double distilled, not Cognac.", '@SK: Cognac is absolutely twice distilled. Here is a detailed description of the process:  http://www.cognac.fr/cognac/_en/2_cognac/index.aspx?page=distillation', 'It is most refreshing and encouraging that the country of hamburger eaters with ketchup has started to produce brandy -- apparently well drinkable, according to the commentators below.', "Tuvw Xyz - What's wrong with a country of hamburger eaters with ketchup?", 'Watch out!  Next they will be pairing the brandy with burgers.', 'Wow, no mention of Clear Creek? They have been doing this for 30 years.......  http://www.clearcreekdistillery.com/', 'Outstanding, complicated brandy. Their grappa is outstanding also.', "I second Ant'ney re Clear Creek.  Excellent product produced with finesse and sophistication.", "An interesting story.  I will have to look into some of the Brandies mentioned.  It is interesting that you quote Mr. Heron when he conveys the sentiment, 'Is it hot'?  I've tried Germain-Robin several times.  I always found their XO to be a fairly 'hot' brandy in that the alcohol was not well integrated, and its heat was prominent on the roof of one's mouth.  I will look for both, Copper & Kings and Osocalis for further 'research'!", "You forgot to mention Lairds brandy (maybe because it's made from apples?). But you did Calvados!", "I love Laird's and I love how wholly appropriate it is that a New Jersey dweller pointed this out!", 'I noticed that, too-- if I remember right Laird\'s is the oldest trademarked spirit in the u.s.(?) But the author also also refers to Christian Brothers\' and E&J\'s "thick, super-sweet style," so you have to assume the research was lacking on some basic level for this piece.', 'Copper & Kings brandies are great. Their absinthe overwhelmingly so.']
summary: One commentator said he would try the brandy featured in the story and a few more from other brands. Another commenter says that the secret to knowing the quality of a cognac is due to its price. One commenter thinks that people should taste the product before buying. Another commentator believes that new products on the market can increase the price and decrease the quality. One commentator thinks that cognacs from smaller distilleries can be tremendously tasty.
short_title: Headline: The Next Big Brown Sip   Keywords: Alcoholic Beverages; Louisville (Ky); Copper & Kings American Brandy Co; Osocalis Inc Distillery   Snippet: Copper & Kings, in Kentucky, is just one of many distillers, large and small, betting that brandy will be the next big brown liquor.

query: The league’s onerous demand in a class-action suit on head injuries seems to show little regard for medical privacy and accepted scientific facts.
comments: ['This is Gary Bettman at his finest. Imagine him at his worst. He takes the typical "republican" approach; when the evidence is overwhelmingly against you, simply deny it exists. Deny, deny, deny. Its a strategy that has worked effectively, especially  with the segment of society who actually fear science. Facts always seem to get in the way when you choose to live in the bubble of fantasy. For Bettman its more like a way of life.', "How 'punch drunk' can one outfit collectively get themselves? Tragically literally.", 'Typical, attack the bearer of bad news, and ignore the news and its facts.', 'Bettmann is a reprobate.', "I'm a huge hockey fan, so I am not surprised by the NHL's attitude. This is a league that has always been too conservative, and the general managers and owners have for too long been extremely reluctant to modernize the game. Bettman has been in control of the league for way too long and a change at the top is way overdue, but I'm not exactly optimistic.", "The NHL, as well as other leagues, tries to give fans what they think the fans want.   The NHL is too afraid to eliminate fighting completely because they think there will be more fans who will ABANDON their product due to no fighting than will START watching or RETURN to watching it.  Which is ridiculous.  Only an idiot would stop watching hockey or starting watching hockey just for the fighting.  They'll gain more fans than lose if they outlaw fighting, considering today's PC environment.  The NHL apparently thinks so little of its sport on its own merits to have the GUTS to eliminate fighting.", 'As much of a hockey fan as I am, this stinks!  Bettman deserves a game misconduct.', "The crucial unasked question is, what about the rest of us?  What's the incidence of CTE among the general population, those of us who never played in the NFL or NHL?  When you go through life, things happen, including concussions.  It would be helpful to know if there's a risk of this condition developing in even non-athletes.", 'I believe that football, hockey, and certainly soccer ( because of the collisions heading the ball) probably do contribute to the risk of C.T.E.--Probably even starts when the participants start playing, long before their professional careers. But , for argument\'s sake, let\'s say that players are pre-advised, of this contingency BEFORE they sign a professional contract. ( like the warnings on cigarette packs and alcohol) What percentage of these elite athletes  would chose to opt out of signing that contract? I\'m. certainly  not blaming the victim here---but doesn\'t the cliche: "Buyer beware" have some semblance of creditability here? This, of course, does not excuse the various sports leagues from doing everything in their power, to educate, improve equipment, and what ever else they can bring their resources to bear to ,at least , mitigate the potential dire circumstances which can result. Not to be cynical here--but flag football, and no-checking hockey, will not improve TV ratings.', 'The denial of the NHL is completely ludicrous, but money talks or is perhaps silent in this situation.  Have they ever even watched the enforcers beating the stuffing out of each other?  And those body slamming checks into the boards?  Talk about brain rattling.  I love watching hockey but as soon as the "enforcement" begins, off goes the TV.  Rather watch a kid\'s game of hockey before body checking is allowed.', 'The NHL would be better served to get in front of this issue in a positive when instead of its current "science denier" position. The NFL is able to survive the unlimited liability imposed via the courts as it is a cash-generating machine. The NHL is not in the same class.', 'Can they get away with that, and actually gain access to confidential patient information? If so, it could make families hesitant to share information with researchers in the future.', "To this day, the tobacco industry has never attacked the anti-smokers' flagrant scientific fraud of falsely blaming smoking for diseases caused by infection. They use defective studies that miss many cases of infection or ignore it altogether. Those infections are more common among those less wealthy, and smokers are more likely to be among the less wealthy, so that's how they cast false blame on smoking. Every Surgeon General report is proof of their commission of this fraud. http://www.smokershistory.com/SGlies.html http://www.smokershistory.com/SGHDlies.html For the government to commit fraud to deprive us of our liberties is automatically a violation of our Constitutional rights to the equal protection of the laws, just as much as if the government purposely threw innocent people in prison. And the mass media are the anti-smokers' accomplices, who silence dissent to force their phony narrative down the public's throats.", 'I like this. Funny without being vulgar.', "That's an interesting bit of off topic revisionist history.  we faked the moon landing too.", 'Those "anti-smokers" are trying to keep "public throats" and your own free of cancer, among other non-infectious diseases. And they\'re generally opposed to smoking and smoke, not to smokers themselves...boorishness of some individuals in either group aside.', "Even here in Montreal, there are reasons why soccer is overtaking hockey as sport of choice among children.  Cost is one; the league's callous attitude another.", 'This is shameful and wrong. The N.H.L. needs to step up and do the right thing--protect current players and try to help those who were harmed playing this sport and making the owners wealthy.', "It's all about the money. Bettman is a shill for the owners and this makes it even more blatant.", 'The CTE science is "good" and will stand up to NHL scrutiny--or any unbiased scientific review. Detractors will throw "concussion" smoke screens and ignore the likelihood that the pathogenesis of CTE is much dependent on incessant small athletically induced physical trauma to the brain. It won\'t take that much time for the researchers to spread their work out again and again. Maybe some almost innocent brains will be spared future damage.  By the way, why do so many "Enforcers" off themselves?', "Hockey, a great sport. It's long past time the league banned fighting and deliberate head shot checks. That would help tremendously to reduce concussions. Go Leafs go!", "Little did the merchants of doubt know how influential their play-book would be. But the core problem with the NHL is not science.  It's Gary Bettman", 'Sounds like the climate deniers, looking for a way to justify their out of date programs and ideas and to protect the money they are making at the expense of others. Same on you Bettman.', 'I can demand that the NYT gives me all thier data, just for the heck of it.  Of course I wont get it, and should not. On what basis does the NHL expect to get the data?  Its not thiers to ask for.  Of course they dont have one single real scientist to look at it. And it would take thousands.', "Beyond sad. The NHL is trying mightily to cover their bottoms but this effort is doomed to failure and doomed to significantly increase its costs in further litigation.  That's a terribly stupid gamble since its resources are far, far less than that of the NFL.   Ostriches, of course, pretend they are hiding when they put their heads in the ground, but they very much leave themselves exposed. This could ultimately doom the NHL.", 'This not shocking, the NHL has had a deny, deny, deny attitude toward this for years, even when the science and the facts say otherwise, maybe they can hire Kelly Ann Conway to teach them how to pivot and present "alternate facts"', 'Duuhhh...how many jocks do you know that believe in science?', 'Bettman is a mouthpiece for owners loathe to protect players. Punishments should be more severe for headshots, and a "good fight" should disappear from the lingo. I no longer enjoy seeing guys risk careers and healthy lifespans, while modelling a stone age tactic to young players. Change will come from parents and families, not the organizations profiting from violent sports.']
summary: Several commenters suggest that Betman and NHL are to blame because they have a long history of denying any evidence against their purposes. Others say that it is really a financial issue and that the NHL just wants to save face by giving supporters what they want to hear. Another commenter changes the topic by claiming the moon landing was fake.
short_title: Headline: The N.H.L.’s Problem With Science   Keywords: Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy; Hockey, Ice; Concussions; Research; Boston University; National Hockey League; Bettman, Gary; Suits and Litigation (Civil)   Snippet: The league’s onerous demand in a class-action suit on head injuries seems to show little regard for medical privacy and accepted scientific facts.
