query: Wednesday: Paid time off for new parents, the New York Jewish Film Festival, and the debut of electric buses.
comments: ['Hope the co-workers who pick up her slack will be compensated for doing  her work.', "Like many entitlement programs, this was passed as self-financing with a very modest payroll deduction of about 1/8 of 1% of annual wages. As with other entitlements, we will soon find that the cost far exceeds the revenue and the 0.126% tax rate will have to be significantly raised or the state will have to cover the excess and raise other taxes. Consider the math: if we average one 12 week leave period per person per lifetime (an amount roughly consistent with the birth rate) at a payout of 70% of wages, the program would need to collect 16% of one year's wages (12 weeks/52 weeks/year * 70%) to cover the cost of that leave. This is only an approximation. Admin costs will increase that percentage, and whether leave is taken more toward the beginning or end of careers can either increase or decrease that percentage due to the time value of money and changes in earning power over the course of careers. But just considering total money in vs total money out, at 1/8% per year, a person would have to pay in to the system for 128 years to cover a single leave period. Since people work 40 to 50 years at best, there is no way a 0.126% deduction covers that one leave period. Further, once family leave becomes ingrained in our culture, use will increase and come to be perceived as essential for care not only infants but sick parents, children and spouses. People will not average one, but perhaps two or more leaves per lifetime and the tax rate or state subsidy will quickly rise.", 'Electric buses with Wifi and charging ports? Cool. Do subway cars next.', 'TURNABOUT TIME Frigid temps are gone today! Nature finally thaw a way.', "I'm surprised that none of the articles on the new paid family leave policy mention the fact that it completely excludes - at least right now - New York state employees.", "Too bad this Family Leave doesn't extend to NYC public school teachers.  They get no maternity or parental leave.  Instead, they must take their own PTO, borrow against PTO they don't have (which they have to pay back) and go on disability.  Get on it Micheal Mulgrew.", "So, why do people who want to spend time on something that is fulfilling to them, spending time with a newborn, get to do so with partial pay, while others who don't have kids, don't get a similar sabbatical to persue whatever interests them? As a childless person am I really expected to pay for others family choices with no reciprocity for my choices?", 'Speaking as a divorced, no human kids, self-employed gal who sees friends, family, clients, neighbors, etc. all go through the ups & downs of child-rearing amidst the changing times . . It must be said that raising kids is not a "personal interest hobby" like taking an overseas year-long sabbatical or collecting art, but a lifetime duty & social investment that -when done reasonably well by ideally both the male & female parents from in utero (i.e. zero/minimal exposure to toxins, alcohol, drugs) and infancy onward - will directly benefit single, child-free taxpayers like you and me. Just think about it: Properly raised kids by involved parents  = increased probability of better prepared students (benefiting from less financially-stressed, more emotionally & intellectually involved parenting w/c pays attention to details like household nutrition, hygiene, discipline, manners, social skills, time management, having kids read to and spoken to in ways that boost their academic & social readiness, etc.)  = increased chances of more adaptive, skilled, productive future adults who are actually employable &/or start/lead income-generating/job-giving enterprises that can lead to more sustainable economic growth, taxes collected, social security and health trusts actually getting replenished in timely ways = childless singles like you and me not being guilt-tripped/shamed into donating beyond our means to charities filling in as parents to under-raised/under-nurtured/neglected kids.', 'LMCinLA: You may excellent point. While people raising kids deserve support, so do childfree and childless individuals. The decision to bring children into the world is a choice. People who have not made that choice or for whom it is not possible should not be penalized or treated as if their lives, goals, and ambitions are less important.', 'But someday you may depend on other peoples children to care for you in a nursing home or hospital.  Without children, it is the end of the line.', 'Looking to the great, hopefully written weather forecast:  “We’re thawing out. At this point, anything above freezing is fine by us, and today we’re in luck.” Tune of “I’m Coming Out” (Diana Ross “get out there and be happy” version) We’re thawing out We’re thawing, we’re thawing out! We’re thawing out Here’s what we’re thrilled to know How high temps will go! We’re thawing out New York is on the go. until the next big snow Hey the weather’s thawing out The wind won’t last too long Let’s all stay real strong For Thursday’s sunny song. The chill will turn around Guess we always knew it That we’d all get through it Oh, yes we got through! We worried we were stuck, but now we’re all in luck Run out and shout, that we are thawing out We’re thawing out! That’s what we’re thrilled to know, until the next big snow (repeat)', 'I love the idea of paid family leave. It is very compassionate. Free health care and university tuition are also compassionate as is the $15 minimum wage. Welcoming in to the US, vast numbers of impoverished people facing hunger or violence in their home countries is compassionate as were 70s style perpetual welfare payments that increased with every child born to unwed and unemployed mothers. Unfortunately, compassionate policies often create perverse incentives and we somehow have to pay for all these compassionate policies. New York is one of the highest tax states, a problem that is growing with the reduced deductability of state taxes and mortgage interest under the new tax law. Considered individually, our compassionate plans may seem affordable, but collectively these things add up to the point where individuals as well as companies with high-paying jobs that create net payers for our compassion move to lower tax states. This happened in the 70s and 80s. The New York economy collapsed as the net beneficiaries of our compassion stayed while the net payers left. We only have to look as far as Greece, Spain and even France to understand where this eventually leads. I know this program is nominally self-financing, but it does add to our total tax burden and there is a real cost to employers (especially small ones) who suffer loss in efficiency and increased training cost to cover leave periods and then work force rationalization cost when employees return from leave.', 'US is the richest nation the world has ever known.  69 nations provide free health care for all citizens and many first world nations also provide free college education and family leave.  But we “can’t “.', 'Tiffany, the problem with Greece and Spain is not compassionate programs! The problem with Greece and Spain was...they FAILED to collect taxes! Their system of taxation needs an overhaul!  Look as Germany, Japan, Switzerland, Sweden, Norway, Netherlands, et., et., and you will SEE the universal healthcare and social justice programs work to help e dry citizen!', "I hate to ask an obvious question, but why are Ms Limongi and her husband having children when they can't afford groceries? I raised my children, now I guess as I New York resident, I'll be taxed to pay for hers.", 'The nation is still fighting for something that is really standard family policy in all other wealthy civilized societies for decades.  Here we have to struggle to protect the little of social policies we have like SS, health care, and even unemployment compensation.', "I love New York.  I believe it's the greatest city in our country - I'm born and bred in NYC and so were my parents.  Hurrah, New York!!", "A friend in London had one year maternity leave with 6 months at full pay and 6 months at half pay  I understood this was not unusual.  We've got a long way to go.", '"Times readers reacted to the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s new admission policy." My reaction: It\'s ridiculous. Charge all adults $15, charge senior citizens $10, students $5, kids free. Period. The Metropolitan Museum will then be treating everyone fairly instead of screwing its money out of out-of-towners and infantilizing city dwellers. It reminds me of how the Greeks treat their tourists -- Greeks get in free, tourists get socked. Free stuff and early retirement have been the undoing of that country.  Besides, the new policy and the chaos that led to it are part of Mr. de Blasio\'s effort to make New Yorkers feel even more like victims. Really, we can\'t pay to go to a museum? People young and old have what they want to have -- lattes, sneakers, cable TV, flat-screen TVs, cell phones. In Flatbush, too. They go to movies. They respect what they pay for. As for the Met trustees: They certainly messed up with their selection of the previous director, literally a fair-haired boy whose disorganization and smugness lost the Met a lot of money. But in the main, trustees serve one purpose: to fundraise. Mr. de Blasio\'s push for diversity in that context is silly. The Metropolitan Museum of Art has a brilliant, diverse collection of works from all cultures all over the world. People just have to push themselves to take a look. You know, the way they go to movies.', "You can afford a trip from Minneapolis to NYC, but you can't afford a fee to enter one of the greatest museums in the world?", 'B., How exactly is favoring New Yorkers, whose taxes help fund The Met, "infantilizing" them?  I\'m not opposed to charging out-of-towners, but $25 dollars seems like way too much. One hundred dollars for a family of four to visit a cultural institution for a few hours? Heck, I would want to camp out there. Of course, all The Met restaurants are expensive too. The admission fees to many NYC museums preclude vast numbers of residents from attending.', 'Linda, unnecessary comment, unnecessarily judgmental. You don’t know what is in their budget or the reason they travel to nyc or *anywhere.', "MTA takes a lot of cheap shots underground. I think their performance compared to many other cities I've lived in is Superior in every way and they have a little entrepreneur or experimental spirit to them as well. Partially blind and very partial to mass transit I salute their continued efforts.", "Can't wait to ride on an electric bus! Thanks New York City!"]
summary: Several comments are concerned with the lack of family policy and benefits for workers (such as PTO, healthcare, college, etc.) and question why the U.S. can't have these if other countries do. Another commenter asks why the subject of the article is having children they can't afford. One commenter mentions that the countries where social benefits failed were those that failed to enforce their tax policy successfully. Another says that the new family leave policy excludes NY state employees. One criticizes the position of those who feel like family leave is a long vacation and unfair to the childless. A commenter criticized the new museum admission fee plan, feeling that it's unfair to non-locals.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Wednesday: Paid time off for new parents, the New York Jewish Film Festival, and the debut of electric buses.

query: Wine may be made in the vineyard, but a huge California trade show suggests it needs a lot of assistance.
comments: ["Been following you for many years and just sharing my first comment. Your experiences in the wine world are of equal interest as your keen point of view on the wine itself. I would enjoy hearing more about your daily 'behind the scenes' experiences from time to time in your column.", "Any talk of putting an ingredients label on wine bottles? Not knowing what is in the stuff I've taken to drinking mostly organic and biodynamic wines. While this is mostly small labels, it includes names such as Giacomo Conterno.  I'm assuming that these people produce wines from grapes and minimal manipulation, but who knows? Ingredients labels seem like a good idea.", 'Wait, are you saying grapes are grown outdoors?', "I live in the Minervois region of France, home to mostly family-owned wineries. One told me that spraying his vines would cost €4K--which could otherwise buy him a nice family vacation--so he wasn't going to do it unless absolutely necessary. Adding water, sugar, oak chips etc. is a big no-no. Many of the vats are made of concrete blocks, which insulate against temperature swings. And the barrels are oak. As OSS Architect says, a humble French table wine can eclipse California's science-driven wine. BTW, the winemakers, like most people around here, dress up for events.", "None of this fancy widgetry will matter when the industry can't get their labor force across the border.", 'The University of California at Davis established a Viniculture Department in the early 70\'s. It introduced a scientific basis for growing grapes and making wine. US Prohibition wiped out the knowledge of traditional wine making brought over from Europe. So, in California at least, it was starting over from scratch. Learning where the right soils were; cloning European varietals that would work in California\'s climate. All vastly accelerated by the "scientific approach". Having focused on California wine for 40 years, I can say it\'s gotten better, but most importantly more consistent. Science Baby... but let\'s not forget a humble French Commune vin de table, made for generations, can eclipse it. One problem we can\'t seem to solve, organically, is how much alcohol is in the bottle. Initially California wine makers tried to make it a plus. Wine at 16-17% alcohol was marketed as "Big". Then we tried to disguise it with excess fruit. Cartoon wine, that made wine with food, like dinning with Super Heroes.  We still need better solutions to extracting excess alcohol from wine. Using a centrifuge is about the "most organic" but it has to have some effect on the structure of the wine (tannins, etc). Or we can wait until global climate change makes California unfit for wine making and move on North  to Oregon and Washington.', 'Wine is Big Business and when considering profit margins in a very competitive global industry that, unlike beer or spirits, only offers one chance per season to create the product for a successful business, this use of technology makes sense.  While I make natural wines at home for my own consumption, it would be too risky and ultimately a folly to do this on any large commercial scale (and no small boutique wineries can provide a living but are not large scale).', 'My favorite piece of wine equipment is the corkcsrew.', 'Good article. The right way to make wine is to bring good grapes into the winery and leave them alone, while monitoring them with more concentration than a helicopter parent.   And to have every available tech tool at your disposal for when (not if) something goes wrong. Dan Kravitz', 'While living in SF over 40 years ago, a group used to meet at a large retail store for tastings ponsored by large and small vintners.  Somebody said we should do our own tastings and pick our wines to taste.  Well I had a large home with plenty of the in the Marina district of SF.  That went well and then we wanted good food wh our wine.  Several of our group used to sell wine to restaurants and they strongly suggested having tastings on Tuesday evenings as that is the slowest night for them.  Then the Every Other Tuesday Night tasting group was formed and is still going today. fr Kermit Lynch was a member of that group but no longer as he has a large wine import company located in Oakland CA. Kermit has written a great book, Adventures on the Wine Route,  Kermit is extremely thorough about this business and visits French and other European locations to physically see how these vintners make their wine and maintain their vineyards.  Kermit\'s wines are frequently recommended by this NYT site.  Having been in the business for 3 years as marketing and sales manager for Sterling Vineyards, Kermit has written one hell of a book - Amazon has it for under $10.  LESEN as my Deutsch friends say!   Yes great wines are made in the vineyard - the vineyard people know when it will be a great year and tell the winemakers, "Don\'t screw it up" - in the vernacular.', 'Make no mistake, even the smallest family-run wineries use many of these tools. And more importantly, these tools DO make things simpler. Spraying prevents mold from overtaking grapes in the vineyard. Mechanized fruit sorting works BETTER than humans, and costs less. Adding yeast decreases your chance of stuck ferment. Filtering wine ensures that microbes don’t continue to grow in bottle. And I could go on and on. If you’ve ever encountered any of these situations while working in a winery, you know that tools to prevent them actually make things MORE simple, not less.', 'Simpler is better, but not when you are trying to make millions of bottles of $5.00 a bottle wine.', 'This report reminds me of the alleged last words of an old vintner to his heirs on his dying bed. This is what he said: "I´m gonna tell you my last secret. You won´t believe it: You can make wine even from grapes!" (This is an old "Little Ice age" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Ice_Age Carnival joke from Mosel area. The original wording is: "Mr´kann uch us Druve Wing maache!") Since 1960-70 this story is completely obsolete because of climate change. Without any doubt "making wine from grapes" is the cheapest way also for subprime vineyards. World famous top vineyards were never affected even In the coldest days (1895).']
summary: Comments seem to be generally supportive and agree that technology has improved the wine industry with new processes and innovation, a few people say that simpler is better, but the overall consensus is that technology works. Commenters also noted that ingredient labels on wine bottles would be very helpful for consumers who don't want wine that's been made with "manipulated" processes.

query: The recent missile test was only the first in a series of nuclear weapon provocations.
comments: ['I cannot agree that diplomacy, talks, etc., will slow one bit DPRK\'s efforts to produce a long-range nuclear missile. I might defer to the wisdom of Mr. Wit as my experience is limited to reading Victor Cha\'s "The Impossible State" and absorbing the more scholarly articles and documentaries. Unfortunately, Kim Jong-un is the best example of "riding a tiger". If he stops or steps down to any degree the tiger will eat him. I\'m sure that that sea of goofy-hatted militarily we see Great Leader periodically address unanimously wishes him dead but for the fear of execution by anti-aircraft weaponry.      Plan A is working for Kim Jong-un. Plan B is a heavily fortified and stocked underground bunker to survive a nuclear holocaust (don\'t think for a moment such does not exist). Kim Jong-un knows that an inch of relenting will eventually open the doors to his populace learning they are starving and deprived. Such would tear him to pieces - literally.', 'The Trump Administration offers a range of diverse policy thinkers. If foreign leaders refuse the reasonable offers, they’ll get the “offer they can’t refuse.” Deal with Sec. Tillerson—or deal with Trump.', 'Didn\'t Trump just reassure us that development of nuclear weapons a delivery system is "not gonna happen"? So what surprises do the brains behind our foreign affairs, who all appear to be ideological idiots who think what they say goes everywhere in the world, have planned for the North Koreans? A pre-emptive nuke, no matter what those dishonest game-playing Chinese or Japanese or South Koreans have to say about it? Inquiring people want to know.', 'North Korea (DPRK) presents a very difficult policy problem for unilateral action by the US: North Korea has been propped up by China, and South Korea is vulnerable (particularly Seoul) to North Korean attack.   However the situation is not as bad as it seems, because China has every reason to fear its nuclearization, and is now making serious moves to rein-in the DPRK.  China just stopped coal imports from the DPRK -- that\'s serious.  In turn, for the first time ever, the state-controlled press is starting to criticize China. http://www.cfr.org/china/china-north-korea-relationship/p11097 ""China provides North Korea with most of its food and energy supplies and accounts for more than 70 percent of North Korea\'s total trade volume." China\'s strategic goals have been clear: to keep North Korea as a buffer, avoid war on the peninsula.  The status quo had suited China well, until the DPRK started to nuclearize, and act more dangerously to China.  "Acting more dangerously" includes symptoms of collapse, and the recent assassination in Malaysia. North Korea had a famine, partly state engineered, that killed 2.4 million people in the 90s., 2015 was a drought year,  with very poor harvests.   North Korea is close to collapse.  Collapse of the DPRK has been widely forecast for years, and hasn\'t happened.  That does not mean it won\'t, particularly as pressures tighten.   The key to the DPRK, as always, is China.  And it looks like China is moving.', 'This reader wants to know what Mr. Wit thinks the U.S. should or could have done to get better behavior from North Korea over the past 25 years (or more).  Some specifics, please.  Otherwise, I have no idea why I should listen to his advice.', 'Another example of the failed Obama doctrine - chide but fail to act in a meaningful way.', "That not-a-doctrine goes way back.  E.g., George Bush II cancelled our previous agreement with North Korea by failing to carry out our side of the bargain.  That forced them to go back to nuclear reactor development.  I'm not saying this to defend anyone, not North Korea, not Clinton (Bill), not Bush, not Obama, not Trump.  I'm just pointing out that the U.S. has been a fickle upholder of the agreements that were made.", "Don't you mean the failed Trump doctrine. Trump has been in office for a while now and has done nothing on this issue. Where's the deal we were promised? Oh, right...his ex-national security advisor probably took it with him when he was let go for possibly selling out the country to Russia.", 'Nothing new or interesting here. Rather sophomoric. We MIGHT be able to get the North Koreans to stop a project that they have been working on for decades if we reduce the pressure on them. A strategy that has never worked and seemingly has emboldened then. No reasons given why this might work now.', "Trump is curiously clueless about our most serious foreign policy and national defense threats. Either that or he is colluding in one of the biggest acts of treason in history by selling out our country to foreign actors. Or both. For a man so concerned about his image, having a missile fired near the country of his dinner guest while they're eating their fois gras is bizarre. Journalists need to press extra hard to get to the bottom of these mysteries. And we citizens have to continue to press our elected officials to stiffen their political courage to root out those who are abusing their power. Our nation is in perhaps its greatest jeopardy since the 18th century."]
summary: Many commenters point the blame for North Korea's nuclear program at Trump, and some commenters note the long-standing failures of the US curbing North Korea's nuclear program. One commenter outlines the complex relationship between North Korea and China and that it is worsening. Another commenter notes that Kim Jong-Un is all but required to continue, lest his country turn on him.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Embargoes and Sanctions; Missiles and Missile Defense Systems; Nuclear Tests; Nuclear Weapons; United States Defense and Military Forces; United States International Relations; North Korea; Pyongyang (North Korea)   Snippet: The recent missile test was only the first in a series of nuclear weapon provocations.

query: After Equifax’s security breach, consumers looked for ways to make the company pay. One option: Persuade employers not to give the company any data.
comments: ['There is a double standard here. Employers make you sign paper work that says you cannot reveal proprietary information (including financial data) about them but it is apparently fine for them to reveal personal data about me to everyone in the universe? There is something rotten in America!', "It's about time.  This & similar companies should not be allowed to operate without accountability.", 'I suggest each NYT reader in HR or in a senior management position bring this article to the attention of their employer.', "I would have been sceptical, like wcdessertgirl. But then I emailed my HR department, and was pleasantly surprised at the result.  They agreed to stop sending my individual data to Work Number, and have agreed to look for alternatives.  So if Mr. Lieber updates us with what alternatives the NYT finds, that would be great.  And I'll keep on asking for what I want, because you never know.", 'I have asked my Assembly member to introduce proposed changes to the NY General Business Law that would make "personal information a property right. The law would identify personal information as any information about a person which can be used to identify a person such as the last 4 digits of a social security number + age and place of birth. Personal information would be the property of the person that it identifies.  A custodian would have only limited rights to the information.  The end result would be a cause of action if the information is lost or misused.  And my proposed law would ban arbitration and non-disclosure agreements. I believe that this law would have bankrupted Equifax, and possibly much of that industry.  Presto, problem solved!', 'Fascinating article showing how difficult it is to maintain any sense of privacy over our even most intimate financial details in the era of Big Data.  As a lawyer who has frequently sued Equifax what I found most interesting is that it appears that Equifax does not reveal this "Work Number" information to consumers whey they request their "files" or "reports" from Equifax - which they are required to do under the Fair Credit Reporting Act.  Instead they appear to require consumers to specifically request information they have no idea even exists.', 'Thanks for the information. However I wonder what recourse does the independent contract/consultant workers have to stop Equifax “work number”  errors  ?', 'Thank you for helping to hold them accountable. And thanks for not moving on to the next shiny object in the current news era. I think many, including the administration, are counting on the short attention spans.', "Hi!  Thank you for this information.  If true that employers use Equifax and other data collectors information which is private and confidential in violation of California State Law prohibiting employers from seeking information about an applicant's former employment - where when and how much then the State of California must sue Equifax with an injunction prohibiting any business operating in California, no matter where else situated, from doing business with any company that employs individuals working in the State of California.  It is ILLEGAL IN CALIFORNIA TO ASK FOR PAST WAGE OR COMPENSATION INFORMATION.  It is illegal in California to ask for conviction histories unless the type of crime for which the applicant was convicted, relates to the trust factor of the employee's job - ie a thief, fraud, embezzler has to fess up about his or her conviction to a prospective employer.   The transaction was noted on my credit report.  Lastly, where the stolen data goes is to India.  In India they sell information to dirty landlords, employers, etc. who use that data to harm their tenants and or employees.   I know because I found a citing from my former rental property owner's India account.  I prohibit the use of my personal data from any third party overseas and by US based business to transfer my personal data overseas.", 'Above I wrote "the transaction was noted on my credit report."  However, I placed it on the last paragraph after the coming sentence. I discovered this on a credit report which cited a rental property owner\'s India account. To my horror I discovered that my landlord an Indian but nationalized US citizen used an Indian bank service to check me out, not a credit reporting agency. It should be entirely illegal for any foreign national company to collect data on US Citizens their financial records if that citizen IS NOT DOING BUSINESS IN THAT COUNTRY As soon as I discovered this, that information disappeared from the internet view of my credit report.   However, I remember it and there is logic to it, and I will investigate to find out who abused my legal rights. If employers are using 3rd parties to collect, analyze, and report on information that a US cannot access under the Fair Credit laws of the US government, then we as the US have a lawsuit to file, an action against not only these companies but the people who use them. Companies in the US have a legal right to understand and know of the work history of an applicant, but not their wages, not in California.  Employer’s use of credit reporting agencies is a vile means to disqualify persons for a job. Further, the Jesse Unruh Act of California prohibits discrimination on the basis of economic class in housing + business.', "I would have agreed with wcdessertgirl, but then I tried it.  I sent a message to my HR department asking if we used this.  They responded yes, and I pushed back.  They have agreed to stop sending in my individual data, and they have reached out to ADP to see if there are other options available.  For that reason, I'd be very interested, Mr. Lieber, in knowing what option NYT decides to go with.  I'd like to help my employer out by sharing that information.", 'Found out when applying for Xfinity that they use Equifax for credit checks. How do we go about having them switch?', 'What we need is legislation. Is there anyone planning to run for Congress in 2018 that will take up this issue?', "The only clear way to avoid this obvious conflict of interest with all three credit bureaus is congressional legislation.  Assume the dolts in today's congress can get anything at all done, and assuming that they actually hold the welfare of their constituents (you and me) above the influence of highly paid lobbyists, we ought to have a law that simply allows aggrieved consumers to sue these pariah credit bureaus and make them pay for their sloppiness with our personal data.  No wasteful congressional oversight, just penalties when credit bureaus fail to do the job they are sworn to do.  Let's ask our congressmen and women to actually act on this!", "What does one do if one doesn't have an employer? Also, it would be good if the government, social security for instance,  had something in place whereby they could give you a special identifying number, or some such, to be added to your social security card, and their records, if you can show you were a victim of identity theft. That would help with one of the problems.  I was one of Equifax's victims and now that will hang over my head like forever.", 'Consumers can act individually to avoid doing business with Equifax too.  If enough people did it, it could have a huge impact.  For example, you have frozen your credit. Now you are buying a new car and you are applying for a loan through your dealership to take advantage of the zero percent interest. Before your loan goes through the dealership asks you to unfreeze your credit to allow them to run a credit report.  At this point you ask which credit reporting agency they will use. If it’s Equifax, you say “I’m sorry, I don’t do business with Equifax.”  You will have to be willing to walk away.  This would be much easier if you were just applying for a credit card!  But if enough car deals and credit card deals fell through because everyone is refusing to use Equifax, the impact would be huge!', 'Here is a thought. If asked to give permission to check your past employment etc I see nothing wrong in giving that permission and adding the following: Due to the equifax breach of the Fall 2017 and its inability to protect my data I do not give my consent for Equifax to be used to check my past salary /employment. Please use another method. Note: the esteemed NY Times is no longer using the equifax service. Perhaps if enough people push back it will have an effect', 'All  employers need to leave Equifax.', 'And why do we need less regulation of these rotten financial industries?  They need to be free to be more incompetent at protecting the public so that they can rake in the profits before they collapse the economy like the banksters did.', 'Experian is advertising services to protect your identity and personal information.  This is the definition of chutzpah after the breach that released the info for 145 million people', 'I think I would be difficult for the average employee or even group of employees to convince their employer to fire Equifax. Ultimately, as individual and employees, Equifax does not see us as consumers, but rather as products. Selling our information is their cash cow. The fact that very few companies have broken ties with Equifax over the breach leaves little doubt that they will be able to continue business as usual without significant loss of revenue.', 'unfortunately this is all too true. Ron - what about the other two credit agencies? Are they as bad?']
summary: Commenters are disappointed with Equifax for the breach and suggest solutions, including congressional legislation and discontinuing business with Equifax. Other commenters have successfully brought up the issue to their employers and convinced them to quit sending employees' private information to Work Number.
short_title: Headline: Quit Equifax? Unlike You, Employers Can   Keywords: Equifax Inc; Credit Scores; Computer Security; Wages and Salaries; New York Times   Snippet: After Equifax’s security breach, consumers looked for ways to make the company pay. One option: Persuade employers not to give the company any data.
subreddit: ['Equifax Inc', 'Credit Scores', 'Computer Security', 'Wages and Salaries', 'New York Times']
short_question: ['Quit Equifax? Unlike You, Employers Can  ']

query: Will Shortz has some good news for us.
comments: ["I don't see how adding the name of a celebrity enhances the experience of the puzzle doer.  Today's puzzle was substandard.", 'Due to extreme capitalism, CBS is currently not available to cable subscribers in my area (yay, capitalism, it always works!). I really hope there will be some kind of work around link provided for people who want to enjoy the segment but are at the mercy of bickering money grabbers.', "I'm looking forward to this. Especially to Neil deGrasse Tyson's contribution.  I'm sure it will be not only challenging and meticulous, but also witty.", "You didn't mention my favorite Jesse Eisenberg film - 'Zombieland.'  And I just flipped on the TV and found out that it's on AMC at 9:00 (Eastern) tonight. How did you arrange that?", 'You need to have Uma Thurmond work on a celebrity puzzle for the 75th anniversary.']
summary: Two commentators like the idea of the upcoming CBS segment, although one's cable provider doesn't give access to CBS. One commentator wanted to hear a mention about a film, "Zombieland." Another commentator thought that the day's puzzle was substandard and that a celebrity's name didn't help it any. One other commentator wants Uma Thurmond to do a celebrity puzzle.
short_title: Headline: Cool Things Coming Up Next Week   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles; Television; Tyson, Neil DeGrasse; Eisenberg, Jesse; CBS This Morning (TV Program)   Snippet: Will Shortz has some good news for us.
subreddit: ['Crossword Puzzles', 'Television', 'Tyson, Neil DeGrasse', 'Eisenberg, Jesse', 'CBS This Morning (TV Program)']
short_question: ['Cool Things Coming Up Next Week  ']

query: The generic townhouse in Carroll Gardens was nothing special. But now it’s family friendly, with surprising details.
comments: ['I worked at 505 Court Street from 1964-69, in the old Doehler Diecast Building, which in the 70\'s was one of the first industrial loft conversions to condos in that area!  It was always a "safe" neighborhood, because the "wise guys" kept an eye out for potential troublemakers and burglars. They were, in effect, the Auxiliary Police!  It was largely an Italian-American working class neighborhood, with many well kept brownstones and brick buildings.  Gentrification had not begun when I was there......', "300k? I don't see it. How much of that was for the 'architect'?    The most glaring one is the hallway photo with the shoes outside the shoe cabinet.  They have two kids, a larger shoe cabinet,maybe?  I hope there is daily maid service to clean all the stuff on the shelves.", 'Some people commented that the place seems cold, but I disagree.  Then again, I like mid century modern (maybe because I am a mid century modern, by birth) and the simplicity of Scandinavian design. It is definitely my kind of home and I wish this family many happy years there.', 'Good luck with your food emporium. You are a smart man. You did a lot with a lot. - Estaban Goolacki out', 'So we have finally reached the era of the $4.2 million "fixer-upper." Nice that Mr. Farah "got into hedge funds" to afford this and make it his own.', 'Funny that to me the pictures make the property look pretty sterile and soulless. And for four and a half million dollars. You gotta sell a lot of kibbeh for that.', "How far away from Nino's or Vinnie's?", 'Loved everything except the bathroom.', "Who could not love Carroll Gardens?! It's only a short healthy man or woman's walk to the Gowanus Canal, which is a Toxic dump! And one is so far away from those Coney Island tenements, and Sheepshead Bay's, and the Atlantic ocean fresh air!!!", 'What a great customization!', 'This is a stunning renovation and not at all like a "developer special" except that it is modern. I too am a fan of historic architecture, but would be thrilled to live in this simple and elegant home. Kudos to the family and the architect.', "It's always inspiring to read about a successful revovation, but to me the interiors still seem bland and soulless and homogenously in synch with almost any other shelter mag or design site.  It may be a contrarian viewpoint given the current dominance of the mid-century modern aesthetic, but I'm tired of it.  To me it's all just mid-century meh (possibly even mid-century yuck).  Why live in an historic neighorbood with distinctive architecture and spaces only to immerse yourself with the same kind of stuff you would have in LA or Seoul or, well, almost anywhere nowadays.", 'I keep wondering how a developer could have built a townhouse so "soulless" that, barely four years later, it was necessary to gut it completely & rebuild the interior from scratch to make it a pleasant space. And one that sold for $4.2M.  I can remember when a woman friend moved into Carroll Gardens with some reluctance because it was considered a marginal neighborhood!', 'Marginal? Not true. Carroll Gardens was a Bononno Crime Family controlled neighborhood for decades. Organized crime but no disorganized crime in the street. Very safe. Camarerri Bakery and Nino’s and Vinnie’s all there. “I lost my hand!!”', '"I can remember when a woman friend moved into Carroll Gardens with some reluctance because it was considered a marginal neighborhood!" Indeed, when I was a kid in the 1960s and taking the B-75 Smith Street bus to Brooklyn Heights to go to school, I used to look around and see graffiti ("Red Hook Boys") and decay on Smith Street. My parents used to drive along Clinton Street to get to church, and on that stretch, too, things were a little saggy. Obviously, those townhouses hadn\'t been built to look saggy. When a new classmate told me she lived on Clinton Street, near Kane, I was appalled. But what a brownstone! The Italian families in the neighborhood kept a sharp eye out, though, and things never got as bad as they did in other parts of Brooklyn. I\'m glad the neighborhood got better. If the brownstones are too dear for my possessing, well, I\'m used to my long commute anyway, and I do a lot of good reading. As long as the barbarians don\'t mess with the plaster moldings and aim for the modern look . . . .', 'Shortly after my friend moved in, there was a large bag of bones left in front of her door. She was terrified; she thought it was some sort of mob symbol to warn her. Later, an elderly neighbor asked her, "Oh did you make soup from those bones I gave you?"', 'I think I know this house,it did need some more pizazz.  I agree with the article, they did a really nice job upgrading some elements to make it both sparkle and homey.  Although it is not shown, I like that although it is a new building, the facade is a traditional townhouse style that fits into and contributes to the Carroll Gardens/Cobble Hill vibe.', 'Beautiful and cozy. Love it.', "Some great ideas.The entry bench and wall hooks are actually easily available and reasonably priced. While there are design elements I wouldn't choose, thank you for opening your home to one and all.", 'I  wonder what was torn down to build something so unappealing that it needed a full makeover at less than 10 years old.', 'There was a parking lot, for many years.', 'This is a lovely redesign, if a bit cold in color palette for my taste. It’s hard to tell how much work was done in all of those 4,000 sf, but $300k sounds low for the level of work described. Especially since this was a design-to-dusting deal.  The other thing that pops out at me is that, aside from the photo of the boy’s bedroom, the home dies not look kid friendly — even the yard looks sterile. I would have liked to see the playroom.', 'I just completed a Bronx renovation that wasn\'t a fraction as extensive — removing 3 non-breaking walls, plaster patching & painting the walls, interior window treatments, dishwasher & a few new kitchen shelves & kitchen tiles, & a bathroom sink —\xa0with finagling a non-licensed contractor (the original contractor\'s estimate was $65K, and they never come in on budget). And that still cost $110K.  I don\'t want to accuse the reporter of not doing hard verifying or of the subjects here of being "creative" about how they came to $300K, but in NYC, you can\'t get that kind of work for that price.', "I'm not sure I agree.  The mechanicals (plumbing, wiring, HVAC) and exterior shell had already been done. The biggest ticket items sound like the wall of steel windows in the kitchen and the other window replacements. No interior walls moved as far I can tell. Otherwise the changes mentioned were mostly high end finishes and details. But adding a reading nook under the stairs doesn't compare to the cost of building the stairs in the first place!", 'Beautiful project, beautiful story....Very inspiring!', 'Beautiful work and sounds like a remarkably positive experience w the architect. Hopefully he does work in Bergen County as well..']
summary: Many commentators approve of the remodeling job and enjoyed reading the story of how it happened. Several commentators call the house "soulless" and wonder what terrible structure existed before to need remodeling after less than ten years. A few commentators throw dollar amounts around about the cost of remodeling and the property's sale price.
short_title: Headline: Remaking a ‘Developer Special’ in Brooklyn   Keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential); Carroll Gardens (Brooklyn, NY); Design; Interior Design and Furnishings   Snippet: The generic townhouse in Carroll Gardens was nothing special. But now it’s family friendly, with surprising details.
subreddit: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Carroll Gardens (Brooklyn, NY)', 'Design', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
short_question: ['Remaking a ‘Developer Special’ in Brooklyn  ']

query: The New York restaurant rises to first place from third in the 2017 rankings by hundreds of judges.
comments: ["Congratulations! We have nothing but evanescent memories of friendly, skillful servers who invited us at the end of our three-hour lunch back to the kitchen to meet the chef and watch the teams at work. They even plied us with a boysenberry dessert cocktail. Surprise and delight--that's what I'll never forget about Eleven Madison Park. Unlike a play I can read or an opera I can hear after an event, this restaurant  just lives vividly in my recollections unaided by props.  No, I've never attempted to recreate one of the recipes. They're just too challenging for home cooks. One last note:  People who spend their money for experiences, not things, don't deserve the derision of people whose priorities might involve expensive cars, clothes, art, or furniture.", 'I must ask why does it Matter? The manipulations these Chefs do to Food and the Outrageous Amounts of $$$$ charged is Grotesque and Immoral. Let the 1% Enjoy', 'Everyone loves lists and rankings and such but do the genuine "people in the know" really believe them?  A native of New York, I lived in Italy (Bologna, to be precise) for 8 years and no one can live in Bologna for 8 years - no one - and not learn SOMETHING about great food, especially of the Italian variety.  I\'ve been to Osteria Francescana and would never say that my meal was bad there because it was very good.  The problem is that nearly ALL meals in Italy are good, if not very good.  Well, it was very good but not especially memorable.  I haven\'t been to Eleven Madison Park, I confess, and will hopefully one day enjoy a meal there.  Still, from what I\'ve heard from people that I know and from what I\'ve read and seen in the press, I wonder if I might not walk away with the same feeling that it was "very good" but not memorable.  I do imagine it will be better than my experience at Per Se, however, which WAS memorable for the $1700 Chateau Lafite 1982 my host ordered as well as the number of courses, none of which I have any recollection of at all.', "as long as I AM NOT PAYING $300 for a meal I will never find out if they can make a dish that I can't make at home just as well.", "The list is nearly fully male. That's a little more shocking than the fact that eleven Madison took the top spot no?", 'I dined at Amber #24 in Hong Kong last year.  While the food was good, it wasn\'t "world\'s best". The worst part was I was dressed in jacket and slacks , many patrons were dressed in tshirts, ripped jeans, shorts.  One even wearing flip flops. World\'s best?  Not by a long shot', "These lists are always fascinating for what they say about food trends - I have eaten at 8 of these top restaurants, and what I got from each one was passion:  for food, flavor, ingredients, a caring for the person eating the food - my wife and I ate at Eleven Madison Park last year, and it was fascinating - from Caviar Benedict to inflated Pigs Baller - here's a look at our feast -  https://johnrieber.com/2017/04/05/eleven-madison-park-2017-winner-of-wor...", "We are beyond delighted that after seven years of trying to score a reservation from out of town we finally ate at Eleven Madison Park a month ago.  It deserves this accolade - service, ambience, food - impeccable.  But from now on you'd be better off reserving for your grandchildren when they grow up .... tough ticket just became impossible ticket.", 'Congratulations !']
summary: Some commenters indicate that they are not impressed with the list. One commenter says that the list is all-male, and another says that they ate at one of the restaurants and did not feel it was the world's best. One commenter expresses disgust at how patrons are overcharged at these restaurants. Another commenter expresses congratulations to the restaurants and salutes them for creating such complex dishes. Two commenters talk about their positive experiences at Eleven Madison Garden, the number one pick.
short_title: Headline: Eleven Madison Park Tops List of World’s 50 Best Restaurants   Keywords: Eleven Madison Park (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant); Melbourne (Australia); World's 50 Best Restaurants; Restaurants; Cooking and Cookbooks; Chefs   Snippet: The New York restaurant rises to first place from third in the 2017 rankings by hundreds of judges.
subreddit: ['Eleven Madison Park (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant)', 'Melbourne (Australia)', "World's 50 Best Restaurants", 'Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Chefs']
short_question: ['Eleven Madison Park Tops List of World’s 50 Best Restaurants  ']

query: Monday: A notable New Yorker, Off-Broadway Week and reflections before Lent.
comments: ['Technically and legally he is an asylee and not a refugee. This matters since asylum seekers are in the U.S. when they file an asylum claim, whereas refugees are overseas and file for refugee status with the UNHCR and the U.S. government.', 'Congratulations on your citizenship!  and thanks for your work to make USA a great place to live.', 'Luis is a hero, and far more qualified to be POTUS than the current one.', 'Mr. Mancheno didn\'t just "raise my hand and putting it down, suddenly I became an American citizen." He helps, daily, to raise, nurture, and spread important human values and norms, such as mutual trust, help, and caring, which are being trampled, increasingly, by diverse people who complacently- actively foster marginalization, stigmatizing, exclusion, dehumanization and a WE-THEM destructive life space. In addition to commending him- which is so easy to do- he is to be joined by an active US, helping as best as one can, whatever our roles, however, whenever, wherever, to make needed differences in the toxic environments which our silence and inactivity enables. Have WE deleted from personal, and national memory, the institutionalizing of violating  the socio-political constructed “ other:” beginning with ongoing dehumanizing of  North America’s indigenous populations by foreigners seeking refuge;The Orphan Train Movement,(1854 and 1929), relocating about 200,000 orphaned, abandoned, or homeless children from crowded Eastern cities to Midwest foster homes as a “supervised welfare program;” the internment of Japanese American citizens; the McCarthy era; America’s unresolved bigotry, and discrimination? Remember Pastor  Martin Niemöller’s “caveat” First they came for the Socialists, and I did not speak out.Because I was not a Socialist.Then they came for the Trade Unionists,and I did not speak out.Because I was not a Trade Unionist… there was no one left to speak for me.', 'On immigration: we are in this world "together".One world. Many here have or had relatives from other countries.   We should show the world more compassion. Instead Trump increases defence spending.  Who will he get to fight ?', "What an amazing story!! I commend him and respect him for what he did! The fact that he wants to help other people is amazing. I don't see him as gay, an immigrant, refugee or citizen. I see him as an amazing human being and I wish him luck, success and happiness.", 'Great story, and I commend Luis for perservering through all of the obstacles during his journey to citizenship and a commendable career. This journey is also not unlike millions of others who also fought over the decads and "who are fighting a gigantic system that tells them they don\'t have the right to a better life".  That being sad, there are virtually no other countries out there that can provide the Luises of the world with a similar outcome. As imperfect the U.S. is in the eyes of so many of its critics, in reality, our country will continue to fulfill the hopes and dreams of more and more of its citizens, as well as those on a path to eventual citizenship.', 'For Lent, I am giving up labels and adjectives whenever I look at or talk about another person. My reason is simple: once I choose a label, such as immigrant or Trump supporter, that\'s all I then see and allow my fellow conversant to see. I don\'t see or present a genuine person filled with hopes and fears, goals and dreams. I see and reveal whatever my attitude towards that label allows me to see. I am giving up adjectives, even positive ones, because they, too, affect what I see and how I respond. Once I tell myself, "She is beautiful" or "He is dangerous," I respond accordingly. So what will I do?  I will watch behavior, listen to words spoken, seek to empathize with displayed emotion, and do my best to respond compassionately, honestly, and appropriately. Will it be easy? No, especially when the other is responding to me as a label. Will I always be successful? No, and that\'s why I practice meditation. Only through that practice of releasing egotistical thoughts and opinions while clearing the mind is such a goal even imaginable.', 'Reading the off-Bway Week offerings look great - but reminds me of the many people saying they have to save up for seats to Bette Midler in Hello Dolly. So crossing spring theater with the "In the News" story about the Mayor\'s surefire second term: Tune of It Only Takes a Moment (from Hello Dollar, I mean Hello Dolly) It only takes momentum To get stats that look real firm The polls show there\'s momentum For the Mayor to snare that second term Those funds and how he spent \'em May make press and pundits squirm But it only takes momentum To get Bill a second term And that is what the story says As long as he can fight the Prez Now Bill only needs momentum And he\'ll have his second term.']
summary: Several commenters praise Luis, calling him a hero, commending him, and even saying he is more qualified to be President than the current one. A couple of commenters focus on the topic of immigration, with one describing the differences between the term "refugee" and "asylee", saying Luis is the latter. One commenter also commends the USA for helping the "Louises of the world," but another has a different view and instead brings up a list of bad things the USA has done. One also remarks on how labels such as "immigrant" are harmful.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Refugee, Immigrant and Citizen   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Monday: A notable New Yorker, Off-Broadway Week and reflections before Lent.
short_question: ['New York Today: Refugee, Immigrant and Citizen  ']

query: Cleveland, which lost to the Cubs in seven games in the World Series, signed the slugger Edwin Encarnacion and will get some injured veterans back this season.
comments: ['Cleveland has the strongest lineup (Santana, Kipness, Lindor, Ramirez and now Encarnacion) in the AL. Add the best reliever (courtesy of the NYY who got several ??s in return for a sure thing) and best manager. If they keep their starters healthy, not sure who can beat them.', "Cubs and Indians again in 2017? This time with game 7 in Wrigglyville? (Yankee and Dodger fans cringe. Cards' fans weep. Phillies' fans just shrug.)", 'Why are the Indians always looked down on? In my world, they are the best. Forget football, which I cannot tolerate. Ugly uniforms, smashing each other, some with injuries that kill or at least seriously maim. Some have never recovered. Our country is supposed to be civilized, but football makes it otherwise.', "All winter, we read that the Indians acquisition of Encarnacion was a sign that they were making another run in 2017.  With all due respect, it's all smoke and mirrors.  The Red Sox were better than the Indians as were the Jays.  My Cleveland friends were shocked when they got to the Series.  We're talking three-man rotation, and overworked stars, Kluber and Miller.  True, Francona had no choice.  But it happened all the same.  And Brantley was overworked during the regular season.  Don't expect much from the rotation.  Tjey are likely to be working with 3 mid-range starters a couple of fill-ins and one overworked middle reliever.  If this team breaks .500, I'd give Francona the Manager of the Year.", 'Last year\'s World Series was an amazing and magical one. I can slightly imagine what it must have felt like to be a Cubs fan because, after all, just a few months earlier we Clevelanders experienced the thrills of a 7 game NBA finals, which finished with The Block, The Shot, and The Stop, and we had one heck of a long-time-coming celebration, too. But to Cubs fans, I would say, "You\'re welcome." The Tribe gave as good as we got, and the result was a Series for the ages, a real white knuckler, and an honor to have competed in. I still get chills just thinking about that final game with its extra innings. Very few in Cleveland were heartbroken the next day; exhausted, yes, but man was that a Series! Baseball! In many ways, no other sport can touch it.', "Royals back big in '17, so this won't be relevant.", "Overlooked, was the midnight application of the rain tarp. The 15 minute delay seemed crucial, stretching Shaw. The umpires' bad judgement handed the tie game, and the series, to the Cubs. I'm Yankee fan, but as a baseball student, that late night call recalled Denkinger's infamous flub.", "So difficult to get to the World Series.....so many things need to break your way.  When Rajai Davis....RAJAI DAVIS.....hit that home run in the 8th and Madden trotted Chapman back out in the ninth to face the top of our order....I actually said, for the first time in those 7 games...that we were gonna win.  Heartbreak.  If we are fortunate enough, again, to overcome key injuries, get hot when we need to, and have our players seize opportunities at the key times they arise....last year's sadness will be forever forgotten and our parade will never stop in Cleveland.  Go Tribe"]
summary: Several of the commenters are optimistic about the Cleveland Indian's chances of winning the World Series in 2017. They believe that the Encarnacion acquisition and a great manager can help lead them to make it back to the World Series. However, several other commenters are more skeptical, believing that Cleveland got lucky to make it to the World Series in the previous year and will not have a great run in 2017.
short_title: Headline: Indians Return, No Longer Underdogs   Keywords: Baseball; Cleveland Indians   Snippet: Cleveland, which lost to the Cubs in seven games in the World Series, signed the slugger Edwin Encarnacion and will get some injured veterans back this season.
short_question: ['Indians Return, No Longer Underdogs  ']

query: A stylish new restaurant melds Asian cuisines in a cavernous former Chinatown theater where a gang massacre once occurred.
comments: ['I was intrigued to note the contrasts between the New Yorker review of Chinese Tuxedo (Feb 13 & 20) and this review. Mr Wells on Mapo lo mein: "short on heat and long on sweetness . . . one of the few dishes that struck me as too sweet but the menu . . . relies on sugar more than it should" The New Yorker on the same dish: "a tad too salty with the complex heat of a traditional mapo" Mr Wells on steak tartare: "seasoned with fried shallots and a glug of fish sauce; it may be more Vietnamese than Chinese but it\'s great." The New Yorker: "the steak tartare stands out, not only for its unabashedly Western appellation but also because its medallions of ginger-and-lime-dressed chopped raw beef, dusted with peppercorns and nestled on homemade rice cracker, are unequivocally delicious."', 'So we have Pete Wells (an American I assume) in great detail explaining if the food made by chef, Paul Donnelly (a Scot) is really Chinese.  The conclusion is an "unequivocal" “sort of.”  Makes sense.', 'Visited in early January and thought it was incredible. Congrats!', "Pete - just a tip: You could have picked a more appetizing photo than the 'fried whole dead bird on a plate' one you used. Yummy is not the first word that come mind.", "Wow... so many culturally-ignorant comments about how the squab is presented in the lede photo. For a second I thought I was reading the Middle America Times, and not the New York Times. As a Chinese person growing up eating food that look like this, I'm quite proud of our tradition of presenting meat in the form of how it was found. So yeah, if that's unappealing to you, go right ahead and eat your over-processed boneless, skinless chicken breasts and pretend that no animals were slaughtered in the process.", "The photographs have a very unappealing tint to them...they remind me of pictures in my old cookbooks (e.g., Mary & Vincent Price's A Treasury of Great Recipes) or 1960s women's magazines. Not at all enticing!", 'Just a matter of time until Chinatown will be in name only.', 'As a vegetarian I found the photo so repulsive I cound not even  read the essay', 'An incredibly disappointing (don\'t know why I had any hopes at all) from Pete Wells. "Chinese strawberries and cream......nuggets of mochi" Mochi is Japanese, not Chinese.  Not really Pete\'s fault since it\'s the restaurant that names the dish, but still a glaring indictment of the establishment.', 'I don\'t understand how it\'s a critics pick with 2 stars (out of 4). I would think it would need at least 3 stars to be claimed a "pick", whereas 2 stars is just average or so-so.', "I love reading Pete Wells' columns. Always something to learn, and his witty prose is the best in the biz.  I can't eat most of the stuff as I'm happily vegetarian for over a decade now. But I've always been a foodie starting from a young age when my parents took me to fancy restaurants and I tried and liked pretty much everything. Unlike my sister, who only ate kiddie food like pasta and chicken fingers.  And there were days when I enjoyed my meat as much as the next person. That said, I don't want to see the claws of a dead bird on my plate, and certainly that extends exponentially for the creature's beak and head. Call me a culturally sheltered dilettante whatever, to me it's gross and unappetizing. Don't even get me started on the practice of eating creatures (seafood is what I've seen) while they're still alive. How does one say yuk in Mandarin?", "I'll be in the city next month and this review has intrigued me enough that I'll give Chinese Tuxedo a whirl. I mean, the two-star rating is the same as Per Se's rating of last year. The history of the neighborhood is fascinating, the dishes look interesting, and the deficits noted are not enough to dissuade me from a real adventure. I'll give it a try!", 'Great to hear success stories like this...it just prove that Australia has a lot to offer to the culinary world. They have a lot more of these in Australia specially Sydney .', "Unpredictable service. Staff needs wine training. Smashed cucumber salad barely dented. Mapo lo mein short on heat and swagger and too sweet. Twenty minutes spent waiting to order. One dessert to recommend. I wasn't reading the love. I was reading reasons to never go.  If food if supposed to appeal to the eyes, the squab in the photo looks remarkably unappealing.  There are infinitely better so-called Chinese-fusion restaurants in Manhattan. This one comes across as something from ten years ago that limped away from the dining scene with scrawny wings beneath its tail.", 'This does not read like a 2-star review. It reads more like a 1-star review with caveats. The bottom line for me is that not much of the food seems appealing, almost as if the chef keeps adding touches to recipes as he prepares each dish, with diners being part of an oddball experiment.  However, I did like the look of the space.', '"Second, there is dumb fusion and there is smart fusion, and Mr. Donnelly practices the smart kind." This distinction is basically all that I want from reviews of fusion places.', "In nearly all cases, I'll gladly accept Pete's suggestions for my NY Culinary Bucket List.  If the Stars and $$ align to my standards (And the Food Porn Pix look good). it goes on my  list.  In this case, it is a very simple NO!  After reading the review twice, I get the feeling that the chef does not really know what he wants to achieve -or does not know how to get there.  There are so many, far better places available...", 'Ok, this is taking "nose to tail" just a bit too far.  Maybe they are used to being served in this style in other cultures, but if I even saw this being served to another diner while I was eating, I would probably have to pay my bill and leave ASAP.', "So. The minimalist dining area is a gourmand's dream.  The whole squab looks like temptingly like something belched up from the Berea Tar Pits. That in no way obscures the nightmare that the last forlorn living creature of the last endangered species on earth, no matter how unpalatable to its natural predators, will be slurped down with noodles by someone in China."]
summary: Many of the comments are about how unappealing the squab in the picture looks and how it is a major turnoff from the restaurant. One commenter mentions how all these comments are culturally insensitive. The commenters mention how the restaurant has only a two-star rating and that the food doesn't seem to taste very good. Overall, the commenters seem disappointed and unwilling to go to this restaurant.
short_title: Headline: Bringing Harmony to Fusion   Keywords: Restaurants; Chinese Food (Cuisine); Chinese Tuxedo (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant); Chinatown (Manhattan, NY)   Snippet: A stylish new restaurant melds Asian cuisines in a cavernous former Chinatown theater where a gang massacre once occurred.
short_question: ['Bringing Harmony to Fusion  ']

query: A group of ethicists have expressed concern that China will use the meeting to convince the world that it no longer harvests organs from prisoners.
comments: ['"In their letter, the ethicists also argued that there was no evidence that China had ended the practice of taking organs from executed prisoners, which they said included prisoners of conscience." There is a logic problem in this argument. Tell me how you would provide "no evidence" to convince me you commit something I am convinced you are a liar" - a test for the NYT "journalist"', 'The Vatican can do more than encourage good behavior, especially if the situation has reached the level of "Nuremberg Trials".  Mr Sisci state that the Vatican is well aware of the situation with organ transplant in China.  That information could be shared publicly.  That would not be considered condemnation of the perpetrators. That exposure might very well help improve the world.', 'what if China told the truth?  The NYT cannot even conceive of the possibility? Perhaps the NYT has reported so many lies from the USA government as if they were the truth that it no longer can tell the difference.  I am not saying China does indeed tell the truth. But the onus to prove her wrong lies with those that accuse her.', 'In the Catholic world you go to confession repent and are forgiven, hopefully not to repeat your sins. China is entitled to this as well if they have abandoned former practices of harvesting without consent human organs. The movement toward a legal existence should not be belittled but encouraged even by those how have some form of general opposition to the Chinese government. Critics need more than “we believe” to loge their charges, and how can that be obtained? Organs give life and should not become political items unless proof exists of abuse; unfortunately they also yield profit so consent will always be a thin veil.', 'The ethics committee, as contended by Bishop Marcelo Sanchez Sirindi, Chancellor of the Pontifical Academy of Sciencr, is "promoting their political agenda"!  If the Chinese officials said they no longer use prisoners\' organs since Jan. 1, 2015, is it that hard to believe them?  There are anti- China NGOs funded by some western countries spreading negative views on China, with fake photos and derogatory news about China, like organ harvesting. Fat Lum Gung is one  of these anti- China organisations. These people with anti-China propaganda of photos, are all over the world. I have met them on streets of Denmark, Hong Kong and San Francisco. Undoubtedly these photos and derogatory news reach the hands of the ethics committee. You cannot accuse the Chinese officials as lying to the ethics committee. After all, they are Prominent Surgeons in China. It is really a shame that these doctors attack their own community of health officials, without concrete proof that China is violating the ethics law. Give the Chinese the benefit of doubt or come up with concrete proof, and not a here say from some sleazy reports. Bishop Sorondo is right to say that these members of the ethics committee are literally promoting their political agenda!', 'In the Catholic world you go to confession repent and are forgiven, hopefully not to repeat your sins. China is entitled to this as well if they have abandoned former practices of harvesting without consent human organs. The movement toward a legal existence should not be belittled but encouraged even by those how have some form of general opposition to the Chinese government. Critics need more than “we believe” to loge their charges, and how can that be obtained? Organs give life and should not become political items unless proof exists of abuse; unfortunately they also yield profit so consent will always be a thin veil.', "Why don't the other scientists take China's word for it? Instead, like the Bishop said, these countries are politicising the whole thing. Pope Francis is trying to normalise relationship with China but instead, these scientist are alienating the Chinese. These scientists must have gotten the erroneous fact from Far LungK Kung, an anti-Communist NGO.", "'In their letter, the ethicists also argued that there was no evidence that China had ended the practice of taking organs from executed prisoners, which they said included prisoners of conscience. “On the contrary, there is evidence that it continues,” they wrote. “Officials from China should not be given the prestigious platform of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences to spread misinformation about reform in China.”' It would be seemly if the signatories of this letter, rather than simply claiming that there is 'evidence that it [i e, the taking of organs from executed prisoners in China] continues', despite the statements of the relevant Chinese authorities that such organs have not been used since 1 January 2015, were to present said evidence. Even when those accused of malfeasance happen to be Chinese, it remains the task of the accusers to present evidence for their accusations, rather requiring the accused to demonstrate their innocence. Or is the notion that an accused is innocent until proven guilty no longer a fundamental principle of jurisprudence ?... Henri", 'Henri - at this point in time, enough evidence has been compiled by researchers that it is truly on the Chinese government to have to prove that coerced, forced organ harvesting from un-consenting prisoners of conscience is not happening. The accusers you mentioned have published their very rational, thorough and damning evidence in 3 books, 7 documentaries and a dozen official reports.', 'Roman B The issue is not what was but what is Chinese policy; the claim of change fell toward the end of 2016, as I recall. If Policy has been reformed that should be the issue – correct?', '@Roman B The issue is not what was but what is Chinese policy; the claim of change fell toward the end of 2016, as I recall. If Policy has been reformed that should be the issue – correct?']
summary: Most commenters defend China, with one commenter saying that people can't seem to believe that they stopped collecting prisoner organs and putting the burden of proof on the accusers. One commenter goes on a tirade about "anti-Chinese propaganda." Several point out that the claim there is no evidence of China stopping the practice is flawed and that the ethicists who claim to have evidence of China's continued practice of this fail to show the evidence. In a rebuttal, someone claims that the evidence has already been previously presented in various publications and documentaries. Most everyone seems to feel that we should trust that China is doing the right thing in regards to organ harvesting.
short_title: Headline: Debate Flares Over China’s Inclusion at Vatican Organ Trafficking Meeting   Keywords: Organ Donation; Transplants; Human Rights and Human Rights Violations; Roman Catholic Church; Huang Jiefu; China   Snippet: A group of ethicists have expressed concern that China will use the meeting to convince the world that it no longer harvests organs from prisoners.
subreddit: ['Organ Donation', 'Transplants', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Roman Catholic Church', 'Huang Jiefu', 'China']
short_question: ['Debate Flares Over China’s Inclusion at Vatican Organ Trafficking Meeting  ']

query: Whether she was photographing graffiti and street games on New York’s Lower East Side, Martha Cooper’s images reflect her quest to show people and their culture in context.
comments: ['Beautiful, colorfully eye-popping photos of what looks like a more innocent time. Before and after computers and cell phones will be the line in the cultural sand of history. Photos capture this exceptionally well. Can you imagine hauling around those giantic boom boxes?', "Great photos. I especially like the one taken in the artist's room.", 'We need a street named after Martha Cooper...but then, she would hate that! But: Respect for the Historians...', 'look how much thinner people were.', 'Kids...getting lots of "exercise"--atop, alongside subway cars, or in middle of street. Now, we die of type 2 diabetes, instead of the third rail...?']
summary: Comments reflect on how life used to be with children more active and people being thinner due to the lack of technology and more outside time. Others talk about how they like the photography of Martha Cooper. Another commenter speaks of naming a street after Martha and how she would hate that.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Graffiti; Photography; Bronx (NYC)   Snippet: Whether she was photographing graffiti and street games on New York’s Lower East Side, Martha Cooper’s images reflect her quest to show people and their culture in context.

query: Wednesday: Keeping up with the cold, a verdict in the Etan Patz case, and the 5-cent plastic bag fee.
comments: ['Maple Leafs mulch Islanders.', "WARM UP TO COLD A man's best friend is a cold; Embrace it rather than shirk. Whether young or old, It's an excuse to stay home from work.", "Lot's of luck getting people on the subways to follow Dr. Sowa's rules of sneezing etiquette. I remember that when I first moved to NYC as an adult I frequently got colds whenever I rode the subway in rush hour during the winter.  When I asked my father who for years had to ride the subway to work how he had avoided this he replied that he didn't and that usually had one continuous cold for the whole winter.  When we moved to the suburbs and he was able to drive to work he said it was like going to Lourdes in terms of its effect on his health.", "What causes colds?? .... This is easy. People who sneeze and cough into mid-air without covering their noses or mouths. Do gloves help? They sure do. Especially when sneezing and coughing types then put their germ-infested hands on the subway pole, or the staircase bannister. Now. Wasn't that easy??? Hope you feel better. NEXT.", '5¢ plastic bag fee? Why not have people recycle them and use the as garbage bags and save 5¢ from not buying a garbage bag.', 'Actually it verges on the lobbyists for the plastic bag industry.', "Plastic bags aren't recyclable~people assuage their guilt by trying to recycle these flimsy bags. They end up in a dump with the rest of the trash.  I've been carrying a canvas bag/s for years when I shop. It becomes a habit.  Just say NO to plastic. Look at the FEED website for a choice of nice canvas~plus, your donation for a bag can make a difference. https://www.feedprojects.com", 'Then why not require the bag be recyclable or better yet biodegradable. Instead of a tax, seems like politicians are more interested in selling more garbage bags then saving environment.', 'Ah, yes, yet another "task force" being paid for months by the taxpayers  to "methodically determine" how to address an issue that already has a simple answer:  a 5-cent bag fee.  And the necessity of this who-knows-how-long study will employ how many bureaucrats?  If the governor is so concerned about the burden on low-income New Yorkers, how about working on some low-income housing or free day care?  His "concern" is misplaced.  I think most people can afford a nickel for a bag.', 'We managed to cause climate change to a place that has existed for 4.5 billion years and it\'s not getting any better, it still baffles me with all the findings we have some that will have you believe that "The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive,". We have droughts, we have typhoons, melting ice caps, we have hurricanes, erratic season changes, and rising temperatures; yet this is still not enough for some to see that climate change is a real global issue.', 'Devils collapse Avalanche', 'I can\'t believe that the names discussed for the new Staten Island Ferry are limited to police and military figures. It\'s high time for them to honor some women. If I recall correctly, the only woman mentioned on a boat was "Gold Star Mother."* *Just checked. There\'s the "Alice Austen." Well, there should be more, or they should be named after minorities who are not Italian. Three of the nine current boats are named after Italians whom nobody not from S.I. has heard of.', 'A podcast called "only human" that was on WNYC once said that flu vaccine protect you/ affective 20% only. She said getting the vaccine is to protect the people around you . When you are sick, you wouldn\'t affect them.', 'Noooooo.  This is dangerous thinking, and it doesn\'t correctly represent what was reported on WNYC.  The effectiveness of the vaccine varies from year to year, for many reasons.  It depends on how many strains of the flu show up by the time that the current year\'s vaccine is developed.  The vaccine won\'t protect you, or at least not fully, against a later-appearing strain.  But in most years the effectiveness is very high.  It is true that people who say "I never get the flu" should have the vaccine anyway, especially if they are in a risk group including by age or are regularly around others who are in risk groups, e.g., over 60, young children, people with chronic immune-system conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.  It it\'s not obvious, though it should be, the bottom line is that everyone should take the vaccine unless there\'s a clear medical reason not to get it.', 'Good point about affecting others… Although I think it\'s not when you\'re sick, AND immunized– The important thing is not getting sick AT ALL, that will protect your "others", or loved ones. This means not getting all touchy-feely about immunization, it means getting immunized, to protect others!
