"Sick" people shed all kinds of viruses, and stuff… That\'s why older people should avoid going to hospitals, because the outcome might not be good', "Maybe those anti-cold tips can be made easier to remember with a song with a good cardio beat.  Tune of theme from Solid Gold The air may be freezing Is that why I'm sneezing? An old bill of goods that's been sold. The sky looks so pretty Still germs have no pity The germs can turn into a cold.  Got a cold? You can't blame the changing weather Horrid cold? Well, your health can be controlled: Give your hands a good washing And take some care what you're noshing. Resistance keeps away germs, That keeps away colds.  Get the right vaccination. Drink liquor in moderation. Resistance keeps away germs, That keeps away colds. Horrid colds!", 'Beautiful photo.']
summary: Several commenters discuss sneezing etiquette and anti-cold tips, including how it'll be difficult to get people in New York's subways to follow that advice. A couple of commenters follow up by discussing the flu vaccine and how it protects people. Others discuss the 5-cent bag fee and how it's not a good environmental decision because the bags are not recyclable, to begin with, and thus end up in landfills. One commenter discusses climate change in general.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Winter Health Watch   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Wednesday: Keeping up with the cold, a verdict in the Etan Patz case, and the 5-cent plastic bag fee.
short_question: ['New York Today: Winter Health Watch  ']

query: The latest Sunday Review intentionally didn’t mention President Trump’s name, and many readers breathed a sigh of relief.
comments: ["I'm ready for anotherTrump-free Sunday review section. The last one was so interesting and such a relief. The man sucks all the air out of the room, as they say, shutting down discussion of important issues - or even just nice, interesting, lovely events - around the world. You'd also be promoting the mental health of your readers by giving us a respite from the misery. I suggest making it a monthly feature.", 'Thank for pulling this off-  how \'bout you do it EVERY Sunday?  Make the Sabbath holy, a day of rest, so we don\'t have to hear the name of "unspeakable."  (lower caps.) caio!', '"The editors debated whether to tell readers more directly but decided it would feel too gimmicky." Actually, what feels gimmicky is this entire column from the public editor. This column reads more like one of the "Inside the Times" puff pieces that the NYT now feels obliged to publish on page 2 of its news pages. The mere fact that the NYT public editor felt compelled to write about such a trivial matter as to the Times not publishing yet another opinion writer\'s (or "news analysis") hit piece against Trump just shows that the Times is overly obsessed with Trump.  Sadly, the NYT Sunday Review section has become little more than filler copy most Sundays. What started as an admirable attempt to breathe new life into the old "Week in Review" section has become, like much of the Sunday New York Times (especially the dreadfully boring Sunday Business section), a rehash of worn-out arguments, screeds and points that don\'t have a logical place elsewhere in the paper.', 'Has Ms. Spayd already run out of column ideas?', 'Why don\'t you suggest some "ideas"?', "I agree, a day or two without Trump and Trashing of Trump is a nice break. I would like to draw the attention of the Public Editor to comments made about the citizens of Iowa who are represented by Congressman Steven King. Several of the comments call those Iowans - by very derogatory names and one even wondered if they are Nazi's. Though I commented that such comments are overboard, they were not removed. Can we please have a column as to why Commentators are allowed to insult, in a most derogatory manner, other Commentators and how this is supposed to help the Common Good,  which I assume the New York Times seeks to achieve.", '"... comments made about the citizens of Iowa ..." Please give an EXACT CITATION for the article with the comments you are complaining about. We are not mind-readers.', 'CWK, The New York Times Editorial Board on March 14th, 2017 published an Editorial: "Into the Void, with Steve King." Mr. King is a Congressmen from Iowa. NA from NYC made a comment - 2 days ago. Stu Freeman/Brooklyn In his response said in part: "...racist, fools and xenophobes" concerning Iowans in Congressman King\'s district. Calling someone a racist is a remark that could get the person - so called fired. Calling them a fool is a personal insult. Calling them xenophobes is a universal statement that Mr. Freeman has not the ability to know. It is followed up by:  Kay from New York City who says: "Is Iowa filled with Nazis ?" Are we to suppose there is not one Jewish person in Iowa ? Are we to suppose that no one in Iowa did not lose a relative in the Shoah or World War II ? Some comments go too far and I am surprised that the editor of the Comment section does not contact the Commentator and ask them to self-edit their remarks. People were calling Trump supporters all sorts of names leading up to the Election and some of them were very derogatory. Thank You, John Brown Idaho', 'Thanks, John. Specific examples are excellent! Note that you can flag comments. Click the "Flag" link at the bottom of a comment or reply. If comments are still open, it is also a good idea to post a reply explaining why you are flagging a comment or reply. \'stu freeman\' is a Verified Commenter, so his comments are not subject to moderation. This reply of his received 604 recommends, so you can see how insensitive Times readers can be to their own bigotry: stu freeman: \'Apparently Mr. King\'s congressional district is one of those "enclaves" he refers to: a community of racists, fools and xenophobes.\' https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/opinion/into-the-void-with-steve-king... \'kay\' received 5 recommends for asking "Is Iowa filled with nazis?": https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/opinion/into-the-void-with-steve-king... NB: I see that you posted a reply to both. BTW, although it takes more work, I suggest supporting statements of fact by citing a source.', 'The fact that the readers bwere enchanted by the absence of Trump-based arrivals suggest that the Times has gone out of its way to find "breaking news" in everything he does at,Moe frequently what he is alleged to have done by some unnamed source. When.the Times " PUSHED" this sort of coverage on its millions of readers, it does a great disservice to itself, The People, and our system of governance. I am surprised. Mz Spayed didn\'t pick up on this sort of editorial indescretion. and bias... This reader s urely has.', 'PE: "The Review wasn’t the only section in the Sunday paper that was Trump-free, but the others — Metro, Real Estate, Sports, Travel and Obituaries — are ones you’d expect to be assembled without mention of the White House." The PE should have made it clear that the Sunday EDITION was not Trump-free. In particular, two front-page articles mention Trump: http://www.nytimes.com/images/2017/03/12/nytfrontpage/scannat.pdf', 'There is a downside not mentioned by the Public Editor.  The hospitals, I understand, were swamped with New York Times readers experiencing serious withdrawal symptoms when faced with a New York Times Sunday Review without the usual tsunami of Donald Trump trashing. Once, maybe.  Better they don’t try it again.', "Yeah, it's not like the President's on board with dismantling the federal government and letting every richard with a desire run roughshod over the country. So let's ignore him, tee hee.", "Evidently, that Sunday Review was read by subscribers as so unremarkable that David Leonhardt found it necessary to devote a whole column to it, and now Liz Spayd weighs in with the kind of institutional congratulations unbecoming of an objective internal critic of matters of journalistic kintegrity. That IS your job, Ms. Spayd, or have you been engaged formally by the Times' PR department? It is hardly as if issues of journalistic integrity disappeared on Sunday. Just a reminder, the flood tide of anonymous sourcing is still on the rise, in case you didn't notice.", 'Now can the Times commit to a single day without anonymous sourcing? Yeah, I thought that too big an ask...', 'The public editor, and The Times, have together reached new highs of the bizarre.  In addition to her usual pandering to Times management ("The New York Times Sunday Review was a fine specimen of opinion journalism this past weekend."), Liz Spayd and assistant editor Alison Mitchell laid out a new standard of non-journalism: "We’re constantly thinking about how we can give people other things...What do we have that’s just delightful?\'”  Spayd says that readers really want a respite from news and opinion about Donald Trump.  She quotes one reader who writes: "I do think you guys (except for today) really overdo it on Trump trashing. Pretty vicious most of the time." So on the day that Spayd praises the no-Trump edition, the CBO declares that Trumpcare will throw 24 million Americans off healthcare over the next ten years, and that 14 million will lose their health insurance next year alone under Trumpcare. So does Liz Spayd believe that The Times should leave out news and opinion pieces about Trump\'s lies to the American people about heath care?  His cruel "replacement" for the ACA?   Apparently so, because Trumpcare is anything but "delightful."', 'Sean: "So on the day that Spayd praises the no-Trump edition, the CBO declares ..." You are confusing the part and the whole. The Sunday Review is PART of the Sunday EDITION. Further, the CBO report was released on Monday, March 13, 2017, so you appear to be asking the Times to do the impossible -- predict the future. Source: Congressional Budget Office American Health Care Act Cost Estimate March 13, 2017 https://www.cbo.gov/publication/52486', 'All the news delightful to print?', 'Nu? How many other "wry winks" does the Times insert, only with the "winkers" being the writers and editors? Therein lays the leftist machinations of the past two years.', 'More and more, as I read  current emanations form the White House, I find solace in the last part of Psalm 123. " Have mercy on us, O God, have mercy on us...Our soul is exceedingly filled with the scorning of those that are at ease, and with the contempt of the proud."  Thanks, NYT, for cutting down on reproducing the blather which assaults us daily.', 'Today the Times does trumpet, A full section with no Trump wit. A break from the insanity, Of the latest Trump inanity, Best enjoyed with tea and crumpet.', 'Clearly, a case of fake no-news.']
summary: Some commenters joke about people going into withdrawal from the lack of Trump trashing and that this was just a puff piece from the NY Times. One commenter claims that a Trump-free day is a day of fake no-news. Other commenters mention the last couple of years' leftist machinations and state disbelief in the Times' ability to go a day without anonymous sourcing. One commenter notes an article published on 03-14-2017 where Steve King called Trump supporters in Iowa racist, fools, and xenophobes.
short_title: Headline: Opinions Worth Savoring, With No Trump in Sight   Keywords:    Snippet: The latest Sunday Review intentionally didn’t mention President Trump’s name, and many readers breathed a sigh of relief.
short_question: ['Opinions Worth Savoring, With No Trump in Sight  ']

query: Friday: Minimum wage at $11, marijuana distributors react to White House threat of crackdown, and Sierra vs. Sierras.
comments: ["Higher minimum wage means a few things. 1) HIgher prices. 2) less hours available for workers leading to less benefits. 3) when a manager has a choice between a nice clean cut person and a slob with his pants down around his knees, who do you think he/she will pick?  Single?  Yep, you get the job. SIngle mother? Older person with medical issues? Forget it. Who wants the added hassles when you have lots of nice clean cut young people who will work 4-6 hours a day and dont give a damn about benefits   AND to add insult to injury, the workers wont be able to afford the things they want to buy because the prices will go up, and their hours go down.. Hysterical really.. Then again, its really not a surprise.  If these people were truly educated, they would understand economics and wouldn't be asking for 15.00 an hour.. Even my 18 year old kid understands it.. and his hours were just cut.", 'Sierras is just as (in)correct as Catskillss!', '"are-you-one-of-us" tests are properly called, "Shibboleth".', "The downside is higher minimum wage will give an advantage to businesses which engage in illegal employment.  Especially true in rural areas, whose cost of living is less than 1/2 of what it is in San Francisco.  And that results in a furthering of the very visible apartheid-like society, more votes for Trump, and the strange phenomena of a special police force dedicated to arresting and deporting the workers who came because Americans offered them illegal jobs - while turning a blind eye to illegal employers.   An alternative strategy might be to ask that Democracy gets its payment up front:  enforce legal employment.  Of course immigrants are needed to keep the economy going, so channel that need into visas with a path to citizenship (that's the payment to Democracy).", 'There\'s another way out of the Sierra/Sierras conundrum: Sierras, plural for "the various mountain ranges in CA that are lumped together and referred to in aggregate, the largest of which by far is the Sierra Nevada range, proper." Sherwin Range and White Mountain Range snowmelt also flows into the toilets of LA - for example. Both are part of the Eastern Sierras, but arguably not the Eastern Sierra (...Nevada Range). Though most East Siders wouldn\'t be caught saying "Sierras."', '". . . in Spanish sierra is plural, so “sierras” is redundant and therefore wrong." No, wrong again. In Spanish, the plural of sierra IS sierras, but that\'s not really the point here.  "Sierra" means "saw" in Spanish, and Sierra Nevada is literally "snowy saw," a term used historically for any snow-capped range, including the Sierra Nevada in southern Spain. I refer the author to the magisterial reference work "California Place Names" by Erwin Gudde, pp 361-362. (University of California Press) for a full exposition of the etymology and origin.', 'Our Democratic state legislature is designing a work-around for the GOP Tax Law assault on Californians. Kevin DeLeon has proposed a bill to allow itemizers the option of converting their state tax payments into a “donation” to a  “State Charity” account, so we can still deduct the fees from our federal income tax. I love my state.', 'If minimum wage could jump like rent did for many Californians this year, our workers would be better off.  Remember if a company employees someone and that person still needs government assistance to get by.  It is the company that is getting subsidized.', 'You have it backwards. Businesses that employ low skill workers subsidize the government assistance programs. If Walmart went out of business and all of its workers’ incomes dropped to zero, do you think we would have to pay out more or less in government assistance?', 'SO it\'s called "the Sierra"', 'As a Californian in exile, I can confidently state that the people saying "the Sierras" are speaking English, not Spanish.  The standard way to make a plural in English is to add an "s".  Why should this word be different?', 'Born and raised in California and lived here all my life, and "the Sierras" is just what everyone says that I\'ve ever known, like we say "LA" instead of Ciudad de Nuestra Senora Reina de los Angeles. Sierra Nevada (and how many non-Spanish speakers even understand what the "Nevada" part means in Spanish?) got Americanized in common usage long, long, ago. People can get over it.', 'I’m a native Californian.  Always called those mountains the Sierras.  Probably learned that from my grandmother whose ancestors climbed over the mountain range in a wagon train.', 'Well, if folks insist on us calling them "the Sierra" instead of "the Sierras," let\'s be sure to also insist on the following:      -using "cherries" as a singular noun, since that better reflects its origin      -using "peas" to refer to a singular pea (same thing here)      -calling all aprons "naprons," since that, too, is more etymologically accurate.      -and while we\'re at it, let\'s just obviate "goodbye" and revert back to "god be with ye". To do otherwise would be an ignorant linguistic sin! Words and phrases change over time. It\'s just how language works. Get over it.', 'I speak Spanish and sometimes we make a lot of mistakes even with the most simples grammar estructure. NYT I will forgive you, but I will not forget it. Also great report. Please continue doing this amazing job. I have faith in Journalism', 'How about those who say Los Angelenos or the La Brea Tar Pits?', '“Every new car sold in the state must be zero emissions by 2040” implies electricity residents use to charge electric cars, over half of which is generated by burning fossil fuel, will be replaced by nuclear or renewable electricity. Or electric cars won’t qualify. Hmm. Next week, California’s governor-appointed Public Utilities Commission will vote to close Diablo Canyon (nuclear) Power Plant - the source of 9% of California’s electricity and 22% of its clean electricity. It will be replaced by burning “natural gas” - fossil fuel methane - adding 9 million tonnes to California’s CO2 emissions total. Jerry Brown hasn’t been forthcoming about how he plans to achieve his zero-emission goal. But by all appearances, he’s aiming for a less-honorable one - that of outsourcing California’s electricity (30% currently comes from out-of-state). Why? It’s cheaper, and apparently he believes moving our emissions somewhere else will make them disappear. I’ve always been confident Governor Brown understood object permanence, but maybe my confidence was misplaced.', 'Increases in pay  should be linked to increases in skills, education, length of employment and overall job performance. I have a fundamental problem with government’s increasing role in regulating what private business do. Private business employment should be influenced by workforce willingness and availability based upon the pay and benefits that employer offers. Simply ratcheting unskilled minimum wage up to $15/hour without job incentives will only add to more entitlement and less personal responsibility for one’s own growth. An unskilled worker will have no incentive to do what many have done (myself included): learn a skill or get an education in order to increase earning potential. Will the increased minimum wage result in people being pushed off Medicaid or will we simply raise the limit for that too. It never ends.....', "I have a significant problem with having my tax dollars subsidize businesses that don't pay a living wage.  Saying that it's all between the employer and the employee skill set ignores that people accept lower than subsistence wages.  They do this because either they will forgo basic needs or because they can get government aid.   If the company wants a human to do a job then they must be willing to pay a living wage.  $15 is fairly arbitrary especially because the cost of living varies but it's in line with estimates of average cost of living.", 'Just imagine how much taxpayer money we’d save if all the companies that employ low-skill workers go out of business and a whole bunch of people’s incomes drop to zero!', 'Mr. Jacobs added that several studies have showed better health in low-income children after the minimum wage increased.  *showed ?!  No need to post, just fix :-)']
summary: Several commenters attempt to solve the Sierra/Sierras dispute by discussing the actual definition of Sierra based on its Spanish roots, and the region of speakers, insisting that Sierras is not correct usage. Other commenters tackle the minimum wage issue by saying that increasing the minimum wage enables companies that employ illegals, resulting in higher prices and fewer work hours. Another says that an increase in wages should be matched by an increase in other essential things such as education and skills.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords:    Snippet: Friday: Minimum wage at $11, marijuana distributors react to White House threat of crackdown, and Sierra vs. Sierras.

query: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon pull it out from under us.
comments: ['gimmes were NUTMEG KITSCH NICHE. quite hard. cottoned on to CHICKEN HEN ROOSTER in the quote. also got ECCENTRIC early. still took over a half hour!  quote was pretty funny. do remember the FUNKY CHICKEN dance from the 60s!', 'This was ridiculously hard and not the least bit enjoyable. Are they kidding with Rowlock, Oviposit, Eric Knight, ICHTHYIC, and Klezemer!!', 'KLEZMER (correct spelling) was one of my gimmes, but I guess being jewish helped. I had heard of ICHTHYARIUM as a fancy word for "aquarium", but never ICHTHYIC before now.', 'My new year\'s wish would be an acrostic a week.   thank you for so much fun and feeling possessed in a good way.....an  "im peck able"  job....I so appreciate your talents.', "Had KODACHROME and WEST WING for a time before realizing the errors. And now I can't get Paul Simon's song out of my head. Spelling Bee! This might have been the longest list ever? Good fun to have so much to work with. Elbow Room is still delightful but so far still easy-ish...which I hate to say because I fear Thinh Van Duc Lai is rubbing his hands with a bomb cyclone soon to come.", 'Loved all the fowl language in the word list. EASTWING, har.', 'I am surprised that so many found this Acrostic easy. I had too few gimmes to give me a toehold in the text, so I looked up the author of Lassie Go Home. That was all the assistance I needed, but it was tough going all the way.  ICHTYIC took me back to my childhood. In pre-antibiotic days, the standard treatment for boils and suppurative  sores was a black paste called Ichthyol, derived from fossilized fish.', 'I had many of the other gimmes shown below but also NICHE. The writer is unknown to me but seems, from this quotation, rather strange.', 'This was a rare crostic for me with no look ups. I started with NUTMEG and knew ERIC KNIGHT (Lassie was a favorite from childhood), FEATHERS and CHICANOS. I soon saw chicken in the quote and in the title. The latter led me to HICKORY, ICEMILK, KITSCH, and EASTWING, and it flew from there. Lots of Cs and Ks and it was fun getting palooza.', 'I really had a great time with this puzzle!  Thanks!', 'I had maybe two gimmes and was trying to figure out what CHICKEN______ could be.  I finished in about normal time, which surprised me in view of how little I had at the outset.', 'What is with the ever-changing ads at the bottom acrostic page? They slow my browser up and are irritating.  Hate to be a complainer but am I the only one experiencing this?', 'Those ads must be coming from your Internet provider. I am not getting them.', 'EC & HR rule the Acrostic roost.', "P.S. DEB, I hope you're not still sick. Your piece today seems kind of short. This is NOT a criticism, of course, but I remember that your illness was the reason for last week's supershort piece.", "Thanks, Jerrold, that's very sweet. I'm markedly better, but still not 100 percent. I hope to be functioning at full tilt sometime next week.", 'Forget the CHICKENPALOOZA, Deb, go with chicken soup.', 'Con-sequences was something new and different. Most of the answers actually were easy. [SPOILER ALERT] The only toughie was FRENCH DRESSING. Being not any kind of a cook, I got that one last, when NCHDR was the only remaining unused consonant sequence.', "You sure you didn't get RANCH DRESSING?", 'The only one I had to skip over the first time through was LDSCH.  Not having marked down which combinations I had already used, I went through them again and isolated it and came up with the phrase immediately.', "OK, thanks! Like I said, I'm sure not a cook.", 'This Acrostic was somewhere in the middle in terms of difficulty. It’s always nice when they manage to work answers in that relate to the quote. [SPOILER ALERT] My only absolute gimmes were NUTMEG, CHICANOS, FEATHERS and KLEZMER. I had to search for ERIC KNIGHT, EAST WING, HICKORY and NECROMANCY. After a certain point, the grid did a lot of filling itself in.']
summary: The commenters tend to disagree on the difficulty of the acrostic. The opinions vary from "ridiculously hard" to middling, and it took one commenter over 30 minutes to complete. One commenter complained about the ads that are displayed, but it appears that they are from their ISP.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Acrostic   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles; Acrostic Puzzles   Snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon pull it out from under us.
short_question: ['Variety: Acrostic  ']

query: How YouTube’s biggest star took a bizarre career turn, and what it tells us about the nascent politics of social platforms.
comments: ['Felix draws a lot of inspiration from South Park, and his sense of humor is of the same style. His on-camera personality is very sarcastic and engages in self deprecation very often. His off-camera personality is extremely kind, hard working, and humble. As for his relationship with Youtube, most of his criticisms were shared by the majority of content creators when those videos came out. They weren\'t particularly associated with him or anyone in particular. He\'s not at all a radical person; he\'s actually very relaxed in his videos and avoids being serious. As for the fiver incident, he felt very bad and acknowledged that not only had the joke been of poor taste, but his action resulted in other content creators being banned. He helped them get started on a new platform, directly contributing $5000, although they were allowed back on fiver anyway. He feels that the media is attacking him because nearly every article seems to be critical and takes his sarcastic humor at face value. In my view, rather than an attack, it\'s more that the media seems to not understand his content. As a result, however, there is now a huge rift between content creators on Youtube and the so called "mainstream media". Most content creators, while acknowledging Felix\'s offensive humor, seem to agree that the articles have been, while not an attack, certainly a mischaracterization.', 'I was born in a wrong century and a wrong decade. Yet, I have my own personal apps a "channel" on YouTube that I call NEILTUBE. Still, I cannot understand these folks surfing youtube all day long looking at these videos.  No wonder, this young man could not see anything offensive, since his real contact is a pc and not a fellow human. To me, that\'s one problem with this generation.   For them, having a Web presence,  constantly checking messages etc - is a critical no, tje only part of living. Forget social interactions.  I wish they would just disengage themselves from pc - and "smell" the roses. I fear we are building a generation that is doomed to fail.', 'As an early "YouTube scholar" (I know, this may sound like the kind of laughable over-statement engaged by Kjellberg, but indeed, I have seriously researched, taught and written about YouTube for years, as have many others), my students, fellow scholars and I have long understood, as you convincingly argue, that YouTube self-reflexivity and ironic bigotry are definitive of the site: its users, uses, economies, and norms (see my born-digital "video-book,"  Learning from YouTube, MIT Press, 2011.).  More recently, however, I have tried to make the link, that you also begin to draw so powerfully here, that these YouTube logics—of dark irony, corporate ownership, fakery and deception, and virality—have altered not just what is and is not permissible on YouTube but what might organize the internet and the political landscape it is now shaping (see my recent  JStore Daily, Nov. 30, 2016).  Thank you for illuminating commentary. Dr. Alexandra Juhasz, Chair, Film Dept., Brooklyn College, CUNY', 'Maybe I\'m just too far gone into my obsession with the Trump train wreck (certainly possible) but I can\'t help but hear echoes of that campaign: the class-traitor, the flirtation with racist memes, the mechanism of celebrity via social media, the attraction of a dedicated base of supporters who project their own emotions onto the "star" and - of course - the overweening ego.  Another data point, perhaps, that we live in times I no longer understand.  I\'ll wait to see if PewDiePie seeks to "weaponize" his celebrity by running for office or seeking some other platform for exploiting his position beyond the confines of YouTube.', 'This is basically a non-story. A lot of what you say here has been taken out of context and twisted for this story it seems to me. Kjellberg/PewDiePie\'s "rants" are nothing compared to the recent breakdowns of other YouTubers breakdowns like Tana Mongeau, Onision, or Marina Joyce. If you had bothered to watch the videos in their actual context that Kjellberg is, in fact, making fun of this type of so-called journalism. Come on guys. While you do have a good point in the fact that the neo Nazis are jumping on the bandwagon here, Kjellberg is NOT trying to subliminally brainwash people into normalizing alt-right and neo-nazi imagery, but he is just an easy target because he\'s the most subscribed person on the site. The claim about YouTube "not being what it used to be" was due to the massive amounts of glitches in recent months which were causing YouTubers to rapidly lose subscribers and viewers to constantly be unsubscribed to YouTube channels-- which was a LEGITIMATE ISSUE, not something Kjellberg "claimed". That was a legitimate fact, not an alternative one. There are legitimately awful people on the site, but you\'re going after the wrong target and, unfortunately, deepening the divide of trust between the media and the people. Please note I am not a Trump supporter nor do I believe in \'alternative facts\', but for YouTube, only two types of people truly understand it: those who actively create and those who consistently watch throughout the whole community.', "I don't worry about pewdiepie becoming more altright but rather his fans. He has the largest audience on the platform and throughout his whole career he's had people criticize his videos because they were low quality content even though they are just supposed to be fun regardless of quality. I just recently became a pewdiepie viewer and I realized that the criticism wasn't really fair on him. This wasn't really that important when it was just people on the internet but with the new controversy, I've honestly begun to be disappointed with newspaper outlets like the wall street journal. It was just disappointing to see them get on the anti-pewdiepie train that he's always had to deal with and now I really have begun to wonder whether or not its fair journalism (and i'm really, really, liberal millennial) I'm trying to keep my trust in the media but, I don't really know anymore from these last couple of days.", "Since when did making a joke place someone in the political spectrum. Assumptions are what started this mess and I can't see how the media still does not recognize this.", "This article was incredibly insightful, and well researched. Thank you for truly caring about the context and facts, culture and jokes, irony, and even the nonchalant and inherent bigotry, that make YouTube what it is. This gave amazing detail and information without expressing an opinion or choosing a side. Unlike many articles I have seen recently, the slight click bait didn't push me away. Please keep up the good Journalism. We need more...", 'Felix posted a video addressing this entire situation.  I recommend watching it as it is pretty clear that one he isn\'t anti-semitic.  And two the article in the Wall Street Journal is basically fabricated and takes every single "anti-semitic" thing he has done out of its proper context...', 'As well written and observant as I have found this article Mr. Herrman, I find that you have misunderstood what\'s actually going on here, but only by a little.   Felix has not politicized himself, the mainstream media has politicized him.  There would have been no reason to make fun and jab at the mainstream media, if they didn\'t point fingers and make political accusations at the drop of every hat. Also as far as the zeitgeist of ironic bigotry being "worryingly instructive."  It has become both ironic and okay to joke about because progressives have made the original concepts trivial.  As Anita Sarkeesian says: "Everything is racist, everything is sexist, and everything is homophobic and you have to point it out." Well sadly as most ideologically dogmatic liberals were clapping blindly at this sentiment.  They were also pointing it out, and as they pointed it out, they made topics of race, sex, and homosexuality, a lot more easy to joke about.  Why?  Because these same people started calling everyone racist, sexist, homophobes, and if everyone is, no one is.   Also if you read Vox on a regular basis you probably are worried about a lot of completely trivial things sane human beings shouldn\'t be scared of that\'s kind of their thing.   History isn\'t repeating itself, that\'s the conspiracy theory.  We aren\'t "becoming nazis" we are returning our generation\'s dialogue back to something more important than identity politics, which are facts.', 'Internet, so much hope for humanity, turned out to be a giant prostitution of the souls of individuals to ratings and individualized broadcast advertisement : idiocracy indeed.', 'I truly feel as though this media fight between various journals and the "alternative media" (mostly Youtube for this case) has gotten out of hand. The video was not hate speech, and anyone who watched the entire videos of those cited can see that it is not directed or meant to be directed in that manor. Additionally, PewDiePew apologized before everything blew up and again about an hour before this article was posted. As a distant consumer who very rarely uses Youtube I looked into these accusations (specifically WSJ\'s article) and found them to be completely unfounded. Could Felix of been more PC? Definitely, but that\'s not what his form of media is about, he seems to find comedy in extreme satire and unless you see a problem with satire I see no way in which someone can say he is supporting the Alt-right movement in anyway. Hold him to the same accountability of the Onion if you find it hard to see him as a new form of media in this situation.', "John Herrman seems to have missed the mark with this one, with his dated commentary on Kjellberg's work overlooking a thoroughly explained tongue-in-cheek aesthetic that Kjellberg himself tends to overtly state throughout his videos.   This piece is the product of someone doing surface-level research and it shows which is really disappointing because until today, the NYT was running on a 100% hit rate for me.", 'I read a fair amount of articles and writings on this subject, but this is the first to make me wonder what I just read. Your point is vague and unclear and you trying to dance around the subject just leaves the reader, whatever his or her perspective on this may be, frustrated.  Also for an article concerned with self-perception and image, this article is ironically devoid of any introspection of how the media covers entertainers like Felix.', "Have you all drunk gas? I'm honestly appalled that your publication would purposefully misinterpret comedy for the purpose of scare-mongering, and endorsing the destruction of a person's livelihood because you don't like his style of humor is simply disgusting.", 'I\'m not a huge fan of PewDiePie, but there is such a thing as satire and irony.  His antics aren\'t even remotely similar to the alt-right goons. To watch these videos and claim otherwise is to engage in willful, tendentious misreading. He\'s an internet goofball, caught in the crosshairs of people looking to be outraged.  This is similar to the controversy in which Stephen Colbert satirized conservatives for engaging in crude ethnic stereotypes of asians; this satire was then criticized (by an asian activist) as reinforcing crude ethnic stereotypes. She called for Colbert\'s show to be cancelled, making the same dumb argument we see here: "even if it\'s humor, it is a weapon used against minorities." It made no sense then, and makes no sense now. I urge anyone who is worried about the state of our culture - especially about the coarsening of public discourse - to actually watch the videos instead of reading this hit piece.', 'The agony of the holocaust and a few other horrors wrought by humanity (lynchings, slavery, terrorism to name a few) will never be fodder for satire, no matter the point it attempts to make. Kjellberg found this our swiftly and painfully.', 'you can never take anything far enough...just dont sell out...no copyright ever forever...these politically correct times are one big reality show...like in unreal...its all about tie-ins, advertising SEND MONEY ...and anything can be turned around, so man start your own deal...but dont sell out this time...stay true. And dont believe anything but Yourself and be sure to have a muse. vachelettres. NO to media mafia exploitation and rape of media mafia pop stars. NEVER WATCHED ANY OF YOUR VIDEOS NOR YOUR YOUTUBE which are prolly  lame. but hey you live love and learn. Now go something cool.', 'The Wall Street Journal article is pure farce. They blantantly take Pedwdiepie snippets out of context with the ultimate end goal of getting more clicks to their site by attacking the most famous Youtuber. When young people see this they will start to mistrust mainstream media and that will in the end be the biggest outcome of this. WSJ has done themselves and the mainstream media in large a huge disservice.', 'All of this hysteria coming from the left over supposed Nazi stormtrooper Youtube personalities reminds me of the religious right in the 90s kvetching over Satanic heavy metal and rap music.', 'It wasn\'t "Death to all Jews". It said "Death to all Jews, subscribe to Keemstar". The joke is that Keemstar is a well known YouTube troll that has said racial slurs in the past. Watch from 4:05 of the following video and it proves that the WSJ taken every single joke completely out of context. Felix should totally take them to court. https://youtu.be/JLNSiFrS3n4?t=245', 'Finally, someone intelligent wrote it right. Thank you for committing yourself to the whole story.', "Felix Kjellberg a.k.a. PewDiePie may look like an anti-semite and talk like an anti-semite but don't let that fool you. He really is an anti-semite.", 'Let\'s not get to "out there" on PewDiePie.  Okay, he\'s crazy.  Brace yourself for a shock, he\'s always been crazy.  As with many other creators on YouTube, and many other people working at Citibank.  Citibank does not fire then, generally.  This is a necessary component of a broad work force, within reason, at YouTube and Citibank.  So, does this blow-up really matter all that much.  I don\'t think so.  He will continue to be PewDiePie and continue to get views.  He got PIPed...not fired.', 'Wow this article is seriously out of touch with reality.............']
summary: Several commenters note that Felix Kjellberg/PewDiePie's comments were taken out of context and that his jokes were not understood by the WSJ. One commenter notes that Felix's humor is sarcastic, and another points out that he posted a video explaining the situation. Most commenters are supportive of Felix, but a couple state that the humor subjects (such as the holocaust) are never appropriate and that the situation is a result of a lack of socialization.
short_title: Headline: YouTube’s Monster: PewDiePie and His Populist Revolt   Keywords: Social Media; Computers and the Internet; Anti-Semitism; Maker Studios; Kjellberg, Felix (PewDiePie); YouTube.com   Snippet: How YouTube’s biggest star took a bizarre career turn, and what it tells us about the nascent politics of social platforms.
subreddit: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Anti-Semitism', 'Maker Studios', 'Kjellberg, Felix (PewDiePie)', 'YouTube.com']
short_question: ['YouTube’s Monster: PewDiePie and His Populist Revolt  ']

query: Maia proves to be a character with no moral center or desires of her own.
comments: ["Not as good as this review suggests. Sweeney was getting way tired during Good Wife. Please stop bringing him in. As much as I like that actor it's a schtick that's way done. Jane Lynch too much like Elspeth and other supposedly crazy pros. I liked the flashbacks best. Effective.", 'Maia and her original lawyer Yesha (where was she this week??) feel like teen drama characters dropped into an adult drama and they are just trying to do their best. I love teen dramas so I love Maia and Yesha the most.', 'Me, too.', 'Not appreciating the lens through which this article viewed the show, though I suppose everyone is entitled to - and has - their own lens.  Of course, Colin Sweeney is privileged and wears that privilege arrogantly. But when he says that it\'s not just black people who get brutalized, his "straight face" is warranted. More white men than black are killed by police every year, though black people are disproportionately brutalized in comparison to their percentage in the general population. And of course, the rest of his rationale was played for humor.  As for Maia, is the author implying that disadvantaged children would never turn a blind eye to their parents\' wrongdoing out of loyalty and love? Ridiculous. There is no need to drag privilege into something that could be a universal experience - the reluctance to see the very clay feet of someone you love, and who has loved you.', "I'm so glad to know this show is doing well, despite its status as online only. It's brilliant! I love it as much as The Good Wife. I still miss Alicia, but I'm grateful to see Diane and the new characters. It's an amazing show! I'm sad it's ending for the season. 10 episodes are not enough!", "I am sad that next week is the last episode of the season.  It seems like they will have a lot of loose ends that can't be tied up in one episode.", 'No one sees this show.', "More Jane Lynch please!  She is a joy to watch. I'd rather have her take down Maia  and her family than Matthew Perry's character who is just too smarmy. I'd love to see Jane Lynch spar with Christina Ebersole. Dylan Baker, as usual, has way too much fun playing Colin Sweeney. I agree that this was a good episode. Where I disagree is about Marissa. I like her character."]
summary: One commenter is disappointed that the episode wasn't as good as the review suggests but claimed the flashbacks were effective. Another commenter calls out what they believe is an inaccurate depiction of racial issues in modern times. A commenter praises Maia and Yesha while another praises Jane Lynch. Others praise the show and express sadness that the season is coming to an end.
short_title: Headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 9: Blinding Privilege   Keywords: Television; The Good Fight (TV Program)   Snippet: Maia proves to be a character with no moral center or desires of her own.
short_question: ['‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 9: Blinding Privilege  ']

query: This short documentary remembers the paleoanthropologist Mary Leakey, who discovered footprints of human ancestors on the African savanna.
comments: ['The moment in this film that stood out most to me was the fact that they just happened to stumble upon such legendary footprints during a game of throwing elephant dung at each other and that was surprising because so many discoveries happen during intense studying and analyzation, but they were able to enjoy themselves and find out many truths about human history while they were at it. A surprise is that Mary Leakey was actually a smoker and a drinker and had quite the bold attitude and that’s surprising because I usually think of paleoanthropologist as quiet solemn people who enjoy spending their time studying the simple, but very important parts of human life – its history. A message that this video provides is that great things can come from strange and random places and as long as you are enjoying yourself, you will find your great thing.', 'This film talks about a paleoanthropologist named Mary Leakey. Mary Leakey discovered footprints of human ancestors on the African Savanna, thanks to her intelligence. Mary Leakey inspired people to be who they are. Mary Leakey was able to change how the world is today. Today her history is still remembered. Working in the field of work, Mary Leakey was able to go to the past and find the footprints. This shows that with simple evidence and common sense we are able to know the paths of our ancestors. Mary Leakey also had a lot of patience, which gave her the results she expected.', "this documentary was very interesting because it talked of Mary Leakey's discoveries of the human ancestor. the moment that stood out for me was when she had discovered the footprints of our ancestors. this really surprised me because i did not know that humans looked that way or that you could even find their foot print. i am glad that there is people who are actually out there finding out more things about humans cause there is so much more we can learn.", 'This film shows how dedicated Mary Leakey was in finding historical evidence that involved the discovery of human footprints. Mary Leakey was a famous paleoanthropologist that would always work hard and she never gave up until she was satisfied with what she found that day. Mary was unique because there were very few female scientists during this time but that didn’t stop her from continuing her passion. She was one of the first to use a different type of method when looking for the discovery of early human ancestors. An elephant dung fight led to the discovery of a fossilized animal print, which goes to show that discoveries could happen at the least expected moment.', "This film opens up our eyes and suprises uswith the things we usually don't think about where they came from. This film gives us the history of our knowledge. Why do we know the things that we know today? well the reason for that is because of the fact that many people( scientist) were curious about many things and whent out to dicover the things that they did not know. It is such a surprize to see where and how far that science had come from. From not knowing much at all to having access to books and research available to us for almost all the questions that we have. A message that can be taken from this film is that Curiosity is why knowledge exsist and it is the building block of our exsistence.", 'As someone who finds most aspects of science very interesting, this video not only serves as an example of determination, but it also informed me about where all of our ancestors came from and how they walked. This film is about Mary Leakey, a famous anthropologist who was dedicated to her work of digging to unlock the secrets of the human’s ancestors. Hs was a dedicated woman and even searched for two years before finding the footprints. This shows that dedication truly pays off if you are able to be patient. As long as you are dedicated and patient, good things might come to you.', 'I agree with you on this. These scientist really wanted to know how we humans canme about and they did everything in their power to conduct envestigations and prove to the world that their is more. They knew that their was something beyond our knowlegde and they went to chase history down to fufill their curiosity and redeem the knowledge that was unknow to human kind for such a long time. By these few people went above and beyond to unlache the box of knowleg=dge that was waiting to be revealed.', 'In the short film "Animated Life: Mary Leakey" filmed by Flora Lightman and Shattuck. Shows a documentary in animation of the famous anthropologist Mary Leakey. This documentary talks about Mary Leakey hard working, never giving up, attitude. The film tells stories about her love for her dogs. Many people want to know the history behind humans. Majority of the people around the world ask many questions related to who was the first human? How were humans created in a world where scientists once said their was no living things?  How did they survive many years?  Mary Leakey had similar questions, but unlike those people Mary Leakey took action, she and Luis Leakey her husband set of to Africa. Luis Leakey and Mary Leakey were a great team while Luis Leakey sponsored is wife. Mary Leakey ancient artifacts, such as her great discovery of human ancestors footprints on the Africa savanna. Mary Leakey contributed in the discoveries of Paranthropus Boisei (1959) and Homo Habilis (1964). Mary and Luis Leakey\'s determination to search for answers of our human history allows people to become one step closer to finally figuring out our Human history. To add on  Mary Leakey is an inspiration to anyone scientist in the world.', 'I agree that Mary Leakey and her work is very inspiring, she spend a lot of time in uncomfortable places like the African Savanna under the sun trying to complete her goals and contribute to our knowledge of human origin or ancestry. She and her husband, Louis Leakey, discovered many ancient artifacts or remains. I was surprised at how much she loved her dogs, she give them butter even though they are rationing some of their foods. Her discovery of the footprints which show when human ancestor began walking on two leg was a result of her determination, this discovery allow human to better understand their origin.', 'I thought that this weeks film was very interesting. It was about a paleoanthropologist named Mary Leakey who was looking for human origin and past human events and bone structure. She is a very dedicated worker, sometimes taking several months, even years to finish a project. We saw this as she spent 2 years looking and finding a footprint, which shows how dedicated and determined she is.', 'I agree with you about Mary Leakey being a very dedicated person when it came to her projects. She spent so much time trying to find information that could lead to a discovery of a human or animal fossil. No matter how long it took to find some sort of evidence, Mary would keep on looking. It showed us how much she loved doing this, not to mention that she was one of very few people to look for these fossils and artifacts. After all this time, Mary finally found a fossilized animal footprint and it showed me that hard work pays off.', 'You are so right she is a very hard worker, taking that much just to study the snippet of the things that occurred such a long time ago is wonderful. She is such a great figure, one that is unfortunately not celebrated enough. Like many other hidden people that work behind the scenes to create the lives that we have today and to also help us to understand our own origins and make up better. I think it is so important to recognize people like her who have put so much hard work into bettering humanity and I am proud to call her a fellow female.', 'The film talk about a famous paleoanthropologist named Mary Leakey. She was dedicated to her work, using careful methods to dig up remains and she was very determined to find out about human origin. Mary and her husband greatly contributed to the search and found many remains of human ancestors. She discovered track from bipedal human ancestor that is preserved with volcanic ash. The moment that stood out to me was when it took her two years to find the footprint because it show how much time she have to put into her work and how devoted she is to her goals. A message you can take away from this film is that people have to stick to their goals and work hard in order to achieve anything.', 'I too believe that she contributed to the scientific community because of her discovery, especially since this discovery proves that the Laetoli people walked on two feet, like us. I cannot believe that she spent two years searching for this tracks. If it were mean I would have given up because I would have lost hope. Not only did she not lose her hope but she stayed determined through the hardships she must have encountered. The message is definitely something that can be followed by mostly everyone because it can apply to anyone in any kind of situation.', 'i agree that she is a very inspiring person when i comes to following your goals and finishing what you have stated because all this information she has found can help us with why we do the things we do and why we act the way we act.', 'I agree with you. Mary Leakey was a very hard working woman that changed the world. With the remains that she was able to find, it seems to me that she could have been an archeologist. Mary Leakey showed people not to give up on their goals and keep trying until they get what they want. Even though it took two years for Mary Leakey to find the footprints, she was still able to find them. Hard work always gives good results. Mary’s husband was also on Mary’s side, helping her find the footprints. With support and courage, Mary was able to meet her goal.', 'Please add subtitles to the Mary Leakey video.  I would like to show this video to my Deaf students.  Thank you.']
summary: The majority of commentators give long summaries about the film, all covering similar ground about Mary Leakey and her surprising discovery of human footprints during an elephant dung fight. Many commentators admire her patience and dedication. One commentator notes that her personality is not the stereotypical quiet and patient paleoanthropologist. One commentator wants subtitles to show the film to deaf students.
short_title: Headline: Teaching With: ‘Animated Life: Mary Leakey’   Keywords:    Snippet: This short documentary remembers the paleoanthropologist Mary Leakey, who discovered footprints of human ancestors on the African savanna.
short_question: ['Teaching With: ‘Animated Life: Mary Leakey’  ']

query: Supplements like cherry and pomegranate juice, vitamins C and E, and black tea extract did little to alleviate post-exercise muscle aches.
comments: ['Aspirin, aspirin, aspirin. Or a steam room / sauna. If I go to a steam room or sauna after a hard workout - no pain. I can work out the next day. If not - I hurt. Aspirin definitely helps as does ibuprofen (which I do not like to use due to possible damage to kidneys/liver, etc).', "Earlier someone asked what Venus and Serena do for soreness. I don't know what they do, but I remember reading an article about a female high endurance athlete who had a team of people helping her survive what looks so wonderful to us and yet is very painful for the athletes. I recall that there was a full time nutritionist, a full time physical therapist and massage therapist on her team. My massage therapist used to work with pro atheletes and musicians and the stories she tells are grueling. I myself take a Tylenol when the pain keeps me awake. Yoga, massage, and chiropractic help a lot.", 'Perhaps the use of antioxidants for relief of muscle pain after exercise is misguided.  Basic cell biology tells us the muscle cell depends on mitochondrial function for energy production, and lactate build up causes muscle pain. Supplements like Coenzyme Q-10, Alpha Lipoic Acid, Carnitine and Benfothiamine enhance mitochondrial function by improving oxidative phosphorylation and transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain (ETC).  Use mitochondrial energy supplements instead of anti-oxidants for better muscle function and less pain.  Alternately, drugs which inhibit mitochondrial function such as statins which deplete CoQ10, and Metformin which inhibits Complex I of the electron transport chain, will make muscle pain worse.  Some antibiotics such as tetracycline, and erythromycin inhibit mitochondrial function because mitochondria share many of the same energy pathways as bacteria. For more see: http://jeffreydachmd.com/thiamine-deficiency-and-diabetes/', 'After shoveling for 5 hours the night before, I am still sore. So I helped to shovel out one of my neighbors before I did not daily a miler this morning. I feel better now :)', 'It is ridiculous to expect instant effectiveness from antioxidants.', 'Readers may be interested in a paper titled: "Antioxidants prevent health-promoting effects of physical exercise in humans" that appeared in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences  vol. 106 no. 21, pp  8665–8670 (2009).', "It reaffirms patients' belief in the judgment of health care professionals when myths are impersonally debunked,  as happened here.", 'Out here in Oregon everyone that hikes takes Arnica Montana. I use the sublingual pellets and use a gel or rub with it on the sore muscles. Works every time.', 'The conventional wisdom regarding antioxidants with exercise, is that they can improve performance, or enable a level of performance with less apparent effort/stress... but they don\'t do much for recovery or discomfort. Lester Packer\'s book, \'Miracle of Antioxidants\' (C) 1999 reports that vitamin E improved running, but not swimming, performance. More recent work reviewed by NYTs, shows that taking antioxidants prior exercise, decreases the extent to which the exercise fortifies the body. An individual\'s response to use of antioxidants can vary relative to their state of health -- when my body was very much systemically inflamed, antioxidants were a healing lifesaver. As my health improved, the benefit of antioxidants waned. *    * Taking \'omega 3\' polyunsaturated dietary oils (from flax/fish) can enable dramatic improvements in soft-tissue healing. However, these oils are much more prone to oxidation in the body than the saturated fat in dairy. Therefore, it is possible that eating polyunsaturated fats can cause such oxidation, and promote reactions such as "accelerated aging" or "cancers". The cure for that is to also take a little vitamin E, which functions to prevent lipid peroxidation.  {For two years i took omega 3 fats without vitamin E, and during/after my running i felt exhausted, and looked like i was dying much faster than planned. This effect ceased when i included some vitamin E in my pre-run meal.} Never take the synthetic form of vitamin E .', "Not evidence, but personal annecdote: I read rave reviews about using tart cherry juice after workouts to prevent muscle soreness. Usually I don't put much stock in such things, but so many people were saying it I thought I'd give it a try.  I had not exercised in a very long time.  I did a long, hard workout (always overdo it, which is why it never becomes a habit). The sort of workout that normally would have me struggling to walk the next couple of days.  I drank the juice after my workout and the next day I felt totally normal!  Very strange, but after my personal experience I'm a believer. Don't know what else could account for it!", "Have someone else give you a placebo by mixing something else with cherry flavored syrup as well as another day with the actual cherry juice mixed similarly so you can't tell which is which. Do it enough times to make it randomize, perhaps twenty times total and then compare your reactions. I bet it will be like a coin toss.", "I understand the reasoning, but I know the difference between between being able to walk and not!  And it's not like I was actually expecting it to work.  I was skeptical. There are other times I've given things a shot just to see, and they didn't work, which was fine.  So I'm convinced it's not just wishful thinking.", 'A friend told me recently, "I ate a whole raw egg today, including the shell." I ignored him, I really don\'t care what he eats per se. Happening to speak with him the next day he said, "No problem since yesterday ...." "Huh?" I replied. "I ate a whole raw egg yesterday, including the shell and no problems!" I noted, "Yeah you mentioned that you did, I\'d expect not." The idea that some food "does something" to you in some precise way in a short term is a psychological hangup, not nutritional science. You are not going to live longer for having eaten this or that, nor are you going to progress in fitness development if you eat "Muscle Mass!" rather than some cottage cheese and sufficient common variety of protein. Claims about foods are driven mostly by the motivations of capitalism.Food claims are scams, food claims are scams, food claims are scams. Get it? "Organic" is very much a scam. The high cost per lb food in a health food store is a scam.  Eating fresh whole food moderately, but in sufficient quantity to keep you from losing weight, is what you do to correctly feed an exercising body. Not wasting money, if money matters to you, is more important than buying organic food for some supposed health benefit. If you like the cultural idea of organic food and don\'t mind the cost, buy it and enjoy that facet of life. Claims about frivolous things like "antioxidants" have so little merit they don\'t deserve mention in a health column.', "The very notion that bits of supplemental food have any effect on any bodily function is foolish. You can eat blueberries until you turn blue, it is not going to change your health picture because of their so called anti-oxidant value.  This column constantly presents small bits of research data as though it mattered, then goes on to play ping pong with that data promoting and dismissing it. Just stop presenting this junk information as though it mattered! The job of researchers is foolish study, enough already. There does exist a huge and overwhelmingly useful body of evidence on these things: the people who actually live lives that include exercise. When I am sore from exercise, which is every other day every week, I take a couple ... hold on to your hat for this surprise: generic ibuprofen! Imagine that! I take a well understood pain medication for pain! Why I don't put on a copper bracelet or eat a clove of garlic or stare at a mandala is beyond me, I must just be lucky.", 'really! Have you even tried it on yourself ?', "I eat powdered ginger root and it has virtually eliminated my after exercise muscle soreness, but it doesn't seem to dampen the pain of a true injury, which to me is a good thing. Having been a runner for years I am well acquainted with morning soreness and stiffness.", "Try using a placebo and after about twenty times you'll see there is no difference. Have someone provide you with the unidentified powder each day...and have them alternate.", 'However, I am a vegan and since I’ve eliminated oil from my diet, I’ve had significant reduction in AM soreness.  Used to dread waking up after a rigorous workout and dream of a massage chair.  Now, just a mild reminder of what I used to have. Has anyone else had this experience?', 'Sandra Rubin - The experience you refer to in your case manifest as associating some diet change with an unrelated reaction is called post hoc logical fallacy, and people have it all the time in all sorts of situations. Post hoc ergo propter hoc. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post_hoc_ergo_propter_hoc', 'I too became no-oil vegan two years ago, have also noticed I no longer get stiff and sore from exercise. Love eating this way. Ate some candy one day, was sore the next day. Coincidence perhaps, but I feel too good to go back to oil and animal products. Also eat whole grains and no sugar. Not sure which element of the diet is causing what, but the overall combination has made me feel better than I have in years.', 'I have avoided icing down my knees for the ages -- finally succumbed to the ice pack -- I put one on my knee, hold it in place for 15 minutes with an ace bandage; bingo, it works, the soreness goes away.', "Antioxidants don't work, but magnesium supplements do. I suspect our factory farms grow pretty fruits and vegetables on soil that has lost any/all nutritional value so nothing in what we eat provides us with what we need....", "It is very difficult to do what Serena and Venus do, but the task is easy to identify: change your parents. It's all in the genes and, try as you might, there's little you can do about most of the problems in life.", 'Kudos to Nicholas Bakalar for yet again shooting down another health superstition.  This time for "antioxidants" -- a rather ubiquitous type of bio-chemical found in so many foods.   Antioxidant supplements have been found not to have any effects on anything, so far.   The money quote: "Authors\' Conclusions: The authors found no evidence to support antioxidant supplements for primary or secondary prevention. Vitamins A and E, and beta-carotene may increase mortality. " https://www.aafp.org/afp/2008/1101/p1079.html No evidence of benefit -- some evidence of harm.', 'I was somewhat impressed by studies of tart cherry in reducing muscle soreness   . . . took it for a couple of months, which included my regular running (25 miles a week), gym work, and one marathon . . . did not notice the slightest bit of difference to performance or recovery in any way, so I stopped it a few weeks ago. Just an n-of-1 anecdotal report which goes along with the finding of this study', "It is important to assess the actual effect that is expected. The research on tart-cherry juice showed recovery of strength in the 24 h after overexertion. The research didn't show an effect on muscle soreness. It didn't show an increase in performance; that increase would be the result of the additional high-intensity training the faster recovery allows.", 'What utter nonsesnse! Some one food product or another has NO effect on your daily body functions.', 'Maybe bodies are just different, and not everything will work for everybody.  Personally, I have been impressed by the results of tart cherry juice in my own experience.  I would recommend trying to see if it helps.  As one who finds any excuse not to exercise, I need all the help I can get! And this works well for me.', 'This is when I ask, what do Serena and Venus do... they both have been playing tennis and for many years.  Is the answer just spend tons of money on professional services... or is there something that the everyday person can do... Gatorade?  Coffee?  People with Chronic Illnesses have muscle soreness, so I suspect the answer would lean more toward a prescribed medication (hopefully not an illegal drug from Russia).']
summary: Most commenters agree that the evidence does not support antioxidant supplementation use for soreness prevention.  Some commenters present alternatives to antioxidant supplementation; others lament health myths and the machinery behind their ubiquity. A few commenters specifically mention the accessibility and efficacy of the Williams sisters’ recovery process.  Alternatively, a minority of commenters share moderate success with antioxidant supplements. One commenter suggests a methodology for performing a self-study and is subsequently criticized and corrected. Finally, a lone commenter shares how they double-down on whatever activity made them sore in the first place.
short_title: Headline: Alternative Medicine: Antioxidants and Soreness   Keywords: Vitamins; Antioxidants; Muscles; Pain   Snippet: Supplements like cherry and pomegranate juice, vitamins C and E, and black tea extract did little to alleviate post-exercise muscle aches.
short_question: ['Alternative Medicine: Antioxidants and Soreness  ']

query: Monday: Saying farewell to a fixture, preparing for a possible blizzard, and applying for city jobs.
comments: ['As a political appointee, Mr. Bharara should have gracefully resigned when requested to by the DOJ.', "I don't know Bharara. He seems like a decent person and a dedicated public servant. As much as I hate Trump and his minions (overlords?), in the wake of Bharara's firing I see a predictable narrative forming in which people like him are cast as unblemished heroes poised against the villains (who in this case, do seem to uniformly awful, unprincipled, and corrupt).  Even the photo of  Bharara (more flattering than usual) that the Times chose to accompany this column reveals its inclination. But fake dichotomies are not helpful.  Today's saints tomorrow end up having feet of clay. I hope for realistic coverage.", 'LYING WHILE BREATHING Flub after flub At the Florida hub, At the country club, At the golfing shrub Over drinks & grub, At a perceived snub-- Hoping that flubbing Results in a drubbing. Could it be this bub Needs a belly rub?', "I don't want to follow your reporters on Twitter. I pay so you will keep me up to date without having to look at 10 different apps.", 'I hope someone, somewhere is keeping careful track of and recording each and every atrocity on justice, attacks on fairness, attempts to destroy  ethical government, etc., in the demented service of promoting  a self-serving , early Third Reich- like  administration which is shamelessly entrenched in a demented tunnel vision illusion of what is really needed.  I am expecting to see the Mad Hatter at any moment.  There is a great book waiting to be written about these very sad days.  Mr. Bharara will have a special chapter to add.  I know he will still be fighting the good fight...as he has always done.', "This man epitomizes what a true civil servant should be. He will be missed. Perhaps he should run for Mayor of NYC instead of the turkey who occupies Gracie Mansion now. At least he'll play fair and he understand how to govern.", 'I don\'t think that De Blasio is "turkey," and running for public office and governing are quite different from managing a prosecutor\'s office, no matter how prestigious and important it might be.', '"A lawyer who defends Muslim Americans has become a consultant to “Homeland,” the popular television show about terrorism." I\'m not sure anything can save Homeland at this point.  I have fast-forwarded through the last two episodes.', 'The land of laws now fractionalized @ local levels United for corruption & bribes exposing their past historical migration roots with nationality. When we the voters hire thieves to protect our interests,be ready to loose all you have under their watches.', 'The National Weather Service says 14 to 24 inches in total for Central Park.', 'Exit Bharara, a man of great integrity.  Enter Eric Schneiderman into the fray, if he is not already investigating the goings-on at Trump Tower.  Schneiderman is an active attorney general and Trump Tower is in the state of New York, after all.  I look forward to the adventures of Eric and friends in the coming months.', "It's hard to believe that there is anyone left in NYC so naive as to believe the Donald could be trusted to keep his word.  At this point it is almost the same las believing you can buy a certain bridge between Manhattan and Brooklyn", 'Per the Dept of Sanitation, ASP has been suspended March 14 and 15', 'What an incredible waste of time, money and resources this all is. All these positions that change potentially every four years. No wonder nothing works or gets done. Can you imagine if private organizations changed hands like this? Mass chaos would ensue and it has!', 'Rmski77, Yes, we should elect a Dictator for Life and have done with it.', "PRAISE SPRING--& TAKE COVER If spring comes, can winter be far behind? Don't  ask the weather man, who's in a bind. Instead of blossoms and hocus-focus crocus, We're getting a blizzard with tons of snow that'll soak us.", "No Blizzard can match the flurry of shock coming after the sudden dismissal of Preet Bharara. Even though in 20/20 hindsight, we should've seen it coming. Mr. Bharara, a star in his own right, dared to shine too brightly on the stage Donald Trump has carefully built for one. But it also didn't help that Mr. Bharara is a no-nonsense federal prosecutor who never stops digging. That may have made Mr. Trump uncomfortable -- How else do you explain the fact that only a few weeks ago he was glad to have him on board? That is something we can think about as we dig ourselves out from under the snow.", "I think Trump is trying to pack his justice department with defenders not fair prosecutors of his many controversial issues from conflicts of interest, to emerging evidence on direct ties between his administration and the Russians – during the campaign, during the transition, and into this administration. Yes I believe it exists to this day, which explains a lot of the more remarkable aspects to his almost phantom government. I also believe he is biding his time until such point as he can lift sanctions on Russia and make sure Congress would ratify. Nobody knows more than Trump the power of the law and its ability to be used for one's own purposes. He is a master of this, using lawsuits and bankruptcies as business strategies. A man like Preet  Bears would obviously be a danger because of his core integrity. I suspect we have not heard the last of him and he will become some kind of activist focused on exposing what is happening inside the Trump administration.", "On March 8, FBI Director Comey met in private with the heads of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees.  No word was publically released on what they discussed. On March 9, Trump moved for the resignations of 46 US Attorneys, including Bharara, who he said could stay on. On March 10, Trump fires Bharara. It looks like whatever was discussed on March 8 leaked to Trump, and it's not good for him, so he moved quickly to remove the most experienced US Attorney in the country, who also happens to be the one who covers the District where Trump resided.", "Charles as much as I loath and detest Trump Obama and previous presidents have done the same. Still Bharara will be missed. He was one of the finest AG's we've had in a long time.", "One of those 'small counties upstate' is Rockland where the Southern District has been meticulously crafting the case against corrupt Town of Ramapo Supervisor, Christopher St Lawrence, Development Head Allan Troodler (who recently copped a plea in exchange for testimony), Town Attorney Michael Klein, and Town Tax Assessor Nathan Oberman; all of whom have been raping the taxpayers for over a decade. Those of us honest citizens have been awaiting the ouster of these four corrupt Democrats (I am usually a Democrat) and are deeply concerned that without Bharara to prosecute thiscwill go nowhere. I am sick of lining the pockets of St Lawrence and his cronies-so now what Mr Sessions?", 'I wonder if there is any way that Preet can become the special prosecutor when Justice finally returns to Washington and the purging of the halls of DC starts post-Trump impeachment.', "Regarding the And Finally section on the ferry and the mayor: The Ferry Song Tune of The Trolley Song Ching-ka-ching went the ferry Ring ring ring for the boats Up up up go the chances For the Mayor to be getting those votes Buzz buzz buzz went New Yorkers Type type type went the press Gripe gripe gripe went the public But they'll vote for Bill nevertheless All over town, more kudos spread We hoped he wouldn't let success get to his head The costs are set, we hear some cheers They're looking for new deckhands and new engineers Soon soon soon comes enjoyment Now now now it's complete Up up up went employment As the boats start to float With the town set to vote, it looks grand As our tickets are scanned And exactly as planned We all stand, give a hand As they've manned the whole fleet And the Mayor can't be beat.  (ching ka ching went the ferry, we repeat)", 'Brilliant, Freddie!  I also was struck by the ferry info and thought you might go for "Ferry Cross the Mersey", but of course, this is so much better.  Thank you for the pre-blizzard levity.', "The beauty of Mr Bharara's tenure -- and accomplishments -- was its apolitical contours: right or wrong, not right or left. Preet, we need you now more than ever.", "finally someone that makes me feel not afraid unlike the current political bozos being given authority.....DOJ needs to save us from this dictatorship ...thank you preet...we're counting on you", 'Run for city office, Preet.', "That often doesn't work out. Political office corrupts, or if it doesn't out-and-out corrupt, the stress of having to please so many constituencies changes people. Rudy Giuliani had the same job as Preet Bharara and was well liked before being elected mayor.  During his service he became conservative and alienated minority groups.  Now, he's a synonym for racism.   De Blasio was respected as the public advocate.  Now he can't take a breath without someone picking him apart.", 'He should run for Mayor. Someone who is actually qualified for the job, not who currently resides at Gracie Mansion.']
summary: Most of the commenters have positive feelings toward Preet Bahara and hope that he either runs for office or can work in the Justice Department once President Trump is out of office. They think that he is a decent person. Some of the commenters talk about the way President Trump runs the country like he runs his businesses, as in forcing the laws to work for him rather than him bending to the will of the law. One commenter thinks the NYT has exalted Preet.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Changes for Preet Bharara   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Monday: Saying farewell to a fixture, preparing for a possible blizzard, and applying for city jobs.
short_question: ['New York Today: Changes for Preet Bharara  ']

query: A study finds the presence of a liberal or conservative justice can move the entire court left or right, and not only with their own vote.
comments: ['How did Photographer Eric Thayer capture that glowing corona of divinity? Real or faux photo journalism?', 'What\'s with the halo and the "gee golly gosh I\'m just the nicest guy" look on his face?  He\'s not.  Propaganda!', "Your lips to God's ear,  Justin. After this Friday,  when the eminently qualified Judge Gorsuch joins the SCOTUS I hope he will move the other Justices in a Conservative direction. Just think of the positive influence a Justice Diane Sykes could have on the court when the Republicans choose the next new Associate Justice!", 'I worked as a clerk to a state appellate court judge in the early 1980s right after graduating law school. Each judge had his own proclivities and views, but I can\'t say I saw any one judge\'s views pull a panel one way or the other in terms of ideology. But then state appeals court decisions are more to do with the mundane legal issues of everyday citizens\' existence, and that of the interplay of local governments and their constituents, whereas the U.S. Supreme Court busies itself with the weighty work of broad social policy.  It makes sense that more liberal- or conservative-leaning quasi majorities will eventually draw in the minority members lest the minority members become totally irrelevant. U.S. Supreme Court judges tend to have big egos and want to think they have a role to play in history. I am sure Hammurabi had the same thing in mind--what did he do again?  One thing I disagree with is "if" Gorsuch will be confirmed. Barring a meteor striking the Senate chamber, it is done.', 'I\'ll wait for the peer review, thanks. Regarding your photo choice: harrumph. Corporate "Frozen Truck Driver" Gorsuch deserves no angelic such glow.', 'If this is true, would not Justice Gorsuch be subject to the same peer effect from the "liberal" justices on the court.
