Of course, this article ignores obvious counter effect.   It has been widely reported that Justices Scalia and Ginsberg were good friends, but certainly any peer effect on each others written decisions are at best minimal. I doubt this paper stands up well to a peer review.', 'The research  on which you base your startling  claims seems meager and weak. It doesn\'t take into account the constraints of precedent and personality. For example,  Justice Scalia had an outsize personality and a memorable writing style. Yet he had far less influence on his peers than Justice Anthony Kennedy who has been quieter but more of a consensus-builder. Observers were shocked by the Citizens United case but it was determined to  a large extent by the precedent of Buckley v. Valeo, and the idea that money facilitates free speech. Since Supreme Court decisions cannot be reversed by a higher court, justices have a greater degree of freedom to express their political ideology, suitably clothed, than lower-court judges. Some justices, like Holmes, Brandeis, and Douglas make their mark in dissents.  They are unmoved by peers, wanting not "to follow a multitude into evil." Biography, American history, and the history of constitutional law are more precise tools for understanding how judges make decisions than economics, which deals with averages, percentages, and gross effects.', 'Whom does a Supreme Court Justice call to ask for a sick-day? Do you have cough exaggeratedly while on the phone, try to sound nasal? Do you later need to show proof you went to a doctor? I guess you really do have to ask a coworker to cover for you.', 'Mitch McConnell and his "conservative", supposedly "christian" buddies are going to do whatever is necessary to try to destroy democracy further by taking over OUR United States Supreme Court and putting someone even more archaic in their thinking than Scalia on it.  Perhaps they will.  Perhaps they will take away the filibuster to flex their "muscles" and try to complete their takeover. One problem, boys.  You underestimate the Good People of America.  You are all simply human beings and will not survive long if you decide to carry out your plans.  You might want to rethink how the universe works.  Your great god removed Scalia.  Remember that.', "I don't know why we have hearing to determine whether or not a person is suited for a position in government, be it a cabinet position or a Supreme Court nominee. When asked questions about their political or social views, these candidates feed Congressional inquisitors what they think will move them along in the confirmation process. A recent case in point is the confirmation of Jeff Sessions. He gave misinformation, was confirmed, and was then called out after the truth was revealed. And now we see Mr. Sessions making decisions based on what his true ultra conservative views are rather than what was presented at his hearings. It's all smoke and mirrors played out on TV.", 'Ahhhhhh.   Music to my ears.  This gives me hope for our nation.   All of the leftist commenters need to realize that their ideology has failed whenever/wherever tried.  If fidelity to the Constitution is tossed on the ash heap, the U.S. becomes just another land mass ruled by tyrants and lawless tribes.', "You're absolutely correct, which is why it was inexcusable when the Republicans refused to hold a hearing for Garland, in violation of President Obama's constitutional mandate. In addition, the unconstitutional corruption and cronyism of our current president means he should be Impeached immediately. As a devoted Constitutionalist, I'm sure you'll agree.", 'The constitution has already been tossed on the ash heap. Our president does as he pleases, in clear violation of law and the constitution, and the Republican congress sits by and protects him.', 'Perhaps you would care to inform us in where in the Constitution it is mandated that a Presidential nominee is guaranteed a hearing and a vote?', 'This is an important consideration in the decision with regard to Gorsuch.  It has not received the consideration that it should.  The Republicans are well aware that this is true.', 'A gloomy forecast of what is the future. Of course, there will be more such appointments shortly, and for the foreseeable future the Supreme Court will bend every law as far toward the corporate will as possible. The only hope is that, somewhere during this bleak 30-40 years, a Democratic Congress and President will have the will to pass human laws the Court will be unable to circumvent.', "Did anyone notice the photo that shows a halo above Gorsuch's head?", "He's got a halo headache!", 'This man will drive this country so far backwards that music will return to beating on skin covered drums and beating bones on logs will have a come back. The "law" is not about morally right, fair or decent.  Remember, it was a "law" that allowed white men to own other men, women and children.', 'And it was law, enacted by Republicans, that freed them.', "This is really interesting -- it's a long term contribution to am important sociological concern.  But such arguments haven't an atom of weight or relevance to the immediate question of whether a Republican government has a pure and presumptive right to replace Nino Scalia with someone that it deems most suitable.  It's the Senate's call, and you know the Senate is GOP and most likely to be more so in less than two years.", 'Graham said, "If my Democratic colleagues choose to filibuster this guy, then they will be telling me that they don\'t accept the election results -- 306 electoral votes -- that they\'re trying to delegitimize President Trump, and that\'s not right and we would have to change the rules to have the Supreme Court like everybody else."  Graham said he hoped that they would not have to change Senate rules. "I hope that we can get 60 votes and not change 200 plus years of history," said Graham. "But I will do whatever\'s necessary, but I\'ve been a pretty balanced guy and enough is enough." Graham is denying reality. McConnell and Grassley refused to allow Garland\'s nomination to go forward. What was he doing, when this was going on? Did he sleep through that disgraceful episode?']
summary: While the article argues that adding a more conservative Judge Gorsuch to the Supreme Court will sway the Court similar to that of Justice Scalia and possibly alter the other judges' leanings. Commenters are arguing passionately regarding how both elected officials are twisting the laws to fil their own agendas.  The concerns that the Court will rule only as far as corporate interests are met, setting aside the human needs in the Constitution. Another commenter who previously worked as a clerk pointed out that the hearings make no difference when the candidates' responses are never seriously considered as far as disqualification goes. The commenters go on to point out that once Court begins, the 'peer effect' no longer holds weight.
short_title: Headline: How Gorsuch’s Influence Could Be Greater Than His Vote   Keywords: Supreme Court (US); Gorsuch, Neil M; Courts and the Judiciary; Decisions and Verdicts   Snippet: A study finds the presence of a liberal or conservative justice can move the entire court left or right, and not only with their own vote.
subreddit: ['Supreme Court (US)', 'Gorsuch, Neil M', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
short_question: ['How Gorsuch’s Influence Could Be Greater Than His Vote  ']

summary_propositions: [{"claim": "commenters express their love for the ambrosia cake", "ground": ["commenters express their love for the ambrosia cake"]}, {"claim": "the cake is not kosher for Passover", "ground": ["the cake is not kosher for Passover"]}]
query: The festive fruit salad or dessert inspired this billowing coconut dessert.
comments: ["I can't wait to try this recipe!!!", "Melissa, I love you, but how can you do this to us on the first day of Passover, what? You don't know from Pesach?", 'My grandma made it, without cream, every Thanksgiving. Now my mother makes it on Thanksgiving.  Love it!  Just know that not every traditional southern version of ambrosia contains dairy products.', "The cake sounds good, but the description of ambrosia at the start of the video threw me for a loop!  Orange slices, coconut, and marshmallows!  That's all?!  In my family, it is made of orange sections, some grapefruit (b/c I grew up in FL?), pineapple, maraschino cherries, shredded coconut, pecans, and mini marshmallows.  Online recipes seem to be variations of this.", "This is perfect. Didn't grow up with ambrosia, except at church suppers.  But, I did grow up with coconut and orange cakes - blending the 2 together is perfect. And, the only 2 fruits my wife hates are pineapple and bananas, so leaving those out will bring a smile to her face.", 'I love Melissa Clark!', 'My pal Mike likes to tell this story: Many years ago he & his friend Bob were going thru the buffet line at the old Riviera hotel/casino.  They reached the dessert section & Bob asked the server, "Is this the ambrosia?", to which she replied "No sir, this is the Riviera."', 'I love it!', "The ambrosial cake always reminded me of the lane cake - white or yellow cakes with fruity fillings and topped with a fluffy over-the-top sweet white frosting smothered with either shredded coconut or some kind of nuts (usually pecans).  I always associated those cakes with the South because they were also so eloquent, had real old-fashioned charm and elegance, and something served with a nicely chilled glass of iced tea (the cakes that is, not the wonderful folks from the South).  All of what I described above, I completely dislike, almost loathe.  I'm a chocolate cake and vanilla ice cream kind of gal.  I think the main reason why my Mother never made an ambrosial cake is because the ingredients were too expensive and we didn't have any extra money for special cakes like that back then.  And the one time I did try these cakes, I thought my teeth were going to fall out because of how sweet they were.  But I love this article and the photographs and I have never been disappointed yet with a NYT food feature.  Now about that chocolate cake - what kind of recipes do you have on file . . .", "for a sweet tooth like me it's the best. dessert. ever."]
summary: Most commenters express their love for the ambrosia cake. On the first day of Passover, one commenter expresses disdain since the cake is not kosher for Passover. One commenter expresses extra things that they always add in when they make the cake.
short_title: Headline: A Slice of Ambrosia (and That’s Just the Filling)   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Cakes; Coconuts; Citrus Fruits   Snippet: The festive fruit salad or dessert inspired this billowing coconut dessert.
short_question: ['A Slice of Ambrosia (and That’s Just the Filling)  ']

query: Unlike the cute and sweet images of dogs on social media, Marcos Javier Garcia’s photos show the lives of dogs that have been abandoned or given up to a Miami shelter where space is limited.
comments: ["Thank you for the article and the beautiful, touching, haunting photographs. My dog was rescued from a kill shelter in Miami and I will be forever grateful to the woman who pulled her out the day before she would have been put down. She's loyal, beautiful (softest fur you've ever felt!), sensitive, gentle, and our best friend. I don't have a lot of free time to volunteer, but donate as much as I can to animal shelters and rescue groups each month. Everyone should adopt a dog from a shelter, or volunteer/donate to one. Adopt, don't shop!", "Bless Mr. Marcos Javier Garcia for being an animal shelter volunteer, help save pets as well as be their voice. For over five years (from the age of 19-24) I worked the front desk at the local humane society/SPCA. My first two weeks on the job I fainted from the seeing the horrific abuse animals suffered and the careless owners relinquishing their dogs and cats. I learned to be grateful that those owners brought their pets in to the shelter. It was far better in there than dumped outdoors to a more horrific doom. It was better at the shelter because those dogs, cats, birds, rabbits, etc. were treated with love and compassion. Sometimes for the first time. We had great volunteers and a superb humane education program. We remodeled, expanded, worked in the community, all to save some animals. Over 20 years later, that 'job' was the best one I ever had. I will never forget being in the kennels and cat ward every day. The smells, the sounds, the adoptions, and yes, the death.", 'It warms my heart to see this article and touching photos Published and shared. We live in our comfortable homes Sometimes forgetting these beautiful dog and cat souls at the shelter .Creating awareness, sharing love with the animals at the shelter and taking some home can heal our souls . Thank you for the beautiful photos and the reminder, Mr Garcia.', 'The fact that pit bulls are forbidden in Miami is a VERY sad reflection on the people of Miami.   Shame that the dogs have to suffer because of fools!!!!!', "Haunting, sad, beautiful pictures. I'll admit--although a dog lover, I find volunteering at my local shelter too heart breaking. I'm on my second rescue now; when she goes (I hope, many years from now), I'll try to rescue a pair or get involved in fostering. Kudos to Mr. Garcia for his beautiful work and for getting involved--same to all the other shelter workers who care for these animals, left through no fault of their own.", 'Please consider donating to Wings of Rescue, an organization that flies hundreds of dogs and cats from high kill overcrowded shelters to no-kill shelters in other parts of the country where they can be adopted.  Please look at their Facebook page.', 'Thank you for this heartbreaking article-  the photos are really touching and made me so sad. I wish people would understand that Pits are NOT THE KILLERS  that they are  branded to be. These dogs used to be called Nanny dogs, as they watched over children and protected them! Humans that have evil in their hearts ruined the reputations of the Pits by beating them and using them to fight and kill like VICK ,have caused the dogs to be banned from many towns and cities.  Shelters are the place to adopt all pets, you are saving a life and getting a wonderful companion. I hope this article plus the lovely photos by Mr. Garcia will convince people to go to their local shelters to ADOPT!!', 'Amazing talent... thank you for being a voice that so clearly illustrates this subject.  More volunteers equals a bigger network to get them placed.', 'Thank you for this article. Mr. Garcia and other brave and caring souls that work and volunteer in animal shelters are my heroes. His photographs tell a sad story that needs more attention.', 'God bless all shelter workers. I can stomach a lot, but would melt in such a place.  You have my respect', 'Thanks so much for this little article.  I hope it will inspire some to consider adopting, and others to do their animals a favor and have them spayed/neutered.', "I volunteer at our local animal shelter. It's a no-kill shelter and they work with other organizations throughout the city and the area. The animals are so sweet, especially some of the large pitbulls. It can be tough, you just want to bring them all home. Many are just lost pets with no I.D. Now the city requires all animals to have a chip, which the city will give for free. My family is severely allergic to animals, so I'm just doing what I can.", 'Heartbreaking.  I have an automatic monthly donation to the ASPCA.  I  have a dog, what more can I do?', "Thank you for giving this issue some attention. There are so many wonderful pets just waiting to be adopted from shelters. While shelter conditions aren't the best place for these animals, shelter workers and volunteers work their tail off getting these animals into homes as quickly as practicable.  While it may seem obvious that the problem shelters face is that supply of homeless pets exceeds demand, that's missing the real cause, which is: communities aren't focusing their efforts on keeping pets in their homes in the first place. If we use our resources as a safety net to keep pets in the homes they already have (think: behavior resources, help with veterinary care, removing arbitrary housing rules, repeal breed specific policies, etc.), intake would dramatically decrease and animal welfare organizations could focus on the animals that are truly homeless. It truly takes a village.", "Is this just a review of Mr. Garcia's photographic essay? If so, where is can the complete project be found? His work is haunting.", "Heidi - to see more of Mr. Garcia's work, go here:  https://www.instagram.com/marcosjaviergarcia/", 'It is on Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/stopbuyingdogs/', 'Not all shelters are as bleak as this one fortunately.  Many shelters, particularly in the north, are no-kill shelters.  Animals are kept until they are adopted.  Some that have medical or behavioral issues go to foster care before they are adopted.  Please visit the Wisconsin Humane Society - Ozaukee Campus, where I voulunteer as a dog socializer, for a much more uplifting view of an animal shelter.']
summary: The users mostly comment on the photography in the article, praising the artist's work as well as his volunteer activities. Some talk about how they also volunteer at shelters or that they wish they could, but they find it too heartbreaking to do so. Other commenters talk about shelters that aren't as bad as the one in the article, other ways they try to help shelters, and policies in shelters that they find good or bad.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Dogs; Photography; Miami (Fla); Garcia, Marcos Javier   Snippet: Unlike the cute and sweet images of dogs on social media, Marcos Javier Garcia’s photos show the lives of dogs that have been abandoned or given up to a Miami shelter where space is limited.

query: Somewhat smaller but more focused than in recent years, the 78th edition of the biennial has diversity, political conviction and many canvases.
comments: ['Nice to see the return of Larry Bell, who has been quietly and persistently pushing his work in new directions over the past 50+ years.', 'People of color, huh? Just want to let you know that my skin has color too, but is neither black nor white (since such human skin colors do not exist among humans on Earth). Did you know race is not a biological concept? Why use terms such as black and white and brown, and why refer to skin color (or other aspects of appearance) at all, when these are not germane to the subject at hand? And, think for yourself?', 'Ms. Locks, by necessity perhaps, lives in a very privileged space. Racism, inequity, and debt are very clearly not ideas (! noted.)  Sounds like she is channeling trump...when "people" keep talking.  What is clear is that Artists  have a responsibility to point out the desperate reality many of us live in which is formed by racism, inequity (did she really mean inequality?) & debt. Curators and Museums have a responsibility to acknowledge the intrinsic social value of  & necessity for artists\' resistance. .', "Artists and curators represent differing points of views, just like the public at large.  If you wish to make political art, then make that art.  Dictating what others should or should not due based on political persuasion is part of the problem of polarization right now.  Lead by example, don't dictate.  If an artist wishes to create aesthetic art or political art or both, it's their choice, and their choice alone.  They have no such responsibility any more than anyone else, and the market of ideas can sort it all out.  Your attitude is somewhat chilling.", "Don't think I'll bother", 'Typical load of bull that this has been for past 20+ years. There was a time tho when you might get a pleasant hit finding something fresh, daring mixed in with the solid proven work. Good to see Jo Baer continuing to get due recognition. I go back to the Noah Goldowsky days when she was breaking out.  Her level should be the criterion for acceptance to this show.  Enough with all these post-academic stylings designed to get a lifer teaching post. Thankfully there are still a handful of strong galleries where one can find the real work.', 'As a painter myself, I\'m glad to see canvasses. Installation art is garbage in that it\'s done by elitist artists for their elitist curators and seems something the Whitney has always fostered. It always seems to say "look how brilliant I am and you\'re not."', 'I love the Whitney Biennial. So many good memories of going with my adult son. My husband always came too, but quickly snuck out to check work emails. He encouraged us and we appreciated that. Otherwise, we would not have a passionate 23-year old curator in the family. Art enriches the soul and pushes our minds in new directions. Dare to discover!', 'Artwork has always opens itself to criticism and discussion. Let the haters do what they do which is complain without stepping up with something better.  Remember,  self-expression continues to challenge our intellect while market support increases year after year.    Looking forward to the Whitney.', "Would love to see this show but at 25$ entry fee, it's too elite for me. When will museums be truly for the 'people'. Yes, I know I can stand on line from 7-9PM to pay what one wishes.", 'I was always willing to stand on line or do what had to be done to get into museums once they started charging - but then I think theatre should also have a paradise tier where poor folks can hang (yes) out.  Maybe there are ways - still SROs?', 'So stand on line from 7-9 PM and pay a penny like I have done for years and make a fun time of it.', "Museum's are like cupboards at a stranger's house which we can wander into for a small fee. Despite the curatorial prerogative it is all so random and limiting. It's too bad museum's can't be 'disrupted' like other businesses...somebody call the nerds.", 'The right-wing of the art world--and beyond--will go ballistic with this focus on diversity and social issues, but the rest of us (or many of us) applaud the burgeoning acknowledgement that visual art is not the exclusive domain of white men.', 'Art? Enough of this nonsense. Installations, performance "art". When is someone going to really create something? Even throwing paint on a canvas akin to a first grade class is better than this. And yes, that stuff, with the right name, is worth millions. Personally I\'ll take the kids. Bye the bye, I heard a MOMAdocent say that this was an expression of "the chaos of the universe". First is was deliberate. Second the universe is not  chaotic, it is very ordered. Third, I guess you have to say something.', 'Please keep coming to the museum anyway, read the curators notes, and look at the most intriguing pieces at length. Pondering art both stirs and calms the soul.  Look at the faces around you at the Whitney. If you see mine, you will know it.', 'Meet the new boss, just like the old boss.', 'The song goes: Meet the new boss Same as the new boss.', 'Deadly dull red boxes. This is not worth looking at.', 'You may be right but have you encountered them in person?  Have you any clue regarding those two sentences you\'ve just written?  If you\'re not open to a possibility of a new, visual language (those "deadly dull red boxes") then, poor chap, that\'s the way your cookie crumbles!', '"Art is what you can get away with."- AndyWarhol.', '"Something is a work of art when it has filled its role as therapy for the artist. I don\'t care about the audience. I\'m not working for the audience. The audience is welcome to take what they can." Louise Bourgeois', 'Exactly!', 'Exactly, sir.']
summary: Several respondents express their support for the Whitney and its curators and favorite artists, and the and the focus of the exhibit on social concerns. Others were highly critical of the entrance fee and the quality of artists, and they seemed to feel that a lot of what was offered was not 'real' art. One respondent took offense at the apparent concerns about race evident in the exhibit.
short_title: Headline: The Biennial: A User’s Guide   Keywords: Art; Whitney Biennial; Whitney Museum of American Art; Lew, Christopher Y; Locks, Mia   Snippet: Somewhat smaller but more focused than in recent years, the 78th edition of the biennial has diversity, political conviction and many canvases.
subreddit: ['Art', 'Whitney Biennial', 'Whitney Museum of American Art', 'Lew, Christopher Y', 'Locks, Mia']
short_question: ['The Biennial: A User’s Guide  ']

query: There are echoes of Samuel Beckett in this short, resonant tragicomedy, written by Will Eno and featuring Michael Emerson.
comments: ['In my comment below, I meant to say "pierces the heart..."', 'You say you were bored, fell asleep or wanted to walk out on this stunning play?  You were probably experiencing your resistance -- and no one blames you.  Being brought face to face with our own impermanence is not easy.   And that\'s what this play does brilliantly. It pieces the heart, but with compassion and gratitude for the gift that is this mystery we call our "life!"', 'This is the worst play I have ever seen. The premise is interesting enough but the delivery was just terrible. The monologue was self-indulgent, full of clichés, uninteresting, not funny, and exceptionally tedious.', 'Either you "get it" or you don\'t. I "got it" I loved it...', 'Overrated author.  How can critics compare him to Beckett?', "Truly dreadful.  A series of random comments.  I divided my time between scanning the audiences' faces to see if they were suffering as much as I, and plotting ways to kill the friend who recommended this play.", "I just saw this play and I just don't get this review.   It was really awful.  Mr Emerson does a fine job with what he was given, which was not much.  I don't know what purpose Ms LaVoy served except to drag this torturous play out longer. It was 75 minutes but seemed like seeing The Iceman Cometh.  The only plus was I only wasted $75 which is better than what I would have wasted had this played on Broadway", 'People walked  out who were seated in the first row after 15 minutes. My wife and I fell asleep.', "Great performance but we both fell asleep.   Sorry, Mr. Eno,but for usthis one didn't work.", 'I haven\'t seen this play (yet). But I have to grab this space for a chance to say that next to Mr. Rylance, there is nothing Michael Emerson cannot do. He is among the greatest actors of our time; everything is does is completely infused and nuanced by his character, but invisibly so. One is never aware that "acting" is what\'s happening. It\'s amazing. I first knew this when he appeared as a psychotic killer father on Law & Order--he scared the living daylights out of me, because I thought he was really insane. REALLY INSANE. Afterward, I immediately started looking for information about who the actor was. I greatly admire this man.', 'Ben, we are so with you! Saw the play on Saturday and can\'t stop talking about it. Deep and dark are perfect descriptions; loved "supernally" for January LaVoy. One of us was in the seat that got the "menacing stare". OMG Muchael Emerson was intense and incredible. We\'re living the "second part" of our lives every day (after the screaming animals). It just spoke so loudly and clearly to the issues facing us as we age. Loved the video (reminiscent of the opening credits of Transparent), gifts and food at the end - celebrate life! For the price of one ticket to a Broadway show we can take ourselves and two guests to see theater being created! And how about the quote above Branden Jacobs-Jenkins\'s vision board: O, death, thou comest when I had thee least in mind! I\'m wearing my "This is your year" bracelet. Because, you know, it might be. Wow.', "I so enjoyed this play - but then I love anything about death and dying and contemplation of one's life. And the little party at the end was a great touch to celebrate the life  and the play", 'The brilliance of this play and performance is hard to accept if one has not spent some time contemplating death, or witnessing it.  The lack of profound statements by the playwright help us enter this strange and "peculiar" world.  The performance is magnificent, but not for the faint.', 'Is the title " Wakey , Wakey " borrowed from the movie , " Kill Bill "?', 'I am a fervent admirer of Mr. Eno and Mr. Emerson is very talented, but Wakey, Wakey is Sleepy, Sleepy. A few funny throwaway lines amid 75 minutes of liens which should have been thrown away as trite, boring and pointless. I was stunned and disappointed that a play by Mr. Eno could be so utterly lacking in insight, interest and humor.', 'Boring beyond death! ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ', "Saw the play a week ago and felt that  the message started falling apart for me about 20 minutes in. After I saw/heard the animal scream video-- which is a very dated  video from a decode ago-- I really didn't know what message was being sent.  I struggled to make it to the end.", '@JM.  "The play Everybody, also currently being performed at Signature, offers a much more lively and incisive perspective on human mortality."  Hmmm.  I agree that Everybody is a joy to watch but "incisive perspective on human mortality"?? --  did you really find it all that meaningful?  To me, Everybody had lots of bells and whistles but Wakey Wakey is far more substantial as a reflection on the human condition.  And, it\'s still a lively (and ultimately joyful) theater going experience.', 'Maybe it will spur us on to deal with death in a dignified way, including the right to end our own lives when we see fit.  When we fight for choice in this country, I always ask for what and for whom.', '"...in the midst of life, we are in death, it is also true here (to borrow from James Joyce) that in the midst of death, we are in life." Why, the play reaches out from the very page to remind us that, right here, right now, someone is reading this review along with us and about to die. That\'s life!']
summary: The commenters have wildly different opinions about this play. Most of the users say they didn't like it, using words and phrases like torturous, self-indulgent, dreadful, and exceptionally tedious. Two users describe falling asleep during it. Others call it brilliant and "deep and dark." Several users comment that the play isn't for everyone, with one saying some people will get it and some people won't. A few also have theories about why people don't like, including one person saying it's resistance to thinking about "our own impermanence."
short_title: Headline: Life and Death Get Him Talking   Keywords: Theater; Wakey, Wakey (Play); Eno, Will; Emerson, Michael (1954- ); Signature Theater Co   Snippet: There are echoes of Samuel Beckett in this short, resonant tragicomedy, written by Will Eno and featuring Michael Emerson.
short_question: ['Life and Death Get Him Talking  ']

query: The four Ntongas have shown a remarkable aptitude for tennis after stumbling upon the Leeds Center and New York Junior Tennis and Learning.
comments: ['That\'s a great program.  I\'m glad those children are taking advantage of the opportunity.  The best part is they focus not just on tennis but also being well rounded academically and health wise.  To me the Cary Leeds center shows why the Kingsbridge Ice Center will be good.  Just like with tennis - some will say "oh but minorities don\'t play" (tennis nor ice sports).  Well duh - it\'s because the opportunity has been lacking.  Both projects are good for the kids of The Bronx.', 'Lady in the harbor is smiling.', 'This is a great reminder of how sports brings us together, and reminds me of the work done by two American students--Marco Sandusky and Meryl Guyer--when they were studying abroad (and I was the director of their program) in Angers, France. They created a free tennis workshop for local kids. Pure joy ensued!', 'Super heartwarming story.  Yea to the Ntonga family.  Yea to the Cary Leeds Center and Billy Jean King.  Yea to America.  We are so fortunate to have you all.', 'What a lovely story! Wishing these kids the very best and looking forward to some future champs emerging from this program.']
summary: The commenters love the story, describing it as heartwarming and inspiring. One commenter applauds the tennis program for allowing students to become well-rounded both academically and in health, while another is appreciative of how it brings students together.
short_title: Headline: New Interest in a New Land   Keywords: Tennis; Cameroon; New York Junior Tennis League; Bronx (NYC)   Snippet: The four Ntongas have shown a remarkable aptitude for tennis after stumbling upon the Leeds Center and New York Junior Tennis and Learning.
short_question: ['New Interest in a New Land  ']

query: It’s no surprise that adolescents find handy, if sometimes quirky, ways to reset when they are feeling overwhelmed.
comments: ['"But what about when teenagers face stressors that defy straightforward solutions, such as unrelenting school or social pressures?" What if the stresses come from the parents themselves? Not all parents want to understand their children or take the children\'s concerns seriously. As for parents\' choosing the children\'s coping mechanisms, rather than letting them choose a non-destructive coping mechanism for themselves, that\'s a recipe for more stress.', 'My 17 year old has been listening to Disney soundtracks and singing at the top of her lungs.  It makes me smile.', "This is the best insight into teens I've read in a very long time. Fits my HS freshman and senior to a tee. And, to be honest, me. We watch/read Harry Potter over and over and over.", "Teenagers: a made-up category. The realty is that we are first children and then adults. Teenagers are just people that parents, schools and the workforce are not allowing to be grownups. And then 'riff off of', as in this article. It's a cottage industry. This infantilization of the 2nd decade of life ensued because education prolonged dependency beyond puberty. But now there should be a social category, the 'young adult' for age 14 and over. Their responsibiities should include academic performance, and real work not to exceed 15 hours a week or three sessions. Their rights include having their own time & space with no interference after meeting their responsibilities. Some youngsters might continue to behave like overgrown children and make growing up ambivalent & neurotic, but most will reach for the status of young adulthood with pleasure; energized. And recognized. Society has no greater imbalance than insisting that people remain children for nearly a decade after puberty. It goes against nature and has affected and infected society for 4 generations. Enough! Let us grow up about children growing up. Finally, the issue with education, its intractability to real improvement, also stems from having misconceived growing up. For the educational system needs to mirror growing up, if it is to work. Late middle school and high school are such a mess because pupils are placed in the impossible situation of having to behave like children when they are really young adults.", 'You have some good points.  However, I think you would benefit from reading up on the research into adolescent brain development that has emerged over the past decade.  There are distinct differences between teenagers and adults.   So while I think that middle and high schools might do a better job in some areas, It is my opinion that as parents and as educators, we do not make a big enough distinction between teenagers and adults.  Teenagers might benefit from more freedom, but they still require an enormous amount of guidance.  As a school counselor, I believe one of the biggest mistakes parents can make is thinking that their job is "done" once their child starts looking like an adult.', "I think your point is valid. But note that I propose a different category from 'adult', that is, 'young adult'; and certainly there shoudl be evidenced-based consideration of what the age group needs and can handle. Also, guidance is fine as long as there is not an in-built bias toward retarding growth, as so often happens. Sexual energy, in particular, comes to the individual gradually and should be channelled gradually into love and also into converting into something that we call, for want of a better word, 'spiritual energy'. The techniques were known in India and China and have been pretty much lost or distorted. What should not happpen with sexuality is degradation in the midst of repression, and then violent release. This is becoming commonplace and embodies the downward spiral of civilization just now. FInally, I believe freedom comes after basic obligatons have been met, not instead of obligations. My basic viewpoint is that society cannot afford the waste of not converting children into adults efficiently. Successful civilizations and tribes have always done this, and it is a pivotal achievement.", 'As a latch key kid I can give a heavy vote for Three Stooges, which I watched on WGN every afternoon. Other than the Marx Brothers, nothing has come close to solving those adolescent migivings, or prepared me better for life.', 'My dad would have oldies radio playing in the car when I was a girl growing up. When I became a teen I discovered his crate of albums - Motown and The Beach Boys was my soothing soundtrack.', "Who are these parents who are surprised that their teens turn to younger pleasures to relax?  Why is anyone surprised?  This is a very common pattern for many people. I still love to re read the books I devoured in my adolescence, children's adventure stories,  or classics like Jane Eyre, or traditional Indian stories. And I am in my 50s. Just like people like to listen again and again to a favorite piece of music, you get the same pleasure from re reading a favorite book. Same for a movie or TV show I guess, for the wired generation (though the neural connections for reading are much richer than for the passive pleasures of media consumption).", "I'm a 33 year old, Ivy League educated surgeon, but I still de-stress with cartoons and comic books. The older I get, the less apologetic I am about my love of cartoons. It isn't about nostalgia for me, because I didn't watch cartoons or read comics as a kid, it's about escape and replay value. Cartoons are far enough away from my life to completely disconnect me from what I'm watching, and they have a high replay value by design. Unlike the shows of my childhood, they are well made too (both Avatar series, Rick & Morty, etc).", 'The movie Spring Breakers depicts this when they take a break from drinking, drugs etc to watch My Little Pony', "Destress...hah. It's called having fun.", 'Winnie the Pooh is the most comforting movie for my college-age kid. My high schooler tends to decompress watching Lilo and Stitch. They laugh at their love for these movies, but keep watching them over and over again.  Great stress relief coming from their early childhood days.', 'I\'ve become addicted to reruns of "Full House" from 10-11 every night since the Republican Convention.  Escape much before sleeping?', 'Teenagers, everyone, wants to hold on to something whose properties remain stable and independent of process.', "Really interesting, I wondered why my 15 year old and her friends had started rewatching High School Musical films when they hang out, which they haven't looked at since they were about 10/11! I did ask my daughter and she just said the songs made her feel happy!", "I like to decompress with Disney movies and stupid shows too, and I'm in my 30s! These strategies help and are used by adults, too, not just adolescents. Which can help the adolescents even more - seeing that they're not the only ones with problems, that stress is part of everybody's life and that we all have our ways to deal with it. They can borrow from their parents' strategies or be inspired to try their own. Or if parent and teen find they share the same strategy, they can do it together and add some quality time together as a bonus! My kids are still too young for that, but I can totally see us laughing over stupid cat videos together when the pressure gets too high."]
summary: Many commenters support this coping mechanism, at least in a general sense, for themselves or their children and speak about resorting to childhood pleasures when stressed. One commenter expresses doubt that such 'straightforward' solutions are capable of alleviating all types of stress. Then there is a comment chain, where one commenter feels that 'teenage' is an artificial designation and another commenter rebuts this, citing psychological studies. The original poster concedes that there is truth in that but feels that teenagehood is more like a pre-extension of adulthood, rather than its own category and that teenagers are more adult than they are usually allowed to be.
short_title: Headline: When a Teenager’s Coping Mechanism Is SpongeBob   Keywords: Teenagers and Adolescence; Children and Childhood; SpongeBob SquarePants (Cartoon Character); Anxiety and Stress; Parenting   Snippet: It’s no surprise that adolescents find handy, if sometimes quirky, ways to reset when they are feeling overwhelmed.

short_question: ['When a Teenager’s Coping Mechanism Is SpongeBob  ']

query: The Times placed several of the poet’s works on Page 1 during World War I, including the haunting “My Boy Jack.”
comments: ['Kipling\'s novel "Kim" should absolve him of "the white man\'s burden."', 'Let us not forget Rudyard Kipling\'s earlier poem "The White Man\'s Burden: The United States and the Philippine Islands" (1899) in which he urged America to fully assume colonial control of that land after defeating then-ruler Spain in the Spanish-American War.  It begins: "Take up the White Man\'s burden,/ Send forth the best ye breed/  Go bind your sons to exile,/ to serve your captives\' need;/ To wait in heavy harness,/ On fluttered folk and wild—/ Your new-caught, sullen peoples,/ Half-devil and half-child" ... And later in the verses, Kipling famously entreats America not to "call too loud on Freedom To cloak your weariness ..." Colonialism and imperialism as the noblesse oblige of the white race? Not surprisingly, Kipling\'s poem and its dreadful sentiments were soundly criticized in their time. Political cartoonist William H. Walker drew an especially sharp satire for Life magazine showing huge Uncle Sam, John Bull and Kaiser figures being carried by struggling blacks, with the subtitle "The White (?) Man\'s Burden."', 'Anything by Kipling. I love his poems and still read Just So Stories.', 'what we still have and are some thought it all in the past that epic battle of civilizations anyone you might stop to ask modern in our civilized nations we treat everyone with equality no discrimination racial shame that is our one defining quality what if some don’t do the same what if old religions still conspire to dominate where freedom lives use the torturous sword terror fire where a good person still forgives political refugee before it’s too late your country where honesty thrives to emigrate infiltrate not assimilate from their failed societies bitter lives whose land despoiled beyond repair breeds uncontrolled victims of nature those with cultures surviving to share can only help those creating a future with the hand of friendship extended decency offers the gift of democracy but wherever the deceit never ended forgive cut them loose if ungracefully', 'Kipling\'s "Epitaphs of the War" are also worth reading. They\'re very brief, and the best of them are written with a powerful blend of clarity, bitterness and compassion. Some examples:  COMMON FORM If any question why we died, Tell them, because our fathers lied. THE BEGINNER On the first hour of my first day     In the front trench I fell. (Children in boxes at a play     Stand up to watch it well.) THE COWARD I could not look on Death, which being known, Men led me to him, blindfold and alone. The last one is engraved on a Belgian memorial for WWI soldiers shot for cowardice. And then there is the epitaph "A Dead Statesman," which I have treasured up in my mind for the day when it will be appropriate to apply it to George W. Bush. I could not dig: I dared not rob: Therefore I lied to please the mob. Now all my lies are proved untrue And I must face the men I slew. What tale shall serve me here among Mine angry and defrauded young?', 'There is another epitaph he wrote after the war. If anyone questions why we died, Tell him, because our fathers lied.', 'He\'s much better than a "blustery champion" - a very fine, and very accessible, poet and novelist.', 'Two points:  First I hazard a guess that the modernists (for example, Eliot dismissing Kipling as a "writer of verse" were actually more offended by the emotions and sentiments Kipling he portrayed than the forms he employed. Kipling was above all sentimental; and this is an area of feeling that was pronounced taboo by modernist and post modernist alike.  It is ironic that what was ostensibly a voice for freedom demanded an inhibition of part of the human spectrum as the Victorians did for sexuality. Chacun son prohibition.  Moderns are actually a quite emotionally inhibited lot.     Second, in much of Kipling\'s poetry -and prose too - there is a powerful subversion of the manifest jingoism and racism.  Think Gunga Din and East and West.  As in many works, the Kipling of racism and jingoism actually  shows the oriental to be the superior person.']
summary: Several commenters love Kipling's poetry and find his work accessible and sentimental. Many commenters cited their favorite works of his, including his "Epitaphs of the War." One commenter cited the controversy of his poem "The White Man's Burden," while another mentioned that his novel "Kim" should absolve him of that.
short_title: Headline: Rudyard Kipling on the Front Page: Battle Cries and an Elegy   Keywords: Poetry and Poets; World War I (1914-18); New York Times; Kipling, Rudyard   Snippet: The Times placed several of the poet’s works on Page 1 during World War I, including the haunting “My Boy Jack.”

query: Cetys University is making an ambitious bid to become the first Mexican member of the N.C.A.A.
comments: ['"Two hours east of Tijuana" are you kidding me, yeah it is in Mexicali.  Good for them, I hope they do kick butt in soccer, and baseball.', 'Why are California taxpayers paying for two Mexican nationals to attend high school in California.', 'That Tec de Monterrey, which even its permissiveness is arguably the best university in Latin America, could not compete in a North American college sports league and a university that most likely has non existing academic filters (such as Cetys) is better positioned to do so now is regretful -- Great way to foster the stereotype of the undereducated Mexican.', 'Great read, thank you for reporting this. One of many cases of cross-border life in the San Diego-Tijuana hub.', 'As a Big Ten graduate, I would be very happy with this.', 'We know which university is going to win the soccer championship....', 'WONDERFUL! MARAVILLOSO! GREAT FOR SPORTS ON BOTH SIDES OF THE BORDER']
summary: Some of the commenters seem to suggest that this is going to be great for spots on both sides of the border. Overall it seems like the commenters seem to be very excited about this article, which is saying that Cetys University is making an ambitious bid to become the first Mexican team to join the N.C.A.A. One commenter is wondering why California taxpayers would be paying for these players who don't live in America.

query: At a small restaurant in East Williamsburg, the usual Middle Eastern dishes turn intense: brighter, earthier, smokier, creamier.
comments: ['On my way there to CHECK IT OUT!!!', "Being born and raised in Beirut, I can more than attest to the incredibly florid ways of my people in describing just about anything from the sunlight streaming through our beloved Cedars to the way garbage piquantly lays there rotting to our more or less inept government and Ligaya's prose would make anyone in our small but literary nation proud!   BTW, you can easily get the incredible smokiness in eggplants by slicing it in half, putting the halves cut side down on a cookie tray lined with aluminum foil and roasting at 400 degrees for an hour.  No more burning fingers over the stove and setting off smoke detectors.  Just sayin'", '"Gulps of bronzed air"? The food sounds great, but this writer is ridiculous.', "Wafa makes Lebanese food like my grandmother used to make. When she announced they were moving to California, I was happy for them but sad to miss the food. A few months ago, my wife said she wanted Middle Eastern food for lunch and we reminisced about Wafa's. Then a short search said they had re opened and were closer to home! We went, they remembered us and lunch was glorious! I've been back several times since. The last time, we brought friends, one of whom is also part Lebanese, they loved it too. Go eat there!!", 'I don\'t know. Ligaya\'s writing is LOVELY. But like a masochist who can\'t get the message, I\'ve gone to 8 of her recs over the years, and if I were a soccer team, I\'d be 1-3-4. BK Jani was as good as she promised. Haldi was less than the sum of its parts (or its bill), but okay. Taste of Samarkand was an oily, gristly embarrassment, especially when there\'s a place like Cafe Nargis (Sheepshead Bay). Safari in Harlem was almost as bad -- the food was dry,  the drinks so bad. Kopitiam was okay, but a little funny to highlight when there\'s Nyonya, perhaps known but still good enough to mainline, five minutes away. The Mimi\'s Hummus East Village outpost is weaker and more perfunctory with each visit. Tone, the Georgian place on E. 17th, was flavorless and soupy. Which brings me to Wafa, where after a multi-month vow of "Hungry City" chastity, I couldn\'t help going last night. And it was all right: The makdous, for all its intensiveness, was fairly ordinary; the babaghanoush solid; but the mujadara no more distinctive than anywhere (I\'m thinking fondly of the upstairs cafe at Kalustyan\'s). And the braised-lamb special we were persuaded to get, at $16.95, was over-charred and just made you daydream of the fall-apartness of the lamb at Cafe Yemen on Atlantic. Only the kenafeh was genuinely monumental. The ironic liability of Ligaya\'s glorious, over-superlativized prose is you forget that, like so many ethnic joints in the city, these places will likely be inconsistent at best.', "I'm with you. For me, Ligaya Mishan is too self conscious a writer to be believable as a food critic. A gulp of bronzed air? Please. I like good food and spare prose. A little more editing please, and a side of  eggplant.", 'Lovely writing, as usual, and effective!', 'love the way she writes "gulps of bronzed air", " a dish that lets you know how it was made" "rose water like a balm thumbed behind my ears"  and on and on. poetry in review. lovely.', 'Bloody hell. Why do half these reviews have NO connection to websites or menus?', 'When I saw the title of this article, I already knew Wafa is great! I miss her food. Yes, I live in Forest Hills where she used to have her restaurant.', 'Sounds like a great place to go. It would be really helpful if you would list the nearest subway and bus stops with the info for your "unsung" restaurants. It would also be nice if you visit the UWS, we have lots of great little neighborhood restaurants that never get noticed by the critics.', 'See that map at the bottom of the review? It shows the nearest subway stop.  You can even go to Google, put the address in, and get directions for both subways and buses. Hint: you can do this for any restaurant or other establishment of interest too!', 'Nor in New York Magazine :(', 'Therese, I also live on the UWS and I would love to know about these great little neighborhood restaurants you mention.  Perhaps it is because I live in "Lincoln Square" but I see mostly overpriced, touristy restaurants.  I would be grateful for a list of your favorites.', "I am in California but I read Ms. Mishan's reviews because her writing is as satisfying as the meals she describes. Such a pleasure to see such talent. Thanks!", 'Such good food, and so poetically described!', 'After the third paragraph I wanted to jump into the next plane heading for NY. I spent my youth in Beirut and that is how I remember the food.', "This place is really wonderful - so nice to see it recognized by the NY Times. Wafa's Express is a real gem and I'm thrilled that they set up shop on Grand Street - the neighborhood got lucky when they arrived.", "Mouthwatering. Not just the Chef Wafa's specialties but Ligaya Mashan's vivid description of them. More please."]
summary: Some commentators praise the writer, saying that the way she describes food is poetic. Other commentators criticize the text because they don't like the way it describes food. Some comments say that they went to the restaurants indicated by her and that they do not offer good food, while other comments say that the restaurants indicated by the writer really serve great food, as she indicated in her texts.
short_title: Headline: The Smoky Allure of Wafa’s Express   Keywords: Restaurants; Wafa's Express (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant); Williamsburg (Brooklyn, NY)   Snippet: At a small restaurant in East Williamsburg, the usual Middle Eastern dishes turn intense: brighter, earthier, smokier, creamier.
short_question: ['The Smoky Allure of Wafa’s Express  ']

query: Friday: Angling season in New York, weekend events and a milestone at the Temple of Dendur.
comments: ['BAR TATTOOS Bar codes are a business boon Marking prices throughout the land, Saving time that used to go To stamping cans and boxes by hand. Now the bar code’s crossing over And becoming a tattoo device, Solid proof if any’s needed, Every man has his price.', 'I doubt very much anyone will see a sea otter in New York Harbor, as they are only found in the North Pacific.  You might see a river otter, which are occasionally found in brackish water.', "I agree with several commenters that catch-and-release is a practice that should be --let's say, released. Almost as bad as keeping birds in cages as pets!! I would also comment that I see gazillions of drivers using a hand held phone as I wait for the bus or to cross a street. PREVENTIVE law enforcement would put a stop to this practice--long before, unfortunately, a fancy device is called into action to look into the content on a driver's phone after a devastating accident.", "Let's leave the fish alone.", 'Nice to know the stripped bass are back, and one can even eat them! -- for years the waters were so polluted they were deemed inedible. Also. Thanks for the nod to "Dock of the Bay"... And for those who don\'t know the great Otis Redding version, you\'ve got a treat in store for you!', "Is it really necessary to torture fish that aren't even going to be eaten, for the sake of a selfie?", "I don't want to be overly sentimental, but the same thought occurred to me. Doesn't removing the hook hurt their mouths?", 'Catch and release is a disgusting practice that is cruel and should be outlawed.', '"Property records show that Mr. Ponte, 70, whose city salary in 2016 was nearly $220,000, and his wife sold their home in Wiscasset, Me., in March." Mr. Ponte, whose absence from his job in Corrections has finally been called out, may yet regret leaving Wiscasset, billed as "the prettiest town in Maine," although with the fairly hefty salary he earns here and the sale of his home, he\'ll do very well. If he keeps his position. (By the way, Wiscasset, unlike its near neighbors, voted for Trump. That does somewhat tarnish the "prettiest" label.)', 'Great column today, and I loved this fascinating link in the “In the News” section:  “The luxurious bathrooms at Bryant Park reopened.” Imagining tourists raving about New York for the luxurious bathrooms.  :) Tune of “Autumn in New York” Bathrooms in New York They’re filled with music and flowers Bathrooms in New York You could just sit there for hours In Bryant Park From morning to dark They wait there for you There’s not much to do Who cares? ‘Cause bathrooms in New York You can’t just call it a restroom Bathrooms in New York It’s much more like an event Tourists with lots of dough May opt for a Broadway show But bathrooms in New York I’m oh so happy I went.', "I recommend you almost every day, Freddie, but the last line of this song?  A bit much.  I'd been hoping for something about the sparkling fish.  Still I thank you, as always.", "Hi Martha, sorry about that in that last line! I’d done my take on varieties of fish before, so didn’t want to repeat, but here it is (since you asked, LOL)  FISH!  (to the tune of Zip) Fish!  The sashimi isn't brilliant today Fish!  Does McDonald's have to fry that filet? Fish!  I was eating Arthur Treacher's last night Fish!  And I think that Arthur Treacher's not right I'd prefer a lunch at Esca Crab and tuna with a Fresca Fish!  That sounds so appealing! Rods and hooks in ocean breezes In the spring where no one freezes Fish!  That could set me reeling Fish!  They say April, May and June is the time Fish!  When the angl-ing is prime. Fish!  Cappellini with raw salmon is fab Fish!  Sturgeon goes real well with almondined crab Fish!  The bodega sells their skate a la carte Fish!  Those omega oils are great for the heart I don't want a Nathan's weenie Get beluga on a blini Fish!  I’d be so ecstatic I don't need to call a pal up Just get me a giant scallop Fish!  I’m so damn aquatic Fish!  I like any seafood, raw or well-cooked Fish!  You might say that I am hooked!", 'Bravo!', 'Braves raze Mets', "Check out Elias Vaisberg's YouTube channel to get a taste of the saltwater fishing opportunities in NYC.  He is a wonderful fisherman and commentator. https://m.youtube.com/user/eliasvaisberg87"]
summary: Some commenters respond to the article's content discussing catch-and-release practices, the unlikelihood of seeing an otter in the New York Harbor, or the excitement they feel about being able to catch and eat striped bass if they'd like. Some commenters disagree if fish should be caught in the first place if only to release them. Others complain about other people who break laws or act untoward.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: New York City; Fishing, Sport   Snippet: Friday: Angling season in New York, weekend events and a milestone at the Temple of Dendur.

query: Wednesday: Tracing tattoo history, tap dancing through Midtown and commemorating women’s suffrage.
comments: ["I've always wondered what it is about tattoos that makes those who dislike them think that they can dictate to everyone else how to treat their own bodies.", 'In the past, I got tatooed by both Mike and Mehai Bakety. Both of them were and are world class Tatoo artists. Also, their shop was like a Misfit Tattoo drop in center in the East Village for years and working or taking a break in front of the shop one could always find a friendly conversation going on about every topic under the sun and I could never pass the shop without a friendly hello from them or their friends and customers. Thanks to the NY Times for this story it really brought back memories of the Good Old Daze before I was gentrified out of the neighborhood.', 'I wonder if anybody ever gets a flesh colored invisible tattoo.', 'As a friend (a college professor) tells his students: " Don\'t smoke; write thank you notes; and don\'t get anymore tattoos.  (note "don\'t get any more tattoos" - as you can see, he is a realist)', '"Tattoo" by The Who should be required listening before getting in the chair.', "When I was a kid, the people I knew with tattoos were former sailors whose breath smelled sour from alcohol. I've never been able to drop the tawdry association. Some contemporary tattoo recipients have no taste. I do like sleeves, but it won't be possible to iron out the wrinkles when they appear.  If you must get a tattoo: --Avoid areas that can't be covered; --No SO names, ink is more lasting than love; --No foreign phrases you don't understand.", 'Re: The MTA finally coming to their collective senses and ending their ludicrous "experiment" to see what would happen if they removed trash cans from stations: It\'s about time.', "sorry, i hate tattoos and have never seen one that I like. That's just me. I prefer nice skin. It's gorgeous if you let it be.  That's me talking: a little bolder, a little less subtle.", "Tattoos desecrate the natural beauty of our skin, especially if done poorly.  I think they can very rarely be beautiful on fair-skinned attractive young people, if the artist and design are good.  I would never get one because I know I would eventually regret it, no matter how good it was, and I'm not young & attractive :) I sometimes see them on Black people and wonder what they are thinking? They usually look green no matter what color it's supposed to be, and are hard to see. What's really sad is a beautiful girl -- (or guy I suppose) with a messed-up / poor quality tattoo, or anyone who has tried to remove their regretted tattoo.", 'BAR TATTOOS Bar codes are a business boon Marking prices throughout the land, Saving time that used to go To stamping cans and boxes by hand. Now the bar code’s crossing over And becoming a tattoo device, Solid proof if any’s needed, Every man has his price.', "Noise from airplanes flying into La Guardia, noise from buses and cars, and noise from subways (sometimes rumbling right under people's living rooms) -- that's just the sounds of New York City. It's to be expected. It is white noise in of itself. What's riling is the incessant honking of car horns, the sonic blasts of car stereos, the inane, oblivious ranting of someone on his cell phone as he paces back and forth, back and forth. Sometimes screaming at his girlfriend. The raucous, too-often menacing shouts of a a gang just getting warmed up.   That sort of stupid, easily controlled but uncontrollable noise is man-made. It's part of a breakdown of civilized behavior. That's the noise that's worrying. Planes flying over Windsor Terrace? Buses rumbling down Ocean Avenue? The Q-train clonking near Avenue H, or the tracks getting repaired at 2AM, night after night? Perfectly fine. Those are the sounds of people at work.", 'Jets land Devils', "Mike Bakaty did a brilliant full-back tattoo on my brother, back on the Bowery, in the same building Kate Millet lived in. Now they've both passed on, their tattoos turned to ash and dust. Is there some deeper meaning there?  I have no idea. I do know that when I finally decide what sort of tattoo I want, I'll go to Mehai's place. I haven't made that decision in the last half century - maybe I will in the next fifty years...", 'Curiously late for the Times.  Ink is fine although I recommend against the face or neck. Never really felt the inspiration.', "Wow, the 100th anniversary of female suffrage? That is a big deal. I'm surprised that it has not received more ink. Too bad that a majority of white females nationally voted for Trump----that kinda puts a dark cloud over it, but what can you do. People should take a ride upstate to Seneca Falls. A couple of years ago I went for a different reason. A warehouse (Mackenzie something) has an annual sale. But while there I discovered the rich history pt the suffrage movement, and enjoyed the town and museums. It is close by and def worth visiting.", 'Unfortunately, a much larger proportion of white MALE voters voted for Trump.  That is an even darker cloud.', '"How tattoo ink got under New York\'s skin" - after that great City Center show last weekend, can\'t resist such a fine Cole Porter reference.   Tune of I\'ve Got You Under My Skin You got him there on your skin You\'ve got him, he puts fine art in it He does it with heart when he does his fine part in it You\'ve got him there on your skin You went there, heard he is "in" You said to yourself New Yorkers really are bold as hell They show their tattoos even when it\'s cold as hell So you\'ve got him, there on your skin You\'ll get quotes from some of your favorite prose Or a symbol of N-Y-C Maybe your spouse\'s name or a bright red rose Or a nice green Miss Liberty But beware, tattooed friend, don\'t try underground This master has history Trust you won\'t get blistery Go to First and First, for a colorful burst That looks great, and so it\'s win-win When you\'ve got his work on your skin.', 'another great tune from Freddie! I\'m surprised the Times did not mention a new exhibit at the South Street Seaport Museum: "The Original Gus Warner. The Maritime Roots of Modern Tattoo" https://southstreetseaportmuseum.org/gus-wagner/ “There is something about tattooing I cannot explain; I find it fascinating & useful in traveling. Every symbol & design has meaning. These on my body are mementos featuring incidents of my life & travels. In every country where tattooing is practiced a tattooed person who is able to tattoo needs further introduction to the natives, be they civilized or uncivilized, or even barbaric and cannibalistic.” - GUS WAGNER "The Original Gus Wagner: The Maritime Roots of Modern Tattoo explores Augustus “Gus” Wagner’s (American, 1872-1941) early life as a merchant seaman & tattoo artist who traveled the world from 1898-1902, & his return to the United States as a professional tattooist & tattooed man." This beautiful exhibit is on view until June 4.  And, because the Times featured a shop:  Daredevil Tattoo has a museum "The collection features artifacts from the early roots of modern tattooing with original artwork, antique tattoo machines, original photos, news articles & sideshow banners. The shop is located in the historic Lower East Side just a few blocks where legendary tattoo artists plied their trade. The museum is part of the tattoo shop; there is no admission fee." http://www.daredeviltattoo.com/museum/', 'I kind of respect the guts it takes to permanently brand your body with a tattoo but I have never seen an aged person with a tattoo that still looks good. Skin says, tattoo sags...      For goodness sake, get some colorful clothes and leave that body alone!', "Are you living in Logan's Run? Who cares if the tattoo looks less than perfect as a person ages--as long as the person who chose to put it on their body is happy, it's nobody's business. If a less than perfect tattoo is all that I'm worrying about as I age, I'll consider myself very, very lucky.", "Clearly, you haven't read the articles on the cost and difficulty of tattoo removal. Buyer's Remorse is real for some tattooed people.  As for judgment, anything you voluntarily do to yourself that other people can observe can and will be judged by someone. That's the price of leaving your house."]
summary: Several commentators remark about tattoo hate of some kind, such as not looking good on older people or preferring bare skin instead. A few commentators share stories about getting tattoos. Two commentators share tattoo-related song lyrics. The rest of the comments are unrelated to tattoos, such as annoying honking in the city, women's suffrage, trash can experiment, and a random sports comment.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Much Ado About Tattoos   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Wednesday: Tracing tattoo history, tap dancing through Midtown and commemorating women’s suffrage.
short_question: ['New York Today: Much Ado About Tattoos  ']

query: Michelle Goldberg reviews McGowan’s memoir, a cautionary tale about the entertainment industry by the actress who accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual assault last fall.
comments: ["By being 'one of the first women to publicly accuse Harvey Weinstein of sexual assault', Ms. McGowan is a whistleblower on Hollywood, good for her.  If only the Hollywood legends such as Meryl Streep, who undeservedly are being fawned over with #MeToo, had been so brave,  Streep is an outspoken moralizer yet is a total hypocrite who 1. gave confirmed child rapist Roman Polanski a standing ovation at the 2003 Oscars and 2. worked with and made tons of money from the monster Weinstein for years, and irreverently and offensively referred to him as God, even though his abominable reputation was an open secret in all of Hollywood. One would think that the complicity and enabling and support of these deplorable men would result in humility and self-reflection, but one would be sadly mistaken. Streep has not apologized at all for this unconscionable support and endorsement, but instead has doubled down and deflects by attacking those with whom she disagrees politically. It is refreshing that Ms McGowan has exposed Hollywood for what it is, and people's eyes have become open, that Hollywood is worse than a cult, and that very few Hollywood actors/actresses deserve the podium that they all are still standing on.", "I don't know if your book is well-written or not, and I don't really care. You found the courage and the voice to start a landslide, one that would end up taking down an army of smug, protected creeps who thought they'd never have to face the music. Thank you for being brave.", 'The Affleck men need to be driven from Hollywood and never work again.Casey Affleck is a predator and Ben Affleck is a weak man with no integrity. Rose McGown is incredibly brave. Thank you, Rose.', 'The thing that\'s really confusing about all of this is that Rose McGowan was known for displaying her body both on-screen and off.  She was, to put it simply, a sex symbol.  So....why did she do that?  Not that in any way she "deserved" to be assaulted -- no one does.  But why make a career of displaying your body when it would seem that that is part and parcel of the culture she despises?', "I really like her and I want her to stay strong, keep her Rose Army movement going. She's very inspiring. The only problem I have in reading this and I guess I'll have to buy the book is that it would appear she didn't say no to Weinstein? Why not? Why can women not say no? And then coupled that with feigned pleasure? I understand she's telling the truth and she should not be derailed or demoralized for that but I also think women need to say no. If your career matters more than saying no, I think maybe that's on you because you aren't serving other women by playing along. Otherwise, it sounds like a great book. I think I'll buy it.", 'Rose McGowan -  hero.', 'What an expert cashing in of victimhood, the American way. She also has a tie-in  reality series on E. For her cash seems to be the revenge. Had she forgone the cash in 1997, may be 20 years worth of sexual attacks by Weinstein could have been stopped.', 'Oh, also a way for some celebrity. A cheap one though, and not particularly intelligent. Any other way of earning the living, lady?', 'Only of the many women the rapacious Mr Weinstein left in his wake. No one should have that kind of power.', "https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/28/business/metoo-finance-lawsuits-haras... There's always a buck to make in America for someone else's misery. We are so exceptional.", 'Yes, Rose McGowan does come across as a bit "unhinged". As I think I would be if I had endured all that she has. She has done a great service to the world - I only wish she had been believed earlier.', 'Sorry, "brave" women do not accept hush money, only to tweet about their abuses 20 years later.  Think about the women who might have been spared these abuses had she *actually* been brave and reported him to the police that very night.', 'No woman (or man) should ever be subjected to the abuse Harvey foisted on her. One hopes that he will die in prison for the crimes he has committed. But, yes, it is a bit much to read how she "suffered" by having to work on a less than intellectually-stimulating hit TV series which I assume was very lucrative. Plenty of people cleaning apartments and working in fast food would love to suffer similarly.  Ms. McGowan could be a potent advocate for women and men everywhere. She must not allow herself to be distracted by the trivial which will only diminish her efficacy.', 'I liked the article and also really like the writer.  I believe she was on Bill Maher the other night and she as the best panelist I’ve heard.  Particularly discussing Israel and Jerusalem with .  Love it when she told him to go see it for himself!  I’d like to tell her how much I learned and enjoyed that exchange.  NY Times,  you have the best staff.  Bravo!', 'I\'m appalled by Rose McGowan\'s story and I\'m glad that she\'s found her voice. Speaking the truth as she knows it is her right and I don\'t object to it. I find it very cruel and hypocritical of the Time\'s Up movement that they do not acknowledge her.  However I find statements like the following: “Your entertainment comes at a cost to us performers...You should know this and acknowledge.” to be misguided and ridiculous. No one forced McGowan into show business- she stayed because she wanted to stay. At any point in her journey, she could very well have simply said, "I\'m out" and gone off to some other job elsewhere. If she felt "robbed" that she had to get married on television before her real wedding, then she just doesn\'t understand that as an actress, she gets to pretend for a living and that\'s the extent of it. The marriage episode on "Charmed" can hardly be equated to what happened to Maria Schneider on the set of "Last Tango in Paris". My take-away from this article (and let me be clear- this is placing the Weinstein-matter firmly to the side to consider the rest of the piece) is McGowan\'s overwhelming bitterness at the superficiality of her career. What happened to her is monstrous. But her decision to stay put and plug away in Hollywood is a choice too and that\'s a fact.', "Having worked in the entertainment industry, the amount of misogyny and sexual harassment is overwhelming.  It is ludicrous to avoid this reality or to attempt to deny it. Rose McGowen is a hero for standing up for herself and telling the truth and for having the courage to deal with the onslaught of hatred flung her way in defense of the indefensible.  While it isn't easy to deal with the almost daily revelations regarding the sexual misconduct of certain celebrities, it is the unknown, less cared about women in the trenches with whom I am most concerned. It is our duty to ensure our daughters, and their daughters, have a life free from the strife of sexual harassment or misconduct, rape, or abuse, and that we provide a climate of trust, equality and fairness.  Neither sex has a right to sexual gratification from an unwilling, or coerced partner or participant.", 'I read stories like this and feel a level of anger that is surely unhealthy.  More than anything else, I want to do something.  How do we stop this predation?  My best thought is (non-monstrous) men and women working together to identify these monsters; women pointing the men towards the monsters, who are otherwise too often too visible to women and too invisible to us men; men, both with and without women, intervening to discipline and punish at every level along a spectrum from informality "don\'t work with that guy, ever, until he admits what he\'s done and makes amends" to full criminal sanctions and hard jail time.  I feel strongly this is a man\'s problem; it is we men who are letting down our sisters through our laziness, ambition and complicity. Evidentiary requirements prevent serious criminal sanctions based on unsubstantiated allegations, no matter how frequent, but we can boycott, exile, providing damning opinions, and refuse to participate, much less enable, and provide all the support we can to \'just say no\' when a monster calls a young woman to his suite.', 'Excellent review. I can’t wait to read Brave.', "McGowan's role as a leadership figure is complex and problematic. She herself is no paragon of virtue - when she first became prominent in the Weinstein saga, I found myself recalling her destructive dalliance with Robert Rodriguez. The movement needs compelling figures to propel it forward. McGowan's tendencies and conduct have helped make her more of a persona that people want to recoil from rather than gravitate toward. She is not helping the cause in a way that best suits the needs of the cause. When someone has only one behavioral volume level, cannot manage their anger, consistently mentions how horrible everything is, and is diligent about naming all the causes of their misery (which are always external), to me, that is a clear sign that the diagnostic manual needs to be consulted.", 'I feel some trepidation about McGowan\'s book, because I know that when a victim isn\'t "perfect" people will use that as an excuse to disbelieve or discount her.  The thing is, while probably a lot of people will find McGowan grandiose and dramatic in an off-putting way (as I do, calling one\'s autobiography "Brave" is fairly narcissistic) - so what?  Weinstein et al aren\'t only going to attack "perfect" women.  The very fact that I worry in any way about the perception of her character is part of the problem.  Any woman can be victimized, whether you like her or not.  I am glad Michelle Goldberg wrote about this book in a way that says while McGowan may be "a bit much," she is honest and compelling and has told a story that matters for women and girls.  She is brave.', 'After reading this review for the book it makes me wonder if she ever had a chance at a normal life. Everything she experienced comes across like something from a Charles Dickens Novel.', 'I have a whole lot of respect for Rose McGowan. Reflecting on her statement "Your entertainment comes at a cost to us performers. You should know this and acknowledge..." - every day I face teens at an inner city school, and it comes at a cost to me - the constant challenge of keeping students engaged, the stress of the job, the attitudes.. But that is the job, one which I am privileged to have. I am satisfied with the work I do, and the downsides are part of it. Every job has costs, perhaps we should all acknowledge each others\' efforts a little more, and be kinder to one another.', 'You know as a man reading all these accounts has been very eye opening. I can see easily before how difficult it must have been for women facing these situations alone. The word Patriarchy is a good one. Well done Rose. Good on you.', 'Around 2009 or so, when all around me feared layoffs and the potential loss of their homes and dreams, I was counseled at work that, above all, the organization prized "being nice".  This meant going along with the crowd with a smile on one\'s face regardless of rule breaking, ethical violations by our superiors, requests to be party to intimidation, and verbal and emotional abuse by supervisors.  Never in my professional life had I experienced these types of behaviors.  I guess I was lucky until then, but I could not partake in that charade - and of course I was deemed the problem: angry, strident.  I got "written up"!  Knowing that I was not clever enough to fool virtually all my co-workers and supervisors up until joining that organization I sought out the EAP to shore up my coping skills and come up with a plan for my next career steps.  The most helpful aspect of that move was when the EAP assured me that I had plenty of company within my organization, which was unlikely to change. I carried out a successful escape, facilitated by my spouse, who was equally dissatisfied in the same organization.
