It involved relocation, more education, the loss of our home, and other disruptions, but nearly a decade later we both feel we are on a more solid footing, financially and professionally.  Gaslighting leaves scares though.  I don\'t trust others as I once did, waste hours questioning my own competency, and nearly tear up at mostly glowing work reviews.  I wish Rose the best.']
summary: Commentators say that Rose McGowan has the right to tell her story, but that she cannot say that she has had a painful life because she chose to continue working in Hollywood. Some think the actress is an unbalanced person, others think this is so due to the situations that she went through during her life. Other commentators say that this book could help other women who are in the same situation as her, as the culture of harassment and misogyny is still very much present in the entertainment industry.
short_title: Headline: In ‘Brave,’ Rose McGowan Exposes Hollywood Exploitation   Keywords: Brave (Book); McGowan, Rose; Books and Literature   Snippet: Michelle Goldberg reviews McGowan’s memoir, a cautionary tale about the entertainment industry by the actress who accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual assault last fall.
short_question: ['In ‘Brave,’ Rose McGowan Exposes Hollywood Exploitation  ']

query: Lonely nomads? Not so much.
comments: ['I remember the thrill of watching Pinito del Oro on her balance trapeze, the tickle that Mister Misten Jr. gave us when he played the xylophone, and the excitement generated when The Greatest Show on Earth was partially filmed in South Philadelphia. But my biggest thrill came twice, when i was part of the group of kids who helped erect the Big Top for the lowly payment of a cheap ticket to the show, when I had already purchased my center ring ticket well in advance.  I was a circus junky kid and blessed to have lived during a time when the world as a more trusting place.', "My grandparents met whilst both were performers with Ringling, she on the piano, he on the trombone.  My great-grandmother insisted that her son go to law school and get away from the circus--my great-grandfather had been a manager for Ringling Brothers and she wanted a more settled life for her children. My childhood memories, clouded by time, certainly don't include mistreatment of the animals, but -- I was a child, and the circus was magic.", "As a boy in the 1950s I remember... the glamour, the daredevilry. They gave us each a box turtle, in a box.  How can this end?  I never took my kids to the circus. I suppose you don't know what you got til it's gone.", 'Maltreatment of animals was the fatal flaw for the circus.', "We're losing an American institution. Thanks very much for helping us understand and remember it.", "I am disappointed to read a sentimental report on the circus by NYT. The circus is closing due to extreme animal abuse by its trainers. As the world became enlightened to this, their sales plummeted. The sad news is that as Ringling closes, hundreds of other circus's remain. Thousands of animals will continue to be tortured so that they can be trained to do ridiculous tricks.  Does anyone really think that a bear wants to ride bike? If you do, take a moment to look into the eyes of that bear.  You will see fear, loneliness and despair. There was a recent report of a bear who was so traumatized while doing a stand up trick, that he urinated on himself.  Imagine his degradation. Circus animals are kept chained to concrete floors and fed spoiled meat.  They are transported in trucks or trains with very little air during all kinds of weather. Sometimes their babies are trampled. The best description I can recall is that of Dumbo being ripped from his mother's trunk.  He was too young to know the lessons of torture that his Mother knew only too well. Please, the only circus worth any sentiment is one without animals. Do we really want to expose our children to animal abuse?  More than all of us, children do look into the eyes of the animals.  Children know that the animals live in fear of the whip, the bull hook and the sadistic trainers who wield them.", 'Sorry, but NO.  Long standing, ritualized and until recently, acceptable animal abuse.  No " greatest" here.  Go go away, please.', 'Nice puff piece.', "Doesn't everyone want to run away and join the circus? Fortunately, some can also keep their day jobs: ) A win-win!", 'Is that all? It felt like a teaser, and I would love to read an entire series on life with the Greatest Show On Earth!', 'I totally agree! I would love to read more about this disappearing lifestyle!', 'Baraboo, Wisconsin (Circus City) was home to the Ringling family, and for many years was the winter home of the circus. I was born (1949) in the Ringling Hospital in Baraboo. My father told me stories of watching the elephants being exercised on Water Street in Baraboo when he was a boy, circa 1920 on the Saturday "shopping day" when everyone came to town to shop. Once the circus began to travel by train, the old circus wagons were discarded and used on farms to haul hay, corn and livestock. However, many wagons have been returned to Circus World Museum and restored to their original glamour. What a day it must have been for a ten-year old farm boy from rural Wisconsin to watch live elephants walk up and down a main street in his home town. The end of an era was long in coming, and yet, way to soon.', "Your memories are innocent and sweet. But, the elephants were not being exercised.  They were flaunted through town so that folks would buy tickets. Behind the big top, the animals suffered tremendous abuse.  Abuse that created the bull hook.  It is used to train an elephant.  As one trainer said, 'it don't work until he screams.'  It cuts into their skin so that it will tear. The state of California banned their use. Animal activists hailed the closing of Ringling.  But, we hailed too soon. There are still hundreds of smaller circus's in our country. Circus owners are often fined for cruelty to animals.  Unfortunately, it is too lucrative a business to cause but a ripple to their bottom line. Only one circus is acceptable; one without animals.", 'Why would the Circus spend winters in Wisconsin?']
summary: Most commenters talk about missing a big part of American history, the circus. Some commenters talk about their positive experiences with watching the circus. One commenter insinuates that the article is incomplete. Two commenters mentions the mistreatment of animals and indicate that it should not be glorified.
short_title: Headline: The Greatest Family on Earth   Keywords: Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus; Circuses; Families and Family Life   Snippet: Lonely nomads? Not so much.
subreddit: ['Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus', 'Circuses', 'Families and Family Life']
short_question: ['The Greatest Family on Earth  ']

query: When a long winter leaves you feeling depressed and deprived, let this bright and warm avgolemono rice revive you.
comments: ['I was watching "The Mind of a Chef" and googled prune and hamilton to land on this gem of an article.  How fortunate am I! Not only Hamilton is a great chef, she is also a great writer. I cannot wait to try the recipe and report back. But I am tempted to embellish the dish by adding mint, dill and fresh garlic (it is coming out now). Thank you, Gabrielle!', 'Beautifully written!  I spent a year in Athens in 1982-83 and was lucky enough to spend a few days in some places like the island described.  The Greeks are the best hosts in the world!', "As a foodie who from a Greek background, I was eager to try this recipe.  I really enjoyed the article and the lovely writing, had just roasted a beautiful lamb for Easter, and I love Avoglemono soup, so I tried the recipe.  I'm really sorry to report that it was't that great.  It ended up being our dog's supper (and he really has a versatile palette).  I'm sorry, I just didn't get it, and I'm usually open to all kinds of interesting food innovations.  But this just tasted acidic to me.  The recipe lacked balance.  I'm not sure why.", 'I loved this recipe/ode so much I read it twice. Reading your words made me feel as if I was coming back to life after the long winter. More please more!', "Once again Gabrielle Hamilton proves what a fantastic writer she is. I probably won't butcher or roast lambs, much less make offal soup, but when reading this, I was there.", 'I totally agree and I now need to go and read her book.', "As the only Greek-American (apparently) in the Comments so far, may I add Kalo Pascha kai Eucharisti Poli, Gabrielle. What wonderful memories you brought back with this column. But did I miss a mention of the traditional red food-colored eggs? To those of you lucky enough not to be made to eat lambs' brains as children, a very Happy Easter and Passover and Joyous Spring to you all! Christos Anesti, Gabrielle!", 'Patrick, With all due respect, get a grip on the concept of baby lambs. Just finished our Easter dinner, Melissa Clark recipe for grilled leg of lamb marinated with olive oil, rosemary, thyme, zest and juice of an orange.  It is sublime, highly recommend', 'Greek Easter is miserable for vegetarians, but avgolemono ( as well as herb pies, the "village" salad, roasted potatoes with oregano, and various Easter sweets) can do the trick until things get normal.', 'The best "patates" in the world, Eh Giorgious?', "Great article and great looking recipe.  Can't wait to try it!  Thank you.", "Lovely writing. Best of luck with your restaurant, the one that thwarts your Easter perfection. I live in asparagus country. The cold spring leaves us mostly without for Easter this year. I doubt my family would eat boiled goat guts no matter someone else's authenticity. When the greens come in, by the grace of Mother Nature, we all revive.", 'Ugh, boiled. But some of them are palatable when sautéed in butter with garlic, Rosemary and/or oregano and a few onions. If you don\'t like the idea of eating kidneys, run when you hear the word "nephrakia." Kali Orexsi!', 'I really enjoyed this. Thank you.', 'Rice is good. There are billions of Chinese and a billion Indians who are sustained by rice. I really enjoyed the writing. The Lambs you are destroying, cooking, and eating are baby sheep. Think about it a while, would you please?', 'Ponderous article. Getting tired of foodies constantly waxing "poetic" and not getting to the point.  Put the recipe link at the top...!', 'You\'re reading a food column. Perhaps if you\'re solely looking for recipes you should look at NYT Cooking, where this recipe (without the accompanying article) is listed. Also, while your disdain for "foodies" is apparent, its worth nothing that the writer is a James Beard award winning author and chef/restauranteur. Personally I feel pretty lucky that I can not only try her recipes, but hear about her inspiration for the dish. Gratitude. You should try it sometime.', 'I totally agree. Well said!', 'Prune restaurant! Love!', "Dear Gabrielle, Thank you for this ! I also lived in Greece, and even though it was on the mainland in the 1950's outside of Athens, the images you draw of the traditional celebrations are accurate.  The processions, candles and solemn church services with incense and bells came back quickly with your ode to that experience.  (As well as the 'koukaretsi' from lamb innards that we as children suruptitiously fed to the cats beneath the table !) I will cook your avgolemono magiritsa and revisit those cherished memories.", 'I really am very much moved and inspired by your vivid and beautiful memories of your former life on a Greek island. I can only hope that one day I also will have the opportunity to experience something similarly beautiful and authentic in a foreign culture.', 'More than a recipe. A rich epiphany. Thank you.', 'Fun fact: "Epiphany" is a Greek word and also a Greek Orthodox (& Eastern Orthodox) holiday, Jan. 6th. Symbolizes the day the Three Magi reached the Christ child in the manger.', 'Such a pretty story. Thank you.', 'A wonderful addition to the menu of the nation of eaters of hamburgers with ketchup.', 'Cliche. I havent eaten a burger in over a year.', 'What beautiful writing. Thank you.', 'Your writing Gabrielle, is, like your food, fresh, bold and nourishing....']
summary: The commenters overwhelmingly love the stories weaved in with the recipe. They agree that the author's writing is wonderful. Some commenters say the article brought back memories of their childhoods. A couple of the commenters mention that this recipe calls for lamb, which is seen negatively.
short_title: Headline: Back to Life   Keywords: Peas; Easter and Holy Week; Greece; Recipes; Lamb   Snippet: When a long winter leaves you feeling depressed and deprived, let this bright and warm avgolemono rice revive you.
short_question: ['Back to Life  ']

query: Asad is a refugee whose refuge keeps receding, in this music drama, directed by Mark Dornford-May, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
comments: ["I saw this production in London last fall.  Assuming BAM's is the same one, I would encourage anyone willing to risk two hours  of less than conventional theater to attend.  Perfect?  No it's not.  Intriguing, uplifting?  Absolutely.", 'Gorgeous music, beautifully sung. This play had an operatic feel at times.  I found the storytelling a bit static and the play was long as has been pointed out in other comments.  It was hard to get my 14 year old engaged.   In my experience, important stories are not always the easiest ones to listen to. This was an important story but watching it sometimes felt like work. Ultimately we were glad we stuck with it and we had some interesting conversations about the play this morning.', "I was at the Thursday performance last night. Really had looked forward to it, as I'd read Steinberg's book and thought South Africans performing Assad's story was especially poignant. But we left at intermission.  The acting was terribly one-note and the production--song, dance, marimba--did not move me as the book had, did not convey the nuance, or the pathos. I'm a teacher, and felt it was more suited to a middle-school audience.", 'spirited, wrenching and often sublime music drama ??? We were at the Gilman Opera House Wed night, but feel as though we saw another show.  It was flat and endless.  We were unable to hear well, and the endless doors on stage are one of my few memories of the show.  Much of the music played in spurts, hard to hear changes in tone and rhythm before the song ended and another door appeared. We actually ran out at intermission.', "Wonderful music, beautiful dancing, brilliant staging.  It was a poignant reminder of what America used to promise even if it didn't always deliver.", 'Running time is not one hour', 'One correction: the show is about 2 and 1/2 hours long, NOT one hour.', 'A beautiful evening of theater, ironically relevant, for reasons outlined in the review, marred only by poor miking of several characters.']
summary: Many commenters thought the production was intriguing, with wonderful music and beautiful dancing. They applauded its operatic feel. Some commenters, however, dislike the acting for being terribly one-note and the music for being hard to hear, saying that they left during intermission. A few commenters corrected that the show is not one hour, but rather about two and a half hours.
short_title: Headline: A Boy Asks: Will America Take Me In?   Keywords: Theater; A Man of Good Hope (Play); Brooklyn Academy of Music; Isango Ensemble; Young Vic Theater Company; Dornford-May, Mark; Steinberg, Jonny   Snippet: Asad is a refugee whose refuge keeps receding, in this music drama, directed by Mark Dornford-May, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
subreddit: ['Theater', 'A Man of Good Hope (Play)', 'Brooklyn Academy of Music', 'Isango Ensemble', 'Young Vic Theater Company', 'Dornford-May, Mark', 'Steinberg, Jonny']
short_question: ['A Boy Asks: Will America Take Me In?  ']

query: There is something powerful about attending an institution that was built for you.
comments: ["There is only one surviving DNA genetic evolutionary fit multicolored human race species that began in Southeast Africa 250,000 years ago.   Color is not race. Color is a chronological ecological isolation response to varying levels of solar radiation at different altitudes and latitudes related to Vitamin D production and protecting genes from damaging mutations. But about 2-5% of Europeans and Asians carry the primitive genetic racial heritage of their Neanderthal and Deovisan ancestors. That is the only bi-racial human survival.  There is none of that genetic heritage in the first and most ancient modern humans in Sub-Saharan Africa. Color as a racial marker is a legacy of the white supremacist American history that denied Africans their humanity as enslaved persons and their equality as Americans during the Jim Crow era and it's aftermath. My paternal great grandfather, who was born enslaved in Georgia, graduated from Atlanta Baptist College aka Morehouse.  His eldest son and my grandfather was an alumni of Shaw University.  My grandmother was the daughter of two enslaved Georgians who sent her to finish college at Atlanta University. My maternal great grandfather was born free in South Carolina and finished college at a South Carolina HBCU. I did not attend an HBCU undergrad nor grad nor professional school as I came of college age in the wake of the late 1960's civil rights era.", 'Human biological differences played a huge rule in black slavery: sub-Saharan Africans have a high incidence of resistance to malaria, and were thus imported to replace dying white indentured servants and Indians.  http://www.malaria.com/blog/american-plasmodium-vivax', 'Integration policies today were initiated by white American legislators in the 1960-1970s protest era against legal racial discrimination. The policies were well-intended, without which we would probably not have made so much progress in freeing black Americans from the oppressive legal shackles of institutional white supremacy. For one consequence was a foreign policy against white South African and British inspired racist laws there. But black colleges and universities have developed an alumni and role unparalleled in developing a black middle-class. And we see brilliant results in the graduates working in our increasingly integrated society. Xavier University in New Orleans, Meharry and Howard are the leading producers of black medical doctors and researchers. The reason is that most white colleges and universities still select black students to fill racial-ethnic percentage quotas, or collegiate sports programs, while working to marginalized HBCUs which do not have that burden and can actually select students based on ability. What irony! Long live the HBCUs and the Black Churches! They are the American historical evidence of things no longer seen. They are the truth.', "More than fifty years after school integration some black folks decide they really don't like attending school with whites after all. Great.", 'I had a similar experience attending a school system where I received a great education but their were very few that students that looked like me.  I too had the opportunity to go to Ivey League schools or play football.  I chose Morehouse College for undergraduate school and Howard U. for graduate school.  Particularly, at Morehouse we were taught that \'more" was expected of us as graduates.  We were there to become leaders and change the world.  No one assumed the only reason you were there was an athletic scholarship.  Great Choice!', "It should be noted that most Spelman students went to segregated southern high schools. Spelman's education is respected. One of my Harvard Law School classmates was a Spelman grad from Jackson", "I don't like the tone of this article or the tone of the comments. both are grievance fueled, tho largely from opposite sides of the fence. the real trick folks is to burnish that coal into a diamond,  like Douglass,  King and Obama.", '"it was at Howard that [my mother] was finally able to learn in a context that validated her history and identity . . .  At Spelman, I found a place for myself in the curriculum, and an opening to learn what it means to be me. There is something powerful about attending an institution that was built for you. Most colleges were built for white students, or at least, with only white students in mind." What was that we were taught about race just being a "social construct", only of importance to racists and white supremacists? Here is a black person telling us just how important race is. Clearly, not for the reasons that racial supremacist believe it is, but because central to any deep and meaningful sense of both personal and group identity. This doesn\'t just apply to black people like Skylar Mitchell, but to ALL people, including white people. Why is there this insane insistence (especially amongst academics) that race doesn\'t, or shouldn\'t matter, when it so obviously does? It is, I believe an overreaction to Jim Crow and even more to Nazism and the Holocaust.  The Nazi\'s criminally insane racial ideology made a big ugly thing of race, where it really was just a social construct amongst the closely related peoples (including Jews) of Europe. In overreaction to this, academics (esp. Jewish academics who were personally traumatised by the Holocaust) went to the opposite extreme of denying the importance - even the very existence - of race altogether.', 'Roger Hicks, UK: British folks generally miss the significance of our Constitution\'s individual equal rights requirement regardless of class, religion, ethnicity, gender, national origin or race. But none of those social markers may be used to discriminate against individuals in violation of our Constitution. Unlike the UK, in America we have no legally privileged class like a monarchy. Hence there is no privileged group here in law, though in social and cultural preference practices we may see evidence to the contrary. An HBCU for many black students is the same preference freedom of selection basis as the personals dating selections where, so to speak, "birds of a feather flock together." (SWF seeking SWM, etc.) Anti-discrimination laws have no force in dating. Why should the same laws deny Skylar from choosing a college or university based on the same extrinsic factors? We would no longer be a free country the day our government selects our mates to force social integration (or social disintegration of previously race-based or gender based institutions).', 'Thank you Beautifully written.  Finding the place where you can be you and grow to be anyone and learn anything is the goal all of us parents want for our children.   There is so much noise out there, we must all slow down and listen to hearts and stop and feel to find what is right.', 'Unfortunately, Ms. Mitchell, the real world does not offer the safety you seek in college. I taught in a HBCU and the students were given too many breaks in their education with many earning grades they had not worked for at all. Not all the black professors complied with this practice, but they were in a minority. One of the professors who taught writing there could not even write at middle school level. This professor was educated in HBCUs. I also experienced a lot of racism against whites and Hispanics, even against Jews, and extreme sexism I had never witnessed in institutions informed by Western culture.', "I don't know where you taught but it appears that you brought your Eurocentric biases and concerns with you. There was a lot you could have learned from this setting, but you chose to view the experience in a stereotypical way. Too bad. You probably left the HBCU in the same limited way that you entered - feeling superior. I went to a HBCU for undergrad and then on to a highly ranked law school. Like the author of this piece, I was admitted to a number of other schools but chose the HBCU. So glad that I did because I received a world class education at a school with exceptional teachers who were demanding and truly cared about my future. To this day, I count the decision to go to an HBCU as one of the best decisions I've ever made.", "I well understand the difference, but Ms. Mitchell is something of a pioneer attracted by the unique choice offered by Spelman  And because there are so many others like her, I never was offended by Ms. DeVos's claim that black colleges are pioneers of school choice,  Sure they were initiated in a segregated world, but they were indeed established by pioneers who created a new and valuable option for college-aged blacks.  I thought the  attack on Ms.DeVos was snickety and mostly semantic,  She was mostly right.", "It's great to go to a Black college if that's what you want.  Good for you.  If that's where you feel most comfortable, great.   My ancestors were serfs - slaves by most definitions.  My grandparents  immigrated to Canada.  I'm the first generation in my family to complete college.  No one helped me pay the bills, my mother had nothing extra to give.  I didn't get much useful help, other than being told to keep going.  I didn't feel like I fit in, because I usually only took two classes at a time and I could never just hang out.  I remember coming to a night class and a classmate commenting that I was dirty.  I'd been driving a tractor all day, I changed my shirt and went to class.  Poor me!  Oh well.  I'm thrilled that I had the opportunity and the tenacity to make it.  A full ride at Spelman, when clearly your parents could be providing you with lots of help.  So some poor Black kid doesn't get to go because you're very privilege self took all the money.  There's a problem with that.   There are plenty of heroic Black men in the world.  Trayvon wasn't one of them.  The Hispanic man who shot him was found not guilty of second degree murder and of manslaughter.  Mr. Martin was not murdered.", "I am not to judge Miss Mitchell's choice. Meanwhile, I feel the need to point out today's race relations, though imperfect in many ways, has benefited from many heroic black men and women in past generations. To say everything is the same as yesterday is being unfair to many who struggled in ordinary and extraordinary ways.", 'A supportive, non-judgemental environment is critical to learning. Besides a top-notch institution, Spelman indeed offers you the opportunity to truly take flight.', "Good for you, Skylar.  My daughter's journey at Spelman sounds almost exactly like yours, from the questioning of the school's legitimacy in high school to her love of ADW to professors not accepting anything less than her best.. It was the best educational decision she ever made. Please know that even after being awarded a full scholarship (awarded to 5 students. with the highest gpa from undergraduate) to an Ivy graduate school, the affirmative action unspoken narrative continued.  Her study abroad experiences were outstanding, Mexico and South Africa.", 'Excellent article. It seems so ironic and interesting that so many  White students  (at least) upper income White students seems to be so antagonistic towards affirmative action given the fact that their economic situation and pedigree White privileged affords them the opportunity to benefit from affirmative action  ona daily basis. The hypocrisy is astounding.', 'So when a white or asian senior looks down the row and see the son of a Doctor who just happens to be black or brown gets a “bonus” of 230 points on the SAT at Princeton - you think that is ironic?', 'I support affirmative action always. Meanwhile, class differentiation among African Americans is a new reality. Spelman costs 45,000+ to attend. Even first-rate public universities cost about half of that for in-state students.', "You were so thoughtful about your decision. How many high school students understand the importance of a core curriculum? Spelman is lucky to have you, but I'm a little sorry for the schools that you rejected."]
summary: Many commentators think that moving the child to a racial school was a good one, giving him a chance to grow. Some commentators mock the decision, saying that it flies in the face of anti-racism arguments about how we're all one species and acknowledges that there are differences. A few commentators work to show that racism is foolishness. One commentator remarks on successful Blacks, and another commentator notes that there are many poor-quality teachers.
short_title: Headline: The Value of a Black College   Keywords: Colleges and Universities; Spelman College; Blacks   Snippet: There is something powerful about attending an institution that was built for you.
short_question: ['The Value of a Black College  ']

query: After a short career covering offbeat stories for The Times, Mark Hawthorne left silently in 1969, re-emerging as the “Hate Man” of Berkeley, Calif.
comments: ['A very sweet piece: thanks!', 'Dear NYTimes. You richly expose life through your obituaries. Please never stop.  Speedy Rice', "I went to the drum sessions (hate camp) in sproul in late 90s, there was a couple stores that would donate pizzas and coffee to us, very nice people. I read some lousy article somewhere said he ate garbage, that is totally not true. I was there and for long time and the culture of America esp rich Berkeley ucb was that some people threw away perfectly good food. I saw this one female student throw away a full tray of fries right in front of me. I was shocked. she was the epitome of this wasteful society (spoiled) that's why we are in trouble as a planet. some people donated food or left it on the sidewalk, it was not like some people think. Berkeley was a special place and Hateman was one of its stars. He would share food and his cigarettes, just push a little bit or slap or just say im taking this. Very cool scene.", 'As one of the handful of people who fully embraced Hate  Man\'s Oppositional philosophical practice (for more than 15 years),  I have one minor correction.  Hate (as we mostly called You)  didn\'t have a problem with positivity,  just with verbal positivity.  As You would say,  "if You\'re feeling positive,  show me,  do something, or just feel it  -- but don\'t say it, "  believing that speaking something generally dissipated it. (And,  in the spirit of Martin Buber,  we tried to keep our discourse in the first and second person pronouns as much as we could, to establish an I-You equivalence.) As extreme as the Oppositional practice is,  I do think it tunes into something that is gradually gaining ground in the world: the need for tools to deal with difficult conversations and difficult interactions on a one-to-one basis that allows for multiple, even conflicting points of view to be negotiated with both candor and equanimity, without third party power structures to define limits and determine acceptable topics and results.  I learned some things about Hate (or Mark)  in his NY Times days from this article!', 'I went to UCB in the early 90\'s--Hate Man was as much a part of my life experience in those days as the lecture hall.  Much of the street life that made Berkeley a vibrant place to live and study is gone.  Instead a sterile, corporate effect has taken over a lot of the culture that shapes the sounds and sights around the campus.  He was a "giant" among the people that made campus and the south side edgy and avant-garde.  How sad that he\'s gone, he\'ll be missed and remembered by countless people.', 'Thank you, I\'m so glad Hate got to have a tribute article in the Times itself! One quote I believe that Hate would have revised during the 20 last years I knew him; he may have said "positive feelings are intrinsically hypocritical", but I\'m guessing he was referring to *expressing* positive feelings here.  The more evolved statement he would make is that he wanted to hear people expressing negative emotions -- expression dissipates an emotion -- but not  positive emotions "I don\'t want to hear them".  *Say* the negative feelings -- but *feel* or *do* the positive ones. Thank you, Mr. Dunlap.', "The Hate Man I knew in Berkeley, besides his wearing women's undergarments,  most notable public discourse contribution was his heckling of the preachers - Jesus is Coming ?! Well, Godzilla may be coming from behind the pine trees, but dont believe it till you see it! And he always played a prominent role in Graduation ceremonies outside Zellerbach hall:   Hey Hate Man - Can I take a picture with you? Sure, you got fifty cents ?", 'I attended Berkeley during his prime, as a inhabited the area near Sather Gate. He was very very smart, and funny. I hated him.', 'Is there any way to get a better resolution pic of the Marya Mannes  article? The current one is impossible to read on a phone.', 'Around December 1991 or January 1992, I spent an afternoon in  Berkeley during which a man was walking in circles for about half-an-hour while shouting " You are a liar like your mother, you are a coward like your father!" He could have been the Hate Man. Most of the people to which I recounted this experience appreciated it too.', 'I encountered Hate Man when I was a student at UCB. Friends told me he used to have a very different life before he became Hate Man...a profile in the Times a number of years ago confirmed that. As I understand it, on a trip to San Francisco to visit a New York Times colleague, Hawthorne tried LSD, and things suddenly clicked. Shortly after what he described as that “mind-expanding experience,” he got bored working for the New York Times, and left it all (including as I recall his wife and family) to become Hate Man.', 'Possibly the last honest man?  Or is that romanticizing an eccentric?  At the very least, an intelligent man, following his own path.  Not many other people who can say the same.', 'Incredible guy.  Talent, insight.  He could have used a good psychiatrist, but then all of us could too.', 'Interesting to see a NY Times front page that deals mostly with New York.  I suppose Trump outrage sells more papers - pity has lusting after circulation has its moral hazards.', 'In fact they just announced they radically cut back on their NYC news staff and expanded its Washington presence. The reason given was chasing circulation.  So live in your dreams, I bet you even think the NY Times is objective.', 'And I\'ll bet you think "their staff" and "its presence" belong in the same "dream."', 'Sorry if I hurt your feelings.', "The East Bay Times has a 33 picture slide show of Mark's life- centered around Berkeley and other photos from his previous life. It is quite interesting, ( www.eastbaytimes.com)  April 3, 2017.", 'The link isn\'t directly to the article. Follow it to the East Bay Times and then search for "hate man," and you\'ll find the excellent photo essay.', "Thank you for the link. Fascinating life. And he's right... we do need to acknowledge our differences before we can discuss our commonalities. #WeAreOne", 'And he was a nice guy, too.', 'I encountered Hate Man on the UC Berkeley campus in 1977.  I was immediately struck by his intense, relentless energy.  Like Diogenes, he seemed fearless.  I figured his shtick was a gimmick, a combination of street theater and narcissism.  Maybe he had been hurt or had suffered a loss he couldn\'t overcome and this was his odd way of coping with past trauma.  Regardless, I had know some major league eccentrics in my time so his antics didn\'t offend me.  Once or twice when I was in attendance he was assaulted by someone in the audience.  Hate Man stuck to his guns on those occasions, unfazed and ever relentless; any cynicism I had about him evaporated.   We exchanged cordial "insults" on a brilliant autumn day.  I never knew his name till now, but I never forgot him.  Thanks for the article.']
summary: Many of the commenters reminisce and tell their own stories about the Hate Man. One commenter stated that he thought his "shtick was a gimmick," but as he got to see him more that all the negative feelings he had toward him "evaporated." One commenter said that Hate Man made the campus of Berkeley "edgy and avant-garde." A few of the commenters discuss the Hate Man's philosophies saying that he wanted people who were happy to show it through action, "but don't say it." Several of the commenters state how they are thankful that the man received an obituary and that he was deserving of one.
short_title: Headline: Mark Hawthorne, a Man of Few Words Except, ‘I Hate You’   Keywords: Hawthorne, Mark (1936-2017); Berkeley (Calif); New York Times; Kaufman, Michael T; Gelb, Arthur; Newspapers; Washington Square Park (Manhattan, NY)   Snippet: After a short career covering offbeat stories for The Times, Mark Hawthorne left silently in 1969, re-emerging as the “Hate Man” of Berkeley, Calif.
subreddit: ['Hawthorne, Mark (1936-2017)', 'Berkeley (Calif)', 'New York Times', 'Kaufman, Michael T', 'Gelb, Arthur', 'Newspapers', 'Washington Square Park (Manhattan, NY)']
short_question: ['Mark Hawthorne, a Man of Few Words Except, ‘I Hate You’  ']

query: Stuffing a butterflied tenderloin with shallots, herbs and capers keeps the dryness-prone meat juicy and giving.
comments: ['I would never use the tenderloin---only the "whole" loin with that thick layer of fat.  The tenderloin is under that fat, and needs the fat to stay tender.  After the whole loin is cooked, I remove the extraneous layer, then slice the tenderloin into serving sizes to freeze for other meals.  (I live alone, and generally get 13-15 meals from a loin.) The "trash" of fat and other striated pieces of meat is processed as "pulled pork" with most of the fat discarded. While packing the loin chops for freezing, add a generous amount of juices to the bag. (I use sandwich bags to freeze my loin chops and pulled pork. My favorite spices for pork?  Rosemary, thyme, sage, allspice, salt.  Use twice the amount of rosemary and thyme as the sage and allspice--or all rosemary you want!', 'Cover the tenderloin with mustard, toss it in some shake n bake and (or your own panko coating) and roast at 425 for 20 minutes or until it hits 145. Easy and delicious.', "Melissa, The way to make pork tough is cook it in a dry oven for too long and too high a temperature, e.g. 145.  Here's another vote for sous vide, which is foolproof.  But not everyone has one, so another method I've used is almost as good and does better with a dry rub.  After sitting with the rub, pin the tail of the loin with a toothpick or twine to make a cylinder. Heat a cast iron grill pan or pan to medium hot, then sear four 'sides' for 5 minutes each, then rest. 20 minutes total produces a nice crust and medium rare, tender pork. Finish in a warm oven if you want it more done.  Slice thin, not as pictured.", "I prepared a butterflied pork tenderloin inspired by this recipe, but with a few changes. As my dinner guest wasn't a fan of capers, I substituted diced pears and mangoes, which provided the moisture.  When it came time to cook the trussed pork, I used my charcoal grill on a blustery Indiana afternoon.  As I cook the pork to an internal temperature of 145 degrees, I found the garlic a tad too raw, so I may saute the shallot and garlic mixture for a minute before adding to the filling. The pork was fork-tender when served, and a big hit with both my dinner guest and me.", 'A much easier approach is to use sous vide. Cuts like Pork tenderloin or steaks are much easier to cook in a water bath. Cook in the bath until done to the required degree of tenderness and then sear in a cast iron skillet and voila, perfectly cooked every time', "Sous vide is extraordinarily effective for meat, especially lean meat, and pork tenderloin is the best example. Also great for Hanger steak. Also for boneless and skinless chicken breasts and drumsticks. And sous vide produced the most amazing turkey drumstick cooked  for 24 hrs and then briefly seared in a casr iron skillet! So it's my primary cooking mode for meat.", 'When, oh When will the NYTimes start close-captioning its videos?  Many people will appreciate that .....', 'Tenderloin here in Iowa is a staple and I pan fry it so it rests for 5-10 minutes and reaches 145.  But I add Coke to the pan to deglaze into a delicious gravy with a little flour to thicken.  Our pork here is high quality and I can buy it directly from the small farmer.', 'I like to rub mine with smoked paprika, add a bit of maple syrup, some red wine, a wee bit of olive oil, some whole garlic cloves and cook in a foil pouch at low temperature. Never disappoints!  The stuffing of this one looks delicious though.', 'Add a little bit of dijon mustard to your pan reduction sauce, and some finely chopped cornichons along with some of your filling mixture, and you have sauce charcutiere, a classic with pork. In fact, to make the whole business even faster and easier, slice the tenderloin into thick round slabs, quickly sear and briefly roast to desired internal temp, and serve with more sauce. Why tie?', "We eat a lot of pork tenderloin when it's just two of us. This is a good variation.  You almost can't overcook it - like beef tenderloin - even overcooked it's still delicious.", "Yum. Now I'm hungry!", "I am not much of a cook, but one of my favorite recipes is for pork tenderloin, so I consider myself familiar with the cut. It's dark meat and very moist. This photo looks to me like the 'loin' of pork, not the 'tenderloin'.", 'I agree.  The photo looks like a boneless pork loin, not a tenderloin.', 'Hi Melissa, I loved it. Great job. Daniel', "Pork tenderloin benefits even more than boneless chicken breasts from brining*. I have never had it dried out on me this way. Can bake at 400F for 25 minutes with a spice rub on the outside, or a coating of bread crumbs/chopped nuts/herbs/spices. *: Couple of tablespoons of salt and sugar in a quart of water. Brine tenderloin for a couple of hours. Don't sprinkle on/add any salt on the meat, though.", "Not a fan of the pork tenderloin.  It's tough, dry, and dark.  And it costs three times as much or more than loin, which can often be had for $1.50/lb or less.  Loin is lighter in color, more tender, takes on flavors easily, and more filling!", 'Long ago, I adapted a Robert Carrier recipe, and it works. Mix room temp butter mixed with mustard, minced rosemary, and microplaned garlic, then smear all over. Tuck the skinny ends underneath. The butter keeps it moist, as long as you keep an eye on the temp.', "Want tender, succulent tenderloin -- don't overcook it. It's that complicated. Dry rubs and glazes will give you a tasty flavor, if you don't like the taste of pork.  And let's not overlook the remarkably low price on this more than adequate substitute for beef tenderloin.", 'I like this recipe and will make it, but I make pork tenderloin weekly and I have never been disappointed in this method: Preheat your oven (with a cast-iron skillet inside) to 450. Meanwhile, salt and pepper the pork. When the oven is preheated, remove the skillet, pour in about a tablespoon of oil (I use canola), swirl, and add the pork. Place the skillet back in the oven for 10 minutes; then turn the pork over and roast for another 10 minutes. Remove from the pan immediately, and let rest for up to 10 minutes on a cutting board, tented with foil.  Moist, juicy, and suitable for pairing with a number of different dishes (our favorite way to use the pork is thinly sliced on top of congee, or in a sandwich).', "Maybe it's my thermometer, but 145 seems way to high a temperature for juicy pink pork tenderloin.  I get routinely good results cooking a single tenderloin to 125 degrees and letting it rest 5 minutes on the cutting board covered with foil.  It is pink but cooked.   It usually takes about 25 minutes at 425 in my oven. My wife would be the first to let me know if it was too rare.", 'You are correct on lower pork temperatures. In the modern farming age, pork is about the least pathogen affected. Much safer than beef or poultry. Still if you are stuffing anything you do want to make sure no part of the stuffing is also not at least 145 (just as stuffed bird requires more caution as well.) Larger tenderloins can be spiral cut, just use a well sharpened filet knife. Then hammer it which gives you an a more symmetrical rectangle to roll. Stuffing with some fats and some sweet elements also work well at adding fats to this lean cut. Fats you can add would be nuts, cheese and/or a small amount of bacon or sausage. Walnuts and apple go well with bleu cheese in a tenderloin. Pistachio and pecan with apricot or date is nice as well.', "Actually, all you really need to do is Step 4 from the Instructions. It's not necessary to butterfly the tenderloin and stuff it, although obviously you can if you'd like.      Assuming you like your pork tenderloin on the rare to medium rare side, you can simply sear it in the skillet and then finish it in a 400 degree oven for 15-20 minutes, depending on thickness, when the internal temperature reaches 145.", 'Hi Melissa, Fair enough, but I recommend that you consider cooking a pork tenderloin sous vide. Delicious, juicy, tender, etc. I do mine to 135. Also works for beef tenderloin (maybe 125). Finish in very hot cast iron pan. Just a thought. Love your column and the food section in general. Avidly yours, John', "I was just about to say the same thing but I got to your post first. One of the most sure fire methods of cooking pork right. So juicy that the leftovers of tenderloin or chops are actually GOOD the next day.  Now back to my bone in rib eye that I'm dropping in the bath now.... Thanks!", 'One more for sous vide.  Dead-simple, inexpensive method to achieve consistent results.  Lean cuts of meat benefit from this technique.', 'And a third for this method - I cook it at 137 for about 1.5-2 hours depending on size. So easy and so fool proof.  https://gigglinggourmand.wordpress.com/2014/07/07/sous-vide-pork-tenderl...', "I've always found pork tenderloin pretty forgiving, whether grilled whole or fried in medallions. Most often I use it to make moo ping, Thai grilled pork on a skewer (neck meat is traditional). Cut into thin strips, it's tender and delicious even when cooked well done.", 'Good idea. Another way to cope with the leanness is to treat it as filet mignon.  Cut it into medallions and broil or grill quickly.  This also solves the problem of the uneven thickness of the tenderloin. I would accompany with a white wine reduction with thyme and/or rosemary and/or garlic or with a sauce bearnaise, as with a chateaubriand.  A riesling from the Rhine or a good white Burgundy would be nice.', "Michael, How thick do you slice it? I'm just guessing about 1 inch."]
summary: The commenters, in general, have many suggestions to accomplish the writer's purpose. These include mustard and cornichons, sous vide, filet treatment, and ways to cut the meat. Another common thread was to cook the meat at a low temperature. A few other comments are less focused, with one referring to inaccuracies in the illustration picture and the need for closed-captioning in videos.
short_title: Headline: How to Keep the Tender in Pork Tenderloin   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Pork   Snippet: Stuffing a butterflied tenderloin with shallots, herbs and capers keeps the dryness-prone meat juicy and giving.
short_question: ['How to Keep the Tender in Pork Tenderloin  ']

query: I often feel relief at not being burdened by hope of a cure — like Sisyphus admiring the view from the mountain after someone stopped the boulder.
comments: ['I am just starting this journey, with Stage IV ovarian cancer. I "officially" entered remission on November 30, 2016. At my last chemo, the nurse said, "It\'s nice that you\'ll get a break over the holidays." I really didn\'t want to think of this as "a break"-- or if a break, certainly longer than over the holidays! I embarked on a coast-to-coast tour to demonstrate to friends and family that I am well. Curly hair and all. I have the addition of a religious past with family who believe God has answered their prayers (i.e., I am cured). And I feel it, as I always have, as an expectation that I get myself cured. So I\'ve resisted. I\'ve insisted that the chances are good that the cancer will return, all the while believing in some way that it won\'t, that I will be one of those 30% who don\'t need further treatment. But let anyone else mention that 30% on my FB page and I delete the comment. It\'s a burden-- and again suggests you have control over something you don\'t. The way I got through the initial craziness of December was to realize that I had done well through chemo and surgery and I would hopefully continue to do well with whatever came next.', "If it's not cancer, it's something else.  After a while they all kind of start to feel like the same.", '"Such a bad attitude would make me vulnerable to the all-too-common view that pessimism breeds disease and that I deserve the cancer I dread." Oh, yes.  I have been told that my real disability was my bad attitude, not my paralysis.  This thinking comes at me in moments of real honesty when I try and speak up about the difficulties I experience.  No one wants to hear about the difficulties of a spinal cord injury, they want inspiration and overcoming obstacles.  They want me to dream of walking again.  That\'s OK, they can hold that dream for me.  I have a life to live in the meantime.', 'Susan - Thank you SO much for articulating exactly how I feel as I am now in my second recurrence for a cancer, like yours, that will keep coming back.  At the time of my first recurrence, my doctors told me I would been in some sort of treatment for the rest of my life.  I have come to learn that quality of life issues are the focus for me and I try to make my life meaningful and fun!  But, as you point out, an ongoing frustration is how friends and family respond, wanting to believe you are "cured."  Thank you so much for your insight.', 'Thank you, as always, Professor Gubar. I do hope you collect your columns into a book. Your teaching and your writing are priceless.', 'It has taken me years to find a voice like Susan\'s that not only resonated with my experience but who I can send my friends to read to understand me in ways I am unable to articulate fully.  At 60 I am a multiple cancer survivor: Hodgins at age 17 (asymptomatic, discovered during a required college entrance physical ).  Treatment- Kaplan protocol- splenectomy followed by massive amounts of full mantal radiation). Last treatment 2 days before freshman year.  Made me sterile. Thyroid cancer at age 25 (from radiation)-thyroidectomy Basiloma at 27 (ditto) Non-small cell squamous lung cancer stage 3B at age 52 (as my oncologist says " radiation, the gift that keeps on giving")in 2008, same year that Susan started her journey.  I was lucky to have the same oncologist as Paul Kalanithi later though he obviously wasn\'t as lucky. Chemo then lobectomy. In addition to these I have Radiation Fibrosis (withering of muscles from nerve cell death) causing inability to support weight of head resulting in discectomy.  Virus infections that others bounce back from take me 4x as long. Why the details?  At 17 no one knew what lay ahead. "The Emperor of All Maladies"- nailed it!  Anyone who has been diagnosed should read that book. Looking back 43 yrs had I known what I know now, I think I might have opted out.  Back then- no counseling, support groups, internet research, bloggers, etc. Keep going Susan- we need voices like yours!', 'Thank you so much, Susan, for articulating so well what I am experiencing. Although my cancer is a different one (anal), I had similar experiences of doctors brushing off my symptoms (e.g. "eat more fiber", "stop eating gluten"). My heart sinks when my friends exclaim that I am cancer-free, which I am not. Also, everyone seems to believe (as I once did) that once the chemo and radiation is over, the suffering and side effects of treatment are also over. If only!!! The one thing I find eminently consoling is that now my chances of dying of Alzheimer\'s are greatly reduced!', 'A writer myself, Susan, I am keenly aware that the gift of precise self-expression can be therapeutic in its own right. As I extend my sympathies to you and your sister sufferers, it is a great consolation to me and, no doubt, to many other readers that your intellect remains capable of the greatest clarity. Studying your present literary experiments makes me proud to be your contemporary. Thank you for presenting your experience with such honesty.', 'Excellent piece about the challenges of maintenance therapy. I have been on maintenance therapy since fall of 2013 for Multiple Myeloma, a blood plasma cancer. Aside from "chemo vacations" and the carrot of a cure I will be on maintenance the rest of my life. Being able to explain this concept to others is difficult. Your article should help make it better.', 'Thanks for your perspective and thanks for mentioning the need for better detection and prevention. I think diagnosis is a real problem. I and others have brought symptoms to doctors, to have them dismissed or not diagnosed as cancer until very late. (A friend mentioned a swelling on her jaw to her doctor, who said, "It\'s nothing." When it grew larger and became painful, it was diagnosed as cancer. Fortunately, my friend is doing well after radiation therapy.)', "After 5+ years of fallopian tube cancer, surgery, chemo, 15 mos of remission, two more rounds of chemo, one year plus of a drug to hold the cancer at bay, my last scan showed it popping up all over.  Now I'm really waiting for the IRS or the Sword of Damocles to finally fall.  I'm feeling fine except for the gifts that chemo leave; neuropathy, fatique, not much appetite, unreliable equilibrium--but I'm happy to be here.", 'Your eloquent words encompass much of what I have experienced in the variety of struggles I have had with my health, including cancer. Internally my fears and self blame, on bad days, and externally, the hopes and discomfort and blame if others. I am an RN and a patient and see both sides. I do understand any external judging  often comes from the American ridiculous belief that if we do everything right we will never die and the admiration of those who "age well," coupled with our terror if our mortality. Thank you for this piece and I will seek.out your other writings.', 'Yes! I am sharing this with family and friends that long to- but are afraid to ask questions. I am Stage 4 BC on maintenance for 2 years and subscribe to the second to last paragraph with exuberance! Thank you as always for putting into words what I feel and where I am.', 'Thank you Susan. Your observations are insightful, your writing beautiful and your honesty is always ever present. Your essays have been a compassionate source of support for me and reflect a similar path despite having a different illness. Always wishing you quality time and joy', 'Thank you for sharing your experiences so that others can appreciate the realities of living with cancer. In a recent CancerCare national survey of more than 500 people diagnosed with cancer, those on maintenance therapy and those in active treatment reported similar reductions in their ability to do important activities, such as work, exercise, entertain, clean, child care and hobbies.  For so many people, maintenance therapy is as debilitating and distressing as treatment.', 'Ten years after my sister had kidney and breast cancer, her doctor told her "You have the same chance as anyone else." While this was meant to be encouraging, the fact is we lost both our parents and many other family members to cancer in their 70s. Carpe diem, I suppose.', 'I never had the pleasure of being in remission, so eight years of OM feels like a gift, albeit a weird one. Thanks, Susan, for describing this experience eloquently & honestly. Keep fighting the good fight.', 'Thank you for these beautifully honest sentiments. your fan, ranger https://www.facebook.com/Cancer-is-SO-funny-197662100303900/', "Thank you for sharing your conversations with us.  The conversations you have with others and, most personally, the conversations you have with yourself.  I've read your books.  I seek out your posts.  Your writing inspires me to put language to my own experiences.  You are a gift to us.", 'good article - thanks !', 'Because after you’ve struggled and recovered from a debilitating condition, you realize what you really need and want in life, and the amusements of your previous life may no longer hold the same appeal. You yearned for “party time,” but now, that might seem a waste of time, once you know how precious time is, especially if the condition might recur.', "Well said.  As a two time (stage IV throat and stage I breast) cancer survivor who is considered 'cured' of both cancers, I still live with the dread of recurrence or a brand new cancer.  Every time I get a symptom like a persistent sore throat the sleepless nights and constant worry comes back.  I even worry that this stress will bring on another cancer sooner.  I have rehearsed my end from cancer over and over again in my head. I long for the days of B.C.complacency before cancer struck.", 'Thank you -- this is such a great read. I have a family member who is dealing with the protracted aftermath of an illness that could have been fatal but wasn\'t. Your descriptions of people thinking "It\'s over, everything should be normal!" (when that\'s clearly not the case) really ring true, even though some of the medical details are a bit different. But the sense of frustration when people can\'t empathize with ongoing physical challenges is the same.', "Thank you for this piece. Like you, I let my hope for cure fade into the background of my life after I realized that it was not helping me live with the uncertainty about my future health.   For one thing, the two ways to know I'm cured--in the sense that most patients mean it, namely, their cancer never recurs-- are if my cancer comes back (i.e., not cured) or I'm dying of something else while in remission (i.e., cured). For another, even if an angel could whisper in my ear that I am cured, that certainty about  my cancer says nothing about the uncertainty of my future health, since I'd still be at risk of accidents and all the other ills of mankind.   While I want to never face my cancer again, I don't spend any time or attention hoping for cure. By letting go of that hope, I freed my time and attention to find and nourish hopes that help me live with the uncertainty, such as hope to get good medical care, hope to take good care of my body, and hope to live each day as fully as possible, whatever is happening medically.   blog posts about hope:  http://tinyurl.com/wshblog012417", 'What makes Ms. Gubar such a rarity is that she possesses the combination of a person not only living with cancer but a highly talented writer and communicator by profession.  Many of us who are living with advanced cancer and the challenging consequences of dealing with the state-of-the-art life-prolonging treatments, get our information from medical professionals who orchestrate and administer the various therapies. The specialists do their best to describe the side effects and the range of possible outcomes but it is up to the patients to figure out how to manage and make the best of their substantially altered lives. Ms. Gubar contributes enormously to this onerous task thanks to her redirected skills as a great communicator.', 'I have been reading your essays for a while now, and enjoy them immensely. My spouse is a physician here @ MD Anderson . While he doesn\'t specialize in your specific cancer I always pass along your works so he has a view from the patients side of things. Thank you, keep writing and wishing you a good "OM"', 'Excellent description of the challenges of the post-treatment ‘uncertain’  situation of cancer survivors.  Thank you for articulating the situation of survivors so eloquently. As Ms. Susan Gubar has described so beautifully, moving to stage of living  with various types of limitations- of appearance, energy level , side effects like loss of sensation in the feet- requires an equal amount of effort as taking the active treatment. I am  a professional working with cancer survivors and also a  cancer survivor, I find that each person has her/his way of addressing the uncertainities of life. One thing is certain for almost all people in this situation- life is not the same , as before the illness.  One of the areas many people find difficult is to respond sensibly to the many symptoms without fear relapse in every situation of distress. I also find that , some way of making a spiritual sense of the illness is helpful to diminish distress of the uncertain future. Another observation of Julian Baird in the NYTimes, (Life’s three truths) to live deliberately is an excellent approach. Prof.R.Srinivasa Murthy, Bangalore.', 'Happy to see your latest post, and that maintenance, so far, is working, without added plot twists.  Are going to bring these posts together in a book? I think your honest guide to the brutal voyage you\'ve been on would be a help to countless well meaning friends and relatives. It\'s hard to imagine an adult who has any familiarity with cancer to remark that you\'re "cured" - - denial and fear run very deep, I guess.  And a dreadful admission - I\'m so glad that I have my problems which don\'t include everlasting debilitating treatments. Thanks again for the well written truth.']
summary: Commenters share their experiences and similarities with their battles with cancer and its challenges after treatment, thanking the author for sharing her story. Although the types of cancer range, there is shared experience in how lasting the effects of it are, even after remission.
short_title: Headline: In Maintenance Mode, Living in the Moment   Keywords: Chemotherapy; Radiation; Drugs (Pharmaceuticals); Cancer   Snippet: I often feel relief at not being burdened by hope of a cure — like Sisyphus admiring the view from the mountain after someone stopped the boulder.
short_question: ['In Maintenance Mode, Living in the Moment  ']

query: It’s official: Donald Trump overshadows everything. Even the Super Bowl.
comments: ['I\'m at a complete loss as to how this article is presented.  "When Patriots quarterback Tom Brady can’t make it through a pregame news conference without talking about our president, it’s official: Donald Trump overshadows everything. Even the Super Bowl."   This, to me, clearly gives the impression that Tom Brady brought up Trump when that is clearly NOT  the case!  Why would you present it as such? This is the kind of reporting that thoroughly infuriates me.  Why wasn\'t it stated that Tom Brady couldn\'t make it through a pregame news conference without being ASKED about the President? THAT is the accurate statement.  Someone please help clarify why this is a "good" article when it misrepresents the FACTS.  I think Trump is the worst thing to happen to the world since AIDS but he is right in his assertions about the media and this article clearly shows that.', "My first podcast. Blaming Obama for Yemen? Really? The plan was the military's. The decider was the President. And, he decides over dinner? And, on a more trivial note, the header that Trump Trumps the Superbowl when the first thing you hear is anti-Trump chants, and then goes on to question how Lady Gaga, who is opposed to Trump, will deal -- despite heavy constraints on her communication? This journalism is not balanced. And, pretty shallow to boot. I won't be listening to MB anytime soon in the future.", 'Michael Barbaro is the voice of reputable journalism.  Hope to be seeing The Daily on Stitcher soon.', 'I love The Daily. Keep it up. You are doing a great job.', 'Michael,  I was disappointed with the coverage of the Yemen raid this morning. Heavy-handed analysis of Trump was delivered with sparse attempts at nuance. For one thing, this was not the Bay of Pigs (a worse disaster by far), but for another thing, not everything is suddenly Trump\'s fault because he\'s oppositional to a left of center press corps. Being the final arbiter matters, surely, but you\'ve overplayed your hand on this one and that hurts you and all of us. One would hope you would have treated Secretary Clinton in a similar fashion had she been elected. I understand that Trump is hitting the press hard with charges of "fake news," but that\'s exactly the reason to remain as fair as possible. Don\'t go out of your way to make this guy look bad. He does enough of that on his own. I expect better next time, I\'ve been listening since the beginning of the Run-Up.', 'The Podcast link will work from any device- not just a phone. You need not play it through the browser. iTunes on a Mac or Windows will download the Podcast for use on your computer or can be synced to any mobile device.', 'Hi there. I just wanted to say that i heard all episodes since the beginning of the show and find them very interesting.Thank´s for the information. Greetings from Argentina.', "I have a long commute, so I was eager to give your new feature a whirl--the first podcast I've ever listened to, btw.  (Just trying to figure out the Play Music thing on my phone was a challenge.)  Anyway, love it!!  I'm on the road at 5:30 AM, so each morning I'll be waiting for your next installment.  Informative, concise, and validating.  Thank you thank you thank you!"]
summary: Several commenters are disappointed with the author, stating that he misrepresents the facts about Tom Brady and Trump during the Super Bowl and has biased reporting of Yemen. Other commenters, on the other hand, thank Michael Barbaro for his great journalism and podcasts. One commenter explains how to download the podcast.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Super Bowl; Yemen; Trump, Donald J   Snippet: It’s official: Donald Trump overshadows everything. Even the Super Bowl.

query: The board has a responsibility to protect residents with regulations.
comments: ['As an attorney replied for another NYT column, residents "have a right to the quiet enjoyment of their apartments." However, many commenters here seem to be saying that residents do NOT have such a right.   You know what?  Tell it to the judge.', 'I wonder if the co-op could countersue the parents for negligence.', "I was such a kid.  I remember (with great fondness) running down the coop's stairs from the 6th floor to the first, taking the elevator up and then doing it again.  It felt like flying.  No one complained, thank you neighbors for your tolerance.", 'Unless the co-op has a large outdoor space, the common areas should not be used as play areas for children and that includes the entry way and foyer. If there is a large outdoor space for kids to potentially play, it should be stipulated in the co-op rules whether this is permissible. Ideally, the kids should be supervised. Unfortunately, unless everything is spelled out in writing, some people will take advantage. Sad but true. There are some people who will let their kids scream, yell, run around and throw tantrums without consideration to others. In NYC, that\'s just the way it is. And to the commenters who say, "kids need a place to play." Yes, they do. Take them to the park - which I realize involves time that the parents either don\'t have or don\'t wan\'t to spare. But that\'s too bad. They\'re your children and they need to run around. That\'s what kids do. I lived on a ground floor apartment in NYC for two years and most people were considerate, however there were also some who used the common areas as personal play spaces for their kids. So I could hear kids screaming and yelling at various times. I learned to live with it but I also hated it.  So I moved to Sacramento and I don\'t have that problem anymore. Overall, people here are more considerate and I live in a really quiet, small apartment complex. After living in NYC for 14 years, it is heaven and I don\'t have to deal with children screaming (i.e. "playing") just outside my door and parents telling me it\'s ok.', 'And NYC is so much happier you are living in Sacramento. Clearly, you have never raised children.', 'I guess there are no children in Sacramento?', "I practice personal injury law on behalf of injured parties for a living and have done so for over thirty years.  I'm not liscensed in New York and obviously don't know the exact law in NY, but it seems to me that unless the law there is very unusual, the answer given overlooks one important concept -- the person suing on behalf of the child must prove some negligence on the part of the coop, or some premises defect. Yes, under certain circumstances, not having appropriate rules, or not enforcing the rules you have might be considered negligence, but that standing alone isn't a terribly compelling case. I think if the coop uses good common sense, takes care of its premises, and provides an adequate safe place somewhere on premises for the kids to play, that should be enough to avoid losing on most claims. And in case some one really screws up, you should have adequate insurance.", 'If the coop allows families with children to live there, thye should make it clear from day one the rules, what areas if any are play areas, and state that the care of the children lies with the parents, not the coop. They should enforce the rules as well. It is the parents responsibility when choosing where to live, to account for play areas; the universe does not owe their offspring  anything.', 'Hillary would say, "It takes a village," but she sure as heck never had to worry about childcare for many decades now.', 'The universe does owe our future generations something, but the particular people in each particular coop may not want to play a role.', "How sad to live in a place where children playing in hallways and stairwells are seen as nothing more than an accident waiting to happen - or, more to the point, a potential liability. Most people living in places where children place in common areas as a matter of course, without the hand wringing and claims of lack of responsibility of parents. If the kids are making inappropriate amounts of noise that are bothersome to other tenants, then I can understanding a gentle admonishment to quiet down. If they're tripping or threatening neighbors, then definitely complain. But none of that seems to be the case. Again, how sad to live in a place like this!", "You're forgetting that one of the joys of living in America is knowing that you can be sued for anything.  You can be sure that if any child were hurt, the Coop would be sued.", 'Madame, what is your personal tolerance for having kids screaming past your door.    Buildings I know where kids play a lot in the halls look beat up and dirty.  Condo and coop owners have a right to push back against hallway play on that ground alone.   How about seniors trying to make their way back to their units?   How sad you think the common  space is their playground.  Reminds one of what some dog owners think of the great outdoors and the rights of their pets.', "I grew up in the NY suburbs in a garden apartment.  We rarely played in the hallways.  There was a lot of outdoor space for us to race around in, plus our parents would have hollered at us and/or chased us outside.   We did not want to get into trouble, so we obeyed.  I realize it is different in NYC where space is a precious commodity but also think if parents must live in an elevator building, it is up to them to keep them safe and occupied.  If something is broken, like a stair step, and it gets reported to the co-op board, it should be fixed immediately or an orange cone placed in the spot pending the repair.  That's when things can get tricky is someone subsequently gets hurt.", "Is the coop liable?  Well, they need insurance.  Lots of insurance.  But they are not really at fault, the damn kids and their parents are!   And, yes, kids play and run and yell, that's what they do.  We all know that, and if they do so in the hallway, cut them some slack, you were a kid once too.", "This is a very good question but the answer seems to say parents are not responsible.  It's the same with pets.  Pet owners think hall ways are pet play areas and ignore clear rules.  Hallways get damaged and nothing happens.  Complaints are faced with stony silence because pets are sooo cute.   Parents and pet owners should be the responsibilities.", 'This is why we have 5000 square foot houses.  Because today there must be a "place" for everything, whether children playing or dogs being washed or present wrapping. In a dense urban environment, all spaces should be inherently multifunctional.  Playing in the entry way of an apartment building is probably the most common sense idea one could come up with.  And I\'m sure older kids will have much more fun with a ball and some chalk and a brick wall than some sterile "playroom" which will quickly fill with toddlers and overprotective parents.  Wow, playing ball outdoors without adult supervision -- these children are out of control.', "If someone gets hurt, someone else must be at fault.  Sue everybody and see what happens.  It's the American way.", "I raised three children in a co op and the thought of suing someone if my kid go hurt from playing in the halls or falling down the stairs is ludicrous. First of all kids should not be playing in the stairwells or in the halls; take then outside. I say sue the parents for disturbing the peace; it is called PARENTING for God's sake.", 'Commenter Ian Maitland makes good points about parental responsibility, though I have to wonder about the consistency of that concept with his suggestion for democracy as the best rule for cooperative living arrangements.  We have many, many thousands of community and condo associations in the U.S. today, and they\'re often something of a legal mess in part because they conceptualize themselves as mini-municipalities with over-meddling, oddball covenants, conditions and restrictions administered by whoever happens "democratically" or otherwise to capture the governance system.  When you\'re talking about intimate human associations, we\'d probably be better off starting on another template like the ones used by successful teams, business units, or even religious organizations.  The political/legal model doesn\'t work real well, writ small.', "Parent's and or Caregivers should be held responsible.", "I am troubled by this analysis. While it nominally acknowledges the responsibility of parents and caregivers to find appropriate places for children to play, the bulk of the piece is devoted to the board's/shareholders' responsibilities. That is part of the long trajectory away from parental responsibility toward collective responsibility. Don't overlook the fact that the parents and the shareholders are one and the same. If some parents want the coop to set aside a place for children to play, then they should persuade other shareholders and the board to do that. There is no a priori duty for the coop or board to provide such a space -- it is a matter for the coop to determine democratically in accordance with the coop's articles of incorporation and by-laws. Conceivably such a space might be impractical or too costly.  Indeed, (from a moral standpoint) the onus was on the parents, when they bought the coop, to make sure there was a space for children to play.", "I concur with Sam. I believe Mr. Maitland, you are missing the point.  In the future you may age, and low and behold, that child you denied a sensible play location is now a physician, nurse, teacher of your grandchildren or second or third family's children, with a lack of community responsibility for future generations. Get a grip Mr. Maitland, please. America survives because we all survive and thrive. Yes, parents have responsibilities, but so does society if you want to have a future society. Is it too much to ask you Mr. Maitland to extend kindness of the heart to a child playing in a common area. It is not important if that child is fatherless or motherless for that matter secondary to death or disability. Needlless to say, the law cannot nor is it intended to right every wrong but the law exists to insure a level playing field so that we can all exist as individuals within the American society.", 'This assumes that people either (i) have children before they buy a coop or (ii) that thereafter they will not have children. Not even the most rigid coop board I know forbids people from having children. People have this annoying way of meeting, moving in together, and then having kids. Then they have to rearrange their lives around these kids and, in New York, abandoning a hard-won coop is often not economically practical.', "Now everyone is responsible for everyone else's children? I use birth control to avoid the possibility of being a parent, perhaps these irresponsible parents should have done them same. You want kids? Then own up to your responsibilities and leave the rest of us in peace."]
summary: Most commenters are critical of the parent's reaction and feel that the parents should be held responsible rather than the co-op. Some commenters suggest that the co-op should set more clear rules for where play is allowed and enforce those rules consistently.
short_title: Headline: Is a Co-op Liable if Children Get Hurt Playing in the Common Areas?   Keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential); Accidents and Safety   Snippet: The board has a responsibility to protect residents with regulations.
short_question: ['Is a Co-op Liable if Children Get Hurt Playing in the Common Areas?  ']

query: Mainstays such as Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz are gone, providing the next generation of players an opportunity to write a new chapter in an old feud.
comments: ['Until the 70\'s there was no "rivalry."  Until the late 60\'s, the Yankees just won.  Red Sox, White Sox, Indians, Tigers...who cared?  Their fate was to battle for second place!  We (Yankee fans) only learned to despise Boston in the 70\'s when Red Sox nerds were naive enough to come into The Stadium wearing Boston colors and then had the gall to complain when someone poured beer on their heads.', 'Maybe no rivalry on the Yankee fans part, but there has always been hatred of the Yankees by Boston fans  going back to the destruction of the ball club by Harry "No, No Nanette" Frazee in the 20\'s.', '.."intense mini-dramas that were so common in the previous decade.." How right you are, and they were so common that it seemed as if MLB\'s Game of the Week" always carried a Sox-Yankees lengthy slugfest that produced monster ratings. Even the so-called fair weather fan knew when these to teams played.', 'As a division one athlete living in Boston, it is clear the rivalry between the Red Sox and Yankees exists less on the diamond and more in the hearts of fans. It is apparent in my life that rivalry drives both teams to be better, and I think this will become clear with a decrease of success if the fans of both of these teams do not continue the rivalry with the new players leading these the Red Sox and Yamkees.', "As a Red Sox fan, born and bred to hate the Yankees, I think the rivalry is alive and well. Yankee fans have consistently downplayed the rivalry with the Red Sox, but if you've been to Yankee Stadium during a Red Sox game, you know it's not the case. And lest we forget, the greatest choke in sports history belonged to the Yankees in 2004, when they blew a 3 - 0 game lead in the ALCS, and the Red Sox finally ended the curse of the Bambino.
