Well greatest choke in sports history until the Atlanta Falcons met the Patriots in the Super Bowl and figured out how to blow a 25 point lead with 17 minutes left in the game. Maybe the Falcons and Yankees can get together and debate who choked the most.  I'd buy a ticket to that event.", 'I’ve lived in both New York and Boston, and believe that historically the  “great  rivalry” between the Rex Sox and Yankees was much more in the minds of Boston fans than in the minds or Yankee fans, since until 2004 when the Red Sox finally won the World Series the Yankees had 23 Titles and the Rex Sox had not won one in 83 years.', 'hmcnally  ....  Good reply.', 'Have to disagree. I was at games in the early 90s when neither team was any good and Yankee Stadium would be 2/3 empty for Red Sox games but the fans who were there hated the Red Sox. And were belligerent about it. A Red Sox hat or Jersey was an open invitation for harassment. There were cheers in the right field bleachers that include "Red Sox suck" even when the Yankees were playing someone else.', 'Like Celtics vs. Knicks?', 'With the aging of the baseball audience, these tensions between clubs may seem childish. Just get out there and play your hearts out.', "The rivalry was all about the Yankees prevailing over the Red Sox, whether in taking the pennant - and watching Ted Williams lose his third Triple Crown - on the last day of the 1949 season or the playoff game to decide the 1978 Eastern Division champions in the American League.  It seemed that when it counted most, the Yankees came out on top. Then came 2004.  In the year after the Yanks won the AL championship series in the 11th inning of Game 7, the Red Sox came back from a 3-0 game deficit to win four straight and go on to win the World Series for the first time since 1918. When the Red Sox won again in 2007 and 2013, the Yankees weren't a factor as the Red Sox weren't when the Yanks won the Series in 2009.  The rivalry's been dead for years; that upon which is was built is gone.", "All your facts are correct, but your conclusion is wrong.  The rivalry still exists.  Its origins were with Babe Ruth being sold to NY by Boston and then fueled by unprecedented success by any baseball franchise and arguably matched only by the Boston Celtics in sports itself.  When Boston did finally win in 2004, things changed but more because Boston had won the World Seies than by their having come from behind against NY in the ALCS after having choked in extremis the previous year against NY.  The real difference is in its current intensity which I attrribute to free agency. Everything changed after 1975.  Th eplayers for each team genuinely hated each other.  Are you old enough to remember Fisk and Munson going at it full tilt one game?  That wasn't just about violating some unwritten rule of the game.  That was about hatred.  Now to be honest, I do not venerate hatred and I despise violence, but I was a lot younger then and it was easier to think that stuff was important.  In an odd almost embarrassing way, it was fun.  I still think that the rivalry is fun; it's just not important anymore. And PS: I love the Upper West Side.", "Actually, I'm old enough to remember Yogi Berra's watching Bill Mazeroski's home run sail over the wall at Forbes Field in the bottom of the ninth in Game 7 of the 1960 Series.   As much as I love the Yankees, I'm in love with the game.  Not only do I remember the Munson-Fisk incident, I remember more fondly when during an exhibition against the White Sox, Deion Sanders (in his rookie season with the Yanks) hit a high pop that could've gone fair or foul, but everyone watching pretty much took it for granted that Fisk would make the catch.   When Sanders pretty much stood there - and after the catch was made - Fisk ripped into Sanders about not running out the ball.  He hounded the kid all the way back to the dugout and when Sanders was looking for some kind of comfort from his teammates, he received none. And, should the Yanks and Sox find themselves fighting for a division championship or LCS, only then will I consider it a rivalry once again.", "The Red Sox - Yankees have such a colorful history going back over 100 years that it is hard to ignore even when neither team is good.  This year both teams may be good enough.  More important, MLB is better off as a whole when they are both good.  For those who regularly watch the standings no matter where they may live, it's a reason to peek at the AL East each day.  And the rivalry does run deep with odd tributaries.  By example, Boston fans hate Orioles' manager Buck Showalter not so much because he is obnoxious, which he is, but because he formerly managed the Yankees."]
summary: Many commenters feel that the historic rivalry between the Red Sox and the Yankees is actually a rivalry between the fans, rather than the actual team members. They recall people pouring beer on the opposing team's fans and harassing people for wearing the opposing team's hats. One commenter says that the rivalry will continue to exist despite changes in the team rosters, like that of the Celtics and the Knicks. Some commenters think that these tensions should be abandoned entirely, letting the teams focus on the game, while others think it motivates the players.
short_title: Headline: Yankees-Red Sox, a Grizzled Rivalry, Gets a Fresh-Faced Makeover   Keywords: Baseball; New York Yankees; Boston Red Sox   Snippet: Mainstays such as Alex Rodriguez and David Ortiz are gone, providing the next generation of players an opportunity to write a new chapter in an old feud.
short_question: ['Yankees-Red Sox, a Grizzled Rivalry, Gets a Fresh-Faced Makeover  ']

query: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists is the newest group to recommend that doctors wait to clamp and cut the cord of newborns.
comments: ['At Michael Reese Hospital Medical Center in 1962 the OB waited to cut the umbilical cord to provide the baby with as much cord blood as possible. Again the date 1962.', 'Great to see this coverage, as iron is so important for the infant  brain.   Would love to see graphic artists find another symbol for infancy (e.g. Footprints, rubber ducks, rocking chair...)as breastmilk is  also important for infants. NYT please find another graphic.', 'I graduated medical school class of 58. At that time the practice was to \'milk" the umbillical cord to deliver more blood to the newborn. Later the prevailing opinion turned to consider the overload of iron to the newborn as potentially harmful. It seems that opinion and practice swing back and forth, based on solid reasoning and meager research data,', 'My niece and nephew were born in the early 1990s. Both were delivered by a midwife who delayed in cutting the cord for several minutes to allow the blood to return to the baby. Also, if there is a breathing problem, the baby is still receiving oxygenated blood if the cord is not cut. Why is it taking this long for the medical profession to even investigate this issue? Birth is a natural process which doctors have turned into a disease. They want to take control even if it goes against common sense.', "I learned this practice in nursing school in the 70s, especially for premies. I doubt anyone should worry that their term baby's cord was cut immediately. As a student nurse I was usually handed the placenta to examine for completeness, and I learned that after pregnancy and delivery that is one worn-out organ.", "There's a few smug comments here chiding doctors and praising midwives, as though they belong to different species. Everyone in the delivery room is working from a perspective of best outcome for mother and child, based on intensive training and the latest science and technology. The previous preference for clamping, while possibly misplaced, was to prevent life-threatening haemorrhaging in the mother. Sure, as someone said, we gave birth in caves for millenia, but maternal and infant deaths are today (in the developed world) the lowest in human history. We left the caves for a reason, people - everything evolves, even science.", 'Midwife deliveries are great until they are not. When they are not (which can happen quickly), you want (need) a doctor ( now). IMHO, If you go that route please have a team that includes a doctor in a birthing center that offers everything you need. You  are being selfish (to your child\'s potential detriment)  if you don\'t (IMHO). I don\'t need to read any comments since the guaranteed great midwife, bad doctor, awesome personal experience are all below. True? Be careful, I\'ve heard what gets transferred to the ER from "birthing centers"...', 'There used to be a program on TV called Maternity Ward. It was filmed in a hospital associated with Yale School of Medicine. Some babies were delivered by doctors and some by midwives in rooms right next to each other. It was amazing at the differences between the care the women received during delivery. One would never imagine the staff could be trained in the same institution and practice in the same hospital. No, I am not writing about cases where there was some medical emergency, but ordinary deliveries.', 'The major reason for the decrease in maternal infant deaths was the introduction of antibiotics in medicine.', 'To quote HB Atlee, our beloved  outspoken prof of OB at Dalhousie Medical School, from his c1957 text Gist of Obstetrics: "CUTTING THE CORD:  Until now the baby has been left attached to the mother by the umbilical cord.  It is the practice of many doctors to cut the cord immediately the baby is born.  This is not a good thing to do, for the following reason:  If you leave the baby attached it gets from the placenta, as long as the cord continues to pulsate throughout its entire length, the equivalent of one or two blood transfusions (50-200cc.).  This blood is surely better in the baby than in the slop-pail.  But God has placed so thick a fog in some medical minds that they cannot see this: perhaps God has done this to you; too bad!  When the cord blanches, and stops pulsating except near the baby, you can cut if off after tying it about an inch from the baby.  Tie it with tape, not string.  String will cut through a friable cord like a knife.  Only in Rh negative babies whose mothers have been sensitized do you cut the cord immediately:  in those cases always tie the cord about 8 inches from the baby so that transfusions can be given into the umbilical vein." What goes around comes around.', 'So delayed cord clamping is okay now that the very same professional organizations who advocated the opposite -- not for years but for many decades -- say so?  Be afraid, be very afraid, of traditional obstetrics practice.  Look to midwifery to lead the way, as it has, decades ahead of the professional obstetrics organizations.  Not just on cord clamping but on every last aspect of obstetrics that deviates from human evolutionary practice.', '“Be afraid, be very afraid?   “Look to Midwifery!” Sure I have a fetus with shoulder dystocia (Shoulder presentation vs head or foot or butt presentation) which is an UNDELIVERABLE position.  That fetal heart rate goes down to 60 I WANT A DOC THERE TO DO A QUICK C-SECTION. Why on earth is it necessary to “take sides?”  There certainly is enough work to go around.  Here in the USA our infant mortality rate is abysmal.  In Texas where they defunded Planned Parenthood--therefore pregnant moms aren’t getting pre-natal care, the mortality rate (death of baby and/or death of mother) has DOUBLED. Instead let’s all work together FOR THE BEST CARE OF THE PATIENTs! Having  been an Army nurse in Vietnam, then an ICU RN, then NP then off to medical school I have seen all sides of the issue--oh yeah and being a mom. So let’s stop the in-fighting!  OK?   Instead we should be writing our members of congress to NOT repeal the Affordable care Act.  You want to get on a soapbox?  Let’s keep insurance for ALL Americans and not just the Trump families and the top 10% of earners. We need universal coverage, nationalized child care, universal pre-K, and maternity and paternity leave as every other modern country has except for us. Susan you may be fortunate enough to be able to choose a midwife.There are WAY too many women who are NOT getting pre-natal care at all.  And for those who dislike immigrants,I’d rather be doing pre-natal care for an immigrant than having $10 million NICU infant.', 'I’m a midwife and an advocate for home birth, evidence-based practice and women’s absolute right to make informed decisions regarding their health and birth choices, and I am concerned by your comment. While I acknowledge the horrendous practices in the history of obstetrics, I have worked with amazing obstetricians who are incredibly skilled and supportive of midwives and women, and I believe anti-obstetrics language ultimately harms our cause and the women we serve.  This is a great recommendation (if a bit delayed) by ACOG and should be recognized as a positive thing—obstetricians may have been trained differently than midwives, but their ultimate goal is helping women and babies. I’m proud of how midwifery has led the way, but I also value the life-saving advances of modern medicine. When you criticize “every last aspect of obstetrics that deviates from human evolutionary practice,” are you suggesting we not intervene to save women and babies? We thankfully don’t see it much in high-income countries, but too many women and newborns around the world still die because they lack the care we take for granted. This does not excuse the real problem of obstetric over-intervention or invalidate the beauty of natural birth, but if we don’t recognize the real risks of childbirth and respect the skills of obstetricians, we are doing a disservice to women.', 'Necrotizing enterocolitis would be more accurately described as "life threatening" than "serious."', 'The brain takes on iron until around the age of 26.  That is why some believe that young teens, etc., are impulsive, as the brain is not fully developed.', "According to a presentation by Dr. Nicholas Fogelson (see You Tube), a baby only has 60% of its blood supply at birth.  By waiting 3 minutes, it has almost 100%.  Early cord clamping/cutting coincided with women who were heavily medicated during labor and gave birth to medically depressed babies who needed stimulation and sometimes resuscitation.  With so many women opting for natural birth or epidurals, this is no longer an issue.  When my grand daughter was born, she got some meconium in her respiratory tract.  They did not cut the cord until 5 minutes after birth, and then began clearing her airway.  She pinked up quickly, and stayed pink during the procedures.  25 minutes later, still grunting a little, she was laid on her mother's abdomen, and within 10 minutes began breastfeeding.  There was no more grunting or any indication of any respiratory problem after that point.  One of the nursery nurses was advocating taking her to the NICU for obsevation, but thankfully the other nurse was recently certified as a midwife and  understood the benefits of delayed cord clamping and skin to skin contact with the mother.   As the doula, and RN childbirth educator and lactation consultant, I was pleased with how the baby was cared for.", 'so docs needed evidence before they would allow delay in cutting, but they didn\'t need any evidence to assert that immediate cutting must be good for the mom? surrounding birth in particular compared with other medical disciplines, there is a lack of evidence-based medical thinking. and probably not enough "if it ain\'t broke don\'t \'fix\' it" common sense.', 'I\'m a layman in this regard but it makes sense to me.  Humans, in our current form, have been giving birth for well on two hundred thousand years.  In caves, on the ground in fields, trees and beds.  Everywhere.  Immediate cord clamping and the like have only been practiced for....what....less than 100 years?  I think it wise, wherever possible, to defer to the practices proscribed by \'ol Mother Nature.  There\'s probably a good reason why "she" does a slow shut-down on the child\'s primary coupling, the umbilical, to the mother.  It\'s been the main conduit, the source of all health and nutrition from the mother, until birth.  This article infers there might be a VERY good reason.  We should conduct ourselves, with our infants, more wisely than we have these past few decades. Just some thoughts. John~ American Net\'Zen', "And once again midwifery protocol leads the way.  Even the notion that one must cut the cord in a case of respiratory depression begs the question of why one must take away the source of oxygen right when the newborn is in the most need. Baby needs oxygen? Well there's 2-4 minutes worth of richly oxygenated blood right there in the placenta. Plenty of work can be done by the mothers side. She's warm and her voice is there. Warming tables are a convenience, not a necessity", "I've always thought about this:  My son was born full term, with mom taking all of the prenatal vitamins and doing every other healthy thing recommended during her pregnancy... no complications pre-birth... the pregnancy went very well.  When he was born though, he had aspirated some meconium, so he wasn't breathing.  The doc cut his cord right away and another doc quickly took him to another room to suction him.  She came back (in what seemed like forever) but probably in reality, five or ten minutes later, with my son crying like a newborn.   For the first two years he was a difficult baby, to say the least.  At two years he was diagnosed with autism.  He's now ten (still autistic).  I was always wondering about the doctor's decision to cut the cord before he was breathing on his own... If a baby is still able to get oxygen from the placenta when the cord has not yet been cut, why cut it if the baby can't breath on his own yet?  Why not set up the suction machine right next to the bed, where the baby could still be attached to the cord?  Could my son's brain have been deprived of oxygen in that five or ten minutes that he was out of the room getting suctioned? Could his autism have been avoided if he was still attached to mom and a source of oxygen?", 'We saved the cord blood from our twins and still have it frozen after more than a decade, for possible use in the future for serious illness or injury. Very, very unlikely to need it, but feels better to have a stash.  On the other hand, there are compelling arguments against the idea -  http://www.parents.com/pregnancy/my-baby/cord-blood-banking/the-cord-blo...', 'I had asked about delayed cord clamping with my son, but my doctor said since we were banking the cord blood, delayed clamping would not be possible. Does anyone have further information on that?', 'When I was training as a midwife, decades ago, we were told to allow the cord to stop beating before cutting it. This was not only to allow blood to continue to flow into the baby from the still attached placenta, but also, and probably more importantly, to insure adequate oxygen levels, especially if there was any delay in the infant breathing. The cord stops functioning on its own when the baby no longer needs it for life support. Considering the benefit to blood and oxygen, I find it astonishing, in a bad way,  that anyone would cut the cord so quickly. What is the big rush?']
summary: Almost every commentator agrees that cutting the cord immediately after birth is a harmful practice. Several commentators note that it allows the baby to receive more blood and gives better outcomes. One commentator preserved the blood from the cord in case of a life-threatening emergency. Another commentator remarks that a particular "serious" condition is actually life-threatening. One commentator takes the opposite side and defends doctors' practices.
short_title: Headline: Doctors No Longer Rush to Cut the Umbilical Cord   Keywords: Premature Babies; Pregnancy and Childbirth; Midwives and Doulas; Doctors   Snippet: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists is the newest group to recommend that doctors wait to clamp and cut the cord of newborns.
short_question: ['Doctors No Longer Rush to Cut the Umbilical Cord  ']

query: Monday: A tradition in Brooklyn, April the Giraffe gives birth, and Duchamp’s “Fountain” turns 100.
comments: ["I grew up on the South Side of Chicago in the mid 1940's and '50's when Polish was the language of the streets. A remarkable time in many ways,it's no longer Polish and the Mom & Pop stores are pretty much gone,as in most Big City neighborhoods. All the food mentioned in the article --and much more-- was something we had on our table throughout the week. I miss it a lot. A couple of years ago,I went to Cracow for a look/see and gorged on all my old favorites; and the Polish beer ! There was even an unpretentious restaurant that served ONLY Pierogi ! A city full of beautiful Polish women and handsome men...and you can't get a bad meal. Go now !", 'Canadiens canuck Rangers', 'A urinal? Really? Art? Then I guess art means anything  ... literally.', "Not to worry. The bad and stupid stuff disappears ... eventually. If I'm not mistaken, DuChamp et freres have pretty much been discounted now. But it can be fun, if you don't take it too seriously—or buy any of it!", 'If Greenpoint has a particular culture, it is definitely Polish, although the community was basically settled from the 1870s on by Irish, Italian and Polish immigrants. However, except for the period from the 1930s to the 1950s, Poles have continued to come here and still do, which is why you hear so much Polish spoken by young people on the streets and in the stores, whereas when I was a kid in the 1940s and 1950s, only the older Polish population spoke Polish. This is a very good thing for the neighborhood (which has always been one of the safest and most law-abiding in New York), as even with the gentrification, it remains largely unchanged ethnically from what it was, say, 55 or 60 years back. Oh, by the way, it would seem that everybody from Poland comes here legally. It can be done!', "Many (most?) Polish immigrants in recent decades came as political refugees during the era of Solidarity.  And there were (and are) plenty of undocumented Poles in the U.S. Undocumented immigrants couldn't have come legally obviously; no one would willingly choose such an expensive and difficult path if it could be done legally.", 'being of Polish descent has its benefits: kielbasa, stuffed cabbage,pierogies etc. Easter, Christmas, Thanksgiving: all of the above are eaten!', 'Just love that mustard that gives you the memorable feeling of your head exploding; I think the key ingredient is that it is a fresh mix of potent seeds.', 'My dad was a Brooklyn Pole - grew up on N 6th street in Williamsburg/Greenpoint before his parents bought a row house in Elmhurst in the \'60s. That part of Brooklyn was so Polish that he literally didn\'t speak a word of English until he went to school at age 6. Up till my dad passed, we always went to the market in Greenpoint for real kielbasa. But this article kind of buries the truth at the end. People who have "discovered" Greenpoint in the last 20 years love the Polish local character, but the largest Polish communities today are really Maspeth and Ridgewood. Those are the real Little Polands in 2017.', 'If I go home and throw water on my wife today to celebrate "Wet Monday", this will become couch patrol week, because that is where I\'ll be sleeping.', 'For the "In the News" item on April the giraffe, and in tribute to the Weather forecast song link - wondering about sitcom possibilities for a giraffe sensation.  Tune of The Brady Bunch theme Here\'s a story of a gal named April And the news that we just can not leave alone We had thought that she was due In the winter And kept watch on our phone.  Here\'s the story of her brand new baby Who weighed in at like a hundred twenty nine His long legs and longer neck Are like his mother\'s And he is doing fine.  And now one day the new calf will have a naming And we wondered as we had our Easter brunch If the zoo could keep the chat up for this fam\'ly And we all will tune in for The April Bunch The April Bunch The April Bunch We\'ll all tune in to watch The April Bunch.', "Thanks, Freddie!  this is a laugh out loud song, much needed after last week, yikes. plus, babies, a cute little 100lb baby here's hoping for a better week in the world", 'My sister used to live in Jamaica Queens. I would visit her occasionally and we would go "Polish Food Shopping" for stuff I could take back with me. We went to a place in Ridgewood which was close to where we\'d grown up off Wyckoff Avenue in Bushwick. My sister retired and left and I really haven\'t a reason to go up there any more. These packages of Kielbasa by various manufacturers don\'t come close to the real thing. There is hope though as a Polish restaurant opened a mile away from my house three years ago and is a great change to the restaurant lineup here. Another opened up across town but it needs a lot of work. It was terrible. Are we Polish? No but we have international taste buds. ( My sister married a Polish Mormon once when she lived in Arizona. He\'s on wife # 7 now.) And no mention of galumpkes? (Stuffed cabbage)', 'Golabki, with the "l"pronounced like a "w" (it\'s a slashed "l" actually). Golabki are not traditionally served at Easter as far as I know. Polish Easter often involves foods cooked ahead of time.', "I stand corrected. The word is similar for the Hungarian stuffed cabbage too? I've eaten them too."]
summary: Several commenters have a Polish heritage and appreciate the traditional Polish food, and many mention kielbasa. One commenter points out that there were refugees and undocumented Polish immigrants, and another describes their Polish traditions. A couple of commenters make glib comments about the article, including mocking the art piece and suggesting a show for April the giraffe with The Brady Bunch theme song.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Easter Monday in Little Poland   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Monday: A tradition in Brooklyn, April the Giraffe gives birth, and Duchamp’s “Fountain” turns 100.
short_question: ['New York Today: Easter Monday in Little Poland  ']

query: How are voters feeling now about Mr. Trump’s presidency?
comments: ['Hey nice article peoples  YES!!!', 'One thing is for sure, President Trump is a very aggressive and very out-there president. It is going to be a very interesting four years of his presidency.', "Let's hope it doesn't last that long", "Its hard to live a normal life with this corrupt, incompetent, nasty wholly objectionable, reckless, impulsive, dangerous clown: corrupt he and his corrrupt family and sychphants-ever lining their pockets with we the taxpayer's taxes.", 'One thing that delights as many people as it disconcerts is that Trump speaks on the record the way officials usually speak off the record and appears to speak off the record as officials usually do on.']
summary: Some of the commenters are negative about the Trump presidency. One calls him aggressive while another calls him dangerous. One commenter says that President Trump speaks to reporters on the record the same way officials talk off the record and vice versa. One commenter enjoys the article but doesn't say why.
short_title: Headline: Questions for: ‘Circling Back to Voters, 100 Days Into Trump Era’   Keywords: News and News Media; Reading and Writing Skills (Education); Trump, Donald J; United States Politics and Government   Snippet: How are voters feeling now about Mr. Trump’s presidency?
