query: At heart, ‘Billions’ is a show about the benefits and limits of alpha-male aggression.
comments: ["Interesting dissection of this episode.  All of these characters sound like they're on cocaine.  Which makes their conflicts all the more inevitable and fascinating.", '"Barely Legal" has always been a wink-wink term in the porn industry, as in "is she or isn\'t she?". Wags is correct in the usage.', "Great recap Scott.  Just want to add that I think Taylor Mason could be a really important character this season.   The show is basically about masculinity.  So far Wendy is crucial because she's immune from all the negative/toxic/weak aspects of masculinity.  She's the grown-up that both Chuck and Bobby need.  But now we have a character that stands even further apart from masculinity, this asexual super-smart Spock-like character.   Bobby is where he is in large part because the way he sees things.  Taylor by nature sees things in a radically different way - a trait that I'm sure Bobby will appreciate.  If Wendy doesn't get back to Axe Capital, then maybe Taylor can be a good substitute, being clearheaded, helping Bobby find a way forward.", 'Yes this cinephile noticed the Nilsson/Goodfellas song, it is indelibly attached to that film and should never be used anywhere else!  Also there was another rip (reflexive or not), Wags in the bathroom snorting and eye dropping, etc, the editing/concept is somewhat à la Requiem for a Dream and the line said into the mirror "It\'s showtime..." is à la All That Jazz.  But despite those derivative notes, it was directed by a woman who is also a cinematographer- Reed Morano.  Nice.', "As the Director of Progressive Prison Ministries in Greenwich CT, the first ministry in the country created to support individuals and families with white-collar incarceration issues, I am spellbound by this show. Sure it's stylized, but it's real enough that every hedge funder I know won't miss an episode. Great fun too.  Rev. Jeff Grant, JD, M Div Progressive Prison Ministries Greenwich CT & Nationwide prisonist.org", "Are there any characters on this show who are the slightest bit human?  I just can't see anything redeemable in any of these characters, and the exhausting ways of trying to shock with new uses of vulgar language is boring. Best of luck to Showtime, I am exhausted at trying so hard to care.", "We actually have seen Chuck and Wendy's kids. Season 1 they were both with Chuck getting ice cream in a park when Chuck was approached by someone he convicted. They were also both excused from the dinner table in one episode and their son was in a scene where Axe introduced the son to his favorite athlete.", '"That both men are so keen to fight on, despite the obvious personal and professional consequences, speaks to the psychology at the heart of “Billions,” a show about the benefits and limits of alpha-male aggression." Or it could simply be to provide a story for Season Two, which promises to be even more ludicrous and laughable than Season One. You are aware that "Billions" (like most narrative TV series) is fiction, aren\'t you, Mr. Tobias? When something wildly improbably happens it\'s not so much a reflection on life or love or philosophy or gender as it is bad writing.', 'billions my hero', "I am so disappointed with first episode of season two.  With propaganda of leftist agenda: same thing over and over, transgenders, blacks watching bad whites people.  It's so boring and predictable!  I feel bad."]
summary: The commenters share their opinions about the episode and show. Several commenters mention how the characters are not relatable and likable, but one commenter argues that it's quite real for "hedge funders." The commenters generally agree that the show features a lot of strong attempts to show aggression and masculinity.
short_title: Headline: ‘Billions’ Season 2 Premiere: Neanderthals   Keywords: Billions (TV Program); Television   Snippet: At heart, ‘Billions’ is a show about the benefits and limits of alpha-male aggression.
short_question: ['‘Billions’ Season 2 Premiere: Neanderthals  ']

query: The Times’s standards editor explains our policies on identifying the alleged victims and perpetrators of sexual misconduct.
comments: ['Thank you for standing up to this horror. In Pueblo, Co. three hospitals , doctors and the judges and DA are covering up the same abuse in hospitals.  Rape of patients. We are tortured and terrified for standing up to sexual abuse. Thank you for your honesty and integrity.', "I would always wish the Times to err on the side of caution, even if it makes a story less 'interesting'.  I am always disturbed by media reports (particularly local TV news) which publish not just the name of a SUSPECT but their address.  If someone has been through due process and found guilty then expose them, but let them have the benefit of the doubt first.", "The Times' revelations are hardly the MOAB one might suppose from a glance at the headlines.    Indeed, work needs to be done to bring light to dark corners of the past and to ensure a safe environment for all going forward.    Let's not make Choate some aberration here. Sex itself has been going for for decades...even in elite boarding schools where traditions of behavorial repression are the norm....'stiff upper lip,' and all that.", 'Turn for a minute to international affairs. Think of the couple trying to escape overland from Iran/Iraq. They were named in NYT coverage. By following their progress in "real time", the NYT very likely stimulated greater government effort to capture them. Such stories lose none of their impact if they are reported as history rather than today\'s page one story.', 'While it is often salacious, and an exercise in schadenfreude... What is the rationale behind publishing the name of a suspect? If - as you state - " [A] single mention in The Times may follow someone digitally forever[,]" wouldn\'t the prudent course be to err on the side of caution, and only publish the names of those convicted? What is gained by a digital rush to judgment?  Granted, there are times when the public safety warrants getting as much information to as many people as possible, but is this always the case?  The journalistic Shield Laws protect a reporter\'s source. Shouldn\'t that same shield also protect those who are "innocent until proved guilty?" In the words of Raymond Donovan - as reported in The Times by Selwyn Raab on May 26, 1987: "Which office do I go to to get my reputation back?"', "Where the Times fails often is the inclusion of a mug shot of the alleged criminal that the story is reporting.  The suspect is usually male and named in the article.  He's been arrested and booked but no photo is in the article. Photos are usually available.  I Google the perp's name and immediately find his mug shot.  Why can't the Times?  This seems like a conscious editorial decision.  Can someone at the paper explain it?", 'curious: why the desire to see the "perp"? What if the story and the sources are wrong? known to happen. Then not only is his identification in the NYT but now his pic as well. Unless he is notorious, not necessary.', 'Perhaps because many people carry the same name, but not the same face. The issue of naming seems to be basically legal.']
summary: The majority of commentators are concerned that the Times routinely reveals private info about the accused, such as name or mug shots. Two commentators relate that sexual abuse has been happening for years in schools and hospitals. One commentator urges the Times to err on the side of caution when talking about a suspect who hasn't been convicted.
short_title: Headline: What The Times Holds Back   Keywords: Sexual Harassment; Assaults; Choate Rosemary Hall; Sex Crimes   Snippet: The Times’s standards editor explains our policies on identifying the alleged victims and perpetrators of sexual misconduct.
short_question: ['What The Times Holds Back  ']

query: Boris V. Shekhtman, who taught Russian to many budding Moscow correspondents, “looked uncannily like the bad guy in ‘Rocky and His Friends’ and ‘The Bullwinkle Show.’ We were immediately captivated.”
comments: ["This is a wonderful tribute to teacher who apparently left his mark on many students. I'm partial to Russian teachers.  I remember with great fondness my own Russian teachers, emigres from several epochs of Russian history, who gave me a very solid foundation at the Defense Language Institute in Monterey, CA, when I was in the Army, in 1969.  They were not despots, though, but it was nevertheless a superb and rigorous program.  I can still read Russian with substantial fluency today, though I've had little opportunity to use the language orally in the intervening years.   But I've kept up through reading, mostly 19th and early 20th c. literature, so my vocabulary is a little out of date.  Being able to read Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Pushkin, Tyuchev, Fet, Pasternak, Akhmatova, Bulgakov, and so many others in the original is a priceless and lifelong gift my Russian teachers (and the Army) gave me.", 'And how could I forget to mention Chekhov?', 'My wife...Natasha (named in Phil\'s segment), my daughters and I all enjoyed the Russian emersion as much as the students. A very interesting parade of immigrants dined with us regularly resulting from Boris and Natasha\'s extended Russian family including many babushkas (and ours...daughters named "Babu" for short). Russians have "soul" coming from their tough lives during WW2 and after. Our experiences with Boris and the Russian community have made our lives far richer than you can imagine. Thank you Boris!', 'Many years ago I accompanied a trade mission to then-Soviet Union. No one in the group, business executives mostly, spoke a word of Russian, but one enterprising fellow, a manufacturer of conveyor systems, had printed brochures in Russian to handout. I was there when he handed out the brochures. Looks of consternation, followed by chuckles, and then wholesale, side splitting laughter. After everyone calmed down, a government translator spotted the problem. The brochure advised those who were interested in learning more about the conveyor systems to "get a good lay" The embarrassed executive could have used one of Boris\' "islands."', "Boris Badenov was based on Akim Tamiroff, Russian veteran of the Moscow Arts Theatre. He and Maria Ouspenskaya came to the US to escape Stalin's Soviet Union.", 'I was luckier than most. Instead of Boris, who was great, I got Natasha Fatale as my teacher. DD Manhattan', "Thank you for sharing Mr. Shekhtman's story.  One of life's greatest adventures begins with learning a new language, which offers a unique threshold to understanding the world.   Goethe remarked that no man can master his own language until he has mastered another.    For journalists, whose work can reflect language applied to  its greatest purpose, the opportunity to have learned a foreign tongue with such a thoughtful teacher must have been transformational both to their craft as well as to their personal sensibility.  It is fitting that the NYT should share this man's contribution through the words of the professionals he helped.", 'This reminds me of my wonderful experience in my first year of high school, when I took my first foreign language class, Russian, in Monmouth Regional High School in New Jersey.  My teacher was Gospodzin Calabrese (sorry, don\'t know how to get the Russian letters in here). His teaching style pretty much burned Russian into my brain, and I remember every single word I learned back then.  I studied Spanish, Chinese, and Japanese after that, and to this day, when I am trying to come up with a word in those languages, the first thing that pops into my mind is the Russian word.  He was an expert in mime, and that is how he taught us. Starting the first class, he held up a pencil and said:  Eto karandash.  Then he said "Shto eto?"  And we all knew the answer was "eto karandash."  That is how we learned. Off topic, but watch the movie "2010: The Year We Make Contact."  It will endear you to Russian and Russians.  It\'s a good HIGHLY RELEVANT tall tale too!', 'The only effective Russian language teachers are despots. There is no alternative.', 'Nothing like learning another language well. That is not the goal of the learning of "scripts" by soon-to-be foreign correspondents in Russia, but nothing wrong with learning the scripts, if that is the best that one can do under the circumstance. Better than nothing certainly. Learning the fundamentals - hard, but rewarding - is the route to any level of fluency. Nice tributes to this person on his death. I hope he heard similar before dying. Russian, yes, a fabulous language with a fabulous literature. Russians themselves delightful as well.', 'I love stories like this, since I love to learn about foreign languages.  Russian is a very good language in many respects - phonetic spelling, and so on.  It has its complicated aspects, as all languages do, but if you listen to Russian speakers you may be pleasantly surprised to notice that you can hear the words clearly,  even if you do not understand their meaning.  All the letters are pronounced.', "Russian spelling is not quite phonetic.  It's better than phonetic:  it's phonemic.  The spelling of the basic elements of words nearly always remains the same, even though an individual sound may change due such factors as a shift of stress or adjacent sounds.  You need to internalize a few easy, low-level phonemic rules, but in a highly inflected language such as Russian, the phonemic (as opposed to a purely phonetic) orthography, by preserving the basic shape of the elements of words, is a big help in learning the language and in reading.", "An excellent and true insights in learning and apparently quite successfully cramming in Russian language skills during the Cold War era. I wish to be one of those free-bed-and-board volunteers at that Bethany Beach cottage:) Then, Shekhtman's teaching method looks like very effective one. It's also truth: If it is not fun ... forget it.", 'I wonder if Donald Trump ever benefited from these lessons.  After all, he just tweeted about the Bannon demotion this way:  "FAKE NEWS!  All lies from Moose and Squirrel!!"', 'Was just going to ask that -- which of the subjects was "Moose" and which one "Squirrel?"', 'Squirrel walks down street.  I drop safe on him like every self-respecting villain; who gets hit? ME!  I send lady spy with package which is really bomb; who gets blown up? me.']
summary: Many commenters discuss their enjoyment of learning languages and their appreciation of the Russian language. In particular, they agree that Russian is a great language because it is phonetic. Commenters describe their experiences learning Russian, as most of them really enjoyed their teachers and the ability to read Russian literature. Several commenters mention their experiences with Boris, the subject of the piece.
short_title: Headline: Learning Russian From ‘Boris Badenov’   Keywords: Shekhtman, Boris V; Language and Languages; Russia; New York Times   Snippet: Boris V. Shekhtman, who taught Russian to many budding Moscow correspondents, “looked uncannily like the bad guy in ‘Rocky and His Friends’ and ‘The Bullwinkle Show.’ We were immediately captivated.”
subreddit: ['Shekhtman, Boris V', 'Language and Languages', 'Russia', 'New York Times']
short_question: ['Learning Russian From ‘Boris Badenov’  ']

query: This superstar soprano has been retiring her signature roles one by one, and however her career evolves, she should be proud of this magnificent performance at the Met.
comments: ["I'm glad to hear an audience boo. It's a sign they're thinking and listening. Some updates of operas work well (Carmen updates have a long and interesting history). But Gelb has a talent for picking directors-as-authors who lack any talent for opera, especially the talent for listening to the music. Audiences, both young and old, don't attend grand opera to see what they can behold on a Broadway stage. They go to see the wonder of what a large elaborate staging can do. Opera was the inspiration for cinema. Modern stagings often reduce opera to cheap small-screen productions. No wonder the Met is going broke. When will the Board wake up?", 'Ochs was a caricature of Trump. I loved the performance.', "Thoroughly enjoyed the dress rehearsal.  However, at the opera's conclusion the young lovers should have traditionally been presented with the silver rose - more poignant than Mohammed staggering, swinging a bottle of wine. And yes, a bit too much frolicking for me. Could have been shortened.", "It's frustrating when the direction goes against the music and/or the text. But English-speaking audiences tend to over-romanticize the piece because, even with surtitles, the cynicism that runs through Hofmannsthal's text (the shallowness of Octavian, the air-headedness of Sophie, who is every inch her bourgeois father's daughter) usually fails to come through all the spun sugar. So don't weep too hard for Der Rosenkavalier, It's a nastier bit of business than you may think.", "Re: booing the production team, it's not for updating the action, but for stage business working in opposition to the music.  Particularly tone-deaf was the pointless waltzing in the background during the Presentation of the Rose.  Strauss' music perfectly capturing the time-stands-still quality of love at first sight is undermined by all the stage movement, which I found distracting and idiotic.  Special hubris award goes to a director who ignores the lighthearted spirit of the woodwind music concluding the opera, originally to depict the servant boy  searching for the Marschallin's handkerchief.  Pulling the set walls back to reveal cannons and armies has absolutely nothing to do with what is happening in the music.  I wish opera directors would LISTEN to the music before they willfully override the stage directions of theatrical geniuses like Strauss and Hofmannsthal.", "I enjoyed the production very much.  The liberties taken from the original libretto were minor and who's to say Strauss would not have appreciated a production that adds depth and stinging social commentary to his lighthearted comedy.  Opera composers have always appreciated that the aristocracy prefers social commentary to be lighthearted and farcical rather than pointed and direct, and have tailored their works accordingly, but the substance is there for a producer who wants to bring it out.", "I think the new production is a vast improvement over the 1969 one, which was well overdue for retirement. Particularly impressive was the obvious care Mt. Carsen gave to shape the interactions between the Marschallin and Octavian -- personenregie of the highest and most sensitive quality. Garanca acted the role with greater believability than I've ever seen, and Fleming was better than I've seen and heard her in many years. Carsen's track record at the Met is stronger than any other director I know -- the superb Onegin and Mefistofele, and now Falstaff and Rosenkavalier under Gelb. Hopefully they'll bring him back for a non-comedic piece soon, as I think that's where his work is strongest. I attend opera performances every few months in Europe, and while I am not a fan of much of the intrusive directorial interventions that are commonplace in European opera houses, European performances are much more successful at attracting audiences diverse in age and background. It will take more productions like this Der Rosenkavalier, which respects the libretto, but takes care to engage the mind and heart of the viewer, if the Met and other American opera companies are to cultivate the next generation of opera lovers.", 'I attended a recital by Ms. Fleming last year in Stevens Point Wi. She patronized us, asking with great skepticism if we had Live at the Met "up here?" (Yes we do, in Wausau.) Then, astonishingly, she asked for a show of hands if "any of you had ever been to a recital before?" She then proceeded to crack up on her first high note of the evening and did not revisit that part of her range for the rest of the evening, instead coyly trying to "sell" us alternate low-note endings. Not impressed at her on a personal or performing level.', "Two friends & I were at the opening & this review's praise is well deserved. It was beautiful musically, vocally & the sets & costumed worked well with the story & music, though the third act location was a little over the top, if you see it you'll see what I mean. All in all a wonderful evening of Opera", 'La Traviata.  Tosca.  Das Rheingold.  Die Walkure.  Siegfried.  Gotterdammerung.  Add to these abysmal directorial disasters another beloved, traditional opera that the Met has destroyed. Just watch the last 10 minutes and try not to cringe.', "I am sorry but Fleming's singing yesterday left a lot to be desired. It was bizarre at best. She was no match for the legendary Cheryl Studer back in '00 also at the Met. Here she is. Read the description in the video for more details: https://youtu.be/3JA9DpCuz1w", "I cannot wait until next Friday to see this from my customary seat.  This is a perfect role for Renee Fleming, even though the Marschallin is at MOST 30, having been married off to an older man when very young.  Might that have happened too in early 20th century?  Who knows.  We always have to suspend disbelief at opera.  Generous of Elina Garanca, who would be a stunning princess if the part were transposed for mezzo, to play a trouser role.  If it is Fleming's farewell to fully staged opera at our house, hail and farewell, we have always loved you.", 'The libretto says the Marschallin is 50.', 'The libretto clearly states that the Marschallin is in her thirties.', 'I think that those that booed last night (and who boo most new productions of work in the "cannon") might be those who have a preconceived and maybe ossified view of the work and how it SHOULD look. Probably because the new production forces them to confront that view which in the case of their "ideal" Rosenkavilier is all whipped cream and gold. But I think the production team carefully considered the von Hoffmansthal libretto and amplified the social and psychological aspects of the work to great effect. It was hardly over the top and was gorgeous to look at with the design amplifying the music an libretto.', 'I could not agree more. Well said! The updated setting gave it more psychological depth. Made you focus more on the social commentary that Strauss and von Hoffmansthal peppered throughout the work.', "If the production team carefully considered the von Hoffmansthal libretto, that's even more depressing.", 'I disagree that the bass lacked depth, he nearly stole the show and had an incredible voice. The first act he was less impressive but as the night went on he really impressed', "What ravishing singing from everyone-- the  sexy Ochs brought a new malevolence to the character -- making him a kind of Don Giovanni . Yes there were some mis steps in the production but I liked the heightening  of the undercurrents of the libretto- desire and death juxtaposing  military and social interactions. Look the last one was wonderful but it was 50 years old;  if nothing else it needed much repair. Thank god this new one  was not like the Traviata travesty -- or the Fidelio I went to in Munich  with Don Fernando as the joker and the singers strapped into a jungle gym, talk about booing the germans almost brought the house down . I will return to this run at least once more  since not only is Fleming leaving her role but supposedly it is Garanca's last Octavian too .", 'This production will be in the theaters as the MET HD. in May. Probably then on TV  from PBS. If you have a DVR, you can record it and if you have the equipment, transfer to a DVD. Maybe there will be a commercial DVD..', "One can be confident that the rare chorus of boos at the conclusion of a new production at the Metropolitan Opera are always for a director's off-key dramatic conception or a scenic designer's edging too far from an exciting and dramatic visual accompaniment to the composer's score to one of disregard, sometimes even bordering on disrespect, and never for the brilliant, dedicated voices on stage.  Renee Fleming and her brilliant colleagues were well aware all the bravos were for them, and most deservedly so; the boos were for the production team.", 'Rene Fleming\'s performance last night was one of peerless, heart-breaking delicacy.  And as everyone in the audience knew that this is her swan song, it was almost unbearably poignant.  Unfortunately, in heavy contrast, the production team\'s choice to conflate the Marschallin\'s passing beauty and erotic power with the historical passing of the old regime by updating the production to the days before World War I, felt painfully banal and coarse.  Instead of making the message of the opera "bigger", it minimized the personal tragedy and final wisdom of the Marschallin.  The unintended sadness of the evening came as a consequence of seeing the pathos of Rene Fleming\'s final operatic performance so badly served by an overreaching production team.  But, my God, was she wonderful, despite all that.', 'The boos were NOT for Fleming, but for the production -- at the Met, it is highly traditional to boo new productions.', "Except when they're not the misguided result of directorial arrogance.  I have been to many premieres that were justifiably cheered.", 'It was lovely last night, all of it. The ongoing "booing" from a small group of the audience was saddening.  It is a reminder that America is losing its decency.  It was especially disconcerting that it happened inside the Metropolitan Opera House, which is a monument to the Arts, and the centerpiece of Lincoln Center.  Last night was a very special night for Rene Fleming. Hopefully, our Grande Soprano heard more BRAVOS than anything else.  Respect in the Age of Trump is becoming a rarity.', "Opera audiences can be as passionate and expressive as baseball audiences. I personally don't boo what I don't like at either opera or baseball--but booing is not a recent phenomenon. Audiences used to be more demonstrative a generation ago--with cheers, boos, and flowers. My theory is that union overtime costs have made American opera companies push through any mid-scene applause that could force a production to run a few minutes over.", 'Nobody booed Ms. Fleming, or any of the other singers for that matter.', 'Maybe grand opera is losing its decency.   Also please note: (1) It was not a "small" group. (2) It was abundantly clear that Ms. Fleming and the other singers were celebrated by the audience at the curtain calls. (3) To some, it was especially disconcerting that this production happened inside the Metropolitan Opera House.']
summary: Respondents generally heaped praise on the production and on the performance of the people on stage, including Garcia and Fleming. Some despaired at the lack of respect shown by a few audience members though others mentioned that the disrespect wasn't aimed at the star performers so much as at the production team, which made some controversial choices related to staging and pointed out that boos are actually traditional anyway. Someone disagreed with the idea that the bass lacked depth. And someone saw a character as an unflattering portrayal of Trump. Someone found the show to be cringe-inducing.
short_title: Headline: In a Work About Loss, A Star Says a Farewell   Keywords: Opera; Metropolitan Opera; Fleming, Renee; Der Rosenkavalier (Opera); Garanca, Elina; Carsen, Robert   Snippet: This superstar soprano has been retiring her signature roles one by one, and however her career evolves, she should be proud of this magnificent performance at the Met.
short_question: ['In a Work About Loss, A Star Says a Farewell  ']

query: Tuesday: Performing Holocaust stories, a push for Uber tipping, and Earth Day events.
comments: ['I don\'t quite understand how Albert Kimmelstiel could have been "freed on May 2, 1945 by the American Army," when Auschwitz was liberated by the Russian Army five months earlier on 27 January 1945, as the Russians had liberated most of the death camps in Poland on their march towards Berlin. The Americans, in cooperation with the other Western Allies, attacked from the west after the D-Day landings on 6 June 1944 and did not reach the western German border until January of 1945.', 'In advance of the approaching Russian troops, the Nazis forced all those inmates still strong enough to march- out of the camp. That March is better known as The " Death March" continued on for months, Mr Kimmelstiel like thousands of others, was forced to "march" in the bitter cold in wooden shoes, through snow and freezing temperatures out of Auschwitz. The conditions were beyond brutal.  They were not liberated until early May in 1945 ( they were in Germany by this time) when their Nazi guards finally fled upon the arrival of US troops.', 'Mr. Kimmelstiel indeed left Auschwitz, January 18  prior to the liberation by the Russians. The Nazis sensing  the approach of Allied troops emptied the camps of all "able" bodied souls in advance of the Russians. Mr Kimmelstiel, along with thousands of other concentration camp inmates was forced to march through the freezing and bitter cold wearing primitive wooden shoes. Many, many died on this "Death March". Those that survived were finally liberated in early May. Mr Kimmelstiel and the other survivors endured continuous unspeakable conditions for  more than 3.5 months trekking across Poland and Germany until they were liberated by the Americans in Germany. Many of their captors fled and removed their uniforms to escape the American forces.', 'If by "Allied troops" you mean the Russians. I find your description of "sensing" somewhat strange. Perhaps they "sensed" the artillery shells that were falling near them.  I have found no evidence that any of the western allied armies went into Poland after the Russians. I don\'t know where you get this information that the Auschwitz prisoners travelled for three and a half months or that they were taken into Germany. The prisoners were, in effect, witnesses who could reveal the "secret" of the Holocaust, which the Nazis were quite eager to avoid. And they were marched to a town in Poland near the Czech border, which is a rather strange route to take if their destination was Germany.', 'My mother, too, hid for a time in a convent in Lyon. It gave me pause to wonder if they knew each other. Her name was Eva Arnheim and she would have been 93 this month.', 'Mrs. Kimmelstiel says she had no education. Perhaps not the kind of which she dreamed, but she certainly had an education in life. And the fact that she continues to try to educate others speaks to her life-long quest to continue not only her education but to instill that search in others. Thank you for highlighting her story.', "No offense. But sadly, in the course of all human history, there has been more than one Holocaust. It isn't something that belongs to any one particular group more than any other, and certainly Nagasaki and Hiroshima are in the same catagory. Let us remember them too. And pray it never happens again.", "Nonsense, N. Smith.  There is a big difference between setting out to annihilate every Jew in Europe -- men, women, and children who had done no harm -- and dropping a bomb on a Japanese island in the course of a war.  For that matter, ask the Chinese how innocent the Japanese were, and what massacres feel like. In the course of all human history, and let's count the 1.5-million Armenians, there has never been a systematic extermination of a people totaling over 6 million. If you'd like, you can count the extra 5-million gay people, Communists, anti-Nazi activists, and mentally deficient in that count.  I suppose you are counting the Palestinians who get caught when their brave terrorist warriors take shelter, and shelter their weapons, in schools and hospitals after launching missile attacks into Israel and then cry foul when the Israelis retaliate. Pretty ridiculous.", "Hate to nitpick, N. Smith, but Africans were, with the help of other Africans, usually rival tribes, imported into the American colonies in order to work, and were bred like animals to perform certain types of work.  Many died, and many were killed because of disobedience. Families were separated, and children were sold off. Pretty awful, but the fate of slaves throughout history. That still doesn't amount to a deliberate extermination of a race of people.  Frankly, slaves were too valuable to waste.  So no, Jews aren't the only ones to have suffered. But I challenge you to come up with any other episode in history that rises to the level of what happened to the Jews.", "Since WW II, the word Holocaust with a capital H has stood for the annihilation of 6 million Jews through the machinations of the Nazi war machine, solely because Hitler wanted to rid the planet of their so-called race.  This in no way belittles or ignores the sufferings of any other group--or indeed of any individual.  Throughout history every ethnic or minority group has suffered at the hands of a stronger group.  Indeed, one of the many important reasons for remembering the Holocaust is to try to make sure that such a thing never happens again to anyone.  To date, we've been pretty feeble in our efforts. So stop venting your spleen on Holocaust Remembrance, and start looking for ways to keep your neighbor safe.", '12 years? I am not questioning the importance of this story. My father, uncle and grandparents spent time under Italian and Nazi occupation during WWII. They also spent time in Bergen Belsen until they were liberated. I am familiar with the timeline of the Nazis and their occupation of France. I am just a little confused by the first sentence of this story that may lead some to understand that the Holocaust lasted 12 years. Please clarify.', 'They were forced to leave Germany when Hitler came to power in 1933 and moved to France.', 'The family fled  Germany and went to France when Hitler came to power in 1933.', 'Yankees bleach White Sox', '"Daniel L. Squadron, a state senator whose district includes Brooklyn Bridge Park, . . . demanded a detailed accounting of the bridge’s defects, faulting officials for what he called a lack of transparency." If Mr. Squadron" had "demanded" an explanation for the selling of the Cadman Plaza Library, the approval of a too-tall luxury tower in its place and the extreme downsizing of the replacement library, and had "faulted" everyone involved for "a lack of transparency," the residents of Brooklyn Heights and the surrounding areas would still have their well-used, busy library. Instead, Mr. Squadron approved the deal. Even now, despite not having put down any money, the developer is proceeding as if he had, and is demolishing the library. (No wonder Mr. de Blasio, in on this travesty, won\'t stop walking long enough to take questions.)', 'It amazes me that anyone denies the holocaust. However, there are people that still do not believe that man landed on the moon, and a flat earth society exists. So go figure?  If someone prefers to believe that six million people simply disappeared, so be it.', 'In America, more people believe in ghosts than in the laws of gravity. With that kind of population, it\'s no wonder that we\'re in the mess we\'re in.  And now that the last of our World War Two veterans are dying out, there will be no one to say, "My platoon went into the camps. It was my job to bulldoze emaciated, rotten bodies into mass graves and cover them over with soil."  Something my uncle, long gone, did, and talked about only rarely.  As for the old black-and-white footage, people will say it\'s photo-shopped.  God help us.', 'Unfortunately, such groups like that do exist.  As an Israeli-born Jew, I do feel offended when anyone claims that the Holocaust was nothing more than a hoax despite the fact that it happened, plus making the claim that it was just to promote a Jewish state by the Zionists.  Even worse, there are anti-Israel activists who even try to claim that what the Palestinians are living is like the concentration camps when such claims have been found to baseless on that.  Seriously, were the Jews doing terrorist attacks before the Nazis made them live in those camps let alone launch rockets and other projectiles from them?  If anyone believes that, then there probably is something wrong with them.  For the record, the Jews never called for the ethnic cleansing of any groups yet so many had called for the ethnic cleansing of them even in this day, which shows how anti-Semitism still lives.', 'Such a moving and important lead story today, also important because we keep finding out how little people in power (and people close to them) know about the Holocaust.  (After the Sean Spicer incident last week, it almost felt like the tragedy was in danger of becoming to so many  a late-night and SNL punch line.)  Thank you for sharing that story.', 'I always wonder why the other 44Million dead of WWII aren\'t remembered. Don\'t they matter. Why not bring their fate to the stage? The Warsaw citizen killed by a Stuka bomb, the Russian peasant woman killed for the purpose to take her livestock away for an opulent dinner. All these people in Leningrad slowly being starved to death. Apparently they don\'t play a role in history. Sometimes I get the strange feeling that for New Yorkers this all is just "collateral damage".', "Why is it whenever there is a Holocaust story there is always someone who comments about the lack of news about the others who died? Of course their lives mattered. There are monuments, cemeteries and memorials to the WW2 dead all over the world. But those who raise the question are denying the facts of the Final Solution. The only time in history that a government planned and orchestrated the anihilation of an entire group of people. And frankly they were quite successful wiping out an entire culture in Europe and shortly following in the Middle Eastern countries. Nations where Jews lived for thousands of years.  So when I inevitably see that question I can't help but feel that bias is the reason. Anti-Semitism is alive and well in our world and raising its ugly head far too often.", "I'm sorry you feel that way because nothing could be farther from the truth.  The world is well aware of the more than 20 million Russians and Soviets that were slaughtered - Barbarosa is infamous, the rape of France, Vichy and the Resistance are bundled as the centerpiece of WWII histories,  the overwhelming of Scandinavia and the Blitz of Britain are the subjects of all sorts of cultural explorations and depictions. The Holocaust gets central billing because it was unique in human history: an institutionalized, centralized, mechanized unrelenting industry of annihilation targeting not a nation, but an entire race of people.  The goal was to eliminate the present, erase the past and prevent a future for anything Jewish. The Romans, the Conquistadores and the European/American slave traders did their worst but could not do (and perhaps did not want to do for economic purposes) what the Nazis did and would have done given enough time or a few more twists of battlefied fate.", 'So as not to put light verse among the comments to today\'s important and too-relevant lead story, in a nod to the "In the News" knish-related item today "An Ode to Mrs. Stahl\'s," I hope it\'s OK to just link to what IIRC was the first time I had the nerve to put a lyric in the City Room section, which happened to be my own Mrs. Stahl\'s Knish tribute back in Oct 2014. Knish to tune of "Zip" - in the comments under https://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/03/new-york-citys-week-in-pic... Thanks, Freddie', 'Well done, Freddie.', 'Thanks as always, Freddie.  hope your day goes well']
summary: A couple of commenters briefly list personal experiences related to the article. One commenter criticizes the decision to move and replace the library. Another expresses empathy towards Mrs. Kimmelstiel's situation. One poster links to their own poetry, which they see as relevant. One poster goes into a long tirade against deniers and irrationality, while the next respondent goes into an equally long tirade against antisemitism throughout the world. Finally, someone details how there have actually been numerous 'holocausts' throughout history.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: A Holocaust Survivor’s Story, on Stage   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Tuesday: Performing Holocaust stories, a push for Uber tipping, and Earth Day events.
short_question: ['New York Today: A Holocaust Survivor’s Story, on Stage  ']

query: Runners focus on getting to the finish line while completing a food-related feat without tossing their cookies.
comments: ['It\'s become a circus of "running events". Road Races for me have always been a serious undertaking - my interest is catching the guy in front of me - or lately, trying not to get passed too much. I don\'t want to see costume, strollers, people holding hands, rock bands or doughnuts. But if you guys want to do it - no problemo.', 'These events fall into the same nonsensical category as mud runs, color runs and other fabricated "challenges" for 20 somethings who can\'t even run a single mile in 7:00.  The sport of road racing has been hijacked and is worse off.', 'Why is this article in the "move" section of the NYT? It should figure in the food section instead under the heading "cheap food orgy masquerading as a sport event". Let\'s do some simple math about the most famous such event: the Krispy Kreme Challenge. Let\'s assume an average runner only downs 10 doughnuts, this is 1900 Kcalories. In the meantime he/she will have burned no more than 400 Kcal in 30 minutes of race (I am being very generous by assuming an average pace of 10 miles an hour very few participants will be able to follow). So the "positive" calorie balance is 1500 Kcal from the most unhealthy food source (refined sugar combined with a lot of fat). Any participant believing in the cheap alibi of a 5-mile race being able to make up for this food orgy urgently needs some serious nutrition advice. This kind of events is a disgrace for all those who are fighting obesity in this country, a scourge that costs hundreds of billions of dollars to our society every year and directly affects health-conscious citizens like me by raising their health insurance premiums by hundreds of dollars a year. So I suggest the NYT stop condoning these disgusting manifestations of unabashed gluttony by placing them in the "move" section. www.fitandwise.com', 'This should be extended to other sports, too. How about shots putting? It would finally make watching track and field fun.', 'The picture of William Coe with an open mouthful of donuts says a lot: Can you say, "Gluttony".  Why is this even in the NTY? Combining a physical activity with donuts and bacon binging is corrupt!', "Oh, brother.  I wouldn't do it but I may want to watch.", "There are events for bicyclists, too.  Staunton, Illinois has the annual Tour de Donuts, a 30 mile race in which riders' times are reduced by five minutes for each doughnut they consume during two pit stops in the nearby towns of Mt. Olive and Eagerville.  I see from Googling that there are similar events in other areas.", "It sounds pretty silly to me, but then I'm 68.  But I also believe these people are having fun and laughing which cuts stress.  When I'm running I'm always surprised at the people I see and wave to that run on by with a scowl on their face.  These people aren't enjoying the run.  Just thinking about a doughnut makes me smile.", 'All doughnuts are gross to me.  Nonetheless I like to see people (usually young) doing crazy things.', "The only possible reason to run an item about food-centered running in the Well column is that you're officially out of ideas, which, judging by the recent content, seems plausible.", 'encourage unhealthy eating, even babies are eating junk and then create a huge waste of boxes--no wonder our country is not so great anymore...', 'Funny as....the hamburger-eating contest....the marshmallow-eating contest...the banana-eating contest....the hot dog-eating contest...the beer-chugging contest...and all the other "stuff yourself until you vomit" contests.', "Our son was part of the Park Scholarships program that created the Krispy Kreme Challenge.  The race is eminently not about the food; that is only a way to attract runners and spectators.  Quite to the contrary of the opinion of the writer who wrote about Americans going to bed hungry, the Krispy Kreme Challenge is a fund-raiser that raises over $200,000 annually for the North Carolina Children's Hospital.  The fun, camaraderie and, yes, even the doughnuts help raise awareness for the participants and spectators (and now Times readers) of the importance of fitness and fund-raising for a worthy cause.  So lighten up, please!", 'Really? Ugh... gross...', "MY kind of races -- as long as they're for charity! :-)", "I don't get this - at all. Sounds so ridiculous.", "Speaking as a Raleigh resident familiar with this particular 'race' for charity,  I wish the organizers would be a bit more proactive in clarifying a few of the very real dangers that potentially present themselves.    We had an extremely tragic death last year of an older gentleman at the tail end of this race, one which  really should not be attempted by more senior participants who may be in not good health.   This is a race for young bodies who can handle the hard physical onslought of running interrupted by mass ingestion of thoroughly artery clogging saturated fat dozen doughnuts,  and then,  more hard physical labor of yet more heart-pounding running,  to-  the finish line.   Another sad example of American branding and marketing acting irresponsibly.  Sorry.", 'A dozen donuts for a short run is a bit extreme. The irony is that donut is actually my pre-race food of choice, among other things. A couple before a marathon is ideal.', 'How many americans go to bed hungry every night and we have people doing this.  How about volunteering at a local soup kitchen instead.', 'To be fair, most of the events raise money for charities, including food banks....', 'Still, it is kind of gross', "Then they should rename the race series the Irony-man. Several years ago we visited a California college campus where the students were preparing for a pumpkin-destroying festival to benefit the local food bank. What next, we wondered - jello wrestling for the women's shelter, beer chugging for AA?"]
summary: Several respondents commented on the gluttony, nonsensical, and gimmicky quality of the article, with one commenter calling it circus-like. One commenter did the math for the donut run and figured out that the run wouldn't balance out the calories taken in, while others posted about the general dangers and sheer wastefulness of this sort of race. Another commenter spoke about the positive social benefits and public good of some of these races. There were also a few shorter comments expressing basic support or dislike for this sort of event.
short_title: Headline: Run. Eat a Doughnut. Run.   Keywords: Doughnuts; Running   Snippet: Runners focus on getting to the finish line while completing a food-related feat without tossing their cookies.
short_question: ['Run. Eat a Doughnut. Run.  ']

query: In a Facebook Live chat, four retired Times staff members described their dramatic 1971 retreat to a Midtown hotel to focus on preparing the Pentagon Papers.
comments: ["In commending not only the bravery but the intelligence and tenacity of those involved in the publication of the PPs, one cannot help but reflect and remember those same qualities, and more, than Daniel Ellsberg possessed.  'Profiles in Courage' indeed.", 'My comment should have read:  ‘that Daniel Ellsberg possessed’.  Apologies for the typo.', 'Goodale states, "I warned everybody at the beginning that it\'s going to be a lot more dangerous to publish the regular text [which was based on New York Times articles], if you leave the documents out."  Why so?', 'In this age of false-heroes, it warms my heart to read these recollections of people who loved their country enough to put their own freedoms on the for the rest of the (ignorant or uninformed) populace. I stand in applause for their fearless, and timeless, work. Thank you fellow citizens.', 'Bravo.  May that courageous spirit continue to permeate all of your endeavors.  It may literally be the only thing we have left.', 'I was a co-director of the 2009 documentary "The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers."  We interviewed 3 members of the Times\' team during the Pentagon Papers: reporter Hedrick Smith, editor Max Frankel and Jim Goodale.  One of the things that Goodale told us is most telling, about journalism then, since and now.  Faced on day two with a telegram from Attorney General John Mitchell, threatening the Times to shut their PP operation down immediately, Goodale, in recollection, said to us on-camera: "What in God\'s name have we been fighting for in this country for two or three hundred years to have the right to speak, the right to publish, the right to think, against a threat by the government, if all we\'re gonna do is give it all up because someone sends you a telegram?"   That spirit was present throughout the Times newsroom, then.  Flash forward 3 decades: The Times had a blockbuster story on FISA eavesdropping, in the weeks before the 2004 election, Bill Keller, exec. editor, MET WITH the Bush Administration to discuss whether they had any objections to their story-- which of of course they did.  The Times held that story for another year before printing it, when their revelations COULD have affected the outcome of the 2004 Bush-Kerry election.  This deference to government power, in my mind, is unforgivable, and one of the reasons the news media of today is less influential, and held in less esteem, than they were in the early 1970s.', "I can't understand why those of you who have written and directed movies about the Pentagon Papers, have not interviewed people who wrote the papers and can give a clearer understanding of what they really meant. Brooke Gladstone's interview with Leslie Gelb, who supervised the project, gives a whole new light to the story that journalists consistently don't report. I'd like to know why? Here's a link:  https://www.wnyc.org/story/what-the-post-missed/", 'My son who is in the newspaper business asked me if there was ever a time worse than now, and I say yes, that time was the worse. How it got that the Vietnam War was based on such lies. And Nixon as a traitor allowed more young soldiers to die was a travesty of this democracy. We need to make that history of that time crystal clear to our young people so they know what courage it took to stand up for freedom of the press.', "Being mid-20 something in 1971, I've considered that question. I believe it's worst because of two very different factors: 1) the political party in power has demonstrated over several years that they wish to remain in power no matter the mechanisms needed including believing that they can control this authoritarian person in the White House whom they chose to run. There are so many factions looking to use this unstable person for their own ideological ends as long as he can be kept in office - CONSEQUENCES TO THE NATION AND THE WORLD ALLIANCES BE DAMNED. 2) The perpetrated deception involves a foreign power whom I believe has been a business ally of the current president for some years, an ally  because no capitalist would finance him. He is beholden to the Russioans. We know that this president believes that government should be run like a business.", 'These are true American heroes along with those in the Washington Post who defied the criminal Nixon regime to bring out the truth about the Indochina war. The US still persecutes those who speak truth to power: Assange, Snowden and Manning.', 'Please always keep in mind Justice Black\'s comment that "you are responsible to the GOVERNED, NOT the governors." Trump is one of the governors so no matter what he says, it is" we the people" who count most in this democracy.', 'But we have to stand up - speak out- and keep on and on and on standing up and speaking out. Takes time and dedication.', "These four were heroes then and it's great to see the recognition continue.  Still, it's a shame this edited version doesn't deliver on the promise to address what's right and what's wrong in The Post.  Spielberg tells a story of Wall Street versus Journalism, not just Nixon vs. the Times.  Curious if there were financial dangers for the Times as well in 1971, and if there's still a willingness today at any paper to brave financial disaster for the sake of journalism?", "OK but keep in mind that the PP issue was only secondarily about press freedom. It was primarily about the government killing tens of thousands of people just so it wouldn't have to admit a mistake.", 'I believe that you made an historic groundbreaking contribution to the principles upon this democracy was founded.  I am grateful to you and truly honor your sacrifices and principles.', "why wasn't the movie called 'The Times' if the Times published first?", 'BECAUSE the movie was about the WASHINGTON POST, who DEFIED the injunction against printing more of the Pentagon Papers.', "Because the recent film wasn't just about The Pentagon Papers.  It was also about the Washington Post, specifically the leadership at The Post, the relationship between the executive editor and owner, the competition between the Post and The Times, and the Washington Post's interest in becoming a national newspaper.", "The Washington Post story had far more drama in Spielberg's eyes than four unknown New York Times people doing what they did. The Pentagon Papers were one of the things that legitimized Katherine Graham--no one thought that she'd be able to run the paper the way that Donald did and she showed them that she had more going on than anyone expected.", 'Thank you so much NY Times and Washington Post for your bravery and journalistic integrity in publishing The Pentagon Papers.', 'I note that only one of these people still works for the paper. That is telling.', 'It tells me that people get old and retire. Or just get tired.']
summary: Many commentators are grateful for the story of publishing the Pentagon Papers, continuing the spirit of freedom of speech. Several commentators note that the story was also about the Washington Post's success. A few commentators rail against Trump and his policies. A few other commentators note that the spirit of government persecution against freedom of speech is still alive and well.

query: A poem recalls a Brighton Beach landmark that is no more, and the delicious treats it sold.
comments: ["Yummm- the cabbage knishes were awesome. Especially because you got to taste them twice. 4-6 hours later you were guaranteed a good burp. The lime Rickey's were great too. I remember being treated like royalty when I would walk in to relatives houses in the suburbs with a tray of Mrs stahls cherry Cheese. Good stuff!  My dad owned the neighborhood record store across the street for 28 years. Stein Brothhers- they had the biggest 45 collection in Brooklyn. Hey hanks so much for the poem- I wrote a novella about growing up in Brighton beach- check it out here.  https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B01M1FEDGV/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid...  sneaker tree steve stein&dpPl=1&dpID=61VIe7FMmJL&ref=plSrch", 'Aaaahhhh...but it was the cabbage knish that captured my palate!  Oh, what delicious memories!', "Walking home from Bay 3 after a day of sun and sand, a stop at Mrs Stahl's Knishes was mandatory. Kasha, potato or cabbage- big decision. Buttermilk chaser was perfect. Sometimes we saw old Mrs Stahl in the back. No knish today compares with hers. I miss the old Brighton.", "I can still taste that kasha knish! I lived in nearby Manhattan Beach and we often went to Mrs. Stahl's for a box of knishes when we were having a party. The wrapper was thin and they were round, not square. But the most special ones, that I've never seen anywhere else, were the cabbage ones! Thanks for the memory.", 'I remember! Thanks for the smile.', 'I remember it fondly.', 'Thank you for that memory!  I used to hop on the train to go get a knish for lunch once a week when I was in high school.  It was worth the pilgrimage!', "Mrs. Stahl's was a treasure. My brothers and l grew up in Brighton Beach and still become nostalgic remembering those heavenly knishes.", 'At one time they served knishes at Shea Stadium....I wonder if they continue this at Citi Field?  Definitely a local treat. Of course a knish served at a ball park would have difficulties. The vendor carried a metal container, and the knish would be tepid warm and wet with condensation. And sin of all sins, they offered envelopes of salad mustard, without offering salt. But it was a knish, and you could munch in your wooden seat while watching the Mets lose another game.', "I remember well. My parents introduced me to Mrs. Stahl' in the mid 1950s. There was nothing like eating a hot potato knish in the salt air off the ocean.  A taste for kasha came later. And the cherry cheese was like having died and gone to heaven. At least we still have Yonah Schimmel."]
summary: After reading Ode to Mrs. Stahl’s, all of the commenters reminisce about eating knish from Mrs. Stahl’s. One commenter says that they hope that they will continue to serve knish at Citi Field. Another commenter calls Mrs. Stahl’s a treasure.
short_title: Headline: Ode to Mrs. Stahl’s   Keywords: Mrs Stahl's Knishes (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant); Poetry and Poets; Brighton Beach (Brooklyn, NY); Knishes; Restaurants   Snippet: A poem recalls a Brighton Beach landmark that is no more, and the delicious treats it sold.
subreddit: ["Mrs Stahl's Knishes (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant)", 'Poetry and Poets', 'Brighton Beach (Brooklyn, NY)', 'Knishes', 'Restaurants']
short_question: ['Ode to Mrs. Stahl’s  ']

query: The Australian city may not seem to rank as a top food destinations, but its marketing offensive was first-rate.
comments: ["I'm so intrigued by the commentary here. It has made me aware how suburban I am, in my adopted home of Melbs. It genuinely did not surprise me - as it has other sophisticated international eaters - that Melbourne could or would host an international food festival. Food, wine and coffee considered very seriously here. Its part of the way Melbourne is treasured by Melbournians. Having moved here from Sydney - which can be charmless once you move away from the sparkling coast - I appreciate the way that Melbourne nurtures and values itself. The locals participate, join, contribute and build the community. The same commitment that gets people out of cosy home on a freezing Melbourne afternoon to watch any sport is the same commitment to eating and drinking quality food. Everyone has a distinct preference about what and where to eat. A discerning population means you can find great food, wine and coffee in most suburbs of Melbourne, and the inner city is full of quality nosh. And its so easy to live here. Come visit.", '"Given the list’s international scope, it made sense to branch out." No doubt. Maybe they have learned from the Formula I Grand Prix organization (not to mention the NFL and the Olympics) that there are big rewards to be had from allowing various cities to compete for their favors.  And perhaps the original sites have become a little weary of the demands and less lavish in their offers. Thus a "global tour" may appear to offer better prospects. But it is always difficult to pin down the value of any of these events to the host city despite the grand claims that are made. Melbourne should know - it has also bought in on Formula I.', 'The strength of Melbourne\'s and Victoria\'s "food scene" lies not in the foppish, big-name restaurants serving the latest fad dishes but in a myriad of small establishments serving a vast range of well-cooked traditional food.  Such unpretentious gems pop up in small country towns and suburban strips, never seek fame or awards, or "re-invent" themselves and rarely survive their founder. The "world\'s best restaurants" are judged by egotistical, professional, critics and rarely take account of what and how normal diners wish to eat.  For a quiet experience seek out restaurants that eschew such competitions in favour of service.  A fine example being the Windsor Hotel in Melbourne.', 'Where does one start...? I\'m and an Australian expat, now 15 years in Paris. Before that I lived for 10 years in Melbourne.  I\'ve also spent a lot of time in New York (20  visits, including next week)and lived as a kid for a couple of years in DC. Culinary capitals, London, New York? What does that mean? If it is to say that they are large cities with a market able to support a good number of high end restaurants, this is clearly the case. But this is true of most large world cities: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Berlin for example. But "culinary capitals"? This conjures up more of an image of a deep grass roots tradition of local cuisine, enhanced by diverse influences where from street food,  to every corner cafe and bar, to the high end, one has an endless array of good honest food experiences.  Nothing could be further from the truth in NY where food is by default appalling and where one is delighted and grateful for eating well to the point where the more decent places have queues and waiting lists and will never seat you "until the full party arrives."  And yes I\'ve eaten at 11 Madison, Daniel and le Bernadin. Food is good, service is awkward and value is debatable versus other cities. London: of course you can eat very well if you\'re willing to pay well for it. Does that make a culinary capital? Not to me. Think more Barcelona, Madrid, Paris, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Lyon, and,  yes, Melbourne, where you can be confident of eating well on every corner and at nearly any price range.', 'Thank you Ashley for such a well informed response to a piece of mediocre journalism.', "Last year's host is this year's winner? That should raise a few eyebrows, even if Eleven Madison Park is an excellent restaurant.", 'I believe myself to be neither a food snob, nor an effete gourmet. But someone\'s selection of (1) London and New York as "international culinary capitals", and then (2) a place like Melbourne, clearly indicates the perniciously pervasive  power of marketing in the world of highly questionable ranking of restaurants.', 'Have you actually visited & eaten in Melbourne restaurants. I have on a multitude of visits and for years have suggested Melbourne as a wonderful restaurant city to my overseas friends.....purely from eating at Melbourne restaurants.', "Perhaps, indeed marketing had a huge hand to play in Melbourne hosting the awards. Australia is far away from established 'culinary destinations' in Europe and America, so our restaurants rarely make in on to the 'important lists', as judges never quite make it that far.  But it is undeniable that the food scene in Melbourne (and Sydney) grossly underestimated. International chefs (David Chang, René Redzepi and Heston) have hosted restaurants/pop ups and all speak highly of the food culture. It surprises everyone who visits.", 'Your first sentence in this article seems, frankly, a little out of date; New York or London - wonderful as they are culturally - are not food capitals. LA is doing better than NYC on food people actually want to eat, fresh and surprising. And Melbourne has some terrific modern restaurants. Come on down, you might be surprised.', 'I don\'t know about the worlds best restaurants, as Melbourne is one expensive city to live and work in; but it\'s hard to find a bad restaurant there. Or even a "just OK one".  The standard of food prep is just way up there. A simple breakfast is amazing. You should schedule extra time for it, because the kitchen will be a while getting it out to you. By the end of it you\'re going to be thinking, "perhaps another flat white; I\'ll just be late for work".', 'Seven chefs cooking at a beach party in Melbourne. That mental picture will put a smile on my face all day.', 'Attica.  Attica. Attica.   It just rolls off the tongue.', "Melbourne is a town where in the cooler weather going out for dinner comprises the complete evening's entertainment - so restaurants better be good !", 'Melbourne and Sydney have had an adversarial relationship, in just about everything, for at least one hundred (100) years. The cooking in both cities improved out of sight only in the last 25 years or so. Before that, the restaurant scene was spotty. What a difference today. Go to either city (in their summer) for great produce, fish and meat. Excellent wines. Wonderful beer. Fine homegrown chefs. As a downhome Yankee, I can heartily recommend Oz.', '...and the wines from Hunter Valley, Yarra Valley and the Mornington Peninsula all add to the enjoyment', "It's not just Melbourne and Sydney either. Hobart and Adelaide are also doing great things."]
summary: Some commenters express skepticism that Melbourne is a culinary capital, including one person who has lived there. One commenter says that going out for dinner in the cool weather is the evening's entertainment so food needs to be good. One commenter recognizes the big improvements that have been made in the last 25 years in Melbourne in Sydney in the culinary world.
short_title: Headline: The Lobbying  Was Fierce  (and Tasty)   Keywords: World's 50 Best Restaurants; Restaurants; Melbourne (Australia); Awards, Decorations and Honors; Advertising and Marketing   Snippet: The Australian city may not seem to rank as a top food destinations, but its marketing offensive was first-rate.
subreddit: ["World's 50 Best Restaurants", 'Restaurants', 'Melbourne (Australia)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Advertising and Marketing']
short_question: ['The Lobbying  Was Fierce  (and Tasty)  ']

query: Two women share a moment on Christmas Eve.
comments: ['This is such a sweet story. It made me cry. It reminded me of my mother and the connections she made with strangers.', 'Thank you, Mary Louise Reynolds.  You made my day.', "The extraordinary thing about this diary entry?  The writer showed her crossed fingers, a small acknowledgement of a small struggle.  The younger woman gave a rose, a small gesture toward motherly love, which the writer showed to a perfect stranger.  Probably didn't even realize it.   God, the world needs mothers of us all.", 'Well.  That was an unexpected tearing up.', 'Bittersweet and heartwarming - a pleasure to read such a sentiment at the beginning of the day.', 'Thank you, Mary Louise, for sharing this incident. You have quietly laid a beautiful rose at the tables of so many.', 'So New York, so human, so ordinary and so extraordinary.', 'I am truly blessed to have mine...and much love to the young woman and the "mom" in this very moving story..', 'This is a beautiful story of simple and heartfelt kindness.  I miss my mother, too.', "Thank you. I'm 72, and I still miss Mom's spaghetti sauce.", "Tune of “Always On My Mind” As she struggled and fumbled With her packages unstable Slightly clumsy and humbled At her tiny café table On that Christmas, I never guessed There was one she hoped to find She had Mother on her mind She had Mother on her mind Every year, on that evening Loved ones gather with each other I'm the one she selected As a stand-in for her mother Due to something that I had done: Casting her my lovely smile It inspired her to be kind With her Mother on her mind", 'Thank you for sharing your beautiful story. I am so moved. I miss my mom deeply.', "That was very moving. Humanity often surprises us, when perhaps it shouldn't.", 'Lovely. Made me miss my mother.', 'Very sweet. And very New York. Thanks for sharing this.', 'That is so sweet. Thank you for sharing this with us.', 'this is lovely.  i would have done the same.  Miss my mother.', 'This story made me cry.', 'A loving act.  It is so hard not to have a mom.  We are never too old for them.']
summary: Most commenters say that the article made them emotional. They thank the author for giving them a beautiful story. Others express that humanity can be surprising, simple, but wonderful. A few commenters talk about missing their mothers who have already passed away.
short_title: Headline: Fingers Crossed Across Generations   Keywords: Upper West Side (Manhattan, NY)   Snippet: Two women share a moment on Christmas Eve.
short_question: ['Fingers Crossed Across Generations  ']

query: A new study suggests that air pollution may accelerate brain aging and contribute to the progression of dementia.
comments: ["My parents lived in a two-shirt steel town - where the men changed shirts at noon because the air was so filthy.  Is this why my Mom's losing her memory?  Now this - and we have Zinke and Sessions to speed future generations to these kinds of deaths.", 'Another good reason to strengthen not eviscerate the EPA.  I moved two years ago from the Northeast back to my Southern coastal home area.  My breathing is better than it has been in years with less medication.  There is no heavy industry near my new home, unlike in the northeast.', "From a researchers point of view it might be interesting to follow a larger group of individuals that live where pollution is a significant problem such as Beijing. A control group that is demographically similar in another part of China with better air quality. Given China's reluctance to share information on viruses and other health issues, it  might be impossible, but you never know.", 'I have wondered if the staggering increase in rates of dementia might be still closer to the individual, and be linked to soaps and shampoos.  The once-a-week bath of 80 years ago has been supplanted by daily showers, with soaps and shampoos that contain long lists of chemicals.  We scrub our scalps and our bodies daily, yet there are no government safeguards for testing personal hygiene products.  Studies have been done on the cancer-causing properties of some of the chemicals used in shampoos; I wonder if anyone has looked at how those ingredients may contribute to increased risk of dementia.', "This makes sense.  Having been an ER RN ever since the mid 1970's, I saw the rise of dementia first hand.   We need an honest, tough EPA now more than ever before.", 'While measuring risks as opposed to pollutant loads in air may not be simple, it represents a cost which should be a mandated consideration in environmental regulation. We now are saddled w/ an administration which claims to care about workers, but looks to reduce demands and costs on employers -- which could lead to a competition w/ China and India that takes us backward.  Its difficult not to see this politically: the message from the reddest states has been that they would like to shun any government responsibility for assuring health/medical care for all their citizens. So the prospect of increasing the numbers of dependent elderly -as with children with asthma -doesn\'t bother them. It\'s a "personal" problem - despite the fact that the exposure cannot be controlled by individuals.', '"Clean Air" may be another casualty if crooked lying Trump and the republican congress have their way, as their ignorance about the environment is willful. They are sold to the polluting industries, given that they are bought for the money required to keep them in office. And climate change, evolution and science in general are to be banned, in their opinion; or at least deregulate basic codes of health safety so the cost of doing business preserves greed. The resultant health loss (i.e. dementia) and even premature death, seem irrelevant. Foolish? Indeed.', 'A timely reminder to vote NO on Scott Pruitt for EPA.', "As we know China has some of the world's worst air pollution.  This make Mr Xi and his government complicit in harming hundreds of millions of Chinese citizens.", 'If the hypothesis is true, people exposed to high particulate content should have high age-adjusted rates of dementia.  That likely includes people cooking over smoky fires, or heating with coal.  Are the rates much higher in China, rural Africa, and other places with polluted (mostly indoor) air?', 'With cities like Austin TX building the center of town denser and denser, without any change to public transportation is clogging roads for hours each day.  Cars are idling for nearly an hour each way.  It will be interesting to see whether this increases the 2.5 PM levels in the city centers.  Austin does not have any monitors in the city center, especially at mouth level for a walker or bicyclist.  The one monitor that it does have is over 5 miles north and west and 4 block removed from the MoPac freeway and on a 50-foot high hill over MoPac.  We need to have hourly measurement daily form the breathing zone next to MoPac and other congested roads, such as Lamar and I-35 where they cross the river and the congestion is greatest.']
summary: Many commenters believe that pollution from heavy industry and public transportation may be increasing rates of dementia. They also believe that the EPA must be strengthened to counteract this, with one commenter giving her own experience as an ER RN working with dementia patients. Another commenter wonders if personal hygiene products like soaps and shampoos are instead to blame for causing dementia. Several commenters argue that pollution is a result of Trump's lies and greed, giving China as another example of a government complicit with bad air pollution.
short_title: Headline: Aging: Air Pollution Tied to Dementia   Keywords: Alzheimer's Disease; Dementia; Women and Girls; Air Pollution; Elderly   Snippet: A new study suggests that air pollution may accelerate brain aging and contribute to the progression of dementia.
short_question: ['Aging: Air Pollution Tied to Dementia  ']

query: Meeting a friendly police horse on a stroll after work.
comments: ['Thank you for reminding me of the power of green space and parks, which I enjoy daily, both in my own landscape and in my small mountain city. Nature, from whatever perspective, connects us with something elemental and good.', 'Where I live up in the Bronx, the police officers train the police horses. This neighborhood (Throggs Neck) is fairly quiet. It is not unusual on a warm Spring day to be sitting in the tavern on Tremont Avenue and see a horses head pop in through the open window.', "In the 1970s when I worked in Manhattan, I escaped to Central Park for the bliss of the canopy of trees in which bevies of birds twittered and tweeted en chorus and horses trotted with tails held out like fans of a Spanish lady ridden by equestrians -and the occasional cop on horseback came past.   Often NYPD's finest would rein in their chargers to give both horse and rider a respite and a drink. I  always had some carrots and apples in my small basket just in case the chance came for me to share with them.  the horses and  I shared empathy-each receiving the happiness we shared one with the other. Central Park can never exist without its horses, anymore than without the birds who provide choruses from the trees above their heads.", 'Not very smart to interact with a horse while it is on duty. Look but do not touch should be the mantra.', 'Part of the "duty" of mounted police is community outreach.  Nothing about police is more inviting to the public than horses.   The mounted officer typically will let you know when it is a good time to say hello to their partner.', 'Did you miss the part about: "Can I pet your horse?" ?', 'Poetic', 'My memory may fail me but it seems to me that "mistreated" carriage horses always seemed to have a feed bag on. I think.', 'Lovely story. Thanks for publishing it, Ms. Reese.', "Elizabeth, you are horse-deprived. I once read an article about women's regrets -- number one was not having a horse as an adult after having ridden when they were younger. Don't let your life slip away without one! Signed, Happier with Horses.", '"Very food motivated and may nip" translates to forage deprivation from Robin\'s equine perspective. Robin should never be without a bite of appropriate forage when he is not at work. Horses evolved to eat and chew forage at least two thirds of the time, if not longer.', "Not to worry, Sid.  Central Park has beaucoup d'forage, not to mention the feed carried by his/her rider while on patrol.", 'Yes, it is wrong.', "No, it isn't."]
summary: Many commenters share stories about their love of Central Park and horses. People discuss feeding horses and how fun it is to have a horse. Some commenters question whether people should touch police horses without asking permission first.
short_title: Headline: A Walk in the Park   Keywords: Parks and Other Recreation Areas; Central Park (Manhattan, NY); Horses   Snippet: Meeting a friendly police horse on a stroll after work.
subreddit: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Central Park (Manhattan, NY)', 'Horses']
short_question: ['A Walk in the Park  ']

query: South Korea is a skiing afterthought no more. The 2018 Winter Olympics is a coming-out party for the country as a winter sports destination.
comments: ['great artical', "They mowed down old growth forests with protected species to build the ski runs for the Olympics. Such things wouldn't have been allowed in the US or the west. International events like Olympics for Koreans are still nationally organized efforts to show off their national pride and they are paying huge, irreparable prices for it.", 'The skiing in Hokkaido, Japan looks amazing. So much powder. I want to go there sometime.', "Judging by the snow (or actually the lack of it) in these photos, I can only assume that having the Olympics there has nothing to do with winter sports. Rather, it's just another political exploitation, not unlike Sochi.", 'Agreed.  Winter Olympics, especially skiing, is never global as there is no winter in many parts of the world (I mean "Winter" by the standards of those who started Winter Olympics).  So, it is open to more blatant political exploitation.  However, as Putin convinced the world that such exploitation only backfires. If I remember correctly, there is one and only one slalom skiing medalist even from Japan (Igaya at Cortina) where people started skiing originally helped by Austrians and others from the  Alpes a century ago.', "I don't understand this comment, there is snow in every picture.", 'Back in 1960~70s, Pyeongchang in Gangweon-do where the Winter Olympics is to held from Feb. 9 to 25, 2018 was just a remote village at a poverty-stricken country, just a decade or so from the four-million-dead, devastating Korean War (1950~53).  But after the U.S., under President Harry Truman, saved South Korea from the armed agressions of communists of Russia, China and North Korea, sacrificing its 50,000 young American soldiers, South Korea has now grown to host such a worldwide event.  We Koreans are greatly indebted to the U.S. for its leadership of preserving a young, fragile democratic country in the far corner of the world at all costs 57 years ago.', 'Most Koreans I spoke with are vehemently against the Olympics being hosted in their country. They view it as another sour mark in the long line of corruption by the right-wing party in nearly a decade\'s rule.
