Alpensia has been losing $55 million annually since it opened in 2011, and it\'s unbelievable the amount of money thrown to make it meet Olympic standards (and into the pockets of government officials and chaebols). It just doesn\'t have the natural climate or geography to sustain as a ski resort. It\'s the equivalent of building a ski resort in the mountains outside Atlanta and then transforming it into an Olympic-worthy venue with hopes that international visitors will visit afterwards. Btw, Pyeongchang with an "e" has been the official spelling since the South Korea adopted the Revised Romanization system in 2000. Same time that Pusan became Busan and Cheju became Jeju.', 'The Wasatch these mountain are not, nor are their snow levels; but I sincerely wish them the best. Skiing is awesome. I think even a so-so day on the slopes beats a good day in the city 9 times out of 10. A great day on the slopes...well few things come close.', 'When I was a young US soldier in South Korea in the 1960s, Korea had yet to discover indoor plumbing and it was not unusual to be waved at by locals who were relieving themselves in their front yards in the morning as we passed in our Jeeps. The stench that rose from such habits covered the nation north to south. And now they have multi-million dollar ski resorts! How times have changed.', "In the 60s, blacks didn't have the same rights as whites. 50 years later, we had a black POTUS !", "I've been to Korea 4x and those toilets are now rare...", 'Yes, but "progress" is erratic and even random sometimes.  I saw Mr Trump recently on TV.']
summary: Several commenters agree that the Olympics, especially the Winter Olympics, can lead to exploitation of a country's resources by politicians, so they are not particularly excited by the Olympics. They believe it was very costly to be able to build ski resort venues in areas where snow may not naturally occur and that there will be few benefits besides national pride. A few commenters were expressing their enthusiasm at how far Korea has developed since the Korean War.
short_title: Headline: New Slopes   Keywords: Skiing; Travel and Vacations; Pyeongchang (South Korea); Olympic Games (2018)   Snippet: South Korea is a skiing afterthought no more. The 2018 Winter Olympics is a coming-out party for the country as a winter sports destination.
short_question: ['New Slopes  ']

query: Military families that moved to areas with high obesity rates tended to gain weight themselves.
comments: ['exercise is NOT  is not a  weight loss strategy.  "healthy" food won\'t  stop one from gaining. BOTH ideas which hurt the economy have been published in this newspaper for several decades.', 'This article reports fairly accurately on a study that had many serious statistical problems (none reported here, as usual). One problem was that the study did not report change in weight of the individuals, although one might think it did. Indeed, the summary of this article for the NYT Well email was, "Military families that moved to areas with high obesity rates tended to gain weight themselves." Luckily, the article itself said no such thing. Without knowing about changes, one can certainly not know about contagion.', 'Did they factor in the mission of the military bases involved? One would expect people on a base that’s home to troops like Airborne or Rangers would be more fit than, say, those on an Air Force base with more sedentary work.', 'No, they did not.', "Interesting article, because military families come from all areas of the country and all socio economic backgrounds--so they really are a good sample for the effect of location on weight.  If we built communities with sidewalks, stores, parks, schools, restaurants and libraries that people could walk to, what an improvement it would be socially and for everyone's health.  Oh well.  'Merica", 'I wonder how much of this has not only to with how the people around you look and act, but with the availability of healthy food and activities in these neighborhoods. I live in a neighborhood that consists almost entirely of steep hills with sidewalks flanked with larger shady trees, has ample parks and outdoor recreation opportunities, only 1 fast food restaurant (also the only chain restaurant), but several sit down restaurants, and 3 grocery stores and 3 hospitals. And just as importantly is relatively safe.  If you live in a healthy food desert, there are is not safe places to play and recreate, and otherwise walk outside...you are bound to be a homebody and and overweight.', 'Nope, can\'t be.  Fake news. Everyone knows evil carbs are to blame. They magically give people diabetes, which makes them fat.  There is no such thing as a good carb, or free will either.  But don\'t take my word for it.  Read Gary Taubes, "science journalist" extraordinaire.', 'Stay uncomfortable. Stay itchy. Stay defiant. Keep moving. My co-workers and neighbors think I\'m "eccentric" for walking any chance I get, anywhere I am. It\'s not really about my waistline. It\'s about keeping my wits. It\'s about staying sharp. It\'s about getting fresh air. It\'s about using my body. It\'s about connecting with whatever environment I\'m in. It\'s an adventure, even if a paved, groomed walking path isn\'t beneath my feet. My neighbors spend barely any time outside and are all 20-30lbs overweight. My coworkers all bought FitBits, pay for gym memberships, then complain if they cannot park next to the door. Keep your curiosity and keep moving -- even if everyone around you does not.', 'Great attitude, but you can keep moving without being uncomfortable and itchy.  I appreciate that you may be speaking metaphorically, but moving can actually make you feel good.  More people need to realize that.', "So if I do the math, for a parent couple who settled in the most obese county compared to the least obese, their obesity rate increased by 5% of (38-21= 17) which is 85%. So even if they were as obese as doctors in the US are (13 % according to Gallop poll, the parents settling in the most obese county will have an obesity rate of 13x1.85=24%. Those in the least obese stayed like the doctors: 13% obese. I don't have the JAMA article to know the details, but their point seems that environment -- your neighbors' lifestyle -- makes a strong impact.  The other half is the self-actuated change -- with mindful eating and activity habits. For this , I think, the military discipline or even knowledge about healthier habits in food and activity has less to do with higher obesity rate than how well an overall sense of a rewarding life one feels where one uses one's both mental and physical capacities in ways that makes one feel fulfilled. That requires more self-reflection than self-discipline.", "Hmmm. Maybe. I noticed this in Mississippi where large bodies seemed the norm. But where there are no food stores to walk to, nothing much to do culturally in the common spaces but go to the mall where you can always afford a cheap, fatty and sugary meal if nothing else, maybe other factors are driving you and your neighbors. That nonsense about will power doesn't help. Children need to be helped not to become obese, especially girls. And what has will power have to do with growing up hungry, even though you are fat, in a food desert?", "Was weather looked at?  The article doesn't seem to indicate that it was. I think warmth and hours of daily sunlight probably play a significant role.", 'I disagree. Indigninous people who live tropics are not fat. Indigenous people who live in the arctic tend to be fatter.', 'Well aren’t you saying then that warmth and hours of daily sunlight DO make a difference?', "I hope to see more empirical research exploring the relationships between physical health and social environments. Social norms exert a powerful, though often invisible, influence on behavior. As a sociologist, I think culture is actually most effective in shaping conduct when we're wholly unaware of it.", 'We are only as fit as who we hang around with. All my friends are in great shape :)', 'God bless you!', 'While society and genetics can certainty have an effect re being overweight and obesity, will power is the final key. If you really want to lose weight you will do it, if not you will not do it. Period.', '"Understanding what regulates fat tissue is the key, and it is not calories." Pooch sorry but No.  Keep believing that if you want to though.  Calories are calories because literally what the word means scientifically (energy calculated in a food).   If a typical adult person stays under 2000 calories a day (which is reasonable) your body can only do so much with those calories and it WILL have to burn them during your day.  It cannot covert to fat what it doesnt have (which is where you really go wrong).   My experience -- Tell this to someone addicted to fatty food and they go crazy because they want to eat meat-fat and fried foods which can go way over 2000 a day in one meal.  Eating fatty foods every day and you will pile on the pounds.', 'Sort of white Buffalo....during these posts I  have learned to substitute the phrase will power to if you wanna do it you are gonna do it. Overweight or obese  people are not any less special than thin people, they have just chosen to not do it.....', 'And, of course, there are those who eat when under stress and those who do NOT eat when under stress. Multiple factors, and certainly no "one size fits all" prescription. :)', 'If we designed our neighborhoods to be more walkable and bikeable (by using "traffic calming," "road diets," eliminating parking minimums, and zoning for mixed-use) more people would bike and walk and we would all be healthier.', 'Road diets like the one in playa del Rey that made traffic even worse and has since been removed? No thanks.', 'But the study evaluated the impact of "shared built environment," which included such things as the availability of parks and recreational areas, and did not see an effect.  That is why the authors proposed that "social contagion" -- the tendency of people to adopt the habits of the other people around them -- might explain their results better than "shared built environment."   Granting that the study could only analyze these effects crudely, what it mainly suggests is that designing an environment with exercise opportunities is not enough to get people to use them!', 'definitely the zoning for mixed-use would be a huge help, I would think. In most of the places where i have lived in Europe, the cities and towns have houses where people live mixed right in with bakeries and supermarkets and schools and doctors and clothing stores and cafés and - well, everything. And there are SIDEWALKS (not to mention public transport... but that is another topic). So it is much, much easier to do things which do not require sitting for long periods of time.']
summary: Commenters find the study to be interesting, but many have questions about other factors that the study doesn't discuss. One commenter questioned what the duties were at each particular base. Where the base is located is another question that is brought up. A commenter suggests access to healthier eating and the ability to walk to run errands would prevent weight gain. Weather and the ability to be outdoors is another point brought up. Overall, commenters seem to agree the study is too vague and lacks important factors.
short_title: Headline: Weight: Your Neighbors, Your Waistline   Keywords: Obesity; Weight   Snippet: Military families that moved to areas with high obesity rates tended to gain weight themselves.
short_question: ['Weight: Your Neighbors, Your Waistline  ']

query: Ancient fortresses, crisp mountain streams, curious people and healing cities: Travelers are discovering the Kurdish region of Iraq, a place of great beauty, haunted by war.
comments: ['Sounds like a fun trip but the travel ban seems pretty prohibitive. I was in Diyarbakir (which is also a fascinating old place) and I really doubt that your overland suggestion of entering Iraq from Turkey is feasible, given the tension between the current Turkish regime and the Kurds. Do you know of any tourists who have done that? There are checkpoints aplenty in that part of Turkey and even in quieter times (like in 2004 when I was there and all local Kurds of fighting age had gone to Iraq) it was not an easy place to travel.', "Fascinating article.  Just one complaint - there's no information about how it is for women to travel here.  This should be included in most, if not all, international travel articles.", 'Tim,  You did an amazing job of bringing to life  a foreign and mysterious place to many Americans.  The descriptive detail is great, and I was able to imagine what it is like there even without the pictures.  Your sensitive handling of a land filled with so much turmoil is exceptional.  One detail I\'ll always remember wsa when you were invited to step through the door but not to step on the threshold because " Angels sleeps in doorways".  Thanks for sharing your adventurous life with those of us who may never see these places ourselves!  P.S.  You were always a good writer, and now you inspire others with that talent!', 'I wonder what the immigration officer will say when you get back to the US...', 'I loved this article and would love to go.  Probably not going to happen but if it did, it would be a trip of a lifetime.   Thanks for this great article.  Keep them coming.', 'Heartbreaking, hopeful and fascinating writing. Another powerful piece form the talented Tim Neville. Standing in what’s left of Saddam’s blown out palace, watching Kurds pack a cooler for a day on the water... thank you for making the choice to tell this story and in your honest, colorful and tender way. My mom retired this year—I will share this with her and maybe this will be the most unexpected retirement trip possible!', 'We have the largest Kurdish community in the US in Nashville and they are fantastic people.  This story was so beautifully written and so quenching, I raced through it. I love it when a story delivers history woven like gold throughout. It also had a ton of heart. Really nice job Mr. Neville.', "Wonderful story, and beautiful photographs. Thank you. I've made multiple trips to Iraqi Kurdistan since 2009 and have been overwhelmed by the generosity and warmth of people I have met and spent time with there. I normally just fly into Sulaimani or Erbil via Istanbul, and am hopeful these airports will be re-opened soon.  One note about the travel insurance mentioned at the end of the story: my experience is that insurance companies classify Iraqi Kurdistan just like other parts of Iraq (i.e., a war zone), and don't take into account the very different (better) safety conditions there. This makes the insurance very expensive, and so for those on a tight budget, it's often not feasible. Since the biggest risk, as in many other places, is probably traffic accidents, the most sensible thing to me always seemed to be to be judicious about how you travel, and to try not to ride with taxi drivers who insist on going 120 mph on one-lane highways!", 'For those of us who will never visit, your photographs are beautiful. Thank you.', 'Interesting to read, but the last paragraphs should be first. Lovely to see a part of the earth that has been closed by war, it is just way premature to consider leisure travel here. Better to watch & read the travelogues than to wind up in a war newsreel', "I have been to Kurdistan and you don't need a visa if you fly directly there. It is very easy to fly from Istanbul or Beirut to Erbil.", 'such a gorgeous place....and just for a moment your article made me feel like I was completely far from our capitol hill home watching street closures in anticipation of our foolish president speak.   I would love to visit.', 'My wife and I just got back from Duhok and Erbil and never once felt unsafe. We flew into Sirnak and drove into Kurdistan. Seven different check points getting out of Turkey and into Kurdistan. We had a wonderful stay at the Rixos in Duhok which is as nice as any Rtiz I have stayed at....and I work in the hotel business! They do not take credit cards though. The people are warm and friendly and I recommend you see many of the historical sites mentioned. Its a special place that will be easier to get to once the airport in Erbil is open.', 'If we actually need a friendly place in that area, Kurdistan would make better friends than any of the others, we should support their desire for an independant State; they are far more civilized than a Palestine!', 'Good to see some regular pictures of Iraq. Let the healing begin !', "Kurds, loved only by US neocons and Israel, are hated equally by Sunni Turks, Shia Iraqis, Syrian Alevis, Christians. Why? 1000 years of treachery. On name stands out - Kurd Saladin. An inspiration to Daesh/ISIL, he was a non-entity till 18th century when Sunnis under Christian guns worldwide needed a hero to chase away the infidel. His claim to fame are two. 1. Victor. He routed Crusaders wanting to open Europe-Asia trade. Christians were being starved by Sunni Kaliphate Tariffs (Arabic word). 2. Father of Madressahs. Believing that research on matter was ungodly, he closed down world's first secular university (Al-Azhar), banned natural sciences (Physics, Chemistry, Medicine), Math, logic, philosophy, art, rhetoric. Re-opening it as a seminary he is singly responsible for Sunni backwardness and ignorance today. 1000 years ago this neocon was aided by Maimonidis, his personal vizier. Once again, Sunni Kurds & Jewish Israel stand in way of China's New Silk and One Belt One Road to unite Europe, Asia, Africa. Trump neocons build walls with Mexico and Canada. China, Europe, Russia will ensure that the New Silk Road is clear of Kurds. This time neocons and Kurds will fail. Is the US on right side of history?", "Amazing story.  On a dreary Tuesday morning before work, what better way to start the day than to open my eyes and heart to the cradle of civilization.  On a sobering morning of the pariah president's State of Union address, we are again reminded of the panacea beauty of the incredible  Middle East, and the people who inhabit them.  Their lives rich, yet languished by century old conflicts, impetuous Western interference, still breathes incredible human spirit.  It is the will to laugh, to kayak, to dance, to worship, to thrive and flourish.     As I head into my day, in this safe haven of comforts, I wonder about Middle East as I pass by people in this multicultural North American city.   How can their families back home flourish and feel safe?  Perhaps Amartya Sen's book, Development as Freedom, is a beginning; then I realize, the most real and proximal I can do is to stop and listen.  Listen to my Middle Eastern colleagues about their lives, invite them for a meal, create a community of understanding.  That is the most real thing I can do before tonights's speech.", 'The 40 million ethnic Kurds are Sunni Muslims with their own language and culture without a nation state where they are a majority.  Kurds are maligned and marginalized by their fellow Sunni Muslim ethnic Arabs and Turks. Kurds are also mistreated by Shia Muslim ethnic Arabs and ethnic Persians. Kurds are ethnically close to Iranians.  The Kurds are the most implacable motivated foes of the Sunni Muslim extremists like al Qaeda and ISIS and the Shia Muslims as well. Saladin was a Kurd.', 'Wonderful piece! More off the beaten path travel like this, NYT.', 'Mark Edward Harris - you rock!  Great POV! Great eye.', 'At the very beginning of the American war in Iraq, a wise commentator said that: "The problem with Iraq is the lack of Iraqis."  Iraq is a fiction:  a  hodge podge of mutually hostile peoples cobbled together for administrative convenience by British imperialism. Of all its disparate parts, the Kurds are outstanding and have always been the most effective, and most steadfast of America\'s allies.  An ancient, much oppressed people, they are well educated, disciplined and courageous. Their weakness historically has been schism in the face of external enemies, with one faction selling out the other and thereby letting in the enemy.  Now, however, the vibrant Kurdistan which has emerged in northern Iraq demonstrates that this resilient people have definitely got their act together. Our policy in that part of the world should have been, from the beginning, focused on supporting the Kurds -- and this is what it should be now. Including in Syria against the Turks.']
summary: Commentators praise the article. One commentator reports that he and his wife had an excellent travel experience when they went to Kurdistan. Other comments praise the way the writer is able to describe in such beautiful detail the places he visited and the people who inhabit these places, as well as the beauty of the photos shown in the article. Others talk about how the Kurdish people suffer prejudice and discrimination.
short_title: Headline: Haunted by War   Keywords: Kurds; Travel and Vacations; Adventure Travel; Iraq; Erbil (Iraq)   Snippet: Ancient fortresses, crisp mountain streams, curious people and healing cities: Travelers are discovering the Kurdish region of Iraq, a place of great beauty, haunted by war.
short_question: ['Haunted by War  ']

query: Learn how to tune in to yourself and the world around you on your next hike.
comments: ['also lookout for bears and cougars', "Yes, mindfulness is very fashionable but this isn't a good way to apply it.  Walking in the woods is its own reward.  Sure, you should pay attention to the sights, sounds and smells, but the kind of mindfulness described here takes you well into yourself not out of yourself.  You can do that anywhere.   Now, are we talking walking or hiking?  I see them as different.  Hiking is more purposeful in amount of energy expended, which is related to distance traveled.  I have found from many hundreds of miles of hiking that I get into a different zone, much like meditation, after about three hours of steady hiking.  That is a lot for some people, and more than anyone needs for fitness purposes, but it's a different experience and requires no formula or book for deriving significant mental refreshment and improved perspective.   But, if taking the advice of this column gets you out in the air and sunshine (or rain) go for it.", "Any hiker knows that the hike itself is a mindful experience; it's silly and counterproductive to make a conscious checklist. At first, one's mind might be wandering, but over time, the regular footfalls put us into a relaxed state and we are constantly looking and hearing. Sorry, you went shallow and below your standards with this piece, NYT.", "Thank you for creating this series of mindfulness articles. It's a nice dose of reality to get me off autopilot and refresh my view of this world I'm passing through.", 'When I walk in the woods my self perception changes rapidly. As I hear the rustlings and sounds of my fellow creatures, I am acutely reminded I am just another animal in the woods and not the smartest either.....', 'Frankly, I feel sorry for anyone who needs to be "taught" how to be mindful while taking a walk in the woods', 'I practice mindful walking and hiking almost every day and have done so for many years. It can change my entire day for the better. I also work with guided meditations as well as mindfulness videos on YouTube that use nature videos as a backdrop. The YouTube channel I use is  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5UNJeib50pL6aMrcMyGQAg Very nice nature mindfulness videos. The guy also does nice guided meditations.', "I rather not think about each step. It only remind me of the arthritis in my knee. Then instead of enjoying the sights and sounds around me, I will start thinking that I may be overdoing it, that I may not be able to walk afterwards ( it's happened). I just want to be blissfully distracted when I hike.", 'Concentrate on bird sounds instead since in the spring it is like music', "Agreed - it'a little sad that people need instructions on how to take a walk, but I really like the illustration. Just looking at it is restful.", 'I have suggestion: Put down the newspaper and go outside. Simply be outdoors with the outdoors. The sounds, the smells, the feel of the air. They will all find you in time. Whether you walk, hike, sit, run, snowshoe, bike, your body knows and will automatically respond to nature. Nothing to it.', 'So, the Times needs to instruct us how to take a walk in the woods?  Please.', 'Thank you for writing this article and I hope more readers try a mindful hike.  I’ve practiced meditating during my hikes for years.  I’m still in decent shape at age 56 and find this is one of the ways I get re-centered.  I find it especially important with all the negative political, economic and terrorist drama we face daily. While hiking, the one emotion/thought I like to keep in the forefront of my mind is GRATITUDE.  I am grateful for the experience to be able to travel with relative ease to great spots, hike and see the beauty, feel my breath and heart rate increase and the sweat pour from my skin.  My best hikes are alone and in more remote areas of the country, especially on trails where I gain altitude and get to look back over the scenery below as I ascend. I experience PEACE as I become one with the universe on these journeys.  The wildlife I see on these trips is exciting and I’m grateful to see nature up close.  I’ve had the opportunity to see a tiny bear cub and mom cross in front of me.  I had a pistol and bear spray in my pack, but grabbed the camera and enjoyed the show.  A buffalo walked up to me once, mountain goats walk by me, owls land next to me, marmots, chipmunks, deer… they don’t seem to fear me and I don’t appear to threaten them. In the national parks, the ability to walk a mile beyond the trailhead will separate you from most tourists.  Traveling into the remote areas requires planning and letting others know your plan.', 'I mostly run 5 days a week on wooded trails. Not unlike skiing in moguls or in the trees, you reach a more intense state of mindfulness, and you reach it more quickly.', 'Isn\'t it ironic that the author produces a check-list for being "mindful". Nietzsche might disagree: "My formula for greatness in a human being is amor fati: that one wants nothing to be different, not forward, not backward, not in all eternity. Not merely bear what is necessary, still less conceal it—all idealism is mendacity in the face of what is necessary—but love it."', 'If you’re a parent, a pre-meditation is required: What previously undiagnosed allergy might manifest itself in your child in these outdoor surroundings? How many ways could he injure himself? How much does your insurance reimburse you for out-of-network? Will your wife decide this trip was a terrible idea halfway up the mountain?', 'Maybe a good start would be to leave the cell phone or other mobile devices in the car.', "The obvious first step for us aging boomers (and the one not taken by Gen X and Millennials) 'put down the cell phone/ear buds'", 'New York Times you have to be kidding that we needed to wait for the mindfulness huh-hah to receive these benefits from hiking. You clearly haven\'t read your Thoreau or Emerson recently. Or Muir or Abbey--Walking takes longer... than any other known form of locomotion except crawling. Thus it stretches time and prolongs life. Life is already too short to waste on speed. ~Edward Abbey, "Walking"', 'Add John Burroughs to that list!', "I appreciate the suggestions, but I can't meditate in our woods in British Columbia.  Between ringing bear bells to alert the black bears, keeping a lookout for grizzlies (who think the bear bells are dinner gongs) and checking overhead for the rustle of cougars lurking in the upper branches of our cedars, my main goal is to avoid becoming 'one' with our natural competitors for the space.  So I do my meditating out in wide open spaces where a stray coyote might give me a glance on his way to hunt a squirrel."]
summary: Some commenters poke fun at the idea of being taught to hike, while other commenters pick up on the mindfulness being taught. Several commenters suggest that reading an article about hiking rather than just going outside is laughable. One commenter mentions that it is difficult to be mindful hiking while children are involved, as they analyze many possible negative aspects beforehand. Another commenter describes the animals in the wild that rob them of the peacefulness of hiking.
short_title: Headline: How to Be Mindful on a Hike   Keywords: Hikes and Hiking; Meditation   Snippet: Learn how to tune in to yourself and the world around you on your next hike.
short_question: ['How to Be Mindful on a Hike  ']

query: How long can a progressive federal agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, stand firm against the deregulatory pressures of the Trump administration?
comments: ['Dear Mr Rivlin, Perhaps in your spare time your readers may consider the Australian South Seas Bubble. You wrote: "Republicans are trying to roll back the Obama rule that requires financial planners to act in the interests of their clients."  Australian banks are resisting a Royal Commission . That remark has been a hot issue. The antiquarian regulation of the monetary players in the Australian economy is a sad joke. Essentially mate do not assume that your Australian bankers  act to make  decisions in the interest of the client or Australia. Low interest rates have led to skewing to the Ponzi real estate market. We currently discuss Australian manufacturing in the past tense. Australian capital investment is  at flat line. The vapid investment on rock solid products such as minerals was not a good idea even in the medium term. China has so much Australian ore on its wharves  it is a major exporter of steel to the US, cheap.  I can\'t see US steelworkers being able to provide for their families soon. My name is Michael Kilgariff. I am Australian Some idiot awarded me a Theology degree after three years of studying economic history. Great article. Regards, Kilgariff', "Democrats should immediately start airing ads featuring working class whites who have benefited from the actions of the CFPB. The ads should be hard-hitting,  with none of that Madison Avenue polish that characterized Clinton's ads in the presidential race. This is a bread-and-butter issue: a tactic Trump effectively used on the road to the White House.", 'I predict that Trump will be so toxic by 2018 that he could easily be forced to re-nominate Cordray to head the CFPB.', "To shore up its political support, CFPB might do well to launch a high-profile campaign on regulation of financial planners. Many of the abuses recounted in Rivlin's excellent survey are hitting people with thin financial reserves.   Republicans are trying to roll back the Obama rule that requires financial planners to act in the interests of their clients.  Looks like a fat target to me. Calling out that flagrantly pro-business idea would resonate with people who DO have financial reserves to manage--and who aren't too stressed-out to vote.", "The basic flawed assumption behind this op-ed is assuming that the DNC isn't also sold out to big money.  Really, and average of $500 returned to the victims of the evil banks? That's not justice. That's vote buying.", 'Why does the R party lazily resort to half measures, like neutering a regulating body designed to protect the public consumer from predatory lending and deceptive banking practices? They need to press their agenda fully, overtly act on their ideology, and create a whole new body which exists and is purely devoted to the full on promotion of deceiving the consumer and advancing the cause of usury.  This is what they are advocating and they should just take the gloves off and go for it.', 'Thank God for Elizabeth Warren.', '"You’re either a staunch defender of the C.F.P.B. and Dodd-Frank or you’re a tool of Wall Street." That\'s intended as hyperbole, but it\'s essentially correct. Consider the environment in which our constitution was written: in 1789, there were no multi-billionaires funding far-right think tanks, and funneling dark money into super pacs. The overwhelming majority of (white male) citizens were basically middle class. Congressmen didn\'t spend half their working hours raising money. There weren\'t even political parties in our current sense.       I expect the framers would be shocked by the extreme inequality of wealth, and thus of political influence, that has come about in the last few decades (see Jane Mayer\'s "Dark Money"). Thus I believe they would step up to defend the C.F.P.B. I would love to see alleged "originalists" (e.g. the conservative wing of our Supreme Court) adopt a truly originalist interpretation of the constitution, that recognizes the necessity for a strong middle class rather than a libertarian oligarchy.', 'What? Which revisionist history book did you ahve? Jefferson owned dozens of slaves. The founding fathers were the rich bankers and landowners.', "BAD idea publishing this. Otherwise, THEY wouldn't have noticed, for a long time.   Best wishes to CFPB.", 'I think folks who voted for the Trump regime have got to have friends and neighbors that have been bulldozed by lenders charging 70 % interest rates and banks doing homeowners the "miss one payment and you are on the street" hussle. If the repubs want to declare that they are OK with that kind kind of nasty behavior, than come right out and say it, and take the consequences. Vote the bums out!', 'Let\'s not forget that the same "mandatory arbitration" scam is becoming more and more prevalent for  appliances and cars. I bought a double oven from the US\' largest maker and when it proved to have a major design flaw was told "we repair we do not replace". When I threatened to sue I found that I can only go to arbitration (in Michigan!)', 'Mandatory arbitration has also become the norm in employment contracts.', 'Elizabeth Warren - in my mind - is living proof, that people who are generally at odds with your idealogy - can still be EXTREMELY useful to the country in certain circumstances. In the interest of disclosure, I\'m a staunch Trump supporter - but plz don\'t stop reading.  I listened to Elizabeth Warren during the Wells Fargo/Stumpf hearings, on C-SPAN Radio. She went into full Trey Gowdy mode on Stumpf, & I LOVED it!!! "This scam you perpetrated on the American people - & it is a scam Me. Stumpf...." He interrupted her to say, "Let me correct you for the record - & tell you This wasn\'t a scam..." BIG MISTAKE!!! If anyone who\'s interested in politics in DC has an effect on everyday Americans, hadn\'t heard the Warren/Stumpf hearings - grab some popcorn - & be prepared to be entertained!!! In this role - she is a valuable asset to this country.']
summary: One commentator thinks the Republican party is neutralizing a regulatory body created to protect the public consumer from deceptive banking practices. Another commentator suggests that Republicans are trying to overturn a rule that forces financial planners to act in the interests of their clients. One comment says that in recent decades, great wealth inequality has emerged.
short_title: Headline: The Bureau of Resistance   Keywords: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau; Trump, Donald J; Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010); Consumer Protection; Obama, Barack   Snippet: How long can a progressive federal agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, stand firm against the deregulatory pressures of the Trump administration?
subreddit: ['Consumer Financial Protection Bureau', 'Trump, Donald J', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Obama, Barack']
short_question: ['The Bureau of Resistance  ']

query: The visual artist on her explicit aesthetic, activism in art and supporting younger feminists.
comments: ['It might be a good idea for the questioner to first describe the answerer, who she or he is, what she or he does, why it is important, etc, rather than having to divine such things from the questions and answers. I have never heard of Marilyn Minter before! If I were doing a question-and-answer session with someone very important in a very small sphere of influence, I would certainly want the readers knowledgeable in larger spheres of influence to know why my interview matters. Repeat: I have never heard of Marily Minter before.', 'I loved the interview. I wanted to say something about the question of "inclusivity" as it relates to the women\'s march and the artist\'s comments here. One idea behind the feminism represented by the march and by the artist is the need to defend each other when our rights are being threatened--as well as to lift each other up generally. And the right not to have an abortion is *not* being threatened. No law is threatening to pass requiring anyone to have abortions, and the choice not to have one is considered generally unobjectionable. So that is why it makes sense to exclude specifically anti-abortion expressions from the march. It seems obvious in a way, yet I\'ve seen enough complaints about the "exclusion" of the anti-choice crowd that it seemed necessary to say.', 'I think it\'s fabulous to reinvent porn/smut and turn it into fine art! However, I don\'t see why porn/smut has to hide behind an "ism" like feminism. It would have been nice to see art work in this article.', "If you're going to write an article about an artist, at least show their work. You're using a literary form to describe a visual product. seems contradictory to me.", 'Does "inclusionary" include pro-life feminists? Not according to the organizing pro-choice"feminists" who headed up  the Women\'s March on Washington.  Sad. We, as women, are weakened when we exclude a segment of the population who identify as female.', 'To the extent that your "pro-life" beliefs require co-opting the machinery of government to take decisions about women\'s own bodies out of their hands I don\'t see how you could claim to be a feminist in any substantive sense of the word. To me, as a male feminist, the movement is as much about establishing full female individual and collective agency as it is about realizing full economic, social, political, and legal equality--in other words, full humanity.  I understand that you see preserving an unborn human life as paramount, but that is a philosophical and religious perspective that women should remain free to choose or reject as they see fit and not have a particular view or choice forced upon them by the state. Your appeal for inclusion sounds sincere superficially but it\'s really nothing more than word play along the lines of arguing that someone who doesn\'t tolerate intolerance in others is somehow being either self-contradictory or hypocritical. Without acknowledging that women are entitled to agency you are not acknowledging either their basic rights or their full humanity.', 'I never understood how one woman or man would think it ok to dictate a choice about personal health and life decisions to another woman. I am sure many pro choice women would make pro life decisions for themselves -- but who decides for another? Not you...or me or anyone. A woman needs to make that choice after much soul searching. We need to provide that space for soul searching and give each woman the dignity of making that choice.  If the pro life movement were as vigilant about not sending our children off to war or providing the best medical and educational advantages for all or paid maternity leave for all -- you get my point-- I would have more respect for the pro life cause.', "This is an article about Marilyn Minter, a artist who lives and works in NYC. This is not an article about the recent massively attended Women's March. Your grudge at that can be better expressed in a more appropriate venue. Also, you can make your own artwork that expresses your personal version of feminism and then maybe if you are good enough at that, you can be in a magazine, too.  What's really SAD is being so offended by women speaking to the need for choice in our  health care  options, that you would throw stones at someone who has worked hard enough at their craft to have gallery and museum shows after decades of work, be highlighted in a paper such as the NYT.  SAD!!!"]
summary: Several commenters make comments about feminism in general, such as how it excludes segments of women. Several commentators want to see examples of the art, with one calling it rebranded pornography. One commentator thinks that the article didn't explain much directly about the author and wants more details.
short_title: Headline: Marilyn Minter Finds Art in the Female Form   Keywords: Art; Women's Rights; Beauty (Concept)   Snippet: The visual artist on her explicit aesthetic, activism in art and supporting younger feminists.
short_question: ['Marilyn Minter Finds Art in the Female Form  ']

query: Tallying a morning’s worth of caffeine.
comments: ["I used to have all of my coffee at work. Doing so saved me some time getting ready and my employer always had good coffee available at the 4 coffee stations we had. It was the second cup that was always the best as I could actually savor and take the time to enjoy it. The first cup was to start the motor running and was usually consumed in an 8:00 o'clock meeting. 'Nuff said... Now retired, I have the first cup as I read the on-line NYT AFTER a light, leisurely breakfast. This first cup was worth all the others getting here...", 'I love really good coffee and as a result only drink the coffee I have roasted, ground and brewed at home.   My favorite is Geisha from the mountains of Guatemala.  This coffee is originally from Ethiopia, the home of coffee.  A few coffee roasters are now selling this coffee.', '"My favorite of the four was the first cup. It’s always the first cup." Economists call it the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility.', 'Why is it that some unfortunate people get "mugged" but never "cupped?"', 'I hope you use a reusable coffee mug for the last two coffees. recycle! reuse!', '8:24am - Waiting for the streetcar my 2 yr old points to Starbucks and says, "Mama, buy coffee pllllllleeeease".  Unfortunately I cannot grab a cup-to-go with her and my work bag.  Not enough hands.  It has to wait until I drop her off and then get to work when I can sit and calmly drink a cup. Love the article.', "I believe that people would feel sooo much better if they didn't depend on caffeine to wake them up. Drink coffee Monday, you're going to need it Tuesday to feel awake. I know. I've given up ALL forms of caffeine. What a relief.", 'I note that you say "cup" when you mean "mug", and a mug is two or more coffee cups. While researchers measure coffee intake in cups, who drinks coffee by the cup anymore? Nobody, because coffee is awesome.   I just wanted to point out that we drink twice as much coffee as we used to just by supersizing the container.', 'Yes! The first cup is always the best.', 'Hope you get the job!', 'I work with a group of Australians. they constantly ask me about my coffee drinking, hoping to entice me into saying "cau-fee", which they find hysterically funny. Like many New Yorkers I\'m good for a half dozen cups a day. Of course I\'d drink 10W40 from our cafeteria if it was hot and free.', 'Was your first cup your favorite because you enjoyed it with your fiancee?', 'Fun. A worthwhile topic.', 'Yes, that first cup in the morning!!! it sure hits the spot.  But make mine a cup of strong tea--with milk, no sugar.', 'I\'m drinking my first cup at about 6:45 AM as I read this piece.  It always is the best. My sister told me "I used to think our mother was a coffee fiend.  Then I became a nurse and now I understand!"', "Cute story! I have four cups a day, too, but it's all from the same cup. The coffee I get in the morning at the deli gets sipped at and reheated in the microwave multiple times per day. By dinner time, the milk is all squanky but the coffee flavor is nice and concentrated. Perfect!", "I know what you mean about the first cup.  Before I go to bed every night I get the coffee ready for the next morning.  I so look forward to the first cup that I wish it were morning already.  To heck with sleep, let's just have that first cup.", "I have a Stanley thermos. It holds 2 quarts. Each day I grind fresh beans, brew a pot and fill it up. By the end of the day, most of it is gone, sometimes all of it. Sometimes a fresh brewed cup after dinner, too. Coffee...it's just that awesome. Especially, that first cup.", 'So happy your first cup was the best. But was the 4th cup truly your last of the day? And if so, did you switch to water for the p.m. hours?', "Carl David Birman - you're very good looking.  Are you married?   Judy Kurland, Pomona, NY", 'GET IT']
summary: Commentators wish the writer good luck in the job search, others praise his beauty. Many commentators agree that the first cups of coffee taken in the morning are the best. Some comment that caffeine is addictive, so they stopped drinking coffee. The rest of the comments are about how much people like to drink coffee, some fill a 2-liter thermos and drink all the coffee during the day, some like to drink coffee even at night, after dinner.
short_title: Headline: Four Cups of Coffee by Noon   Keywords: Coffee; New York City   Snippet: Tallying a morning’s worth of caffeine.
short_question: ['Four Cups of Coffee by Noon  ']

query: Homeowners around the country have opened up their living rooms for political causes and to help build community.
comments: ['I attended this event in Montclair on 2/26 and wrote a piece about it which I would love to share if you are interested. It is a tad long to post as a comment and I see no way of getting in touch with the writer of this piece.', '"Most of the members are women or identify as women." this sentence has four extra words at the end.', "I have a simple observation. In the series of pictures I see one lone woman wearing a headscarf she appears a couple of times. this looks more like a middle class woman's book club that the apparent political event you are writing about. I have nothing against book clubs or political events. Just an observation from a neighbor.", 'This is a fantastic article -- the centering of domestic space and of women\'s actions in a way that inspires more resistance and hope is quite the breath of fresh air!  Anyone of us can attest to that.  As a geography student, I\'m constantly thinking about how people come together to form identities and build political projets in space.  The living room is a site of protest we haven\'t heard much about. I have one qualm with this article.  It\'s important, I insist, though it might seems maybe only semantic. Reading the sentence "Most of the members are women or identify as women." shocked me -- if you identify as a woman, aren\'t you a woman?  I give the author the benefit of the doubt given the rest of the article, but the sentence smells of transphobia.  We live in a transphobic world, I get it, but an article focusing on a feminist take on resistance must be careful with its language and value all women, equally.', "Oh we all feel so good now. A yummy casserole changes everything. NOT! Having legal immigrants over and helping with their socialization is fine. Having illegals over won't change the fact they are illegals and that they do not belong here. And if an immigrant doesn't want to adopt our culture, but rather tries to ram their cultural demands down our throats, the exit door is open for them too.", 'Very well said.', "You're confusing people enjoying getting to know other cultures with it being rammed down their throats. The last paragraph of your comment isn't relevant to the article and the fact that you think it is shows your true stripes--insecure and paranoid.", 'They are undocumented immigrants. People cannot be illegal.', 'Here is our red state of North Dakota, five of us had our first "home" meeting on January 29th to come together to form community and start our resistance to #45 in our "Stronger Together - Nelson County" group.  One of us is even contemplating running for the ND State House in 2018.  We meet again next Sunday, in another home in another town in our Senate district, and are actively recruiting others to join us via word of mouth and our Facebook page.  Forming connections and building a network of activists who will speak truth to power and hold our elected officials accountable will only strengthen our cause now as well as when next election rolls around.  Delighted to know that this very thing is happening in NY and elsewhere.  Appreciated the article - very encouraging.', 'After three years of many neighbors and I trying to convince our county commissioners to legalize backyard beehives and chickens like most of the rest of our region allows, on November 10th I decided "screw it" I\'m going to get backyard beehives and chickens even without the consent of the commissioners. So I\'ve now got 5 hens and am sharing the many extra eggs with the neighbors . This Spring I\'ll catch a swarm and fill a hive with honey bees. Life is too short to wait for our elected officials to catch up with the will of the people. I\'m also hosting a  neighborhood "seed swap" this Spring - advertising it on Nextdoor. I\'ve gotten a lot of interest. To my knowledge seed swapping isn\'t outlawed like the backyard bees and chickens. If the people will lead, the leaders will follow. Onward.', 'Man, the Trump bashing even extends to the real estate page. 7 of the top 10 business articles are Trump based.  Some are of dubious business interest.', "That is because Trump is a horrible person who doesn't actually care about his supporters or anyone else except himself.  Thankfully, many other people are getting outside their comfort zone and trying to help those in need.", "@ George: And it will continue until he is out of office. Then, he will have to come home to us in NY as a failed pretend-president, and his bashing will continue, only you won't hear about it in Houston. There is a reason why Trump failed to garner 95% of NYers' votes. We know him well as a con man. We got his number. Too bad supporters like you didn't study up on his sordid history. That is why you were so easily conned.", 'Persist!', 'You lost me at "baked ham."', '\'\'\'\'to the extent that women have power, it tends to be in the home...the goddess of the hearth is a woman, for God\'s sake" In my home the hearth as well as the housework is shared equally with my husband.  To do otherwise would do him a great disservice and would act to enslave me.  My power is nonexistent as a fully functioning human being if confined only to the home. I believe that would be called \'house-arrest\'.  Dressing up and presenting this as anything other than what it is, enslavement, is an outrage.', "That's true for me as well, but our own experiences do not negate the truth of Ms. Steinem's words, which are backed by decades of research.", "Decades of research?  No slave was ever been empowered by the fact of the work they did.  Cotton pickers were not empowered in any way by the effort of their forced labor.  A woman may organize and run a household but that does not necessarily mean she holds any power in regard to the house.  I think what the statement implies is, unfortunately, that a woman's place is in the home. How tiresome Ms Steinem has become to me.  She is no more than the media's chosen spokesperson for contemporary feminism.  Her involvement with the CIA gives me a chill, I can never be sure who was really responsible for the creation of Ms. Magazine and what their true agenda may have been.  Unfortunately I suspect a inclination to moderation when perhaps outrage would have been more appropriate.  The fact that a woman's biological rights are being questioned once again speaks volumes.", "Ronda, thank you for this wonderful article.  It's inspiring to see the level of resistance, activism and community in response to the new regime, much of it in my native Brooklyn.  And on a personal note, thanks for making the Real Estate Section so much better and more relevant to the lives of ordinary New Yorkers.", 'The best of America! Thanks for a beautiful story.', "The NYT is running multiple articles per week like this in various sections - all variations of the same theme. The take-home message being immigration - both legal and illegal - is good for America and we must be good citizens and take everyone in. And if you don't agree, you are xenophobic. Although I can conjecture why this message is being carried out, I must admit I don't understand the underlying motive in its entirety.  On the surface, yes, it's very nice these people are inviting immigrants - both illegal and legal into their home. But I'm just so tired of seeing articles like this. Is it possible to curb illegal immigration compassionately? Wouldn't that be best for Americans? Of course when you meet people on an individual level and invite them into your home, it is far different than dealing with immigration on a large scale. But we need to enforce our laws and not reward people for coming into this country illegally. I didn't vote for Trump but I'm also tired of the liberal agenda on this matter.", "@ Various commenters. I speak two other languages (although not fluently) and have lived in other countries. It's possible to be a global citizen and still put America first. I worked in NYC for years - both in hospitals and schools - and treated many children and patients who were most likely here illegally. Many times these patients had better health insurance than myself. In other words, I could not have received the same quality of healthcare. Certainly, people here illegally have it difficult. I know that first hand from working in the poorest sections of the Bronx where many are just hanging by a thread. But I also know from my work in healthcare that people come here just to have children and for the benefits provided.  And I have to ask myself, what about the American I treated today in the hospital who was homeless with no safety net who will wind up back on the street? Like I said above, it's nice to invite people into your home but until you see illegal immigration first hand and how a subsection of Americans are either pushed aside and/or have lost jobs because of it, it's easy to think America can take care of everyone. We can't and we don't and Americans are suffering because of it.", "My ancestors came here LEGALLY with DOCUMENTS. These people are aiding and abetting lawbreakers. Where is the compassion for Americans who can't get a job because they don't speak Spanish, Russian, Chinese, etc? -- many of whom are black Americans. Are you suggesting that anyone in the world who wants to come here should just be allowed in if they are a nice person? There are billions of nice people in the world.", 'I\'m curious about your ideas about ways to compassionately curb illegal immigration.  I have a feeling that your position is not very far from the "liberal agenda" you are feeling frustrated by. The liberal agenda is not to reward lawlessness-- no mainstream Democrat has come out against the vetting system for refugees or that we should just forget borders altogether.  Democrats have tried to pass and would still like to pass immigration reform that  would tide the flow of illegal immigrants while providing a path to legality for those that have already made a life here (the compassionate part). I do also think "the left" in general believes that it\'s our moral duty (and honor) to take in asylum seekers and refugees. I think that\'s the compassionate thing to do as well, but there are rules about asylum seekers and vetting for refugees; no one (in the mainstream) is arguing for those rules to go away, just that they are humane, with due process and fair treatment. Exactly what you seem to wish for.', "It's wonderful that one of the widest reactions to Trump's political overreach is the energizing of civil society on the left. For keeping a democracy vibrant and healthy, there is no substitute for grassroots mobilization and the in-person political dialogue it creates. Part of the wide success of the Tea party was precisely because it relied upon such local levels of organization.  It's extremely easy to decry the president and to shout about the ills in the world, but to gather anywhere from four to four-hundred people and discuss what should be done? It is from that, that we find practical steps to take. We need to be reminded that, as a democracy, the weight of bad governance falls upon us. If we refuse the personal responsibility that comes with our freedoms of speech and action, we are not citizens, but serfs.", '"Part of the wide success of the Tea party was precisely because it relied upon such local levels of organization." The Tea Party did not start and persevere with neighborhood potucks.  They were funded, organized and directed by "dark money" from the Kochs and other plutocrats.', "Yes, but the Koch money was channeled into this sort of 'living room' and 'neighborhood' mode of organization.  And that was smart, because it masked the big dark money.  But the model of gathering the like-minded, and keeping their political energy up by using the bonds of community, is one that can be -- and is now -- being used by groups with quite different political objectives.  I think that's great.", 'Sometimes the best resistance is for people to meet and find out the scariest people are the ones telling everybody to be scared.', 'This is encouraging.  When people share bread together and can actually talk to each other, our collective humanity is undeniable.  I have given up social media because of the hatred and bile that is so toxic on all sides of the issues.  What would really be encouraging is if people from the right and left could get together like this and actually hear each other out.']
summary: A good number of commentators enjoyed the article and its points. A few of these commentators shared how grassroots efforts and simple kindness have helped them understand others. Several commentators are upset with Trump and attack his character. A few commentators are against illegal immigrants and complain about favoring them. One commentator gets offended at a woman doing all of the housework, saying that she and her husband share it equally.
short_title: Headline: Resistance Begins at Home   Keywords: Refugees and Displaced Persons; Greenpoint (Brooklyn, NY); Maplewood (NJ); Sunset Park (Brooklyn, NY)   Snippet: Homeowners around the country have opened up their living rooms for political causes and to help build community.
subreddit: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Greenpoint (Brooklyn, NY)', 'Maplewood (NJ)', 'Sunset Park (Brooklyn, NY)']
short_question: ['Resistance Begins at Home  ']

query: Finding reliable, affordable child care can be enough of a challenge at home. Where does one even begin to get help on the road? Here are five tips.
comments: ["Everyone's different, but childcare on vacation is a fantastic offering in my opinion - I'm not a stay at home mom, but that doesn't mean the idea of a few days at a resort where I'm not constantly attending to my 15-month old doesn't sound appealing. I love her more than I can describe in words, miss her when we're apart, relish every second I'm with her, and still insist on taking time for myself. It's that time I take, time my husband takes, time we take together, that make us better parents. If we went to a resort for a week, I think 3 or 4 half or full days plus a couple evenings of alone/us time sound about right (of course that's assuming we know she's enjoying her caregivers/activities). I wouldn't want to limit childcare to evenings. It would be so nice to take a few hours a day to lounge by the pool with a book, go snorkeling, go for a hike, get a massage, work out, grab lunch....and spend time with my daughter too! There's room for all of it.  What works for one family won't work for another - so isn't it nice there are many different options out there?", 'If you are a not stay at home parent with children at home  take a day off while the kids are in school. If you can afford these pricey vacations you can afford to miss a day of work.', 'Why go on a vacation with your children if you\'re going to farm them out to complete strangers?  In a foreign country, no less. $340 a night is ridiculous--"top-shelf liquor" notwithstanding. As for the childcare, you can call the caregiver a "nanny" all day long, but the correct term in this context is "babysitter."   Good gravy, NYT.  No wonder you didn\'t see Hillary\'s loss looming like everyone else did.  Look at the writers you\'re surrounded by.', 'Good gravy; is it really necessary to make an article about child care during vacations political?  Give it a rest.', 'I recently returned from a Beaches resort in Turks and Caicos with my 2 and a half year old. She loves the resort as there is a strong immersion of Sesame Street characters. I do want to pint out that the private nanny service is an additional cost. What is included, in the all inclusive price, is Sesame Camp. A camp where you may drop off your child, open until 9pm.', 'Or, you could relish the opportunity to spend time with your kids.  Might be good for both of you.', "That was my reaction, too. Unless you are a stay-at-home parent, in which case you may well need a break from the kids. But for us working parents, with young kids who have early bedtimes, we see so little of them during the week that I cannot imagine leaving them behind with strangers to go have fun alone. It would not be fun for me, thinking I'm missing time with them, and thinking of how upset they'd be to be left behind (on a *family* vacation!). Don't get me wrong, I sorely miss alone daytime time with my husband, but sacrificing precious time with my kids is not the answer. Not while they are awake anyway. Family vacation is a time for the family to bond and spend quality time together.  Now, after the kids go to bed, that's a different story. That's when we get our alone time, and that's where babysitting help is the most needed. We will travel with another family with kids this summer, and will take turns watching the kids and going out. We will also be in adjacent hotel suites so the adults can gather in one suite's living room for chats and drinks after bedtime, with the visiting adults bringing a baby monitor over from their suite. That's the best and cheapest (free!) option for us."]
summary: Commenters' opinions on utilizing child care while on vacation diverge, but most commenters do not support it. One commenter suggested taking a day off of work on a school day to enjoy some alone time, and another suggested utilizing a baby monitor to allow you to enjoy some "adult time" in a friend's hotel room. One commenter doesn't understand bringing your child on vacation only to pay someone to be rid of them for a while, and another clarifies the charges that they experienced at their resort.
short_title: Headline: 5 Tips for Child Care on Your Next Vacation   Keywords: Travel and Vacations; Child Care; Caribbean Area   Snippet: Finding reliable, affordable child care can be enough of a challenge at home. Where does one even begin to get help on the road? Here are five tips.
short_question: ['5 Tips for Child Care on Your Next Vacation  ']

query: Feminist Voices was banned from Weibo, a Twitter-like service, for 30 days after it posted an article about a women’s strike planned in the U.S. in March.
comments: ['30 days is not enough.  All feminists should be suppressed, if not openly persecuted. Egalitarianism is incompatible with reality, and has taken countries that have adopted it backwards. For instance, much of the Anglosphere and western Europe suffers greatly due to their compassion for others, mostly because of the disproportionate credence given to their women.  Also note that these Chinese feminists all have a link with west, often hidden under the disguise of "International forums". China is wise to crack down on them, and America would be wise to follow suit.', 'I personally think this group is not banned because of their feminist views and posts, but rather because they mentioned "strike", a sensitive and triggering word in China, especially just two weeks before China\'s parliamentary meetings (as mentioned in the article). Any other group, feminist or not, would also have been banned had they mentioned any political sensitive words on Weibo. Regardless, this still reveals the degree of censorship and political oppression in China.', "Western tactics and ideals don't necessarily work so well in China, even though we are claiming the western values are universal, in a way similar to Christianity centuries ago. But we obviously haven't figured out how to make the Chinese think like us.  On the other hand, this is not a necessarily a bad thing.", 'An article by Didi Kirsten Tatlow keeping as current on Lu pin’s opinions. The Chinese Feminists mentioned here are not 5 young ladies protesting being man-handled on the subway but  effective Activist: They have “since 2011 directed theatrical street actions ranging from occupying men’s public restrooms as a way of pushing for more toilets for women, to wearing wedding dresses with fake blood to draw attention to domestic abuse. They had been using WeChat, a popular messaging app, to organize the anti-sexual-harassment campaign to be carried out nationwide around March 8, International Women’s Day.”  https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/15/world/asia/out-of-beijing-jail-chines ... Five can be five hundred and you have a movement and where will that lead? Xi Jinping in 2012 gave a speech to top leaders about the Mikhail Gorbachev problem (easing central restrictions that activated the demise of the USSR?). Sina.com  reaction is built around that “problem,” nothing new, but will a movement follow at some point and will feminists be at its core? The Times will let us know.', "Detailed coverage informing me of how the account was banned. Keep following this group's updates.", "The depth of repression in China is inconceivable to Western liberals.  Where's the outrage? Rather, those liberals would rather bask in chic Mao suits.", "Consider the deeply disturbing  Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute's China exhibition back in 2015", 'Amy If there is repression the Chinese will feel it and their history shows react accordingly. The CCP has the apparatus to stiffly discontent but not the means to resist wide spread discontent; save for dissidents and the ethnic minorities of Tibet and Xinjiang you have a population basically content with its government; is the same true in your Land? Wise to focus concern were it can have some effect, if it can – not always evident but know to happen.', "It's so nice that men in power are on the case, making sure that women will receive their rights, as long as women just remain silent about them, already.", 'Interesting report.  I will follow the efforts of this feminist group.']
summary: One commenter spoke about how we shouldn't have the same expectations for china as for the U.S. Another commenter comes down hard against feminism and even egalitarianism and supports crackdowns on feminism. A poster emphasizes the power and effectiveness of the movement, while another poster points out that China may actually have a problem with the idea of a "strike" rather than with feminism itself. Another commenter comes down strongly against what they see as a history of oppression and censorship by the CCP. And then there are several brief displays of support for the article and for feminism.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Women's Rights; Feminist Voices; China; Censorship; Social Media; Lu Pin; Weibo Corporation; Demonstrations, Protests and Riots; Cyberspace Administration of China   Snippet: Feminist Voices was banned from Weibo, a Twitter-like service, for 30 days after it posted an article about a women’s strike planned in the U.S. in March.
subreddit: ["Women's Rights", 'Feminist Voices', 'China', 'Censorship', 'Social Media', 'Lu Pin', 'Weibo Corporation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Cyberspace Administration of China']

query: A study of amateur players found that frequent ball headers were far more likely to report pain, dizziness and feeling dazed.
comments: ['I have a hard time believing anything about this article. A study of 222 players is a very, very small sample size for starters. Second if you are including practices does that mean they are throwing the ball back and forth to each other practicing headers? If that is the case they would feel headache symptoms only if they wernt heading the ball properly, which means the coaching staff isnt doing their job. NYT much to quick to jump to conclusions without nearly enough backup data. Poor', 'big data would be very helpful . There are dozens of top flight professional soccer leagues out there with hundreds if not thousands of top flight players. all these games are on record . the videos can be studied to determine how many times each player heads the ball, the velocity of the ball. the weight of the ball is also a known, ( it has been decreasing over the decades as new materials and assembly techniques are discovered). The players can be followed for years and in retirement to determine correlation between concussions and frequency of heading the ball. There is no mystery, just money and will to do this once and for all.', 'I was knocked witless by more than one soaking wet soccer ball in games played in wet conditions. Dry ones? Not so much', 'What else is new ?? Over 50 years ago the Liverpool(UK) perjorative for a slow witted person was--guess what ?  - a  " head-the-ball"  !', 'The latest research shows jaw position can effect neck strength, consequently raising the risk of injury. Many times neck injury is a co contributing factor to injury severity, yet there are no standards in place to evaluate the neuromuscular function of the necks musculature. A simple evaluation using myofacial EMG computerized technology can easily create a baseline of the individuals neuromuscular health. Ignoring these new standards of care is perpetuating the "mystery" of concussion injury.  www.purepowermouthguards.com  uses these high tech protocols to evaluate and form fit custom appliances commonly used for sleep apnea and night grinding of the teeth.']
summary: Many commenters disagree with the article's findings, saying that the study's sample size was too small, that many professional soccer leagues still head the ball, and that the study did not use myofacial EMG computerized technology to create a baseline for neuromuscular health. One commenter says that dry soccer balls never affected him when he played.
short_title: Headline: Brain: Headers and Concussions   Keywords: Soccer; Concussions; Brain   Snippet: A study of amateur players found that frequent ball headers were far more likely to report pain, dizziness and feeling dazed.
short_question: ['Brain: Headers and Concussions  ']

query: Friday: Opening of the Coney Island Circus Sideshow, Earth Day events, and a makeover for our newsstands.
comments: ['I was prepared to read about the great Fredini, [Fred Kahl] who has been swallowing swords at Coney Island for many years now—besides his day job. So I really enjoyed this article; although I spent many, many weekends at Coney several years ago, I haven\'t been back for a long time, and maybe it\'s time to pay a visit to the freaks again.  "Down the hatch without a scratch," is my favorite line out of Fredini\'s spiel.', 'YES! i worked with Fredini too, wonderful guy -- and yes, "Down the hatch without a scratch" is absolutely priceless :)', 'i am glad to see that the Coney Island Sideshow is still going strong, and YAY!  to female sword swallowers! before i came to work at "Sideshows by the Seashore" myself (in the early 1990s, when the Sideshow was still located on the Boardwalk), i was lucky enough to see the amazing "Lady Diane" Falk wow the audiences with her incredible sword swallowing a number of times -- so i am happy to see that Ms. Hochendoner is carrying on this proud tradition!', 'RACKS & RUINS I think that I shall never see A corner that is clutter-free, Especially now that newspaper boxes Proliferate on all our blockses.', "The Sword Swallower's Assistant Gary Glazner (After being chosen from the audience to pull out the sword.) When I wink- you ready, steady, pull. Don’t go side to side. Whatever you do- Do NOT! Go side to side! Blade into mouth, Epiglottis flipped open, Alignment, placement-go- Blade into glottal chamber, Behind the prominentia laryngea, Past the voice box, Past the pharynx, Through the upper esophageal sphincter, Down the esophagus, between lungs, Nudge aside the heart, past the liver, Relax the lower esophageal sphincter, Blade kisses the bottom of the stomach. This is no time to get creative. Don’t think of the sword as your manhood. Ladies and Gentleman! See me bang the sword? Solid, it does not bend! It’s perfect inside me… Step right up! See the freaks! Want to be the sword? When you pull it out, Pride clings to the blade. Tug on it, to get it loose feel my insides grip the steel.", 'Gary, that was breathtaking. So exciting.', 'Rangers skate Canadiens', 'Wow, certainly Kiri Hochendoner and the side show people at Coney Island deserve an admiring musical tribute! KIRI - a Coney Island tribute-update Tune of KYRIE (Mr. Mister classic recording) The moves are smooth although they’re dangerous It’s what she does, she does it best The blade goes down past the esophagus Before it goes into the chest It’s cutting close, when passing by her heart The sternum’s fine and does not bleed To reach the stomach is a risky art But your reaction fills a need (chorus) Kiri says hey, come see us all perform at Coney Kiri says hey, we’re doing shows each day and night Kiri says hey, there is no sword that can’t be swallowed Kiri says hey, if you’re revolted that’s all right Uh, uh, oh, uh, uh, oh (2x) Kiri says hey, we’ve got a guy who’s breathing fire Kiri says hey, we charm a snake and it won’t bite Kiri says hey, there’s a discussion group that follows Kiri says hey, any reaction is all right  (repeat chorus)', "Dangerous/esophagus! That may be a first.  You've outdone yourself, Freddie. Way to go!!!!", 'Bravo, Freddie. Especially rhyming esophagus and dangerous.']
summary: Many commenters are happy to see the Coney Island Sideshow continuing, with several citing the Great Fredini's sword swallowing act as their favorite. Several commenters write their own renditions of songs to cheer for the Coney Island performers, including Kiri Hochendoner.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Friday: Opening of the Coney Island Circus Sideshow, Earth Day events, and a makeover for our newsstands.

query: Vania Isler, the owner’s daughter, steers the unfamiliar toward dishes “you can find only here,” like pastel de choclo, a casserole topped with a charred crust of corn and basil.
comments: ["Despite what some defenders are saying, it's pretty clear Mishan did not like this place very much. It didn't get a Critics Pick, and ultimately she only recommended fried fish (which didn't even come up in the article, probably because it's not particularly Chilean), cookies, a drink, and a single Chilean dish.", "So if I'm reading this correctly a chacarero is some tough steak slices inside a stale bun with string beans and you need to add mayonnaise to make it taste better? Wow! Can't wait to go! Thank you dear ligaya for another mouth watering dish from the gorgeous mosaic that is New York!", "Hi. You're actually not reading this correctly at all. A chacarero is a sandwich made with beef cutted in thin slices, string beans in julienne cut, and tomato slices. and mayonnaise. this in between bread slices. also some restaurants in Chile add green chili pepper slices too. Homemade bread, in case you don't know, actually stiffens when baked at morning and eaten in the afternoon or at night. the comment about mayonnaise is because it helps soften the bread, not to correct the taste of the sandwich. I'd advise you to either give the place a shot, or google search images for the dishes, to see how they look. wikipedia entries also help.", "Good grief.  You seem like the type of person who won't visit the Grand Canyon because it's just a big hole in the ground.  And as Max has pointed out, no, you didn't ready that correctly.  Not one bit.", "Been here plenty of times before and I can honestly say the food is great! *Don't let this review sway your decision and give it a try. NYC is cut throat when it comes to reviews and I have seen restaurants close down because of a few bad ones. If you are going to write a review make sure you get your point across to the reader. The entire time after reading this article I couldn't understand if the author enjoyed the food or hated it.", "The descriptions are of authentically Chilean dishes no doubt about it. Excellent to see they're baking own bread. Good review.", 'A Chilean hotdog, or completo, is not anything like a US hot dog, and it deserves a whole restaurant unto itself. I appreciate the attention paid to this restaurant, but I agree that more care could be put into describing the food in an appetizing way.', 'I lived in Chile nearly ten years ago and felt so nostalgic reading this review. Mote con huesillo, eaten on a hot day from a sidewalk vendor, or completo, the hot dog as described, eaten while standing at the bar at Domino... lots of memories. My favorite dishes while living in Chile felt like comfort food, nothing elaborate but things that filled and fed you. I would love to know if there is chorrillana on the menu (fried onions, meat, and egg on a bed of French fries - mmm.)', "I don't know if this place is any good or not;  but based on the menu, this is authentically Chilean.  Pastel de choclo, mote con huesillo, the Chilean-style empanadas, seafood stews, completos (Chilean-style hot dogs) and any baked goods containing manjar are pretty much the ONLY dishes that characterize widely-popular, Chilean-distinctive cuisine.  The only off note is that, while nearly every completo has the mayo, tomato and avocado, sauerkraut would not be used universally.", 'I am at a loss to explain the author\'s lengthy paragraph about "paila marina." I defy any reader to tell me, based on the paragraph, whether this dish of frozen and imitation seafood with "afterhought" broth is any good, much less worthy of a paragraph.  Are we being warned off this dish, or encouraged to eat it? I have absolutely no clue at all.  All the paragraph does is describe what is in the dish, something I could likely find out in ten seconds from Google images without the author\'s help. In fact, it\'s not all that clear from the paragraph whether the author even ate the dish. Maybe she just looked at it.', 'Here is the paragraph in question: "In Valparaíso, paila marina, a seafood soup, would brim over with the day’s catch. Here, the chefs, Alejandro Salgado and Emilio Macera, make do with a mix of frozen seafood, cramming as much of it as they can into the bowl: half-shelled mussels lined like shields along the rim; gaping clams strewn with little tentacles of squid and pink whorls of imitation crab; shrimp, strips of octopus and mild whitefish — pangasius, a kind of catfish farmed in Vietnam — lurking below.
