The broth is almost an afterthought, but clean and simple." The "afterthought" comment is to stress that the soup has so many things in it that one can take it as a stew. Listing out all the things that make up this "soup" prior to the last sentence is a stylistic (and effective) way of building up to that conclusion (i.e., the broth being almost an "afterthought.") Finally, the overall verdict is implied at the end of the last sentence: the broth itself is "clean and simple." This, in spite of the chefs using "frozen seafood." So yes, I do think the author liked this dish. Hope this helps.', 'You certainly did not make much on this menu sound attractive: smelly or frozen seafood, oversized hotdog buns, doughy empanadas. Not that I live there, but thanks for the warning for others.']
summary: Some commenters feel that the article describes the Chilean food menu in an unappetizing, unattractive way and that the food descriptions are uninformed and poorly-written. Other commenters say that the Chilean restaurant is authentic and actually has very tasty food, and several commenters recall their own time eating Chilean foods such as chacarero and pastel de choclo.
short_title: Headline: A Nation Vibrant in Food and Drink   Keywords: Restaurants; Corona (Queens, NY); La Roja de Todos (Queens, NY, Restaurant)   Snippet: Vania Isler, the owner’s daughter, steers the unfamiliar toward dishes “you can find only here,” like pastel de choclo, a casserole topped with a charred crust of corn and basil.

query: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer a delicious palate cleanser after a week of American-style crosswords.
comments: ["I vowed to learn how to do cryptics this year, and I think I'm well on my way. Annoyingly, what held me up the most was 25A. Eventually, I figured out the answer, but it took me a while because I didn't see any visual clues to indicate the anagram. Grrr. Also, once I realized that 12A wasn't FIDDLE FADDLE, I had an easier time filling in that area.", '"potted" is the anagram clue in 25A. A bit unusual, but fair. FWIW, Michelle O, I try to post a classified list for each cryptic when it appears (see my note below), designed specifically to assist new cryptic solvers. I love cryptics and hope more people will learn their charms.', '[Just clarifying one part of that: the clue ending "potted plant" is designed to mislead the solver into thinking "potted plant" is the definition/clue. It is not. First of all, nightshade is a "weed" and, being nicely poisonous, hardly a normal candidate for the definition "potted plant." Secondly, "potted" is a way of saying "all jumbled up" (it is also a synonym for drunk). This kind of thing is very standard in a cryptic: you initially read it as "potted-plant" when the answer requires reading it as "...potted. Plant."]', "I've been a fan of theirs ever since I unraveled the TV corn hoax and maps puzzles in the Atlantic. Thanks, Cox & Rathvon.", 'Thanks, Susan and Jack!!', 'Please explain 22D. Thanks.', 'The definition is lady in pop music. The answer is formed by a word meaning prevent the free speech of. Plus the letter a.', 'Prevent free speech of =GAG. Add "a" = GAGA,  lady in pop music.', "Wow! A HEX Cryptic in the Saturday WSJ and a HEX Cryptic in the Sunday NYT. Weekend puzzles don't get any better than that.", "Great cryptic. I just need help with 23d. I put in WETS, but I don't see the cryptic connection. If that is right, can someone explain why. If it is wrong, can I get a hint for the right answer?", 'I am very much a newbie but, with the able assistance on MISTER MING and CONNING TOWER, the rest fell into place.  I know I will give myself a DOH but still cannot put 23D in place even with NIGHTSHADE and EGOMANIACS.', "Unlike Deb, I got CONNING TOWER right away.  I couldn't tell you what it is exactly, but I knew it existed.  (Actually, I didn't know it was unique to the submarine and thought it had something to do with the crow's nest.) But I had two entries that I had to extract bit by bit from the cryptic parts of the clues because I just didn't know the straight answers:  MISTER MING and NAHUM. SANYO was another that was difficult for me.  I saw what it had to be but had some trouble parsing.  That Aha! was very satisfying indeed. So I found this puzzle wonderfully crunchy, just what a cryptic should be.  Thanks.", "I got SANYO, but cannot figure out the cryptic. Help! I need the satisfying Aha! even if it's supplied to me by someone else.", 'Whatever can be thought of as any. It gets invested in right, which can be thought of as just so. Any inside so makes Sanyo, a Japanese company.', '25A?', 'SPOILER ALERT: Help, please. Can anyone explain 12A and 17A to me? I know variations of both terms, but I\'ve never seen the terms as presented in this puzzle. I must assume these are both legitimate spellings--the NYT is usually very careful about that--but I can\'t find either term in my reference library. (HERE\'S THE SPOILER PART: 12A should have an "a" in the second word, not an "e," and the Greek term in 17A was taught to me in my college Drama History course as ending in "on," not "um." I can\'t find the "um" spelling anywhere.) Help!', '12A - I think it\'s just the word FILED out of order with some of its letters haphazardly repeating. The word "FIDDLEDEEDEE" can be used as an interjection to mean, "Nonsense!" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z0hTvKgsKsY 17A - An ODEUM is an ancient Greek theater (place for performing). An ODE is a type of verse and UM can mean "well, ..."', 'Thanks, Susan. FIDDLEDEEDEE never even occurred to me, but of course it\'s the right answer. I had FIDDLEFEDDLE, and I wondered why it was spelled that way. Duh. And the "ON" versus "UM" in certain Greek words is never going to be clear to me. Thanks again.', "Thanks, Hector. Between you and Susan (above), I think I'm up to speed. But I still don't like ODEUM. It sounds positively distasteful (Cryptic Crossword in-joke). Thanks again.", 'A fun one.  I happened to know CONNING TOWER from an adolescence (partly) spent reading WWII thrillers, some of which involved submarines.  I had to change ODEon (which I\'d justified by thinking of someone who\'s doing well as being "on."', "(My contribution to encouraging new cryptic solvers - here's the classified list for this puzzle. SPOILER ALERT but no actual answers are given. If you're stumped by a given clue, you might get help by seeing which other clues rely on the same trick of clueing.) 9A, 15A, 20A, 25A, 27A, 5D, 7D, 11D are all the same type (see *) 26A joins 3D & 8D and is nearly the same type as 10A, 17A, 1D, 4D, 14D (see #) 6A & 13D (see +) 1A & 2D (see ^) 12A, 18A, 19A, 16D, 21D, 23D are standard cryptic buildups * - anagrams # - redivision / double definition + - containers ^ - homophones", '(Oops, 22D and 10A belong in the # category too. They represent the surplus of "a" stands for "A" I mentioned in my earliest post.)', 'This helped me finish those last frustrating clues - thanks so much!', "megan g you just made my day! I'm so glad you took a moment to post.", 'Cryptics give me fits, but this one I finished in record time (with some help from the ckecker).', 'Even though I don\'t do the Cryptics and PandAs myself, I always enjoy reading Deb\'s piece and the Comments. That\'s why I still can\'t figure it out about TUBA. Why does the clue include the word "except"?', "This was tough, and I didn't know a couple of the answers: CONNING TOWER, MISTER MING, NAHUM. I agree with Deb that puzzles shouldn't always contain only things we all know already.  But I'm not sure about that when it comes to cryptics.  Otherwise it was very nice."]
summary: Commenters express delight and surprise that there were HEX Cryptic clues in the New York Times crossword puzzle. Most write about their experiences of success and failures in identifying the answers to clues, with many soliciting help understanding clues that others have solved already.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer a delicious palate cleanser after a week of American-style crosswords.
short_question: ['Variety: Cryptic Crossword  ']

query: Most complaints against imitations depend on a hard nature-versus-art distinction, one that never really holds up.
comments: ['Real flowers outside and fake ones inside (especially well made silk orchids).  Stops me from going crazy in the winter.  We can love both people - flowers are good for mental and emotional health.', 'The best part of your essay is your mother\'s reaction to your fondness for fake flowers. "She told me she found my worldview joyless and bleak." Hilarious. Over flowers! My daughter and I shared an Easter giggle as I read it over the phone  - it\'s going to be our new response to all disagreements in taste. Meantime, I adore locally grown fresh flowers, preferably from my own garden, but appreciate a well crafted imposter. Beauty is beauty. And I don\'t give a fig what people think of my choices!  Bill\'s wife, Colleen', "Many faux flowers are not so great. The top of the tree are truly awesome. For the best of the best, go to  www.dianejameshome.com  or to any of the shops and stores that carry Diane's creations.", 'Thanks for this! I love to garden, and I have a silly little gnome planter I keep for sentimental reasons. Its design is bad, and each summer the colorful annual I put in it die off quickly. This summer some cheerful silk buds are going in and I defy anyone to spot the fakes among my otherwise beautiful blooms.', "Not handmade, but the range of plastic 'succulents' now available make for very nice bits of green, grey-green, pinkish-green, and other colors.  Plus they look as good as the real ones, that unfortunately die within days in my home.  And after the horrible winter still going on in parts of the country, why try to make already-depressed people feel badly for wanting some bit of greenery in their homes?", "I love seeing geraniums spilling out of flower boxes everywhere we travel, but I'm no so successful at keeping window boxes alive.  I'm going to put silk out the windows and real on the front porch to fool 'em all!", 'Hmm...so man-made imitation of nature is less natural than cutting off living things and letting it putrefy in a man-made vase spiked with "flower food"? I honestly find humans so weird at times. Haha.  I\'m an equal-opportunity flower and plant-lover. If I find "fake" flowers/ branches that are attractive (i.e., beautiful color, no fraying edges, looks delicate etc) then I do indulge in them. After all, imitation = ultimate flattery :-) Also, it bothers me (in principle) to spend a lot of money, say $20, on something that lasts for 3 days.', 'I love fresh flowers but am allergic to their fragrances including \'natural" ones. Grateful there are alternatives.', 'People that " hate" fake flowers are just pretentious.  I love both, for different reasons, and seasons.  Unless you grow your own fresh flowers, the fakes are a better option for the environment.  I have some purchased 20 years ago, still perfect.  AND, still make me smile.  Isn\'t that the point?', 'My mother has always loved gardening.  One particular Spring/Summer, only her roses in the back of the house would bloom.  The ones in the front were healthy, but no blooms.  She read in some magazine that fake flowers would make the plant "jealous," and therefore bloom. With her tongue firmly planted in her cheek, and feeling out of options, she hot glued some silk roses on the trellis.  People strolling in the neighborhood began to comment on her lovely climbing roses.  She got so tickled that she started mixing the colors of her silk roses.  That sent the other gardeners in the neighborhood in a tizzy, thinking she had found some "new hybrid." She thought this was hysterical, but she finally had to come clean.  My mother.  Ha!', 'Did it work? Did the real roses grow?', "I love fake flowers. I've recently started buying gifts and flowers from  www.ecochicbouquets.com  love the look and they offer different fragrances if you like them scented.", 'Thanks for the recommendation. Great look and will be ordering.', "I do prefer fake flowers, mainly because you don't have to take care of them. An additional benefit is that they don't smell.", 'I love the look of flowers!  However, the floral industry, shipping blooms covered in pesticides, grown by underpaid people in third world nations and flown across the world, is not sustainable.  I know some will tout the "rain forest alliance" grown flowers sold by Whole Foods and other retailers, but really?  If you are concerned about globalization and the environment, maybe fake flowers are the way to go.  Or maybe, just maybe, we should try growing them ourselves, and enjoying them when they are actually in season where we live.', 'I love fake flowers! Thanks for the affirmation.', 'Fake and real are totally different things and one can adore and indulge in both!!!!!!! No need for warring camps.', "Artificial flowers bring cheer, just like real ones. And they're always ready when you need them!", 'vanitas vanitatum omnia vanitas - way to go Eco!', "I often put silk flowers in my backyard to spruce up an area that needs a little color and I can't tell you how many times my friends will come out into my garden, and those will be the blossoms that are first complimented. Maybe because it's a surprise that my peonies are blooming in April, or my foxgloves in August but if it adds to the feeling of a peaceful blooming environment where one is happily surrounded by flowers, why not!", "What a great idea!!!   Thanks for the tip. I'll keep your secret.", 'Especially works with day lillies, which are lovely but all too fleeting. You can get away with placing a few " fakes" for a good several weeks through July and August in the NE.']
summary: Commenters try to reconcile the two points of view by stating that both real and artificial flowers serve important purposes and should be equally valued. Some state that artificial flowers have benefits such as requiring no care and do not cause allergies. One points out that those who hate artificial flowers usually have deeper issues that don't really relate to flowers.
short_title: Headline: Fake Flowers   Keywords: Flowers and Plants; Etsy Inc   Snippet: Most complaints against imitations depend on a hard nature-versus-art distinction, one that never really holds up.
short_question: ['Fake Flowers  ']

query: It’s not just sluggers earning fat contracts anymore. Outfielders like Kevin Kiermaier, whose great defense is highlighted by new technology, are newly getting their due.
comments: ["I can't believe people need Statcast to determine how good a player is defensively. Everybody in the baseball knew how good Paul Blair, Jim Edmonds were in center field. They were obviously among the very best of their time. If you watch enough baseball as baseball people do, you don't need Statcast to tell you how good someone is.", "Correct me if I'm wrong, but aren't pitchers the highest paid baseball players? And, with the exception of Bumgarner, defense is the only thing they do.", 'How does Red Sox Jackie Bradley jr measure up?', 'Hi John,  Thanks for asking. Like Kiermaier, Jackie Bradley Jr. also made 17 catches with a 0-50% Catch Probability in 2016. Bradley, however, had 64 opportunities (26.5%). Kiermaier\'s 65% rate (17 of 26 balls) is superior.  Bruce Schoenfeld, who wrote about BAM for The Times Magazine, goes into detail about what makes Bradley such a great fielder--perhaps, even the "ideal Statcast outfielder." https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/02/magazine/can-new-technology-bring-bas...', 'Jim Edmonds, defensive savant/longtime Centerfielder for the Cardinals, was beloved by the fans, and the pitching staff.  This is a wonderful development, defense finally being recognized, including other measures such as pitch framing by catchers.  This is long overdue!  I can\'t wait until elegant defense and superb catches replace the oft replayed clips of a ball bouncing off Jose Canseco\'s head or "Manny being Manny" in the Fenway outfield.', "I think anything that promotes recognition of defensive skills is a good thing.  Still, I'm a bit leery of  a system that relies on statistics alone.  Judgment by skilled humans has to be part of the equation.", '"Defensive Dynamos"? What exactly is a "defensive dynamo"?  Sounds nice, and alliterative, but what does it mean? And as for: "Last season, the technology expanded to measure outfielders’ defensive aptitude, including a defender’s arm strength, first step, route efficiency and reaction time." Is this technology REALLY needed to measure how effective a fielder is?    I think a smart baseball guy could access a fielder\'s skills and overall effect on a team, no?  (They somehow managed to do that for over 100 hears somehow!)  And does ANYONE need such stats to know that Wilie Mays, Brooks Robinson, or Craig Nettles was a great fielder, both all the time and one capable of turning a game around with a single, great play?', "Yes, there is need for sophisticated and meaningful statistical analysis ESPECIALLY to measure and evaluate defensive prowess. Defensive reputation, far more than offensive output, tends to linger longer and barely adequate fielders, though exceptional in their prime, are still considered elite long after they are statistically and demonstrably not. Derek Jeter and Cal Ripken, Jr immediately come to mind, admirable as they were.     It's also very valuable in convincing stars,who are often the last to know, that it's time to move. Now right fielder Andrew McCutchen, an historically overrated CF, though a fine player, is a good example of that.", 'This is an excellent development for baseball. Besides the obvious emphasis of advanced statistical analysis on offense and pitching over the last few decades, now comes the analysis needed for the "third stool" of the game, defense. I don\'t mind home runs (although hit and runs and the stealing of home are more interesting plays to watch and enjoy), walks, strikeouts, or slugging percentage; what turns me off sometimes is watching bad defensive baseball. I believe much of the bad defense exhibited in the last couple of decades is that parents and youth coaches (along with the speciality clinics young players attend more frequently) is the result of decreased emphasis on teaching and practicing defense, over batting and pitching. Even the best hitters don\'t keep up over .300 averages for their careers, meaning about seven of 10 at-bats result in outs. Solid defensive play should be coached, practiced and rewarded, to bring back balance to the game. With these new analytics, maybe these same parents, coaches and clinicians will now start to stress the importance of defense, and how it improves the game, and now, perhaps, baseball careers.', 'I believe that in addition to the dh, baseball should have a df, a designated fielder who fields but does not bat.  The pitcher would bat, as in the National League.  This gives us the bat of the dh, the excitement of the great fielder with a weak bat, and the strategy challenges of when to bat for the pitcher.  Now how do I drum up support for this idea?', 'Very glad that someone has finally figured out how to attach a measurable value to the defensive part of baseball, which, in my opinion, has been too long undervalued by too many.  What the article does not underline is that a great catch or fielding play that otherwise would have allowed a man to reach at least one if not more bases, not to mention scoring a run, is the equivalent of the player himself getting a base hit.  For example, if the score is tied 1-1, and the player makes a great catch that saves a run, the score remains tied at 1-1.  If he does not make the catch, the opposing team leads 2-1.  That run-scoring missed ball can only be made up for by player himself or a teammate getting a run-scoring hit, thus tying the game at 2-2.  In other words, a player who prevents a run from scoring by making a great play, makes the equivalent of hitting for a run.  Tired to make that clear, but not sure if I succeeded!!  At any rate, long live the defensive side of baseball.  Nothing better than to see a base runner testing the arm of a great outfielder.', "KK is just a treat to watch. He is a superb athlete with stellar instincts as well. In the day fans would come to the ballpark early just to watch great players like Tony Oliva and Ozzie Smith display their defensive skills in fielding practice. What's fielding practice you say?", 'Does Statcast also consider how effectively a player positions himself prior to a pitch? The need for speed diminishes if the fielder has less ground to cover on a given play. In other words brains and experience can compensate for lost speed as a player ages.']
summary: Most commentators agree that quantifying defense players' stats is a good development and leads to greater recognition. A few commentators see it as unnecessary because everyone can tell who good players are. A few other commentators talk or ask about their favorite athlete. One commentator gives some statistics on players. Another commentator has questions about the new system. One commentator wants to add an extra player to the field.
short_title: Headline: Baseball’s Data Revolution Is Elevating Game’s Defensive Stars   Keywords: Baseball; Kiermaier, Kevin (1990- ); Statistics; Major League Baseball; Tampa Bay Rays; Data-Mining and Database Marketing   Snippet: It’s not just sluggers earning fat contracts anymore. Outfielders like Kevin Kiermaier, whose great defense is highlighted by new technology, are newly getting their due.
subreddit: ['Baseball', 'Kiermaier, Kevin (1990- )', 'Statistics', 'Major League Baseball', 'Tampa Bay Rays', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
short_question: ['Baseball’s Data Revolution Is Elevating Game’s Defensive Stars  ']

query: Walden Pond may conjure images of a New England idyll. But given the human activity around Thoreau’s touchstone, you’re more likely to find people taking selfies than engaging in self-reflection.
comments: ["Having grown up in Concord, MA I am quite surprised by this account of Walden Pond. I get the impression that the author wanted to tell a story -- about denigration of nature, about vanity in modern society -- and sought out details to tell that story, ignoring anything that didn't fit. While Walden Pond is of course not pristine, I don't believe the situation is nearly as dire as the author portrays. For example, the Concord Landfill -- bemoaned for its proximity to Walden Pond -- has been capped for many years, since well before this article was written. The Landfill is now used for public yard waste composting, a used paint exchange (so the paint can be reused), and a large photovoltaic array. Concord, MA made the news in 2013 for being one of the first communities to ban sale of small bottles of bottled water. In addition to splashing around in the shallows, many swimmers regularly swim the entire distance across Walden Pond, or its 1.7 mile circumference. What is more an act of solitude than swimming in open water? One swimming website even uses Thoreau's 1846 map! And as for the horror of selfies, perhaps the author will note that Thoreau's Walden was autobiographical! Humans have been recording themselves and their actions since the beginning of history.", 'Not that different from all the boomers that stopped at Walden Pond to smoke a joint and ponder their navels.', "Went there frequently when I lived in Boston. Didn't smoke. Found my navel uninteresting. Thought of other things.", "I have lived five miles from Walden Pond for decades and am a regular visitor to the pond (its actually a lake) and the surrounding woods which are extensive. Can on find solitude at Walden? Absolutely! The crowds tend to concentrate on the beaches near the entrance. One can find quiet spots along the edge of the pond if one is willing to do some walking. As for me, I'm just as happy that not so many people want to bother with that extra effort. And in literally two or three minutes one can walk into the woods around Walden and experience blessed solitude and enjoy the same sorts of transcendent insights once enjoyed by Thoreau and Emerson. Due to a serious drought and perhaps some other causes presently not well understood the water level at Walden is at a historical low point. Seeing the pond with half of its normal water missing is distressing to regulars like me and must be puzzling to first time visitors.", '“It’s not the kind of place that lends itself to the kind of solitude that might really facilitate any sort of deep self-reflection." He obviously doesn\'t get what Thoreau was talking about.  Solitude and self-reflection CAN be found at the Pond. Its there to be had if you go in search of it. Go beyind the beach. Go beyind the Pond itself. Its there. Only then will you discover that its been inside you all along. Walden has trees; there were almost no trees when Thoreau lived here. Walden has solitude within those trees, away fronm the bustle at the beach. Walden Pond is NOT denigrated or defiled. Its beautiful.  How do I know? I\'m there every day.', "I'm surprised the urban metro-types even get in the water. New Englander's are wimps when it comes to swimming in the elements, comparatively speaking.", 'Fortunately, there is much beautiful and pristine conservation land in Concord that has not been made famous. One can still walk quietly, appreciate nature, and reflect.', "Not too much hope for Thoreau's wisdom in contemporary America, is there?", '"Think what the east would look like if Thoreau had been heeded," wrote John Kauffman. Too late for the environs around Walden Pond, and all the rest of the land we\'ve claimed in the name of "progress." But there\'s still a lot left. Thoreau had an idea on how to protect it (and other things): "Cast your whole vote, not a strip of paper merely, but your whole influence." More important than ever these days.', "The reason there aren't photos of people is because you can't take photos of random people at a State Reservation and publish or use them for personal benefit without their permission.  Most professional photographers should know this."]
summary: Several commenters disagree with the author's portrayal of the Pond, saying how you can find solitude if you go beyond the beach and pond itself. Others agree about the current state of the Pond and youth in America, which would not be to Thoreau's liking.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Photography; Walden Pond (Concord, Mass); Thoreau, Henry David; Walker, S B   Snippet: Walden Pond may conjure images of a New England idyll. But given the human activity around Thoreau’s touchstone, you’re more likely to find people taking selfies than engaging in self-reflection.
subreddit: ['Photography', 'Walden Pond (Concord, Mass)', 'Thoreau, Henry David', 'Walker, S B']

query: Friday: Plowing the streets, trekking to Fashion Week, and digitizing the Met.
comments: ['Re low-level offenses and amnesty: "Some opposition came from the Police Department, which claimed that old warrants sometimes proved helpful. Dangerous suspects often had low-level warrants, which gave detectives a legal mechanism to make an arrest more quickly than if they had to wait to develop probable cause." For the record, when our police precinct and undercover cops arrested a dozen men for drug dealing in our neighborhood two years ago, public urination on my block pretty well ceased. At least several times a week, I used to see men urinating near where I live, and now I don\'t. And that\'s just what I saw.  I mean, unless you\'re 75 years old and just can\'t hold it, urinating in public is an anti-social act. What, not toilet trained at 16 or 35? Please.  And the nocturnal din has ceased.', "ARCTIC MOVES Layering up and layering down, That's how the winter goes; Layering on and layering off, Donning and doffing clothes.", 'What happened to the column yesterday? Am I imagining that it didn\'t appear?  I thought you were like the Post Office: "Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds."', 'Hi! We turned the column into a briefing yesterday to better cover the snowstorm. We sent it out in our morning email. You can see it here:  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/09/nyregion/winter-storm-nyc-niko-weathe...', 'Thanks for the explanation.', "I'm surprised that no one is reporting on the power outages caused by the winter storm yesterday.  You can see on Con Ed's outage map that at least 500+ people are currently affected: https://apps.coned.com/stormcenter/external/default.html My building--and the whole block-- has been without power or heat since about 8:45pm last night. It's 23 degrees outside! Multiple people in my building reported it to Con Ed last night, and when I left for work this morning, a truck was on the street. It seems like they're on it. I realize storm outages are common, and to my knowledge, nothing dramatic enough has happened to make this one particularly newsworthy. Still, I'm surprised it hasn't even been mentioned in reports on how the storm has affected the city.", 'I live in Park Slope around 5th Av and 9th St.  The streets and especially the avenues are meticulously plowed, the sidewalks are a different story though.  Crossing the streets at intersections is almost impossible: Snow banks and solid frozen puddles.  Same thing at bus stops.  As usual, cars are top priority.  All the snow is plowed to the side, walking is really difficult for fit people and impossible for the elderly.', "while the nets aren't having a banner year, at least let them play at home tonight. see you at the game!", 'Rangers stalk Predators', 'While it is true that the 9.4" of New Yorkers received was the most since last year\'s blizzard, it should be read in context.  Last January 27.5" fell on New York.   In comparison to that number, less than 10" doesn\'t seem quite so horrific.', 'A tribute to Lindley Hanlon and her Statue of Liberty costume! Lindley To tune of "Windy" Who\'s riding out to visit the airport Giving them all a great meet and greet Who\'s reaching out embracing our freedom Now we all know, it\'s Lindley Who rides the train in stitched-up green curtains Wearing the costume no one can beat Who\'s dressed the best to capture the moment Now we all know, it\'s Lindley She\'s catching our heart and eye A torch lifted way up high And as she goes walking by Her Brooklyn crowd Must feel so proud Who knows the great U.S. Constitution Never should be knocked down in defeat Who knows the fight\'s not just for the moment Yes we all know, go Lindley!', 'Thank you for giving Lindley a song.', "I found Lindley's email addy wiht a quick google search, since she's at Brooklyn College. Though she probably reads the NYT, we can't be sure. I wish you'd send her these lyrics, Freddie, she'd love it!!", 'You, Go, Freddie!!!! --']
summary: The commenters focus mostly on a discussion about the weather. Commenters are without power or experiencing sidewalks completely filled with snow. Several commenters focus on other issues besides the weather, such as policing policy and Lindley Hanlon's Statue of Liberty costume.

query: Get out in the first 60 seconds. Don’t open the door.
comments: ["Purchase a vehicle survival tool. It has a cutter for a seat belt that's stuck and a hardened steel point to break a car window if they won't come down. Keep the tool within hands reach and hope you never have to use it. You can purchase them on-line or in a good automotive supply store. Ideally, as stated, you hope to exit the vehicle while the windows still work and while the vehicle is still floating.", 'Well, reading that was incredibly stressful. Fight or flight before coffee.', 'So this sounds like a situation where the car hits and floats on the surface for a bit. What about a situation where the car dives nose down fast under water? I was always told to wait for the interior pressure to build hen try to open the door and go out with that pressure. No?', "I tried this explanation on colleagues who still think that Ted Kennedy could've saved Mary Jo K - that he let her die.  But if you panic and open the door, then you only have time to maybe save yourself.  How many people are trained, in any fashion, to try to open the window first?  These people believe that there was a bubble of air and she would've been waiting for Ted to go running for help - but, as soon as the car was going down, it was quickly filling with water.  She was dead within minutes - but the right wing media dredges up alternative facts every time, blaming Kennedy for not being Superman.  Sad.", "And if I can't swim, I'll drown anyway.", 'Thank you, Mr. May that was very informational.  And I will make sure to buy one of those little key chain hammers for all of my loved ones and myself, as well. Time is of the essence. You need to know this prior to ever having the misfortune of finding yourself in your car in water. I will also share your article, so they too can inform others. Thank you, for looking out for us!', "I used to train lifeguards. We made the students swim in long-sleeve shirts, jeans and sneakers. It was a struggle for them to get 25 yards across the pool. If you have time and will have to swim more than a few feet, take off your shoes and socks. And pants, once you get to the surface. Otherwise you might not be able to make it to shore. Seriously. You can also tie the ends of your pant legs, push air into them and use them upside-down as a floatation device. You'll have to keep splashing more air into them but you'll float. Shaun Eli Breidbart www.BrainChampagne.com", "How about driving over bridges with the driver's window down? That was the problem of breaking the glass or lowering the window does not come up. I'm a bit phobic about driving over bridges just because of this. It was good to know that the car will float for a few minutes. I thought it went right down, in which case if the window was down a rush of water may come in or impede my exit. Someone mentioned a video in you tube with some demonstrations. Why to post the link?", "So pretty much, I'm a goner.  Good to know.", "But it's good to know....just in case.", 'I watched a video on this that has been running recently on the internet. They had four sturdy, strong men demonstrate how to very quickly escape from a car BEFORE it sinks. I have to say, it was pretty unrealistic, especially if there are small children, elderly people, or this with limited mobility in the car.', 'Nonetheless, Dani, a beloved colleague of ours here in Idaho died in just this way a year ago, and the advice in this column might have saved him. You never know whose tragedy you may be dismissing with statistics now, do you?', "This article leaves more questions than answers. What if I am unconscious due to impact and come to after the first 60 seconds? While it's good info to have, the reporter should have asked a few questions.", "Whenever I'm stuck on the GW Bridge, and it's swaying up and down, I think of how I'd get out of the car once I hit water. Maybe the airbag will make a good flotation device.", 'This is useful advice I hope I will never use. But if people are drowning in water shallow enough to stand up in, the best advice may be "Don\'t panic," or more likely, "Don\'t drink and drive."', 'Apparently deaths by drowning in cars represent about 0.02% of yearly death. This article feeds on the culture of worry so present in America. Pathetic.', 'What about escaping through a sun roof?', 'Same as the opening the door principle. Water will come in too fast. The push of water will prevent the passengers to exit through the window.', "and when I go up on a ladder I wear a bicycle helmet.  I drive 5 mph under the speed limit when in our camper.  I no longer climb on roofs, too old and not coordinated enough even though I probably could do it.  We don't hike when there are thunderstorms.  We are careful to not leave things on the floor at night.  We carry a seat belt cutter and small hammer in our console.  On and on.   When you add up enough .02% you might just live a lot longer."]
summary: One commentator says the article's instructions will be useless if he can't swim. Another comment provides tips on how to swim more easily, such as taking off shoes and socks. A commenter thanks the author for the tips and says that he will share with as many people as possible.   Other advice says that a piece of important advice that can be left is that the person cannot panic in the event of an accident. Some comments suggest buying a hammer to help break the window glass in case of need.
short_title: Headline: How to Escape From a Car in Water   Keywords: Traffic Accidents and Safety; Drownings   Snippet: Get out in the first 60 seconds. Don’t open the door.
short_question: ['How to Escape From a Car in Water  ']

query: “I couldn’t resist taking a photo of my sneakered feet on the North side of the room.”
comments: ["From safely outside the DMZ, Trump's bellicose posturing renews the treatment of Korean people, in the South and North, as geopolitical pawns.  A hoary American tradition that dates back to the US stepping aside while Japan invaded and occupied Korea -- thereby checking Russian expansionism. One should recall that feeding Japanese Imperial ambitions with Koreans (and others) turned out to be a globally disastrous miscalculation -- setting the stage for World War II in the Pacific. US foreign policy made more miscalculations by placing the Korean peninsula outside the US area of concern.  That led to the Korean War and over a  million Asian casualties (Korean and Chinese) along with tens of thousands of US & UN casualties.   The posturing of guards in the Joint Security Area may seem like theater, but the potential consequences could become all too real and bloody, again.", 'It reminds me of my visits across the Berlin Wall in the 1980\'s. Walking the no mans land at Checkpoint Charlie, the totally disinterested French, British and American troops at "our" end and the rather more severe guards in the DDR. But it was fascinating and on a human level the officials and civilians I encountered in East Berlin were perfectly nice to me. At that level we are all the same and you do wonder how we let ourselves become pawns in the great game played by the "others" who run our world.', 'This article is misleading. The DMZ and Panmunjom are very popular tourist destinations with several companies running tours there frequently. Many of the tours offer the exact same experience of walking on North Korea as the author. Having a US passport has no negative effect on a person being able to take such tours.', 'Also, there is no "minder" since access is from the South Korean side.', 'Indeed there are many tours of the DMZ.  And tourists may mock the boundary within the building.   But the larger truth is that the Korean people remain divided by an arbitrary boundary imposed by the US and the Soviet Union as they gamed out World War II in the Pacific theater.']
summary: One commenter describes the article as misleading since the DMZ and Panmunjom are actually popular tourist destinations, while others state that it still divides the Korean people and is the result of external political forces and foreign policy that has made the Korean people geopolitical pawns. Another commenter compares the Korean DMZ to the Berlin Wall.
short_title: Headline: Straddling the Divide   Keywords: Korean Demilitarized Zone; North Korea; Panmunjom (South Korea); United Nations Command   Snippet: “I couldn’t resist taking a photo of my sneakered feet on the North side of the room.”
subreddit: ['Korean Demilitarized Zone', 'North Korea', 'Panmunjom (South Korea)', 'United Nations Command']
short_question: ['Straddling the Divide  ']

query: Like Phil Jackson and the Knicks, Doc Rivers is at a crossroads with the Clippers. But the troubles of the Clippers are mostly confined to the court.
comments: ['The harassment of Oakley reminded me of the Rodney King beating given to him by police officers.  I\'m looking forward to the lawsuit with McEnroe as star witness.  We\'ll find out if Oakley was just minding his own business or not.  Put your hands on a man and you should expect to get put back in your place. Have we gotten to where its okay to paw at someone because you\'re a security guard?  Seems Dolan sent his security to just "stand next to his seat and let him know he\'s being watched."  The lawsuit should be front page news unless it gets quashed as the Dolans are capable of doing with all that family Power.  NYC is behind you Charles.', 'Why would any basketball player -- in his right mind -- want to play for the Knicks after this. If I was C. Anthony, I would waive my no-trade clause, and try to go play for a "winner" as soon as possible.', 'I wouldn\'t walk around the corner to watch an NBA game, even if you gave me free court-side tickets.  The officiating is laughable and there are more divas per square than at the Met.  If you wanted to have a conversation about the game (maybe discuss substitution patterns or defensive decisions?) with a person sitting next to you, you\'d have to compete with the incessant "entertainment," cheerleaders, T-shirt cannons, ear-damaging  music...all in all less fun than sitting home and watching the Weather Channel.', "The MAJOR problem with Anthony's contract is that he is guaranteed  $26 million next year and $27 million the year after, NOT that it has a no-trade clause. Do you think that ANY TEAM wants to be on the hook for that $$$$???", 'DSM-  Do you know anything about basketball? Do you realize that  a winning team is not  the coach, any  number of superstars, the owner or the GM? It is the right combination of individuals at the right time. Even the best coach cannot force wins for certain teams- likewise-  a team  chock full of superstar talent and ability- cannot succeed without   a decent coach. So how do we measure  ability? Some would say,  winning percentage.  Not every superstar team has been successful and there are plenty of examples of  superstar-less teams- that have won championships (Pistons for one) So what makes the difference? The coach has to  be able to decipher  how to combine players, bring out the best with what he has, draw up appropriate plans for his team and whatever opponent they face- all the while dealing with personalities/struggles- ( Dennis Rodman) KB etc etc Phil Jackson is the winningest coach of ANY professional sport. Right now  his talents are not be utilized', 'If justice had prevailed, Dolan would have been thrown out and arrested, and Oakley would have been given his seat, to the cheers of true Knick fans.', 'Harvey, an article idea: Is it possible that Phil -- who promised transparency with the media -- has been ordered by Dolan explicitly not to talk to the media? Dolan is likely the one behind the fiasco that ejected a Knick fan favorite Charles Oakley last night.  Dolan was sued.  In fact, based on what happened to the Clippers ownership after Adam Silver forced the sale of that team,it would have been not only possible,but probable that had Silver been commissioner during the Dolan/Isiah era he would have FORCED DOLAN TO SELL, as he did Sterling, for his behavior.  Phil may not be helping himself, but he did THE SAME THING in LA tweaking Kobe (about not passing enough), and Shaq (weight issues)-- mid 3peat,but the difference is now every comment is made into an example of Knicks dysfunction. Maybe your Phil or Melo/who should go comedy piece missed the point. It starts at the top. You just wrote Steve Balmer\'s Clippers are "a stable, forthcoming organization that stays on top of incendiary team issue", could you have ever imagined writing that sentence under Sterling? Dolan is NY\'s Sterling. Asking him to sell will trigger his defiance, as we saw with Oakley ejected last night (a logical guess).  So make a case for him to sell. Find a buyer who could afford to overpay & make him an offer he cant refuse: Larry Ellison (who wanted GS)? New Yorker Zuckerberg? Dolan is doing a lot of great charity work, let him focus on that &his band.  Maybe he\'ll listen to you Harvey', 'Hey Phil!  He means you.  "because he has not yet devolved into a holier-than-thou, thin-skinned curmudgeon."', 'Does anyone still believe that Phil Jackson is a basketball genius, rather than someone who was incredibly fortunate to be given multiple superstars discovered by others to coach? And is Dolan anything other than a rich kid who has only caused harm to what he was given by daddy?', "I am commenting here since no comments were invited on the separate Oakley story.  Charles Oakley is not one for half measures.  If he was your teammate your back was protected.  He dislikes the direction of the club and hasn't hesitated to criticize the Knicks organization and Jim Dolan personally.  Neither man likes the other, but that's besides the point. For what Oak did as a player, he should have been among the Knick greats recognized during the celebration of the 70th anniversary of the franchise.  Excluding him was childish. The classy thing for the Knicks to do would be to ask for the criminal charges to be dismissed, then have somebody like Pat Riley, who coached Oak and isn't part of current Knick management, mediate setting up a Charles Oakley Night in the Garden.  God knows Knick fans could use a reason to go to a game, with the on-court product so appalling.  Let Dolan have the guts to introduce Charles, say that they do not and probably never will see eye to eye, but he respects that Oakley gave his all for the Knicks, and that deserves recognition.", "All roads lead to and go from Dolan. He is the one variable that has handcuffed this team to the exclusion of all others. Another spoiled rich overgrown spoiled child in charge not unlike....you know who! (I'd rather not utter the name. There's too much of it to go around and around and...)", "By resigning Carmelo to a contract with a no-trade clause, Phil probably forfeited his last his chance to turn the Knicks around. Carmelo may be well-liked by his peers (he's a very nice guy) but I wonder how many of top flight players  believe they can truly compete for a championship with him in a leading role on their team. After Phil departs, I'm sure he'll come out with another tome. I wonder whether Phil will divulge whether Dolan forced him to resign Anthony.  Or maybe Phil's contract contains a non-disparagement clause that will require him to remain silent. That would be ironic.", 'I viewed the coming of Phil Jackson with some skepticism, but I had no clue that his reign would lead the Knicks further down the rabbit hole. Compounding the grave error of trading for Anthony, giving him a top dollar, no trade, franchise player contract was sheer insanity. I\'m not the greatest basketball mind around, but the time he had spent with the Knicks clearly showed that while he undoubtedly is a first-rate offensive player, his overall game is a notch (or two) below the many truly great players in the league. Was the contract Jackson\'s doing or Dolans? We\'ll never know, but Jackson has no leg to stand on; if Dolan forced the move, Phil should have stood up to him, up to and including walking away. There was always another job awaiting him in LA if he needed the money, and the "story" was that he was going to have "complete control". Shame on him for not standing up to Dolan if that was the case. If not, and the decision was Jackson\'s that\'s even worse. The current Carmelo stay/leave fiasco is being managed as poorly as can be imagined. Public criticism of any player at any time is not a good idea. Criticism of Anthony while trying to trade him and his bloated contract?...."hey--we\'ve got this guy, he\'s a ball hog, he\'s not a winner, doesn\'t make his teammates better and he\'s got this bloated contract--what can I get back for him?"  If Carmelo is traded, it\'s pretty clear the Knicks won\'t be getting much of value.', 'Trade Jackson. This primadonna needs to go....now!', 'If there was any justice in the world it would have been the arrogant Dolan who was dragged off.', "Charles Oakley charged with Assault in the Third Degree (N.Y. Penal Law 120.00). This means that he intentionally caused physical injury to another person. Oakley is not playing basketball anymore, so he's being treated like most black men are treated in New York City. He's a nobody. The police have arrested him, and it appears that the District Attorney may charge him. If he is charged the Court will probably issue an order of protection preventing Mr. Oakley from going to Madison Square Garden -- or from having contact with certain other people (violation of the order of protection is a crime). The powerful use the police and the criminal justice system to do their dirty work. This is a perfect example.", "As a refugee from NYC, now living in an undisclosed location. I cannot understand why New Yorkers would spend $ 50,000. $60,000 or even more. For season tickets  to Watch such a hapless team year after year. Don't Spike Lee and John McEnroe Have anything better to do with their money and time. Time to blow it up and start all over..................again.", 'Oakley for next Knicks coach.', 'The Knicks will NEVER be winners with that pathetic joke of an owner Dolan. How dare he eject Oakley who played his heart out for the Knicks and got them within a basket of winning a championship. The Knicks are currently a clown with ringmaster Dolan. Eject HIM!', "Dolan must go.  There should be a boycott of going to games and watching them on tv.  Perhaps a boycott of Cablevision would be better.  There is not a player on this team who can play with the fire and grit as Charles Oakley.  It is a disgrace how Oakley was treated last night. I hope he sues.  Jackson is a joke too.  Give me Jordan, Pippen, Shaq, and Bryant and I'd win.  And stop blaming Melo for being who he is, and for taking the money he was offered.  The Garden brass are amateurs, and they've now stepped over the line.", 'Doc Rivers is a fine coach who gets as much as possible out of a team that has had unfortunate injury problems at unfortunate times.  Los Angeles should be pleased to have Rivers and wait for better team health and a subtle remolding of the team bench.']
summary: The commenters generally agree that the Knicks' owner, Jim Dolan, is a despicable individual that needs to be removed before the Knicks can rebuild. Many of the commenters lament how Charles Oakley was treated and believe he should be honored rather than charged with assault. A few commenters question Phil Jackson's coaching ability and the signing of Carmelo Anthony. In general, the commenters agree that the Knicks are in a poor state.

But the troubles of the Clippers are mostly confined to the court.

query: Tuesday: A lesson before Lent, Fat Tuesday festivities, and a girls-only chess challenge.
comments: ['I give up pizza every year. It seems silly but it IS a sacrifice for me and it makes me aware of how often I eat it, how much I miss it when I cant have it, and forces me to eat something else (which is typically healthier). It really does seem like nothing, but after 40+ days without something you love to eat, it allows a little perspective into my life.', '“If you go back far enough with ‘shrove,’ which comes from the word that means carnival, it’s to absolve or to take something away,” said Dr. Michael B. Brown, senior minister of the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan." I don\'t think so. Coincidentally, I had already looked this up. "The expression "Shrove Tuesday" comes from the word shrive, meaning \'absolve\'." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shrove_Tuesday', "I'm not giving up for Lent, I'm adding. I'm going to be attending weekly church services again. For too many years I've used Lent as an excuse to give up something to gain something I wanted. I'll give up chocolate because I want to lose weight, I'll give up spending because I want to save money. There would always be a tangible gain in the end. This year, I'm going back to the real origin. I don't know that I'll be more religious or if I'll keep it up at the end of it. It's going to be a hassle and it's going to be boring. But it's what I should do and Lent is for grappling with ourselves, our shortcomings, and our strengths. That said, I will also not be spending money.", '"by" 30th St???', 'Orthodox Lent started on Monday, before it was cool. Fat Tuesday is for Catholics and other slackers :P Cheers', "No more caffeine starting tomorrow. I started working full time in January, so I've been waking up much earlier than I've had to in much of the past four years. Morning coffee has been one of the most enjoyable parts of my day.", 'Raptors turntable Knicks', 'Pancake eating has long been  been a  fun and happy custom on Shrove Tuesday.  However, the word "Shrove" has nothing to do with eating pancakes. The word derives from the word "shriven" which is a custom in which many Christians would reflect on their transgressions and practice repentance and confess their sins preparatory to Ash Wednesday. I believe in Shakespeare\'s "Romeo and Juliet" there is mention of one of the characters being "shriven."', 'Loved the fun pancake info and puns especially, but this alliterative In the News item really got me humming.  "President Trump, and the fear of falling tunnel tiles" Tune of Autumn Leaves (The falling leaves...) The falling tiles drop on your windshield The wayward tiles, as you drive through Though they cascade inside the tunnels The M-T-A says it\'s not true Since you rant away So loud and strong And you won\'t hear That you are wrong New York will take the extra jobs, and funding So our "falling tiles" will not fall.', '@Melinda:  Get a grip! Trump IS everywhere, and Freddie is a gem!', "To Melinda, to be fair, I parody about folks like de Blasio (just yesterday, for example), Cuomo, even Quinn and Weiner, in the comment boxes here. The Democratic candidates during the election also - even wrote a book equally singing about both parties. Not just President Trump. He's who is current now. :(", 'She seems not to have read the article.']
summary: Several commenters focus on what they are doing for lent, with several giving up things (pizza, chocolate, and caffeine) and one also saying they are adding going to church. Two commenters focus on the word "shrove', with one saying it means to absolve or take away, and the other saying it comes from "shriven" and has to do with reflecting on transgressions and confessing/repenting for sins. One commenter talks about the writing in the article, specifically liking the pancake puns and the alliteration throughout.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: A Plethora of Pancakes   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Tuesday: A lesson before Lent, Fat Tuesday festivities, and a girls-only chess challenge.
short_question: ['New York Today: A Plethora of Pancakes  ']

query: After The Lancet ran a series of papers on preventing stillbirths, Matthieu Zellweger was assigned to capture how parents dealt with their loss.
comments: ['Beautiful and heartfelt writing.  Reminds us that the full range of life is so sweet, sad and fragile. Blessings to these families.', 'Great article...except for the picture of the crematorium. My 29-year-old son was cremated. I got the ashes but never dared contemplate the process by which his body turned into ashes. That slide of the crematorium gave me an unnecessary shock. Cruel!', "We lost our beautiful son 2 weeks before his due date 8 years ago. Even though we are blessed to have 2 healthy children, not a day goes by that I don't think about Danny. Agree with other posters that this is a subject that is not discussed which makes it even more difficult. I was fortunate to have wonderful therapists and would recommend counseling to any other family going through this tragic event.", "Thanks. 15 years ago on Good Friday we lost our twins. You can't imagine the horror of delivering a baby like that. And the isolation. I hope this article helps people talk about it, but we have a long way to go in US.", 'As a pediatrician, I observed many couples go through this difficult process, Stillborn infants (and even some early spontaneous miscarriages) might be described as producing a deep sense of the loss of a parent\'s commitment to the pregnancy but without concrete memories of a child they can attach their feelings to. "These things often work out for the best." Is sometimes true, but it is not usually helpful. The only platitude that seems barely appropriate to the situation is, "I am sorry for your loss."', 'Having experienced the death of a fragile, preemie baby, as a grandparent, I think it is essential to allow family members to talk openly and freely about their grief in order to learn to live with the sadness that will always be in our hearts. Thank you for this article.', 'My niece was unexpectedly stillborn about three weeks before her due date. At the graveside service where she was laid to rest, no one shared memories of her, or talked about the things she accomplished in her life, or shared a small laugh over something she would have appreciated, or any of those things that make a funeral more bearable. We didn\'t have any of that, only grief and an infant-sized coffin. But because it\'s not something our society often talks about, I found many people did not understand the depth of grief that accompanies such an experience. Whether someone had experienced a still birth in their own family or not made the difference between "Sorry the pregnancy didn\'t work out" and "Sorry someone you loved died."', 'I despair when I see images like the sixth photo in the slideshow, showing the couple releasing balloons in memory of their stillborn child. I hope grieving families please find other, harmless ways to honor their family members, because balloon releases kill thousands of birds and other wildlife, including endangered sea turtles, each year. What goes up eventually comes down, and balloons kill animals on land and in the oceans by ingestion or getting tangled in broken balloons or balloon strings. In honoring a life lost by stillbirth please avoid balloon releases that can inadvertently kill innocent animals.', "I have to admit, I don't understand this. I'm sure it's very sad for the couple but to me, it's much sadder when people who are born alive, live for a period of enough time to have a personality, die. There was a stillborn in our family and I sometimes wonder what life would have been like had that person actually lived a real life. But in the end, this happens every single day in the animal population and the human population. The world is overpopulated with humans as it is. I wish we could focus on babies and children who are currently alive and desperately need homes and love.", "You don't understand it because you have never gone through it! As a mother who has, I pray you never have to, but you probably will be spending much of your time focusing on alive children and opening your home to them instead of overpopulating the world.", 'From the moment a woman realizes she is pregnant, the loving bonding with that baby begins.  Parents sing to it, kiss it, and share their hopes and dreams for this child for 9 months.  Early ultrasounds reinforce the reality and the sex of the child, beginning the process of figuring out a name.  Both parents listen to the heartbeat and experience kicking movements together. Rooms are painted and cribs are purchased based on these hopes and dreams for the future. Then, wham, that love, the excitement, and future die suddenly with the death of the baby.  Parents grief for their child that grew inside literally and symbolically, and the future memories they will not experience.  I think that there is enough compassion in the world to support those that die too early and those who live, but are suffering.', 'The love and attachment a parent feels for a child, even in utero, is unmatched by anything on the planet.  A stillborn birth is heart-breaking.  It is portrayals such as these that can help to cultivate the "understanding" -- the empathy, the compassion -- that you say you lack.  Study these photographs; powerful, educational.', "This is such a powerful story. Thank you for putting a spotlight on stillbirth, one of the least talked about tragedies of our time. If anyone would like to learn more about stillbirth prevention, please visit  www.countthekicks.org  --- it's a public awareness campaign that is saving babies across the US.  In Iowa, where Count the Kicks began, our stillbirth rate has dropped 26 percent. We went from 33rd worst stillbirth rate to 3rd lowest in just five years. Email me at  price.emily@healthybirthday.org  if you would like to learn more.", 'As a DES daughter, I have lived with the threat of having a stillbirth for many years, and in fact, we came extremely close to losing our baby a few years ago.  Emergency surgery, strict bed rest and other methods saved my pregnancy, but the sonogram picture taken on the day we came within hours of losing our daughter will haunt me forever.   My heart goes out to anyone who has gone through this terrible loss.', "My daughter was stillborn on Thanksgiving Day, 2009. We have photos of her, a special box with cards from family and friends, and mementos from her short time with us...including an impossibly small fabric pouch containing her cremated remains. Erin Kristine is always with us. Not a day passes that I don't think of her and miss her.", 'For Elias Jeanne who was upset by the photograph of the creametorium for dead -- born died babies.  I find nothing objectionable  about the photo.  We need to FACE reality.  And there it was staring us in the face.', 'Having had a stillbirth myself, I feel deep sorrow for the woman who had an induced labor after being "told 22 weeks into the pregnancy that the baby had a severe genetic abnormality and would not survive." And I feel intense horror for all the women the Republicans intend to force to carry such doomed babies week after week after week, induction forbidden, their hearts breaking into ever-smaller pieces. Induction would be considered "abortion," and therefore illegal, until that waning life finally dies and built-up toxins trigger a natural stillbirth at long last. Which is what happened to me, many years ago.', 'Thank you for your witness.  Am sending you my love and respect.', '❤', 'The lens story on still born infants should NOT have included that last photo showing the glowing orange oven in a darkened room. It made me gasp with horror and sadness for grieving parents. It was insensitive to include it, in my view.', 'I agree completely.  And, I am no shrinking violet when it comes to death and the aftercare of death.  It is deeply disturbing that the editor "approved" this image. I grew up in my Grandparent\'s funeral home.  We learned about "respect" for the deceased and their loved ones.  Four of my family members have died in my arms.   That image of the "oven" was not only disrespectful to the grieving parents, but also  to the infants.  It is emotionally cruel to every parent and family who is struggling with grief. The NYT knows better.  Therefore, the question remains: why further hurt the innocent?', 'Agreed. It was horrifically macabre and unnecessary', 'I 100% agree with you that the crematory photo should not have been included.  It is extremely disturbing.', "Our critically acclaimed documentary Still Loved shows how families survive after a stillbirth. It's a beautiful, sensitive & compelling film & is now available on Vimeo worldwide here:  https://vimeo.com/ondemand/stillloved"]
summary: Many of the commenters recall their own stories and grief at delivering stillbirth babies or being in families that have suffered the loss of a pre-term infant. They talk about rituals and events they went through to try to understand, grieve, and move on from their personal tragedies. They talk about all the preparations they made for having a child and how those happy moments were made tragic. A few commenters talk about other topics such as abortion and the photos in the article.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Photography; Stillbirth   Snippet: After The Lancet ran a series of papers on preventing stillbirths, Matthieu Zellweger was assigned to capture how parents dealt with their loss.

query: Sports betting offers the prospect of restoring an older, purer version of fandom — rooting for teams over players.
comments: ["Truly fascinating. I didn't even know gambling was illegal in the US. Probably comes from the moralistic worldview that also spawns those Creationists, nudity censors and 21-to-drink advocates? Well, the intelligent approach is clear. But who knows? Feelings matter in politics, too. We have seen that 2016.", 'Hegemonic, toxic masculinity reaps what it sows.', '"Legal gambling on sports doesn’t necessarily mean we will soon follow the example of European and Asian soccer teams that put the logos of online betting sites on the front of their jerseys." Mr. Kang, "doesn\'t necessarily mean"?  Affixing such logos might prove mighty tempting to Ivanka and open up a whole new option for her clothing line. She surely will not let European and Chinese couturial trends get ahead of her. The Trump family motto: "ONE FOR ALL! ALL FOR ONE! THE WORLD IS OUR OYSTER! GAME IT!" President Trump warned us that we would sicken of "all this winning."', 'Generous government pensions are a hungry, hungry beast and states are always looking for ways to feed it, whether by jacking up taxes, holding lotteries, gouging on tickets, fines and tolls or charging $13 for a packet of cigarettes that contain 25 cents worth of tobacco leaves. Sports gambling, legal dope and prostitution will keep pension plans afloat for a few more years -- and the best thing about it, only losers pay.', 'Dont do it!! Its legal here and in my view there will be a whole generation brought up to believe that the only way to enjoy sport is to be constantly betting on each move in any game. I am not a sports fan so I  am not well qualified to comment. However one only has to look at any live game to see the constant advertising in the ad breaks  and on the banners at the grounds. The tv ads in particular show how "normal" it is to betting all through the game with excessive shots if "high fives" as you "win big" with your mates. Australia has a big gambling problem and I suspect the industry is only too happy use this as another funnel to  groom future gamblers at the youngest possible age. You can now get yourself into big financial trouble right at home gambling on your smartphone as son as you are 18(?) and can get a credit card. The genie is out of the bottle here and I dont think it will ever be put back.', '"Over the past 20 or so years, the world of fantasy sports has broadened its originally stultifying conversations [...] into inquiries about how games are actually won on the field, whether by examining the way a baseball catcher frames pitches or by establishing the most efficient spots to shoot from on a basketball court. Fantasy talk evolved into real insight." Bill James and Rob Neyer and a whole generation of people who had begun the sabermetrics revolution would beg to differ.  That real insight was already being developed independently long before fantasy sports exploded, fantasy sports just made the masses aware of those insights.', "Old-timers remember when professional football and basketball were nothing in this country.   Until television came along, gambling was a major element of their success. During law school, I used to hang around a bookmaker's office as a diversion.   He ran it like the phone company - no rough stuff.  If your tab got too high, the utility was cut off.  Also, he was a registered professional gambler with the IRS.   Playing golf with law enforcement did not hurt. Nevertheless, after an NFL weekend the bookie generated a valise of earnings from the juice.   The NBA was almost as profitable given they had more dates.", 'Long overdue. Stop the nanny state.', 'My European cousin.. Wants to know Why gambling is illegal in the USA. In Europe people love to gamble, as do people in the far east , in fact gambling is one of those things that unite civilizations, something all can agree is enjoyable and exciting. So he wants to know why Americans do not like gambling. I told him American love to gamble, that we are no slouch in this department we spend Billions just gambling on one event-the Superbowl. So, he asked, why can\'t they do what they enjoy? Why make something they like to do illegal? aren\'t you people the Yankee doodle boys, don\'t you run your own country?   I explain to my European cousin, that gambling is allowed in certain cities, like Las Vegas. He wanted to know what make Las Vegas different from other cities, shouldn\'t something legal there be legal everywhere else. It can\'t be much of a crime if you can by whim and location make it legal.    He asked me if gambling was legal in NYC. I answered that it was illegal in NYC, unless its Horse racing, Again he didn\'t understand, why is one form of gambling is legal and another illegal?.   My Cousin left me with this: "You Yanks are very confusing,I know you people say you are the land of the free, but you have self imposed laws that check that freedom, i say Let people Gamble, the biggest gamble is life, and most of the time the dice come up snake eyes, so lets have some fun and excitement while we\'re here.".', 'The lesson here is, if you can\'t eliminate "bad" behavior, then regulate it.  So, legalize marijuana and prostitution, bring them into the mainstream economy, and reap taxes that will pay for schools and hospitals and other good things. Win-win.', 'What will be the real results of legalizing sports gambling? 1. more problem gamblers 2. more family problems ending with a disaster 3. more suicides 4. more bankruptcies 5. more foreclosures 6. more repossessed cars 7. more credit card defaults 8. more loss of employment 9. more unpaid loans 10. children without food or shelter 11. more white collar crime 12. more violent crime If sports gambling is legalized, after about 5 years the States will have no idea how to deal with this major problem. Problem Gambling - the hidden emotional disease. 1/4 of 1% of sports gambling revenue for education, research and treatment would be humane. If Government is going to be in the problem making business of sports gambling they should be in the business of knowing what to do with problems that this gambling will cause to the population.', "I like a bet every now and then on the football. A couple of quid on an accumulator and I'm done. However, gambling ruins lives and the ubiquity of it in the UK is staggering. You are bombarded all the time during the game. It's just so easy to fritter away thousands of pounds if you have a problem.", 'Well, except for the players who will now be enticed to fix games.', 'No.', 'This will happen.   Government is always looking for ways to increase revenue. Lotteries, computerized casinos, race tracks, and now, marijuana. BTW, fantasy is gambling.']
summary: Some commenters oppose legalizing sports gambling because it would ruin the experience of watching games and could even ruin people's lives by addiction and emotional stress. Several commenters feel that legalized gambling would be a cash grab for the government, like it is when they regulate marijuana and race tracks. Some commenters are surprised to find that gambling on sports is illegal, to begin with.
short_title: Headline: Could Legalized Gambling Save Us From the Insufferability of Fantasy Sports?   Keywords: Gambling; Fantasy Sports; Law and Legislation; Bradley, Bill; Christie, Christopher J; National Football League; National Basketball Assn   Snippet: Sports betting offers the prospect of restoring an older, purer version of fandom — rooting for teams over players.
subreddit: ['Gambling', 'Fantasy Sports', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bradley, Bill', 'Christie, Christopher J', 'National Football League', 'National Basketball Assn']
short_question: ['Could Legalized Gambling Save Us From the Insufferability of Fantasy Sports?  ']

query: Broiled butterflied trout works just as well for a weeknight meal as it does for company.
comments: ["When I had a Jenn Air I used to broil boned trout on it's broiler. Delicious, especially with browned almonds and couscous. So easy. Miss my Jen Air. I live where trout is plentiful.", 'Trout "Blau" is the best - with the head - savor the cheeks!', 'This is even better if you broil the trout skin side up... spray with skin with pam and salt it and let it start to blister. The flesh will be done but the skin crispy', "We love butterflied trout. If you'd rather not use the broiler, it's very easy to pan fry it in a teaspoon of oil and one of butter. I like to lightly dredge the seasoned fish in flour first, which really browns up nicely in the pan. Another fine topper is sliced almonds, browned in butter.", "If you gut, head and bone a trout (or any fish for that matter), what's left is fillet.  The fact that the two fillets are still connected makes absolutely no difference in taste or texture.  To get the taste and texture of whole fish, you've got to cook a whole fish...and that's a good idea anyway.", "That's a tomato server the squeezed lime is resting on.", 'In my part of the country (Boston) trout is often not available or not very good.  What kind of trout should one get and where?', "If you don't fish yourself, I would highly suggest making friends with a fisherman!"]
summary: Several commenters agree that the broiled butterflied trout is a delicious dish, and others suggest using fresh fish and broiling the trout skin side up. One commenter disagrees with the preparation method in the article, stating the butterflying the trout doesn't change its taste or texture but rather leaves it like two filets.
short_title: Headline: Fast and Easy Fish That Can Even Be Fancy   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Trout   Snippet: Broiled butterflied trout works just as well for a weeknight meal as it does for company.
short_question: ['Fast and Easy Fish That Can Even Be Fancy  ']

query: A London native who sped by motorcycle to cover the terrorist attack at Parliament recounts the mix of emotions it evoked.
comments: ["Lovely article. Beautiful architecture. Can't wait to go back.", '"So no, the city did not panic" - it is immensely tedious that the evening news here, our major newspapers have glowing reporting, OpEds (a reference to Churchill is sine qua non) glorifying the resilience, "the stiff upper lip" (thankfully, Farrell has spared us this), the unflappability of Londoners whenever there is an attack. Makes you wonder how deficient the people of Dresden, Hamburg, Berlin, Leningrad, Stalingrad, Nagasaki, Hiroshima, Hanoi, Aleppo, Tripoli, Gaza..who appear to be severely deficient in "stiff upper lip" if our media is to be trusted. Is there an element of closet racism involved - the same week as London an US commanded aerial strike on Mosul may have killed as many as 200 civilians. Trump\'s "Bay of Pigs" botched escapade on Yemen killed one of our elite soldiers but apparently 12 children including a child who was an US citizen.', 'In school during the Cold War, American kids were taught a lot about WW11, the Blitz, Churchill and what to do if the "big bomb" came. Londoners became our icons and heroes and I remember thinking, if they could take it, so could I. Churchill\'s words uttered years before my birth still give me a chill, "... if the British Empire and its Commonwealth last for a thousand years, men will say, \'This was their finest hour.\'" My heart to you, Great Britian.', 'Thanks for this interesting screen shot of the city of my birth. I left it for the first time after being bombed out in the Blitz. The houses on each side were destroyed, ours obviously not. Fate is a strange bird. And at that time, the house of Commons was also destroyed by a bomb, but is still there, with the statue of Churchill. London Pride.', '"There will always be an England"', 'As someone married into a English family and who has worked with many Brits overseas, the image of the stoic, always be an England, Brit is an illusion.  They are sick of immigrants, sick of being foreigners in their own capital, and most of all they are sick of these people bringing their conflicts to England with them.', "As someone who's lived in and around London for much of my life, I dispute your observations.  London, as a great gateway capital, has always been a city of immigrants and tourists.  It's the nature of the city, and has been for hundreds of years. London is entirely at ease with this.  As for 'these people bringing their conflicts to England (sic)' - the man who committed this crime was not an immigrant, or a foreigner, any more than the people who blew up the Grand Hotel in Brighton in 1985, in an attempt to kill Margaret Thatcher.  Is it OK for people to bring their conflicts here as long as they're white and nominally Christian? All over the UK, and particularly in London, we've endured bombs and attacks and endless disruption, and coped with stoic pragmatism.  I imagine we will continue to cope with the inevitable future disruptions.", "But London overwhelmingly voted to Remain in the European Union. Yes London where the full richness of multiculturalism is evident in its most extreme form. So sorry to undermine your hope to ride a tragedy with your your racial message but that doesn't work in London.", "Some are, having been spoon fed hate by the far right tabloid press for years. It's always telling that the people most likely to be against our new global Britain are the kind that live in the most ethnically homogenous places in the country. The only UKIP MP ever represented an area which was 98% white. These people have no real contact with foreigners, so they base their opinions on the hateful drivel in the mail or express. We are currently living in one of the most peaceful times of all time in London. Before the 97 there were multiple IRA attacks or attempted attacks in the country every year. This was the first since 2005 and was a bit of a flop really. More people die in crashes on the M25 every day. Don't let the lunatic succeed in driving a wedge into the heart of British society.", "There was no panic either during the IRA bombings of the 1980s. I worked in Westminster then, when bobbies had no guns, and the cops around Parliament were armed primarily with giant dental mirrors for checking the undersides of parked cars for bombs. Every now and then, not often, there'd be a muffled -bumpf- and some bomb would have gone off, somewhere nearby. It did not derange the tourists or the media or the government; we all just went about our business. It seemed to me the most sensible approach I have seen to terrorism and I miss it quite a lot here.", "Took me back.  I was a child in London during the IRA's campaign and anytime there was an  incident, nobody panicked. Everybody just got on life, went around the diversions, came back on a different day when places were closed.", "The day London is no longer exposed to terrorist attacks will be the day it withdraws into its shell.  It's no accident that London and most of Britain's other big cities voted to stay in the EU.
