Ironically, the Parliament that was close to, if not the direct target of, the latest attack is populated by too many cowards who are unworthy of London's cosmopolitan reputation.  I wish that its members would rediscover their spines, show some leadership, and reverse their headlong retreat into Little England.", "And while Big Ben continued tolling, Trump Jr. sent a mean spirited, sarcastic note to London's mayor on the very day of the attack.", 'Big Ben Tolls And The Statue of Liberty Still Guides us And The Arc de Triomphe reminds us And The Pope smiles at the capture of his hat and there are shoals still undiscovered To sink good ships... But ...when we have courage and good will To Survive There remains much hope.', "This city did not panic, but it's fair to say that the stiff British upper lip died a long time ago.", 'Not true. Speak to Londoners. Or live there.', 'A very moving article filled with memorable historical references. As the writer points out, London is a global capital in many ways- which is why it was attacked. These terrorists are attacking symbols of our civilization by killing innocent citizens. Yet, I wish the media would focus more on the victims than the attackers and pay more attention to the better aspects of our society, the average citizens from all over, on the streets of a global capital.', 'During the Second World War when London was blitzed there was a saying "London can take it". The city has certainly faced worse times including the Great Fire of 1666. I don\'t think an attack like this will stop the city in it\'s tracks.', 'They fought back in WWII, they should do the same now.', "'Fight back' like in WWII - how? Bomb Birmingham? (where the attacker came from). We Londoners, thankfully, don't see it that way. 'Refuse to be defeated', as we said after 7/7, as we said during the IRA period, is to refuse to be manipulated and bullied into abandoning our values and our solidarity and camaraderie.", 'Nestled (seemingly) safely here on the West coast of America in California, we too face our existential challenge of the day.  Is American democracy sound enough to withstand the natural social centrifical forces of boredom and angst, or will it now falter, shudder, and fail in some sort of an unforseen social malaise?  The human struggle to uncover what is truest deep wihin our souls will continue, until finally one day, it will succeed.']
summary: One commentator said that the Great Fire of 1666 was a worse event than the attack suffered recently. Another commentator liked the article because it was moving and for citing historical references. Another comment said that terrorists kill innocent people and attack national symbols, and I would like more attention to be paid to victims than to their attackers. Some comments were reports of personal experience, in moments of other attacks. Others say the attack will not succeed in overthrowing the English nation.
short_title: Headline: Big Ben Still Tolled   Keywords: Westminster Attack (March, 2017); New York Times; London (England)   Snippet: A London native who sped by motorcycle to cover the terrorist attack at Parliament recounts the mix of emotions it evoked.
short_question: ['Big Ben Still Tolled  ']

query: Wednesday: Sinatra’s “New York, New York,” a bull escape in Queens, and representatives around town.
comments: ["I'm disappointed no mention of who the baseball player was sitting next to Sinatra.It's Phil Rizzuto,a Brooklyn boy and a real New Yorker.", 'CORRECTION: With due respect to Messrs. Kander and Ebb - not to mention that consummate performer, Ed Koch - a torch song (pun intended) that would do New York proud, is the \'other\' New York-themed song from "On the Town." It is "Lonely Town" by Leonard Bernstein, with lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. The song must have been close to Frank Sinatra\'s heart, as he was apparently particularly peeved by its erasure - along with most of Bernstein\'s music - from the 1949 film version of "On the Town" by Arthur Freed, the all-powerful head of the "Freed Unit" at MGM, which produced the bulk of the lavish MGM musicals from the late 1940s to the 1960s. Sinatra would eventually record "Lonely Town" for his 1957 album "Where Are You?", and he performed it, one might say "with a vengeance," years later at a concert in Carnegie Hall. There he introduced the song by stomping his foot a couple of times on the floor of the stage and announcing to "Arthur" that he was going to sing "Lonely Town," and this time "Arthur" wouldn\'t be able to stop him. It was clear even to those in the audience who weren\'t in the know, that whoever "Arthur" was, he was "six feet under." Indeed, Arthur Freed had died the previous year.', 'When I was growing up, "The Bronx is up and the Battery\'s down!" was THE New York song and I always enjoyed hearing it. Maybe it\'s just because I loved it first or maybe it\'s really better (well, how can one song be "better" anyway), but I like it about 1000 times more than I like "New York, New York" which by now I actively dislike. It was okay the first couple dozen times I heard it, but by now, just ugh. The bombast that Sinatra projects became very off-putting.', "Senator Jeff Klein's constituents in NY Senate 34 are concerned with his alignment with the State Republicans. We would like him to have a town hall. After repeated calling he still hasn't decided.", "Sinatra did make this his own, but boy, Minelli's version resonates!", 'It will always be Liza\'s song, not Frank\'s.  It should be said that it is really Kander and Ebb\'s "Theme from New York, New York."  Sinatra changed the lyrics, much to Fred Ebb\'s chagrin.   John Kander said that he prefers Liza\'s version on NY1 recently.', 'NO BULL THIS Unlike Pamplona, with Devoted chasers full, Right here in old New York The bulls run after the bull.', 'I really don\'t know why you wouldn\'t make Billy Joel\'s version of "New York State of Mind", by Billy Joel....a choice.   Ms. Keys is definitely iconic, but so is he - and he wrote it.', 'In her cabaret act, Kaye Ballard said, "Several years ago, Liza Minnelli had a song about New York written just for her.  Recently, Frank Sinatra had the same song written just for him." Not only did Sinatra change the lyrics ("A Number One" was never IN the song let, alone inexplicably repeated) but due to his diminished vocal capabilities by the time he got around to singing it, he modulated DOWN where Kander and Ebb modulated UP, which has always made his version unlistenable for me, despite being a big Sinatra fan. To her credit, when Minnelli appeared with Sinatra and they sang the song together, she sang it in his key.  Still, for many of us who first heard her introduce it in the film, her original version from the soundtrack is far superior to his (admittedly better-selling) recording.', "Being a huge Sinatra fan, I was in New York last year, and rode the bus over to Hoboken to pay homage. My husband and I took the walking tour of Frank's boyhood haunts. We gazed at Manhattan from the shore. It was February, and in the winter light, I have never seen a more beautiful view of New York City.", "I always thought it was odd and dare I say it, sexist, that the Yankees would play Sinatra's version when they won, and Minelli's version when they lost. Not sure if they still do that though.", 'Jay Z\'s "song" is nothing but a uncreative laundry list of things in NY. I think it\'s garbage. The classic songs about NY that will last forever are New York, New York by Frank Sinatra, and New York State of Mind by Billy Joel. Jay Z\'s song should go the way of the subway token.', 'A quintessential New York song*   Another Hundred People  Another hundred people just got off of the train And came up through the ground, While another hundred people just got off of the bus And are looking around At another hundred people who got off of the plane And are looking at us Who got off of the train And the plane and the bus Maybe yesterday. It\'s a city of strangers, Some come to work, some to play. A city of strangers, Some come to stare, some to stay. And every day The ones who stay Can find each other in the crowded streets and the guarded parks, By the rusty fountains and the dusty trees with the battered barks, And they walk together past the postered walls with the crude remarks. And they meet at parties through the friends of friends who they never know. "Do I pick you up or do I meet you there or shall we let it go?" "Did you get my message? \'Cause I looked in vain." "Can we see each other Tuesday if it doesn\'t rain?" "Look, I\'ll call you in the morning or my service will explain." And another hundred people just got off of the train. ... https://www.allmusicals.com/lyrics/company/anotherhundredpeople.htm *To reopen a controversial subject, you\'re not a "real New Yorker" if you came by train.  :-)', "Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen's constituents (NJ 11th) scheduled Town Halls for him in four locations for this week after being told by his office that it was too difficult to find venues. Two have been held this week thus far, but he didn't show up. There are two more coming up: tonight at 7 in Little Falls and tomorrow at 7 in Livingston. Doubtful he will attend those either. They are being livestreamed on Facebook. See  http://www.nj11thforchange.org/  for details.", 'For a City song I prefer The Sidewalks of New York. I\'ve never seen all the lyrics before. The Sidewalks of New York Down in front of Casey\'s Old brown wooden stoop, On a summer\'s evening, We formed a merry group; Boys and girls together, We would sing and waltz, While the "ginnie" played the organ On the Sidewalks of New York. East side, west side, All around the town, The tots sang "Ring-a-Rosie," "London Bridge is Falling Down." Boys and girls together, Me and Mamie O\'Rourke, Tripped the light fantastic, On the sidewalks of New York. That\'s where Johnny Casey And little Jimmy Crowe, With Jakey Krause the baker, Who always had the dough; Pretty Nellie Shannon, With a dude as light as cork, First picked up the waltzstep On the Sidewalks of New York. East side, west side, All around the town, The tots sang "Ring-a-Rosie," "London Bridge is Falling Down." Boys and girls together, Me and Mamie O\'Rourke, Tripped the light fantastic, On the sidewalks of New York. Things have changed since those times, Some are up in "G," Others, they are wand\'rers, But they all feel just like me; They\'d part with all they\'ve got, Could they but once more walk, With their best girl and have a twirl On the Sidewalks of New York. East side, west side, All around the town, The tots sang "Ring-a-Rosie," "London Bridge is Falling Down." Boys and girls together, Me and Mamie O\'Rourke, Tripped the light fantastic, On the sidewalks of New York. http://www.kididdles.com/lyrics/s033.html', '"Sidewalks of New York" Traditional, familiar, and reminds us of Al Smith, the prototypical NY ethnic progressive whose vision foresaw the New Deal and the contribution of immigrant populations in the most cosmopolitan city in the country.', "Wait, Jay Z and Billy Joel get their credit and Leonard Bernstein doesn't get mentioned for 'On the Town'??", "I was born in New York, New York.  I've lived in the South Bronx, Mt. Eden, Moshulu Pkwy, Queens, Brooklyn, Jewel Avenue and Manhattan. New York, New York. There is nothing else that describes our wonderful metropolis.", 'Senators filibuster Devils', 'Played to death - in the same category as Stairway to Heaven to rock lovers and Suwannee River to Ralph Kramden. I have the same reaction to NY, NY that I have to "USA! USA!" - yeah, I love it too, but could we come up with something a bit less annoyingly repetitive? I\'m fine with any of the others you mentioned.', "Great day for this story of the Kander and Ebb classic, with Kander,s (somewhat experimental sounding) newest show opening tonight. A tribute to a composer who hasn't stopped working or trying to push boundaries.  Tune of Theme from New York New York Start checking the news They open tonight Dark show with lots of heart in it It's his new work We've seen all the clues And hope they are right You'll want to be a part of it New work, new work You'll want a ticket while the prices don't get too steep Next week there's E number two G number five, C seventeen, A number one There's nothing to lose Though seating is tight Fans wanna see John make a brand new start with it With his new work Aaaand if they make a splash down here Bring it uptown later this year Come on come through New Work, New Work! New Work!", "Joan,  I'm nostalgic for the days when theater was affordable. I grew up in white collar working class family and lived in a housing project. Yet my mother saw everything, and took me to four or five shows a year.", 'Off- and off-off Broadway are still affordable and doing wonderful things.  Check out a subscription to the Vineyard.  They have a pretty good track record. That said, I do remember the $1.95 seats in the balcony where we could get to see even the biggest Broadway shows!', "Joan: I do occasionally see off-B'way shows as a guest. The quality is even more uneven than for B'way shows today."]
summary: Most of the commenters say that they liked the article and go on to talk about their favorite songs about New York, New York. A lot of commenters note Frank Sinatra's song New York. While a few commenters mention that they like Jay Z's song On the Town, one commenter claims that On the Town should go the way of the subway token. One commenter says they feel the NY Yankees are sexist for playing Sinatra when they won and Minelli when they lost. A few commenters make a note of NY politics and townhalls.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Our City’s Anthem   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Wednesday: Sinatra’s “New York, New York,” a bull escape in Queens, and representatives around town.
short_question: ['New York Today: Our City’s Anthem  ']

query: Would you say you are more of a “glass is half-full” or a “glass is half-empty” type of person?
comments: ['I am both a pessimist and an optimist depending on the situation.  I stare at what once was a pile of marshmallow peeps and think how sad it is there is only one left, but also on the bright side there is one left. I switch between views often, but on most matters, I am one or the other. Usually I use pessimistic views to tell jokes and optimistic ones to help people see the bright side of things.', 'There will always be optimists and pessimist wherever we go. Whatever you choose to be, is up to you. Optimists look at the glass half full where as pessimists look at the glass half empty. Optimists usually radiate positive, they will motivate other to do better and will smile at the simple things in life. Pessimists have a gruff time do this. I am a very busy 18-year-old and I try my best to always look at the glass half full.', 'Glass half-full!', "the past is history - the future a mystery - all we have is now - enjoy every moment ! that said - I've read that habitually negative people may have suffered a major disappointment/trauma as a child -  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Qjy-ydl9QE  - I can't help that - or their gloomy reality, but I'm happy to keep on my happy track !", 'This afternoon, I looked at the pictures and thought that the cup was half full. This makes me an optimist, a person that sees the bright sides in things. However, sometimes I also see the negative side.  In my experiences, when it rains, I am happy we won’t have a drought, but I still don’t like it. I cannot enjoy the nature and things around me when everything is wet. I just don’t feel comfortable. When I was a little kid, I sometimes didn’t enjoy rain because I can’t go outside and play.  So I suppose I would describe myself as neither an optimist nor a pessimist.', "\xa0 \xa0 \xa0_______________________________________________________ \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0If you aren't getting your wish... \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0simplify it: wish only for a tomorrow... \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0\xa0 \xa0 \xa0you'll be happy everyday, except maybe one day. \xa0 \xa0 \xa0_______________________________________________________", 'I see where you are coming from but if everybody wished for tomorrow nothing would happen today', 'If yesterday didn\'t give you what you wanted, \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 today isn\'t over. If things aren\'t what you wanted today, \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 look forward to tomorrow. If tomorrow doesn\'t bring you your "wants", \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 become a Buddhist -- they reincarnate forever... \'til they attain Nirvana!', "I am a person who looks at as many sides of an issue that I can--the positive as well as the negative. I wish I could only look at the positive--the positive people I know tend to be the happiest.  But they also tend to not look at issues very deeply.   When I ask an optimist for his/her thoughts on consequences, or motivations, or questionable histories, they think I'm a Negative Nelly, when I am really simply trying  to learn more. I really wish I could find people who could talk about all aspects of a situation, without being considered a kill-joy.", "As an optimist, I am struck by pessimists who seem to find no joy in the simple miracle that we are here and that we are capable of helping each other within our own abilities and skills.  Pessimists seem to compare their situations versus others and remember best the times when they or someone they know was victimized/injured/screwed and rarely reflect on their success and that of others.  To many pessimists I know Life is always a slog - people cannot be trusted because they are 'always' selfish - and the like.", 'Now 77 years old and having worked on a Medical device invention for 25 years, and about to launch the product and expect to live to at least 110 I would say that I am an Optimist']
summary: Most commenters indicate that they are optimists or that they wish they were optimists. One commenter says that it is important to keep trying. Another commenter says it is important to enjoy every moment as much as possible, while another marvels at our sheer existence. One commenter indicates that they look at all aspects but wish they could look at mostly the positive.
short_title: Headline: Optimists and Pessimists   Keywords:    Snippet: Would you say you are more of a “glass is half-full” or a “glass is half-empty” type of person?
short_question: ['Optimists and Pessimists  ']

query: In this video, Times journalists at a BTS concert in Newark explore what draws so many black fans to Korean pop music.
comments: ['This film shows how many African Americans like Korean pop. A lot of African Americans a like to attend the concerts of the Korean pop band named BTS. Some African Americans wanted to change somethings about Korean pop. One African American woman said that Korean pop music doved her crazy when she heard Korean pop. At the beginning of the video the lady who is speaking says that Korean pop exploded in the years since Youtube was created. This means that this music genre has been popular for a very long time. In my opinion, BTS is a very great band with a lot of talent.', 'What stood out most to me was when multiple people talked about how similar k-pop was to hip pop, and to be honest I don’t listen to k-pop, but from what I have heard and/or seen they are not that similar. The whole video was a surprise to me. I had no idea that k-pop had such a huge black fan base. The best part was when someone had said that the reason she loves k-pop was that she could be herself and let her creativity flow and others say they love it because of how it brings people of all types of people. And the message that that idea sends is that just because something isn’t necessarily “popular” in your situation doesn’t mean you can’t pursue it, all that matters is that you are happy in the end.', 'I have a couple of friends who are black who have been long-time fans of many K-Pop groups and artists. At first, I found this odd because the two cultures seem dissimilar in many ways; but the music itself has unified these groups of people despite it. Throughout the history of popular music, language barriers have never been too great for people of different parts of the world to connect and enjoy. I think it much easier now for the music to spread with a greater access to technology. People are no longer limited to only hearing the music that plays on their local radio station or what is sold nearby. I think this interaction shows how much more dominant Western cultures can be in music. In the video, many of the black fans said they can find some similar styles and English phrases in the songs that they enjoy, which makes me wonder how much of the Korean culture do they actually truly learn more about or appreciate. Though I find the "crossing of cultures" good and important, I hope that the appeal towards K-Pop comes from more than its similarities to Western/American popular music but also its uniqueness and strong depiction of Asian/Korean culture.', 'The film surprized me in the fact that I can see a cycle in the globalization steak. It is not just a one way thing where the music is diffused to another area but on top of that the ather areas have put their influence on the music, altering it in a different way and then diffusing that music style as well. It is fascinated to see the streanght of communication that music has brought among our cultures. People from completly different cultures who are absolute opposites of one another in features, backgroungs and even belief systems are able to communicate well with each other in music.', 'Trying to watch this video was a major fail because of the spinning effect it had on it, so instead of getting to watch the video I had to listen to the audio. While listening to the teens in the video speak about K-pop it sounds like it has the same effect a regular band has on other teens. K-pop lets teens be themselves and allows them to make new friends that shares the same excitement as each other. One complaint I heard was the fact that K-pop uses a lot black genre but never credits it. They also have controversy in cultural races causing racial problems, but other than that K-pop seems to keep their fans happy!', 'Watching this, I was very intrigued that people with different cultures could come together to do things that they enjoy. As this one girl said when she was interviewed, "I love the way it brings people together. People from every place around the world can come together for one group with a language they don\'t even speak, but somehow, music is universal and they all understand it." K-Pop sounds similar to the type of music in America, which shows that there is cultural connections between the two.  Music can bring people together from around the world and it showed that any music can influence any person anywhere in the world.', 'I agree, the magic of connection in music is amazing. Music is something that can bring different people to get findings of something similar to one another. From all across waters, across borders, across neighborhoods, across religions Music will spread through any place. Music is not for one person it will cause Korean Artist to apeal to African Americans. From the United States to Asia, Africa, and western Europe. The main message of the film has all and everything to do with people and music. It is very special in that these are the things we do but do not highlight. Music is made to connect, spread, and change. But most of all music is a brige that leads to many routes.', 'I was also intrigued by how the fans were all able to understand the music despite it being in another language. The video shows how K-Pop unifies the different cultures, but also how the cultures have adopted some elements of the popular styles of music as their own. Part of me feels like this is the major reason why some many people can enjoy it: because it sounds similar to popular music in Western/American culture. I think that the lines are becoming more and more blurred in the differences between many genres of music. I think that the video showed how this has been unifying but also controversial.', 'In the film "Crossing Cultures: Black K- pop Fan in America", shows a K- pop group who sings and rap in Korean. This Korean group are formerly known as the BTS and their are one of the best K -Pop groups. The Korean group has sold out two shows in New York and New Jersey. Nicole Fineman , Samantha Quick, and Logan Jaffe film artists want to know why. So these film artist went to the show and interview people. To get a better understanding why so many people in America want to go see a Korean group. While interviewing the film artist found out majority who paid to see BTS perform were African Americans. I found it quite surprising that K- Pop is listened to by many African Americans as soon as i heard that I became very interested in this film. I always appreciate in people finding interest in other cultures. While the film artist were at the K -Po show they interview the audience on why they are fond of the BTS. Sometimes the BTS music can have controversy between people. However many people enjoy BTS crossing of music.', 'I was surprised to see the combination of Korean pop culture and Black culture. It was very intriguing to see how that combination would play out. The two cultures seemed pretty different to each other and they are uniting together to enjoy a similar genre of music. The reason why I found this combination so intriguing was mainly because of the difference in location to where these music genres are popular. K-Pop is very popular in Asia, which surprised me when i saw the trend spread to America, especially people associated with " black culture ". But I also understand the trend because of the similarities between american pop music and K-pop. The language is different, but the style of the music is similar which is why k-pop has influenced so many different types of people.', "This film was very interesting because kpop is widely seen as Asian music by a lot of people, it was interesting to see that many of the fans and supporters were black.  This was because I i did not expect black americans to be so into the kpop culture. This film goes to show that music unites people, cultures and countries and that you can't judge music just like you can't judge a book by it's cover", 'The mixing between the Korean pop culture and Black culture is odd yet great combination. The two cultures have many differences but have found a way to intertwine and unite, which is the whole concept of America or the “melting pot”. Many Korean pop songs include english phrases or words, however the song is not entirely in english which is why it is an odd concept when it comes to non-Korean speaking fans, such as many of their black fans. One of the examples of K-pop groups that have many black fans was the male group BTS, and some fans explained they liked the group because of the added rap in their songs. I have heard many of the BTS songs myself and I do admit the rap in some of the songs sounds like American pop music, except for the language difference, which may have affected my opinion of the band.', 'I absolutely agree with Emily Gardner statement "Mixing between" the Korean pop cultures and African American culture "is old but great combination. The Korean cultures is very different from African culture. So to hear a band called the BTS sing songs mixed with African American culture in it I was truly curious on how they came up with such an idea. Throughout the film I was hoping Nicole Fineman, Samantha Quick, and Logan Jaffe would ask the band on what lead them to combined African American  culture and their culture into their music? Another question I wanted an answer to is do they know their combining the two cultures together and If so how come they have not given credit to the African Americans? Even though my questions were answered it\'s still nice to hear people finding interest in other cultures.', "The cross between the K-pop culture from Korea and black culture in America is something I would have never guessed, causing me to be rather intrigued. These are two completely different cultures from opposite sides of the world that have connected and made people feel included in something they love. The globalization of culture is now being blown up due to online platforms such as YouTube and Twitter as stated in the video. Another interesting thing is seeing how many people go to these K-pop concerts while a majoroty of people in America don't even know that it is a growing culture with followers from all walks of life.  That just goes to show the power of music and its ability to connect people.", 'I am not surprised that K-Pop is so popular because it is very easy to enjoy. You do not have to worry about the language of whether or not you understand the feeling that they are trying to convey. All you do is sit back and enjoy the music. I for one listen to K-Pop as well as reggaeton, even though I do not speak Korean or Spanish. I was shocked that there is such a large following of black K-Pop fans in the U.S. but it makes a bit of sense because we have our roots in hip hop and many K-Pop artists include that in their music. Unfortunately, there has been a stereotype of K-Pop listeners as being “weird” which is something we should eradicate because there are weird people in every following. Another reason why K-Pop will not dominate the American radios is because people want to be able to understand the and even its meaning - which is strange to say, have you listened to what’s on the radio?', "I never knew about K-Pop or what it was until about a few months ago, I also never knew any K-Pop music groups or that they performed right here in the U.S. What was suprising was that these concerts actually get sold out. Also it was mentioned how 90's R&B is somehow heard into K-Pop music and how one girl was saying how she wished they gave out credit to that. I agree with her even though I never heard any K-pop music I could here in the video the BTS group singing some vocals and I got that 90's feeling. 90's R&B is the main type of music I listen to so maybe when I find the time I will try to listen to a few K-Pop songs and try it out for myself.", 'Globalization help spread and blend many cultural elements of different groups of people into something unique. American music, which is pop culture, is listen to worldwide so it is normal for other country culture to have some influence on the U.S. The African American people in the video state that K-Pop appeal to them because they can see African American artist influence on the music or some of their own cultural ideas in it, they like the blend of international music. I was surprised that there are so many fan of K-Pop who are English speakers because they cannot understand the meaning of the lyrics and it was intended for a Korean audience. The message you can get from this film is people should try to be open minded and willing to be exposed to different cultures.', 'After having watched this video I realize that you are absolutely correct no one freaks out that American country music is played in places like England or South Africa, so why is it such a big deal now for k-pop to have a lot of black fans. The people of world are becoming more interconnected and even if some social norms tend to be completely different in different places there will always be some point of similarity and it could honestly just go down to how they are simply both human and those similarities can create strange/random connections like this one, but in truth they are just people trying to express their individual love for a certain type of music and who knows the blending might be a lot better than the things being celebrated separately.', '|TAB| While K-Pop may be becoming more and more popular around I don’t see it ever becoming a trend or common thing. The problem is when it comes to its popularity is many people see it is as dumb or pointless and I have to admit I tend to feel that way. I really do not comprehend the point of listening to pop music you can’t understand. While some may argue “It’s not about the words it’s about the music” I feel like that really only applies to more artful styles of music like opera not pop music. Another reason I don’t see its popularity growing is because of how people view its fan base. While I don’t believe in stereotypes K-Pop viewers have developed the stereotype of kind of being weird people. And of course they’re not all weird people and all fan bases will have weird people it’s just they have been given that stereotype which will impede the spread of the music.', 'i also agree that most people might think that listening to it is pointless but there are many genres of music that do not have words and there are lots of people who listen to it. i also don\'t feel the need to listen to kpop because i don\'t enjoy most music out of hip hop. i wasn\'t surprise when one of the interviewee\'s stated" they should accredit hip hop.', "Although most of your statements do make sense Todd, I have to disagree with you because even though you feel as if Kpop is not becoming a new trend and is pointless, there is a huge fan base spanning across the world that would think otherwise. And again I also know that it is your prerogative to voice your opinion about people listening to Kpop without a clue, but listening to music is not about understanding it. It is actually about learning about a different culture other than your own and gaining a sense of respect for an individual's art. I personally can say I understand listening to music I cannot understand because I am an African American but I really love spanish music but that does not impede me from listening to it. When hip-hop was starting out many people were reluctant to listening to it because it was seen as bad and had a small fan base but little did they know it would spread like wildfire and attract people from every culture and influence other genres of music similar to Kpop. I think Kpop will make it onto the world stage but things take time to happen.", "yea! I've never heard of K-Pop until this year. I still wouldn't listen to it though because it doesn't sound like something i'd be interested in. I also don't think it would become a common thing because not everyone likes korean music , but its nice to see cultures connecting with other cultures.", 'In today’s society, it is unusual to see cultures connecting with other cultures. Considering the culture of black people, they are usually seen as strong. Asian culture is usually seen as respectful. Seeing these two cultures connect is intriguing, as it is evidence that cultural differences don’t always separate people. It’s common to think that cultures with vast differences will never join together, but eventually something will show up and connect them. It is important to know that differences will never make connections impossible, despite flaws and contradicting cultural aspects. Our society of today still doesn’t understand that and still acts baffled when things like this happen.', "I agree with your statement. Cultures are rarely merged together, which makes this instance very complex. It seems that the people can't get along with each other due to cultural differences. But if you put those things to the side then you can find many similarities between many cultures, which is expressed heavily when it has to deal with the cultural music of a certain group of people vs another group of people", "I agree with you that seeing these two cultures connect is truly intriguing. The fact that these two different countries can share a common cultural connection is something that people could act baffled about. It comes to show that people are going to find interests in other countries that can influence the spread of their interest. As K-pop is now spreading to America, it could cause more people to listen it and make it even more worldwide. It comes to show that differences in people's cultures makes it still possible for other people to enjoy the same thing they do or listen to.", 'I agree that black culture and Korean culture have a vast amount of differences, and in this case in particular it could been seen as peculiar that they have crossed together through k-pop music. Their differences keep the cultures unique though they have taken parts or bits from one another and fused each of their cultures in a way. I also agree that even though they may be highly different cultures they share similarities that can be shared and can create a connections between different groups of people. Even when they do not share similarities they can adopt something from another culture that can then serve as a common attribute.', 'This film was very interesting because I would have never guessed in a million years that kpop has become the new trend in the world. Although kpop is widely seen as Asian music by a lot of people, it was interesting to see that many of the fans and supporters were black.  This was because I i did not expect black americans to be so emerged into the kpop culture. Proof that kpop has become the new cultural and music trend can be seen at my school because a new kpop form has been started for people similar to of that in the video. This film goes to show that music unites people, cultures and countries. From now on I will not judge a book by its cover', 'While most of your statements are true K-Pop is definitely not the new cultural and music trend. While our school may have a K-Pop club it only has about 12 or so members at a school of around 1,500 students. And K-Pop can never really take off because people wanna connect to their music. They wanna be able to sing along with it and understand the meaning behind the lyrics, and most people do not speak Korean so they really cannot do that with this kind of music. So while K-Pop may take root with some people it will never be a widespread thing in the U.S.', 'I agree that it was surprising to find out so many African American are fans of K-Pop since they don’t speak that language. Their cultural differences make it seem unlikely that African American would be attracted to K-Pop and their messages. I did not know about the increasing popularity of K-Pop or that it have some African American influence before this film so it was interesting to learn about their diverse fans. I also agree that music can united people because it allow them to express themselves and shared something in common since you don’t have to understand the words in order to enjoy songs.', 'I agree with you. I thought that Korean pop was not as famous as it is today. It is amazing how people from another culture like African Americans are fascinated with Korean pop. I expect African Americans to like hip hop or rap more than they lie Korean pop. Korean pop is a music genre that has been growing a lot in recent years. This type of music unites cultures with other cultures, and countries with other countries. Just because Korean pop does not sound very popular, it does not mean it is not popular. Korean pop should be played on radio stations so more people are able to hear it.']
summary: Commenters overall express surprise that there are a large number of Black fans of Kpop. They cite the huge differences in cultures as why they are surprised. However, others comment on how it's not surprising because of the globalization of trends, including trends in music. Finally, some commenters talk about how music is a universal language, so it makes sense that Kpop would have fans of all races.
short_title: Headline: Teaching With: ‘Crossing Cultures: Black K-Pop Fans in America’   Keywords:    Snippet: In this video, Times journalists at a BTS concert in Newark explore what draws so many black fans to Korean pop music.
short_question: ['Teaching With: ‘Crossing Cultures: Black K-Pop Fans in America’  ']

query: Julia, a new character on “Sesame Street,” gives me hope that my children will grow up in a world where autism is normalized.
comments: ["I'm glad of this step Sesame Street has taken.  Much better than the short-lived Sesame Workshop character with a parent in prison.  We need these new characters to continue to live and work through the special problems that come with the burdens they carry.  We have a lot of children in this country who are trying to live well despite their parent's incarceration, and they deserve all the help we can give them.", "My 9.5 year old son (adopted at birth) has autism and ADHD likely from FASD (fetal alcohol w/birth mother & his older birth father's sperm.  Man. Oh. Man.  Im tired.  My little guy's gotta be.  If that yard and a half of fleece can make one day easier, we all win and I'm going to kiss her little fuzzy brown lips.", 'I commend Sesame Street for their well-intentioned efforts.  However, the important thing is to find out what is causing so many of our precious children to be born with or develop autism.  No matter how much you try to "normalize" it, it is an impairment and a life sentence that you wouldn\'t wish on your worst enemy.   Something - probably the pesticides, untested chemicals and other toxins we are all exposed to - is harming far too many childrens\' lives.', 'Being autistic is "a life sentence you wouldn\'t wish on your worst enemy"? What a horrible thing to say. I have a joyful autistic son. I treasure him, and I wouldn\'t trade him for anyone in the world. Thankfully the people around him love him, respect his differences, accommodate his needs, and help him reach his full potential. You should learn more about neurodiversity--and kindness.', "Being over 60 and looking back at my childhood classmates, I can recognize several cases of undiagnosed Asperger's.  I suspect the more serious cases of autism were diagnosed as retarded, as was referred to lack of reasoning capacity back then. To me it is like dyslexia.  My father (born 1917) in hindsight clearly had dyslexia.  My brother (born 1954) clearly has it.  My niece (born 1992) was diagnosed as dyslexic when she started school.  She had ameliorative intervention and graduated from college, a project that her dad and her grandfather had each started but been unable to finish.  My otherwise sensible social worker mother in her last years would often lament that she had no gotten that help for her son and I would have to remind her that no one identified dyslexia when he was a boy,", '“Spectrum” implies a common physiological cause, differing only in severity.  Sharing some symptoms, while differing enormously in say intellectual ability, does not establish anything more than suspicion of a common cause.   And folks, exactly why are new, costly episodes of Sesame Street necessary?  All those years of past episodes lie dormant.  They already done terrific.', 'New episodes of Sesame Street are welcome, particularly to address contemporary issues like this one.', 'If I hear one more person say "I was diagnosed with autism in my 30s" or "40s" or whatever, I will explode. You do not have autism, even though you\'d like to think you do. If you truly had autism, you would have been diagnosed at 2 or 3 years old. All you are is socially awkward. You can call it Aspergers if that makes you feel special. In fact, a lot of us are socially awkward but, over time, we learn what works. I am sick of people saying, "Tee hee, I am so socially awkward. I totally have autism." Even Jerry Seinfeld and Darryl Hannah claim that they have autism. Out of respect for people who truly have autism, like my daughter, please stop it. Yes, it\'s a spectrum, but you are not on it.', "That's certainly an opinion. Some of us who are 40 years old have been diagnosed with many psychiatric and physical disorders, given numerous medications and treatments. None of it worked. It only made me feel more alienated. I thought my response to noise at work was absolutely bizarre. So did my boss, unfortunately. Too many footsteps or voices outside of my office and I would become irate. Then I'd shut down and fall asleep. When my sister's 2 year old was diagnosed, so was I. The very same day! What a relief it has been to get appropriate treatment. Don't ever tell another person what they do or do not have. It's discouraging and not very thoughtful.", "As the sibling of someone with autism there are few things I've learned.  The problems other people have with anyone who is different don't end once the person is an adult.  They continue and, in some cases, get worse.  If there is a way to take advantage of a handicapped adult, especially one who has autism, it will be done.  If it's to a person's advantage to portray someone like my brother as a danger that will be done.  If there's a way to say he's a sexual predator even though he's not, that's done too.   What I've learned is that normal people are more of a danger to my brother than he is to any of them.  Even the police don't know how to deal with someone like my brother.  Even seasoned educators prefer to call the police rather than tell him to his face to leave them alone.  It's not enough to introduce a Muppet that is autistic to a children's show:  how about introducing a few adults who are autistic to serious adult shows?", 'Hey hen3ry, thanks for reminding us why you are so righteously tough. Hang in there.', "As an adult who diagnosed himself with high functioning autism after my son was diagnosed, I share your hope that Sesame Street's Julia will lead to greater acceptance of Autism. . Another character doing that:  Sheldon Cooper on the Big Bang Theory.  Jim Parsons has said that he plays Sheldon Cooper as Autistic.   I think he gets it right - in a comic way.   The show's creators have danced around the Autism issue - but maybe that's a benefit:  we can get to know Sheldon Cooper as Sheldon Cooper (with all his Autism inspired quirks) because Autism isn't played up in discussion of the show. . All of that said, I am eager to see how Julia is portrayed on Sesame Street; and whether Jim Parsons will come back and appear in a skit with her.", 'If people say they\'ve learned about autism from watching this show, will the response be "You\'ve watched a muppet with autism, that means you\'ve watched ONE muppet with autism"? It\'s wrong to think you know something about it from a nephew or a neighbor, but a fictional character it\'s OK?', 'I think a lot can be said about how others respond.', 'When my autistic daughter was in elementary school, she walked the perimeter of the playground. The other children used her for target practice. They got the most points if they hit her in the head with a ball. Will Julia help with bullying?', 'What evidence do you have that diversity in programming doesn\'t have any affect on how these groups are perceived?  There is evidence that 1. Children watch and enjoy Sesame Street, 2. They learn from it and 3. Increased presence of racial, ethnic, abled, LGBTQ, and religious diversity in the media does change public perceptions. You may not "see" race, but then you\'re also not hearing perspectives that are different from yours!', 'Folks on the autism spectrum only have some things in common, each is also a unique individual, like the rest of the neurotypicals. Yes kids and adults will continue to be intolerant, but it can become less acceptable to be intolerant, just as it is now unacceptable to praise the institution of slavery.', 'Um...based on the comments here few appear to have a clue about what autism is.  I am not saying that this is the case with the writer and her family, but I also suspect that docs may be diagnosing too many people with autism, just as they have done with "attention deficit disorder."  That said, I am all for Sesame Street, its autistic puppet, and its groundbreaking work in general over the years.  I wish it started even earlier and that our current president had the oppurtunity to watch it on his gilded TV and perhaps learned something about empathy, that is, assuming he is not the sociopath he appears to be.', 'To be brutally honest, I think this idea for an autistic muppet is ridiculous. It\'s not like including all this "diversity" in children\'s programs really does all that much to make kids more tolerant. Kids are always comparing themselves and each other. This just feels like a waste of time to me.  I had plenty of non-white friends growing up for instance. It\'s not because of black history month or any of the *insert stigmatized group here* week/month initiatives. Really, the less tv or anyone spoke to us about our "differences," the more we were willing to hang out. We just saw other kids- not black, white, asian, paraplegic, what have you. Suddenly you consciously bring up someone\'s differences and say that their "special" in their own unique way and you\'re just giving kids ammo to attack each other. It doesn\'t make anyone more tolerant, it\'s validating the fact that they\'re different. Telling kids "this person\'s different, be nice?" Not going to do anything other than put them on display.  Kids already are looking for reasons to insult or exclude each other. It\'s unfortunate but normal, and part of growing up. Don\'t put certain kids on display- you\'re just giving other kids one more reason to stigmatize them.', 'What evidence do you have that diversity in programming doesn\'t have any affect on how these groups are perceived?  There is evidence that 1. Children watch and enjoy Sesame Street, 2. They learn from it and 3. Increased presence of racial, ethnic, abled, LGBTQ, and religious diversity in the media does change public perceptions. You may not "see" race, but then you\'re also not hearing perspectives that are different from yours!', 'Actually, in my life experience, it definitely was more a matter of "the less we point this out, the more likely we are to shrug off difference." I\'d hang out with other kids of diverse backgrounds and get a better understanding of their lives BECAUSE we weren\'t consciously talking about race. You go to another kid\'s house not thinking about the fact that they\'re different from you, and you\'re just immersed in a different world, and it\'s interesting, but at the end of the day you really don\'t treat them differently and you\'re still treating each other civilly on the schoolyard.  Now I go to university, and all this diversity programming has people buying into these fabricated or half baked realities of what these groups are like. You get a student from a wealthy white suburb who never actually dealt with the people featured in diversity programs, and they think what they\'re told is the whole story, and act on this impulse. And it creates a xenophobia in its own right. Like I\'m against BLM not because I\'m racist, but because I\'ve seen the statistics, I\'ve worked in situations side by side with people in these communities, and BLM doesn\'t seem to be hitting home at the real issues as I see them. But you have all these kids who grew up with their spoon fed realities based on diversity programs and the like, and they just shut off as soon as you tell them otherwise. "My school said this" or "the tv said this," and suddenly that makes it correct?', 'When my son was little, another mother complained to me about all those black and hispanic muppets. "What are they trying to prove," she asked. I replied that it\'s nice for kids who watch The Muppets to see themselves reflected in the characters. She was stunned. Apparently, it never occurred to her that some of the children watching Sesame Street aren\'t white.', 'I think it is an interesting idea to introduce Julia along with additional materials for families to discuss and learn from her role.   Given that I don\'t see how having an autistic muppet makes it any easier for her children to "navigate the social world".  That requires going out and just doing it - even if you\'re a neurotypical as she calls others.  They would also do better with coaching from their mother who seems to have found success with the diagnosis.', 'It’s a particular problem with kids who rarely speak and then when they do, they don’t speak normally.', "My son has autism spectrum disorder and he is 4 and he goes to a preschool specially for kids with disability's and now he is talking like he should be.", "Ed, that's inaccurate-- autism is much greater of a spectrum and much more complicated than what you described.  https://www.autismspeaks.org/what-autism"]
summary: Several commentators share stories of autistic families or children, such as one being used for target practice by other children. Several other commentators hope that an autistic character on Sesame Street will forward greater acceptance of autism. Some commentators criticize the article for oversimplifying the issue. A few commentators believe that many people with "autism" don't have it. One commentator goes on a long rant about an autistic puppet being "ridiculous."
short_title: Headline: What a Muppet With Autism Means to My Family   Keywords: Autism; Television; Asperger's Syndrome; Elmo (Fictional Character); Sesame Workshop; Families and Family Life; Children and Childhood   Snippet: Julia, a new character on “Sesame Street,” gives me hope that my children will grow up in a world where autism is normalized.
subreddit: ['Autism', 'Television', "Asperger's Syndrome", 'Elmo (Fictional Character)', 'Sesame Workshop', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood']
short_question: ['What a Muppet With Autism Means to My Family  ']

query: Modern tools of communication make it possible to spread lies with lightning speed. But conspiracy theories are nothing new.
comments: ['Where did we get the term "conspiracy theory"?  From the theory that there was a conspiracy to kill President John Kennedy. That theory has, 54 years on, been shown to be correct. The exact details may still be hidden from light, but the essential facts are all there to show that the notion that Lee Harvey Oswald, acting alone, killed the President is laughable. Thus there must have been, and was, a conspiracy to murder the President. But now the term itself has been twisted into being a put down, a slander, a mocking term to describe anyone and everyone who believes all manner of things, much of it utter nonsense, some of it very possibly true. Now there is no distinction between the nonsense (vaccines cause autism, Sandy Hook never happened) and the possible/probable (the 911 attacks were allowed to take place).  It\'s an effective tool, to twist the term "conspiracy theory" into a direct association which crack-pottery. Label someone a "conspiracy believer" and you might as well call them crazy. When in fact, someone who believes that an unknown group of people, possibly within our own government, may have been behind a plot to assassinate President Kennedy, is not a "conspiracy theorist" like the  Sandy Hook truthers.  The people who believe JFK was killed by a deliberate plot, carried out by more than just Lee Harvey Oswald, base their determination on facts, reason, and logic, bolstered by years of fact finding.', "Pure speculation on my part, or conspiracy if you will, but I'd guess there's an inverse relationship between the flourishing of these theories and the state of education in America. Not to mention that they quickly acquire value as commodities. How many books has the Kennedy killing spawned at this point? Hundreds, I'm guessing.", 'Conspiracy theories are not new.  Kennedy assassination theories, phobias about Monsanto, theories in the black community that white people invented AIDS to hurt blacks, claims that Bush knew Iraq had no weapons of mass destruction...  what is new is that in the past few years, they have been as common on the right as on the left.  That is why we are now hearing about it, because it finally provides progressive journalists a chance to feel superior, or so they think.', 'Two years ago, in JFK related forums, possibly question were discussed. This is one of them: ========================== “There are many authors and people in America who contend that between November 1963 and Watergate, the trust of Americans toward our institutions was broken, some claim irreparably. People became cynical and reluctant to join efforts like the Peace Corps, or acts proper of democracy such as voting. “The tragic aspect is that even if the government acquiesced to reveal everything it knows about the assassination, there are no warranties that the people will believe it. “There is an initiative for the people *themselves* to investigate and solve the crime. Universities would be encouraged, in a completely open and scientific environment, peer reviewed to determine, as an excellent example, once and for all the physics of the violent back snap. This would be done by our brightest minds, with the government providing not only the necessary funding but a warranty that those scientists will not find the head of a horse in their bed. “That would be the only way for the broken trust to be repaired, and the healing to begin. “The mentioned initiative was inspired in ‘Ask not what the government can do for you…’ Your opinion, Madame Secretary Clinton (or Governor Bush, [whoever])?”', 'There should be an independent agency to question government gross mistakes as in the case of President Kennedy.  Government employees should be subject to be called upon until an acceptable answer is given or at least resolves the problem.  Without a better watch dog the, "I don\'t Give a Doma", attitude prevails.', "This article does not distinguish between theories about why something happened, such as the JFK assassination, and the simple spreading of outright lies.  How can there be a conspiracy theory about something that didn't happen?  The focus of the article could have focused more on why people believe assertions that have no basis in truth.  To me, it is disturbing that anyone would believe that Clinton operated a pedophile ring.  It is a sign that education standards are incredibly low and that people have not developed the capacity to think critically.", "Hi Norm: I'm not sure the distinction you mention is that easy to draw - is there a clear difference between a non-existent pedophile ring, and a non-existent government operation blowing up the world trade towers? What strikes me is that, according to my sense of how the world works, both are clearly impossible. As are most of the JFK assassination  theories. And yet there are plenty of people who find many of these theories plausible. (But I really doubt if there are many subscribers to the pedophile ring fantasy.) I don't see it as being a question of education - or at least, not academic education. The reasons they seem impossible to me have more to do with a general experience, over quite a few years now, of how plans actually work, or more often, don't work, how the government operates, and so on - leading to a sense that most of what people sense is wrong with society is actually right out in the open. I wonder if people drift away from conspiracy theories with age and experience?", "Of course, education is the key to combat or fears of the dark. to fight the dark, we need some light. the same light of Truth will take over fifteen minutes to get to Neptune and back, so your Twain's Boots must be tricky difficult to wear, indeed! Knowledge, curiosity, good faith, and honesty: share some, have some, give some, and live some and all will be well.", "The graph in the video showing the erosion of trust in the government since the Kennedy assassination is very revealing.  When someone is murdered police look at who would benefit from the person's death for clue as to who is responsible.  Tracking the downward trajectory of trust in the government from Kennedy's death to Trump, also shows the level of corruption in the government, now at a new low.  Even the election is suspect.  Who has benefitted?  Corporations.  Republicans. Enemies of the people out to enrich themselves at everyone else's expense.  I'm just saying....", "The non sequitur of this article is that, if the alternative to the lone gunman theory is a conspiracy theory, then Oswald must indeed have shot Kennedy. However, from the Warren Report alone, it is pretty clear that Oswald could not physically have been on the 6th floor to shoot but be encountered by a Dallas policeman two minutes later on the 2nd floor, and have been seen at the relevant times by co-workers having lunch on the 1st floor. Even the Warren Commission admitted they couldn't find a motive. The Tonkin Gulf incident soon enough proved that suspicion of official stories was justified. That said, most conspiracy theories are indeed ridiculous, and thus may well be part of a meta-conspiracy to discredit conspiracy theories!", "For anyone reading, please realize that gs's assertion that the Warren Report renders impossible Oswald's presence on the 6th floor is false. Read it for yourself. Oswald could have been, and was, there. And Oswald could, and did, make the three shots, killing Kennedy. With respect to the Gulf of Tonkin, gs is on somewhat firmer ground. While the Incident did happen (from the perspective of the commander and crew of the USS Maddox), as a result of confusion, misinterpretation and nerves over a couple of sorties of North Vietnamese gunboats, the Johnson administration did spin it to what they believed to be their advantage, and Congress subsequently adopted that fateful resolution.", 'Yet another reason to increase funding for education & for media to be as voluble as possible at exposing alternate facts.', 'Great documentary. For more on fighting the problem of fake news, see:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TN16OBSb_BA']
summary: The comments say that education, knowledge, and curiosity are important to combat the fears that exist in society, and that this would be a good reason to increase funding for education. Several comments cite the assassination of President John Kennedy to exemplify conspiracy theories, and some people believe them, while others do not. Another comment says that the article should have focused more on why people believe unsubstantiated claims. One comment says that Americans no longer trust institutions.
short_title: Headline: Who’s Fueling Conspiracy Whisperers’ Falsehoods?   Keywords: Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations; Fringe Groups and Movements; Social Media; Kennedy, John Fitzgerald; Rumors and Misinformation   Snippet: Modern tools of communication make it possible to spread lies with lightning speed. But conspiracy theories are nothing new.
subreddit: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Social Media', 'Kennedy, John Fitzgerald', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
short_question: ['Who’s Fueling Conspiracy Whisperers’ Falsehoods?  ']

query: How much is civics on your radar? Discuss the importance and priority of civics in your personal life and school.
comments: ['I am fairly young so I cannot speak towards what past elections have been like but many people have told me how different 2016 was to about every other election. The publicity and hype around this election was caused mostly by the media and like what was mentioned in the article "fake news". Teenagers and youths have so much more access to the internet and everything going on in the world. I found myself tuning into the CNN app on snapchat everyday to get the low down on what was going on in the election. The media took full grasp of their opportunity, especially when sharing their opinions, to reach out to a new age and generation. This past election has taught me so much about politics and civics and just government in general. I was asking my parents every night about something new that I saw in the news or about an in depth discussion I had with a classmate. I think that having younger kids introduced slowly into the world of politics is healthy and beneficial, it can help start a new age.', "Yes, I do see a huge increase of people talking about politics. I feel like I don't know a lot of facts and figures to participate in the conversation, so I just sit there, and listen. Sometimes when people talk about politics I feel as lost as a sheep. I also see my friends and family talk about politics more than before. I think the benefits of students sudden interest in politics is good, because the students are the future of this country and I think it's very important that students know whats going on in their country. I agree with the quote because that means the kids want to hear and understand the others point of view.", 'My family is not really into politics we\'ve never really talked about it ever but, recently my family and I have talked politics quite a lot. It\'s mostly my dad that talk\'s about politics and how Trump will do great things for the country. He thinks Donald Trump will put his full-time and hard work to helping the country. I think Trump will do great things for the country. "He will try to make the world a better place in any way he can" said my dad. My whole family doesn\'t stop talking about it now and sometimes they get into fights with each other about its actually quite funny.', "In my Criminal Business Law class, there are two types of people: extreme liberals and extreme conservatives; there is no in between. As much as I value my own opinion, it is extremely enlightening to hear the other side's opinions. It has been the most valuable lesson- learning how to deal with, but respect at the same time, the argument of the opposing side. After much research and discussion, the class finally agreed on one thing: in order to be informed, you must read from an abundance of sources. Much of the media is  skewed and therefore one cannot form a stance without outside influence. It is imperative to get political information from more than one resource or news station. The class agreed that yes, there is much more political discussion in core classes, but whether or not these students are properly educated and not taking information from the most convenient source. There has been an influx in political participation.", 'Hello, Sally Kim. It is interesting to read your well-written response. I taught English in South Korea from 2003-8. (US citizen) I wish you were one of my neighbors here in Ohio now; we could have some nice chats. I was teaching at a middle school outside Seoul during the 2008 US election and students were spending some class time following events.----------KC', 'My name is Sally and I\'m 17 years old and I\'m a soon-to-be high school senior in South Korea. When I was younger, as in 13~14, I knew the basic gist of the news but I was never really involved in civics. But as I grew older, I just started to get into the news and found myself becoming extremely engaged in current events. And my passion for government and politics developed much further in 2016 with the US election and also the presidential scandal in Korea. Social media has played a large role in my involvement with the news. I think I really started to get interested in the American elections by watching an independent media network called The Young Turks. They are a progressive news outlet that isn\'t technically mainstream media but they had one of the best coverage of the election, and it was much more approachable than traditional media. I am very involved in Model United Nations so I was very interested in global affairs, including the Syrian civil war, so I followed AJ+. I subscribed to the New York Times, funnily enough, right after Mr. Trump accused it of being "dishonest media." I don\'t necessarily "talk" politics with my friends and family because my social circle at the moment is quite limited and I don\'t have a lot of people that interested in American elections & Middle Eastern conflicts. And I disagree with a lot of my conservative peers about human rights issues so I try my best to steer away from causing trouble, but not enough to be rendered silent.']
summary: The commenters discuss how politics has affected their personal lives. Some commenters have seen their families talk about politics more during Trump's presidency. Several commenters suggest that access to social media and news sources, especially for teenagers, has helped them become more involved in political conversations. Another commenter, however, says media is skewed and emphasizes the importance of getting news from multiple sources, but agrees that political participation has increased.
short_title: Headline: Are You Having More Conversations With Friends and Family About Politics?   Keywords:    Snippet: How much is civics on your radar? Discuss the importance and priority of civics in your personal life and school.
short_question: ['Are You Having More Conversations With Friends and Family About Politics?  ']

query: A puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that speaks to us.
comments: ["I learned a little bit about ESPERANTO--by which I mean I learned that it existed--in grade school in the late 1940s or early 1950s.  No threats involved.  I thought it sounded interesting, but it was treated just as a footnote in our classes. I expected this puzzle to be harder than it turned out to be because I started out with only one absolute gimme, SEA LEVEL.  So I went to Tier 2, filling in things I thought might be right--TUGBOAT, HOSANNA, BARTER, RIBCAGE, ELVISH, FOREST, and DEMENTED, which turned out to be right, and MIDDLEMAN, which didn't. When I turned to the quote, LANGUAGE/S and DOCTOR FRANKENSTEIN leapt off the screen at me, and from there on it was just backing and forthing until I got the music. Total unknowns were DOTHRAKI and WORF, although the latter sounds familliar.  Unknowns as clued were HAYMAKER, EZEKIAL, OUTFIELD, and REGGAE.  I know from puzzles that the Alous are baseball players, but I was looking for a city or a team or a park, not a position.  Never heard of Toots and the Maytals. As always, a delightful outing from EC&HR.  Thanks to all.", "I thought this might be tougher than usual when I was already at Clue J. before I had a single gimme (OINTMENT was the first!), but after that came a bunch of them (DOTHRAKI, GO-BETWEEN, ELVISH, WORF, SEA LEVEL). That was enough to tell me that the puzzle would have something to do with invented worlds, and it didn't take long from there to come up with DOCTOR FRANKENSTEIN. I think this may have been one of my fastest puzzle solves, helped along by having a daughter who had once studied Esperanto. Once I recognized the outlines of ZAMENHOF, the whole thing just filled itself in.", 'I thoroughly enjoyed this week\'s acrostic. My gimmes were SEA LEVEL, WARF, and GO-BETWEEN. I was pretty sure about OINTMENT, but waited for a letter to confirm. Also, I had the back halves of SUNBONNET and TUGBOAT. For some reason, I was thinking of a place called "Galadriel\'s Tongue" rather than a language, but once I had ESPERANTO it came to me. And fortunately, I\'m enough of a nerd that with a backfilled letter I got DOTHRAKI fairly easily. The puzzle was just the right difficulty: it required a little work with backfill to get all the clues solved, but recognizing letter patters in the grid wasn\'t too tough.', 'Burma(Myanmar) Liberia and the USA.  The only three non metric countries in the world.   What does that say about us?    As for Esperanto, if only every country had introduced it in elementary schools all those years ago, we might all be communicating so much better now, but all retaining our own language as well, as was the idea as I understand it. Congratulations to those who did make a stab at it.  Oh, the puzzle.  I had no gimmes at first, and really struggled with this one, but once I did a bit of research it finally came together and was worth the struggle.', "gimmes include: TUGBOAT, GO-BETWEEN, OUTFIELD, SEA LEVEL, BARTER, RIB CAGE. like OUTFIELD best -- very clever. I knew the four didn't just stay on one baseball team, Most recent one was Moses Alou, an outfielder on the Mets.", 'This one went a little faster the some others recently.  TUGBOAT, SEA LEVEL, WORF are the gimmes I remember.  We were never threatened with having to learn Esperanto, although we did have at least one language teacher who claimed to know it.', "This one was easier and faster for me than most of the recent acrostics have been, although I didn't have many obvious answers after the first pass: I had TUGBOAT, EZEKIEL, FOREST, WORF, and REGGAE. So I tried a second pass and came up with SUNBONNET, HAYMAKER, GO-BETWEEN, and SEA LEVEL. Like Beejay, I knew the zygomatic arch was somewhere around the eye, but CHEEKBONE took a while. With those answers, FRANKENSTEIN and DOCTOR jumped out of the grid at me, and LANGUAGE/S followed quickly thereafter, and then it was just a matter of going back and forth and filling in. I didn't remember ZAMENHOF's name, so bits of it were the last to fill in. It's fun when the puzzles solves smoothly like that!", 'Nice linguistic tie-ins to a few clues, although I thought for a moment we were headed to sci-fi/fantasy land.  ELVISH and WORF were gimmes, and although I didn\'t remember the Game of Thrones language off the bat, I knew I\'d recognize it with a few letters.  I have no idea why one of my gimmes was HOSANNA.  DERANGED before DEMENTED. Both Esperanto and the metric system went beyond threats in my school, though unlike Jerrold I recall no Esperanto, and only "it\'s a quart, and a liter bit more" stuck for metric measurements.', "I thoroughly learned the metric system on my own as a young adult in the 1970's, after taking an intense interest in it. At that time it was being predicted that it would be completely adopted here in the U.S. by the mid-1980's. The public's resistance to change is frequently underestimated. Personally i was disappointed that it never happened.", 'I was well on my way to learning the metric system too, Jerrold, with the help of my college science courses. I was also disappointed that it never happened. For a while they were even printing both systems on sewing patterns. Alas.', 'Funny and sad, Beejay, about the sewing patterns.  The only other immediate metric conversion I can do is "4 inches = 10 cm".  It\'s on every ball or skein of yarn as a gauge measurement (how many stitches using a particular size needle or hook).', "Great quote! My sister found a class in and studied ESPERANTO as an adult. I hadn't realized it was that old. I got started with RIB CAGE, GO-BETWEEN, ELVISH, and SEA LEVEL. I soon got language in the quote, picked up the pace with the back and forth, and Frankenstein came shortly thereafter. Thought I remembered the zygomatic arch being a bone in the face, but it took me more letters to get CHEEKBONE. I was wondering if the Alous played together elsewhere besides San Francisco, and smiled when I remembered finally (with more letters) they were all OUTFIELDers. Wonderfully fun!", 'Let us utter a "(C)ry of ... acclamation" for yet another splendid Acrostic from EC & HR!', "This was an especially easy one for me, thanks to several correct guesses right off the bat.   I'm not complaining -- it's been a long four weeks.  It felt good to tackle a problem with a quick and easy solution.  :) Thanks, EC & HR!", 'This was one of the better balanced solves in a while - lately the Acrostics have had too many gimmes in the clue list for me to feel as challenged as I used to be. In this one, there were several smallish words in the quote that helped me along the way, and it was satisfying seeing "language" when only the first G was in place. I really enjoyed this one. Add to the reading list the little book by Arika Okrent, "In the Land of Invented Languages." She goes into the history and theory of language invention and it makes interesting reading, though in the opinion of a Tolkien fanatic I think she underplays Tolkien\'s contributions.', '[SPOILER ALERT] My gimmes this time were ESPERANTO, TUGBOAT, RED TAPE, GO-BETWEEN and ROUGHLY. (I learned a little bit about Esperanto sometime around 1964, and so “unua” came flashing back to me as meaning “first” in that language. Wow, what you learn in childhood you remember for life.) I was surprised at myself for not knowing OINTMENT before getting some of the letters. I sure had to search for DOTHRAKI and REGGAE. The latter I of course had heard of, but I never heard of that singing group. Chest protector!  There is always at least one trick answer. I remember once reading about a professor who assigns the novel “Frankenstein” to his students.  He said that he takes off points when a student refers to the main character as “Dr. Frankenstein”, because in the book he was never called Doctor. The professor said “He got his doctorate from Hollywood”.', "P.S.  I always read Deb's piece only after I have posted my own, and sometimes the coincidences are surprising. In my own case back then, it was a thick library book about the world's languages, not my school curriculum.", 'This is true. Victor Frankenstein is an undergrad at the University of Ingolstadt, and he proceeded on his science project without checking in with is advisors, M. Waldman and M. Kempe.  My colleague Esther Schor knows this, as a fellow-scholar of Frankenstein herself, but was, I guess, trading on the popular iteration "Dr. Frankenstein."  That said, Bridge of Language is a wonderful book, and I\'m delighted to see it honored in the esteemed archives of the Sunday Times Acrostic']
summary: A couple of commenters think that the crossword puzzle was easy and had many gimmes, while another commenter thinks it was well-balanced, while yet another thought it was too difficult. Other commenters discuss new words and ideas they learned about from the puzzle, including Esperanto, the Dothraki, and Zamenhof. One commenter enjoyed the linguistic tie-ins to a few clues and sci-fi terms.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Acrostic   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles; Acrostic Puzzles   Snippet: A puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that speaks to us.
short_question: ['Variety: Acrostic  ']

query: How far back can you recall events in your own life and how old were you when you first remembered them?
comments: ['What Is Your Earliest Memory? I agree with the research that suggests the formation of children’s earliest memories are linked to when they begin talking about past events with a parent. Although I am able to remember bits and pieces of my earliest past events without looking through photographs, I recall the most when I discuss past events with my parents. Personally, I believe my parents have a more vivid memory of my past considering I was young and not aware of the world. “When four of us shared memories of our very young lives, not one of us could recall events before the age of four” (Gilpin). I agree because the earliest memory I can remember was when I was four. When I was younger, I lived near Toys R Us. I always wanted to be there to the point where I would refuse to eat dinner at home. I would eat my dinner to Toys R Us while I played with the toys. Eating dinner at Toys R Us did not occur only once during my childhood. This memory actually occurred and was not just a dream because I have seen photographs and my parents constantly laughs at this memory whenever we are together. “Remembering events only after age 3½ or 4 is typical” (C.
