Claiborne Ray). I find it surprising how I am able to recall events that happened when I was four, but not younger without discussing with my parents.', 'What Is Your Earliest Memory? I agree with the research that suggests the formation of children’s earliest memories are linked to when they begin talking about past events with a parent. Although I am able to remember bits and pieces of my earliest past events without looking through photographs, I recall the most when I discuss past events with my parents. Personally, I believe my parents have a more vivid memory of my past considering I was young and not aware of the world. “When four of us shared memories of our very young lives, not one of us could recall events before the age of four” (Gilpin). I agree because the earliest memory I can remember was when I was four. When I was younger, I lived near Toys R Us. I always wanted to be there to the point where I would refuse to eat dinner at home. I would eat my dinner at Toys R Us while I played with the toys. Eating dinner at Toys R Us did not occur only once during my childhood. This memory actually occurred and was not just a dream because I have seen photographs and my parents constantly laughs at this memory whenever we are together. “Remembering events only after age 3½ or 4 is typical” (C. Claiborne Ray). I find it surprising how I am able to recall events that happened when I was four, but not younger without discussing with my parents.', 'I agree with this opinion that we probably cannot remember memories from such that young age, but when our parents tell us something about what happened at that time, we will remember more or less something then. Just like what C. Claiborne Ray writes, “One widely studied idea relates the formation of children’s earliest memories to when they start talking about past events with their mothers” (C. Claiborne Ray). There is a connection between our memories from very young age and informations from our parents. My earliest memories is when I was 3 or 4 years old, my mum rent a “electric toy car” for me, I could actually sit in the car and started “driving”. I do have a photograph of it and my mum confirmed the memory. I know this memory probably just because it was really fun and I was just at the age I can remember something, and I have no idea about what was going on before this memory. In the article “Recalling Early Childhood Memories, or Not”, the author states, “For adults, remembering events only after age 3½ or 4 is typical, studies have found” (C. Claiborne Ray). Shows the reason why I can remember my first memory that happened at the age of 3.', '1: Yes, I agree with the research that this artical has provided. I think that, after parents tell their children stories of when they were younger, they feel as if they remember every detail of that event. 2: Personally, my first memories were when I was in preschool and kindergarten. I remember running around outside playing in my backyard with my brothers. I remember they I refused to play with dolls and I would only play with cars and power rangers. 3: I remembered most details from photographs and of other people, like my brothers, explaining some of the games we would play. They explained some of the ways that I got hurt or the ways that they would mock me and make me mad.', '1. Yes, I agree with the research that this article is showing us. I think that there is a connection between brain memory and speaking, whether it be in sign language or English. 2. I have early memories. The first dream that comes to mind is when I went to Hawaii when I was 2 years old. I know that this memory is real because of pictures and because my family went with and know about the trip. 3. My oldest memory was when I was two years old. I can still remember it now, but I assume I thought about it when I was younger as well. I remember being in Hawaii and it was raining the entire time. I also remember "eating" a giant pear. It was fake.', 'my earliest memory is when i was in pre school', "I can remember being in my crib and also being fed in my high-chair as an infant & toddler among other early memories. I recalled the details and described my observations to my Mom who was surprised but it was quite accurate and the actions I described  were real and beyond my understanding at the time. ...including my older sister writing on the wall above my crib.....my Mom thought I had done it but it was out of my reach....when I told her she cried and apologized for blaming a baby for what was my older sister's  mischief.. I can remember breaking a little green chick egg cup while in my high-chair and my Mom coming to clean up the broken china & egg mess....mundane stuff like that but very early memories.", 'I would have to say my earliest memory was in preschool, I was 4. I would remember coloring every paper handed to me, playing doctor with my friends, running around outside. One memory that stuck out was the day I got told on. I remember being scared and hiding from the teachers, I even remember the girl\'s name, she was my best friend but we were fighting that day. Her name was Natalie. I find it crazy how I cant remember anything before that. "Most of the participants’ earliest memories came from when they were 2 to 4 years old; the average was age 3." (Ray,1)', '"For adults, remembering events only after age 3½ or 4 is typical..." (Giplin) I agree with Giplin because it is hard to remember anything before I was about 3. My earliest memory was when I was about 3-years-old. I remember waking up really early in the morning to slide down the stairs in my pajamas down the spiral stair case and heard a noise to find my mom with about 6 puppies. I was playing with them and helping to feed them and I liked to snuggle with them. After i was all done the puppies took refuge right by their mothers side.', 'The earliest memory I have is waking up on my fourth birthday and barreling out of bed, being extremely excited, and happy to be another year older. I can\'t remember anything before that, my mom will tell me a million things that I used to do as a kid and I don\'t recall anything she tells me. "The phenomenon was named childhood amnesia..." (Ray, 1) I think they\'re right with saying that because most people can\'t remember memories past 3 years old.', 'I do agree with the information stated, because I talk about memories of my childhood with my parents, and the information stated in through and accurate, “The Henris published a questionnaire on early memories in 1895, and  . My early memories are going to Sea World when I has two years olhe results from 123 people were published in 1897”  (Giplin, 1). I know this because I remember going to Sea World, and my parents have a lot of pictures of me in front of Shamu. My earliest memory was me drinking a 16 ounce bottle of formula in my little rocking chair, I was watching the Wiggles on my T.V, And I remember being sick that day as well.', 'When I was around the age of 4 I remember it was laundry day and I was sitting on my bed sheets that were in a pile on the floor and my older sister started dragging me around the house. I remember laughing so hard, smiling so big, and never wanting my sister to stop. It was like I was on a roller coaster. "Most of the participants’ earliest memories came from when they were 2 to 4 years old; the average was age 3." (Ray,1) That statement is very true because I can\'t  remember anything before that memory.', 'I remember when I was younger I used to swing in my swing (crosson 1). I would laugh and smile while my mom would play with me. It was like giving candy to a little kid. I would stay in the swing until i would pass out or get hungry and want food.', "I remember when I was little and my twin sister Lauren got out of her crib and tried to tech me how to get out too, but I couldn't.", '"When four of us shared memories of our very young lives, not one of us could recall events before the age of 4 or possibly 3," (Ray, 1). I can relate to this. When I was 3-years-old, my family would always go to my grandparents house. My grandpa was a mechanic and always has tools and car parts all over his back yard. One day my older brother and I went on an adventure. My brother found a suspension spring to my grandpas car, a few nuts and bolts to an old engine he had in the shed, and an exhaust pipe. We went back inside and grabbed some glue to glue on the nuts and bolts. We were making our little robots and drinking carpi suns. My grandma was there helping us with the glue. It was a good day.', "The earliest child hood memory I remember was when I was like 2-years-old, I would go to my grandpas house. When I was at my grandpas house I would sit in a chair next to him and eat candy that was in a purple and gold small round box. We would watch television, talk about family stuff, and eat chocolate bars.  My grandpa use to say don't tell your mom so i wouldn't, but when he died I told my mom everything that we use to do and she just laughed.", 'The article states that "...remembering events only after age 3½ or 4 is typical..." (Ray 1). I have to agree, because my earliest memory was when I was 4 years old. My earliest memory was at the time where my mom\'s friend\'s house. My parents were at work, so they couldn\'t take care of me during the day. Anyways, I recall myself sitting on a wooden chair, eating delicious food, and looking out at the window. My mom\'s friend owned cows, and I found that amazing. Suddenly, while I was looking out from the window, a gush of wind came through. Two seconds ago, it was quiet. It\'s like there was a tornado, but there wasn\'t. I believe I saw a small tree fall down, too. The gush of wind only lasted for 2 seconds. I know this is such a random memory, but I believe the only reason why I remember is because I never understood why there was a sudden gush of wind.', 'My memory is like a history book. My earliest memory is from when I was about 4 years old. I think the older you get the less you remember. "...  the average was age 3." (Gilpin, 1). I think someone can have a better memory, have more rememberable memories, and someone might not want to remember somethings.', "I disagree with the research, because I remember things that I have never discussed with my parents or anyone else. My earliest memory was when I was nine or ten, and I watched my abusive step-dad slam my sister's head into a wall, then yelled at me to go to my room. I know this actually happened because my sister got a concussion, there was a hole in the wall, and because I observed him doing things like that to both of my sisters all the time after that.", "My son very vividly remembers seeing a woman kicked in the head by a horse when he was about 2.5 years old. He vividly described the event, which was confirmed by his Au Pair. (He's hated horses ever since.) My earliest memory was when I was about 4. I begged my father to teach me to whistle, and we sat on the back garden steps together. Unfortunately I couldn't manage it, and my father gave up on me, and it was never discussed again. But I never forgot the feeling of rejection from a father who meant so much to me. Now I've perfected a piercing whistle.", "It might not be as early as all the rest of you but my earliest memory was when I was 5 my sister being born (like Carla). I remember going through the long hall with beeping until we got to a window and there was my Mom and Dad with my brand new baby sister. I don't know why 5 is my earliest memory and that was only 7 years ago. So that's my earliest memory. :)", 'My earliest memory was being born.  It was very dark – and then, all of a sudden, it was light.  My twin sister was born about ten minutes before me.  My first words were, "After you."  I was a good southern gentleman.', 'I was three years and two months.  It was the day my sister was born.  I remember going to the hospital with my father and they would not let me go with him to visit my mother so I was left in a room with black leather benches and wood paneling that was filled with men, most of them smoking.  I was very angry, which I assume is why I remember it so clearly :-).  I have one hazy earlier memory of a man taking away our dog - I would have been about one and a half - I can see him walking the dog down the front steps but it is a very brief image.  There are no photographs of either event.', 'I was only nine months old.  I woke up trapped under a white sheet.  I can still see the whiteness all around me.  I cried, and my mother unwrapped the sheet and picked me up.  I confirmed the memory - and my age at the time - with my mother; I had tangled myself up in the crib sheet during my afternoon nap.', 'I was less than three.  I remember everyone running around and shouting and holding little us flags.  everyone seemed happy.  I learned later it was v j day. I did see a photo of us sitting on the porch at our sumner house.  But I remember the noise and all people running around and shouting.']
summary: One commenter says he agrees that we can't remember when we were very small, but he believes that if our parents tell us about an event that occurred during that time, we can remember something. Several commenters agree with the article, say they remember things that happened only after they were four years old and report the first memories they have. Others say they remember some events that occurred when they were less than four years old.
short_title: Headline: What Is Your Earliest Memory?   Keywords:    Snippet: How far back can you recall events in your own life and how old were you when you first remembered them?
short_question: ['What Is Your Earliest Memory?  ']

query: Older adults who started sleeping more than nine hours a night were at more than double the risk of developing dementia 10 years later.
comments: ['When i was suffering from undiagnosed, untreated Lyme diseas, i slept almost 20 hrs/day for three months (and progessively less over the following two years). I had "brain fog" and often the sense that if I didn\'t sleep immediately, I would collapse. I felt like poison was coursing through my brain. When I awoke, my head always felt significantly better. The first time I read about amyloid buildup, I sensed that this, or something similar, was occurring. I used to be able to easily remember a sequence of perhaps 20 numbers, but became unable to remember more than 4 or 5  (altho my long-term memory was intact). Since I began recovering, my sleep has gone back to 7 hrs/day, and doing memory and logic games on my phone, my memory is back to normal. I realize this is not dementia, but clearly I had dementia-like symptoms. During the worst of my illness, sleep always felt like a shower for my brain.', 'So many cranky writers here...', "'started sleeping' ? - undefined. I might sleep more than 9 hours on odd occasions if I was short previous nights. I guess the unstated assumption is 'on multiple subsequent nights' ?", 'Depression might be a risk factor and causes people to sleep more. Indeed many things cause people to sleep longer. Correlation is in no way causation. This is a very analysis apparently from data from a much larger study, interesting but just one data point so to speak.', "Your story about prolonged sleep and dementia were like you were talking about my mom.  For three years I took care of her and I can relate a lot to this story. Now when I visit my mom in the nursing home, she says nothing and stares .  What I wouldn't love is to have her be back the way she was before this happened.  If there was a test I could take to find out if I was a candidate for dementia, I wouldn't have it.  I want to keep on living.", "when I was working I would have to be 'on call' I would sometimes be up 25-30 hours working a day, my body and really my mind felt like it was broken, could not remember phone numbers and co-workers names, that's from lack of sleep; retired now I enjoy long winter afternoon naps and I feel sharp-rested-alert", 'Every week it seems like there is some new "theory" about causes and preventions of Alzheimers. Researchers are no closer to finding out or preventing this disease. I am sick and tired of articles which contradict themselves: do crossword puzzles, no doesn\'t help, sleep more, sleep less, eat a certain diet, no, wait, diet doesn\'t help, get more exercise, but only running will help ward off the disease, etc. Enough, already!', 'This is a pretty vague correlation. The reasons for lengthening sleep cycles among the elderly are so complex that to say that this behavior change may be a marker for dementia is pushing it. Depression would be my more immediate concern, if I noticed excessive sleep in an older person. And then there is the matter of what one is supposed to do with this information. Worry more?', "Honestly, NYT! Are you so desperate to fill the 'Well' space that you publish something this light-weight? Once again, catchy headline and nothing more.", 'I read "Well" for one reason only. entertainment. The "Well" column has a well-worn non-scientific methodology: present a single hypothesis-generating study with zero relation to other studies, explain the heck out of it, and then get a researcher to make a comment in which the results of the study are hedged in hypothesis-generating terms. Then watch with how readers respond, suckers like me. If "Well" were serious about educating readers, it would print the link to the publication. Instead, readers have to hunting, and for any person not attached to an academic institution, that is very difficult. Well, due to its methodology, "Well" is next to useless if a reader really wants to know how to control their own health or ask their GPs the right questions.', 'The link is posted in the text.', 'It\'s especially galling to make a joke of it with that snarky, "Don\'t go wake up grandpa" quote. It is insulting to the readers.', 'The factors that led adults to suddenly begin sleeping more should be investigated. Depression, diet, lack of exercise, or more exercise or stress than usual, drugs, and interactions among these. In particular, a diet of simple sugars, compounded with little reason to get up or escape from problems, is suspect, in my opinion.', "From what I understand Parkinson's, Alzheimer's etc are being understood as inflammatory diseases, caused by barrier deficiencies.  I have atopic eczema, where my skin's barrier deficiencies allow staph aureus, normally harmless, to cause immune system dysregulation when the dead staph's endotoxin triggers an inflammatory cascade that is more conducive for aureus' survival than my healing.   Constant inflammation takes a toll on the body, using up resources that should be directed to thinking, moving, digesting, etc.  I would assume the most tired people are sick with persistent inflammation of some kind, and that the sleep is the body's attempt to heal, not a part of some disease.   Microglia in the brain run on circadian cycles and switch from inflammatory during the day to 'healing' at night.  Sleeping is probably the canary in the coal mine here; a symptom, not a cause.", 'Sleeping more than normal is also a symptom of depression. Maybe depression causes Alzheimers or vice versa. It can change the brain structure. Also ten years is a long time so there are probably a lot of changes in the older persons life during that period besides sleeping more. Maybe a coincidence that they started sleeping more due to other factors.', "A little tired of these -potentially misleading?- studies. My mother had Alzheimer's and slept poorly in her adult life.", '"were at more than double the risk of developing dementia a decade later than those who slept nine hours or less, researchers report."  very poorly written.  Because of the sentence structure it seems as if the people sleeping more would get dementia a decade after people who slept less rather than after ten years they were twice as likely to get dementia years than those who slept less.', "“My suspicion is that this is a compensatory mechanism: that at a time when amyloid is building up in the brain, people may be sleeping longer as the body is reacting and trying to remove it from the brain,” Dr. Seshadri added, cautioning that is only a hypothesis. - Mm, so a non-news bit of headlining. First, scare the reader into reading it, and then reassure her that there's nothing to worry about, unless, of course, there is, in which case, she'd better keep an eye on this space, because she might need to alert her physician so that she can get started on an anti-anxiety med that might reduce her risk of something or the other.  Just in case.", 'Terrible for the NYTimes to disseminate "this is only a hypothesis" with little or minimal proof. As someone who has lived through three Alzheimer\'s victims and known many others and their families, it is clear that researchers are grasping at straws. Yes, some victims sleep a lot. Others, not at all. Others, with no discernible sleep symptoms. Why publicize this and distort public perceptions?', 'Or is the increase in hours of sleep a symptom of health conditions that are developing or have developed?', '"How much did you sleep last night"? "Don\'t know. I can\'t remember".', "Quick! Go wake up grandpa! I don't care what they said in the third paragraph---why take a chance?", 'There may be more real reasons than just longer hours of sleep. When we retire we throw away Alarm clocks to enjoy relaxation time.', 'Thank God for the up front exception of: "— but had not previously slept so much —"!', 'Correlation is not causation. This story is a really poor presentation of a data collection project.', "but causation may be indicated by correlation, either directly or from a cause common to what is observed and what is suspected; a hypothesis needs to have some suggestion (though as Feynman is said to have noted: a hypothesis contradicted by an experiment is wrong!) but yes, it's a misleading article and shouldn't have been published as-is", "This story is 5 paragraphs long.  2 of these paragraphs are entirely devoted to assuring the reader that correlation is not causation. I'm not sure what presentation could have impressed this point more succinctly.  Indeed, this seems to be more a story about how correlation is not causation than it is a story about how sleep is related to dementia.", '@CK "Correlation is not causation" Indeed -- and the article was very clear on that point: "We think this might be a marker for the risk of dementia, not a cause”', 'Researchers say they are not even certain beta amyloid is a cause or a result of Alzheimers.']
summary: Some commenters are critical because the article lacks solid evidence or conclusion and emphasize that there are multiple factors, such as depression and diet, of longer sleep hours that need to be investigated--beyond dementia. Others dispute how the article is vague, poorly written, suggesting that it may be just another new and passing theory.
short_title: Headline: Sleep: Sleep and Alzheimer’s Risk   Keywords: Alzheimer's Disease; Sleep; Dementia; Elderly; Nerves and Nervous System   Snippet: Older adults who started sleeping more than nine hours a night were at more than double the risk of developing dementia 10 years later.
short_question: ['Sleep: Sleep and Alzheimer’s Risk  ']

query: In the early 1900s, Wrigley pitched its products as being good for children’s teeth.
comments: ["Here's what I know about chewing gum: the sight of an adult chewing gum is revolting and, if you have misophonia, as I do, the sound of someone chewing gum is sheer torture.", 'Been chewing gum as long as I can remember. Then somebody invented sugar free bubble gum, and I became an addict. I have about a two weeks supply of sugar free gum, which reminds me that when I had to spend a week in three different hospitals (I am 80), nobody offered me a stick of gum. An Earth without gum would not be a fun place. We should have an official CHEW WEEK when all of us gummers can get together for a group chew. Peace.', 'I agree with all of the gum chewers that have commented here. I can easily chew half a pack a day and have been doing so forever. No adverse affects that I am aware of. Gum chewers unite!', 'You failed to ask the most important question:  Is cracking gum, or blowing bubbles, good for toddlers? or anyone?  I am certain that science will show that the louder the crack, and the bigger the bubble, the more evolved the human species: Proof -- chimpanzees do neither.', "I have been chewing gum for 60 years, generally sugarless, and I have almost all my teeth. I have always enjoyed chewing and now that I'm old and not so rich, the simple pleasure of gum is much appreciated.", "I have attention deficit disorder with hyperactivity and chewing gum allows me to focus and sit still.  As a female I hid my ADHD quite well in school and from my family, never getting a diagnosis until middle age.  I realize now my mother had it and smoked from an early age to focus. Gum allowed me to get straight A's in school. I chewed it alone (never in public) so I could read long books, write papers and study for tests. I was self medicating without realizing it. When I stopped chewing gum is when I realized I might have ADHD.", 'Having spent much of my life suffering from motion sickness, gum is the only solution. As mentioned  by another post, gum has helped me cut down on smoking. And the additional payoff: a nice, clean minty taste in my mouth. My favourite flavor Spearmint. Never leave home without it.', '"She added: \'If you’re 2 and something tastes good, you swallow it, regardless of whether you’ve been cautioned not to.\'" At the risk of losing Parent of the Year, I know this to be factually inaccurate, at least some of the time. My two year old has been chewing sugar free gum for a while now without swallowing, thanks to his big sister.', 'Chewing gum has helped me to remain a former smoker. Some days, a piece of sugarless gum is all that stands between me and a cigarette. Three years now. Five years before that, e-cigs.', 'It does ease the pressure in ear canals when ascending or descending on a plane.', 'My mother was a war bride from New Zealand. She couldn\'t stand it when her American children chewed gum, and said ( evoking a wartime memory of so many soldiers based in NZ) " What is the difference between an American chewing gum and a cow chewing its cud?The intelligent look on the face of the cow!"', 'Chewing sugar free gum that contains the sugar alcohol xylitol has been shown to decrease cavities in children and may also decrease the incidence of middle ear infections.', "Xylitol? Isn't this ingredient necessary to declare chewing gum as a health benefit for one's teeth and mouth?", 'The question posed in heading is barely answered and addressed.']
summary: Most commenters express support for gum. One commenter says that gum helps them to deal with ADHD. Another two commenters express support for gum, saying it helps them to stay away from cigarettes. Another commenter suggests gum with xylitol in order to fight off cavities. One commenter says that it is good for decreasing ear canal pressure. Two commenters indicate that chewing gum is annoying and unsightly.
short_title: Headline: Ask Well; Is Chewing Gum Good for Toddlers? Or Anyone?   Keywords: Chewing Gum; Teeth and Dentistry; Children and Childhood; Advertising and Marketing   Snippet: In the early 1900s, Wrigley pitched its products as being good for children’s teeth.
subreddit: ['Chewing Gum', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Children and Childhood', 'Advertising and Marketing']
short_question: ['Ask Well; Is Chewing Gum Good for Toddlers? Or Anyone?  ']

query: Rich and gamy, these have found their way onto restaurant menus and can be made easily at home.
comments: ['Try the duck wing appetizer at Primitivo in New Orleans (Fried Duck Wing Confit, Wing Sauce Herbs & Sunflower Seeds). Absolutely delicious.', "I normally read recipes with an eye to preparing them but I think I'd leave these to the pros.  I love duck in most incarnations I've tried and have no doubt I'd love these too.", "Just confit and deep fry them in regular cooking oil in a stockpot. Why fry in duck fat? It's just a medium for cooking the meat. The duck wings have plenty of their own duck fat. Kenji's confit/fry wing recipe on serious eats is probably the way to go.", "Those sure look like legs to me. Look at that joint. That's a knee joint.", 'As a home confit maker for decades, I agree: I see duck legs, not wings.', "Isn't that a picture of thighs? I would like to see what duck wings look like.  Please.", "The preceding readers' comments do not address a basic question: one or two wings, are they filling enough for a meal? The answer is undoubtedly, it depends on the size of the bird. Anything smaller than an ordinary chicken or pheasant, it would be too little. Perhaps something of a size of a wild goose, swan, wild turkey or some of the heron species would be right. But the effort of gnawing on such a wing or dissecting it finely with a knife and fork -- I am not sure that the game is worth the candle.", 'The Ausable Inn in Keene Valley, NY has served Duck Wings in various sauces  (Sriracha, Maple BBQ, Buffalo) for years.  They look like wings and taste great.  (I am not affiliated with the Inn...just a fan.)', "Duck fat can't get hot enough to crisp the skin without burning - you need to fry them in 375-degree oil such as canola oil to get crisp skin, which is half of the point of having duck wings.", 'The duck wings at Upland are tasty.  A great way to end a work day at the bar with a cocktail.', "The Photo is misleading. You can simply look at the photos in the 'Tastyduck.com' link and draw your own conclusions.  Further to 'Tuvvw Xyz' Comment, the only thing duck wings are good for is making stock.", 'I agree with reader TWWREN: the anatomical parts on the 2nd photo do not look like wings. Wings of any bird are difficult to eat while keeping good table manners: a fork and a knife make the separation of the bones from the edible parts tiresome and time consuming. The result, the wings are not worth the effort ...', "I've butchered and cooked many a duck.  The photo are like no duck wings I have ever seen.  They look like duck legs without the thighs to me.  And I know my ducks.", 'Clearly legs, not wings.', 'Hi there, The dish on the menu at Upland is called “crispy duck wings.” They are made with duck wing drumettes, which look a little different than the standard wing.']
summary: Some commenters are responding to the photo, expressing surprise and doubt that the photos are of wings because of their large size, suggesting they are, in fact, duck legs. Others talk about how the recipe is for only two wings, and that may not be enough for a meal depending on which type of bird is being cooked. Other commenters talk about the recipe presented itself, including what type of fat duck wings should be cooked in.
short_title: Headline: Wings of a Different Feather   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Smillie, Justin; Grilling (Cooking); Poultry   Snippet: Rich and gamy, these have found their way onto restaurant menus and can be made easily at home.
short_question: ['Wings of a Different Feather  ']

query: Scroll through this list of questions that touch on every aspect of contemporary life — from social media to sports, politics and school — and see which ones most inspire you to take a stand.
comments: ['111 is not really a question to be asked it is very sexist and others are not', "You have two comments about girls and careers (#44-45). Why not ask why more boys don't pursue careers in nursing, early-childhood education, or other professions with a gender imbalance?", 'Parents pressure their kids too much. Some children in Elementary school go to Middle school and can be best friends. There is a high chance their parents have met or their friends have seen their parents. Some parents compare one to another based on their intelligence or their skill that their kid doesn\'t have. Parents also pressure their kids by checking up on them constantly by making them do their homework. Parents are a big part of our life since they made us born and took care of most of us until 18 or maybe even older. Parents always want their kids to be smart and get good grades and to get into a good school. Some parents choose their kids future jobs and say "You should be this" specific job. Parents should be more chill and shouldn\'t be so aggressive and pressure their kids. I think there are more ways that parents pressure their kids.', 'It is true I think kids get there judging from there parents or it could be there friends', "kids shouldn't be told that guns are ok to carry around not even for self defense only soldiers need that kind if right", 'If anything, more children should be told to carry around guns both concealed and unconcealed. By doing this we are teaching children to exercise their second amendment rights. This also will reduce the violence believe it or not. No one is going to shoot up a public event if multiple people are armed. If we eliminate guns from those who legally have them then there will be no one to protects us from the criminals who illegally own them.', 'Actually the top states with the absence for a permit to purchase a firearm usually end up with more gun related deaths. Take Alaska for instance. According to CBN News it has the highest amount of gun related deaths in the US. So saying and armed society is a peaceful society cant really be backed up.', 'Children and teens should be taught how to cook in school. Cooking is a good trade to learn and a tool you will have to use later on in life. School doesn\'t prepare students enough for life after it, cooking would be a good way to start. Cooking could even lead to a career for students. In a ny times article by helen zoe veit it says "The home economics movement was founded on the belief that food preperation was an important subject."', 'So, you guys claim that this list has, "hundreds of prompts below that touch on every aspect of contemporary life" when out of all 401 I don\'t see a single article on religion. Why? Religion is not a bad thing to talk about, and yet it is removed from everything. I just want an explanation as to why there isn\'t a single article touching on any aspect of religion in, as you say, contemporary life.', "Hi Bryton, We have a separate prompt list,  650 Prompts for Narrative and Personal Writing , which has a whole religion and spirituality section. In our experience in crafting writing prompts for a general site like The Learning Network, the subject of religion is generally more conducive to personal writing than argument writing for students.  That said, this list of 401 argument prompts does include a few related to religion, such as: Can You Be Good Without God? - How Much Control Do You Think You Have Over Your Fate? -  How Important Do You Think It Is to Marry Someone With the Same Religion? If you scroll down, you'll find them in the Personal Character and Morality section.", "this is the best website to use for papers I struggle in english and know i'm like the best in my class                                         NOX", 'This is so helpful I recommend this to a friend', 'This is so helpful for me, thank you!', 'This is SO good! I have what I need for my paper!', 'i love it! it has every thing i need for my prompts!', 'Hey this is cool...', 'Wish they still let us comment...', 'This is really helpful and helps me find my own prompt, like really!', 'These topics really spoke out to me', 'Love this stuff', 'this was very helpful', 'littttttttttt', 'this is really helping me with my aurgumentative essay. I LOVE IT!!!!!']
summary: Many commenters state that the writing prompts that the article provides are very useful and that they would "recommend this to a friend." Other commenters were more critical saying things such that some of the prompts provided were sexist. Another critical commenter asks why out of the 401 prompts, none involve religion, and that "religion is not a bad thing" to write about. Another commenter mentions how parents sometimes "pressure their kids too much," and push them to careers that the kids may not be interested in.
short_title: Headline: 401 Prompts for Argumentative Writing   Keywords: Education (K-12); Reading and Writing Skills (Education)   Snippet: Scroll through this list of questions that touch on every aspect of contemporary life — from social media to sports, politics and school — and see which ones most inspire you to take a stand.
short_question: ['401 Prompts for Argumentative Writing  ']

query: Misinterpreting a friendly glance on the subway.
comments: ['Though I am still young, or at least far from old, from time to time I might exchange a smile with an older woman, and more than offering up a seat I may be thinking huh, funny. Attraction can happen -without regard for what society sanctions or defines as normal.- it can just happen... and when it does I feel happy to be surprised, and be unburdened of that wet blanket of banality which are the so called norms.', 'Funny!  Yes, I\'m a woman nearing that age; hair is mostly still black, I don\'t think I dress 70, some days I think I look quite cute.  It hurts my feelings momentarily as well when an attractive younger man is walking towards me and says "hello ma\'am" when he nears and rushes to open the door.  It always brings me back to reality', 'Well, I don\'t know about all this "offering of a seat" business, but what I do know is that my name is no longer Billie. The only names that I am called by now are as follows: sweetie, sweetheart, honey, sunshine, darlin\', honeybun and dear. The other day I ordered a burrito supreme at a drive-thru and, when the girl handed me the bag, she smiled broadly, saying, "Here you go, Beautiful!" I used to be offended, but now I say: "Thanks!" After all, I could be called worse names than these. So, I say to all of you fifty-plus females, "Thanks for reading my comments, Cupcakes!"', 'Ah, yes - a delicate situation - I never offer a seat unless it\'s a pregnant woman OR I see someone looking around to see if a seat is desired....my radar is 100% that way. But I can also 100% relate to Mr. Castro -my knee jerk reaction can range from "how old do I look today?" to being appreciative! I\'m proud of the second reaction, reflective of the first. But I have long since successfully adapted to the supermarket "senior citizen day"! I make sure I get the 10% but have cautioned my favorite clerks to be discreet in asking "newbies"!', 'You are not alone. I am similarly situated and have had the same delusional experience several times. Thanks for the memory', 'Funny!  Actually, as a woman, for me, aging brings a bonus - being able to go anywhere without the constant, unwanted male leers and catcalls.  I know that for some women, it\'s a blow to their egos when they realize they\'re no longer seen as "hot babes" - but really, who needs it?  Maybe those women whose entire identity has been built on their looks and sex appeal - which is pretty sad. I still get plenty of attention from men over age 55 & up - and from the one man in my life whose attention is most important to me. Yes, as commenter Cheryl notes, most women are more realistic about this - if we\'re over a certain age, we don\'t delude ourselves that men young enough to be our sons or grandsons are flirting with us!  And if a young man offers me a seat on the bus or subway - or offers to help me at the supermarket?  I\'ll take it. One thing age has taught me is not to turn down help, especially when you do need it! - OTOH, I never offer a seat to an older man unless he clearly needs it, i.e., he\'s visibly frail and/or struggling to walk or stand, or is using a cane or walker - because I know from experience it\'s more of a blow to a man to be seen as physically infirm. And sometimes even the 90-year-old in the walker will refuse the seat - and flirt!   P.S. Mr. Castro, a man with a sense of humor about himself is always "what the ladies like."', 'I do! I absolutely think they are...because I constantly forget that I am 60...in my mind I am still that 30 year old...', 'Not so sure "most women" who were once hot realize they are not. I know white a few in their 50s and 60s who dress like they\'re 20. Invaribly they are the ones who got by on their looks. Sad!', "Natasha, I know what you mean - inside, I'm still the rebellious teenager... the young woman in her 20s and 30s focused both on my career and active social & dating life... in my 40s and early 50s as my career peaked... and as I am now, over 60 - all at once.  People I know for decades still see the version of me they first knew - not always a good thing!  But strangers and those I know only the last few years only see my current self. That's reality.  I don't mind people seeing me as my older - and definitely wiser - self. I do mind being dismissed by our culture and the workplace as obsolete and useless.", 'I would smile sweetly, " No, but thank you ..." Great story ... didn\'t see it coming.', 'Funny!  My husband and I still feel young in our seventies, but kind people have been offering him seats for years - which is actually a good thing, if we admit it.', "Now you've got this 64 year old thinking... did you accept the seat?", 'great story!', 'Interesting that if the tables were turned (young man smiling at a woman in her 70s), it\'s highly unlikely she would think "I\'ve still got what it takes."', "I gauge how I look by whether I'm offered a seat.  One day 3 teenage girls did it - really bad!", 'Happens all the time and reflection on reality is painful but needed!!!', "Very nice. As a new entrant to my fifties, I am finally experiencing the strange disconnect between the physical image in my head (frozen at about 40) and how others see me (closer to my 40s).  This wasn't present when I was younger. It is jarring.   Thank you for the chuckle.", "Cute story - and no offense to the author, who seems nice! - but here's a fun thought experiment: Reverse the pronouns...this story would never, ever happen. Seriously, what on earth would make a man in his 70s think an attractive young woman would be attracted to him based on looks alone? (Besides society as a whole, I mean...I'm just talking about objectively speaking, in a rational world.) Sincerely, Young Women Everywhere Who Find It Personally Demoralizing That Guys Old Enough To Be Their Grandfathers Think They've Got A Legitimate Shot", 'Well, you still have your wits and that matters a lot! I really like your witty story (and its title).', 'Irony - I love it.', "Lovely. There's a flip side for women - -  we don't fool ourselves so easily- I think. But there was a shock when I realized that young men who often do speak very easily to me and my friends --were not seeing us as their mothers, as I feared, -- but their grandmothers.", 'Alas . . . Reality!', '......and gravity.', 'Great short story!', "So true.  I'm not as buff as Mr. Castro, but have noticed that young women are willing to engage with me.  It soon dawned on me that my age made me cute and completely nonthreatening.  Once you get over the slight to your ego, it's a plus.", "I'm a middle aged woman, and although I miss my once-beautiful skin, I am enjoying that people actually listen to me more now that I am no longer cute.  Sometimes it may be because I remind them of mom, but I'll take it.", 'I forget who said it, but the "Six Stages of Life"  are said to be..." -Irresistible -Resistible -Transparent (like a sheet of old plastic, fuzzy around the edges) - Invisible, then eventually... -Cute!"', 'Thanks for the chuckle...', 'You still got it!']
summary: Several commentators enjoyed the story and thought it was cute. Several other commentators identified with the story, noting that getting older makes you less threatening to others. A few commentators gauge their appearance by the number of seat offers they get, with more being older. Two commentators remarked that, if the genders were flipped, the story wouldn't happen.
short_title: Headline: The Smile Didn’t Mean What He Thought   Keywords: New York City; Subways   Snippet: Misinterpreting a friendly glance on the subway.
short_question: ['The Smile Didn’t Mean What He Thought  ']

query: Rarely is a writer quite so good at making words’ sounds match their meanings.
comments: ["Buy the book. Read it. Put it down. Pause. Pick it up again. It's so much more than can be described here. It's a book for all the Earth Days.", '>"She understands that words are not antiseptic little meaning-cubes to be stacked neatly into sturdy towers of logic."< That\'s quite a nifty sentence itself, Sam. Kudos!', 'Huh, Sam\'s take on the meaning of, “The refreshed river hissed” is entirely different than mine. I hear raindrops hissing on the surface, not "swiftmess of swollen water." But I haven\'t read it yet, so perhaps the cotext makes for our different image.', 'I have long been an Annie Proulx fan, but eyes "like dried peas" is more imaginative than I can abide.', "I LOVE this new column, please keep up the great work. I can't wait to share these beautiful sentences with my students.", 'I count the letter "r" three times is the quoted sentence, not four as the author states. It\'s a small point but necessary in such close parsing of a text, an activity I engaged in for many happy hours while studying for my undergraduate degree in literature.', 'Two "r"s in "refreshed" and two in "river."', "RefReshed RiveR hissed = 4 R's. Count 'em.", 'I\'m much taken with this novel, in part for the stylistic gems you single out, but there\'s one passage that puzzles me: the description of Duquet\'s first voyage to China aboard the Steenarend begins, "So the ship departed, down the Channel, past Brest, past Portugal, then west, well out to sea . . ." [Loc. 1273] which would make more sense from Le Havre or Amsterdam, not La Rochelle. Could such a skilled writer miss this, or have I missed something in my reading?', 'What an enjoyable, fun read. Your description of a "intergenerational soap opera about lumberjacks" is spot on.', "billo, what is 'spot on.' Is that the same as right on or goodo or you betcha or whatelsesomeeverwhere. Where did spot on come from. Surely not from pa. What means spot on, billo?", 'This informal adjectival phrase dates to the 1920s, and according to both British and American usage, means "exactly right."']
summary: Commenters' responses are overall positive, encouraging readers to enjoy the column and the mentioned book.  Some offer minor disagreements. One says that the reference to dried peas is a little too graphic for her liking. Another finds an error with the author's reference to the number of r's in a phrase, while another states that he has a different interpretation of the phrase.
short_title: Headline: ‘The Refreshed River Hissed.’   Keywords: Proulx, Annie; Books and Literature   Snippet: Rarely is a writer quite so good at making words’ sounds match their meanings.
short_question: ['‘The Refreshed River Hissed.’  ']

query: For more than a century, The New York Times Index guided readers precisely where they needed to go, and offered concise summaries of world events.
comments: ["The treasures abound, and thank the good Lord that David Dunlap is helping bring some forward so most aren't entirely lost in our technological shuffle.", 'Funny how the New York Times seems to quietly weave its way through the landscape of America and we never fully realize it until it is not there.', 'I used to use the Times index all the time when I was in college and afterwards when I needed to find information.  But years ago. it disappeared from the public libraries and I didn’t even know it still existed.  It’s a terrible loss.  It means that much of modern history will be unavailable, not just to  students but to all seekers of information about our world. As a substitute for the index, the Search feature in the online edition is completely useless, even for finding current information.  When I want to find something in the NYT, I go to Google and specify the Times and I get what I’m looking for immediately.', '"Who controls the past controls the future. Who controls the present controls the past." -- Party slogan, "1984" by George Orwell. “We can try to understand the New York Times\' effect on man” -- Bee Gees "Stayin\' Alive" Neonihilism tells us all these "facts" ain\'t necessarily true, and you can\'t believe everything you read in the newspaper. There was a day when I believed nearly everything I read in the Chicago Tribune - and I ended up voting for Nixon and Ronald Reagan for cripe sake. I deeply rue those votes, of course. You are only as good as your reading material and who knows where to turn now. Away?', "I think I missed something, why couldn't an electronic version of this be produced? If electronic, seems like it would be a much easier way to help locate critical information than a websearch, where you may be confronted with thousands of references to irrelevant material. I would have paid extra for an electronic version of this but didn't know it existed.", 'AW: "... a websearch, where you may be confronted with thousands of references to irrelevant material." For web searches, you can append "site:nytimes.com" to restrict searches to the Times. The Times has a search box at the top of its home page, although searches can sometimes return a lot of unwanted results.', 'The reason why the index was useful is because it had subject headings rather than full text searching. Subject headings reduce irrelavavant hits.', 'I wonder if any of today\'s readers or Times writers remember, but there was a Katherine Hepburn-Spencer Tracy movie about this eventuality,(humans replaced by computer), made in the 50\'s called "Desk Set". It was a romance but it was also prescient concerning the push towards replacement of research people in a news organization by  computer. Machines failed in the movie, and having used many library systems, myself,  trying to retrieve information, I know I am happier with the way people arranged data in 1900 than now. Computers remain cold and hard edged and always will be. The end of humans in research libraries and newspaper indexes will diminish the ability of students to obtain information and thus diminish everyone\'s ability to draw on such resources.', 'mabraun: "Machines failed in the movie ["Desk Set"] ..." The failure was probably due to a programming error that should have been caught during testing. You can blame Spencer Tracy\'s character for not doing his job. :-) mabraun: "The end of humans in research libraries and newspaper indexes will diminish the ability of students to obtain information and thus diminish everyone\'s ability to draw on such resources." In my experience, reference librarians will do a web search when answering questions more complicated than: "Do you have a book about such-and-such?"', 'While the Record certainly served a vital purpose, I would urge those who appreciated the fact that on " your way to finding whatever it is you\'re looking for  you\'ll be diverted by a lot else, all of it enlightening. For example a search about Armstrongs walk on the moon brought me to this :  "...a reproduction of the never-\xaddelivered statement William Safire prepared for President Nixon in case the Apollo 11 moon landing went disastrously wrong and astronauts were stranded on the lunar surface..."', "Sic Transit Gloria Mundi!  Truly a sad day to see the honored resource disappear.  I could not have done my dissertation research without the Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature, the stacks at the Paul Klapper Library at Queens College, the 5th Avenue brance of the NYPL, and of course, the venerable NY Times Index!", 'What does the "Newspaper of Record" mean exactly. Is it a self indulgent superlative, that has no real meaning outside of newspaper circles? Is it a nickname like "The Grey Lady"? Is it a researcher\'s term? Does it, actually, have any historical significance? I would like to brag that my opinions are based on reading "the Paper of Record" but I don\'t feel comfortable using that term when I can\'t answer the, simple, question "What does that mean?".', 'So what replaces this? Is the cheap visual image replacing the thought of summarizing and indexing?', 'Simultaneously awe-inspiring and heart-breaking.  Thank you, ladies and gentlemen of the Times.', 'Sorry to see this go.  The New York Times Index was always my go-to resource for all my undergraduate and graduate projects.  Of course, that was a few decades ago.', "Back in my high school and college days, the Times Index was just something that you learned about and how to use. Didn't know it was still in production and sad to see it go although truth be told I haven't needed it since college. Question: I have a vague memory, also about 40+ years old, of going to a facility on the West side [theater districty] where old editions of the Times were stored to be perused by those doing research. Do I have that correct?", 'RML: "... a facility on the West side [theater districty] ..." The Times had a printing plant at 101 West End Avenue from 1959 to 1975: 1959-75 | The Rise and Fall of the West (Side) By DAVID W. DUNLAP AUG. 28, 2015 https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/28/insider/1959-75-the-rise-and-fall-of-...']
summary: Most of the commenters are sad that The New York Times Index is being discontinued. Many have fond memories of looking through the Index for research papers in school. Others wonder what will replace the Index, with one commenter wanting to know why it couldn't be published electronically instead. Another commenter mentions that this reminds them of a Katherine Hepburn-Spencer Tracy movie about computers replacing humans.
short_title: Headline: A Record of the Newspaper of Record   Keywords: Indexers and Indexing; Newspapers; New York Times; Trump, Donald J   Snippet: For more than a century, The New York Times Index guided readers precisely where they needed to go, and offered concise summaries of world events.
subreddit: ['Indexers and Indexing', 'Newspapers', 'New York Times', 'Trump, Donald J']
short_question: ['A Record of the Newspaper of Record  ']

query: Each trip pushed us farther apart. So why would I continue to get on a subway with this person, never mind board an airplane?
comments: ['Engaging. Thoughtful. Closure.', 'Favorite line among many: "It was like sleeping in the heart of a jogging giant." Beautifully written.', 'So well written. I can place myself precisely in each of the situations the author finds herself.  Well done!', 'this is an amazing piece, perfectly balancing humor and poignance. thank you so much for sharing', 'Clever, quite writerly.', 'I adored this. Thank you, Sloane. So relatable and sad but a healthy outlook. And FUNNY. Maybe I will think twice about the couples I idealize on island beaches from now on.', 'This made me spit my coffee out and then the last paragraph was a gut punch. Great piece!', 'This and the Alexander Chee were such delights to wake up to. So heartfelt and evocative of the journeys we take to find love. And this one is refreshingly realistic because it so often takes many incidents to break a couple up and is not the dream AH-HA Oprah moment.', "I am a big Sloane Crosley fan and loved seeing her in this section. I only with this had been longer, as she covered three cities and not one. But as someone who has recently been through a divorce after 10 blissful years of marriage -- learning they were not as blissful as I thought! -- I found such comfort in Ms. Crosley's humor and insight about travel. The irony is that the vacation my ex and I took to Aruba where we he brought up the conversation that turned into the Big D conversation was also where we had our honeymoon. Brilliant article.", 'All of these read as though they were typed on a tight deadline by Hannah Horvath.', 'More than a little flaky....', 'Shallow, narcissistic and self centered people have relationship issues. Who would have thought!', 'Right! Deep, self-aware, generous and loving people never, never, ever have relationship issues for they are perfect people living in a perfect world.', 'Agree. Is this commenter reacting to the same article? I was impressed by the self-awareness.', "So boring! I confess, after the nth mention of her Chuck Taylors I couldn't go on. This isn't about travel--it's about the author's unremarkable-to--anyone-who's-not-her-friend (though sad!!) romance.", "It's as if you wrote this for yourself.", 'Travel distracts one from the negatives in a relationship.', 'Instead of discovering that the relationship isn’t working out while reading the piece it appeared to be doomed from the start. Why try so hard to make something work when the easy part is already done, you know it isn’t going to work? I guess the hard part is saying it out loud.', 'I am most definitely not enjoying this series. The pieces read like satire. The series needs more variety in social class and race of authors. I realize that many writers come from upper middle class white backgrounds but you need to consciously break out of that trap. NYT readers want their horizons expanded. And in this time of Trump, pieces with this privileged tone are especially unwelcome to many of us.', "What is class-based about this? I think you're making assumptions. You could be correct but -- heh? These are affordable destinations and this is the travel section!", 'I loved this piece! Light yet insightful.', 'Fantastic essay. So true about the intricacies and secret places, both mental and tangible, of which only those in the relationship are aware.', "This was so funny and beautiful. Like many readers, I have been in both situations, been both people, and it's never easy. But I loved how you articulated how destinations make things worse (or better in some cases, I'd like to point out!). My favorite of the section, tks.", 'Thank you Sloane. This touching story made me smile and feel wistful for those awkward "romantic" trips when I was younger. My love/travel memories seem extra vivid -- the sheer delights, and the sharp (but instructive) disappointments.  As they say, hindsight is 20 - 20.  This piece reminded me to cut myself some slack and laugh at the mistakes.', "Can relate to this. Two decades ago my high school/college boyfriend and I went on our first real trip together to Greece and while it wasn't a complete disaster (we did see some nice things) it showed all the cracks in the relationship and we maybe lasted another half or year or so together after. There were crazy long silences during the trip, semi-embarrassments (a guy came around selling flowers at a restaurant and my then boyfriend shooed him away in the least romantic gesture ever). He got a cold, I got some sort of heat rash on my hands. Lots of other small instances that showed the distance between us. Years since we broke up we have mutual friends and still see each other occasionally, emails on birthdays, that kind of stuff.  There is nothing in person when we see each other that is awkward or weird. But when I think of Greece and ever possibly visiting again I get an icky feeling, like a crime scene I don't want to revisit.", "This was the weakest of the stories in this series; written as though unaware it was to be part of a travel issue. Isn't what it felt like to be in LA, SF or Miami while experiencing the increasing isolation/heartache the narrator did meant to be central to the essay? I learnt nothing about those citiies. Perhaps this essay would make sense somewhere else, but I imagine this was solicited by NYT. Placed in this issue, I agree with Arthurstone's comment that this comes across as little more than navel-gazing.", "Lighten up. It's an amusing, poignant, relatable essay about love lived and lost in places other than one's place of residence. Did you skip over the part where the author pulled off Santa Monica Blvd weeping about how lost LA made her feel while her relationship was unraveling, or the personal fond memory of night kayaking in Puerto Rico she knew would not be shared by fellow travelers on a subsequent trip? You want more in depth info on LA, San Juan, and Miami, check out Fodor's.", 'Sloane, I really enjoyed your story. The last paragraph summary is beautiful in a very special way; some people and some places are meant to be forgotten. Be it friends, relationships, hometowns or university cities. It takes guts to be able to acknowledge the bitter truth that your trips have uncovered; that you and Max were not meant for each other. Imagine having not boarded on that plane to go to Los Angeles or San Juan or Miami. Surely, the discontent would be there but had you not taken the trips, the elephant would still be in the room albeit hibernating. Thanks for your wonderful story.', 'Please let this be the last "Love Issue" in Travel. Reading of interesting destinations which end up serving merely as backdrops to hipster romances is excruciating. Travel writing as navel gazing.', "Maybe you didn't read the part about this being a series where authors were asked to recount experiences where relationships and travel intersect.   This is a creative idea and I think the authors are brave to share a little bit of their lives.  If you don't care for personal accounts, no need to read them but it is unkind to make such a sour comment.  I like this essay, as well as the others and hope to see this series again in the future."]
summary: A commentator does not like the story of the novel written by the author.   Another commentator praises the story and comments that it takes courage to recognize that the couple in the story were not made for each other.   Other commentators recount their personal experiences with failed novels.   One commentator did not like the author not to have gone into the feeling of being in a big city while facing a difficult period of life.   Another liked writing to be about how love can be lived and lost anywhere.
short_title: Headline: Three Trips, Three Steps Closer to a Breakup   Keywords: Dating and Relationships; Travel and Vacations; Los Angeles (Calif); Miami (Fla); Puerto Rico   Snippet: Each trip pushed us farther apart. So why would I continue to get on a subway with this person, never mind board an airplane?
subreddit: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Los Angeles (Calif)', 'Miami (Fla)', 'Puerto Rico']
short_question: ['Three Trips, Three Steps Closer to a Breakup  ']

query: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have the last word.
comments: ["Wasn't Ed Asner a TV news editor in the MTM show, not a newspaper editor?   Or is there another TV show that I'm not thinking of where he WAS a newspaper editor?", 'Some fine clues today. I enjoyed clues U, B and N.', "Got a little derailed on this one, because I thought the Frisbee team was the Warmothers. But apparently that's the women's team!  Once I got past that, a smooth and entertaining solve.", 'Clue N--My favorite double-entendre clue of all time!', 'Gimmies were Ed Asner, roach motel, Norton, elephant, earthworm and anther. liked dish towel. did remember Ethelred the unready!', "I was able to start with NORTON, ED ASNER, GARFIELD, DISNEY, and ELEPHANT. Had ANswER before ANTHER, urg. Was close to getting ETHELRED, knowing it was one of those medieval names like Athelard or something, but finally looked it up, and was stuck on clothes line. Enjoyed the cluing; several GROANERS, like EYELID (oh those bats and balls). Tried to anagram Swarthmore, but didn't succeed, but I found that the women's team are the Warmothers. I also love Dave Barry. Fun, fun, fun.", 'I had a brain freeze on the English king and "knew" for sure that it was Richard I.  I had more than usual answers on my first pass through, all of which I was fairly confident about and Richard just wasn\'t making it, finally the head smack, 1100 wasn\'t the year in question.    After that it was fairly smooth.  I loved the Ogden Nash quote, and coincidentally I have just watched The Pink Panther on the telly.  I wanted the non electric dryer to be something like a clothes line, something I use a lot as I never  tire of mentioning. Fun quote.', 'Nice acrostic that solved pretty readily.', 'I just love N and its answer.', 'Great puzzle, including funny puzzle message itself (last puzzle word nailed the message) as well as great clues, such as the Swarthmore frisbee team and Ogden Nash clues. Missed the unintended political interpretation of the "unsuitedness" clue, but if the shoe fits...', "P.S. After reading the Constructors' Notes, one thing is not clear. I did not remember ANY elisions or ellipses, and I just went back now to double-check. Aren't elisions or ellipses normally indicated by dotted lines? There aren't any of those at all in that quote.", 'This Acrostic certainly was challenging. It was only toward the end that the grid began to “fill itself up”. [MAJOR SPOILER ALERT] My gimmes were GARFIELD, NORTON, ROACH MOTEL and ANTHER. I had to search for EARTHWORMS and ETHELRED. This one sure had its share of tricks: EYELID, DISHTOWEL, DISNEY. I had EAGER instead of ITCHY for a long time. It is almost impossible to believe that the “unsuitedness” question was not intended as a political commentary, even though the puzzle was presumably constructed some weeks or months ago.']
summary: Most commenters enjoyed the clues to the acrostic puzzle, especially Clue N. Several commenters got Ed Asner as an answer at the beginning, and one commenter was confused about the English king clue. Others thought that the puzzle was challenging and had a funny message.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Acrostic   Keywords: Acrostic Puzzles; Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have the last word.
short_question: ['Variety: Acrostic  ']

query: In many states, reducing the rate of incarceration has become a bipartisan goal.
comments: ['The following facts are ignored in this article. 1. A criminal who is incarcerated commits far fewer crimes than if he were not incarcerated. 2. the lives of many crime victims are ruined 3. the costs to society to solve and prosecute crimes is enormous- the failure to jail criminals is far more expensive than jailing them 4. releasing felons prematurely to return to high crime areas will inevitably increase the already high crime rate', 'This mild movement for reform, a movement toward more sanity on the issue of prisons, is long overdue. Naturally, most of the right comes to the movement from the perspective of cost rather than decency, humanity or the economic benefits of productive, rather than idle, people. We need to understand that five years or more in prison breaks people who were not previously mentally ill. It breaks them in ways that cannot be repaired in the lives of most people. Rare is the person who comes out of prison and leads a fully successful life. Families lose financial support, children lose guidance from fathers (yes, someone who has committed a crime can still love and provide help to their children) and communities suffer when a huge portion of the males are locked up. There will come a time when long prison sentences, especially those for non-violent crimes, are viewed as most people now view the death penalty: barbaric. There will come a time when future generations look at ours the way we now look at slavery: how could a decent society allow such a thing? Until that day arrives, the goal should be to reduce prison populations as much as public safety will allow and to refrain from sending people to jail as a first recourse to problems that arise.', "'' Jailing people is really, really expensive. '' The bill has come due and it is a whopper. That is the only reason that there is '' bipartisanship '' in this regards. Aye, I am cynical, bur republican reasons for reform are cost and Democratic reasons for reform are that it is morally wrong to jail so many for so long for such flimsy reasons.  The nanosecond that really starts digging into the private prison industry's bottom line ( huge republican supports\\monetary givers ) then that is when the ''bipartisanship '' will stop.  Get as many out as we can until that happens.", 'I was present  (taken by a politically powerful patient as a guest) at a small luncheon meeting with Governor Mark White -term:1983-87- where several prominent developers (some of whom were participants in the S&L debacle) discussed the logistics of private prison construction in Texas. The author fails to mention the role of profit and privatization in filling up Texas prisons with people of color. And then there has been the privatization of managed prison health care which further punished the incarcerated while making big contributors and political insiders rich. Is it any wonder that the two men who were recently charged with robbing a jewelry store in a San Antonio mall, and killing a bystander, got their criminal starts years ago in jail thanks to relatively minor drug offenses? Things are not as rosy here in Texas as the author contends. One thing she does get right: politicians of both major parties bear responsibility for making prisons and jails big business in Texas. We need to hold all the old "experts" on law and order accountable for their bankrupt ideas, profiting off minor drug offenses, and ruining the lives of the disadvantaged and mentally ill.', 'Huh? When we reduce violent crime, then and only then can we reduce incarceration.', 'If anyone has watched "13th" on Netflix, this information is not surprising.  The real problem is that prisons are big business.  Corporations that serve prisons have a vested interest in keeping them open.   And right, not only is treating these individuals CHEAPER, but it\'s the right thing to do.  No one is born "bad" or even strives to become that way.  Due to a number of, at times, uncontrollable circumstances, people learn to get their needs met or survive in the world in illegal ways.', "Ah, the almighty dollar finally shows legislators the light. Pay to build enough extra prisons, each complete with a revolving door out front, or actually help the 80% with drug addiction or mental health issues. It's no surprise which is cheaper.", 'Heck, here in California, they just send the criminals to San Francisco or Los Angeles.', "Sounds promising but: How do you respond when the president ignores fact? An engineering approach will work if you pay attention to facts. When has Trump demonstrated any attention to facts? The 'law and order' guy. Are you kidding? Prison reform, criminal justice reform requires facts and the courage to act on them. Where in this mish-mash of tweets is it found? I don't think that Sessions will be of much use. I don't really know. Maybe he isn't as bad, or dumb as he is portrayed. I won't be holding my breath.", 'I remember the 70s in New York City, when "progressives" repeatedly lectured us that there was nothing that could be done about crime, that it was a societal issue and people had to be "rehabilitated" etc.  As a result the City was a hellhole.  I remember people being advised to carry a second wallet or purse with them - containing less money than their real purse - as something to offer the inevitable mugger.   Progressives now want to return to those days.  And most of them live in nice houses are gated communities; they don\'t have to worry about gang-infected places like Chicago and other cities (where crime is rising by the way, not dropping).  I\'m always amazed at how progressives\' sympathy for criminals is seemingly boundless; but not for the victims of crime.  And the so-called "mass incarceration" issue is always expressed in racial terms, so that any opposition to their de-carceration plans is attacked as racist.  The real racism is occurring in places like Chicago, where innocent blacks are shot in the street daily but the police aren\'t allowed to stop it.  Oh, I forgot, that\'s painting a "dystonian" or "dark" portrait of the inner city, which is now also considered racist.   Incredible.', 'Even in Texas... Ah, yes, bastardize the largest border state with our drug addled southern neighbor for wont of a modicum of achievement. With better border security/enforcement the flow of drugs into the country ( http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/texas/article/Wharton-DA-Clever-...  will continue to bring this prison number down.', 'Unfortunately, this new fashion has coincided with the homicide rate in big cities shooting up about 25% over the last two years.', '"What is proven to work to keep people out of prison?" People not breaking the law comes to mind as one strong possibility.', 'When "breaking the law" includes petty crimes like personal drug use and possession, the blame falls on the legal system.', 'No crime against me is "petty".', "This article is especially encouraging because it shows a healing taking place.  Of course progressives are generally willing to find a reasonable common ground.  Maybe now that the ice is broken, conservatives will listen to other ideas such as preserving social security and Medicare.  These programs are not expensive when the benefits to the economy and GDP on the back end are factored in.  It's the government spending money to make money.  And the win-win is that citizens' lives are improved.", "So, they won't put them in prison, but they also won't help them with treatment.  Great.", 'Well yeah, these folks are all now felons and not allowed to vote, so it makes no sense for Texas or Georgia to keep paying for three slices of nutraloaf a day, a bed, and medical care. The desired goal has already be obtained.', 'Politicians ought to run on being "smart on crime". No politician was eve elected for being soft on crime. Being tough on crime is like spending monopoly money.  There is an endless supply of monopoly money. Judges need to wake up.  When they sentence criminals they are spending real money.  Give each judge a sentencing budget and let them spend it.  When they run out of money, hello, welcome to the real world. Running justice systems is more complicated than being tough on crime.  There is no support for deterrence theory. Look at the "school to prison pipeline" to see the link between school and community failure.   Police have absolutely no impact on this problem.  Where is "smart policing"?', "One of the reasons argued for the precipitous drop in violent crime in most parts of America over more than a generation was the resolve to incarcerate large numbers of criminals for long durations ... basically keeping them off the streets and unable to prey on society generally. There's the human argument, then there's the OTHER human one. If by emptying our prisons and returning large numbers of criminals to the streets results in a material increase in that violent crime rate, expect a boomerang effect in our courts, and the RE-incarceration of the small minority of people in our society who disproportionately CAUSE predatory violence.", 'This is a wonderful example of people finding common ground on an important issue. We should try to do it on other issues as well, and not just be sandbagged in our positions.', "Imprisonment is not intended to deter crime or save money.   It is simply a punishment system for those who have committed crimes, most often violent crimes.  Those who think that nonviolent offenders heavily populate our prisons are making things up. Prisons are dangerous places populated by dangerous people.  Ideally, 100% of violent offenders convicted over the last year should be imprisoned.  And the discretionary spending on their behalf should be as high as possible, suggesting attention to their needs.  Sound incarceration policy is to imprison the violent for at least a year and make the year constructive.  As usual, when everyone agrees on prison policy, they're all wrong.", "Nobody has much evidence that there are a lot of nonviolent drug users in prison.  There are gangsters in prison on drug charges who were too scary to get testimony against them because they were likely to have witnesses murdered, like Al Capone went to Alcatraz for tax fraud. But that's not what people want to find.", 'Good question, Eric.  About half of California inmates were imprisoned for violent crimes.  Many of the others are drug offenders.  The average drug offender has 9 prior arrests and 4 prior convictions.   Of the 9 prior arrests, 3 were for violent crimes.  Of the 4 prior convictions. one was for a violent crime.  So virtually every California inmate is serving time for violent crime  has a significant violent crime arrest record and has been previously convicted of a violent crime..', 'Drug dealer often means you killed-off your competition. See Chicago shootings.']
summary: Commentators talk about prisons being viewed from the point of view of economic costs and not from the point of view of re-socializing prisoners.   Commentators say that imprisonment for petty crimes leads these people to learn to commit bigger and more serious crimes, as the arrest is seen only as a form of profit by the government. Others comment that prisons are places to punish those who commit crimes and that everyone in prison is already violent and dangerous. Others accuse the government of not caring about prison reform.
short_title: Headline: Even in Texas, Mass Imprisonment Is Going Out of Style   Keywords: Prisons and Prisoners; Sentences (Criminal); Mandatory Sentencing; United States Politics and Government; Drug Abuse and Traffic; States (US); Texas; Dunn, Tim; Madden, Jerry Agnew; RightOnCrime.com   Snippet: In many states, reducing the rate of incarceration has become a bipartisan goal.
subreddit: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'States (US)', 'Texas', 'Dunn, Tim', 'Madden, Jerry Agnew', 'RightOnCrime.com']
short_question: ['Even in Texas, Mass Imprisonment Is Going Out of Style  ']

query: The most fun you will ever have with a crossword without ... well, without vowels.
comments: ['Really enjoyed this puzzle though it took me until the February 21st to finish. Would be happy to see another vowelless crossword in the future.', 'Not a fan.  I had never heard of vowelless puzzles, so had no idea what was going on. That was a good thing, because the struggle to figure that out what was fun.  Then the solve was fun.  Until I got about 30% through, and then it went from interesting/different to slog. I can see the attraction...just not for me.', "Out of town all weekend so not getting to this till now.  I came here to ask (BUT I JUST ANSWERED MY OWN QUESTION) what BCT was for 42A Tap (6).  Then I changed DEBATABLE to DOUBTFUL and now I can't get Farrah Fawcett Majors out of my brain, and that's not a bad thing for an old guy like me.", 'Could someone explain NDRGS (37D)?', 'I must insist that "Y" as in New York Times is not a vowel, but a consonant.  I am surprised that this escaped the notice of the editor.', 'This was my first vowelless crossword, and I enjoyed it much more than I expected to.  My having worked for a couple of decades in New York City helped a lot, although my fading gnomic memory gave me a fair amount of trouble.  It took me a long time to remember the name of the Frank Lloyd Wright museum with the spiral viewing ramp, and I was obsessed with trying to fit in Gertrude or Geraldine as the first name of puzzle editor FARRAR, before MARGARET suddenly popped out from that bowl of soup between my ears.
