My biggest teeth-gnasher, however, was not remembering La-Z-Boy. All in all, it was good mental exercise for a snowed-in day.', 'lvd t!', 'That was hard.', 'Love it!   It did help, though, that there was that NYC theme.', "I didn't care for it. With the exception of the NYC trivia (which was annoying for those who don't live there), it was too easy.", "That was a nice, nasty little challenge, not equivalent to a cryptic but still sufficiently irritating in places to be worth the effort. Some favorites were NDRGS, MPRCS, SBPLT, because there were such feasible alternatives unless you got the crossing answers...of course I realize the constructor's achievement was building those titanic New York landmarks vowel-less-ly. But who in heaven's name was Margaret FRRR? Sounds like a foreboding character.", 'Margaret Petherbridge FaRRaR (March 23, 1897 – June 11, 1984) was an American journalist and the first crossword puzzle editor for The New York Times (1942–1968). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Farrar', 'The patron saint of the NYT XWP. May her legacy endure.', 'Please. No more. Better another cryptic than this. So boring. Verbless post. Uninteresting, yes?', 'This was a lot of fun.  I hope we will be seeing more vwlss pzzls.', 'My first vowelless, found it fun and intriguing. Love the word tosspot and will have to incorporate it into my vocabulary.  Hope to see more of these.', "I just want recommend THIS to anybody here who has not already found it on their own: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/02/11/obituaries/smullyan-logic... By the way, I got the first two right, but I could not figure out the others at all. I'm a lot better at math puzzles, and word puzzles, than I am at logic puzzles.", 'Notepad: In this puzzle, the letter "Y" always counts as a vowel. What has always irritated me about the vowelless is the unequal status of semivowels "W" and "Y."  The possible solutions: 1. Treat both as vowels. 2. Treat both as consonants. 3. Treat each according to its function.  This could cause problems at crossings, however. 4. Unpredictable behavior.  This is my favorite because it adds another challenge to the dilemma.', 'I was messed up by the one clue I have no idea what the starting word would be:  13D, Beat in athletic competition (7).  I thought it would be TOPPLE--> TPPL but there are 4 letters not three. TPL was the answer. Is there a different word I should have been thinking about that reduces to TPL?', "Thank you to Jenna.  This was the one answer I wasn't able to parse.", 'Thanks Jenna. That was one of many that I had trouble with.', 'Outplay', 'I was happy to see the Vowelless again after a long time. I did it online, and I kept having a problem that I wonder if other people were having. Letters kept changing "on their own" to other letters. I don\'t know if the glitch is in the Times\'s computer system or with my own computer. [SPOILER ALERT] Anyway, as a New Yorker I liked the theme. For a long time I had DEBIT CARD instead of SMART CARD. I kept mentally going over the map of the PATH system, trying to figure out just which station would fit into (6,3,6). Finally I realized NEWARK, NEW JERSEY. I grew up in Brooklyn, so I wound up being surprised that I had to search for BUSHWICK instead of knowing it.', 'P.S. I forgot to include: [SPOILER ALERT] I wonder if RHENISH is still used to refer to some German wines. After getting some of the letters, I remembered the character in "Hamlet" saying that Yorick had once poured a "flagon of Rhenish" over his head. How about those two consecutive tricky answers, BOOKCASE and NEURON? In each case you are misled into expecting something pertaining ro computer technology.', 'Reading your post, Jerrold, I realized I had fooled myself. I completed the puzzle (wondering what non-New Yorkers were thinking but mentally reminding them that the NYT is our "hometown paper"!)...where was I? Oh, yeah, I got it down to one answer I knew had to be correct, but not what it stood for. It was the intersection of 6D and 20A that done me in. I now see that 6D is not BKCN, answering the question in the clue with BOOK CAN! Okay, lame, but the trouble was, I could not check it because I didn\'t know the cactus. (*That* clue belongs in Tucson\'s hometown paper!) But that one tiny glitch did not nullify all the fun I had doing this puzzle. I\'ve done vowelless XWDs before and it\'s often much easier than you think it\'s going to be...especially if you live in the target city. ;-)', "It's hard to say for sure, since vowelless crosswords come up so infrequently, but I believe this is the best one I've seen. That's saying a lot, given the theme and my status as a born-and-bred Philadelphian..."]
summary: Commenters seem to be torn on this vowelless crossword puzzle from Variety Puzzle. Commenters are divided in the comments, with some saying they really enjoyed the puzzle, however, they did note that trying to complete a vowelless crossword puzzle is much harder than completing a normal one, one user noted that it made it a little easier because the NYC theme, which they seemed to be familiar with. Other commenters thought the task was boring or too difficult for them.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Vowelless Crossword   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: The most fun you will ever have with a crossword without ... well, without vowels.
short_question: ['Variety: Vowelless Crossword  ']

query: While the Junior Naval Scouts encouraged enlistment in New York City, young German soldiers in France reached the end of their fighting days.
comments: ['The days of "War Horse" come to mind.  Powerful. Youth so short.  War so long.', 'Recalls the great Phil Ochs song "I ain\'t marching anymore" "Its always the old who lead us to the war and always the young who fall…"', '"The pacifist is dead," huh? Maybe we should change the label of "pacifist" to war hater—put a little more fight into it.', 'The most eager "warrior" among the group I was part of heading to DaNang, VN, was also the youngest of the group.  The most broken and disillusioned that I heard of from that group when leaving was the same person, having mistakenly killed some of his own platoon in a firefight.  War, what is it good for...', 'This sure sounds like a 50 year old "war story" the kind told so often on the Internet. The kind of story folks may even start to believe themselves. I\'d love to know your mos and outfit. Your story has a certain something about it.', '1/46th, 196th Light Infantry Brigade, 23rd Americal Division was the outfit I served longest in, among two other units.  I served as M60 machine gunner for long-range patrols in mountains out of DaNang, and two missions with Recon teams to edge of Laos. I understand your reluctance to accept comments on their face, especially given the nature of the internet and the despicable inclination of too many to fabricate stories.  I only mention my experiences rarely and briefly, knowing there are people who take this bit of history seriously.  My comments are meant for them alone.', 'The young always fight the wars of the old--obviously that is current up-to-the second today, as it was then.', "why is that? it is because the young are not wise enough to know better. youth as the saying goes is wasted on the young.  very few of the richest and political people have skin in the game which makes it that much easier to beat the war drum. If Trumps kids were first in line to fight - maybe he'd be more reasonable. Our choice of him as president shows we are in moral decline.", 'Sumptus de Bello              (Cost of War) "Just  war\' with horny hands from hell All God\'s good reason does dispel, And wrests from human minds the form That holds them well, worthwhile, and warm. Many never find their way back home; Some still rot beneath a foreign loam, Or lie under an oceans waves No wreaths to decorate their graves. Having given all for "God\'s good fight," Which will matter not in time\'s short flight; Soon conquered land will be "just ground," Where only churning worms abound. Years later we will check the score, To ask then what the war was for; As we have barbeques and no parades, And with old foes have open trade. Yet unstirred, in quietus, will lie, Those whom for glorious cause did die; And wanting hearts, still empty, break, With a pain no balm can ever slake. Yet now we proffer with feigned verve, "It was an honor to have served." Come next plight, though, we must quest  - To waste not on war the country\'s best.                                                      d.a.', 'Can anyone provide the name of the author of Sumptus de Bello?', 'It is don Anderson', 'I just popped it on because I thought it related.', "I'll be a lot of families would be surprised to learn they had ancestors who attempted to enlist in wars while they were underage. If you go to a certain popular genealogy site, you can look up WWI draft records. I discovered both my grandfather and my great uncle attempted to enlist and 14 and 13 respectively. I knew they lied about their ages because I had other records showing their true ages. They didn't get selected to go, though, just as well because in that case chances are I and my other relatives wouldn't have been born.", 'An ancestor that served in the Union Army lied, saying he was 17 and not 15. He also talked either a cousin or a brother into enlisting. Both boys (I guess men, if war makes a man) served at either Vicksburg or Fredericksburg. My great-great grandfather lived. The family member he talked into coming with did not.', 'I just had a conversation with a cousin doing some research on my Dad who enlisted before WW2 at 15 he lied about his age and said he was 17 that was in 1939 it was a family joke that he had 2 birthdays.', 'Reminds me of Margaret Mitchell\'s  book " The war that ended peace " WW 1 never ended just awoke Germany to re-arm and restore dignity to the Germans. Hitlers primary model.', 'Wilson is the great failure in Presidential history. The American entrance whoich ended stalemate created the inevitable conditions for Hitler. And near economic collapses because bank speculation on farm land. Indirectly , the cause of wide depression in Europe.', "Nah . . . it just delayed 'em.", 'Wilson is a failure to the undereducated and the infirm.  Which one?', 'A sweet story from some 75 years ago.  I get it, war is not good, especially for teenagers. But we haven\'t learned a thing.  Just this past Monday at the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan I saw a young man, perhaps 25 years old.  He tried to play some music for some money but it just didn\'t sound right.  I looked at his hands and he didn\'t have them - only some medal hooks.  I asked what happened and all he said was "Afghanistan."  I gave him some money and was deeply ashamed of this country and myself.', 'And you are sure his answer was the truth...how?', 'It always amuses me that the closer you get to ongoing extensive combat at the tip . the less you see of flag waving, parade-think, and general good cheer and optimism about the nature of combat itself. there is a reason that those flagswaving big talkers in the rear,  safely out of combat ,are thought of so poorly by those at the tip']
summary: Most commentators agree that the young suffer the most from war, including a touching story about a young man who lost his hands in Afghanistan. Several commentators note that the biggest war hawks are those who are nowhere near the front lines. One commentator talks about underage enlistment in past wars. One other commentator muses about the effects of WWI on Europe. Another commentator posts lyrics to a war-related song.
short_title: Headline: Some Boys Celebrated the War, Others Were Prisoners of It   Keywords: Prisoners of War; New York Times; Fifth Avenue (Manhattan, NY); World War I (1914-18)   Snippet: While the Junior Naval Scouts encouraged enlistment in New York City, young German soldiers in France reached the end of their fighting days.
subreddit: ['Prisoners of War', 'New York Times', 'Fifth Avenue (Manhattan, NY)', 'World War I (1914-18)']
short_question: ['Some Boys Celebrated the War, Others Were Prisoners of It  ']

query: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to and comment on front-page headlines in the news right now? What is your opinion of its message?
comments: ["What the image is saying is immigrants can not come into the U.S. This relates to the news because Donald Trump put a temporary ban on people coming from Libya, Syria, Iraq, Iran, Yemen, Sudan, Somalia. The reason being that those seven countries are terrorist originated countries. The reason why Donald Trump  issued a ban was because we don't know who or what is coming though our Eastern and Western borders there could be terrorists trying to kill Americans, illegal items to profit gangs and criminals, and drugs that hurt Americans and kids that are in school. So I don't like this picture because there is a good reason why Donald Trump put a ban from people coming from those countries.", 'I think that this image is showing us the two people and the government is the big shadow . The government is like the darkness, it is scary, It is telling us that us the people will not go into politics because it is scary. We think  that it will cause anger, judgement and pain .', 'Everyone is basing on the shadow and how donald trump is so powerful, but everyone is forgetting we have 3 branches and theyre all as powerful as the other; so maybe immigrants need not to be scared and enjoy.', 'I see two people seeing the statue of liberty very scared because of how tall it is and how the shadow looks like. I also see that theres only one hand raising and the other hand holding a book', "I don't like the symbolism in this picture. In this picture there is Lady Liberty and in her shadow is Donald Trump, but instead of Donald holding a torch, he's holding a bat. The people in the bottom are immigrants trying to enter America. The size is definitely not random piece of this puzzle. It's symbolism. The picture is showing that Donald is bigger and has more power than all of the smaller people. Trump being the shadow of Lady Liberty is showing that he is the dark side of  the current America. I don't like this picture because Donald isn't just getting rid of people and keeping them out of the country like rodents. He's protecting our country by keeping the bad people out. I don't like the symbolism in this picture.", "not all immigrants are people trying to destroy america, also the people have american visas. its saying that trump is abusing Muslims even though they have a right to be here. a woman with a full US citizenship and a US visa was turned away, had her visa stolen and forced back on the plane to go back to the middle east. she was the wife of a doctor here and was only in the middle east to vist family. there're just people trying to make their way in the world, fleeing the radicals like ISIS. and you want to send them back into the lions den to die from ISIS oppression, or become a statistic from american bombings.", 'Hey Jayden, have you ever thought about what the lady of liberty was meant for? Many saw the lady liberty as a proud symbol of America. Not just as a symbol of freedom in America, but also as the opportunity of freedom given to all who wish to come to America. I do believe the reason why trump is depicted as the shadow of our lady of liberty is because he is rescinding the chance for others to become true and proud Americans, such as you and I. If anything, it is un-American for Trump to keep not just the small number of "bad" people out, but many good and hardworking people as well.', 'The symbolism in this picture has a point and makes it well, though? It\'s not so much him "keeping them out like rodents" but that America (setting aside the mistreatment of native americans) was founded to give people a better life? Not every immigrant who comes here is a drug dealer or a terrorist, and that\'s the point that\'s being made in how the immigrants in the picture present themselves. They\'re abiding by the laws and in banning ALL muslims from America, Trump is adding to the harmful idea that ALL muslims are terrorists, here to put people in danger which is far from the truth. Yeah, "not every bad person LOOKS bad", but still, you shouldn\'t use stereotypes and bad apples as a gist of an entire group of people. The ban is misguided, unconstitutional and forgets what America stands for as a whole. Don\'t get me wrong: of course I want to be SAFE, but NOT at the cost of people losing opportunities or being demonized for their race or religious practices and such.', "There is Lady Liberty but the shadow of her is the real Trump, with his now famous 'side' hair holding a billy club rather than the lighted torch welcoming the new arrivals.  I vision Lady Liberty to also be covered/made of green dollar bills, although not depicted in the cartoon.  The individuals with visas are standing in fear it seems rather than the former anticipation of a new life in the States.", 'For all that Lady Liberty has meant for the refugee and the migrant since the French people gave us this remarkable symbol, the Republican complicity in Mr. Trump\'s reversal of the most important values of America is deeply troubling. For todays 60 million refugees to look up at Miss Liberty and expect welcome, and then to find the angry sword of Trumpism replacing her welcoming reputation, can only be one of the most awful experiences one can experience. For Christians and Jews, "I was a stranger and you welcomed me" is fundamental. For Americans, to witness the wave of deeply distressed and endangered refugees witness Miss Liberty turn her back on them is to witness a moral failure of the exercise of our most deeply held values.', 'Sure, it may seem cruel that people from war-torn countries are not allowed into the US, the "ban" is very necessary. Not only would our tax dollars go towards possibly dangerous sanctuary cities, not only would we have to be armed head to toe from possible radicals, not only would we end up like Germany and the rest of Europe with their policies, but it would be a burden worrying about the threat they may bring. Just imagine if Hillary won and she took our guns away and poured in millions of refuges into our country. Picture the migrant crisis like this, you have a bowl of M&M\'s, 10% of them are poisonous, would you grab a handful?', 'American has the hardest screening process in the world, and yes it is cruel, you are sending people back to the middle east to die from radicals. imagine those m&ms you are able to detect which ones were poisonous very easily. also its a bad analogy because if you send these PEOPLE back to these countries, they will be tortured hungry and possibly probably die. you are killing innocent people and with US security. the odds of dying from a terrorist is  1 in 20 million. ( www.lifeinsurancequotes.org/additional-resources/deadly-statistics/)', 'TO MEL IT MEANS LADY LIBERTY HAS BOTH LIGHT AND DARK SKIN.  WELCOMING EVERYONE BOTH WOMEN AND MEN.', 'You are welcome into the country as long as you follow and respect our constitution.  In other words, you must be believe in free speech.  We do not kill people for the cartoons they draw, regardless of their opinion.  We also do not allow women to be beaten in the streets, regardless of their relationship.  Muslims are welcome, but Sharia law is not and many are caught in between.', '"If you are a Christian, welcome or you get beaten up"!! Poor Muslims are frightened to death!!', 'I see Lady Liberty facing down a nefarious, angry Trump, empty folders in one arm, his other hoisting a defiant billy club in a show of shadowy power against her. The scenario has immigrants scared and confused, wondering who will win.', "The statue represents how people had freedom at one time and now they don't.", 'The statue that americans see is the statue of liberty and the new people think its bad.', 'Lady Liberty is currently a fake, appearing to be welcoming in the harbor of NY, but the underlying (darker) truth is that we are not so welcoming.', 'The statute that Americans see as "Lady Liberty" is seen by new immigrants for the first time. To them it looks like a mean bully that holds a bible in one hand and a stick to beat them in the other.', 'In this picture is showing that maybe they are new to the us and trying to figure out what it is, but then in her shadow is showing that is somebody that dont want them here its like they dont want them here.', 'they are making fun of lady liberty', 'It shows that the liberty of freedom will be gone to all immigrants that ever goes to the United States of America.', 'the people in the photo is new to the us and is looking at the lady liberty and is wondering what is symbolizing', 'it looks like a someone did not pay bills, or there taxes and are being questioned or being told to leave and dont come back. They look like there afraid of the statue and running away from it then walking towards it.', 'In this picture i see that the shadow of the statue of liberty is another person with what looks like a cap side ways and holding billy stick up and the people that are looking at it are afraid.', '2 Faced lady liberty one with a side of good and side of bad']
summary: Many of the commenters are discussing their interpretation of the image shown. Quite a few of the commenters believe the shadow in the image represents the government, or namely Donald Trump, and how he is casting a shadow over America. One commenter believes that the image represents Lady Liberty "turn(ing) her back"  on endangered refugees. Some of the commenters disagree with what this image implies, stating that anyone is welcome in the United States as long as they "respect our constitution" and that life is better in the USA than in other countries.
short_title: Headline: Lady Liberty   Keywords:    Snippet: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to and comment on front-page headlines in the news right now? What is your opinion of its message?
short_question: ['Lady Liberty  ']

query: Wednesday: Reactions to a minimum wage boost, unusually warm weather, and summer jobs.
comments: ['Can anyone explain to me why fast-food workers should get a higher minimum wage than other workers?', "Nice that the McD workers got their raise but this will only mean fewer of them as the minimum reaches $15/hour ($31200/year). McD and BK are automating the ordering process and fast food prep automation is on the way. The fast food places will manage this. Local restaurants will be squeezed by the $15/hr min. wage. They can also automate ordering in some cases but will hire fewer people to hand out cheese danish or pizza slices at $15/hour. And restaurants also have to put up with increasing city fees and charges, not to mention increased rents brought on by commercial building property tax increases. Park Slope and Greenwich Village may enjoy paying $5 for that (smaller) cheese danish but more and more restaurants will close up all across the city. It's already starting.", 'Has anyone looked into the fact that many of these fast food chains are looking for ways to minimize the work force by putting kiosks in fast food restaurants? Nobody is stating this fact and it will be a rude awakening in the next 2 years for many of these folks who are now getting paid more.  Also the point of these jobs is to force the labor employed here to look for better, higher paying jobs. This just keeps them from moving up which should not be the goal. These are entry level jobs for high schoolers, not people in their 20s, or 40s.', "And the kiosks get cheaper every year which is why you're starting to see them in local non-chain restaurants. And this is next - http://fortune.com/2016/03/17/automate-fast-food/ http://newsexaminer.net/food/mcdonalds-to-open-restaurant-run-by-robots/", 'I was not aware that some jobs exist to channel workers into better careers. Who established this principle? If you are the low level of anything there is a desire to move up, if you can, but to justify what is essentially exploitation based on a theory of social engineering is misguided. Also, fast food may be a convenient example but there are many other occupations that are kept at minimum pay.', 'What fails to ever be addressed is that the reason wages are so low is because of illegal immigrants driving down wages.  If employers did not have access to illegal workers, they would have to move wages up to find enough employees.  Many will argue that there are not enough Americans willing to fill all of the low wage jobs and that is correct, they are not willing to work for the depressed wages but when you take away the illegally hired workers, employers are forced to pay more and Americans will work if the price is right.  Artificially raising the minimum wage is a temporary fix, inflation and reduced hours will wipe out artificially imposed wage increases.  The real solution is to not allow illegal workers and real wages will go up.', 'If your going to use round numbers to describe the $1.50/hour pay increase, an extra $260 per month is much more accurate than the $240 per month stated in the article because it is based on a 52 week year rather than a 48 week year. Better yet, why not be totally accurate and simply say the increase comes to $60 a week.', 'On April 15 there might be a surprise not for the 22 year old but the woman with a daughter: EITC, Earned Income Tax Credit. It is a nice amount for low income earners but less as income increases.', 'Thank you for giving specific examples of how this pay increase really does materially improve the lives of so many people, b/c you get those who say "ah, it\'s buck fifty; who\'d even notice that after taxes?" - and the answer is: lots of people notice it and find it makes their lives better. Now I wonder: what\'ll it take for the billionaires to make an effort and pry open their welded-shut wallets a tiny bit?  They seem convinced they can "take it with them" when they go.', 'Hornets tear Nets', 'What employers pay to have you on the payroll: a 6.2 percent on each employee’s wages  for Social Security until a salary of 118,500, 1.45 percent of each employee’s salary as Medicare tax up to 118,500, Federal Unemployment  rate is 6 percent of the first $7,000. All states require that you purchase workers’ compensation insurance once you have someone on payroll. Rates vary by state, for NY 2.83% Because unemployment taxes and social security taxes phase out after a certain compensation level, you will pay a higher relative percentage for low-paid employees than you will for well-paid ones. If you do business in a state with a high unemployment tax rate and a higher workers’ compensation rate — like New York or California — that will also add on a few more percentage points.', '@CB:  Well-said!  Thank you.', 'Medicare does not end at 118,500.  It is taxed on all income.', 'In Australia the adult minimum wage is $17.70 per hour AUD or $13.49 US. Casual workers also receive a 25% loading to compensate for missing out on leave payments like recreation and sick leave that is $16.86 US/hour. Those who work unsociable hours, weekends, public holidays, evenings and nights, are entitled to penalty rates ranging from 1.5 to twice their normal rate. Tipping is in appreciation of good service, not a customer\'s supplement to poor wages. These are the minimum rates. They may be higher in the fast food industry if an employer has an "Enterprise Agreement" with workers. The safety net for each industry is the Award and and EA cannot fall below the Award. The Award cannot fall below the minimum wage. There is a "Better Off Overall" test, so lower pay would have to be compensated in some other way. In addition to that employers pay into superannuation (employee retirement funds) and for worker\'s compensation insurance in case of injury. Health care is socialised so employers don\'t contribute to employee health care as they do in the US.  Yes, some employers in the hospitality industry complain bitterly about the above but, contrary to their complaints, hospitality - restaurants, fast food, holiday accommodation, hotels (bars) etc - is one of the fastest growing industries in Australia. US experience in California shows that minimum wage is actually good for economies as well as the workers.', 'Thanks again Freddie.', "That's trickle-up economics, folks: more minimum wage, more spending by more people; more spending, more economic multiplication. (vs trickle-down tax cuts, which gets invested or spent on idle assets -- extra homes, cars, boats and other toys)", "How wonderful allowing many to take care of themselves and the company's that have a little less profit for it.  A win win.", 'I got a summer job through the City youth jobs program at 14. The pay was $39 a week. I would have been happy to work year-round, but my neighborhood was economically depressed and there were  no opportunities. The jobs today are more interesting. Too bad the program is only six weeks.', '"[...] and send more money to her parents in Bangladesh." Um, if you\'re already struggling for money, it\'s probably not a good idea to send money to family. You need to make sure that you can meet your own needs before you worry about someone else, even if it is your parents. This doesn\'t make good fiscal sense.', 'That may indeed be an admirable thing to do, but does it then actually constitute the "cost of living" for those employees?  Pointing to a low paid worker at the low end of the economic spectrum and who sends a goodly portion of their wages abroad  does not then constitute evidence that the wage is too low if the argument brought forth is predicated on how much it costs to live in NY such as food, rent, etc.  That no doubt sounds cold, but it is a legitimate element of the discussion.', 'They are hungry helping to feed them makes sense', "This is  a cultural norm in Asia.  I am sure the daughter is proud to be able to participate.  She isn't asking you for the money; she is working for it.", "Since the groundhog said early spring, maybe it's not too early to break out a summer song for today's And Finally section.   Tune of Summer Nights Summer program, sign up real fast Summer program, spots will not last Age 14 to 24? And this year, they're paying more Summer wage, scroll down the page And go for a Summer Job Well oh well oh well oh hmmm Tell us more, tell us more You like working with art? Tell us more, tell us more Then that list is a start! Uh huh uh huh Work at Mo-ma, give it a try Or design at D K N Y At Mount Sinai nurse folks to health Or at Chase, manage some wealth Summer youth, ain't it the truth They all want a Summer Job Tell us more Tell us more!", '"She said the extra responsibility as not a problem..." More pay requires more responsibility....WOW, what a concept!']
summary: Commentators are arguing about raising the minimum wage. Some think the low wage is due to illegal workers who accept to work for lesser pay than legal workers would accept. Other commentators believe that raising the minimum wage is beneficial as it will stimulate the economy. A few commenters discuss taxes that employers pay to retain an employee and that these rates vary by state. Other commentators address how the increase will affect those who need to work to support themselves and still send money to relatives in their countries of origin.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: What a $1.50 Pay Raise Feels Like   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Wednesday: Reactions to a minimum wage boost, unusually warm weather, and summer jobs.
short_question: ['New York Today: What a $1.50 Pay Raise Feels Like  ']

query: In this visually ravishing production, Bobby Cannavale steps into a part that has been waiting for him for decades.
comments: ['A terrific and insightful review by Mr. Brantley! Here in all its concrete emotional explosivness is the essence of what disgusts and is so destructive about classes in society. The staging by Stewart Laing is absolutely BRILLIANT! So brilliant, in fact, it might very well turn out to be the greatest theaterical experience of your lifetime.  The play abounds with his many spectacularly creative visual delights.  Bobby Cannavale, as always, is beyond superb. What a talent! He plays his role which calls for very demanding physical acting gloriously and delivers a magical performance. This searing play about how capitalism creates a snobby upper class that looks down on and abuses the laborers they depend upon is as relevant today as it was almost a hundred years ago.  Powerful, soaring theater at its very best!', 'The staging was magnificent. Too many words to express the amazement.', 'There is not a play or musical-and that includes the H musical -playing in New York that can touch this production.  BRAVO !', "A production of monumental proportion with elements of surrealism, expressionism, absurdism and crushing pathos.  The cast is brilliant as are the machine-ballet choreography and stereo industrial sound design.  I did find it odd to be trapped inside a sinister conveyor belt with the liberal elite, watching a condemnation of the liberal elite.  But I cried at the end, I couldn't talk, it hit me that this play is about every person who has ever been ignored, devalued and thrown away.", "Really powerful production in that amazing space of the Great Hall, but no one is mentioning the tremendous sound design! The placed effects thrown about the room from isolated speakers, the distorted and altered 1920s music for the bizarre dance of the zombie swells; the sound design was as compelling as Cannavale's powerful performance.", 'agree with everything in the review about the power of this production (it is memorable), but my enjoyment negatively affected by 1) the extraordinarily uncomfortable hard plastic seats which dug into the middle of my back and 2) the horrible acoustics of the brilliant space. The voices echoed, were overly mic-ed  and hard to understand at times creating an unbridgeable distance between audience and performer.', "Because Cannavale starts the first scene at the top of his range and never modulates, his final scene isn't heartbreaking. At least it wasn't for us. And it should be. Production is truly phenomenal, but I thought it's style almost created a distance from the pain one should feel for these characters.", 'I remember the part of Yank,played wonderfully by William Bendix in the old movie version....,an unforgettable role.', 'I saw "The Hairy Ape" at Knox College, Galesburg, IL, in the early 70s, directed by Richard Riddell, who went on to a successful career in theatre, including a Tony some years back. I also photographed the production for him; perhaps somewhere those Ektachrome slides still exist. And I had read the play, which is profoundly sad and moving, before I saw it done. It\'s appropriate that this new production of the play is in New York City- a place which, more than any other I have visited, demonstrates the huge gulf between "society", and the labors of those who makes society\'s privileges possible.', 'O\'Neill\'s one-acts should be taught in schools throughout America.  We barely teach any plays, other than a handful of obligatory Shakespeares.  With "Emperor Jones" and "Shell Shock" and "Hairy Ape" you have entry into many themes America is facing 100 years later.  They are basic yet deep, setting a foundation for more complex, longer works. I hope to see this production.  It sounds great.', 'We have an uneducated fool as a president and a GOP Congress and Fox News all determined to lower the educational standards of our country so hoping for students to be enlightened by the arts is hopelessly naive.', "We can't accept the status quo of the no-nothings Trump cabal. We must resist and fight back for the sake of our children and theirs.", 'Everyone who appeared in "The Station Agent" went on to become big names and respected actors. It\'s not for everyone, but If you can\'t afford to see  Bobby Cannavale on Broadway, this early performance might give you a clue as to what the fuss is all about. And he\'s third billing.', 'I also liked him in "Blue Jasmine". He was one character that was sympathetic, in spite of being assigned the "Stanley" role.  Same with "Win Win". Cannavale often has a winning quality to his gruffness.', "Well, where were all you Cannavale fans for HBO's Vinyl?  He was great in the lead role, a real ur-Cannavale character struggling through the drug-infested hyper-sexualized music industry in its greatest days. My hope had been Netflix would pick it up. But if you want to see him on the screen, there's no better example of what he can do.", 'The Station Agent was one of my favorite all time films.  Understated yet brilliant performances by everyone, especially Cannavale and Peter Dinklage.']
summary: Most commenters praise the play and indicate that the production stands out. One commenter praises the insightful review. One commenter talks about everyone appearing in "The Station Agent' becoming respected actors and big names. Another commenter says that the production was good but that the style was nothing special.
short_title: Headline: The Caged Beast Awakens   Keywords: Theater; Park Avenue Armory (Manhattan, NY); The Hairy Ape (Play); O'Neill, Eugene; Cannavale, Bobby; Jones, Richard (1953- ); Laing, Stewart   Snippet: In this visually ravishing production, Bobby Cannavale steps into a part that has been waiting for him for decades.
subreddit: ['Theater', 'Park Avenue Armory (Manhattan, NY)', 'The Hairy Ape (Play)', "O'Neill, Eugene", 'Cannavale, Bobby', 'Jones, Richard (1953- )', 'Laing, Stewart']
short_question: ['The Caged Beast Awakens  ']

query: A loss in the Wordplay family.
comments: ["Mac Knight was a kind and loving man who bore his illness with grace and good humor. Sending condolences to the Knight family and to all who were lucky enough to call him friend.  Thank you, Leapy, for sharing the link to his and Merrilee's wonderful photographs.", 'I join the rest of the Wordplay family in sending my condolences.  He brought a lot of pleasure and insight to all of us with his posts.  RIP.', "http://www.pbase.com/macknight/root Visiting some of MacKnight's views of his world.", "Thank you for the URL for his photos. I much appreciate the chance to see his work, and I'm impressed. I regret not knowing him better. Condolences to the family.", 'I can\'t do much more than join in on every comment that appears here - I certainly appreciated the way his posts were uniquely upbeat, showing a spirit of joy in the world we share here (crossworld) and joy in the world we share out there (most especially his portraits - "photographs" doesn\'t do them justice - of the wild birds he loved so well). My sympathies and prayers are with his family in this time of loss and change.', "It makes me inexpressibly sad to learn of MacKnight's passing. Such a good and courageous man. Condolences to Merrilee, Calliope and all the family.", "I can only add my voice to what has already been said here, with special eloquence by Martin and Jimbo. Since coming to Wordplay a few years ago, I learned to look forward to Mac's thoughtful and gentle posts.  I particularly enjoyed his beautiful bird photography that he was so gracious to share with us. Condolences to Matt and all of Mac's family.  Be happy with your memories of this lovely man.", 'Goodbye Chief Mac Knight, I am so sad to read of your passing...Mac\'s appreciation of and skill with avian photography is just a part of what the WP site will now be lacking...To Merrilee and family, I am so sorry for your loss...This is "Anthem," a 2008 performance from Leonard Cohen.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6wRYjtvIYK0', "I can only echo what has been said here. A bright star in our constellation has been extinguished.  My great sympathy to Mac's family. His comments were always a ray of light in our solving lives.  His cheerfulness in the face of suffering was an inspiration. I feel so very sad.", 'I am so sorry to hear this sad news! Mac had become a good online friend, and I always enjoyed reading his posts, and being a Facebook friend. I will miss his good will and wit, and his lovely photos of birds.', "Can only add my own condolences to the family and express my sadness at his loss.  It won't be the same here without him.", "One of the wonders of the internet is its ability to bring together people from all over who share a common interest.  And then to learn more about those people through their words and pictures, until they become true friends, even if they've never met in person.   I admire Mac for his unwavering good nature, delightful sense of humor, wide range of knowledge, and bravery in facing his health challenges. And for his willingness to share all that with us.  A cherished member of our WP community.  I am saddened that I will not get a chance now to meet him in person, but I'm pleased and proud to call him my friend.  My condolences to his loving family.", 'Sorry to hear the sad news.  I will really miss Mac’s positive Wordplay contributions.', "I am so sad to read of Mac's passing.  I will miss his posts both here and on Facebook as well as his photographs and recommended books/authors.  My sincerest condolences to his family.", "Tears. I'm pretty new to this wonderful blog but have been here long enough to know what a very special person Mac was (is.) He will be missed. But most importantly he will never be forgotten.", "Just a few days ago in the blog Mac sent me words of encouragement after my own SMM diagnosis.  I didn't realize how sick he was at the time, and it makes it more poignant that he took the time to boost my spirits.  Yes, he will be missed.", 'What sad news about one of our most delightful members of the wordplay family. We will miss his apt comments and lovely photographs.  My condolences to all the family.', "I was so sad when I turned to Wordplay and read of Mac's passing.  Always such a positive contributor and apparently even in the face of devastating illness.  It's good to know that he truly enjoyed being a WP contributor.  My deepest sympathies to his family.", "and Elke We are truly saddened at reading that Mac K. has passed away. Martin expressed so eloquently our feelings . Mac's comments were always so gentle and kind. We loved his beautiful bird pictures. And Elke remembers especially his delight in his granddaughter, Calliope  . He was a very special grandfather , and  it's  very sad that his family did not get more years with him. Sincere condolences to all- he will be sorely missed.", 'I am so sorry for your loss, and for ours.  Mac was the kindest person I\'ve ever encountered online.  He never had a harsh comment, and you could tell how special a person he was.  I\'ll miss his optimism and his wonderful photos more than his family could ever imagine a "stranger" might.  He really felt like a close friend and I\'m sure that many in this group feel exactly as I do. My condolences to all of Mac\'s family.', 'Over the last few years Dad has told us many times how much he loved being a part of this group. I cannot express my gratitude properly for all you have done for him through your connected love of words. Deb, thank you so much. You are a good friend and we appreciate the joy you shared with him. -Matt', 'Condolences for the loss of your dad. I also know this loss of a loved one leaving too soon. Mac always set a lovely upbeat tone in his comments which were enjoyable to read.', 'Like many others here, I always looked forward to his comments. Certainly he made our daily discussions more enjoyable for all. Our sympathies are with you during this time of grief and loss.', 'Thank you very much. This has helped our grieving process. If anyone would like to talk more about dad. Please let me know, I am always available to talk.']
summary: The theme from all commenters is one of sadness at the death of Mac Knight. Most sending sympathy and condolences to Mac Knight's family. Many commenters recall Knight's positive post and pictures in this crossword puzzle community. One commenter says that he is Knight's son and shares how much his dad enjoyed being a part of the group.
short_title: Headline: Mac Knight, 1952 — 2018   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: A loss in the Wordplay family.

query: A plan to build a barrier to seal off South Vietnam from the North was rejected as ridiculously expensive in the 1960s. But the idea lived on.
comments: ['Back in the day (post Viet Nam...) I worked with some people from (D)ARPA. Brilliant in a Dr. Strangelove way and, quite often, very "toungue-in-cheek". I rather suspect Taylor\'s barrier proposal was not all that seriously considered, mostly due to its obvious idiocy...', 'Ironically, the real engineering feat of the Vietnam War was probably the Ho Chi Minh Trail.', 'Implicit in this article is the standard rationale for the Vietnam War, that America was defending South Vietnam against aggression by North Vietnam. Challenging this view are the writings of Noam Chomsky, for example “The Legacy of the Vietnam War,” an interview published in Indochina Newsletter, Issue 18, November-December 1982. Here and in other writings he tells us that the object of the U.S. presence in South Vietnam was to destroy its rural peasant society. (And let’s remember that the government that invited the U.S. presence was its puppet and hence illegitimate, making the U.S. presence an invasion, under the Nuremberg Principles a war crime.) The U.S. wanted to destroy rural Vietnam because it supported the National Liberation Front, and the NLF’s ideas for an independent South Vietnam, had it been allowed to come to power, would not have been in the interests of the U.S. As Chomsky says, “[The NLF] was clearly a nationalist movement — and in fact a radical nationalist movement which would separate Vietnam from the American orbit. It would not allow Vietnam to become another Philippines. It would trade with the United States but it would not be an American semi-colony.” Like the other in this series, this installment fails to address the fact that the U.S. presence in Vietnam was a violation of international law. Easier to talk about a technocratic folly cooked up by the “best and brightest,” who like their bosses were evidently untroubled by such matters.', "It might have worked.  East to West just below the 17th parallel, sea to Mekong is much shorter than along the Vietnamese-Laotian border.  A 200 m wide cleared strip with watch posts to call in air support.  It wouldn't have stopped every infiltrator, but would have stopped regular North Vietnamese divisions, which are what defeated South Vietnam. Hadrian's Wall worked for hundreds of years.  Our technology is better.", 'If there is going to be discussion of the Trump wall in comparison to other walls, proposed and actual, it seems to me a more relevant comparison would be with the Israeli West Bank wall/barrier, built for the purpose of inhibiting unauthorized entry by unregimented groups of undesired persons.   Yet instead, we are offered a comparison with a wall, never built, that was proposed for a tropical climate where active and organized military hostilities were occurring.', 'Having recently driven across the old DMZ between Northern and Southern Vietnam, it is hardly noticeable except for some highway turnouts with pretty views. The concept of a North and a South Vietnam was always a Western construct and existed mainly in the minds of the US political and military leadership. I firmly believe that Vietnam is one country today because the Vietnamese saw it that way and wanted it that way.', "There is mis-nformation in the description of the sensors dropped by the Air Force. They didn't sense convoys, they sensed heat. Water buffalo, groups of people, elephants and civilian vehicles were unable to be differentiated one fom another. The moral implications of this are obvious and shouldn't be over looked as they are in this article.", 'Chi My experience, and I believe it\'s reliable, is that sensors were "accoustic," that is, they sensed movement (like seismographs do) as well as sound patterns. To confirm that I looked up Operation Igloo White, the defense department program that encompassed this program, and found this extract: "The Defense Communications Planning Group\'s research and development program created an advanced technological system. "Muscle Shoals" (aka, Igloo White) would consist of three interdependent parts. First, there were air-dropped, battery-powered acoustic and seismic sensors.[18] The camouflaged sensors were to be dropped in strings at predetermined geographical points along the PAVN logistical network. Once emplaced, they would serve as tripwires to any movement or activity along the system." I\'m relatively confident other designs were used in other applications, including heat, as you suggest. For instance, in Long Khanh province, our area of operation, there were intelligence choppers flying at night that literally sniffed the air for concentrations of urea and methane to detect the massed presence of men who had to urinate and defecate, releasing related aerosols. The NYT requires me to be polite about this. Was it effective? My infantry company was sent to bunker complexes because of that technology disclosed to us in commands only as "usually reliable source."  I\'m confident that multiple forms of detection were deployed.', 'The money to build the wall will be diverted from needed infrastructure projects. So a wasteful and ineffective pile of bricks in the southern deserts instead of repairing economically vital bridges, roads and railways across the USA? Is that really what trump voters wanted?', "Speaking of walls, there's a black granite one in Washington, D.C., with more than 58,000 names on it that, rather than American genius or American exceptionalism, speaks to American hubris and the fact that instead of learning from our mistakes, we tend to double down and, invariably, repeat them. With tragic results.", "Desperation: the mother of all American wars since WWII. Why again, please, do we call POTUS the Commander in Chief? He doesn't seem to command much in the way of military brilliance. See: Truman to Trump.", "Technology has come a long way. Fields of acoustic sensors would be far superior and more flexible vs. Trump's Folly - even better if at least partly mobile. Though still a stupid idea.", 'The geniuses who want to build physical walls forget that the human mind knows no such barriers. Ideas travel with the speed of light, not the trudge of footsteps and the rate of cement drying. The idea of building a wall on the southern border of the USA is as ridiculous as building the Berlin Wall or this idiocy of of General Maxwell Taylor. All the walls do come down, especially the ones found upon diversionary thinking and erected by the likes of a mean-spirited Humpty-Dumpty.', 'Why are WE always the deciders of how other sovereign nations are to be divided up? Whether in Vietnam, previously in Korea, or whatever WE propose for the future of the Middle East, we have no legitimate claim to any of those countries. So what, beyond self-imposed American exceptionalism, empowers us to make such arbitrary determinations?', 'I do not know who the "we" is. Was it the Military-Industrial Complex that formed the "we?" Spiro Agnew\'s "Silent Majority?" The Unholy Four (Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon) who pursued a "known we will loose" war against Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia to buttress their own political reputation(as uncovered by The Pentagon Papers)?  The we certainly did not include me, nor many of those military and all of civilian innocent human beings killed by the lies  told by those aforementioned. Aah, for the good ole\' days when lies were pure and simple lies, not versions of an alternate reality', "In addition to harsh reparationst from Germany,  the Treaty of Versailles is a good example this tendency. Divisions of Mesopotamia and Syria ignored ethnicity and religion and led to present hostilities, thanks to France and England's desire for retribution.", 'Versailles demanded less from Germany than Germany extracted from France in 1871.  The French paid their reparations and were stronger for it, instead of inventing a victim complex.', 'There were many stories about these fabled sensors during my tour as well, including the fact that the sensors, dropped from aircraft like weighted arrows intended to stick in the ground and resemble plants, would pick up animal movement as well as human movement.  There were multiple stories of our listeners detecting what sounded like "heavy rainfall", until they realized that the NVA, who could readily identify the fake \'plants\', were urinating on them.  The wonders of modern warfare.  One can only (regrettably) imagine what someone as loosely tethered to reality as our current so-called president can come up with for ideas.', "One ray of hope. HR McMaster, National Security Advisor, is a fierce critic of Taylor's actions as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, which cut off any advice that the generals were legally obligated to provide Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, allowing both leaders, in collusion with Secretary of Defense McNamara, to edge into a misbegotten war without tangible consultation with the JCS or Congress. In 1964, Taylor replace Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. as ambassador to Vietnam. From this point on, Taylor and McNamara conspired with Johnson to hide the realities of the situation in Vietnam from both the public and Congress in order to not muddy the waters of Johnson's Great Society legislation. Johnson and McNamara continued to micromanage the war from afar using Taylor as the on-the-ground conduit to prevent oversight and advice from the Joint Chiefs, Congress and the public. The so called Vietnam Wall was a mish-mash of broken chain of command ideas, some by the rookie McNamara, some by Taylor who abetted Johnson's and McNamara's conspiracy, and some by the various service chiefs who had little clue what Johnson, McNamara and Taylor were up to. Johnson and McNamara both lived long enough to profoundly regret their disastrous actions. For the moment, there is at least one player in the Trump administration, McMaster, who is acutely aware and well studied in the folly of Vietnam and the likes of hair brained wall schemes. But political expediency often ignores sound advice.", 'I also read McMaster\'s book.  Too bad Trump is a non reader. I think that McMaster and "Mad Dog" Mattis may be the only competent members of the Trump administration.', 'We hope that as intelligent humans we would learn from our mistakes and either improve on the technology or design. We learned so many years ago, as the piece describes, the difficulties in preventing "infiltration". Our President would be well served if he would toss the bait used in his bait and switch campaign rhetoric concerning the Great Wall of Shame and rely on, well, facts, rather than fiction, and the lessons learned in one of our greatest fiascos so many years ago.', "That I lived through this and nothing has changed, just astounds me. I have to reread this article. Who knew? Will read Ricks book. As an aside, I read his book on IraQ.  I was 20 in 1967. My life changed. To those whose didn't, you are the problem.", 'Toward the end of my 14 months in Vietnam in 1969 and1970 I worked in battalion tactical operation center. I was one of the RTOs required to get a secret clearance in the interest of even hearing and conveying some of the information that passed through. That included the use of sensors placed by recon units in abandoned fire support sites and along discovered NVA infiltration routes. There\'s no doubt that the sensors sent "information," but a problem was that our area of operation contained a lot of animal life, some of it large enough to trigger sensors as would a human being. Whether the artillery fired on those sites accomplished anything more than possibly terrorizing the fauna and destroying the flora was never to my knowledge confirmed. Effectively the U.S. and S Vietnam constructed a barrier of combat units along the border with N Vietnam. They infiltrated through Laos and Cambodia, despite horrendous cost paid as casualties along those routes. And the NVA still won the war. Trump\'s wall on our border with Mexico is just another sign of failed thinking exhibited in trying to solve humanity\'s problems. He could spend money trying to provide those in Central and South America with economic alternatives and better government. The cost would be far less and more effective. http://www.theirishgolfblog.com/2017/04/eric-trumps-visit-to-doonbeg-201... He\'s a man trying to wall out the ocean in Ireland. He isn\'t sophisticated enough to try practical solutions.', 'Spend money in Central and South America to provide "economic alternatives"??  You should know that such money has been spent for such purposes many times all over the world, all at the expense of "economic alternatives" for American workers - who, by the way spoke up last November.', 'Back Up So alternatively this new administration, like others before it, rather than continue to try to devise aid programs that will improve life in other nations toward the end of stabilizing the societies and population movements, apparently intends to support governments that oppress and deprive, spending the aid money, as one example, on "a wall" that is unlikely to be completed, or effective, and, as another example, investing heavily in the most expensive form of national insurance, our military.  Incredibly expensive military action is effectively another possibility selected by voters last November since, now, they have no control over what the administration will do, and have effectively encouraged military spending and increasing military spending. Good luck with your outcomes.  And thanks!  I didn\'t vote for this guy, but his being in office will ironically help me from a tax perspective. I\'d have preferred more progressive outcomes, but since I\'m entering retirement this administration will facilitate and enable that.  I have no doubt that a lot of people will suffer because of this government, but coincidentally many of those who will suffer chose that outcome. I\'ll never understand why they did, but it\'s their experiment.  If it works, well, what do you know!  If it doesn\'t, as seems probable based on past outcomes, the question is will they still fail to learn from that failure as in the past, or try it again?']
summary: Several commenters agree that this undertaking was needless. It used funds that were needed badly in other areas. Other commenters highlight that humans are too brilliant to be deterred by such things and that the system was very flawed because a lot of misinformation was sent because of the high population of wildlife. One commenter suggested that the bombing did little more than harm the environment.
short_title: Headline: Five Decades Ago in Vietnam, a Different Great, Great Wall   Keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces; Vietnam War; Defoliants and Herbicides; Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency; McNamara, Robert S; Trump, Donald J; Vietnam   Snippet: A plan to build a barrier to seal off South Vietnam from the North was rejected as ridiculously expensive in the 1960s. But the idea lived on.
subreddit: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vietnam War', 'Defoliants and Herbicides', 'Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency', 'McNamara, Robert S', 'Trump, Donald J', 'Vietnam']
short_question: ['Five Decades Ago in Vietnam, a Different Great, Great Wall  ']

query: The wine panel finds great potential and at the same time ponders why some bottles seem so vibrant while others do not.
comments: ['Eric, I love your writing and I really don\'t want to flog this idea to death but I would face off a $20 2014 Domaine Trouillet Pouilly-Fuisse or if you want to splurge, a $30 2012 Domaine Louis Jadot Santenay Blanc "Clos de Malte" against any of your picks. I am sure the Norcal wines are great but the pricing is just out of whack. And the I wines I picked had ratings, if I were to exclude that I can probably go down another $5-$10 and find something that competes.', 'Sorry, no California chardonnay is worth $75.', 'My name is Ed. And I like chardonnay.  Wow, glad I put that out there.  Even one of my kids (he\'s 21 now) like\'s to say "Dad likes ponies and chardonnay". I suppose he, like one of the other commenters, is suggesting chardonnay drinkers have the sensibilities of teenage girls.   And when the waiter comes to deliver a glass of pinot noir and a chardonnay to my wife and me, it\'s more often reversed than not.  How have I dealt with this unconscious, and sometimes very conscious, bias? I have the conviction that a wine mentor of mine instilled in me about 30 years ago: drink what you like.  Really, can I do that?  Even when it is no longer fashionable?   By powering through and drinking what I like, I have developed some great memories and moments that are associated with the flavors and experiences of my chardonnay journey. Thank you, Mr Asimov, for reminding us that wine has the power to be part of the complex emotional fabric of our selves.    And at the risk of blowing up the potential sweetness of that sentiment, I\'d like to also mention that the beautiful smell of freshly deposited horse manure also triggers my sweet dreams of someday having, as my son would say, a pony.', "Mr. Asimov has an energetic imagination. But his attempt at metaphoric melody doesn't change the tune: It's California chardonnay. And while it's a fine starter wine for teenage girls (at home, with parental supervision), forking over $75 for a Sonoma white will indeed leave a bitter taste in your mouth!", 'Lovely California wines are available at under $15 per bottle that upon blind taste test are typically found identical to those mentioned.', 'Identical? No way. Even for someone with an average but experienced palate like me. Virtually all under 15$ california wines are "zip code" products, blends of multiple sites and sources. Many are perfectly drinkable for sure.', 'Given this amazing "potential" we can only hope that the beautiful coastal woodlands are not turned into rows of grapes', "A wonderful read ! I'm very familiar with the Sonoma Coast,an awesome area. The chapel at Sea Ranch must be seen to be believed. There are many wonderful Sonoma wines that are more affordable however. One of my favorites ,albeit Napa is Rombauer Chardonnay,very reasonably priced and tasty.", "Energy? Don't you just mean properly balanced with slightly higher than normal acidity but enough fruit to buffer it? Sadly, many of California's most highly regarded (in Maryland, anyway) Chardonnays have too much alcohol and too little acidity to be worth drinking a second glass. The Sonoma Coast is a good place to look for the ones that don't.", "Great read. I'm quite familiar with the awesome Sonoma Coast,Sea Ranch Chapel a highlight. It is such a serene place. I'm certain the wines mentioned are wonderful but more reasonably priced Chardonnays are readily available. A favorite is Rombauer Chardonnay, lovely.", 'Rombauer Chardonnay:  sweetish, overly-oaked dreck.  Not at all  like most of the Sonoma Chardonnays discussed in this article.', "kcp: our opinions obviously differ . To the readers, try it,it's not dreck.", "it's terrible imho can't think of a worse wine to introduce someone to California chardonnay", "Probably like a lot of folks, I got tired of California chardonnays and stopped drinking them for about 25 years, because most of them were so bad--most chardonnays were way too oaky and acidic.  How do we know which ones to try after this experience? This article helps pave the way for restoring my faith in the possibility of trying a good glass of chard based upon the author's recommendations.", 'Asimov writes that the Eric Kent wine is "closer to Los Carneros and San Pablo Bay than to the coast." He does not advise that there is what out here is referred to as "true" Sonoma Coast and the broader Sonoma Coast AVA, which includes Petaluma. This could be a disservice to those looking simply for "Sonoma Coast" on the shelf. This "energy" business is a pernicious species of wine speak. He then refers to the three wineries at the bottom of the numerical scale and states: "Each makes more expensive single-vineyard designates that are often deeper and more complex." How often are they? Not in vogue, but the 2014 Russian River Valley Chardonnay from Chasseur, IMO, is the equal of the vineyard designates, including the Lorenzo Vineyard, which is a true Sonoma Coast vineyard. Just who in the New York Times readership is going to be able to buy the wines from Rivers-Marie and Ceritas? I live right here in San Francisco and I can tell you that no one can buy these wines here without already being on their mailing list. So, in terms of the two wines which are the most highly rated here, neither will be available.', 'toniomaran: \'He does not advise that there is what out here is referred to as "true" Sonoma Coast and the broader Sonoma Coast AVA, which includes Petaluma.\' To be fair, he does write about the region extending far inland, and that the rich-flavored 2014 Sangiacomo Green Acres Hill from Eric Kent was grown   \'considerable east of Highway 101.\' But how\'s yer average consumer supposed to know that from the label? I only know it because the vineyard is a 10-minute walk from where I live. Asimov\'s observation \'that racy wines from the coast and richer, fruitier wines from inland may wear the same appellation\' bears repeating and I agree with you that consumers looking at "Sonoma Coast" labels on the shelf could be misled.', "The Ceritas and Rivers-Marie wines are well worth the effort to get on their mailing lists, if you want the Sonoma experience.  Unfortunately, the RM wines this year are in especially short supply. Ceritas' chards are simply outstanding, not that there's much of it out there.", 'agree the peter martin ray vineyard from caritas is a step from the one tasted', 'I have always found CALF Chardonnays to be better than Non-CALF ones. They are more oak-tasting and dryer.', "Wonderful piece which resonated with me as I'm quite familiar with the wondrous Sonoma Coast. One of our favorite stops on the way to Gualala,a lovely oasis,is the Sea Ranch chapel. What peace and joy the chapel conjures up. Timber Cove Inn which is near the home described in the article is also a terrific destination. Add Rombauer Chardonnay to this list !", 'OK Eric, you’ve explained that a wine with “energy” is not one that is heated. But “racy”? I never did understand that one. What does “racy” mean? Is it a wine with petrol character providing “energy” down the racetrack? Or a wine of low viscosity that “races” down your throat? Or does it mean something more akin to “varietal,” as in “races” of man? Help! How do I tell if I’ve got a “racy” wine?', '"Racy" is a common wine descriptor. It usually means the wine has a bright, tangy acidity--typically used to describe a white wine that\'s tart and "zingy."', 'There are plenty of fantastic Sonoma Chardonnays that are less than $40 (or $90) a bottle. I understand that the author is attempting to describe wines that are delicious and well balanced through the use of the term "energy".  However, too often, these articles celebrate wines that are very hard to obtain or which are unaffordable to many wine enthusiasts. While they are interesting to read, they are of limited practical use to many, many wine lovers.', "I couldn't agree more with this evaluation. I just wish he would just talk to those for five people that these articles are written for and leave the rest of us in peace.", "I agree with the earlier comment about energy as a category for a wine tasting. The traits in the wine that keep you  wanting more have more to do with proper balance, and acidity is a key balance to any white wine. There's nothing worse than a flabby wine.  The other comment I'd like to make is of the price points. Yikes! it should be easy to find delicious wines at these price points.  The real challenge is to find a nice wine at a nice price.  Can't the selections be more affordable. Or are the tasters saying to stay away from any Sonoma coast wine under $30?", "I think this article shows just how many facets of the whole wine tasting experience/hobby, or however you want to approach it, there really are. I really enjoy talking about wine when I go tasting and it's even better when the winemaker is poring during the tasting.  Beyond the short patter given at most wineries, discussing and most importantly learning ever more about wine is what I enjoy just as much as the experience of tasting new wines.  So I just tell anyone who might be confused or overwhelmed with wine to just realize that wine tasting is a learning process that never ends.", 'I have a huge problem with the following... "You might ask what energy means in the context of wine, and it’s a good question. For me, energy is the quality that impels you to take another sip. It’s a forward thrust, a sense of tangy vitality that is lip smacking and thirst quenching. It’s texture as well. Some wines feel so good in the mouth that you want another sip to regain the feeling" There are enough intangibles in the wine world for the public to consume and  this statement will lead to further confusion.  How does the public, who are already intimidated by the process of buying wine, now go shopping for wine asking about "Energy?"  Furthermore people that think they know about wine are now going into their wine shops asking about wines that have "energy."    I would differ to the idea that energy is created on a certain level.  That feeling when you have a perfectly aged steak, with a wonderfully aged nebbiolo or the sancerre that pairs with a wonderfully roasted fish with a splash of citrus and olive oil, there is energy that occurs in these chemical and emotional pairings....or is this synergy...']
summary: A number of commentators give commentary on wines, their qualities, and their prices. Several commentators criticize a few terms that the author uses, especially about wine having "energy." A few commentators refuse to pay $75 for a bottle of Sonoma white. A few other commentators enjoy the article and praise it. One commentator hopes that new wineries don't ruin a coastal region.
short_title: Headline: Chardonnays of Energy and Memories   Keywords: Wines; Chardonnay (Wine); California   Snippet: The wine panel finds great potential and at the same time ponders why some bottles seem so vibrant while others do not.
short_question: ['Chardonnays of Energy and Memories  ']

query: “The rent is too damn high,” the celebrity chef Tom Colicchio posted on Twitter, announcing the end of the 15-year-old restaurant.
comments: ["Here's to hoping the landlord gets stuck with an empty space for so long that he's forced to take LESS than Tom was paying.", 'Craftbar is a lovely neighborhood restaurant. It is welcoming, the food delicious and service warm. Part of its charm is the normality of it all: just good, old fashioned, honest American cooking. Craftbar became part of the fabric of the Flatiron. I hope it is reborn soon. #SaveNYC.', 'n a couple of years  he is slated  to open in a new building at the Downtown Brooklyn Cultural District on Lafayette Ave. The City gave the land to developer for 1 buck.', 'Filthy per cent increases may they these greedy pigs be vacant forever', '"The rent is too damn high?" What, is Colicchio running for Mayor?', 'Come to Harlem.', "What is it about these huge ego chefs ?  Anytime they start to do an outpost of a  successful restaurant they spread themselves too thin.  If they would stop at four that would be plenty of income and they'd enjoy life a lot more.   In the next recession in 2018 there will be a number of these guys with broken dreams and little to show for their efforts.", "Landlord greed is paving the way for ghost towns or neighborhoods, once again. I live in Northern Westchester, and my once-adorable town has seen a restaurant, ice cream parlor, and liquor store all go out of business in the last year or so; another restaurant has turned over 3 times in about 22 months.  it's all because of the rent.  Tom--I wish you well.  I love all your restaurants, and know you'll prevail, and succeed. good luck.", 'In a few years, it will just be $500 dollar tasting menus and Duane Reade sushi. Enjoy your glass cages while you can, oh privileged denizens!']
summary: Many commenters are frustrated about greedy landlords raising the rent and forcing businesses to close, and some even hope that they remain vacant. Several commenters hope that Tom reopens his lovely restaurant, possibly at the Downtown Brooklyn Cultural District or Harlem. One commenter says that chefs shouldn't open outposts and spread themselves too thin.
short_title: Headline: Craftbar in Flatiron District Will Close This Spring   Keywords: Restaurants; Chefs; Colicchio, Tom; Craftbar (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant)   Snippet: “The rent is too damn high,” the celebrity chef Tom Colicchio posted on Twitter, announcing the end of the 15-year-old restaurant.
short_question: ['Craftbar in Flatiron District Will Close This Spring  ']

query: The band created one of indie rock’s most indelible sounds, built around the collaboration of David Longstreth and Amber Coffman. Now he’s reinventing their music without her.
comments: ['Seems about effete as I imagined he would be. For someone who left Yale because it was "training a global power elite," he seems to represent those same sanctimonious, highly pretentious things that elite artists do. Not that there\'s anything WRONG with that. He\'s a very competent artist. It\'s just incredibly boring.  I\'m also kind of blown away at just how blase his interests are. He contracted a case a late aughts Brooklynitis, and I\'m afraid it\'s terminal. He\'ll live out the rest of his life in LA, so comfortable that he\'ll mold to the contours of his Ikea couch, prompting Ikea to release a new design in his honor, the Longstreth. Long may you reign, David!', 'Please, please tell us who, at the Times, allowed this sentence to slide by a good copy editor:   "He wore an unkempt beard and scuffed desert boots that — after he spotted a narrow gap in traffic — transported him across the asphalt and into a bodega on the other side." As this is writte, n his beard and scuffed desert boots transported him across the street. This is the worst kind of high school writing.', 'I will never understand fanboy fascination with the minutiae of music making and music makers. I just listen to the music.', "It's the same as anyone's love for anything behind the scenes. If you truly have a passion for something such as music, it wouldn't be a stretch to assume you'd be interested to know what goes into your favorite artists' albums.", 'sometimes the process can be interesting if not more interesting than the art itself. you ever wonder how anything you own gets made or who is making it?', "This is one of the strangest comments I've ever seen on here. Why did you read the article then?"]
summary: One commenter questions why people would be interested in how music is made, while several others retort that being passionate about music-making and how artists develop their albums is a good thing. One commenter says that the artist in the article is pretentious, and despite being competent, is just boring. Another commenter calls out the Times for its writing style.
short_title: Headline: Going Solo   Keywords: Pop and Rock Music; Dirty Projectors (Music Group); Longstreth, David; Coffman, Amber (1984- ); West, Kanye   Snippet: The band created one of indie rock’s most indelible sounds, built around the collaboration of David Longstreth and Amber Coffman. Now he’s reinventing their music without her.
