short_question: ['Going Solo  ']

query: A mother’s good-night kiss has unexpected consequences.
comments: ["I wonder if VisualDx is also available for veterinarians. I just saw 3 vets, only one of whom used the scientific method to eliminate heart-related issues for my dog's symptoms. The other vets were content to charge me for tests and meds she did not need, none of which addressed or diagnosed the problem. I am so glad to read a story of someone pursuing a diagnosis through research and not guesswork. Glad to know the third-year student is becoming a physician; we need more like her.", 'Or instead of a week delay and guessing via online software the parent could have simply taken the girl to an eye care professional. Since that is where she ended up anyway. What\'s the worst case had that been the choice from day one? The girl had simple bleparitis or viral conjunctivitis and been treated one and done? I\'m confused how we are happy that online software exists that can kind of get doctors working outside their speciality to maybe get closer to the diagnosis...possibly; when we have ample professionals that specialize in a  given tissue/system (for most specialties). Would we herald this is an eye care provider used online software to start treating systemic conditions(or any speciality far removed from the issue st hand)?  These programs have niche settings for ER and after hour settings and that\'s about it. I saw a person in my chair this past month who was "tele-diagnosed" with  a corneal abrasion with edema.  Was treated for 3 days...they had angle closure glaucoma. The problem is until a human looks at something the symptom list and even basic signs of many conditions overlap.  Don\'t let your health get farmed out to computers people under the guise of saving money.', 'Having experience with Herpes 1,2 and shingles, I can only say that having had HIV treatment for a long time has practically stopped the recurrences of herpes, but not the shingles, which I already had 3 times.', 'Query:  At the outset,  I want to note that, while I am a lawyer, my practice does not involve representing clients in medical malpractice cases, either on the plaintiff or the defense side. Second, however, at what point does the standard of care require that a physician use either VisualDx or some other, similar, software.  Going one step further, should a physician "log" the searches he or she makes in any particular case, setting forth the reason(s) a potential diagnosis was either accepted or rejected?', "My mother was infected as a child with herpes IN her right eye.  The stress of having her father develop and be permanently institutionalized for schizophrenia was a complication.  She suffered recurrences all her life usually when under stress.  She developed secondary glaucoma, her cornea clouded over reducing her sight and the pressure that developed in the eye was excruciating and nearly required the removal of the eye.  It was a life long disability and not in any way trivial.  I hope this child's parents and doctors are vigilant and cautious.  It is nothing to be trifled with.  Thank God for acyclovir.", 'How is this different from shingles? I had shingles around my eye a couple of years ago, in spite of having had a shingles shot. Of course, I was 70 at the time and had had chicken pox as a child. Presumable this child was vaccinated against chicken pox. Still, the treatment for both of us was the same, and she definitely has my sympathy. It was no fun.', 'They are two different viruses. Hsv is not the same as the varicella or "zoster" virus of chicken pox and then shingles. Similar class but very different in treatment and dx', 'Shingle is caused by a different virus, Herpes zoster not Herpes simplex. Somewhat related but significantly difference. ID doc', "Shingles is caused by the Herpes Zoster Virus (HZV) and this young girl's symptoms were caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). They are part of the same family of viruses, and can cause similar symptoms in the eye that may recur. When HZV affects the nerve innervating the eye, this is Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO). Receiving a vaccine for shingles or the chicken pox would not vaccinate against the simplex virus. HSV can cause cold sores, skin blisters, and genital lesions depending on which type someone acquires. Typically, recurrences are caused by stress, sickness, or sun (UV light).", 'After 50 years of suffering herpes blisters on my lips and nose I am almost free of occurrences after realising that it was exposure to the sun. Now I wear tinted sun screen and am very happy with the results.', "Someone who touched my oldest daughter in the first few days after her birth passed on the virus and it went into her eye. My daughter ended up being flown to a hospital in the main city of our state as the infection became dangerously inflamed. It flares up behind her cornea each time. She has had recurring problems throughout her life. She's legally blind now and will never drive a car. Doctors say a corneal graft might be of help eventually but it won't cure the virus.", "How does a parent kiss a child when that parent has a cold sore?  My mother never kissed us when she had a cold sore.  I'm sorry but this parent needs to be educated on communicable diseases.", "The article is missing important information.  It doesn't say that the kiss occurred when the cold sore was visible.  You thus can't be that the mother was careless.  What the article should mention is how early on a sore can be contagious.  Wouldn't you think that the most likely thing was that the kiss came a little before the mother noticed the sore.", 'You are actually most infectious right before the cold sore becomes visible. The mother kissed her daughter right before the cold sore appeared. There is no warning, such as itching, to let you know that you are shedding virus.', 'You can shed Herpes simplex without a visible "cold sore" around the mouth or other sites of infection such as genital or even skin (whitlow). ID doc', 'I myself had herpes in the eye about 10 years ago (age 51). I had the same medications.  There was damage to the eye but not that bad.  I have never had a re occurrence.', 'Two or three paragraphs into the article,  I thought "herpes."  I had herpes in my eye in my early thirties.  I had a period where I was getting it in my throat as well.  I believe stress may have played a role.  My doctor finally gave me a series of gamma globulin shots.  Almost 40 years later, there have been no recurrences other than a small fever blister on my lower lip, generally always in the same place, perhaps every couple of years.', 'So, this type of essay replaces the Think Like A Doctor challenge? Sad!', 'Very interesting!  Thank you.', 'Fortunately the pediatrician went along with the mother\'s decision to test the daughter but the amount of information the mother had to have and the persistence she needed to get the right diagnosis is disturbing.  She had to be the doctor in this case.  This happens all too often and children without the benefit of an aunt in medical school or an informed parents are at risk.  Doctors too often write off the parent\'s report of an unusual behavior that would signal it\'s not something "trivial".  The little girl could not tell you how her eyes were feeling.  It was up to the pediatrician who failed abysmally in this case.', "Interesting piece.  Children are always being kissed on their faces.  In addition they're not always good hand washers. Bravo to Bard & Mom for their persistence & advocating for the little girl. Technology is not a panacea but when embraced & not belittled, it can be a miraculous resource. Thank you for sharing the story & giving readers an additional tool.", 'I am missing Think Like A Doctor...', 'It sounds like an infomercial for VisualDX.   I know some hypochondriacs who would love that kind of software.', "It's interesting the pediatrician told the mother (and aunt Bard) that there was no herpes infection in the little girl's eye. The pediatrician's assessment turned out incorrect -- and could have caused a more severe infection had it not been for the mother insisting on a test. Even doctors make mistakes. This is a fact. We as consumers of healthcare must sometimes push our caregivers to do things even when they say it's unnecessary. Sometimes they are wrong. However, we must be aware not to over-rule them too much. After all, they are experts - and right most of the time.", 'I think you mean to say that the error rate with VisualDx was 1/4 of the error rate without the software.', 'Check the math in the next-to-last paragraph. If admitting physicians not using the software made errors 28% of the time (72% accuracy) and VisualDx users were 4x more accurate, then VisualDx users would have an accuracy of 288% - far greater than 100%.', 'As noted in the article those having been infected by the herpes I virus are more likely to experience recurrences. More common is herpes labialis (lips).  If present on lips or lids in children it is important to emphasize that they not touch the vesicles so as to avoid the fingers opening these "blisters" and spreading the virus to the cornea. Adults too,of course. A simple way to kill the virus on the lip is to apply a styptic pencil to the blisters. Styptic must NOT be used on the lids or anywhere near the eye ! If herpes anywhere near eyes best to see an ophthalmologist before doing any thing.']
summary: Many commentators congratulate the mother on her persistence and criticize the doctor for the misdiagnosis. Several commentators comment on the herpes virus and the problems it can cause, including one person being legally blind from it. A few commentators speak about VisualDX, with one calling the article an infomercial. Two commentators want the "Think Like A Doctor" challenge back. One commentator thinks that the mother was careless to kiss an infected eye.
short_title: Headline: Why Was This 3-Year-Old So Irritable, and What Was Wrong With Her Eye?   Keywords: Eyes and Eyesight; Herpes Viruses; Medicine and Health   Snippet: A mother’s good-night kiss has unexpected consequences.
short_question: ['Why Was This 3-Year-Old So Irritable, and What Was Wrong With Her Eye?  ']

query: These books don’t tell you that everything is going to be O.K. but rather that nothing was ever really O.K. to begin with.
comments: ['Why does the picture accompanying an article about presidential biographies include a book on Benjamin Franklin?', 'so far tump, in this race to the bottom, is behind the even the congress itself, which boasts a number of convicted felons in its recent past and shady characters under every rock as we speak... perhaps also worth a try might be a feature piece. biographical sketches, on the blowhards who threw away their chance to become president, (whew). mccain has to have the first chair, he. the scold critical of all judgements not his own, demonstrated his own fatally flawed acuity when he chose sarah palin and trashed what would have surely been a two-term presidency, (mccain\'s luck being advancement without merit - as a student, a pilot and a naval officer - look it up - behind a bulwark of privilege), then romney who could not keep his pencey prep phoney in check until school was over, (the 40% diss did it) and hillary who would be president today if, instead of consigning us to baskets and instead of using people, black moms, the khans, as props, gave one of the them an open mike, as trump did with "his guy"....good thing none of this lot got the electoral stamp.', 'I made two resolutions this year. One, read some of the classic fiction I avoided as a young woman, and two, start reading biographies of U.S. presidents.  Well, I have finally read "Uncle Tom\'s Cabin" and I read Jon Meacham\'s "American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House".  I was delighted to see this piece in the Times, and it has strengthened my quest to become more knowledgeable about the men who have previously held the highest office in the land.', 'For any interested in reading presidential biographies, there is a fine site dedicated to identifying and reviewing presidential biographies.  For me it has been enormously valuable.   https://bestpresidentialbios.com/', "I've heard many from opposite sides of the spectrum want to crown either George W Bush or Obama as the worst president ever but they all lack historical perspective in making that judgment. Millard Fillmore, Franklin Pierce, and James Buchanan all helped the nation slide into Civil War. Andrew Johnson behaved in some very erratic ways in the post civil war era (first out for blood with the defeated Confederacy then pardoning almost all of them). Then there is Warren Harding. Woodrow Wilson post stroke was not really in charge at all. Even Presidents we regard as great have tainted histories, Lincoln presided over the largest mass execution in the history of the Federal government (Sioux Indians, though more would have been executed except he pardoned a number. of them). Jefferson tried total trade stoppage as a way to keep American vessels from having sailor's seized for service and the helmboat were trying an attack on Vicksburg?", "Exactly! While working early voting for a Congressional candidate here in NC, more than once I remarked to folks that the only thing keeping me sane was that I read a lot of history. Sure, things are crazy right now; but, when haven't they been? It doesn't resolve my angst, but it helps.", "Being depressed by our current president, I began reading Doris Kerns Goodwin, The Bloody Pulpit about TR and it worked.  As bad as the current holder of the office is, TR is great.   I would also strongly suggest Ron Chernow's Grant as he is IMHO our least understood president and was one of our best.  Chernow does a great service for all of us with this book. Although he wasn't a president, my favorite founding father was Alexander Hamilton and Ron Chernow's book is a real winner IMHO.  An ancestor of mine fought under Hamilton's command at Yorktown as a private in the VA Militia as one of the 400 men who helped Hamilton capture British Redoubt #10 while Marquis De Lafayette attacked and finally took #9 with help from Hamilton and my ancestor.   Comparing our founding fathers to the current inhabitants of the WH is useful. We will all survive these people and hopefully learn and never ever make this mistake again.", "OK. I will stop reading the news until there's a new President.", 'I just started a similar project, to read a biography of every single president, from 1 to 45. At first, it didn\'t have any thing to do with our current POTUS, but with Trump\'s election it\'s given the project a whole new meaning. The project reminds us that the American political system is a dialectic of sorts; to paraphrase what President Obama told his staff after Trump\'s election, the tide comes in, and the tide goes out. Just as Trump is supposedly the "answer" to Obama, the same can be said about many many presidents before. Reading a biography of all the presidents gives me great hope and calm that we\'ve faced many great tribulations before and that we can unequivocally weather this storm.', "Why oh why is the Benjamin Franklin book in the picture? At least tweak the caption so those books aren't described as all being presidential biographies?", 'Presidential biographies are my favorite way to read about U.S. history.  If more Americans read them, I doubt Trump would be president.', 'Thanks for the column. I have been doing the same thing but have addd Revolutionay War and Civil War histories. Humanity struggled through those and we entered and defended what continues to be a great experiment in democracy. We are a resilient people and our government was designed to be balanced and durable.', "Yes, this has been exactly my experience! Thank you for this! I have found that I can only read history now - novels seem trivial and uninteresting. During the late stages of the campaign I very much enjoyed The Year of Lear in which we learn about the many terrible things going on early in the reign of James I (plague, the Guy Fawkes plot to blow up everyone) and then I moved on to Chernow's Hamilton. I'm onto John Adams now and plan to look at things from Jefferson's point of view next. I had no idea about the constant fears about civil war and the incredibly high level of personal animosity and mistrust among the founders. It is a very small comfort, but a comfort nonetheless. Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose.", 'Robert A. Caro\'s trilogy on Lyndon Johnson (Master of the Senate, The Path to Power, and Means of Ascent) are unparalleled. Beyond presidents, I would have to add Eleanor Roosevelt\'s autobiography. I am currently reading Allida M. Black\'s "Casting Her Own Shadow: Eleanor Roosevelt and the Shaping of Postwar Liberalism". I am in the middle of the chapter on how Eleanor championed Civil Rights. Her energy, commitment, use of media (she wrote her "My Day" newspaper column long before blogs), and amazing skill as a politician made her a true force of nature. Her opponents prayed that she would "get tired." She didn\'t.', "How true.  I just finished Team of  Rivals, and immersing myself in Lincoln's enduring kindness and wisdom stoked just the sort of escapism I yearn for these days.  But the obvious foiling carries some bitterness too - even if no presidency is without blunder, especially when viewed by contemporaries, and even if Lincoln is an unfair standard for any mere mortal, it's hard not to plainly see the vital necessity of having a grown adult of some elemental decency and integrity in command, and the disasters that could easily ensue without it.", 'Perhaps fill one shelf with Presidential biographies, but, to ward off the seductions of exceptionalism and survivorship bias, fill another shelf with histories of failed states and autocratic populists who destroyed their countries.', "I too often turn to presidential biographies in times of national - and personal - distress. I've spent much of the last few months dwelling on Chester Alan Arthur.  In my most optimistic moments, I wonder if we will one day look upon Trump as the contemporaries of President Arthur saw him: as a kind and upstanding man who rose to a station he never sought out, even to the point of hiding his fatal illness. Of course, Trump was not so disinterested. But few could have guessed that a man who embodied corruption and spoils would have helped usher in its end - at great personal expense. Perhaps President Arthur would have lodged the same defense of his corrupt behavior as Trump did. In this sense, Chester Alan Arthur represents the highest myth of the American presidency: that the job will dignify even the undeserving. But...any biography (all two or three of them) of President Arthur emphasizes his strict upbringing and the moral responsibility his abolitionist father instilled in him; his extraordinary work ethic (even at expense of his marital relations); and, most importantly, his congeniality of character, the very quality that separated him from the more prominent blowhards of the era.  When I think of that, my optimism drains. And what dawns on me is not a sense of ease with the shambles of history...but deeper disillusionment.", "Well, maybe I just picked the wrong one then. I've been reading The Bully Pulpit about Taft and Roosevelt. Great men and great visionaries. Puts me in an awfully depressed mood when I think about our current situation. I was watching some stupid President's Day commercial the other day when the realization that this reality TV star clown now joins the ranks of Washington, Lincoln, Jefferson, Roosevelt really hit me. Sheesh. But I get your point.", "Best feel-good presidential bio ever: McCullough's Truman.", "I've just been making my way through several biographies by Edmund Morris. I could not agree more with your advice. Though many of the events of this last election are highly unprecedented, it is important to remember that it is not the first time something so unprecedented has happened.", "Currently, I'm reading Avlon's book on Washington's Farewell Address. While Washington's writings will never compare to those of Jefferson, Franklin, Madison, Hamilton or Paine, the advice and observations in his address are very resonant today. It's unfortunate that we've forgotten the 4,000 words he wrote. His address was adopted by Jefferson and quoted by Lincoln in defense of the Union.  Read it. You will have new appreciation of and gratitude for the man that almost single handedly made sure that fledgling democratic republic still exists 240 years later.  Now, if only Caro would finish the 4th and final installment in his biography on LBJ....", "Words of wisdom. let's not forget: twelve presidents owned slaves (eight while president), a sitting Vice President shot and killed our first Treasury Secretary, Johnson bungled the Restoration, Nixon bugged the Democrats and, Clinton had sex with a young intern and then lied about it.  Indeed, presidents are people to.", "I'm looking at the photograph of the presidential biographies and wondering why Benjamin Franklin's is included.", 'Would love to have your list of titles published here.  Had the same urge; just finished Sean Wilentz on Andrew Jackson, Gordon-Reed on Andrew Johnson, and have moved on to Bunting on Grant, intending to work my way through the Progressive era into the Depression, trying to explain to myself why the Republicans want to undo so much legislation meant to help others, championing an outmoded individualism in a 7 billion person world where we either help each other or the slaughters of the 20th Century could easily become comparatively insignificant digits.', 'One of the presidential biographies pictured is about Benjamin Franklin, who, while certainly a founding father, was never president.', "Trump's election left me feeling adrift, unhinged.  Like 911.  I was annoying my friends, ranting and frightened. I desperately needed perspective.  I wondered if Trump and the Mercer Bannon Brietbart gang were the worst.  I hit on the idea that reading biographies of all the presidents might give me perspective.  I have so far read Washington, Adams, and Jefferson.  It has helped enormously.  I just started Madison.  This column made me want to jump ahead to Arthur but I am resisting.  I recommend reading presidential biographies to all as a way of staying sane in the presence of a seemingly insane presidency.", "I, too, am a huge fan of political history and biography---and for the same reason. History offers us a much needed sense of perspective and a way to honestly gauge the state of the world in which we live. Chester A. Arthur was a pitiable excuse for a leader, but spending time with James Garfield, a noble and good man if there ever was one, made him want to be a better person. And to his credit, that's exactly what he did. None of us is wholly good or wholly evil; neither is any time in our nation's history. Being able to discern that and see it for what it is is absolutely essential, and it always has been.", 'Another Presidential podcast talked about Julia Sand, who wrote Chester A. Arthur hundreds of letters during his presidency, urging him to be a better man than everyone expected him to be. After the election, I kept thinking of this quote from one of her letters: "Great emergencies awaken generous traits which have lain dormant half a life. If there is a spark of true nobility in you, now is the occasion to let it shine...Do what is more difficult & brave. Reform! It is not proof of highest goodness never to have done wrong, but it is proof of it, sometimes in ones career, to pause & ponder, to recognize the evil, to turn resolutely against it...Once in awhile there comes a crisis which renders miracles feasible. The great tidal wave of sorrow which has rolled over the country has swept you loose from your old moorings & set you on a mountaintop, alone.”']
summary: Several of the commenters also express the benefits of reading presidential biographies because of the helpful and informative perspective they give to current political events.  One commenter suggests broadening the scope to include biographies of others, including presidents' wives. Another suggests that reading presidential biographies could actually be depressing because of their tarnished characters.
short_title: Headline: Presidential Biographies   Keywords: Presidents and Presidency (US); Books and Literature; Trump, Donald J; Arthur, Chester Alan; Bush, George; Garfield, James A   Snippet: These books don’t tell you that everything is going to be O.K. but rather that nothing was ever really O.K. to begin with.
subreddit: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Books and Literature', 'Trump, Donald J', 'Arthur, Chester Alan', 'Bush, George', 'Garfield, James A']
short_question: ['Presidential Biographies  ']

query: A new book documents the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II through images by Dorothea Lange and others, including Hikaru Iwasaki, who had been sent to a camp.
comments: ['Ansel Adams was one of the photographers at Manzanar -- ironically one of his most famous Sierra scenes -- Winter Sunrise -- was taken of the Sierra Crest on a morning off from his main duties.  Running Dog Press published those several years ago -- a huge fight with the "guardians" of the Ansel Adams Trust years after his death, because Adams\' pictures were given to the Library of Congress and hence in the public domain. There were more "modest\' internments of Italian Americans on the West Coast, documented in the museum at Fort Mason in San Francisco.', '"We learn from history that we do not learn from history." -- George Wilhelm Hegel "The only thing we learn from history is that we do not learn." -- Earl Warren', "My Grandfather, a German-American  immigrant and restaurant owner, was consistently harrassed by Federal agents during WWII primarily because the restaurant was a local gathering site for Germans and other European-ancestory Americans  There were no concentration camps for Germans or Italians during WWII, but that is likely because identifying them on the West Coast was more difficult, not because action wasn't taken against them.  The stress eventually lead to my Grandfather's death.", 'Great images...Not surprising though...DId not see  any "internment camps" for Italians or Germans ....I wonder why...These were U.S. cItizens of Japanese descent...it can happen here again if we are not vigilant...', 'This isn\'t even America\'s worst wartime atrocity perpetrated on immigrants.   During the US Civil War scores and scores of "rioters" were gunned down in the streets of NYC during the so-called Draft Riots.  These were by far most of the riot dead and many of the "dangerous rebels" were women and children.  150 years later no one will talk about it.']
summary: Two of the commenters talk about how there were Japanese internment camps but not ones for Italians or Japanese (also the "enemies" in World War 2), with one attributing it to racism and the other saying there may not have been internment camps, but they were still discriminated against. Other things the commenters focus on are other wartime atrocities against immigrants in the US, the photos themselves, and quotes from historical leaders about history repeating itself.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Japanese-Americans; Heart Mountain Relocation Center; California; Lange, Dorothea   Snippet: A new book documents the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II through images by Dorothea Lange and others, including Hikaru Iwasaki, who had been sent to a camp.

query: Snippets of conversation at a grocery store.
comments: ['"All the news that\'s fit to print"?  Spare us this drivel.  Don\'t contribute to the dumbing down of journalism.', "Why is the NY Times so obsessed with the Park Slope Food Coop?  Aren't Whole Foods (whole paycheck) and Zabars better topics for ridicule? The PSFC was created 43 years ago by ordinary people on the site where it still exists. It has grown from a few dozen to many thousands of members based on the economic  and cultural values it offers. It is the largest and most successful nonprofit food coop in the country, by far. Meanwhile the Times is drowning in obsolescent irrelevance, shrinking every year. Mock yourselves, why don't you?", 'i love shopping at the psfc..often making me smile at paged slope-isms - definitely needed now-a-days.  Aisles are narrow & crowded, shoppers, people stocking shelves but overhearing (kiddie) conversations often is priceless.  Like no other place! We usually have a few delicious hot chocolate mixes + equal exchange...bottom shelf under teas closest to back refrigerated sections.', 'the park slope co-op is the most obnoxious place on earth', 'Oh the Humanity!', 'As a founding member who moved west in 1990, I think back to the days when all there was available were the produce items we picked up at the Hunts Point market very, very early on a Thursday morning. Amazing that the Coop is now in its fifth decade. The folks who founded it would have never eaten caviar of any kind, but that was in the earliest days of gentrification of the Slope. Fond memories!', "The land under the co-op is worth millions. Why haven't they sold the building and moved someplace else with more space?", 'Convenience trumps greed?', 'Even the masses love co-ops?', '(In which person who makes mistake owns it and rectifies it, at his own time and expense, rather than the community doing it for him.)', 'I am so amused, but wish Freddie were around to put the scene to music.  How about "Yes, we have no bananas"?', 'and we wonder why Donald Trump was elected President! if one wants to get him re-elected (God forbid) just make a video of these Park Slope co-op types discussing each other\'s "badness " in Ohio and Michigan etc... and he will be a mortal lock.', 'What! No hot chocolate mix. This would never be allowed to occur in my adopted home of Switzerland. No Swiss food co-op is complete with hot chocolate mix!!!', 'Yep, that is just how cooperation works.  More folks should try it. "We all own it!"', "That may be true. Still, friends, I think I'll order room service", 'I loved it! Some of my best NYC stories have been from the corner market. One cold night in February, I landed inside of the Food Pantry, coughing like a sick kid. A stranger climbed a rickety ladder to retrieve a lone bottle of cough syrup from the top shelf. I ripped off the top, then guzzled it down. I went to say thanks, but the gentleman had already gone. When I got to the register, I found that he had also paid for it. You don’t find that in L.A. !']
summary: Several commenters find the article's snippets of conversation from a grocery store as amusing, while others think this dumbs down journalism and that there are better topics to cover. Other commenters discuss the Park Slope Food Co-op, including the expensive land it sits on and the layout of the store itself. A couple of commenters reminisce about buying produce in the 1990s.
short_title: Headline: Overheard at the Park Slope Food Co-op   Keywords: Shopping and Retail; Park Slope (Brooklyn, NY); Park Slope Food Co-Op   Snippet: Snippets of conversation at a grocery store.
subreddit: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Park Slope (Brooklyn, NY)', 'Park Slope Food Co-Op   Snippet:']
short_question: ['Overheard at the Park Slope Food Co-op  ']

query: Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole find the human factor in a repetitive musical about battling cosmetics magnates.
comments: ["I just saw War Paint with the two Patti's, Ms. LuPone and Ms. Cohenour. They make a wonderful duo both visually and verbally.  Ms. LuPone is her fabulous self, bold and brash, with a terrifically vivid presence on stage. She portrays her larger than life character as both someone worthy of revulsion as well as sympathy and understanding.  Ms. Cohenour plays her counterpart beautifully with style, grace and elegance. These completely different foes meet in battle where their weapons are toxic cosmetics and phony sales pitches. Sadly, their love of the all mighty dollar deprives them of family and happiness. The songs are clever and the women's costumes are over the top fabulous. What a good looking show! In addition, the book provides some interesting insight into how cosmetics became such a pervasive presence in our culture. I definitely recommend you see this show.", 'The Carol Burnett Show kept coming to mind as I watched the stars trying to take their roles seriously in this silly show. If Patti could have said just once of one of her costumes : Oh. Its just something  I saw in the window " we could all have had some fun. For now we\'ll have to wait for the boys at Fire Island Pines to do their revival of War Paint.', "Grey Gardens was one of my favorite musicals and so I expected some gorgeous melodies sung by two of the greatest Broadway stars. Instead I suffered thru a boring non story, ugly sets and awful repetitive music with no melodies. Patti Lupone had an unnecessarily heavy accent and was nearly unintelligible throughout causing me to miss nearly all her jokes . I was in the third row and about ten of us who didn't know each other at the start became fast friends lamenting the wasted talent.", "'lucky to get a ticket for opening night - & HRC was there - how apropos.The Nederlander has one of the best seats in Broadway so even top mezzanine seats has full view of the stage. Love these two women & have seen them both in other shows. This was a good pairing. I don't know much about Helena & Elizabeth but Ms. Lupone & Ms. Ebersole played them so well I believed the storyline to be true. I plan to see the show again, this time with my daughter.", 'I went last weekend.I loved every moment, as did the audience!! The opportunity to see 2 legends at the top of their game makes it worth getting a ticket any way you can.Wnen Ebersole sang "Pink", women around me were crying.', 'I have to say that I found the lack of growth in the two characters detracted hugely from the enjoyment for me. The staging was lovely, the singing great, but the story? Banal.', "Saw the show at the Goodman in Chicago. A bit tedious. Ms Ebersole's songs completely understandable. Ms LuPone too heavy on the Eastern European accent. I grew up listening to my Bubby and could not understand the words. Show is good but not socko. Knowing NY prices can't recommend you drop all that money despite the privilege of seeing  two fabulous actressed", "Seeing it next weekend. I'm happily spending New York prices to see two Broadway legends.", 'How about a Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons musical for the next Ebersole-Lupone pairing!']
summary: The current incarnation of War Paint stars two legends of Broadway, Patti LuPone, and Christine Ebersole as cosmetics legends Rubinstein and Arden. They are both worth the cost of the pricey admission, and their performances are great. The show is pretty to look at but boring, and the songs are uninspired if you can even understand the words that LuPone is mumbling, with a thick Polish accent.
short_title: Headline: Sing a Song  of Face Creams   Keywords: Theater; War Paint (Play); Ebersole, Christine; LuPone, Patti; Greif, Michael; Arden, Elizabeth; Rubinstein, Helena   Snippet: Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole find the human factor in a repetitive musical about battling cosmetics magnates.
subreddit: ['Theater', 'War Paint (Play)', 'Ebersole, Christine', 'LuPone, Patti', 'Greif, Michael', 'Arden, Elizabeth', 'Rubinstein, Helena']
short_question: ['Sing a Song  of Face Creams  ']

query: John Parker, a former slave, was a daring conductor on the Underground Railroad. His home in Ripley, Ohio, helps to tell his story.
comments: ['While I recognize that ignorance still rears its ugly head in Ohio (evidenced by the Confederate flag), I will still stand as a proud Ohioan for the sacrifices men and women made as the center of the Underground Railroad and as a state that committed sixty percent of all the men between the ages of 18 and 45 (320,000 men) to a Civil War that was needed to eradicate the vile practice of slavery.', 'New Richmond, OH is also on the river along route 52 and also has an Underground Railroad historical site.', "Here's an account by a slave who sheltered with cousins of his former slave owner in Ohio after he escaped across the Ohio River from Kentucky.  Not all of the Claypools were going to hell.  Fred Douglass published his account, that hot ticket Trump's been gushing about. http://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/jacksona/jacksona.html", 'My family is from the northern KY/Cincinnati area.  I lived there for a while but grew up in different states, too.  I love the National Underground Railroad Freedom Museum.  I always go there when I visit, and I am a member.  The slave holding pen that was discovered in KY and dismantled and rebuilt for permanent exhibition is intensely disturbing.  The current exhibitions depicting discrimination and slavery of all kinds are profound.  And when I see the "eternal" flame on the museum deck from the KY side, I am in awe of the significance of the Ohio River.  Everyone should go to this museum. Re- the Confederate flag.  When I lived in Jacksonville, FL in the 1970\'s, it seemed that white redneck Lynard Skynard devotees had these in their trucks.  There was often little thought or regard to racist implications.  However, when I have seen that flag in New England over the years (and it is not common here), there is little doubt about intention.  It has been too often used as a symbol of hate to mean anything else.  And I have seen many of them flying in Ohio when I drive to see family.  Hate, ignorance and bigotry in the contemporary USA is everywhere---in some places more than others. Thank you for Parker\'s story.  It\'s so very important.', 'I have most certainly seen Confederate flags in Geauga County, well north of the Ohio river.', 'Very informative and inspiring. Fulton County, NW Ohio where I grew up also had a number of UGR places. One very minor correction . Poplar is a soft wood, so should have read "wood floors" "The hardwood floors, in poplar, are from the original construction."', "The reporter must have grown up on US Highway 68. There hasn't been a state route 68 in Ohio since 1933.", 'I know of what you speak concerning the Confederate flag. In these parts the flag is closely associated with poor whites who most probably migrated from Kentucky and Appalachian areas. I would view these types as probably poorly educated and very clannish (preferring to stick closely to their families and other kni). I am not sure you would call them racists as they have much in common and suffer economically like poorer blacks (and today you would see more black and white couples or babies from these mixed race relationships [marriage usually reserved to those with better economic prospects and educations] in these areas)  I would interpret the Confederate flags you may see as their identity (pride) with the lost cause of the Old South and all those who they would see as having died valiantly in the face of great odds. I would not see it in these parts as the racist statement liberals would like to arrogantly assume goes hand in hand with such flag.', 'At best I - as someone who grew up in southern Ohio - would allow you with regards to those living there and displaying the Stars and Bars is that they are confused, not that they are rooting for underdogs.  My experience is that in any other realm they seldom do.', 'Southern Ohio has a border state history.  Parts of Ohio can be very Southern in attitude and mores.', "My mother grew up in this spectacularly beautiful little town, and both of my parents are buried here.  Mom was always very proud of Ripley's role in the Underground Railroad.  Well worth a visit.", 'Ripley, Utopia, and Cincinnati are not the only places in this corridor to learn about the legacy of the UGRR in our region. The Ohio River National Freedom Corridor ( http://www.ohiorivernationalfreedomcorridor.org/)  is an organization which works to promote the sharing of all of the stories which exist in this "freedom corridor." UGRR activity took place all along the Ohio River. While Ripley\'s stories, and the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center share some of the most well known stories, if one digs deeper, there are many more stories to learn. Anyone interested in learning more can get in contact with the Ohio River National Freedom Corridor, or come participate in our annual conferences. We welcome all those interested to participate with us in preserving and sharing the legacy of the UGRR in our local modern communities.', "I'm  kind of shocked that your otherwise nice article did not include mention of Ann Hagadorn 's classic book,  Across the River, about John Rankin and the Underground RR in Ripley. The Rankin House is expanding and will offer much expanded programs.  Also I believe the cabin and slave pen at the Cincinnati Freedom Center are the real things, not reproductions.  Along with the Parker", "Agreed, Mark.  Hagedorn's book is terrific!", 'Ditto! Across the River is a gripping history of Ripley and its role in the UGRR. Hagedorn is an excellent writer.', 'Someone please tell me the difference between the Confederate flag and the Nazi flag?', 'It was the Elizas and the John Parkers who helped rescue our country from the sin and infamy of our baser elements. Their courage stands out against the cowardice of the thieves who believed they had a right to claim ownership over other people.', "Too bad you didn't take time to really learn the area history.  Wilmington, OH, to the north was a Quaker town.  Its Quaker college houses a remarkable archives.  You missed several tunnels running from the river to homes and Gallipolis. KenOVa, where KY, OH, and WV meet is an area where, perhaps, the most families were divided.   After the Revolution, many families moved from Southwestern VA north into what became WV, and KY, due to cheap land.  Wayne County, just below Huntington, raised over 1000 men for the Confederacy, many of whom did not own slaves.  The naming of children shows they still retained close ties to SW VA.   Fighting at Gettysburg, the men were sent to Fort Delaware, an island, between NJ and DE, where approximately 2,500 men died, their bodies floated at high tide to NJ, and mass graves at what is now Finn's Point National Cemetery.   When people ask me if I am ashamed that my family, rebels (AKA patriots) in the Revolution owned slaves, I say no.  It was a time of different social values, and legal.  Am I to be ashamed they owned slaves, but proud they were rebels?  My father was a German POW.  Does that time make up for slave owner ancestors?  I consider slavery horrific, but I have been educated with different views, standards, and laws.   I also resent shame articles. which are how history is changed and forgotten.  We can't have conversations about change.  We can't understand where we are if we can't talk about how we got here.", 'Ridley is an inspiring place.  I urge all who can to visit it and see the Parker and Rankin houses.', 'Martins Ferry Ohio was the first settlement in the state of Ohio. Marietta was the first permanent settlement.', 'Ms. Drake, As an Ohioan, I apologize for the silly display of that awful red rag, the symbol of slavery.  Time to put it away, children.', 'The the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center in nearby Cincinnati shows a dramatic film of the John Parker/John Rankin story, narrated by Oprah Winfrey, and filmed in Ripley. The entire Freedom Center is well worth a visit; it places the narrative of the fleeing slaves against the backdrop of the competing voices around how to abolish the "peculiar institution."', 'Enjoyable reading and interesting article. And regrettably, today there are more than a few of those flags flying in my state, not far from Ripley is the Ohio birthplace of Ulysses S. Grant. And further north is Lancaster, Ohio, home of William Tecumseh Sherman. Were either General Grant or Sherman alive, their reaction to seeing that flag flying on their home state soil would be unbridled fury.', 'There are cautionary tales and inspirational tales and of course this one is inspirational; maybe even topical and timely. Are we re-envisioning an America that is poised to hide "run-away" immigrants, undocumented workers and families who do not want to leave the USA? Will it be a railroad that reverses their migration, and perhaps gives the Illegals a safer and more dignified passage back to Mexico or Central America? A plane ticket? A stipend? The Underground Railroad was all about Americans getting on the right side of history. We have had other moments join in, in recent history some that put the participants at risk; the Civil Rights marches, the protests against the Vietnam War and the Second Invasion of Iraq. I was too young for the first one, but after careful reflection, joined the second.  A local building supply company in a more conservative suburb of liberal Portland used their big advertising billboard to make this state: Forget the Wall Build a Deck And invite everyone over.  By protesting now, we are taking little real risks. Those may come later. It is good to read how some of our ancestors made their stands and did the right thing. This country has a history of its citizens getting on the right side of history. I have a feeling, that opportunity is rapidly approaching again. When the next generation looks back, be sure they find you standing on the right side of history!', "Slavery, the forceful subjugation of black folks, a lame excuse to exploit their bodies based on the color of one's skin, must be shown permanently as an opprobrium of those 'evil' souls, inventors of deadly discrimination, an awful blot to the human race, And the depiction of the underground railroad is but one of the sad chapters of our torturous  mind.", 'The story of Ripley, Ohio\'s history as a hub of the Underground Railroad is told very well in Ann Hagedorn\'s book "Beyond the River", for readers who want to know more. My forebears were members of a Philadelphia church that was a stop on the Underground Railroad, though I don\'t know if they were involved. The stories of these abolitionists, black and white, are inspiring and should not be forgotten.', "Dean do you know of other books that chronicle it?  I'd love to read more. Where I grew up in Maryland there was a single span bridge at Cabin John, rumored to be a 'station' - we all grew up with the passed on story.  It haunts me.", "I am deeply pleased to see the article on John Parker's role in the period of the Underground Railroad. He is truly a hero. Two of my ancestors, John Sutton Beasley and Alfred Beasley, worked with Parker and with John Rankin. My family was divided: some who stayed in Kentucky owned slaves, while those who crossed over to Ohio worked to help slaves escape and to end the institution of slavery. The Ohio River at Ripley is narrow, but it was a wide divide between cultures and economies. Thank you, Monica Drake, for the article.", 'Beautiful article about my newly adopted home state.', 'Dear Monica, I thoroughly enjoyed reading your article on Ripley, Ohio. To give even more exciting context to the story you should take a look at the book "Beyond The River" (Simon and Schuster), an award winning book about Ripley, John Rankin and John Parker that is the basis for the in-process film treatment called "The War Before The War". Ripley is a marvelous little town with a great history and bravo for you for drawing national attention to its greatest.']
summary: One commenter says that the history of abolitionists should not be overlooked and recommends reading a book for anyone interested in knowing more about Ohio's history. Some comments praise Ridley as a wonderful and inspiring city. Another commenter says that slavery is a terrible stain for the human race. Other comments talk about the Confederate flag and the meaning of its symbols.
short_title: Headline: The World of an Antislavery Warrior   Keywords: Slavery (Historical); Underground Railroad (19th Century); Blacks; Travel and Vacations; National Underground Railroad Freedom Center; Stowe, Harriet Beecher; Ohio; Ohio River; Cincinnati (Ohio); Uncle Tom's Cabin (Book)   Snippet: John Parker, a former slave, was a daring conductor on the Underground Railroad. His home in Ripley, Ohio, helps to tell his story.

short_question: ['The World of an Antislavery Warrior  ']

query: Humming during a checkup, and getting an unlikely accompaniment.
comments: ["The flip side of that ... at my dentist the hygienists can control the music in their rooms. They don't ask for my input. I had one who hummed along to country music and would burst into snatches of song in random places. It was so irritating. I wish I were more assertive and asked her to cut it out, but I figured, oh well, it's not for that long ...", "I prefer not to hear the incessant chatter of a dentist while I'm a captive audience who can't even say a word without drooling. Please work on my teeth. I don't need to hear about your week-end non-stop or your chit chat with your assistant.", "Floss every day and use fluoride mouthwash and the hygienist won't have to be that aggressive, and there won't be any discomfort when you're in the chair.  Took me a long, long time to learn that.", 'Were you humming Dyanu, perhaps--if you took so much plaque, that would be enough--Dyanu', 'Joan and Raquelle, what a great idea to use Dayenu. Wish I\'d thought of that. The possibilities boggle the mind almost as much as The Ten Plaques.   Tune of "Dayenu" If you do twice-daily brushing Daily brushing with no rushing With no rushing, do the brushing That\'s enough. (dayenu) Sing dayenu, sing dayenu Brush twice daily, dayenu, dayenu, Nu! If you cut out sweets and sugars Cut out sugars from your diet Change your diet, darling try it That\'s enough! (dayenu) Sing dayenu, dayenu, dayenu, Nu! (add more dental hygiene tips. And one for Molar, as the old song almost goes) And of course like the real Haggadah song, we really needed the whole list of things to be done, but are happy with what we get :)', 'Dayenu, I assume. (It would have been enough.... from the Haggadah)', 'I have always been a little phobic of the dentist.  Fortunately, over the years, I have had dentists that sang or did stand up while I was feeling my most panicky. My hygienist fills me in on what has been going on in her life since the last visit.', "That can be disconcerting. As I lay on a table in 2008 having stents inserted into my heart, the surgeon and the nurse were playing a game where one would hum a song and the other would guess the song's title. They were very animated at times, as he watched the screen and guided the stents into place. Only when I started humming the funeral dirge did they laugh and cease.", "Once upon a time, I would have scoffed at the idea that a clean and check up could be painful. Then my dentist got one of those ultra sonic tools (or whatever it's called) and at the next clean I almost shot through the roof from the shock of it all. Forget about humming - now I have to take a painkiller before my bi-annual check up! Sometimes advances in technology aren't necessarily improvements.", 'I certainly wish that any of the dentists or dental techs who have worked on my mouth in the past 2 years to clean up a mess left behind by C-Dif had hummed, sung or done something besides play the insipid "easy listening music" on their stereo while I sat through the work! At least when you get an MRI they give you a choice of music or none at all!', 'I once had an MRI where the technician asked if I wanted music. "Sure."  "what kind?"  "Classical."  So he puts on Ravel\'s Bolero.  As it got more and more intense, I almost went out of my mind.  I tried to yell to him, but no luck.  I will never ask for music again.', "An old secular favorite from Mouth Pacific.  Tune of Wash that Man Right Out of My Hair I'm gonna get that plaque right offa your teeth (3x) Then rinse the gunk away I'm gonna scrape that tartar offa your gums (3x) And send you on your way Don't chew hard candy now Cut down on sweets a bit Keep the floss handy now Here's a new dental kit In six months just come on back We'll miss you Go home and brush that food right offa your teeth (3x) And do it twice a day Good hygiene's gonna pay!", "Great!  Let's have more from you, Freddy!  You got style, pal.", 'Chad Gadya?', 'I guess dentistry is becoming a sort of strange multi-media event. A TV in the corner playing and old movie, folks singing in the chair. One of my recent dentists would sing along with the music videos playing on his office video system while he worked on my teeth. I just wish he had trained in singing as much as he had trained in dentistry.']
summary: Some commenters dislike when dentists sing, play music, and talk incessantly, especially when they play intense classical pieces like Ravel's Bolero or sing poorly. Others find singing comforting, such as the song Dayenu, and wished their dentists did it more. Many commenters agreed that hygienist appointments can be very painful, and some offered suggestions for fluoride mouthwash, flossing, and even painkillers.
short_title: Headline: Music in the Dentist’s Chair   Keywords: Teeth and Dentistry; New York City; Passover   Snippet: Humming during a checkup, and getting an unlikely accompaniment.
short_question: ['Music in the Dentist’s Chair  ']

query: A sea of books yields a link to a source of a woman’s lifelong love of reading.
comments: ['At a large library sale I bought a copy of "Uncommon Therapy," Jay Haley\'s biography of iconoclastic psychiatrist and hypnotherapist Milton Erickson, who in his youth had barely survived polio. When I got it home and opened it, there on the flyleaf, inscribed in shaky post-polio handwriting, was a name: Milton Erickson. It must have been his personal copy.', 'I bought a book at the book sale from the library at Amsterdam and 81st, meant to give it to my six year old granddaughter who enjoyed learning to  read on her own.  When I opened the book at home, an envelop with a birthday card fell out, with love and good wishes to a grandson from his grandmother, and a government bond without any names on it.  There was no full names inscribed  anywhere on the book, nor any dates.  The reason why  the book and card were probably never opened by the boy nor anyone else has haunted me.', 'A few years ago, I searched and searched for a copy of the first book I remember reading "by myself" at age five. What wondeful memories came rushing back the day that copy of "Lucy McLockett" arrived in the mail!', "I have enjoyed Metropolitan Diary for years. These little vignettes often remind me of my husband's Aunt Mat, and this one definitely did. Thank you so much for this lovely story.", 'I am not always a fan of Metropolitan Diary submissions (but always read them) but I absolutely loved this one!  Thank you.', "What a wonderful example of serendipity. I am also a book lover. I grew up in NYC in the 50s & 60s and remember w/ great fondness my trips to the library. My branch was on 67th street between 1st & 2nd Ave across from St Margaret's park. I remember the smell and the coolness of the building even in the summer. How happy I was when I could finally get books from the adult section - you had to be in the 8th grade as I remember. But there was still a restricted section for young adults where you had to get the librarian to agree that you could have the book. Love of reading & books is the best addiction for humans.", "I'm a little puzzled by the 8th grade restriction.  The branch on 100th street on the west side put no obstacles in my way, aged seven and eight.  I don't remember a childrens' section, but I doubt it would have interested me after the first grade.", "I know that sale! I still have books FROM that sale, and I haven't lived there in decades. I LOVED this story. Thank you for sharing it. I have an aunt who helped me love reading, and anther who helped me love theatre. Their passions live in me still, as does your aunt's, in you. Ain't life grand?", 'A signature as madeleine?   Thanks for sharing that lovely story.', 'I, too, have been a reader since I was young. We moved several times from when I was in 4th grade through high school so reading was a way to escape what was sometimes a difficult adjustment and became a different kind of escape as years have gone by. I love to read! A day without reading is like a day without sunshine to me.', 'What a wonderful story!    And a little gift from your aunt.    I loved books as a child too and also read whatever I could get my hands on and try to understand.', 'Although I realized where this memory was going to end, it still gave me chills.  I still have the first book I bought with my allowance -- an abridged version of Little Women -- when I was in the second grade.  Thousands of book purchases later, it is the centerpiece  of my library.', 'Thank you for letting us read about this. It lightened my morning in an unexpected way. I still believe that incribed books are among the best gifts one can receive.', 'Such a lovely remembrance. Thank you so much for sharing this!', 'I can just imagine how you felt hearing a voice from your past and knowing, too, that a rich tradition of reading & learning was being passed on to others, strangers of course, but in some ways not.', 'I have always had trouble with algebra. My Grandma Cooley, a well-respected English teacher at our small town high school, had had trouble with it, as well, but through hard work had finally mastered it. She would help me with my problems, scribbling on each page that I, myself, had then mastered with these words: “Keeping everlastingly at it brings success!” When I cleaned out my attic this April, I found that old algebra book. I opened the battered cover and there, on the first page, I read her words again. I’m still rotten at solving for “X,” but I’m better at it than I was in ninth grade. I’m still “keeping everlastingly at it” but now it’s my writing!']
summary: One commenter says that they attended the same sale that the author did. Many of the commenters express love for reading like the author. Some say that giving books to others is a wonderful idea, and one commenter expresses disdain they felt because of a used book they bought that had a personalized card that appeared unopened.
short_title: Headline: Finding a Familiar Signature   Keywords: Manhattan (NYC); Reading and Writing Skills (Education)   Snippet: A sea of books yields a link to a source of a woman’s lifelong love of reading.
short_question: ['Finding a Familiar Signature  ']

query: During an epidemic, self-delusion won’t reduce the viral load.
comments: ['The "shot" won\'t keep you from getting "it" but it will stop "it" from killing you.', "I loved this humorous peek into a very universal experience.  I love black eyed peas and collard greens by the way. I, too, had my annual flu shot, and now I'm just hoping and praying that dark angel passes by while I sleep.", 'The reason why Tamiflu is not given out indiscriminately is because influenza viruses can develop resistance to it. This occurs in an analogous method to the way that bacteria can become resistance to antibiotics.', 'I have seen many with flu this season. I still don’t understand the reluctance to use or prescribe Tamiflu. Flu vaccines make good sense but they simply don’t protect many folks for many reasons.', 'Tamiflu reduces the length of influenza symptoms by about 24 hours, and carries with it the a very significant risk of adding nausea and vomiting to the already miserable set of flu symptoms– a hefty price to pay if someone is not seriously ill. It is best reserved for those who are very ill with flu, such as those hospitalized or at risk of needing hospitalization.', "Much too much being made of this flu season, I have yet to know one person who has had, let's Move on....", "I have yet to meet one person who voted for Trump, and inexplicably he's the president.  So moving on is not always the solution!", "That's a clear example of an availability heuristic at work. You may not personally know anyone afflicted with the flu, so you may not think it's a serious issue. But the data shows that there is an alarming abundance of cases out there. This year's virus is going to kill quite a few people. That's really unfortunate. But the real problem is that we're not prepared for a truly deadly strain of influenza. In 1918 we had such a strain. It killed over 50 million worldwide, more than 3% of the population. Our modern world is denser and more interconnected. The death toll would be far worse.  We need to provide additional funding to flu research. Our goal should be to find a vaccine that's universally effective against all flu strains.", 'Actually, if you look at the CDC data (FluView), you will see this season is on par (or maybe a little bit worse) with the 2012-2013 and 2014-2015 seasons. It is not as bad as 2009, 2003-2004, or many others most of us have lived through. I am very curious why this season is getting so much media hype.', 'Just say NO:  stay at home, absolutely wallow in your misery, do not infect others.   TV and fluids are your friends. Others are optional.', "Thanks Margaret Renkl, now I feel like I've already had the flu in this season of suffering.", 'At first soupcon of a "feeling" in my throat (making me feel like  a hypochondriac), I run to the kitchen to squeeze fresh lemon that I pour into orange juice and a bit of black cherry juice. Sometimes I add good honey. Go bundle up and lie down. Often the sensation evaporates, only to show up later with a burning at the back of my pharynx. More of the lemon formula, perhaps in hot tea; and on and on. Preventive guaifenisin (Mucinex). If chills occur, I get out the Tamiflu. I like to think this works but have not done any control experiments, obviously. ALWAYS take my flu shot, with or without success.', 'Blame Thanksgiving &Christmas--our great petrie dishes of mobile & intermingled germs holidays!!!', "So well written! Even as I sit in bed taking some extra rest because I've had the flu/laryngitis/upper respiratory SOMETHING since December 10th, I really enjoyed reading about your misery in such an entertaining way.", "Hmm, I'm not sure I've ever had the flu. But when I turned 70, I started getting the shots. No black-eyed peas, though, since my mother-in-law died.  Thanks for the column, although it's almost too painful to read.", 'Thank you, Ms. Renkl, for giving me a bunch of worries about the flu. Also a bunch of smiles and laughs, which are sometimes harder to come by than the flu.', 'And you thought pork chops, black-eyed peas, collard greens and champagne were only on the menu; you were on another menu.', 'One real bout with the flu is all it takes to turn the annual flu shot into a ceremonial experience. You do the ceremonial "Please don\'t die" dance over the washer and dryer, and recently your car. You knock on wood anytime someone tempts fate. And you get the flu shot every Columbus Day weekend, with your daughter, who is home from school.  Waking up on the bathroom floor with no idea how you got there is a real heads up moment. And staying so sick that the journey to the kitchen to get water is beyond your ability for almost a week, cements that impression. Just say no to flu. I don\'t care if the vaccine is dead on, or only 10% effective. I\'ll do my part. It is akin to painting the lintel with blood, and hoping death will pass you by, only there is science behind the action, ot just a reliance on the mercy of angels.', 'Every year the nursing students from UMass come to the State House, where I work, to inoculate the willing. The annual debate turned surprisingly heated this year over the claims of some that they had never had the flu, and after a few minutes of this I lost it. "Oh, stop your complaining," I said. "It isn\'t all about YOU. Now go downstairs and do everyone else a favor and get yourself a bloody flu shot!" It worked. They did. And you know what? None of the complainers in my office has had the flu this year.', 'I had a flu shot.  I ate the collards, I ate the black eyed peas, I even ate the cornbread, but I got the flu.  Oh my oh my oh my.', "As a young boy, flu or flu like symptoms were treated with the following remedy by Mom. First a good lathering of Vicks-Vapor Rub on your chest, followed by Campbell's Chicken Noodle soup with saltine crackers, then to bed.\xa0 And the best part, no school. That was 65 years ago, wonder if Mom's\xa0 remedy is still in use? And thank you for the memory.", 'I am lathered with Vicks Vapo-Rub as I read this. Still works its magic. ;)']
summary: Some of the commenters talk about getting the flu shot as a way to avoid the flu. A handful of the other commenters speak about having the flu. Others reflect on and reminisce about black-eyed peas and collards in their past. Some posters also talk about remedies for the flu, such as Vicks vapo-rub and rest.
short_title: Headline: Happy Flu Year!   Keywords: New Year; Influenza; Vaccination and Immunization   Snippet: During an epidemic, self-delusion won’t reduce the viral load.
short_question: ['Happy Flu Year!  ']

summary_propositions: [{"claim": "The comments convey affection to the author of the article and thank him for sharing his experience with his grandmother", "ground": ["the author has affection for his grandmother"]}, {"claim": "The story left commentators inspired", "ground": ["the affection that the author has for his grandmother"]}]
query: As my grandma’s mind deteriorated, I felt myself holding on to her by becoming the woman we both wanted to be.
comments: ['What a beautiful testament to your grandmother and the influence she has had on your writing.', "Just spoke with an older friend who I had not spoken with in months (she lives over 1000 miles away now). She has fully succumbed to dementia, and it's so sad. Her husband told me he was gratified that she remembered me and my voice. So I will be writing her with photos so she can refer to it again. My friend was a vibrant, very intelligent, well educated and widely traveled lady. So so sad!", 'As a grandmother eager to help others pen, the depth and poignancy of this article resonates with me.  I am so glad you and your grandmother had such strong bonds and deep respect for each other.  May you continue to celebrate your heritage and gift, each word a celebration of love and honor.', "The piece reflects the enduring power of female lineage.  May your grandmother continue to be treated with the dignity she deserves.  May the author continue to blossom through life, love and loss.  Through this piece we take away the invisibility of the aged female and shine a light on the human heart.  As the author's writing refines in stages so does the human spirit.  Thank you.", 'This is so beautiful, Shannon. It is also a kick in the butt for all writers out there. Get everything down on paper or on your computer screen before your mind goes. Or you die.', 'Well.  This broke my heart, but also filled it with gratitude that your grandmother continues through you.', 'I am crying as I write this, thinking of my Nana. It is because of her, that I am the woman I am today. My Nana was sharp till the day she died at 95. When I lost her, I lost "my home". I am now losing the only family member I have left, my father, to dementia. The realization that there is no one who remembers my early life, my formative years, no one I can ask, no one to verify or question about my past, is the most difficult. Thank you for sharing your Grandmother with me.', "In the chaos of my parent's on again, off again relationship I found a welcome respite in weekend spent with my widowed grandmother.  In a kitchen filled with aroma of percolating coffee, our morning conversations over never ending games of solitaire made me feel like a grown-up, with my own point of view and important ideas. We discussed poetry and relationships and politics and much more.  My grandmother's own struggles were rarely raised in those conversations - her life as a single mother left alone by her husband's untimely death when my Dad was six. But her confident view that women deserve a higher education and that we should without apology express our opinions have shaped my adult life.  I've often taken solace in the poetry she taught me to enjoy and the memory of her strong love for me.  I miss her.", 'This is simply beautiful. Congratulations to you and your grandmother for such a wonderful essay.', 'Thank you so much for writing - and sharing- this beautiful essay.  I\'m actually both of you, combined.  At 82, I\'m a grandmother of six, and I have also been writer all my life.  I started as an advertising copywriter (even before "The Feminine Msystique", then moved on to primarily tech writing, and am now long retired...doing volunteer writing for various organizations, writing poetry, and REwriting an autobiography so my grandchildren will really, REALLY know who and what they came from.  I hope you will do that too, since you sound like a treasure that should definitely be shared.', "My grandmother took me in after my mother's death.We shared her two room house. She learned to read and write when her children went to grade school. Every winter morning at 6 a.m. she started the small coal stove to melt the ice in our drinking water pail. If there was meat available, she put it on my plate. All of it. Four of her six children preceded her in death. Her last days were shared with me, a 14 year old who was wild with grief. I'm now 67 and excessively comfortable with food, housing and love. It seems that I daily gain more insight into the woman who saved my life.", "A beautiful story and loving tribute to your grandmother.  May your grandmother's force become stronger as you wish  though I'd say you are doing well all on your own.  Your gift of writing is a joy.  Wishing your grandmother peace and you as well.", 'I am the grandmother. I hope and pray my daughters and grand children will also remember me with not only love, but wisdom, competence and a smile. Thank you for this eloquent and introspective letter. And yes, it made me cry.', 'Lovely - just lovely!  Thank you for sharing this story with us.  Blessings to you and your beloved grandmother.', 'Wonderful.  Through tragedy comes a life lesson and inspiration. All of my wife and my parents were/are  victims of dementia and Alzheimers.  But there are moments of clarity, such as you experienced, that can just take your breath away.  They are a blessing.', "Beautiful.  My 18 year old daughter dreams of being a writer, more specifically a journalist. Her first piece of published writing was her grandmother's obituary which was fitting as her grandmother wrote for her local paper as a college student and majored in journalism.", "Lovely.  Thank you so much for sharing a bit of your grandma with us.  What a precious gift she was to you, as you were to her.  I will remember her holding your educator's guide in her lap and squeezing your hand.", 'This is just beautful.  Thank you.', "You are so fortunate to have your grandmother and her encouragement in your life!  Those who had dreams like yours, but who were discouraged by their closest family members, can only wish for what you've had with your grandmother.  I don't think it's an overstatement to say that it's life-changing.", "I can relate. My grandmother died in 2011. I wear a piece of her jewelry daily. It keeps her with me. What a lovely story. You've done her proud.", 'Thank you, thank you, thank you!  I have been struggling with transcribing the dozens of journals sitting in a box in my closet.  You have inspired me to direct the conversation toward my 14-year-old granddaughter.  Time to let it flow.', "I understand th writer's love and respect for--and connection to--her grandmother. My 91 year old father had Alzheimer's disease and lost the battle fourteen months ago.  My mother and I were with him there, in the medical facility, when he took his last breath. My father had been a reader all his life, a passion which I picked up and still enjoy.  Even as the disease continue to take its toll upon him, he continued trying to read even though mostly what he was doing was resting the books or magazines upon his lap as he casually and routinely flipped the pages without paying attention to what he was doing. In watching him, however, I knew that his love affair w the printed words was, subconsciously, what he enjoyed and was trying to maintain though he realized that his comprehension of the texts was no longer there. It was the action, not the performance, that was so calming for him to engage and for me to watch. The writer's tribute to her grandmother was inspirational, and I thank her for sharing this very personal narrative.", 'I lost my sister to brain cancer at age 57. She was a lifelong reader, writer, and editor. Even when she was very ill, she would read whatever was within her range of vision--a calendar, subtitles on a TV, magazine headlines. It was a habit and a joy ingrained from a lifetime of reading and relating to words. I can relate to your story.', 'To have that kind of support throughout your life truly is a blessing.', 'What a woman she is and what a woman she nurtured. Recalling with affection and insight how she helped you become yourself brought both of you into focus for me. Lovely to read, thank you.', 'Thank you for this tender and loving essay about your dear grandmother.', 'Thanks, Shannon. I cried.', 'Beautiful portrait of your relationship.  How fortunate you are to have had your grandmother in your life.  Thank you.', "I'm happy your still in your grandmother's life.  Alzheimer's is a rough disease, and many family members decide not to visit the person anymore.  She needs you even more now.  Lovely story."]
summary: The comments convey affection to the author of the article and thank him for sharing his experience with his grandmother. The commentators were touched by the affection that the author has for his grandmother and said that the story left them inspired. Some commentators shared their personal experiences with their grandparents and parents.
short_title: Headline: My Grandmother’s Story Is Ending as Mine Begins   Keywords: Grandparents; Dementia; Families and Family Life   Snippet: As my grandma’s mind deteriorated, I felt myself holding on to her by becoming the woman we both wanted to be.
short_question: ['My Grandmother’s Story Is Ending as Mine Begins  ']

query: The most important frontier for robots is not the work they take from humans but the work they do with humans — which requires learning on both sides.
comments: ['We just lack vision. We are trying to adapt human beings to technologies, when technologies is the mean, not the purpose. What do we want society to look like in 20 years ? How can Robots help ? These are the real questions. We need to switch mindset with foresight. The consumerist, quantitative growth, ROI, etc... current economic system is depleting nature. Vital environmental and ecological imperatives forbid us to continue in the manner that today’s consumerist model requires. An “economy of quality” must be invented, one that technological progress can contribute to. Let\'s mobilize collective intelligence and collective imagination to invent a new model and channel technological progress in this direction, one of a "sustainable humankind and planet".', 'The mention of Norbert Wiener\'s intention in coining the term "cybernetics" misstates both his goals and his actions. He—among many other scholars of the  1940s era, including Gregory Bateson, Margaret Mead, John von Neumann, Claude Shannon, and others from philosophy, psychiatry, neurophysiology, and more—recognized that certain systems could be construed as having goals and therefore could be studied effectively from that frame, regardless of whether they were mechanical, electrical, biology, or social. His conceptual work and its applications encompassed both "animal and machine", as Wiener\'s famous subtitle to his 1948 "Cybernetics" asserts, but his purpose was the study of purposive systems, not merely "the relationship between living beings and robots", as the article states. Cybernetics was a revolution that rocked the entire culture and which reverberates today. While the term has been diluted by appropriation of its prefix (cyberspace, cybersecurity...), cybernetics at least remains a placeholder for a discipline that stands as an effective lens for understanding human actions and interactions, human organizations and societies, and, yes, our relationship to the creatures we create in order to, hopefully, do what we want.', 'There\'s a lot of misuse of the term robot.  This article is typical.  The machines described in it are machine tools, not even simple robots.  A robot is not a machine run by a computer---that would make all computers robots.  No, a robot is a machine run by a computer that is able to carry out the majority of its instructions without input from a human.  These tools might move closer to being robots if they could do things like decide if there was work to to.  Or, even whether it should work.  That\'s far beyond  rudimentary "collaboration."  For such a sensitive subject, we shouldn\'t treat language casually.', 'The idea that the only limitation for robots is our "appetite for human interaction" doesn\'t make sense, at least not yet.  We all have experience with the customer service robots on the phone.  If our question does not fit obvious categories the robot won\'t even understand what we\'re talking about.  So the idea that a robot is an adequate substitute for a financial advisor is far-fetched.  Perhaps it might serve for some initial analysis but that\'s about it.  In time this well may change.', 'After Garry Kasparov was defeated by Deep Blue, he reflected and shortly afterwards started a new form of chess called centaur chess (or freestyle chess), in which humans and AI could collaborate on the same team. The top teams are almost all centaurs (human-AI hybrids) rather than all human or all AI. Similarly, we can use robotics to strengthen where we are most weak and focus our attention on that which makes us most human. Are these tasks really a loss? “The man whose whole life is spent in performing a few simple operations, of which the effects, too, are perhaps always the same, or very nearly the same, has no occasion to exert his understanding, or to exercise his invention, in finding out expedients for removing difficulties which never occur.” - Adam Smith, The Wealth of Nations', 'Robots are wonderful. They will vastly increase our ability to produce. The trouble is products have to be bought. Whether it is food, hardware, toys or other things like roads or bridges. People have to buy them through earnings or taxation. With 90% of the working population being employees whose income is more and more under threat where is the demand for this increased productivity going to come from?', "Issac Asimov wrote a book back in the 1950's about the problems of integrating very advanced humanoid robots in the culture of a future Earth: 'The Caves of Steel'. It made interesting reading back then but reading it now makes it amazingly prescient.", 'Kim, excellent writing, superb article!
