To “android disbelievers”: Let’s go back (in thoughts), perhaps to the times of Davy Crockett – to see how it feels technology-free… Of course, at that instant, these silicon-liquidcrystal-GigaHertz colorful contraptions in front of our eyes & noses would vanish, so we would have to find a piece of paper and ink – to exchange our subsequent thoughts and experiences collected in early 19th century… And, also: we would have to toss our motor-vehicle technology (dubbed “cars”) aside, for there was none, at the time, in the Wild, Wild West… So, I’ll say: Future has always been more appealing to me, then history.', "Any discussion of the future must include not only a technologist but also an economist, a politician, and a demographer.  If a small amount of robotic automation gave us Trump, then what would a large amount give us, the political would ask. If the economics of having a child shifted such that raising that child cost too much and they would have nothing to do as adults, then what happens to the birth rate, the demographer would ask. If only robots work and robots don't buy handbags and vacations to the shore, then what happens to aggregate demand, the economist would ask.  People are already reaching to what's coming in ways both inspiring and frightening.", "As the mass of knowlege grows and is accessible to propetly educated perople; as the ability to know how the life habitat is being affected by established practices of wealth creation by transformation of matter, with more and more powerful impact on the environment through technology and organizational integration; and with the idea in the heads of the finance capital people that investment must generate fantastic profits, not just a decent return for production that finds economic harmonization of both human capital and machines: there are plenty of jobs out there for workers employed by our communities to plan, test and assure sustainable use of our essential habitat. It is no longer possible to fail to know and seek to know at a very high level of precision at all times the natural foundation upon which life depends. Scarcity conditons gave men permission to see Nature as an enemy of life, too big to damage.  We continue in 'scarity mode' even as it's now consumption driven, not life sustaining. We're the fish out of water who can't fathom why her breathing thin air is killing her. We have created a perfect storm of the military-industrial complex of WWII fame: Corporations whose investors allowed no say in policy are use pension fund capital—worker money—to eliminate jobs, or send them to foreigh slaves outside our laws.  Their justification is that they are morally bound to produce (excessive) profist for investors, i.e., worker savings and retirement funds.", 'fantastic article,  thank you', "As far as jobs that can't be automated, the restaurant server example is incredibly weak. Most of the economy is 'budget' experiences, and as we get more inequality, we get more automation and even fewer people will have jobs or money. So, yes, Chez Jacques Noire won't get the robot, but fast food will be toast - already 'blue collar' places have tablets for ordering - and as that happens more and more people will only afford robot service, including hotels, home health care, senior living and food service. Robots will be 'good enough' soon enough, unfortunately. It's not 'going to happen' anymore, it IS happening. Self-driving cars, restaurants with tablet ordering, electronic payments, free online education, training, entertainment. All those tasks represent a lot of the economy.  We live in the future, jetpacks notwithstanding. I had to laugh at the 'There are people with value who are not programmers', well, yes, there are MBAs, too, right? But seriously, that just isn't how our economy is structured. We're a sink or swim society, not one built on Christian charity. The Republicans won, didn't they?", "I remember well in the mid 60's when the suggestion that robots would take over the jobs of humans first came out, and that it would give humans plenty of free time to enjoy life. Well, a few decades later, it is clear that this prediction was wrong, for 99% of we the people. In fact, quite the opposite occurred. We are now working harder, making less money, and stressing out, trying to provide a good education for our kids, put food on the table, pay for health insurance, and try to put away savings, if any, to help us live gracefully in retirement. Thank God for Social Security.", 'About 1981 the Pacific NW chapter of Robotics International, IEEE, was founded by Mark Jones and 14 others.  Our first seminar brought seven outstanding robotics professionals to explore for us the safety aspects of having robots working alongside humans. What happens when a human is careless? How do you protect him from serious injury or death? What happens when the robot has a computer glitch, is about to become dangerous, . . .  ?  How might we make it visibly and audibly clear that danger is approaching? We can often tell when our neighboring worker is breaking down. Can we build fail safe that will turn it of or direct its movements to a harmless position?', 'Increasingly sophisticated Robots and other technology will displace human workers, at all levels, including professionals.  A substantial number of those workers will not be retained or retrained by their employers. The Government should react, now, to those certainties by: 1. Creating retraining and placement programs that will qualify displaced workers for jobs that have better salaries than those from which they were displaced. 2. Imposing a tax on robots that is a percentage of the income the displaced worker(s) would have earned if they had not been displaced, (As to the tax, see: Bill Gates calls for income tax on robots, Financial Times, February 19, 2017,  https://www.ft.com/content/d04a89c2-f6c8-11e6-9516-2d969e0d3b65) . It is also certain that some people will attempt to use robots to commit crimes or to otherwise violate public policy. The Government should start developing statutes that define, discourage and punish the misuse of robots for criminal purposes.', 'I remember from childhood with my father, grandfather; It"s pass. Future live now robots and more progress.', 'This is a fascinating article.  I am particularly taken by the idea that a "human" worker in one location could use virtual reality goggles to "control" a robot elsewhere for something as mundane as folding laundry.  That one idea alone starts my head reeling.  On one hand it seem so liberating, but on the other.....well, just frighting. I thank Ms. Tingley for her article and hope that she will be able to follow these ideas and trends even deeper than she has gone here.', '...if they learn from us, they will treat us like we treat our \'inferiors"...', 'How much happened with the theory and practice of robotics this low-official-joblessness spring and summer?  A lot!  See  http://worksnewage.blogspot.com/2016/09/robots-marching-on-adding-to-eff... .', 'These robots can increase our efficiency a tenfold. But human greed will make sure that we will still want more, no matter what our GDP.', 'automation is here: complete with job loses, and more to come, and no clear plan what to do with the vast number of unemployed to come.  Only so many can replace the illegal aliens.    War?    No health insurance,.    No emergency room access without cash for the doctor.   Manditory 2 or 3 day permited to work.  Cashless economy so no black market can exit.   More prisions.    Will be America turly be like  Brazil in 10 years, 15.', "Toiling away, copying manuscripts in skilled calligraphy, I thought the monastery life brought me closer to God. But then, we acquired a robot named Xerox, who could copy in a second, what took me weeks by quill. Alas, Xerox's talent at faithfully reproducing manuscripts with calligraphy that rivaled my own, created a wedge between me & God.", 'Well said. Robots and automation, in conjunction with human guidance, ought to strike a balance, allowing us some more free time for family, hobbies and even guiltless idleness to feed the spirit. The current capitalistic system, its inequality derived from hugely favoring capital over labor, and its inequities, should become manageable with sensible regulation. Poetry, anybody?', 'I\'m a lead engineer that fights daily with an engineering department full of software developers that think they know what users want. I\'m a big proponent of spending time with actual end users and asking them how they do their job, and how to build applications that help them. The telecommunications industry, where I work, has hundreds of thousands of highly trained technicians that do what I call "putting cupcakes in a box". They hold on to doing a few repetitive functions within a long complex process to establish new network links. When I show them how our application allows them to do the whole job end to end, by themselves, it\'s a hard sell. Part of it is they see this as losing job security. "If I can do the job of 10 people, what happens to them?... and eventually, me?" I point out for every job that gets done, there are 10 things that are never done, but are still important. Or that task diversity is more "fun stuff", and having a computer do the "boring bits" so you can do "the interesting bits" is a win-win.  We call all these issues "social engineering". It\'s stiff resistance to changing one\'s work habits. My company spends 100\'s of millions of dollars to construct "workflows" based on current practice; we test them in our software user experience lab, and we test them with lead customers, and self identified "change leaders" in their workforce.  What we can\'t seem to engineer, is people.', "Great article, thanks! We'll all be benefiting greatly from the productivity-amplifiers that robots are. If we're smart enough to.", "I fear that our moment's literalist fixation on robots--machines which imitate human movement or speech or other physical characteristics--is crowding out discussion of the more truly threatening aspects of automation, such as supercomputers with the brainpower of 100 (or 1000 or billions) of humans that can control other mechanisms anywhere on the grid simply by being plugged into a power outlet (the wiring is the grid, if you didn't get that); or the ability to invent or revise biological entities with the techniques of biochemistry and genetic engineering.  Machines that walk like people to get somewhere are simply stones in a universe where artificial intelligence can communicate its thoughts to the rest of the universe at the speed of light.  We need to know what they will be saying...", '"A study at Ball State University\'s Center for Business and Economic Research last year found that trade accounted for just 13 percent of America\'s lost factory jobs. The vast majority of the lost jobs — 88 percent — were taken by robots and other homegrown factors that reduce factories\' need for human labor." From an AP story on robotics in manufacturing. This was also referenced in a NY Times story recently.  So, don\'t believe all that static coming out of Trump\'s mouth. American manufacturing is actually doing quite well. What is missing is the ability to find American workers that have the technological skills. The days of screwing a door handle on a car for $35 an hour are gone, forever.']
summary: Several commenters appreciate the article and agree with the benefit of robots, defending their usefulness against the criticism that robots replace humans and take their jobs. They cite examples of how humans can be more effective and productive by working together with robots. Based on his position, one commenter states the need to be very tactful in selling the idea to human workers. Another states that future success requires advances in technology and demographics, politics, and economics.
short_title: Headline: Automation   Keywords: Layoffs and Job Reductions; Robots and Robotics; Labor and Jobs   Snippet: The most important frontier for robots is not the work they take from humans but the work they do with humans — which requires learning on both sides.
subreddit: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Labor and Jobs']
short_question: ['Automation  ']

query: Friday: Becoming a politician, weekend events, and a question inspired by Passover.
comments: ['The new, hospital-white LED streetlights spreading across the boroughs feel like a sort of plague.', 'PASSOVER SURPRISE Ten plagues beset the Egyptians: blood, frogs, lice, flies, pestilence, boils, hail, locusts, darkness, and the killing of a firstborn. Today we have a new plague: Donald Trump.', 'Depression and anxiety.', "One of the reasons we're in the mess we're in today is because anybody thinks they can run for office. Just a bit of friendly advice. Be of, by, and for, the People. And have a mandate first.", 'Modern plague?  Voice Response Systems!!!!  Especially ones where after you sit through 12 different options, and then 6 different sub-options, and 5 more sub-sub-options, result in "No one is available to take your call right now.  Please leave a message."', '"The plagues are, traditionally: blood, frogs, lice, flies, pestilence, boils, hail, locusts, darkness, and the killing of a firstborn." Those plagues were beyond man\'s control.  Cyberbullying and terrorism and, for that matter, the "networking for personal gain," can be controlled by everyone\'s following the Golden Rule -- first stated in Leviticus, by the way, and rephrased centuries later by Jesus: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.  False equivalence.', 'Mets terrify Braves', "The current plague of power networking for personally gain infecting the office of the President. Helps to know a lot of the world's heads of states in the real estate business or any other business.", "Tune of Da Doo Ron Ron Ptogress up in Albany is standing still Should you run run run Should you run run Somebody told me they can't pass a bill Should you run run run Should you run run Yeah, they're standing still They can't pass that bill So instead of mouthing off Should you run run run Should you run run Lots of matching funds to match what you have raised Could you run run run Could you run run It's easy to get signatures, you'd be amazed Could you run run run Could you run run Yeah, funds get raised Yeah, you'd be amazed So if you have got thick skin Could you run run run Could you run run (12x). Could you run run run, could you run run", 'I hope you have a good weekend, Freddie.', 'Over the past months, we have witnessed legislative rollbacks and executive orders spearheaded by President Trump—truly a modern day Pharaoh—aimed at preventing refugees from accessing the safety of our shores.  People across America today are encountering hate speech, bigotry, and violence. These are modern plagues that we must not ignore! Passover is a particularly charged holiday for our community, as we retell one of the greatest stories of workers collectively rising up against their oppressors and escaping terrible abuse via an exodus to a “promise land.” Our Passover haggadah represents one of the first accounts commemorating the refugee experience on a grand scale. This saga resonates today as never before, as our country now faces a government-driven assault on immigrant rights, civil liberties, health and welfare benefits, and worker protections.  This month, as our Jewish community gathers with friends and families to share our traditional story of resistance and exodus, we must consider this reality as a renewed call to action. I have written a fuller account of my thoughts at:  http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/fighting-a-modern-day-pharoah_us_58e...', "Great, Freddie! Worthy of Albany's Legislative Follies, if they still present them!"]
summary: Some commenters agree that certain people choose to run or get elected because they have the ability or means and not because they have the public's best interest at heart. Many commenters talked about Biblical plagues and made references to them. One commenter shares ominous song lyrics that echo some of the comments and the article.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords:    Snippet: Friday: Becoming a politician, weekend events, and a question inspired by Passover.

query: In this installment of Match Book, a woman seeks a work of fiction that will unite her “disparate group of avid readers,” also known as her children.
comments: ['So happy to see Fugitive Pieces recommended here. I LOVE this book! In 5 decades of reading, it remains one of the most beautiful novels I have ever read.', 'Can you adopt me?', 'Anne Tyler: Accidental Tourist, Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant, or Saint Maybe, or Celestial Navigation, or or ... Anne Tyler!', "If you liked Station Eleven, you might like Pattern Recognition, by WIlliam Gibson.  The two books aren't really alike, except that they roused the same kind of enthusiasm in me when I read them. The Secret Chord by Geraldine Brooks, if you haven't all read that already, since you enjoyed People of the Book.", 'There are so many good suggestions from other commenters.  I would add "The Goldfinch" by Donna Tartt and "Birdsong" by Sebastian Faulkes.', 'I second the recommendations for Life After Life (Kate Atkinson) and The Handmaid\'s Tale (Margaret Atwood).  Maybe also consider: 1) Fates & Furies (Lauren Groff)--for passionate book lovers 2) How to Start a Fire (Lisa Lutz)--for its brilliant organization, suspense, and snappy dialogue 3) The Buddha in the Attic (Julie Otsuka)--for its captivating "1st-person collective" point of view telling the story of Japanese brides.  For more, see my blog Only Good Books.', "The Elegance of the Hedgehog would be my choice. Has a YA slant and an intellectual one as well. And it is set in Paris. What could be better? You could get some lovely French cheese and wine from Formaggio in Cambridge and have a rousing book discussion!  (I am also from New England and know Canton well. A lovely town. I was just back in Boston with my husband for a visit. I miss it so much.) anyway, new book is coming out by a local New Englander. (He hails from Medway, MA) His name is Tom Ryan. His first book was Following Atticus and his new one is entitled Will's Red Coat. Both set in New Hampshire as they climb all the 4000 footers in the White Mountains and the book about Will is about his rescue as a senior dog. Both non-fiction, but good reads. Many tie ins to the MA area.  I love that you have a family book group. My daughter and I occasionally read the same books and we do love discussing them.", 'I would suggest "Lamb" by Christopher Moore.', 'Caleb Carr, The Alienist Michael Chabon, The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay Min Jin Lee, Pachinko, as well as her first, very different book, Free Food for Millionaires Donna Tartt, The Secret History (her first book, wonderful) and if you are very adventurous, Hanya Yanagihara, A Little Life', "Eudora Welty, The Optimist's Daughter Jeff Greenfield, The People's Choice Peter Taylor, A Summons To Memphis Willa Cather, The Professor's House Dana Hand, Deep Creek", "First things first: All of Penelope Fitzgerald's books are worth reading. Secondly: A Gentleman in Moscow by Amor Towles is delightful.", "A Visit from the Goon Squad, Jennifer Egan Handmaid's Tale, Margaret Atwood These have the YA element of edginess and deep themes such as dystopia and anomy like Kafka. However they also have interpersonal and metaphysical themes and are fairly short and engaging to read. They are provocative and provide lots of angles for discussion. Handmaid's Tale is a newly released movie which could add a dimension to the discussion.", "For your fun and strange Ya/Kafka mashup, in addition to what's mentioned and based on your book club books that previously worked, I'd recommend the following novels (plus a connected stories novel): A Tale for the Time Being, Ruth Ozeki Lincoln in the Bardo, George Saunders Exit West, Mohsin Hamid The Tsar of Love and Techno, Anthony Marra The Nix, Nathan Hill Life After Life, Kate Atkinson", 'A couple of recommendations of recent authors and books: - David Nicholls, "Us, A Novel.". About family, relationships, what happens when everything seems to fall apart. - Patrick Modiano, "In the Cafe of Lost Youth." About identity, memory, forgetting - all the typical concerns of a fine French writer.', "Thanks Nicole! I never cared for A.S. Byatt's novels, didn't finish Possession. Loved everything her sister Margaret Drabble wrote, though, starting with Thank You Very Much (aka The Millstone) - haven't kept up with all her recent books after Peppered Moth. But I will try Byatt's Babel Tower. Your other picks sound good too. I have Fugitive Pieces somewhere in my house and will look for it. I think the only book my whole family has read is Neil Gaiman's take on A Midsummer Night's Dream, a comic book with the dark sensibility of his Sandman stories.", 'Con Brio, I completely agree with you about Byatt and Drabble! Never cared for Byatt\'s novels, didn\'t finish Possession, loved everything Margaret Drabble wrote (or, at least, everything that I have read by her)! And may I recommend the movie of "Thank You All Very Much"? I usually dislike movies that began as books, but even the venerable NY Times liked it! Here\'s the review:  http://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9502EFDF1439EF3BBC4152DFBE668382...', 'Wonderful recommendations. Fugitive Pieces is achingly lyrical and beautiful in its prose, and the style supports the story with great sensitivity. If one is going to suggest a family novel by a great Penelope, Penelope Lively\'s Consequences should get some attention as well. This is a book that you just cannot put down, a real and rare big "small" canvas achievement.', 'These are great suggestions.  Fives and Twenty-Fives by Michael Pitre would be a change for everybody. It is told from the point of view of a Marine lieutenant in Iraq and his interpreter, who uses his tattered copy of Huck Finn as a lens to understand American.', 'The Shadow of the Wind by Carlos Ruiz Zafón News of the World by Paulette Jiles', 'Middlesex by Jeffrey Eugenides.  I think this is one of the great American novels and the themes are so timely, with immigration and gender fluidity such divisive topics right now.  And thank you for reminding me of Fugitive Pieces which I will start to re-read tonight for the third time.', 'Yes to Middlesex! One of my all time favorites.', 'I just read Exit West by Mohsin Hamid and loved it. The sentences are lovely and lyrical and it deals with war and the refugee crisis in a way that is strange and magical. Even though it has magical elements, the characters have feelings and actions the same as all of us. The book would give your family a lot to talk about.', "Rule of the Bone by Russell Banks, a coming-of-age novel with a compelling homeless-teen protagonist (apparently controversial for its adolescent-narrator's discussions of drug use and sex, including abuse of a minor); I first read this over 20 years ago, and Chappie still ranks among my favorite characters in fiction.", 'These are all great suggestions. I would add A Prayer for Owen Meaney, Underground Railroad, and Wide Sargasso Sea.', 'I have to second A Prayer for Owen Meaney!', 'His Dark Materials by Philip Pullman Leviathan by Philip Hoare Enigma of  Arrival by VS Naipaul East Travel to Other Planets Ted Mooney']
summary: All of the commenters are talking about books they would recommend families read together, with extremely varied results such as the comedy "Lamb" by Christopher Moore and the much more serious "Middlesex' by Jeffrey Eugenides. Some express how much they like the idea in general and praise the author for creating a book club with their kids.
short_title: Headline: Mom Seeks Novel for Family Book Club, No Kafka or Y.A. Allowed   Keywords: Books and Literature   Snippet: In this installment of Match Book, a woman seeks a work of fiction that will unite her “disparate group of avid readers,” also known as her children.
short_question: ['Mom Seeks Novel for Family Book Club, No Kafka or Y.A. Allowed  ']

query: The best trick to increase productivity is both the simplest one and one of the most difficult to master: just getting started.
comments: ['Years ago, I read article where Matthew McConaughey said that when not motivated to exercise, “Just tie your shoes” was his starting mantra. It’s stuck with me, and I say it to myself when I need to get a process of any kind started. Seems he knew this trick all along.', "“Don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good.”  Merci Voltaire", "I find my biggest challenge to be getting stuck on a task. Some tasks I can sail through and check off my list. The trouble is when task #3 has issues that hold me up. Do I spend the next three hours on that one thing or stop and put it on tomorrow's list, unresolved? It's so frustrating when I can't get the answer I need to keep going.", "Wow, this is great. If I can break down everything I have to do into sufficiently minute micro-tasks, I can spend so much time making lists that I can feel continuously productive without actually having to do anything at all. But didn't Zeno think of this first?", "I love Kara's newsletter. It's the perfect length with the cutest amount of motivation to get my day started!", "I write magazine articles and enjoy, often even love the work. However, most times, getting started is difficult. I've discovered that if I can open  my word processing program and type a catchy title, I'm golden. Then, when I'm in the piece, I caption paragraphs in bold to help me focus send get excited to flesh out the idea. Seems silly but it works - I have been doing it for thirty years. Now, I find out I stumbled onto a proven technique. I suppose thanks ate in order?", 'I just tried this method today and I actually finished a  task I had been totally procrastinating for about two weeks!  Thanks!', 'Tim, Thank you, I feel so much less alone. I knew procrastination was a real "thing," but I thought my level of, shall we say, expertise was nearly unparalleled. Mais non. When I started college (a long time ago), a well-meaning dorm-mate said, "There\'s no such thing as a deadline at [XYZ school I loved]." Worst life lesson ever.  The only thing I do NOT procrastinate about is filling up the gas tank. I\'ve never run out of gas in close to three decades of driving. Gas light may have come on once. Why can\'t I do that with everything? (Getting gas really is easy! Stop when it isn\'t raining and you aren\'t already late ...otherwise it will be and you will be.)', 'This theory is old.  It has never worked for me if I truly dread something. I get started and keep thinking "No wonder I put this off. This is awful."  It doesn\'t get better. I doubt I\'m the only person who has experienced this.', 'The most valuable work advice I was ever given was to make a list at the end of the work day, do and cross off one small task, and leave knowing what the priorities for the following day will be.', 'This just reiterates the old saying “ Yard by yard it’s very hard,  but inch by inch,  it’s a chinch.”', 'Sometimes the first item on my list is “make a list.” Then as soon as I’ve made the list, I can cross off item #1. A silly, but motivating tactic.', 'In teaching, a writing intervention that is shown to be quite effective is called SRSD--self-regulated strategy development. The strategy aspect (usually a formula or mnemonic device) is only effective if supported by teaching children to self-regulate through positive self-statements and goal-setting. The goals usually look a lot like the micro-goals described here. I learned the value of micro-goals and positive self-statements for myself after I learned about SRSD for my middle school students. If I need to tackle a daunting task, I now do both the positive self-statements and micro-goals. For example, I just sent a daunting parent email. I was avoiding it at first, so I said, "You\'re the kind of teacher who does what is right for students." Then I did the smallest possible step, opening my browser. Then I said, "Look, you\'re already started!" Then I clicked "compose". Etc. Soon it was over, just as this article describes, and I\'d done a nice job, too.  So if you like the idea of the micro-goals, I\'d recommend adding simple positive self-statements ("I\'ve done this kind of thing before," "Each time I\'ve tried this it\'s been better," "I can get through this, little by little"). In the education world, these have been shown to be effective when paired with micro-goals. It might feel like it\'s "baby-talk", but what\'s wrong with that? Sometimes it\'s good to tell yourself something simple and kind.', 'This is the heart of project management -- and is called a work breakdown structure (WBS).  Been a standard practice for over 50+ years and what I do every day at MPMM.', 'I\'m a writer and my mantra is "You can\'t improve something that doesn\'t exist." So get something down on the page, anything, because anything is always better than nothing.', "I'm one of those people who easily makes split-second decisions in a crunch, but is paralyzed for hours when time is not an issue - especially when the decision to be made is a toss-up.  Staring a a pile of odds & ends wondering what to do with it all takes forever - but the advice here is sound: just do something.  Keeping the ball rolling is easy after that.", "Weirdly I have instituted one change in my life since January first that has helped me be productive in general, which is that I make my bed every morning on arising. I know a lot of people don't make their beds at all, but I ALWAYS make mine before I get into it, which has sometimes meant making it at five in the afternoon or ten at night. Having a made bed in my back pocket so to speak makes me feel like I've started the day with a completed task before even getting any coffee. I have had a much more productive January than usual, and have not sunk TOO far into the SAD despond.", "Thank you for getting me started. Not that I wouldn't consider guiltless idleness an art, but if one wants to accomplish a task to show relevance, any which way to get a foot in the door counts. But no rest for the wicked? How about a little 'espresso' to gather the materials, then a little run (or rowing). You have no idea the fatal attraction of procrastination has on some of us. But, once our job is completed, it doubles the joy.", "When I was writing up my phd dissertation I received a piece of advice that I use constantly in my life generally. It was to leave one small task unfinished at the end of each day so that when you sit down in the morning you have a clearly defined task that you can begin and complete immediately. It's hard to begin a big job with a blank canvas, so start with something little. A body in motion...", 'It\'s called "leaving some water in the well."', 'Thanks for these wonderful tips on micro-progress. But allow me to offer two suggestions that I am working on: 1) Use slogans. -------------------- For example, I have an Easy button, from Staples. It says, "that was easy" when you press it. (The Global Easy button, has different languages). There are free Easy button apps. The idea is to focus on easy steps, first. Of course one does not need a button to realize this, but it might help, at times. And the button is something I can use to impress other people with. 2) Motivate micro-press by helping others (Golden Rule) ---------------------------------------------------------------------- I think it often helps to do a task for the benefit of another person. Ironically, we are often more motivated to help others, than to help ourselves. And sometimes helping others carries more urgency. For example, I am motivated to send this comment, in order to help readers and Tim. There is an urgency about this because if I wait, the comment section will close... Thanks so much, Tim. This is super! ===========================', 'In 1983 I was terrified to apply for an important arts grant and used the micro-progress approach.  For the first step I choose the least scary...buying mailing supplies for slides and proposal.  Then on to the following steps choosing the next least scary.  After a few days my application was completed with no major freak-outs.  I intentionally was very busy and tried to forget the application.  When a letter arrived announcing my grant I was so thrilled I called everyone I knew, including art school professors.  This was a major lesson learned and I have used it several ways, such as going to the dreaded dentist.', "I like large blocks of unstructured, uninterrupted time to work on creative projects. So I tend to take care of all the smaller items on my to-do list first, while in the back of my mind I am ruminating on my big project. It may seem like I am procrastinating, but really I am just clearing the smaller nagging tasks out of the way, kind of on auto-pilot, while the creative part of my brain is humming along, figuring out ideas and approaches to the bigger project. And since I like creative projects, it's almost like I use them as a reward. As soon as I get all these boring little tasks done, then I get to have some fun! Sometimes I will write a big to-do list for tasks to get done on the weekend, and then when the weekend rolls around, I don't feel like doing any of them. I used to feel guilty about this, but now I just remind myself it's MY LIST, and I am probably the only one who cares if the tasks get done or not. I can either do the stuff on the list, put it aside for later, or crumple it up and toss it!", "I work from home and suffer greatly for it without a team around me or a work environment or a power suit and although I have tried may tricks [ getting power dressed in the morning to pretend Im going to a work place ] the home environment with the ' YOUR HOME IS YOR CASTLE ' etc keeps tripping me up and I end my days being super non productive because I end up doing the home things . My hobbies - my leisure activities - my home activities and work is not done because Im not ' AT WORK ' ..However and as easy sit is to deride this article it is 100% true ..just get started and then one thing will lead to another and that is 100% true its just that starting is a huge mission and truly far easier said than done .", 'OMG...when I first started working from home...before "everyone" did, all that housework I\'d avoided before, looked "do-able" in the face of work.  When I was stuck on something work-wise...that cob-web up in the corner was all consuming. :-)', 'One thing that helped me stay focused when I worked from home was establishing a dedicated office space, in my case, a room in the basement. When I was there, all I did was work-related, and I never did work elsewhere in the house. Having a devoted area really helped me compartmentalize and keep work separate from other things I did around the house.', 'I\'ve taken Mark Twain\'s advice of "eating the frog" to heart.  It is best to start with the task you are dreading most. Oftentimes, it isn\'t that bad -- it just seems that way while it\'s taking up valuable mental real estate. Once you\'ve finished it, the rest of your day will look much easier.', 'oh I have the completely opposite experience. I find that if I start with the easiest thing it gets me going on "work mode" and having the small accomplishments under my belt puts me in a mood to tackled the \'frog\'', 'Which of course Mark Twain never said. So that helps to start your day, checking what you think is true.', 'Old stuff, maybe, be worth repeating over and over again.']
summary: Several commenters voice their support of the micro-progress approach and offer their own success stories. Making a list of small tasks is common to several commenters. One commenter calls this approach work breakdown structure (WBS), and another even uses "make a list" as the first item on their list. One commenter extolls the benefits of self-regulated strategy development (SRSD), and another explains the benefits of establishing their own dedicated office space.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Productivity   Snippet: The best trick to increase productivity is both the simplest one and one of the most difficult to master: just getting started.

query: A take on a Flemish carbonnade, this stew is braised in Belgian ale, which cuts through the sweetness of the golden-brown onions.
comments: ["Well, looking back in the NYT archives for previous preparations of carbonnade flamande, lo I see this one in 1939 uses tomato, even pureed if need be:  https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/06/11/113354691.html?... ®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=70 And this recipe emanates from the Belgian state, no less! it was served to guests at the restaurant of the Belgian Pavilion at the 1939 New York World's Fair. Fair's fair, and I take back what I suggested below, that tomato has no place (being originally a southern, or warm climate, vegetable). Of course for a hyper-terroir approach, perhaps one should omit it, pace those enterprising prewar ambassadors of Belgian cuisine. By the way where's Belgian beer (as a drink) in the 1939 review? No mention of it. One would think the Belgians would have promoted their reputed brews we well. Maybe they weren't reputed then?", "Well, as it's a take on carbonnade, not carbonnade, you can't gainsay it, but adding tomato, a southern vegetable, to a northern dish, traduces the concept really. For those wanting the real thing, omit tomato (coriander and cinnamon are okay but not necessary), and use the essential beer, sugar, and vinegar as the medium. No stock: to me stock takes away the essential taste, although some recipes call for it. Mustard on the bread, yes, added at beginning - it dissolves in - or at end as a commenter states. Bread should be French type, a little stale. For the beer, almost any one will do. Really. The end result doesn't disclose the beer character that much. The choice is more pointed when it comes to the accompanying drink. Beef carbonnade in the Flemish way is one of those deceptive dishes. It sounds like an age-old peasant dish, but try to find a citation before around 1900: not that many.  It's probably a late-1800s bourgeois development, when enough people had money to use beef in cooking and hence dish coming to some prominence. Some readers may recall too it was a 1960s food fad, I don't know why, but it was.", 'made this today for superbowl.  Only mods as adding 2 big portabellos, cut in same size as beef.  And served with tater tots, FTW!   superb.', 'I read and made this recipe yesterday. I purchased a 2.6 pounds chuck roast and cut my own stew meat, that way I know the meat to fat ratio. I proportioned all the ingredients for my 2.6 pounds stew meat, I also noticed there were no mushrooms or garlic in the recipe. That just didn’t work for me, so I sliced 1 pound of mushrooms (half baby Bella and half white mushrooms) and about three close of garlic. I added the mushrooms at step 3 and added the garlic at the very end of cooking of the onions and mushrooms so they wouldn’t be overcook them. We serve the stew over Trader Joe’s brown rice medley. It was incredible.', 'I forgot to mention, I cooked it in a pressure cooker on high for 30 minutes.', 'A good pressure cooker makes this a 30 minute meal.', 'I bought an insta pot. Any recommendations on how to modify to accommodate?', "Love this recipe.  My husband doesn't cook but he taught himself to prepare Beef Carbonnade from the Silver Palate (and cooked it for years) over noodles. It then fell off our menu since we limited our beef consumption. Now, I don't eat beef at all and he only eats it once a month.  I'm salivating seeing the picture and reading about an old family favorite, I miss it.", 'Like bacon, everything goes better with beer.', 'In Belgium I learned to finish this dish with thick slices from a baguette with one side covered in a layer of Dijon mustard. Just before serving push the bread into the dish mustard side up, and grill until brown. That adds the touch of mustard and the bread soaks up some of the sauce.', '@ Nan Chicago Yes, nothing could be better than to mop up the sauce with a thick slice of a crusty baguette with a soft alveolar interior. Perhaps as a lightly snobbish view of the table manners, I do not use the fingers for such an operation, but I impale the baguette slice on a fork and proceed to dip it in whatever is liquid on the plate.', "I do it with pain d'epices (you can find some on the UWS at, you guessed it, 'Pain d'Epices on West 70th St.) Slather the pain d'epices with Dijon mustard and cover the whole pot with it. It all breaks in the sauce after 1 1/2 hour of cooking.", 'So . . . "brawny" beef. Is that a flavor, texture, appearance--what, exactly? And how does that brawny beef square with the dish\'s "beefy tenderness"? I like descriptors that actually describe.', "Just a small note:  the first time I made Guinness beef stew, which doesn't have many onions, I was disappointed by the bitterness of the gravy/sauce. I tried another recipe which had you put some dried prunes in late in the cooking process. They dissolved into the stew and did a nice job cutting some of the too bitter, for me, flavor. I mention this because if you make the recipe here, which sound luscious, and need to tone it down a bit, you could try this prune solution.  Sounds a bit bizarre, I know, but it works every time I make it for my son the Guinness lover.", 'Nancy - I have read in some Mennonite recipes the notion of chopping up prunes and adding them to a stew to enhance flavor.  I never thought of prunes countering the bitterness of a beer like Guinness.  Your suggestions was spot on and very useful.  Thanks for the reminder.  And for those folks wondering, the taste of prunes is NOT detectable.', 'The recipe I used for Guinness stew (from an Irish book) had one stuff each dried prunes with a hazelnut.', 'With beer?! Not with dry red wine?! My, my, how the mighty have fallen ...', 'Just as I would not use an undrinkable wine for cooking (did that once, and in addition to ending up with a barely edible dish, my house smelled horrible afterward), I would not use a flavorless, undrinkable beer. People need to understand, though, that a pleasantly bitter IPA will be concentrated in the cooking, and might end up more bitter than they like. As has been noted, using beer versus wine makes a different dish, neither better nor worse in prilciple.', "Conversely Suzanne, would you use premium wine in cooking? If not, why use a premium beer? Par to the reason beer is a great marinade for beef, is because it softens up tougher cuts. I often soak top sirloin in beer for 3 to 4 hours before grilling. Suffice it to say, it makes said cut as tender as a wing, T bone or rib steak---no lie.  My point is that premium beer is made for drinking, not cooking. I've also tried to use wine for marinating chicken and steak fajitas, but it didn't turn out well in my opinion. Then again, I've also had purists suggest I merit death for not using strip steak, and marinating it in lime juice. They further assert that chicken fajitas don't actually exist as well.", 'Arcticwolf: Would I use premium wine in cooking? Define "premium" wine--or beer. Does "premium" mean expensive, and does expense = quality? Not always. The upper limit we spend for a bottle of wine is maybe $30 US. We buy what we like to drink; whether it counts as "premium" is not a consideration. The craft beers we buy, even the most expensive, cost no more than $3 US for a bottle, or about $7 for the equivalent volume of a bottle of wine. That does not strike me as extravagant. And if it provides the flavor I want for the dish, it\'s quite reasonable.  All ingredients should contribute positive quality and appropriate flavor to a dish. If they don\'t, the expense is wasted. Greater expense does not mean they will add greater flavor. But using cheap, flavorless ingredients does no dish any favor. And as for those "purists" who lambaste you for your basting habits: ignore them. Cook how you like.', 'the first time I saw a guy pour some beer from the can he was drinking onto a beef steak grilling on the BBQ - and then tasted it - I was converted - beef and beer - is a good combination !', 'Life is Most Important in Life is the most important truth in life. The violence needed to kill these animals was unnecessary and was not in the best interest of life in general. These animals were killed for the sole and unnecessary purpose of personal gratification. Pretending a truth doesn\'t matter is one thing. Pretending "Life", the first self-evident truth, the most important truth does matter is another.', 'It’s nice you think about this stuff, but no matter what, the basic rule of life is that it must consume life in order to exist. A nice recipe like this is a good way to do it!', "Humans are omnivores and your sanctimonious preaching won't change that evolutionary truth.", 'You could always restrict yourself to eating stones and dirt, but Swedenborg says they have souls, too.', 'Oh my gosh, what a delectable and enticing dish to make this weekend.  My husband read this article immediately after me and wanted to know when we were going grocery shopping to pick up the ingredients. Once again, the photography is spectacular and that third picture shown where the meat "absorbs all the oniony broth that surrounds it" is so luscious, I can practically taste the meat, the onion, the sauce. I\'ve always used red wine when making dishes like this one, but I think beer will add that special something to the overall flavor.  Cannot wait to try this recipe. WOW - I think you may have hit a grand slam on this one Ms. Clark.  Thank you for the idea and the recipe.']
summary: With only one comment criticizing the recipe, the majority of commenters loved the food. Commenters recount their first time tasting the beef and beer combo, one stating that they have been converted. Overwhelmingly, the commenters agree that beer makes the recipe, one claiming that just like bacon, everything is better with beer.
short_title: Headline: Warm, Hearty and Meant for Each Other   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Onions; Meat; Beer; Belgium   Snippet: A take on a Flemish carbonnade, this stew is braised in Belgian ale, which cuts through the sweetness of the golden-brown onions.
short_question: ['Warm, Hearty and Meant for Each Other  ']

query: There will never be another Arnold Palmer. But many of his endearing qualities can be found in the men competing at the Masters. Together they form golf’s composite King.
comments: ['I was at Royal Troon in 1962 when Arnold had an eagle on the dreaded 11th "Railway" hole, a par 5 that year, hitting a one iron, a two iron and sinking a 25 foot putt.  We loved him for more than that.  He went on to win The Open Championship by six shots and was carried of the 18th green on the shoulders of his Scottish fans.  Changed days!', 'Thanks.  A great story in time for the Masters. One thing stood put.  No mention of the Tiger as it relates to anything what Annie stood for - as indicated in this article with other golfers. Anything significant?? Or should I conclude that both Annie and Tiger are in class by themselves - no need to compare.', "My Dad loved watching Mr Palmer play, and I loved sharing the watching with him. I treasure seeing the moments of joy Arnie put on my father's face.", 'I was born in Latrobe, PA, my dad worked there in a steel mill, and I grew up about 10 miles away in the mountains. We often stopped at that Latrobe airport to watch planes take off and land.  My grandfather, a machinist and farmer, looked liked Palmer, and had a similar slightly stooped posture, and the same lines on his face. A lot of them men there did in the 1960s and 1970s, from working so hard. My grandparents, about the same age, thought he was the king.', "After decades of courses closing and fading interest, its time for this hobby to go away. It is far too expensive and there's too much water and space being wasted just for rich people to hit a ball around.", "I'm not a golfer, but my dad was, and Arnie was his all-time favorite. There was even a strong physical resemblance between the two (which unfortunately didn't extend to my dad's game). But I suppose because of his affinity for the man, some of it rubbed off on me, too. Arnie remained a fan favorite long after he won his last tournament largely because of his humble, open and generous nature, a philosophy which just about every modern athlete would be wise to emulate.", "I was 14 years old in 1970 when Arnold Palmer arrived at the golf club just north of San Francisco where I was a caddy. He descended in a helicopter to land in the parking lot. He was there to do an exhibition for a group of businessmen. My friend Jeff was chosen to carry Mr. Palmer's bag while my brother and I were allowed to follow along with the 30-40 excited golfers. He played about 9 holes and then did a short seminar on hitting from the sand trap on the final hole. Then it was over and all the men (I don't remember any women) went off to the men's grill to have lunch. But then I spotted Mr. Palmer walking by himself and I got up the nerve to approach and ask for his autograph. Nobody else was around. I thought it was so strange. Here is the greatest golfer of his time and one of the most famous people in the world and he's taking his time to sign my card and say a few words. I remember he had large hands like a working man's, they didn't seem to belong to a golfer. And that he was so normal. Standing next to him I was completely at ease. He had the manner of a favorite teacher or uncle. He was a real gentleman.", 'Karen, what a great piece. Thanks.', 'Fantastic article!', 'And Arnold Palmer could hit a golf ball 350 yards, using an actual wooden headed driver in 1950.  As I recall, so could Sam Snead. But Palmer was the first real superstar because he became a champion in the age of television. Great player!', 'Anyone playing golf could be getting some exercise. If you consider golf exercise, then you really need to get in shape.', "I wonder what Palmer thought of Tiger Woods. Guess I'll have to read Callahan to find out.", "Today's golf stars are amazingly talented. They make the game look easy, but that's an illusion. I respect their talent. Still, they seem interchangeable. Rarely do they say anything memorable.", "One thing you neglected to say about Phil M is that he's playing with an auto immune disease called Psoriatic Arthritis. This debilating disease robs its host of doing such trivial things as walking, let alone swinging a golf club. I was never a big fan of golf but have become one to watch Phil as I too suffer from the same disease. Watching Phil play encourages me to try harder. If Phil can do it, I can try.", "I had the privilege of not only caddying in Mr. Palmer's group in 1967, but also playing his Latrobe Country Club on the day after his death last fall. Neither experience will ever leave me.", "Golf is strictly a rich man's sport, who even wants to hear about it anymore, let alone care.  All the water wasted to keep the grass green should be put to something useful.  Better to just leave it in the ground than wasting it by pumping it out.", 'Karen: Your journalism is the best, just the very best. In my view, you are the Herbert Warren Wind of your generation. Thank you so much.', "i don't like golf really. but a gorgeous day at torrey pines in the early 80s when arnold palmer looked me right in the eye is a memory that will stay with me forever.", 'As a life-long golfer of a certain age who watched and admired Palmer over his career, whenever I\'m in trouble on the golf course I always ask myself:  "What would Arnie do?"   Then I hitch up my pants, I get a glint in my eye, the confidence flows through my body and I proceed to hit a massive hook, slice, worm burner, chili dip or some other awful shot.   See, I know what he would do but I can\'t do it.  That\'s why he was Arnold Palmer and I\'m not.  Alas.', 'One of the most famous men in America and perhaps the world.', '"iced tea and lemonade" It didn\'t hurt Arnie\'s legend that he had the first great sports agent in Mark McCormack, who was so brilliant as to copyright the name "Arnold Palmer" for Arnie\'s favorite drink of half iced tea and half lemonade.  Ka-ching!  Has there been any other athlete so beloved that, as with Arnie, people not only not resent that they\'re paying into his estate when they buy an Arizona Iced Tea Arnold Palmer, but find it appealing?', 'Karen, a beautiful tribute, to Arnold and the players profiled here.  Difficult to read through the tears, though.  Thank you for this.']
summary: Commenters are praising the homage paid to golfer Arnold Palmer, some also praising the journalist who wrote the article. Several commenters report encounters with the player, saying he was a pleasant person. One commenter said he was inspired by it when he needed to make a decision in golf and didn't know what to do.   Another comment says he doesn't like golf and considers all the water that is used to water the grass on the golf courses a waste.
short_title: Headline: It Only Takes a Small Army to Equal Arnie   Keywords: Masters Golf Tournament; Palmer, Arnold; Johnson, Dustin; McIlroy, Rory; Mickelson, Phil; Pampling, Rodney; Schwartzel, Charl; Snedeker, Brandt; Spieth, Jordan; Stenson, Henrik; Golf; Watson, Bubba   Snippet: There will never be another Arnold Palmer. But many of his endearing qualities can be found in the men competing at the Masters. Together they form golf’s composite King.
