short_question: ['It Only Takes a Small Army to Equal Arnie  ']

query: In his final speech, Gov. Chris Christie spun a rosy tale, boasting a litany of accomplishments seemingly at odds with his constituents’ current view of him.
comments: ["I have lived in NJ all my life.  Governor Christie was not the evil, self-centered person your Digital reporter reported. He did what was required to try to keep our tax rate as low as possible and sometimes it took a lot of patience to offset the constant criticism from the unions. newspapers and Democrats. The bridge issue resulted in a traffic jam, but no one died or was injured as a result.   It's often a daily occurrence.  The journalist Corasaniti declared that NJ's unemployment was a poor 4.9 percent vs. USA 4.1.  NYS unemployment was 4.8 percent in 2017, hardly better than NJ,", 'Hit the road!', 'Mr. Christie probably would have made a decent governor, he is smart and politically is more of an old-style Republican who understands the need for effective government. He worked with Obama after Sandy and was dedicated to ending the heroin epidemic. His corruption was probably no worse than Cuomo\'s and a host of other politicians, though the private prison thing was a big strike against and of course his abandoning of NJ while seeking the presidency and kowtowing to Trump was inexcusable. And too bad he resorted to being a bully. I also believe he was not helped by how he looks. People will gang up on overweight people, once they have an excuse; it\'s a kind of prejudice. Just think of the widely distributed photo of his family on the beach. Given "permission" by Christie\'s unpopularity, people didn\'t hesitate ridiculing his "fat thighs". Maybe the whole bully thing was a kind of defensiveness.', 'Not one word about his biggest, despicable action?  No mention of Bridgegate, which was a travesty put on the shoulders of commuters for days, put people with health issues in danger, not to mention ruin the lives of two of his staff members, one of which was a single mother.  Did the thug, at least, pardon them before he rolled out the door?  Incomplete reporting.', 'Weep for New Jersey and what might have been: a nearly completed ARC tunnel for one thing.', 'Reviled by his constituents is as kind as one can be to this bag of wind.  It takes a special sort of inane hubris to waste 90 minutes of a legislatures time.', 'I guess he never did get to the bottom of bridgegate as he promised he would do.', "Hang on to your wallets New Jersey! Big man Murph is comin' to town, with grand and expensive plans. In 2 years you'll wish you had Christie back, because he's had his finger in the dike for the last 8 years. Hang on! JimF from Sewell", 'Well, if you liked Christie, you must be loving Trump.', 'Good riddance. Maybe now the tunnel construction can begin. Would have been completed by now if not for this useless blowhard.', 'Hmmm... No mention of Fort Lee, nor of indicted senior officials.  Odd.', 'Christie is a boastful bully, as self-centered as Trump except for a few more neurons to recognize his own bluff. Good riddance. New Jersey deserves better, no question about that.', 'Gone and immediately forgotten, a blowhard with a style and lack of substance right out of the Trump playbook.', 'Christie was a terrible governor, who did terrible policies and New Jersey stumbled along for 8yrs...the last year and a half of his governorship he was barely around as he crossed the country humping for Donald Trump after he gave up his own Presidential hopes. Christie is not a nice person, and I believe that was evident in his ungracious speech, dumping on his predecessors and being condescending toward the new governor. Over the years I have worked in a position where I meet and get to know the New Jersey governors ....Christie has been one of the worse. He earned the distain of the New Jersey voters by being arrogant, nasty and self serving...he will not be missed.', "Christie got a bad rap because he took on the Unions and had the nerve to ask teachers to contribute to their own health care.  There are old people in this state who have to give up the houses their great grandparents were  born in because they can't afford the ever rising property taxes.  Christie at least tried to rein in the some of the spending.   The last thing NJ taxpayers need to pay for is a redundant rail tunnel and  cancelling it was probably the best move he ever did. Even with Federal and State Funding,  NJ Transit is still highly dysfunctional. It has not the  equipment nor capability to fully utilize the tracks that are already there. (Amtrak is partially to blame for this also)    Let's hope Mr. Murphy will also show some  financial restraint as well.", 'Said by someone that never goes to NY.', 'Mr. Christie, Now that your Republican buddies in Washington have backed off a "commitment" to fund a new tunnel into New York do you finally see the error of your ways. You sold out the East Coast for your dream of being President and so you aligned yourself with the likes of Sarah Palin.  Now that New Jersey is going to be wrecked with elimination of the SALT deduction, and a failure of public transportation, your speech yesterday should have been a mea culpa followed by a long apology. No use ignoring the tunnel issue. It\'s what many will remember you for doing. You have been a bridge to nowhere.', 'Too many missteps destroyed a loyal American, I wish he and his family well!', "“I ran to be different,” he said. “I ran to speak bluntly. I ran to shine lights on all of New Jersey’s real problems.” Chris Christie Well done, Christie. You indeed shone lights on New Jersey's real problems, and you were state's number one problem from cancelling the Gateway project, through Bridgegate, to camping for almost a year in New Hampshire in preparation for presidential run, only to be followed by sitting on Trump's transition team. The last two activities were taking place while New Jersey taxpayers were paying your salary, in addition to millions of dollars that went into the wallets  of your private lawyers concluding that there was no collusion between you and Bridgegate. The New Jersey voters couldn't be more happy that their real number problem is no more.", 'History will not be kind to Christie. Nor should it be.', 'can he just fade away into well-deserved obscurity', "He and Trump have one thing in common:  loudmouth liars and bullies when it comes to politics.  And let's not forget that one reason the railways are the way they are in this area are due to Christie's decision not to go forward with the project once he became governor of New Jersey."]
summary: Almost every commenter has something negative to say about Chris Christie. They have criticisms of the actions he took while in power and his alliances with Trump. Many state that he is a bully and that he performed poorly as a politician and/or governor. Most do not wish him well, and some also hope they do not have to hear from him again.
short_title: Headline: Christie’s Farewell Offers a Glowing Look Back, With No Apologies   Keywords: State of the State Message (NJ); Christie, Christopher J; New Jersey; Trenton (NJ)   Snippet: In his final speech, Gov. Chris Christie spun a rosy tale, boasting a litany of accomplishments seemingly at odds with his constituents’ current view of him.
subreddit: ['State of the State Message (NJ)', 'Christie, Christopher J', 'New Jersey', 'Trenton (NJ)']
short_question: ['Christie’s Farewell Offers a Glowing Look Back, With No Apologies  ']

query: The International Paralympic Committee said that it would not restore the nation’s team to compete at the Pyeongchang Games, but that some athletes could compete as individuals.
comments: ['Please watch Icarus on Netflicks, all your questions will be answered. I think the other countries need to refuse to compete with Russians. Why would anyone at any level of sport want to compete against dopers? The Olympic committee is NOT protecting the games.', "The Olympics and FIFA are a joke. Russian athletes should not be competing. Period. I won't be watching either the Seoul Olympics or the FIFA World Cup.", 'Anyone who wants to see where the USA is headed under Trump, just check out Larry\'s comments here on behalf of Russia. Blanket denial and counter accusations of propaganda, without a shred of proof. Right out of the Trump playbook, It\'s just like a child saying "I know you are, but what am I?" As for this Russian team being banned, it looks like they have nothing to worry about, if the IOC\'s tepid, fake-ban of Russian athletes is any indication. They\'ll all still be there, with inadequate doping oversight, casting a pall over the events and taking medals away from more deserving athletes, just like always.', 'So even with something as innocent as the Paralympics is important enough for Russia to cheat.  And the Republicans in Congress and in the Trump administration continue to claim that Russia had nothing to do with our election. They must think the Russians believe the election is of far less importance than the Paralympics.', 'I think the Olympics have become a bit of a joke now.  I no longer have any interest in watching them.', 'Huge victory for putin!! Gives no ground on saying Mclaren is true and his athletes are in!', "It sounds as though readers haven't been following this story. It's all in the Oscar-nominated documentary Icarus:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qXoRdSTrR-4   You can watch it on Netflix today. Putin instituted Russia's state-sponsored doping program and, exactly as Trump would do, has declared all IOC investigations and findings baseless. Dr Rodchenkov is the Snowden of this story, the whistle blower who exposed the scandal to the world. Due to threats on his life, he's currently here in the witness protection program.", 'So, what changed? why now they can tell which athlete is clean which one is not? And if they could not tell that in the Rio Olympics how do they know that the athletes from other countries were clean? All this collective punishment looks like political game. After all there was no repercussion against the USA, when it turned out that American team used doping en masse for years. Yes,  individuals were punished but not the whole country.  Moreover, the medals won by Armstrong were not reassigned to other athletes. I am wondering why?', 'Putin and his government are beyond the deep abyss.  They have sunk so low in the realm of decency and morality that the Devil himself must be dancing around his bon-fire with glee.  A charred red carpet is awaiting them. But let us not so quickly throw stones at these folks on the road to perdition.  Our government - the way it is now under Trumpism - is in lock step with Mother Russia.  We are no better...for you see, this administration along with its Congress, exploits the weak and vulnerable from our seniors, to the poor, the sick, the disabled, the child, minorities, and to the refugee and immigrant.  We are lying to ourselves and no better than this president when we are blind to our own corruption and project it onto a hostile nation embraced by Mr. Trump.', "Putin obviously enjoys his nation's status as a pariah nation. The bar is so low now, anything else is the script from a National Lampoon movie!", "The difference in treatment of disabled athletes vs able-bodied is disturbing.  The athletes are who will suffer and in many cases I'm sure they had no idea they were being doped.", "Why do you think so? Do you think that disable athletes are more stupid than able-bodied athletes? or you think their wish to win is less than that of able-bodies athletes? if so, don't you think the Olympics itself is immoral, because it forces the disable athletes to suffer through grueling regime without appreciation of the reward?", 'Okay, so the Russians are so hell-bent on winning that they dope their disabled athletes?  There just are no words...', "with all respect, Russia is not accused to forcefully dope their athletes, disable or able bodied, but rather it is accused to cover their doping violations. Unless, you believe that the disable athletes don't have same free will as able body athletes, your outrage is just strange. I think it should be directed on the American cyclists team where people were pressured to take doping by the leader of the team.", "It's a new low, even for Russia, to take advantage of disabled athletes with doping. The Olympics has become a farce and a mere shadow of its intended purpose.", 'Just shameless. To me, the Paralympics embraces the Olympic ideal more than the Olympics do anymore. Anything competitive that Russia — and by extension Putin — touches somehow becomes sullied and tainted. National pride and ego run amok.', 'Really? They have been doping the disabled athletes?!!  How bizarre.', 'Has Putin learned nothing from his American protege?  Declare it all fake news and pardon everyone involved.', 'Doping disabled people.  You have to be kidding.  Jezzus!', "Can you believe the stupidness and total abomination of this action based on some Russian turncoat reportedly under United States control who accused his countrymen of doping over 4 years ago. Didn't some on the super Norwegian skiing team get caught using asthma steroid medication and they're skiing in the Olympics?.  All US contrived most likely", "Trump won't like you talking about the US like that, Mr. Putin.", 'The Russian whisleblower, Rodchenkov, was spirited out of Russia where he was in immediate danger of being arrested by the CIA, and he remains under their control in "an undesignated location" in the US. The allegations he made to WADA, also under US domination, formed the bases of the cases that the IOC used to bar the Russian athletic and para-athletic teams from Rio and now Pyongchang. For me, any campaign under CIA direction stinks.']
summary: Users respond to news of continuous Russia doping with anger, generally, and use see it as an example of how Russia deals with things in general. Many say Russia should be banned from competitive gaming, calling it especially low to have para-athletes dope, considering how the competition is specifically for disabled people. Some of the users point to the Netflix documentary Icarus as illuminating on this topic.
short_title: Headline: Paralympics Upholds Ban on Russia for Doping   Keywords: Paralympic Games; Olympic Games (2014); Doping (Sports); Russia; International Paralympic Committee   Snippet: The International Paralympic Committee said that it would not restore the nation’s team to compete at the Pyeongchang Games, but that some athletes could compete as individuals.
short_question: ['Paralympics Upholds Ban on Russia for Doping  ']

query: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles, including the Spelling Bee.
comments: ["Not really a spoiler alert since they're not legal answers, but to find Obama, Bannon, and Batman together was fun. Well, not really fun, more melancholic. Sniff. Anyway. But there's a legit Spelling Bee answer that can also be found (pluralized) in the Vowelless. Or the Vwllss. Wei-Hwa teased us last week with a good, tough Capsules, only to revert to one of the easiest...I barely lifted pen from paper. (Yes, I'm  a newspaper 'n' pen solver.)", 'Whirlpool is one of my favorite “middle” puzzles. [MAJOR SPOILER ALERT] PALEST/PALESTINE should have been a gimme, so I was surprised at myself for that one having been the last answer for me to get. I had to search for OREGON, REGIS and ASTROS.', 'Genius Points?', 'Points: 8,15, 22', 'Thank you!']
summary: All commenters enjoyed the Spelling Bee puzzle in the New York Times Magazine. One commenter enjoyed the combination of "Obama, Bannon, and Batman," also referenced the Vowelless, and solved the puzzle with a pen. Another stated their enjoyment of "middle" puzzles.
short_title: Headline: A Little Variety   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles, including the Spelling Bee.
short_question: ['A Little Variety  ']

query: The State Department notified hundreds of Yemenis they could enter the United States, but when the travel ban went into effect, they were rejected.
comments: ["So the message we are sending to the world is that America can't be trusted to keep its word. These people were told their visas were approved and then found out they weren't. Whether or not you think we should allow these immigrants in, you should be concerned about a government that yanks people around.", 'Yemen is a war zone and one of the worst humanitarian crises in the world now, with widespread food insecurity and a destroyed health care system.  If the Yemenis applying for visas have ties to legal residents of the US, they should definitely be allowed to com here, especially if they are women and children.', "Why does anyone anywhere believe what we say? Our president can't see straight, talk straight, read or comprehend policy. If the choice is class or crass, he chooses the latter.", 'People with seven kids or a heart condition can stay home. And before you get mad at me, those were the conditions prevailing at places like Ellis Island. They would have been sent home back then. Health care is not free. Only those of sound body should be let in here. This is a country not a hospital.', "You took the words right out of my mouth!  Let families unify in their homelands if it's so important to live near an uncle, for example. Meanwhile, people I know of Indian decent manage to visit back home quite frequently for weddings and when they're lonely for relatives. The US can't be expected to provide homes and schools and healthcare for all the world's needy. Does the Times not get that yet?", 'Doing what’s best for the USA. Putting Americans first. We owe the world nothing MAGA', "I am saddened by stories like this, and especially like Mr. Garcia's deportation.  I can only say that I'm so thankful the Government didn't treat my, and likely your, ancestors this way. If they did, it's doubtful we'd have the country we do today. Our ancestors who came here, and worked so hard, may have decided it's just not worth it.", "These sob story anecdotes to promote open borders are getting ridiculous. These are people who are going to go straight into the public trough, supported by taxpayer dollars, and may even bring some terrorists along with them. Let's take care of our own first - the unemployed, the sick, the homeless.", "@Chris - Your country doesn't care for its unemployed, the sick and the homeless. Your wish will fall on deaf ears in Washington, DC. But that you have no empathy for people fleeing the Yemen, a region bombed by US drones guided by some foolish militarists of YOUR country out of offices here in Germany (Stuttgart) is lamentable. Maybe you should inform yourself.", 'Yet more evidence that the United States is the least reliable international partner in the world today. And among the least humane.', 'What country allows someone with a heart condition to move there? Or someone with five kids?', 'A PRI 3/25/10 report by Mira Baz titled "Yemen Where Men Marry Children” gives the Yemeni attitude towards educating women and describes who marries whom.  Yemenis fear that education "risks turning their daughters into unmanageable wives”.  So, instead of seeing that their daughters are educated, they marry them off young.  Men pay dowries to their future fathers-in-laws.  Older men typically “buy" child brides.  It is not uncommon for a 30 year old man to marry a 13 year old girl. The man may have begun marrying as an adolescent.  The article tells about a young man who married a much younger bride, in his adolescence.  He was now tired of her, and planning to marry off their 8 year old daughter.  With the dowry that he expected from his daughter\'s groom, he would “buy” another wife for himself. Islamic law allows a man to have up to 4 wives. Yemeni culture is so very different from ours that it would be better for Yemeni refugees to settle in an Islamic country.  It would also be better for us to focus our attention and resources on our own people, such as the crime-ridden communities in Baltimore and Chicago.', 'Americans would be outraged if their citizens were treated this way by a foreign government. It’s too bad they aren’t holding their own government to a standard that would make them proud to be citizens of what was once a moral leader in the world.', 'We owe them nothing Americans first', "NY Times: This is an important story but it does not belong in the NY region news. This is national news. The Times' coverage of NYC is generally inadequate.", 'This whole xenophobia and desire to keep out people who are different than we are makes me both sad and angry. This country\'s richness comes, in part, from our being a nation of immigrants. Instead now we are a fearful country hunkering down trying to keep out anyone who thinks differently, dresses in other than "western" clothes, and/or has darker skin.  The claim of a "threat" is very much overblown. Yes, some adult offspring of immigrants have committed terrorism, but so too have many American of European ancestry - Newtown, Las Vagas, Aurora, Texas church, Oklahoma City - and this list goes on.', 'Yemen is the homeland of Osama bin Laden. It is the base of Al Queda on the Arabian Peninsula as well as having a long history of bitter internecine warfare.  Terrorism is a daily occurrence in Yemen; do we need to take the risk of terrorism from disaffected Yemeni immigrants?', 'I don\'t know where you get your information from but Yemen is not the homeland of Osama bin Laden and besides he is dead. The term "disaffected" has a xenophobic flavor that reads to me as unkind.  I wish you could visit my university and meet the wonderful Yemenis I know.  I am sure you would have a different view. It might make you happier to learn about great people sharing the globe with you and angry about how they are being treated.', 'Kudos for reading the Times. Shame for spreading misinformation.', "Osama Bin Laden's father emigrated from Yemen to Saudi Arabia.  The Bin Laden organization Al Queda on he Arabian Peninsula is a prominent poltical/terrorist  force in Yemen. Immigrants from Yemen pose a threat to America, hence the Trump travel ban. Thank you Mr. Trump for banning potential terrorists.", 'Bad faith decisions on the part of the US Government have become a commonplace reaction to promises made.  Who are we, really? Not who we like to think we are.', 'I am in favor of banning people coming into this country without first being checked......no one should be allowed to enter this country unless they have a profession or trade and are sponsored by a US citizen (someone born here).  Also, they need to check in with immigration every six months and provide proof of employment and/or college courses. Also, this country should establish quotas every year for all countries -- once the quota is filled, they cannot enter the US.....they will be put on a waiting list!', 'Quotas--ah yes, that worked so well for Jews because the US established quotas favoring white Northern Europeans at the expense of swarthy eastern and southern Europeans.  Northern European quotas went unfilled while US offices in Germany, Austria and eastern Europe were besieged by day-long lines of Jews trying to get out even though quotas were already full.  I should know--my grandfather was one of the last Jews to get out of Vienna in October 1939; my grandmother despaired of ever getting a visa and committed suicide in Vienna January 9, 1939.  Yep, quotas will be a great idea.', 'Your comments indicate that you are not very familiar with the visa process.  Rest assured, EVERYONE who comes to the US as an immigrant is thoroughly checked, especially from places like Yemen.  In fact, for a while and perhaps still, relatives from Yemen had to have DNA results to prove their relation ship to their sponsor.  Currently the only way to enter the US is to buy an immigrant visa - oops I meant invests a lot of money or buys luxury property here, be sponsored by a citizen (naturalized or natural born), or win the lottery.', 'Shameful!', 'Ok, I will just be honest. America should be the first and foremost. There are millions of Americans without insurance and they are waiting for helps. As a tax payer, I question the wisdom of bringing in more people. Heart condition, seven kids? Social welfare system should be based on an earned credit system. I was so mad when I heard this story yesterday from a colleague. There are immigrants who brought their aging parents to this country and their parents got free apartments and monthly allowance. Because the money is free and if they don\'t use it up it will be "wasted", they just buy stuffs for the entire families. Stop the stupid and wasteful chain migration and diversity lottery. Also health check-up should be part of the scoring system of a new immigration system. I am sorry that I might be sounded heartless. But enough is enough. We should not be taken advantage of any more. If you need helps, please earn it first. This is what I know after been here for more than 25 years. There is no free lunch. I must work hard to support my family. I want to be helpful but it must be fair. America is the land of opportunities for immigrants. But social welfare system should not be part of the opportunities!', 'Not heartless at all but definitely in keeping with Oregon history--the state was established as an all-white preserve.', "Why is it okay to immediately call all people from Oregon racists? Where did JC say anything about race? Why is even the slightest hint that perhaps we can't take in a billion people immediately met with such fury from the Dems?", 'Was a Union State during the civil war, the war that freed the slave']
summary: The majority of commentators are outraged that someone with a heart condition or many children would be allowed into the country, saying that people like that soak up resources. Several commentators criticize the government for deporting the man. One commentator is openly pro-immigration. One commentator reports about people marrying children in Yemen.
short_title: Headline: ‘Your Visa Is Approved.’ Then It Isn’t.   Keywords: Immigration and Emigration; Visas; Yemeni-Americans; Citizenship and Naturalization; Executive Orders and Memorandums; State Department; Djibouti; Yemen; New York State; Trump, Donald J; United States Politics and Government   Snippet: The State Department notified hundreds of Yemenis they could enter the United States, but when the travel ban went into effect, they were rejected.

short_question: ['‘Your Visa Is Approved.’ Then It Isn’t.  ']

query: An uptick in green cards illustrates an effort to draw more investors and celebrities, but for other foreigners, residency restrictions have increased.
comments: ['They do have massive illegal immigration - from the countryside to the cities.  Many illegals live in the city doing work that the cities depend upon, but without legal protection or services, such as rights to education for their children:  http://factsanddetails.com/china/cat11/sub72/entry-4473.html', 'Sorry, where is the line for applicants for permanent residency in China?', 'Has Trump done that to you? Canada is closer and much easier.', 'Glad you asked, "JFK."  All along the Yunnan-Vietnam border.', "China during Mao's Communist control closed itself inwards, not allowing people  to leave nor enter.  It held the long traditional belief that Chinese are intelligent and independent and capable of sustaining itself without trade or contact with outsiders.   It is fundamentally still a closed society in terms ethnic purity.  However, the sons and daughters who have left China often prefer to remain overseas to enjoy the freedom and prosperity afforded by countries with an open immigration policy.  The sum and total is that China exports far more than gain in talents as long as it imposes such strict residency rules.  China is a good copier, but a bad inventer. As to the current clamor of limiting immigration both in Europe and US, using the erroneous claim of difference in cultures as a reason, it is nothing more than fear of strangers in their midst, the hatred and distrust of someone different, a tribal identity of primitive society.   America has been successful in building a multi cultural society because we gain more than we lose. As no culture, political ideology, nor religion is perfect, we learn to respect our differences.  (We hope President Trump will someday gain the wisdom to embrace all immigrants to America.)   Limiting new immigrants who brings in new ideas, energy ultimately limits China from becoming truly innovative and democratic as a nation.  Nativism causes societal regression to any nation looking to building a Wall.", 'Language has not been mentioned in this discussion by Chinese is recognized as one of if not the most difficult to learn in the world. English is exposed to all educated Chinese in school but is not a live language for most. There are more than fifty million Diaspora lives in Asia; more than two million have followed China’s sprawling supply chains as far as South America and Africa. China is thus becoming more homogeneous at home while blending with societies beyond its borders. It would be in China’s interest to attract some of the category back but even there language can be a problem as Mandarin is not what many know. And the unique problem: Thousands of wealthy Chinese politicians and industrialists have fled with their often ill-gotten gains to Canada, the United States, and Australia, among other countries. Rather than sending the IRS, China dispatches covert agents of the Ministry of Public Security to intimidate these rogue citizens into returning home— before they seek asylum and U.S. citizenship or other.', "China is wise to limit the number of outsiders in, and one can only look at certain European countries that are losing their ethnic identify by allowing refugees in who are 100% the opposite in everything from ethnic background, religion, to cultural beliefs.    One need only look at Brexit and how many vote for Britain to leave the EU, believing the influx of non English speaking, non Christian, newbies were watering down what Britain had always been.   And don't think its just the Chinese.  How many western, non Muslim newbies are allowed to take up resident in Iran, Saudi Arabia and other conservative Muslim countries? Not that one would want to.....", 'We are in a race with China to import as much skilled talent in the world as possible. With "extreme vetting" and all the hysteria he has invented to sell it Trump has just shot us in the foot.', 'China is not taking any refugees but it can with its prowess in construction be of major help in restoring the homelands of refugees from Syria, Iraq, Yemen, Somalia, Sudan and Libya and leverage cessation of bombings as a permanent member of the UN.', 'I can\'t blame the Chinese. They can see how immigration is destabilizing both Europe and the United States. They have not taken any refugees, either, and nobody is denouncing China, 98% ethnic Chinese, or Japan, which has taken no refugees, either, and 98% ethnic Japanese, and which also has very restrictive immigration policies,  as "xenophobes, Islamophobes " or "racists." Even the New York Times reserves these denunciations exclusively for Americans and Europeans.', 'China and Japan respectively are very different countries from Europe( western) and the US.  The former has no shortage of skilled workers now or in the foreseeable future.( skill is gained by training not by birth!). Japan has been going through post-industrial economic downturn for many years ( like the U.S.) and shrinking population on top. In both cases unlimited immigration though sounding noble is hardly the solution.', 'point well made. Those in western nations that oppose immigrations are derided while those in CHina are not. It shows who the true racists are.', "I would just like to point out that China has 56 native ethnic minority groups, but your point still stands without the nuance. However, I would like to say that it isn't true that China and Japan are not at all seen as xenophobic or racist. There is a lot of discourse - maybe more in East Asia than USA - about how East Asian societies tend to be very inward-looking and wary of outsiders (euphemisms for racist and xenophobic). In fact, experts in their own countries have criticized the government for not pushing hard enough for the acceptance of immigrants. Rest assured, xenophobia in any country will be called out somewhere by someone.", 'I hope no one expects China to follow the US in how it conducts its green card or naturalization program. Currently, China has a different need in a different time in history. They are simply looking after its own national interest the same way the US has. In terms of which one is better is not for us to decide as time will tell. As China emerges as a world leader, its immigration needs may change which may be dictated by economics and labor needs. Not that we will, but let us not jump into conclusions and start meddling or dictating how China should run its immigration policy.', '"encouraging the top, controlling the middle and limiting the bottom", "address labor shortages by bolstering fertility rate", it\'s all so... utilitarian.  It\'s a testament to the global triumph of an economic cost/benefit thinking that has permeated everything and has led to an overemphasis in the three global wealth blocs China, USA and EU in thinking of people (immigrants and emigrants) solely in economic terms, without considering other - humanistic, moral - reasons. China\'s ABC-foreigner ranking, USA\'s wall-building and EU\'s Turkey "deal" come to mind.  The only government and leader from whom I\'ve heard a rhetoric that goes beyond discussing migrants in purely economic terms is the German government and Mrs. Merkel, whom invoked humanitarian grounds to permit refugees to Germany (granted, "wir schaffen das" is far from perfect). How things have changed.  Just an observation.', 'Would it be nice that a country has self-determination? The U.S. immigration system is not only eroding what it is to be an American, it is also eroding what it is to be a Chinese, a Somalian, or a Haitian... (because people nowadays think "oh, I can just immigrate to America). Stop mass immigration, it\'s confusing.', 'These Immigration policies in China will fail because the have conflicting goals - racial identity vs. desire for foreign workers.  America abandoned that option in the 1960s and put it\'s faith in the belief that migrating to the US was a life changing act that transformed the migrant.  We believed the distance between the migrants and their home countries forced them to make the "entrepreneurial" choice of abandoning old cultures and assimilating into their new world.  There was a survival instinct at play.  To survive in America you had to became "American"  That included hard work, learning English, and personal sacrifice - culture was not an option. The challenge today is that technology has reduced the distance to any country in the world to mere hours.  We now have large number of very hard working migrants living within walking distance of their old homes and some have became comfortable transferring their lifestyles to the US.   What is we need now is an open discussion on what America will look like in the 2020s and beyond not nostalgia for the 1950s.  If we could ALL hold off on the urge to indulge the highly vocal xenophobic minority, we would realize most Americans (including recent immigrants) want a mature discussion on where we are heading as a nation of immigrants and whether the old assumptions are still relevant.  Donald Trump would earn my respect if he could ignore the "noise" and make that discussion the theme of his first State of the Union.', "Encouraging highly skilled talent to move into China is both practical and smart. China still has a large migrant workforce--they don't need more low-skilled laborers. There are millions of people in the countryside who are trying to move into the cities and can perform low-skilled labor. Of course it would make sense to attract talent that there is a shortage of. China is not the only country that does this--America has also placed more importance on highly skilled talent for immigration purposes at one point as well. Many other countries have as well. There will always be low-skilled labor workers around but highly skilled individuals are hard to come by.", "I have always been wondering who invented the myth of immigrants take the jobs ' regular Americans' don't want.  I have yet to meet one such American.  Mimi Zou's rather simplistic analysis seems to follow the same outdated diagnosis that ignored the real problems of post industrial world by implicitly suggesting mass immigration is the solution?!", 'Encouraging highly skilled talent to move into China is both practical and smart you do know that China is a very homogeneous racial nation that does not espouse multi-culturalism?', 'Like almost every country in the world, China regulates  who are legally allowed to settle there. So why all the noise about the deportations from the current President of the USA?', 'because there are racists who condemn white people who desire to limit immigration into primarily European nations while simultaneously refusing to condemn the Chinese for refusing to permit wide scale non-Chinese immigration into China.', 'Because here in the wild West we need those immigrants.', '@yoda “,,,for refusing to permit wide scale non-Chinese immigration into China.” It is difficult to get a work permit (Z visa) and even a tourist visa does not come easy but is there any evidence of demand for wide scale non-Chinese immigration into China? The overseas Chinese who wish to come probably have little difficulty unless they happen to work for the N.Y.Times. The West earned its reputation when it did come in the 19th C and after.']
summary: Many commenters note what a closed society China is, and one commenter describes them as a "good copier" but "bad inventor." One commenter suggests that getting highly skilled talent to move to China is a smart move, but another notes that immigrating workers conflicts with national identity goals. One commenter notes how everything, including immigration, is discussed in economic rather than humanitarian terms, and another agrees that immigration should be limited. One commenter notes that European countries are losing their ethnic identities. A commenter suggests that China aid other countries.
short_title: Headline: China Wants to Attract More Foreigners (at Least of a Certain Kind)   Keywords: Immigration and Emigration; International Labor Organization; China; Labor and Jobs; Foreign Workers   Snippet: An uptick in green cards illustrates an effort to draw more investors and celebrities, but for other foreigners, residency restrictions have increased.

short_question: ['China Wants to Attract More Foreigners (at Least of a Certain Kind)  ']

query: Italy’s cooks have a long tradition of transforming vegetarian staples like potatoes and pasta into filling, fragrant one-pot meals.
comments: ["What's with the 2-starch-yikes comments? It's not like the recipe says you must eat at least so much of the potato and so much of the pasta. Just eat only as much total carbs as you would eat and enjoy at any other meal -- no? Sounds like a delicious recipe to me.", 'Made this for dinner.  I threw in a piece of parsnip and a piece of broccoli that were lying around the fridge.  I thought the paprika might be overpowering so at the last minute I added grated orange rind.  My spouse (normally spice averse) thought it was great and said so three times (!) during dinner.  Would be excellent with  meat added or beans as well.  Excellent basic recipe that invites tossing in stuff.', "To all those carping about this double-carb dish: lighten up.  The author did suggest some substitutes for one of the carbs - didn't you read that? Most of us reading and commenting in the NY Times are fortunate enough to enjoy a wide array of food choices - which may include the occasional carb-heavy comfort food. We don't have to rely on a steady diet of such cheap and satisfying dishes.  But we still can appreciate the ingenuity of poor people - mostly women - who created delicious dishes out of meager resources, and still do so here and throughout the world.   And we certainly can still enjoy a dish like this on a dreary winter evening - and the fact that it's inexpensive and easy to make doesn't hurt, either.", 'When I was a kid growing up in Queens we called double carbs a potato and egg hero.', 'This was incredibly satisfying. I added more paprika and water, let it cook for much longer and cooked the pasta seperately as it was for later in the evening and I wanted it to remain brothy.  I usually finish with a squeeze of lemon.  Would also be delicious with chickpeas!', "Definitely a winter survival food.  I had many variations of this at my grandmother's table and loved it all. Try chickpeas instead of potatoes. Any leafy vegetable is worth a try.  Escarole of course.  I use spinach from time to time, but my grandmother did not. Flavoring is key. A few tablespoons of leftover tomato sauce with meat drippings. If you want to avoid meat flavor, there are many pepper and hot sauces to try. Also cook the pasta shells first, then add them to the soup. Putting hard pasta shells straight into a soup is a no-no.", "For all those complaining about the starch-on-starch:  you can always add greens, as the author did - escarole, spinach, any of the dark greens - plus any beans you might have around. The author also mentions tomatoes - can't hurt! If you're carb-averse, you can substitute parsnips for the potatoes and use one of the low-carb or non-grain or high-protein pastas that are now available. Another great way to add protein to a soup like this:  serve it with a fried or poached egg or two on top. Dishes like this are a good way to make use of small amounts of leftover meat that wouldn't be nearly enough for a meal but add flavor and protein. Soups have always been a way that thrifty cooks recycle and stretch food resources into satisfying meals.  Perhaps this concept is alien now that many of us in this country waste so much food. But if you're on a tight budget or just hate waste, this is a good way to go - and it's delicious.", 'Some people have such a delicate regard for their health when it comes to diet, criticizing a dish as wholesome as this one just because it has pasta and potatoes together. You can go a whole day without eating anything. Just move your body. You have enough *#&@! nutrition.', 'Would people please stop with the Parmesan rind idea, the rind is coated in wax.', 'From the source (of Parmigiano Reggiano): "Parmesan cheese is completely additive free and the rind do not contain any waxing or coating, it is made of cheese. The Parmigiano Reggiano rind is formed during the brine stage, when the wheels are soaked in water and sea salt for 21 days. In our region is custom to store the rinds in a fabric bag at the bottom of the fridge. "Once you have build up a decent cheese rinds you should start worrying about what to do wit them. You should scrape them a little with a knife and remove a thin layer of the external part. After all it was its protection and it have been touched and handled in different environments so better remove the impurities. Once you have cleansed the cheese rind you can cut it in small cubes and add it to Minestrone or virtually to any soup. Once you have cooked it do not discard the rinds but serve them with your soup, by cooking them they become soft and chewy, in fact one of our childhood favourites." https://www.emiliadelizia.com/tag/how-to-use-parmigiano-reggiano-rinds/', 'If you own a knife you can solve the wax problem by cutting it off.  Just saying.', "No way. If it's real Parmigiano-Reggiano, there's no wax on it.", 'Throw a rind that you save from a good Parmesan into the soup and fish it out at the end. Adds a lot.', "Starch on starch concoctions can be yummy.  Melissa Clark's recipe of pasta with roasted parsnips comes to mind.", '@ Marc New York Allow me to disagree with you: I believe that parsnips, turnips, squash, etc., are for a hunger diet.', 'Now did you try the roasted parsnip dish or are you pulling up something from your distant past?  I thought the roasted parsnip dish was wonderful.', 'Oh yes.  This is a perfect dinner for tonight.  Thank you.  Once again, NYT Food to the rescue!', 'Sorry, but I am not enthused by this recipe. Potatoes and pasta are pure carbohydrates filling the stomach and feeding the temporary hunger. I would rather have them not in a thick soup, but skillet-fried and sprinkled with grated sharp cheese. Nevertheless, bon appétit to all who will like this dish.', "It's OK to have a little pasta and potato in the same dish", 'Better to replace the potatoes in the soup with cannellini beans or lentils. If you use whole wheat pasta, that makes a complete protein.', "It's not uncommon in Sicily and other parts of Italy to have a pasta and potato dish.  first of all, there's nothing wrong with it, and potatoes are loaded with vitamins, minerals, and fiber.  Millions of people grew up eating this way, and their ancestors are here to tell the tale and are doing rather well, thank you very much. https://en.julskitchen.com/vegetarian/pasta-with-potatoes-south-italy", "I'm not keen on starch-on-starch concoctions. Give me pasta. Give me potatoes, but not both. It's like putting potatoes on pizza. Why?", "Italian peasant food is generally simple and satiating. Has anyone ever had gnocchi?! It is potato pasta made with both flour and potato. This soup, while lovely as it is, could easily be made with white beans instead of the pasta or the potatoes but that is not the point. There are so many recipes at your disposal here if pasta e patate is not for you that's fine but there is no need to debate its value. We all come to the table with our own preferences and food culture.", "Gianna, Guanna, good points.  For anyone who's so upset by the idea of pasta and potatoes or carbs or fat or whatever is delicious - as opposed to your concepts of ideal nutrition - no one is forcing you to read this, let alone eat it.", 'Darn, Portland OR, not Portland ME. Potatoes on pizza is divine. Especially with some nice herbs and bacon and sharp cheese.', '"As for the double-carbohydrate, starch-on-starch nature of this soup, I regard it as a satisfying win-win." Bless you for that. And yes to escarole over kale.', 'Instead of kale - you could use escarole - definitely an Italian ingredient!', 'To die for!', "Back Ina time when lawns weren't sprayed with pesticides and herbicides my NaNa would be out digging dandelions for their leaves.", "yum. it's also vegan."]
summary: Commenters come to the defense of this carb-laden soup. Many appreciate the soup for what it is: satisfying and traditionally Italian. They point out the nutritional benefits of the potatoes and even offer alternative ingredients that can replace one of the starches for those opposed to two starches.
short_title: Headline: A Satisfying Soup From the Italian Pantry   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Pasta; Soups; Potatoes; Italy   Snippet: Italy’s cooks have a long tradition of transforming vegetarian staples like potatoes and pasta into filling, fragrant one-pot meals.
short_question: ['A Satisfying Soup From the Italian Pantry  ']

query: Each extra serving of fruits and veggies is associated with a 4 to 8 percent lower risk of developing lung disease.
comments: ['Good advice - blueberries in particular.  We are what we eat.', 'We routinely measure vitamin C in our clinic and find that smokers tend to have low vitamin C levels.   This has been reported in the medical literature. Dr Chow found that not only is vitamin C (ascorbate) low in smokers, Vitamin A (beta carotene) is also low. See Chow, C. K., et al. "Lower levels of vitamin C and carotenes in plasma of cigarette smokers." Journal of the American College of Nutrition 5.3 (1986): 305-312.   Replenishing these vitamins in smokers by diet modification (eating more fresh fruits and vegetables) and/or  inexpensive supplements makes sense. For more see:  http://wp.me/P3gFbV-qL jeffrey dach md', 'Thanks, as a former smoker (quit 19 years ago), i have come to enjoy fruits and veggies on a daily basis. Put another way, I ate such occasionally when I smoked, now I eat them daily. Now I learn consumption of such is a benefit -- time for a bowl of blueberries.', 'Neat to have the effect quantified. All the more reason to eat your fruits and veggies!', "Very cool, thank you. Also predictable, boring  and did the study control for the ever important 'good posture ' variable?", "Yet another medical study with 0 female subjects. Who remembers the day when we believed women didn't get heart attacks? How many women have died as a result of incomplete medical research? I suppose our lives aren't worth the inconvenience.", 'Action Plan: 1. stop smoking today. 2. eat your broccoli and apples/oranges/bananas.', 'While eating considerably more fruits and vegetables than most Americans currently do may not help non-smokers reduce chances of lung cancer, the benefits of a more plant-based diet have extraordinary health benefits generally.  Hence, all health articles should encourage the increased consumption of fruits and vegetables in lieu of animal-based products whenever possible.']
summary: Most commentators agree that the advice for smokers to eat more fruits and vegetables is solid advice. Two commentators note that a plant-based diet, in general, would improve health outcomes. One commentator notices that there were no females involved in the study, as if they can't get heart disease. One commentator cites an article about smokers being low in Vitamin C.
short_title: Headline: Eat: Smokers, Eat Your Vegetables   Keywords: Smoking and Tobacco; Vegetables; Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease; Emphysema   Snippet: Each extra serving of fruits and veggies is associated with a 4 to 8 percent lower risk of developing lung disease.
short_question: ['Eat: Smokers, Eat Your Vegetables  ']

query: The tension between justice and vengeance is the subject of Martin Zandvliet’s tight and suspenseful feature, which is up for best foreign language film.
comments: ['A terrific film. Well worth watching.', 'I was ultimately disappointed in the film.  The role reversal of oppressor and oppressed was quickly understood and easily felt.  The boys were young, thrown into a one-way, unjust and tragic situation and were never a threat to the Sergeant.  The suspense was ever present because death was imminent, just how much not known.   The emotional story is about the Sergeant’s journey, but the movie is shot objectively and key dramatic events happen with the Sergeant off screen (Sebastian and Werner with the little girl and the securing of the release papers) or are unexplained (were they not going to be fed for 3 months?), so the emotional impact of his actions is diminished.  The liberation was not liberating.  We were ahead of the Sergeant the whole way. Another movie reminding us that war is hell.  I did like the metaphor of the shifting dunes and the sequence of the boys almost "flying" over them.', 'Just seen the film and it justifies all awards, especially for the subtle change in Sgt Rasmussen\'s attitudes. A small point: his shoulder flash was in English "Parachute Regiment" (and he wore the red beret of the Paras).  The British 1st Para was sent to Denmark after the war, so does this mean that Sgt Rasmussen had served with the British military during the War ? And his German language was conversational.  I\'m aware that Danish and German are similar, but different ("thanks" in Danish is "tach"; in German it\'s "danke").  I\'m sure if he\'d remained behind occupied Denmark, he would have picked the language up - but then not served with the British. Any thoughts ?', 'Just saw the film and appreciate the difficulty of Sergeant Johannsen. Biggest problem was why was he tasked with the job of supervising the "kids" by himself? How is it possible not to allow ANY food for them? I was waiting for him to relate a dastardly German occupation story but none came. My granduncle was taken prisoner after he hid Jews in his attic in Dragor, Denmark and was tortured somehow, but we never here an y justification for Johansen\'s hard heart. Great tale.', 'On A. O. Scott\'s review of "Land of Mine," directed by Martin Zandvliet, Feb. 9, 2017. I haven\'t seen "Land of Mine." However, reading Mr. Scott\'s review of this film convinces me that nowhere in it does Sgt. Carl Rasmussen tries to learn from the very young German prisoners of the Allied forces in Denmark, individually, why they decided to enlist for Herr Hitler and risk their lives abroad fighting for him. Confidentially, each of them would have told him that their elders were told it was a patriotic duty to do so. They would also have told the Sergeant that they didn\'t understand Hitler\'s Nazism or his anti-Semitism. They merely obeyed a call to duty. In other words, their minds were poisoned with jingoism and racism.For the reasons above, we cannot call the German youths in the film the enemies of the allied forces. This would add weight to the film\'s underlying theme of moral ambiguities of war. I would definitely watch "Land of Mine" if it ever makes it to my state. I expect it to rub my face in the slime of reality that none of the other Oscar-nominated movies even try to. The young German POWs in "Land O Mine" remind me of the impressionable Muslim youths willing to die for ISIS today.']
summary: Commenters seem to enjoy the film overall, with one person saying the film was terrific and well worth watching, while another said that they had just seen the film and it was well deserving of all the awards it had won. There was one commenter who went on a rant and said they were ultimately disappointed with the film due to most of the key moments for the main character being off-screen or unexplained, but the overall consensus was that the movie was good.
short_title: Headline: Postwar Perils and Ethics on the Beaches of Denmark   Keywords: Movies; Land of Mine (Movie); Folsgaard, Mikkel Boe; Zandvliet, Martin Pieter; Moller, Roland (1972- ); Academy Awards (Oscars)   Snippet: The tension between justice and vengeance is the subject of Martin Zandvliet’s tight and suspenseful feature, which is up for best foreign language film.
subreddit: ['Movies', 'Land of Mine (Movie)', 'Folsgaard, Mikkel Boe', 'Zandvliet, Martin Pieter', 'Moller, Roland (1972- )', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)']
short_question: ['Postwar Perils and Ethics on the Beaches of Denmark  ']

query: John Higgins was harassed by fans for his performance in a game in which his bosses felt he performed well, illustrating referees’ often thankless task.
comments: ['Incomplete story without a description of the contested calls. Also NCAA should be insuring that their referees are not emulating European soccer referees, some of whom took huge bribes to affect match outcomes. Missed goal tending call would be good place to start. How did no one see the net rise well above the rim? The photographic evidence is there if anyone cared to look.', 'I did not see the game in question, so cannot comment on it. However, the NCAA official\'s comment that reviews show that 19 out of every 20 calls are correct, and the claim that a panel of officials review every NCAA tournament game can be deeply discounted. If you ever wander onto an "officiials" web site, you will quickly learn that no official makes a bad call - Ever!', "The criticism of officials is only going to get worse in the years to come because fewer and fewer young people are taking on the challenge of pulling on the stripes.  And why should they?  It's a profession with few rewards and an avalanche of criticism.  As the pool diminishes, so too does the quality of work.  If you think officiating is not up to par now, just wait a few years.", "Having refereed games in college (in intramurals, where the skill level is lower and the complaining greater), I feel for the refs. They have a very hard job. At least I didn't have the second guessing of the instant replay. I am constantly amazed at how many calls that, on first look are wrong, but turn out correct from a different viewpoint.", 'Thee pace of the Carolina-Kentucky game, especially when Carolina had the ball, was extraordinary.  And Carolina had its share of misses, leading to lots of contested rebounds.  When a shot is going up every 7 seconds, fans in the arena are unlikely to be able to follow the ball consistently enough to second guess the referees.', "The refs in last night's NCAA Title game seemed to think the game was about them. Whistling a foul on the slightest touch affected the outcome of the game and also made for a less than wonderful viewing experience. My wife finally gave up watching given the incessant foul calling and consequent numerous delays in the game.", 'I disagree the speed had anything to do with the UK-Kentucky game since the most obvious missed calls were one sided calls on UK that resulted in the best players to sit most of the game.  Also, when points are taken off the board for goal tending, it should be reviewed (it was not and would have made the difference in the final score).   This referee has a known issue with Calipari which should have been recognized and never been allowed to be selected. (Seth Greenburg noted this on his show after the game.)  Why escalate the issue by putting officials and coaches together that have a bad history?  The NCAA is as inconsistent on their referee selection as they are with not applying penalties to Universities that offer fake classes so their athletes can make better grades for 20 years.']
summary: Most commenters express support for referees and that they have a difficult job but that often their calls are correct. Some commenters talk about their experience being referees. One commenter says that the quality of work in referees is going to diminish in the next few years, and some commenters indicate that the quality of work has already gone down. Another commenter seems to insinuate that many referees are corrupt.
short_title: Headline: In Amplified World, Critics Take Aim at Referees   Keywords: Officiating (Sports); Basketball (College); National Collegiate Athletic Assn; Higgins, John (Referee)   Snippet: John Higgins was harassed by fans for his performance in a game in which his bosses felt he performed well, illustrating referees’ often thankless task.
short_question: ['In Amplified World, Critics Take Aim at Referees  ']

query: The chef plans a restaurant in the West Village where this food will be the focus and fresh.
comments: ['fantastic story. The world needs more people like Ms Admony.', "Mourad Lahlou's cookbook, Mourad: New Moroccan, also has his recipe for homemade couscous. Like Eina's process, very labor intensive, but the results are astounding. Or, you could just eat at his restaurants Aziza or Mourad next time you're in San Francisco {smile}.", 'Go Einat!', "Interesting, she grow up with Iranian and Yemenite home, they don't have couscous in the menu. I'm defiantly going to try it! good luck!", 'I grew up in a remote village of the Kabyle mountains of Algeria, where couscous was synonym of "food". We had no electricity or any mechanical means whatsoever. My mother ground wheat by hand in a stone-mill, the wheat was grown in a land plowed by oxen and the very word chemical was unknown to anyone around us. If you are looking to have the same taste couscous in New York today, forget it. You can\'t even have it in my little village which isn\'t remote anymore. They now have tractors and the old stone-mills are collected as souvenirs. They still "occasionally" roll couscous by hand, but most prefer the instant kind. Not quite the same taste, but close enough, except on special occasions when it is worth the trouble to roll it.', "The only place I've eaten couscous is Tangier. I suspect it would be a disappointment in NYC. I have yet to find authentic Moroccan food in this city.", 'There is also a recipe for hand-rolled couscous and instructions for steaming it, adapted from Paula Wolfert, in Emily Kaiser Thelin\'s new biography of Paula, "Unforgettable."', "Oh my God, Einat Admony!  I'm exhausted just reading this article!  Next time I'm in NYC I'll make a point of tasting your couscous.", 'Many years ago I could get real cous-cous and it was delicious, steamed over a liquidity lamb stew in an improvised couscousiere.  Then along came instant cous-cous, which is essentially devoid of texture and flavor, and it quickly forced out the real stuff - so I stopped making it. Sorta like stone ground grits versus instant grits.  Or steel cut oats versus instant oatmeal.  Convenience produces mush.', 'sounds like the fresh bread, perfect rice, perfect potato chip - steaming, fluffy, white - a childhood pleasure associated with the end result of time-consuming effort - part of the pleasure comes from the recognition of the effort gone into it']
summary: The commenters mainly express support for Ms. Admony and her making couscous from scratch. Some commenters say that it sounds like a lot of work, while another offers a recipe for hand-rolled couscous. Two commenters express doubt that authentic couscous can be found in NYC.
short_title: Headline: With Couscous, a Chef’s Patience Pays Off   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Couscous; Restaurants; Admony, Einat; Balaboosta (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant)   Snippet: The chef plans a restaurant in the West Village where this food will be the focus and fresh.
short_question: ['With Couscous, a Chef’s Patience Pays Off  ']

query: The Heinz History Center and the F. Julius LeMoyne House document Pittsburgh’s role in the Underground Railroad, but some sites, sadly, are gone.
comments: ['I have never been to Pittsburgh but now have a reason to go! Thanks for this article.', 'Three Rivers Park? I believe your referring to Point State Park, can we get the facts correct.', 'Good article. I grew up in Pittsburgh and attended kindergarten in an old mansion in Mt. Lebanon, a suburb of the city.  The mansion had several hidden rooms.  I remember opening a bathroom mirror, pushing the shelves behind the mirror open like a door and finding a room behind.  I have always wondered if that house was part of the underground railroad.', "We might have thought that the election of Barrack Obama evidenced the end of racism in our country.  But his successor, Donald Trump, has resurrected the  most vile and disgusting patterns of racism that have ever existed in America.  We are living in a culture of hate.   We hate the blacks who fight back against racial stereotypes cultivated at every level of government.  We also hate the Hispanics  who seek to defend their productive lives in our country and be given the right to become citizens.  There will be no immigration reforms. Instead, we will pursue with military efficiency the expulsion of as many Hispanics as possible, even those who have never been convicted of any criminal attacks.  We will ensure that blacks and Hispanics never have the right to defeat government of, by and for the benefit of white people.  Our only hope is that Republican business suffers irreparable losses as we subjugate or  deport millions  of workers who have helped to build our country's economy.", 'Not mentioned was the Point View Hotel on Brownsville Rd. Torn down about 10 years ago. It was one of the oldest buildings in the area. Very sad to see it replaced with an unneeded medical arts building. They also had the best fish sandwiches outside of The Original Oyster House.', "I grew up in Pittsburgh in the 1960s-70s and was never taught this. I had no idea about Pittsburgh's role in the Underground Railroad. What a shame!", "I grew up in O'Hara Township, just outside the city. My friend lived in an old farmhouse behind which was an old stable house. If you went around the back of the stable house there was a separate living quarters. He used to say that it was part of the Underground Railroad. Would love to know if that was true.", 'As is the case, I see, with others who have commented here, I too, born in 1948 in Morningside Heights in Pittsburgh (of parents who were both born in Pittsburgh), and educated at North Catholic High School on Mount Troy in Pittsburgh, never heard of the Underground Railroad when I was growing up, either at home or at school.  So I was fascinated to read this article.  I am imagining, as it is mentioned here that rivers played an important part in the UR, that the Monongahela River, which flows north into Pennsylvania from West Virginia, might have played an important part in escaped slaves getting to Pittsburgh.  I intend to learn more about this.  Thank you.', "I grew up in Sewickley, about 15 miles downriver from The Point, and recall stories told in my grade school of houses along the river that were part of the underground railroad. That was in the 1950s and 1960s, so I am very interested to learn of this part of Pittsburgh's history.", 'When you mention Three Rivers Park I had no idea what you were talking about. The name of the park with the fountain where the three rivers meet is called Point State Park.', "Worth noting Dr Ellis is August Wilson's niece, I think.", "This work is so important and these articles are great.  Thank you.  And thanks to everyone who works tirelessly to make sure the memory of this doesn't fade, we need to remember. We need to know.", "What an informative and important article! I grew up in Mt. Lebanon, Pa, a nearby Pittsburgh suburb, in the 1960's and sadly, don't remember ever being taught about Pittsburgh's importance in the Underground Railroad. I have a question: I don't understand what the author meant when she wrote that in the 1800s some businessmen supported the Underground RR because they feared the competition. I would appreciate further clarification on this point. Thank you.", "They feared the competition from the slave owners. If you could run a business and labor was free, you could sell the end product for less than if you had to pay the laborers. The businessmen in Pittsburgh didn't want to be undercut bc they had to pay for labor and the southerners didn't.", 'Ditto. I went to Baldwin High School at the same time, and this is all news to me. Welcome news!', "Thanks for your thoughtful article on Pittsburgh's importance to the Underground Railroad. One correction... the park you were in is Point State Park, not three rivers park.", "I just moved to Pittsburgh in November, and now that spring is coming, in looking forward to learning about my new city.  I didn't realize the strong connection to the Underground Railroad and I'm fascinated to learn more.", 'I lived my first 8 years in Wilkensburg Pittsburgh, then my parents moved north about 13 miles to Hampton Township.  When I was in middle school my favorite book was a biography of Harriet Tubman.  I read it so many times, the librarian went to the bookcase and took it out when I opened the library door.  She never mentioned the role Pittsburgh played for the underground railroad.  I wonder if she did not know either.', 'I grew up in Pittsburgh and knew none of this.  It was certainly not taught in schools....I hope that is no longer the case']
summary: Many commenters praise the article and vary in their familiarity with Pittsburgh. Many grew up there, one just moved there, and one has never visited. Several commenters express their interest in learning more about the region's role in the Underground Railroad. One commenter added the business logic for some businessmen's support of the Underground Railroad. Two commenters correct the name of "Three Rivers Park" as being "Point State Park." One commenter laments the resurgence of racism under Donald Trump's presidency.
short_title: Headline: History Preserved, and Not   Keywords: Historic Buildings and Sites; Blacks; Slavery (Historical); Underground Railroad (19th Century); Travel and Vacations; Wilson, August; Washington, Denzel; Obama, Barack; Monongahela River; Pittsburgh (Pa); United States; Fences (Movie)   Snippet: The Heinz History Center and the F. Julius LeMoyne House document Pittsburgh’s role in the Underground Railroad, but some sites, sadly, are gone.
