short_question: ['History Preserved, and Not  ']

query: A poet recalls a grittier era in New York from the vantage point of a subway station.
comments: ['Oh my. this poem has pushed some buttons. Hot on the heels of 70s hippies, tokes and spliffs, come the helpful neighbors and unlocked doors of the 50s and 60s--followed by a summary of the decline of certain Brooklyn neighborhoods with a dash of wistfulness for simpler times -- though one hopes this is not some Trumpian call to "Make Brooklyn Great Again."      Everyone is entitled to their own nostalgia, no? Ms. Galanter\'s poem, in a mere seven lines, isolates a time and place so keenly that you can taste it. The images may not be to everyone\'s taste, but they are true, real, succinct, and more vivid than the sentimental prose and poetry that purports to comment on it.      A poem is not an opinion, it\'s a living, breathing entity. Why not take it for what it is, what it wants to say, and then comment on whether it has succeeded or not?', "I grew up in Brooklyn in the 70s.  I saw kids play in the streets and not come home until they heard their parents calling for them.  I remember the screams of delight from the truck that had the half-moon ride that came around. I remember that after running errands with my mother, we would go to Brownie's for lunch and eat our sandwiches in Union Square Park and watch the squirrels.  I never saw a rat. I loved the 70s.", 'I was under the impression that there was a huge mafia presence in Brooklyn back then. Were they the ones that kept the neighborhood all sparkly clean? All those shops and movie theatres were "vibrant" as long as they paid for protection. I\'m kidding. Must\'ve just been the movies. More hogwash or something.', "Once, in the middle of the night, a mob backed drunken prizefighter drove down Sackett Street and dented a row of parked cars, including my fathers'. The next day a guy came by with the name of a repair shop that would fix any car damaged for free. Now that's neighborly!", "I remember the area you are describing.  My mother used to take me there for back-to-school shopping. I remember the Buster Brown on Flatbush and the Brach's around the corner on Church Avenue right near the beautiful theater.  It was a bustling commercial area (except for the churchyard, an historic island of serenity).  I don't remember the trash, but it is possible that I didn't notice, being all caught up in the experience of going there. I do know that I never experienced any fear or anxiety about going places or just being in my neighborhood, Kensington.", 'We once left our doors unlocked, We helped our neighbors shovel snow, And rake leaves, and mind the kids. This was the 1950s, the 1960s. Our families were working stiffs, But we read history. We were neighbors, We knew one another, And that what Brooklyn became later Was an aberration, A deviancy. Not really Brooklyn.']
summary: Several commenters suggest that life was in some ways more pleasant that many portray it, giving examples of a man offering to fix cars dented by a mob for free and how neighbors would help each other. Some share both positive and negative experiences that formed their memories of Brooklyn. Another commenter adds that all view experiences differently and have different ways of finding positivity in the midst of what others would deem unattractive.
short_title: Headline: We Were Ghouls   Keywords: Subways; New York City; Poetry and Poets   Snippet: A poet recalls a grittier era in New York from the vantage point of a subway station.
short_question: ['We Were Ghouls  ']

query: The strange soundscapes of an early electronic musician came with a whole philosophy of listening.
comments: ['Thank you, Claire-Louise Bennett! I first heard a recording of a work by Oliveros in 1969-1970: "I of IV", a stunning, wonderful, shatteringly refreshing electronic work on the Nonesuch album New Sounds in Electronic Music.  I too wish you had named some of her compositions, but you have written a wonderful little obit for her, and for that much thanks. I look forward to essays from you in the future. For those of you searching online for her compositions, there are CDs of her music available at various websites.', 'Wonderful essay and I am so pleased that Pauline Oliveros is getting some attention. Fantastic work.', 'Any recommended recordings? Thanks', "A lover of many different kinds of music, I've read more about Ms. Oliveros than I've actually listened to her work. This article encourages me to change that. Thanks!", 'Yeah, but what recordings specifically do you recommend people listen to of hers?', 'Wonderful piece of writing about the legendary Oliveros, for whom listening was a mode of being present. Thank you NYT for publishing this essay.', 'The music of Pauline Oliveros takes our ears beyond the concert hall and helps us explore the sounds around us. But more importantly, she teaches us to listen with our whole being, not just with our ears. Pauline knew all existence, all time, all dimensions and possibilities exist in the same moment and can be accessed via various patterns of energy.  Her presence at this moment in time will be greatly missed. Thank you Pauline for your great courage.', 'lovely piece - glad to discover her - now playing TT', 'This is a philosophical position that I would love to follow throughout my life! Thank you for posting this article!']
summary: Many of the comments praise the article and it's subject, expressing a strong appreciation for Oliveros and her music, including requesting more information and recommendations about the music. Several commenters go on to praise the talent of Pauline Oliveros and the beauty of her music.
short_title: Headline: The Recordings of Pauline Oliveros   Keywords: Music; Ears and Hearing; Oliveros, Pauline   Snippet: The strange soundscapes of an early electronic musician came with a whole philosophy of listening.
short_question: ['The Recordings of Pauline Oliveros  ']

query: In which we see Sam Ezersky’s handiwork two days in a row.
comments: ['My first post here, so I beg your mercy.  I\'d love to know the purpose of "wood" in the clue for 53D.  Is it the operative for making "tree\'s" an anagram?  If so, why?', "Paid extra for online puzzle access and spelling bee was not posted on Thursday night at 10 PM as promised. Last week's answers late too. What gives?", "This was a fun puzzle to solve. Schmos at 15D is correct but I don't understand why. Would someone explain, please.", "It's 2 abbreviations -- SCHool MOnthS.", 'WHO is the SCHMO that keeps using SEEPY words like YEASTY? YEABIG *only* because we "just had it" in another puzzle. Nice. I liked MLB with four A\'s. And adding G\'s to A BOOR.', "Deb's apology notwithstanding, I still don't like P&As. Give us more cryptics.", "A fun one.  Hadn't heard of BILL WIThERS.  Thanks to those who explained SLEDGED.", 'Bill Withers wrote and performed "Lean on Me," "Ain\'t No Sunshine," "Lovely Day," and "Just the Two of Us." You may have never heard of him, but you\'ve heard his music.', 'not sure why "Puh-lace to hide out" is layer. Or why basinboy has anything to do with spelling clarification. Any help?', 'They\'re meant to be heard in a drawl. The robbers have a puh-lace to hide out, it\'s their la-yer. basin boy is meant for B as in "boy," a way to make spelling clear (over the phone, etc.).', 'Puh-lace as in Place, layer as in lair. The last being a place to hide.', 'Very enjoyable, and not too TAXIng.', 'Can someone explain the answer SLEDGES at 45-down? Thanks for help understanding this one!', 'It\'s SLEDGED, and the idea is that these are words whose "edges" are the letters S and L. S-L-EDGED.', 'Each word in the clue has S and L at the "edges" of the respective word.', 'Thank you!!', 'I really have to admire the people who are good enough to solve these. Out of curiosity, I "Revealed" 6D.  I can\'t figure out what TONIC has to do with that actor. or with his name.', 'Gift tags generally say "TO" recipient and "from" gifter.  Actor NIColas Cage.  (He\'s not Nicholas.)', "LOL. All MY life I've had to explain to people that I'm Jerrold and not Gerald.", 'G+ALUBEH 7,14,21', "Thanks, Hector!  Somehow people seem to think hat even though we are paying for full digital access, that shouldn't include the spelling bee puzzle.  So unless someone posts it like you did, we just get told to subscribe to the full crosswords package too (I'm terrible at full crosswords, so it isn't much of a deal for me!) I don't understand why Deb is so head-in-the-sand on this, since ur full digital subscriptions certainly help pay her salary.  Sigh.", "Solved, but I still don't understand the clue for 1 across.  The most difficult cross for me was that young washroom attendant area.", 'I stabbed at this too, getting a person\'s name who is a leader but not understanding the clue.  Until:  Look at the "odd" (alternate) letters of "a great feast".  Groan. I actually liked "washbowl attendant".  Detested cluing for "s\'cut", especially with the cross for "kind of acting", which is not an anagram, nor a pun, and is an abbreviation, and doesn\'t seem to belong in the puzzle. Went slightly nuts with "in a decathlon\'s vicinity".  Had the start and the end, but the leeetle two-letter middle had me cross-eyed.', "I liked S'cut for S'LOPPED.  If you didn't, s'tew bad!", 'The IMPact of solving a lot of P&A puzzles is that you get that kind of acting as a matter of course.  There is nothing unusual in "a decathlon\'s" anagramming to CLOSEATHAND when the key word vicinity is supplied.', "Even though I don't do the PandAs and Cryptics, I still find it fascinating to read Deb's pieces about them. So now, about that BILLERS: I STILL can't understand it. How are you supposed to know that you should insert WITH into it?", 'BILLERS--It\'s "BILL" with "ERS".  Together, that\'s BILL WITHERS, who, in case you didn\'t know, is a well-known singer.', 'When I had BILL____ERS, the rest was easy.  Had I not known the singer, I might have needed more crossings.  AVOWS vs. AVERS held up one of those crossngs.', "For 5D: southwest eggs = SW OVA.  Then once you 'return' it, it becomes AVOWS."]
summary: Many commentators want some kind of help on the puzzles, such as explanations for certain clues or outright asking for answers. Several commentators voice their enjoyment of the puzzle. A few commentators give criticism for various parts of the puzzle. A few other commentators explain various clues and answers. One commentator got the puzzle late and is disappointed.
short_title: Headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: In which we see Sam Ezersky’s handiwork two days in a row.
short_question: ['Variety: Puns and Anagrams  ']

query: An awkward, soothing television tower, for Germans and expatriates alike.
comments: ['My recollection of the Fernsehturm: Visited Berlin way back in 1989, while living and working in Vienna. At the cafe up the tower, we attempted to take a place at one of the many empty tables. "No, those tables are closed," we were told. Not a way to profitably run a restaurant, keeping tables closed while there is demand. But this was during the time of the DDR.', "I enjoyed MS Oilers' appreciation of the Berlin Funkturm. While with the US Army stationed in Germany for over 20 years I traveled to Berlin many times. One of the things that was most interesting was that until the fall of the wall, Berlin was not considered part of Germany, neither the DDR (GDR) nor BRG (FRG). It was an occupied city. Crossing “Checkpoint Charlie” meant I (as a US Military personal) was only visiting our ally, the Soviets, in the eastern sector. All the restrictions and experiences I, or others in know have experienced as well. Ms Oyler did fully explain why the Funkturm was called “The Pope’s Revenge”. The story I heard was that after the war the Vatican donated several million dollars to rebuild the city’s bombed out churches. The money was used instead for erecting the com tower, hence the sobriquet, “The Pope’s Revenge”.", '"I enjoyed MS Oilers\' appreciation of the Berlin Funkturm." ------- The Funkturm is another tower, in the western part of Berlin, by the Olympic Stadium. It looks like a smaller Eiffel Tower. I haven\'t been able to find any mention of the Vatican donating money to rebuild churches "The Pope\'s Revenge" is just another example of the Berliners\' wry sense of humor.', 'I find the "golf ball" tower an architectural atrocity and wish it had gone the way of the "Palast der Republik." Communist regimes everywhere had/have this arrogance/inferiority complex which forces them to destroy the present in the name of some utopian future. That utopia never arrives.', 'Strongly recommend  the  " Funkturm"  the Radio Tower by the Exhibition grounds (Messe Berlin) in the Charlottenburg district built in 1924  iits 147 meter tower clearly inspired by the Paris Eiffel Tower. A miraculous survivor of the battle of Berlin. Funkturm was first used as an aerial mast and from 1929  transmitting Germany´s first televised images and in 1935 world´s first regular television programme.  During the Berlin blockade (June 1948-May 1949) it became again an aerial mast guiding the "candy bombers" to the Tempelhof airfield. During the Cold War Funkturm served as a beacon of freedom for the legendary Radio Free Europe. Today´s  Funkturm is a rather romantic  jewel in its own right with a wonderful restaurant  from every angle offering a  grand view of Berlin.', 'The Fernsehturm had another purpose. It allowed those within to spy on those below, and to act on those observations. In the days before Internet and satellite photography, observing movements along the streets with binoculars and telescopes was a vital part of policing the city.  In the case of a military invasion or an uprising it would have served as a vital military command post, as would the other Eastern bloc towers. To the younger generation it may be merely amusing but there is a darker side.', 'What a lovely story about an oddity of which I knew little.  I have not yet visited Berlin but hope the tower is still there when I do.', "I got off a train from Cologne in the late 80's early one morning and went to take a photo of the Berliner Fernsehturm. I was immediacy shouted at by an East German soldier. Apparently it was verboten to take a photo of something - maybe the train. Then we found out that we had missed getting off the train at Zoo bahnhof and were instead at Friedrichstrasse station in East Germany - a big no-no  in the still-divided city. We were lucky to slip onto an S-Bahn train back to West Berlin without getting in trouble.", 'the Fernsehturm takes me back to around 1982 when I crossed Checkpoint Charlie, visited the Pergamon Museum and found a friendly girl working there who I invited out.   She took me up the Fernsehturm where we spent about half an hour french-kissing - so yeah the Fernsehturm is special to me too', 'During the first summer after the fall of the Berlin Wall, a friend from N.Y.C. visited together with me Berlin. One day we waited for our train at the  Alexander Platz Station, where my friend spotted once again the TV Tower. I still hear him commenting on his view: „the smokestack.“ I loved his  label for the former pride of the G.D.R. Because I disliked its architecture deeply. The wrong design at the wrong place. My dislike for the tower hasn’t changed till today. But if I recollect, what my friend coined  as a  mark for Berlin’s TV Tower, the smokestack, it  works always as a real relief.']
summary: The Fernsehturm television tower in Berlin is a historic piece of architecture that many commenters reminisced visiting many years ago, giving anecdotes about how it went through the Cold War era, how they were shouted at by East German soldiers, and how some even found romance in the tower. Some commenters disliked the tower for being an architectural atrocity. Several commenters also offered historical facts about the Fernsehturm's role in spying.
short_title: Headline: Berliner Fernsehturm   Keywords: Cold War Era; Berlin (Germany); Architecture   Snippet: An awkward, soothing television tower, for Germans and expatriates alike.
short_question: ['Berliner Fernsehturm  ']

summary_propositions:
[{
  "claim": "Hackensack is a great place to live",
  "ground": [
    "the songs about Hackensack",
    "how cheap the real estate is",
    "how well connected by public transit",
    "Hackensack's diversity",
    "Hackensack has the best hospital in the state",
    "great memories with their family in Hackensack",
    "Hackensack has a great community",
    "Hackensack has affordable pricing"
  ]
}]
query: A less expensive alternative to many New York City suburbs, Hackensack is building additional housing in an effort to attract millennials.
comments: ['Re cljn\'s comment on January 19, 2018: Yes, it was a rhyme scheme when Billy Joel namedropped Hackensack in his hit song "Movin\' Out."', "Wow!  What a really nice town.  I'm guilty of having Billy Joel's words in my head and actually thought it was more of an industrial-type vibe.  Looks very cozy with much to offer.", 'Lived there in early 1970s. One of the first hi rises on Prospect (# 380) Loved the city . It was great with ethnic Italian stores and interesting restaurants. Life brought me to different places. All good. Very glad to hear it is thriving. J', "People either get Hackensack or they don't.  But if you're the kind of person who values convenience, diversity (socioeconomic and racial/ethnic), good food and chill people, this is a good place for you.  And I cannot adequately explain how awesome it is to have the best hospital in the state (competitive with NYC's best) a few blocks away. I'll say that families with children who are worried about the school system should look into it for themselves.  My children were in the local Catholic school until it closed down and a job loss forced us to put them in the public system.  Despite the many warnings I got, my children are happy and doing well academically and the teachers are fantastic!  (Some of the highest teacher salaries in the state attract quality candidates.)  The fact that the classrooms are like a mini UN delegation is just a bonus. But the best thing about Hackensack is the total absence of snobbery.  No Park Slope locally-sourced, organic cotton baby sheets, what-college-did-your-kid-get-into pressure here.  Just tons of delicious, authentic ethnic food from Italian to Latin American to Indian to African, made by immigrants from all these places.  Not to mention a handful of good pubs and the classic Stony Hill Inn.  (And our high school grads go to good colleges without all the anxiety.) Nice place to spend a life. Now if only we could get rid of these winters...", 'I have been living on Prospect Ave since 2002 in an apartment with a beautiful full view of NYC. I commute to NYC with the bus right outside my door. The maintenance in my co-op is not bad because there are more units in my building, so it depends.  I am very happy about the zoning laws changing to more residential/mixed-use and this should have been done a long time ago.  Hackensack is a very convenient town to live due to the proximity to shopping, restaurants/cafes and entertainment. I hope the revitalization is successful with the understanding to attract younger people, there needs to be a cool factor...', 'As a former Hackensack resident, be mindful of location.  I lived on Kaplan Avenue and had the Teterboro planes going right over the roof of the home where I rented.  Beware!', 'Yes. That’s another major omission in this upbeat article. Noise from business and celebrity jets using Teterboro Airport is the biggest quality of life issue after streets that go unpaved for decades, especially for Fairmount residents and those living in Prospect Avenue high-rises.', 'Never thought of Teterboro Airport being the proverbial elephant in the room! LOL', "My father lived on Summit Ave. back in the 1980's-90's in one of the older larger homes with an office attached to see clients.   While the home and grounds were beautiful, Hackensack has a very long way to go with regard to property taxes, schools, and crime.", 'I have often wondered why Mr. Joel chose Hackensack (rhyme scheme?) when there are oodles of options on his native LI that are just as fitting and that he would be more familiar with.', 'No nitpicking intended, caljn, but Billy is technically a Bronx native (he moved to Hicksville, LI when he was growing up). But I wonder: had "Movin\' Out" been composed by Bruce Springsteen instead of Billy Joel (or had the former recorded a cover of the aforementioned song, for that matter), would you have preferred that Springsteen have name-checked a town on the Jersey Shore instead of Hackensack? Just my two cents.', "I assume Ms Masara's daughters attend private school in NYC? That's a long day for a school age kid, adding 2 hrs of commuting to their school and homework load!", 'Hackensack sounded like a great deal and I even checked prices for apartments on njmls.com.  I was shocked by the extremely high monthly maintenance fees of many of the apartments.  I guess the high property taxes that one of the posters mentioned here are rolled into the maintenance charges.  So before everyone runs to buy these seemingly affordable co-ops, they need to check total cost of ownership.', 'I found the same issue, Irina.  Low coop or condo prices but the maintenance fees and common charges were $1200 and above!', 'As the co-owner of Hackensack’s only active brewery, I am a bit disturbed at Mr Lombardo’s quote wishing for an active brewery. We are proud to call Hackensack our home, having opened almost 2 years ago. I’m disappointed that Mr Lombardo doesn’t seem to be aware of this fact, and would be thrilled to welcome him to our taproom for a pint. I’m sure our Mayor, a frequent patron, would be happy to join.', "I've tried to find your brewery .... Do you serve food, too?", '40+ years ago my husband and I moved to a marvelous 2/2 on Prospect--one block away from the then small Hackensack Hospital. The apartment was one of those pre-war beauties that had all the majesty you\'d find on the Grand Concourse. We loved the easy commute into NYC but the downtown was dispersed and all signs pointed toward despair. I went back a year ago and was thrilled to see the vibrancy of "downtown" fueled, no doubt by favorable rents, proximity to the City, the growth of work at home and the explosion of the medical industry. Can\'t wait to go back...and maybe even consider purchasing back on Prospect. What goes around....', 'Best little city in the world with every amenity, nice people, near everything and affordable.  One of the few genuine middle class communities that welcomes all.', "I have fond memories of Hackensack, including walking hand in hand with my mom to Carvel right there in the town's Fairmont section while my dad was at work just a few minutes away in another part of town. Though I was just 2 years old, life seemed sweeter in that quiet town. Or, perhaps that was just the sugar talking.  Then my sisters showed up and those Carvel days were replaced with moving plans to a larger home out of Hackensack!  20 years later, through a series of random (and fortunate) events, the whole family moved back to Hackensack. The Carvel and all of our childhood stores were long gone except for faded signs reflecting a bygone era. But the town still retained the charm and relative affordability. Soon thereafter, one by one we left our little ol' town for marriage, work, and the calling of our own newly minted kids. Perhaps one day, they will discover Hackensack on their own and begin a similar journey, and maybe set up their greying parents in those lovely garden apartments the article mentioned, never too far away.", 'Hackensack is also the name of a song by Thelonius Monk.  I grew up in Teaneck not far from Hackensack near Fairleigh Dickinson.  I used to ride my bike down Cedar Lane across the bridge over the Hackensack River and stop at Sears on the other side.  We had moved from the Bronx. My father had bought a house for $11,500.  The halcyon days when Ike was president.', 'Despite Billy Joel\'s famous "dig", Hackensack is a place to get a lot for your money. It\'s just a 45 min commute (when NJ Transit behaves) to NYC, and well connected by bus, road and rail to other parts of the region. On  realtor.com  there are several co-ops in doorman buildings starting under $50K; on the other end of the spectrum one can find a massive Colonial or Tudor on a large plot from $600 - $700K. And there\'s plenty in between to select, in areas urban and suburban depending on what one prefers or can afford. Great restaurants, a large university campus, a reviving downtown and plenty of shopping. Diversity of the population makes all welcome. As my hometown - Manhattan/NYC - becomes homogenized with iconic shops, restaurants and clubs replaced by big box stores, banks, and empty condos Hackensack and similar places are increasingly appealing. One can always take the train to all Manhattan offers, just like from a borough. Transport costs much more, but housing costs are the tradeoff.', 'yep...."who needs a home in hackensack, is that all ya get for ya money..." i think the poor dude in this song moved to LA....ouch!', 'Nothing personal, needed the cadence and alliteration to match "heart attack" if you recall.', "I enjoyed this upbeat look at the North Jersey town I've called home since 2007, but there's a huge hole in the article: Property taxes are unusually high because home and business owners have to make up the revenue denied the city by huge tax-exempt entities the writer mentions under The Vibe:  The Bergen County Courthouse and government offices; the ever-expanding Hackensack University Medical Center; Fairleigh Dickinson University, a culinary college and other so-called non-profits. So, the city has to provide police, fire and other services to these institutions with essentially no compensation. And home and business owners have to pay higher property taxes as a result. Several years ago, the hospital's tax-exempt property would have generated $10 million in revenue, a burden that fell on home and business owners. My property taxes have risen from about $14,000 annually to more than $18,000 in the 10-plus years I've lived in the Fairmount section. Now, residents are hoping taxes paid by all those new apartments under construction will stop the rise in taxes.", 'Little to nothing, Steve.  NJ property taxes are one of the principle reasons why my partner and I are eyeing an exit in the next few years.', "I have fond memories of living on Prospect Avenue in the late 1990's.  I was working in midtown Manhattan at the time, and commuting was relatively easy.  The express bus stopped right across the street from my building and I could use the bus to get to NYC on the weekends without having to drive.  After living in NJ for several years, I moved to NC and I get a kick out questions like the one Steve raised about the taxes.  Yes my taxes were cheaper in NC (less than $4000) than they were in NJ ($6000 in 2010) but people fail to realize that revenue for the state must come from someplace.  Property taxes are lower in NC, but NC taxes food, has higher gas taxes, taxes personal property (cars, boats, etc.) and many personal services.  While most people probably don't have a boat, almost everyone has a car and everyone has to go to the grocery store. So NC property taxes may be lower, but the state gets revenue from other sources from taxpayers.", 'A couple of days after the incomplete Times story appeared, the Hackensack City Council filed "an omitted assessment appeal" against Hackensack University Medical Center, hoping to prompt negotiations with Hackensack Meridian Health, which owns the hospital, according to the local daily newspaper. The story, in The Record of Woodland Park, said city officials are seeking an estimated $19 million in taxes it would owe if it were not tax-exempt.  The story doesn\'t say, but I\'m assuming that\'s $19 million annually. Long-suffering home and property owners would love to see that.']
summary: Commenters recall the songs about Hackensack and talking about how great of a place Hackensack is to live. How cheap the real estate is, how well connected by public transit and things like that. Another commenter talks about Hackensack's diversity and that they have the best hospital in the state. Another commenter recalls moving there 40 plus years ago with her husband. Another commenter recalls great memories with their family in Hackensack. All the commenters praise Hackensack for its great community and affordable pricing.
short_title: Headline: It’s Time for Billy Joel to Take Another Look   Keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential); Hackensack (NJ)   Snippet: A less expensive alternative to many New York City suburbs, Hackensack is building additional housing in an effort to attract millennials.
short_question: ['It’s Time for Billy Joel to Take Another Look  ']

query: The rituals for ordering wine can seem arcane and confusing. Here are suggestions for how to make it work for you.
comments: ['I love all the fuss about wine and the "rules" of drinking it. Having been raised in Northern California, I have spent far more than my share of time in some of the best tasting rooms in the world. And, over the years,  I\'ve learned that there are really only two things that anyone needs to know about the enjoyment of wine.....First, there are only two kinds of wine - red and white. And, secondly, red is better than white. Once these basic principles are fully understood the mysteries surrounding the choice and enjoyment of wine disappear.', '"by all means ask the sommelier to choose a bottle.."  As a younger man I felt the need to select wine from the list in an effort to impress my dining companions.  I would always play it safe.  In my later years I\'ve found that asking the sommelier to recommend a wine that pairs with the meal selected has consistently produced pleasant surprises.  I\'ve enjoyed wines from small wineries whose names I didn\'t recognize, grapes I am not familiar with and wines from parts of the world I lack knowledge of.', "If you decide you do not like a wine after the first taste, isn't the restaurant left hanging with an open bottle of wine because of your bad judgment?", 'No, they can offer that wine by the glass at the bar at five 5oz pours and probably make a bigger profit than they do selling it as a full bottle.', 'As the other Times article notes, they can sell the wine by the glass and probably make at least as much.', 'Good sensible article, but leaves one potentially awkward question: "State your budget clearly". I am hosting the party.  I may really prefer not to state clearly in front of my guests that I want a bottle for no more than fifty bucks.  Alternatively, no less than five hundred bucks, or that the sky is the limit. Please advise how to handle. Dan Kravitz', "In hosting a party or large group it is rec'd and often expected that the host will  pull the maitre'd or sommelier aside and suggest the budget and ask for red and white, for example.", 'Another option (if it\'s not possible to pull the sommelier aside) is to open the wine list and point to a wine in your range, and then state that you\'re looking for something similar (depending on how discrete you want to be, you can state "around this price" or "in this range" or just "like this" while pointing to the price; the sommelier will get the message).', 'I once read you should point to a price point on the menu in view of the sommelier and say something along the lines of "I\'m looking for something around here." I\'ve done this several times and they have always quickly picked up and directed me at or below that price point.', 'I once ordered an expensive Italian red at a very highly regarded restaurant in NYC. After tasting and pouring the waiter placed the bottle in another location. Later when the waiter returned to pour there was only one glass left in the bottle. I complained and they opened another bottle. Moral of the story; if possible have them leave the bottle on the table.', 'It evaporated:-)', "In all of the biz meetings I put on in ExpAcct type NYC restaurants for 25 years, I always asked for unfinished bottle(s) to remain on the table. And, I usually requested that we would pour our own refills vs having the sommelier push more bottles with giant top off pours as they orbited the table every 10 mins. We eat and home and enjoy fine wine at 70% 'less' per bottle, these days. ;)"]
summary: Commenters offer each other advice that they have about ordering and drinking wine. One commenter has a question about how to state a budget for wine when there is a large party, and several commenters suggest discreetly pointing to a certain price range on the menu to the sommelier and ask to be within the range. Other commenters discuss how they prefer asking the waiter to leave the wine bottle on the table to make sure they get the full bottle worth.
short_title: Headline: Wine Service, Deconstructed   Keywords: Wines; Restaurants   Snippet: The rituals for ordering wine can seem arcane and confusing. Here are suggestions for how to make it work for you.
short_question: ['Wine Service, Deconstructed  ']

query: As America prepared to go to war in the spring of 1917, German forces were in strategic retreat along the Western Front.
comments: ["Much of the discussion about this war is about causes and which countries were at fault. A better consideration is to understand  the circumstances that made the war happen.  America's entry into the war one hundred years ago was to effect a circumstance in which future wars could not happen. The Europeans failed and so did we, eventually.", 'And the world thinks the French will buckle because a few religious fanatics turn to terror.  Vive La France.  The only nation I would fight to defend.', "My Wife's maternal Grandfather was killed at the 2nd Battle of the Marnes in 1918, Samuel Sinclair, of Detroit, Michigan, is buried in France.", 'Several years ago, my wife and I rode our bicycles through much of the Somme battlefield and on through Noyon. There were still bullet holes in buildings in the centre of Noyon - possibly left as a reminder of what war can bring. One of the best sights we saw during that cycle four was in Peronne (close to Noyon) where the British, French and Germans had "repurposed" an old fortress as a museum in honour of the soldiers who had fought in the region. The museum had very tasteful displays of the hardships of war without the "triumphalism" of many war memorials. My thought, at the time, was that the three nations had finally shaken off the worst nationalistic effects of WW I. Of course, that was before the "Brexit" vote and before this weekend\'s French election. It remains to be seen if the worst aspects of nationalism are really dead and buried in Europe.', 'The soil in this area (and others) continues to cough up ordinance from WWI--some of it still lethal.  The farmers call it "la recolte en fer".', 'My grandfather, Frank P. Lazarony, served in WWI. Frank was born in Sicily and emigrated with his family at age 3 to the Western NY. He enlisted as a whole person, and endured the trenches, and lost his hearing there. Frank was not a citizen when he served. Frank lived well into his 90s. On each Memorial Day the VFW would organize Frank and the other vets in town to walk the Memorial Day parade. After many years had passed, Frank was the sole surviving WWI vet, and put him in the back of a convertible to ride in the parade in Fredonia, NY ... every year to honor his service....  During his entire life Frank never, ever voted in any election, local, state, or national... He was afraid that they would ask for proof of citizenship, discover that he was not a citizen, and deport him.', 'In our town, Memorial Day was celebrated with a parade. I still remember when I was a child over 50 years ago when WWI veterans marched while veterans of the Spanish American War rode in open cars.', "So many of the problems that have vexed the world since can be traced to WWI: the bitterness of the German loss and the terms of the subsequent peace would help propel the rise of Adolph Hitler, the carving up and appropriation of the Ottoman Empire by France and Britain abetted by an American-shared interest in oil has led directly to the failed warring states in the mideast today, and the failure of Wilson's dream of a League of Nations to adjudicate disputes between nations has left the entire world vulnerable to the same anachronistic medieval impulses that threaten to ratchet up destruction to apocalyptic levels in this nuclear age.", 'So few Americans know anything about World War I.  These photographs are a wonderful contribution to our knowledge.  I hope the Times finds a venue for displaying these to the general public.  For myself, they bring a sense of great sadness at the harm done to so many for so little reason.  Most of all, they bring me a closeness to both of my grandfathers, who each enlisted shortly after the US entered the war and not surprisingly, though they did not know each other, served not far from each other in that terrible border of France and Germany.  I never knew my maternal grandfather, who died of pneumonia in the early 30s, his lungs damaged by a gas attack in the war.  These photos allow me to begin to see what they saw.', 'In April 2016, I spent four days touring the battlefields around Ypres Belgium, generally known as Flanders Fields.   Ypres, also known as leper, was subject to destruction three separate times as the battle lines moved back and forth.    It was rebuilt with German reparations money by 1930. Tall buildings of all kinds were subject to bombardment because they represented artillery spotting locations on a generally flat topography.   Thus, the destruction was tactical, not spiteful. One cannot really appreciate the horrors of WW One without touring its battle sites.  A hundred years later, there are still large craters, some now filled with water, from the war.  Men who were miners in civilian life built tunnels under the enemies lines, and placed high explosives there.  When the explosives were detonated, the earth, including the men on it, were blown hundreds of feet into the air.   There are cemeteries and memorials everywhere.   After the war ended, the German cemeteries were consolidated.   At one, there is a pit that contains the remains of about 30,000 soldiers.  The British placed cemeteries, conveniently, outside field hospitals.   World War One was a war where technology exceeded the military tactics to use those technologies efficiently.  The result was unimaginable death and carnage.  Its a sight to see.', 'One more point.  Tens of thousands disappeared on the battlefield, blown to smithereens or otherwise vanishing without a trace.  Over 50,000 British alone, missing in action.   Farmers plowing fields, or construction excavation, is still turning up human remains, several sets a month, a hundred years later.', 'Still the most stirring book on WW1 is All Quiet on the Western Front, by Erich Maria Remarque.']
summary: Several commenters love the photographs from World War I because they provide an insight into the history and hardships of the war. A few commenters give anecdotes about their grandparents' time in WWI. Several commenters argue that we should consider what circumstances caused the war and its outcomes, including the rise of Hitler, the fragmentation of the Ottoman Empire, and the failure of the League of Nations. A couple of commenters talk about how they visited the old battlegrounds in Noyon and Flanders Fields and the effects of the war that persist to this day.
short_title: Headline: In Devastated Northern France, the French Flag Flies Again   Keywords: World War I (1914-18); New York Times; France; Germany; Newspapers   Snippet: As America prepared to go to war in the spring of 1917, German forces were in strategic retreat along the Western Front.
short_question: ['In Devastated Northern France, the French Flag Flies Again  ']

query: Durant left the Thunder last season as a free agent, and his former teammate Westbrook didn’t take it well. With both on the Western Conference All-Star team, their reunion has been frosty.
comments: ['When the Giants traded the greatest baseball player ever - Willie Mays - I learned that teams have zero loyalty to their players.  Why should any player have any loyalty to a team?', "I used to play a game somewhat similar to this when I was a kid, the difference being that I played in alleys and always cared about winning. A sorry spectacle that henceforth should be known as the All-Millionaires Game or the We-Don't-Give-A-Damn-Game, I turned it off after five minutes, feeling ashamed for the players and sorry for the spectators.", "I met Kevin Durant at the last Breakthrough Awards in Silicon Valley. He's very interested in science and technology. He's in the right place now for that. Oklahoma is not such a great place for science and technology nerds, California is much better for a guy like him.", 'Westbrook had his NBA title taken out of reach. I would be angry also. Durant just switched vehicles to his first title. He is not a loser in this transaction. Westbrook has to adjust to and play through the disappointment. A tough assignment certainly.', 'Time to move on.  Durant made a good choice.  Westbrook needs to grow up.', 'I watched much of a thoroughly enjoyable All-Star Game, and simply appreciated the beauty of Durant and Westbrook on the court and could care less about whether they smile at each other.', "This isn't about smiling.  This is about the relationship between two superstars.  Durant's abandonment of OKC is a lot like LeBron's Decision.  It says a lot about Durant's values.  In my mind it says he'll take the easy road to a ring, rather than to earn it the hard way, because it will increase his revenues from commercials.  Superstars are few and far between and it is dismissive to say you are only interested in how they play basketball.  I saw Durant play at Texas and it was clear even then that he was no ordinary player.  Still, forgive me, but even in light of his professed love of his mother, I have no respect for the guy.  I agree with most players -- his going to Golden State to create team head and shoulders above all others reflected very poorly on him.", "Look seriously and thoughtfully at your first few sentences. The judgment and superior mindedness of your attitude regarding people you don't know at all, displays more of what is wrong in sports than anything either of these two players have done. You ask for forgiveness in your second to last sentence 'even in the light of his professed love for his mother'. Read your words aloud and listen to yourself. You might even end up forgiving yourself.", "I'm not sure that this article makes clear that, until 2012, Harden played with Durant and Westbrook at OKC.  If they had found a way to keep these 3 together, there would be no Warriors-Cavs rivalry, and Cleveland would likely still be in a championship drought.", "I don't blame Westbrook for being angry. OKC could have challenged for the championship this year. Now, as good as Westbrook can be, OKC is gonna get beaten by GS or by SA. And if everybody stays healthy, it's hard to see OKC challenging in the foreseeable future.  But KD was a loyal, hard-working player and a good guy. Anyone who hasn't heard his MPV award speech and wants to know what he's all about, check it out. KD's a mensch through and through. I don't see why he shouldn't have gone to California or any place else if he wanted to. Players have the opportunity to shop their skills around and choose to live wherever, just like anyone else. Cacciola is right when he says Westbrook is using emotion as fuel. I hope he does average the triple double, and I hope he gets the MVP, too. KD predicted he would someday. It might be nice for it to be this year.", 'Almost every basketball fan opposed LeBron\'s "Decision" despite the fact that he had the right to go to Miami as you suggest.  Of course, Durant not only left, he disrespected the GS OKC rivalry.  He is to a Thunder fan what Johnny Damon is to a Red Sox fan.  The Celtics seldom trade with the Lakers.  The Brooklyn Dodgers didn\'t trade with the Yankees,  And the Packers and Cowboys seldom trade.  I\'m glad KD loves his mother.  But he is a terrible traitor to OKC  fans.  This is like when OKC left Seattle, when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, and when the Browns left Cleveland.  There is no kissing and making up for some treachery.  Durant is just such a traitor to OKC fans.', 'Michjas, there are many intersubjective realities that surround professional athletics, and they are almost always good for the sport and for the fans. The overarching reality is that the business arrangements management makes with individual athletes, which are called contracts, allow for players shop their skills around. KD fought hard for OKC and seemed to reciprocate the affection of the fans. Treachery seems an overcharged word to describe a young man wanting to play basketball outside of Oklahoma.', "But you don't know the facts and therefore don't know the truth.  Durant grew up in Compton, he played at the University of Texas, and he loved Oklahoma where he was the biggest celebrity around. He clearly did not do this to get out of Oklahoma.  So throw that idea out and re-apply your intersubjective realities.", '" Last season, they extended the Warriors to seven games in the conference finals — and probably would have advanced to face the Cleveland Cavaliers in the N.B.A. finals had Thompson failed to engineer some late-series heroics." Last season in the SF OKC series if Durant had played basketball the way he routinely does in any of the three deciding games OKC would have won. But he didn\'t and instead went to SF.  Durant is a great player who can go where he wants.  But his failure to play  basketball to his own established standards is why OKC did not win the NBA championship last year.', 'No matter, these are 2 of the greats now playing as well as they ever can.  There will be decades to come in which to become as friendly as they choose, but now play on apart since they are actually apart.', 'No matter????  Apparently you do not appreciate sports rivalries.  When Ruth went to the Yankees, the Red Sox embarked upon an 83 year curse and the Yankees built a house in honor of Ruth and won 26 championships.  No matter???', 'Settledown, Michjas, its a game, right?  I know, we are all fans and I am just lucky enough to be a Warriors fan, but man, there are other things in life apart from team fanatics.']
summary: Several commenters praise Durant's abilities saying that his ability could have won the previous game and that his high goals and interest will likely lead him away from OKC. Some say that despite players' efforts their team does not adequately reward them. Others comment on Westbrook's loss and justify his anger, saying that he just needs to endure the disappointment as well as he can. Another suggests that Westbook's response may be immature.
short_title: Headline: Once a Dynamic Duo, Now Just an Awkward Pairing   Keywords: All Star Games; Basketball; Golden State Warriors; Oklahoma City Thunder; Durant, Kevin; Westbrook, Russell   Snippet: Durant left the Thunder last season as a free agent, and his former teammate Westbrook didn’t take it well. With both on the Western Conference All-Star team, their reunion has been frosty.

short_question: ['Once a Dynamic Duo, Now Just an Awkward Pairing  ']

query: Friday: How children can celebrate the holiday, warmer weather on the horizon, and an ask about airports.
comments: ["It's good to know that all buildings will have to show addresses soon. Here's another suggestion: corner street signs should show the number of the first building on the block--as is done in San Francisco.", 'Bill deBlasio is worried about re-election, and more than 87,000 people applied for 104 subsidized apartments?... Can what he really should be worrying about, get any clearer than that???', "This year we're celebrating A HOLIDAY. That's what it's called. Just A HOLIDAY. Done deal!", "Yankees because that's where my best friend's dad took us to doubleheaders as children. Yellow cab since Uber changed their policy to be too intrusive, but mostly MTA. La Guardia because the taxi ride is cheapest from the UWS.", "What, no mention of Manhattan's only native president, Theodore Roosevelt??? For shame!  For an off-beat presidential sightseeing trip, head to 123 Lexington Avenue, at 28th Street (currently Kalustyan's spice store). That's where Chester A. Arthur lived and where he was hurriedly sworn-in as president after the death of James Garfield in 1881. If you make the pilgrimage but have forgotten what Arthur looked like, walk to nearby Madison Square park and check out his statue.  FYI, there have been only two presidential swearing-ins in NYC: George Washington's at the site of Federal Hall and Arthur's at 123 Lex.", 'Senators impeach Devils', "Kennedy or LaGuardia? Are you kidding...I'd rather drive to my destination. But seriously, at least JFK has the airtrain.", "We used to celebrate Lincoln's Birthday AND Washington's Birthday separately.  No school on BOTH days.   My birthday is the same as Lincoln's, so I always had my birthday party on my birthday.  It was a big deal in my social circles at PS 87.", "Re Presidents' Day: As the child of a wonderful father who spent all of World War II on a destroyer escort in the Pacific, I have flown my American flag on holidays and also on family anniversaries; my father's birthday, for example, and in commemoration of the day he died. Sometimes I just have it out to show my appreciation for our country. Yes, I am that old. Since the November election, I have not flown it. I am too heartsick.  For all you Trump fans out there: While we've had presidents who have not served our country during wartime, and with whom I've disagreed politically, we have never had a president who so willfully and proudly has flouted our laws and customs and now sullies the honor of the office with outright lies, one after the other, easily seen for what they are. My late parents, one an Independent, and the other a Republican, would have been disgusted at this president's demeanor and amorality.   I had some real reservations about some of President Obama's policies, but at least I wasn't embarrassed to fly my American flag while he was in office. I'd hate for anyone to think that my flag is an endorsement of this crooked, treasonous imposter of a president.", "The official name of the holiday is Washington's Birthday not Presidents Day.", "The photo says it all. I don't even want to teach my kids about our history anymore. It's become an embarrassment.", 'Newark.', "Tune of Kids (What's the Matter with Kids Today?) Kids Don't know what to do with the kids this week Kids Gotta look for something fun and unique. Kids If they'd read the article, there's so much to do Could some touring be alluring to them And teach them in the process Kids If they're left to doing just what they please Kids Ours would sit and study at their PC's Why were they given homework Who wants to be a geek When there's so much kids can do this week!", 'Love it; thanks, Freddie!!!    Happy long weekend & will miss your cheery lyrics until Tuesday!', "Thanks Jeanne Marie.   There really is something about how New York Today so beautifully balances life's highs and lows and gradations between. I don't know that there's any daily column in journalism that so consistently scores at doing that. Really something to want to burst into song about."]
summary: Commenters express their doubt about how the lack of various presidents being mentioned. One commenter remarks that there was no mention of Theodore Roosevelt. Other commenters agree on the lack of acknowledgment of various presidents. Another commenter states that celebrating Lincoln's birthday is a big deal for their social circles.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Friday: How children can celebrate the holiday, warmer weather on the horizon, and an ask about airports.

query: Gangsta Garden, a community garden in South Los Angeles founded by Ron Finley, has turned to business leaders from Newman’s Own Organics and Annie’s Homemade to save its land.
comments: ["This article does not do justice to the energy Ron brings. I have been charged up by Mr Finley since I saw his Ted talk a few years ago. The man is more than awesome! He presents as an irreverent, irascible and intolerant of bureaucratic and  societal nonsense. He is a man of action and good energy. I highly suggest watching his Ted talk and if you are not a fan after that, well, there's not much more I can say.", '"hell strips" are not a good place for vegetable gardens.  seems likely to result in polluted vegetables, unless everyone there has been running no-exhaust electric cars. How many vegetables contain lead because gardeners don\'t test before planting in urban areas?  http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/yard-garden/soils/lead-in-home-garden/', 'What an inspiring story about someone taking control of their food situation. I wonder if chickens could play a role on this farm?', "This is great news and what has been done to promote this urban gardening is very important for the health of a population. But you definitely don't need $500,000 properties for gardening. It is amazing what can be grown on a sunny balcony in pots and planters (tomatoes, beans, peppers for example) and it is much easier to maintain in planters. This will have a positive impact on the health of future generations and instil an appreciation for quality, accessible food. Congratulations!", 'Gardens and gardening not only supply fresh produce, not  locally available, but also speak to the soul of the gardeners.  As one gardens, time, stress, disappointments, disappear giving way to calm and enlightenment.  Keep up the good gardening for all of us', 'During WWII every home had a Victory Garden. People of all ages and socioeconomic status were involved in tending them.  Once you taste vegetables from your own garden, you will not want to return to buying the cardboard substitutions from in a grocery store.', "I'd love to see more community gardening in urban areas.  When people are connected to food they care much more about what they eat and care more about the food they buy.", 'Good Luck Mr. Finley.  Our hearts are with you.  It is about the kids.', 'Best of luck to you Mr. Finley. I am betting that in next next few years charitable giving is going to be stretched paper thin as more and more budget cuts are proposed to worthy causes. I laud your efforts and sing praise to the donors who have helped you get there.', 'More pictures would have been nice. The garden sounds fantastic', "Scott - Just 'google' gangsta garden in LA -- tons of wonderful pictures.", 'You can still donate to the Gangsta Garden ! Keep this garden growing.', 'That would indeed be the best kind of revolution: where the poor and powerless become self-sustainable and self-determined, creating their own economy of work, good health, and cooperation, bypassing all the crap we call "reality" that really only serves to keep a minority in power and wealthy. Good karma growing.', "Maybe someone should check on the value of the property before paying $500,000.  It might also be interesting to see what is really owed.  If I had the address I could find out.  Just sayin'...", "The address and property prices are public record and certainly easy enough to access. Why not check them out? Sounds like you need a project, 'just sayin'. Right.", "I was wondering what the plan was for paying any taxes on it once it's been purchased."]
summary: Most commenters express support for community gardens and admire Mr. Finley's energy. Commenters mostly express support for the reason that people can have pride in gardening and also obtain fresh vegetables. One commenter says that the $500,000 property for the garden is not necessary, as this type of gardening can be done on balconies. One commenter says that urban vegetable gardens are not as good as they get polluted.

query: In recent years, the Knicks have not been renowned for their stability or for their aptitude at basketball.
comments: ['Take a headcase dilettante buffoon of an owner, add several pinches of terrible coaches and/or team "officials," hire a headcase egomaniac team president who himself hires a no-experience coach and trades for over-the-hill headcase players no other team wants, add a large pinch of a guaranteed contract for an "it\'s all about me" star whose only influence on prior teams has been to trash them.   Mix well and add some bitters (for the fans) and you\'ve got.... the KNICKS!', "This article & these comments are being too hard on Anthony & also not looking at reality. This is the 1st time Anthony has actually had other shooters, & a couple players that create their own shot on the Knicks beside himself. This team is not bad at all. I have written this before, the biggest problem beside Phil Jackson's childish behavior, is the center spot. HermanGomez should be the starter, or even O'Quinn, not Noah. They have two very good forwards in Anthony & Porzingis, they have good guards in Rose, Jennings & Holiday (who I like alot), & lots of talented backup. They need more consistency from Rose. And they need to really work harder on defense, the latter is the coach's responsibility. I really think they might be able to deal Noah to the Clippers for Austin Rivers, & if they have to add Rose, maybe the Clippers would do a couple picks too. Although now with Paul injured they might not part with Rivers.   This team has shown they can win against tough teams. They are only 4 spots out of the playoffs & have half a season to go. So I don't think the season is crumbling at all. If they make the playoffs anything can happen in the East. The article talks of winning a championship, but what teams right now are in a position to do that, only a few. Cleveland, who will most likely win the East. Golden State, of course, & San Antonio. Maybe Toronto or Houston. So most of the league is lacking, as far as the title. Shut Jackson up & deal Noah. It will be OK Orange, NJ", "How does any well placed basketball person presume Melo would be a franchise savior when his history as a player screams offense not defense, and scorer not facilitator. Melo is a very good player and in the right setting (look at Syracuse 2003 NCAA champs lineup) could be a key element to a championship run.  But the Knick's expectations for him have not been realistic. He's not LeBron, a do everything point-forward - he's not Jordan who set example at both ends of the court & imposed his will on the supporting cast. The Knicks should look to Boston's rebuild around Paul Pierce (scorer supreme) who couldn't win it all until Garnett (the fanatical defender), Ray Allen (deadly outside threat & stretcher of the defense), and Perkins (interior muscle) joined him & Rondo to make that great run.  Melo is not going to admit he's an average defender, he knows it's his skill at the other end that keeps him in the lineup & spotlight. But this isn't his mess, he's been playing the way he's always played and can still deliver. It's up to ownership & management to fill their roles to see the big & better picture for the franchise. Either rebuild around valued pieces (Boston 2008, Miami 2012, Cleveland 2015) or get value for those pieces and move on. This is the worst off-broadway drama ever.", "When making a trade, or trying to, it's standard practice to talk up the player you're trying to move. Common sense. Instead, we're treated to the spectacle of Phil J. ostensibly trying to move Carmelo, while simultaneously endorsing the opinion that he's a ball hog, a poor defender, not a championship player, etc. Personally, I don't disagree with those perceptions, but this is definitely not the smartest way to negotiate a trade. I doubt that the Knicks will find a trading partner, but one thing is certain--if they do, the chances are excellent they'll receive little or nothing of value in return. And while we're on the subject, even if he were available, Kevin Love doesn't make a lot of sense--not on a team whose 2 greatest assets appear to be Porzingis and Hernangomez.", 'Chance at what title? Sandbox league of midtown?', "Anthony has been picked to replace Kevin Love on the All-Star team. He himself said he'd rather not play, that Porzinigis should go. So instead of looking toward the future, for both the Knicks and the league, we're stuck once again with a player who seems to be the antithesis of what team play is all about. But people keep paying to see him. They deserve what they get.", 'Hypothetically speaking can the Times find a reporter to write about the Knickerbockers rather than the New York Saint Carmelos? Only a hypothetical.  But sooner or later it must happen.', "Carmelo will never play on a championship team.  He's not a hardworker.", 'Seems every sports team in New York is perpetually rebuilding and spending fortunes, and for what results?  What a terrible waste of money it all is.', 'Think about all the bad actors the various pro HOFs are currently so sensitive about admitting, then maybe the anti-Carmelo claque might want to rethink things just a little. Charles Oakley for example , a surly guy with a good work ethic, is revered by Knick fans. But he never won a championship, despite playing alongside Patrick Ewing, who was by magnitudes superior to anyone Anthony has ever had the pleasure of playing with. Yes, Melo is often a ball-hog/gunner, but when your wing men are so bottom tier where\'s the sin in that? But around the league, nobody from the Commissioner on down has ever called him out on those famous "personal issues." Oh btw as to another consensus HOF player, Charles Barkley,who through no fault of his ow never won the big one (even in college) and whose credentials , despite his occasionally crude (but always entertaining) behavior, no one ever denies was the real deal. I think Anthony is being made a scapegoat here for inept management that includes not only all the usual suspects, but Phil Jackson. Who is ultimately the one who tied Melo to the Knicks by giving him a contract (I\'m sure none of his detractors would have turned down) that tied him so inextricably to the Dolomites that he will probably never get to sit, even on the end, of a bench, of a championship team. OK, maybe he\'s not  Jordan, Le Bron. Bird, Dwayne  or Shaq. but really he deserves better than he gets. Particularly from fans in my own former city of New York.', "Few All-Stars make the players around them better.  Tim Duncan did.  LeBron James does.  There's no evidence that suggests Carmelo Anthony has that ability.  His strength is in creating offense for himself, not to play within a team concept.  Deep down, there are Knicks basketball decision-makers that knew this when they threw money at Carmelo.  they were in for years of mediocrity.  And please, don't ship him to Boston...there aren't enough basketballs to keep him happy.", 'The Knicks will never again be anywhere close to championship caliber.  Period.', "Assuming the Knicks can find another team willing to pay Anthony's $26 million next year and $27 million the year after. Let's stop the charade, he will be with the Knicks for two more years. Thanks, Mr. Jackson.", 'The Knicks\' problems began over a decade ago when Isiah Thomas traded 1st round draft picks for overpaid veterans like there was no tomorrow. Even now the Knicks rarely have 1st round picks and that is the primary reason they keep losing. After this season will be the time to "blow it up" by trading Melo and rebuild. They\'ve got a good young big man in Porzingis but they need about everything else.   Melo needs to go to a team like Boston or OKC where he could be the last piece to a championship run, while the Knicks need a young power forward, move the 7\'3" Porzingis to center, and a couple of speedy young guards so they can run \'n gun.  The Melo era needs to end this yr.', "Boston surely doesn't want him.  I can't imagine Brad Stevens would blow up his roster for Carmelo.", "I gotta say, one HOPES they have a good young big man in Porzingis. Right now, he's very inconsistent and is not deserving of the hype he's received. But, let's face, knick fans are desperate for ANY good news. To me, the real issue is that Jackson traded for has-beens in Rose and Noah. Neither of them has lived up to their hype. Rose is a selfish shooting guard in a point guard's body. Noah is an ineffective big man. The knicks have guards, but no real point guard leader. Rose is pathetic, making players WORSE rather than better.", "It's odd to me that Carmelo is being portrayed as the wronged party here. As inept as this franchise is, let's not forget that this guy, as a pro, has never been much of a winner. He's had some seasons where his teams have been good. But not much more. Denver had the most wins in a decade in the season AFTER he left.  The year he joined the Knicks, had been, up to the point he joined them, one of their most exciting in a long time. It was a fun, young, if inconsistent team, centered around Amare Stoudamire. As soon as Carmelo joined, that all went away. He's essentially a nicer version of Stephon Marbury. Or  a slightly more talented version of the original Glenn Robinson. I don't blame the Knicks for wanting to move him. I'm sure their desire would be to move Anthony, let Rose walk at the end of the season and his contract (or move him too) and build around Porzingis.", 'The whole thing needs to be blown up...Again! Dolan is the biggest part of the problem but Carmello is right behind him.', "Who except the Knicks were  dumb enough to believe you could win a championship led by Carmelo Anthony. If he was really that motivated then he would have joined the Bulls . A championship player makes his less talented teammates better and thats how you win . Carmelo has never been that kind of player. maybe someday he'll take a minimun contract in the twilight of his career  and play with a winner but not today."]
summary: Numerous commentators agree that the Knicks are currently not a quality team. Many commentators heap criticism on coach Phil Jackson and his mismanagement on various levels. Many other commentators attack Anthony and his perceived lack of ability. Several commentators attempt to defend Anthony, pointing fingers at other problems.
short_title: Headline: Anthony’s Bleak Season Crumbles Into All-Star Anticlimax   Keywords: Anthony, Carmelo; New York Knicks; Basketball; All Star Games; Trades (Sports); Free Agents (Sports)   Snippet: In recent years, the Knicks have not been renowned for their stability or for their aptitude at basketball.

query: A woman is suddenly thrust into the delicate business of picking fruit and making change.
comments: ['Just say no next time.', 'Delightful little anecdote - you made smile and I took my puppy for a walk. She was happy too.', 'That was fun to read and I bet a fun experience for you!', "Carla - you're very kind and worth your weight in mangos!", 'I just LOVE New Yorkers like you!  I always wonder about outside vendors and what they do when nature calls!', 'am constantly amazed & impressed by the hard-working produce vendors. no matter the weather or time of year, there they are, polishing, arranging & selling their basic wares. the morning after the evening proprietor was robbed by multiple assailants, my neighborhood vendor was at his customary perch. lined up on the sidewalk before him were a scattering of locals inquiring about the wellbeing of the assault victim, who turned out to be his father-in-law.', 'Sweet story; I smiled as I thought of your kindness to the fruit vendor and your previously unknown produce-selling skils!']
summary: Commenters are amused by the story describing it as sweet and delightful. Others commend the bravery of New York vendors amid difficulties and robberies. One commenter commends his kindness and praises his new-found vending skills. Another commenter suggests the author should have turned down the opportunity.
short_title: Headline: The Accidental Produce Vendor   Keywords: Fruit; New York City   Snippet: A woman is suddenly thrust into the delicate business of picking fruit and making change.
short_question: ['The Accidental Produce Vendor  ']

query: A look at what the health bill would do, who it would affect, and how it changed to get more lawmakers to yes.
comments: ["I don't understand why we are allowed to elect public officials to represent our interests. A Government run single payer healthcare system would provide universal coverage and reduce the cost of our country's healthcare on the order of  $800 billion dollars a year - that is more than enough money to balance the Federal budget and provide every citizen a check for $1000; and you could repeat that every year. Instead we seem to be stuck with a bloated, complex, jackass dumb healthcare system, that doesn't begin to serve our needs. What is the matter? Is everybody in the Congress just plain stupid?", "Forget dollar signs and charts and graphs. Forget political ideology. Let's instead talk decency and empathy and care. Let's talk about helping each other without expecting something in return. If we could see past our obsession with money and start to think that all people regardless of well...anything... deserve to live with some kind of happiness and security, maybe, just maybe, we'd be able to say with true conviction that we are the greatest nation on earth. Right now, we are vain, small and mean. We are earning our fall from the top of the heap.", 'This discussion needs to include a statement made by Dr. James L. Madara, the Chief executive of the American Medical Association: "Although the MacArthur Amendment states that the ban on preexisting conditions remains in tact, this assurance may be illusory, as status underwriting could effectively make coverage completely unaffordable to people with preexisting conditions."  Status underwriting gets a thorough going over in an article in the Henry J. Kaiser Foundation on Health Reform, titled: "Pre-existing Conditions and Medical Underwriting in the Individual Insurance Market Prior to the ACA."', "As in the article, the Republicans now have, at least in Republican-governed states that will choose to get the new waiver, a return to pre-existing-condition-screened individual insurance with (still massively underfunded) state high-risk-pools to try and cover some of the people with pre-existing-conditions, Besides all of the problems of the pre-Obamacare state-run pool system: (a)lousy pools with low coverage max payouts, waiting lists, high premiums, overtight eligibility requirements, (b) the complicated process of applying for health insurance where you have to write down every out-of-range lab test and every abnormality and condition you've ever had and wait a few weeks or months to see if the insurer accepts you and how much they will charge you, and then possibly repeat the process with a different insurer,  (c)That insurers frequently, on getting a big claim, requested additional medical records, and rescinded coverage and refused to pay bills if they found a condition left off the original application, even inadvertently, there's a new wrinkle due to the Genetic Non-Discrimination act of 2008 ( http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/02/health/policy/02gene.html  ). The result is genetic screening results can not be considered a pre-existing condition, allowing people who know they are likely to get a disease, but have no pre-existing-conditions now, to game the system and and thus increase costs for non-gamers. (I wonder what Republican policy wonks say about that?)", 'After my divorce, I\'d have ended up in the state health insurance high-risk pool, had not Obamacare come along just when I needed it.  I\'m 61 and disabled, with several chronic medical conditions resulting from longstanding domestic abuse (both child and spousal), however, due to a technicality I cannot get disability payments.  I have to make ends meet on just over $2K/mo of alimony, and I don\'t have the ability to increase my income.  (This all despite both a BS & MS in engineering/scientific fields.)  Currently, with subsidy, I pay $278/mo for my health ins — manageable.  But the Colorado high-risk pool that was in existence prior to Obamacare used to charge $1200/mo, and they were the only ones who said they would insure me before Obamacare.  There\'s no way I can pay $1200/mo for health insurance, my alimony disqualifies me from Medicaid, & I require several expensive medications to manage multiple conditions.   Republicans have no use for someone like me.  To them, there\'s no excuse for being smart, educated, hardworking, AND...have chronic health problems, especially complex ones.   People like me don\'t exist.  Either you\'re so broke that Medicaid covers you, or you should get up off your duff and make enough dough to cover those premiums.  In between? Doesn\'t happen.  I can easily imagine Paul Ryan dressed up like Ebenezer Scrooge, muttering, "If they be like to die, they\'d better do it, and decrease the surplus population." Such progress we\'ve made since the 1840s.', 'Clear and compelling.  I am holding on to this one for my daily phone calls to my tow the line, I can deal with anything except a primary challenger Republican Representative.', 'TrumpCare = Republican Death Panels.  No healthcare, just get sick and die.', 'Well, as always in Trump-world ... what was "true" yesterday is not true today. "The G.O.P. Health Bill Is Alive Again"  ... NOPE.  It\'s DOA.   Ryan says that they will pass it "when they have the votes."   Duh.   1 + 1 = 2.  But this Zombie bill is crueler than the first AHCA.  It has zero chance in the senate, because it cannot possibly be passed by reconciliation.   This was all about trying to give Trump a "victory" and all it has done is make it more obvious what a complete failure the GOP has become.', "The Republican Party cannot function without an enemy - they can't run or govern on their policies - and clearly, after reading this, their current enemy is the American people.", 'Please, please, please! This is about Health INSURANCE, it is only tangentially related to Health CARE. Health CARE is intended to make citizens lives better. Health INSURANCE is intended to make insurance company Fat Cats richer by sucking money out of our Health CARE system. Please!!', 'Nope. Dead again. In an attempt to give Trump a last minute 100-day win, Trump took yet another loss.', "Sure.  Give the wealthy huge tax breaks and bring the poor and sick down to their knees begging to get healthcare. Isn't America Great?", 'The article mentions that one new feature of the Republican proposal since the failed one is that states can be exempted from "same premium regardless of health status" provided the state sets up a high-risk-pool. In the article, Ms. Sanger-Katz points out that the high-risk-pools (which existed in most states pre-Obamacare) were generally miserable.   (Waiting lists, low maximum bill payout, unreasonable eligibility restrictions, high premiums, etc.) I note further that the Republicans propose sending states only a tiny fraction of the funding needed to make high risk pools work.  (They\'ve proposed $2.5 to $10 billion dollars a year, when more like $100 billion are needed--see  http://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/blog/2017/mar/high-risk-poo...  .) In a  recent article, Ms. Sanger-Katz also pointed out that the application procedure under the old pre-existing-condition-screened system was slow and complicated: you fill out an application with your pre-existing conditions, and they get back to you a month or two later. Let me throw in a third fact about the old system.  You could apply for health insurance, write down your pre-existing conditions as best as you could remember, and the insurance company might issue you insurance, but then not pay your bills if it decided, after a big claim came in, that you accidentally  left off a pre-existing condition. (See 3:20-7:00 in video here:  http://www.pbs.org/moyers/journal/07102009/watch.html)', '" It would rearrange the subsidy system that helps middle-income Americans buy their own insurance coverage, creating new winners and losers." This is the greatest fundamental problem that America must face before it is ever going to create a viable Universal Health Care System for it\'s people as do most other developed Nations. Has any reader realised what that fundamental problem is? It is the Thinking and Mindset as well as the Attitude that too many people are seeing the issue at hand as and as a consequence, diminish the chances of success. Here it is: There Can\'t be any Winners and Losers! Or Haves versus Have Nots! It is health care for EVERYONE. that is why it is called "Universal" This is about an entire Nation and all its Citizens benefiting from the Health Care System one and all.  No one is left behind.All people are covered. EVERYBODY is a Winner! Something that is easily accomplished by the wealthiest Nation on Earth if it wants to serve it\'s people\'s best interests just like all the other advanced Democratic Nations have been doing for theirs for decades.', "I cannot in all honesty speak for the systems in both Britain and Canada in regards to waiting lists for non essential procedures or anything about actual rationing of care in regards to an expensive procedure/drug for cancer Treatment etc...but can with confidence talk about my countries system , which like any, is not perfect but compared to the U.S System in all areas of outcome, costs, performance, and all the relevant and important measures that matter in regards to a National Health Scheme that covers every Citizen, there is no comparison. From Prescription Drug prices,  Doctor visits/checkups , scans, bloodwork X-rays and diagnostics...there is Never a wait (of more than an hour) and nothing to pay. My family of 2 adults (one a chronic Smoker the other with a Heart Condition from birth) and 3 Boys take out the top Private Health Cover to support the system as well as Provide additional Dental, Orthodontic, Private Hospital Room , Optometry, Birth and much more , we pay a $500 excess for Private Hospital Room just once per annum no matter the bed stays by any or for how long and pay nothing if not used once in any year. Premiums for the entire family cost A$300 per month.  march I had cardiomyopathy and had the best treatment by one of the Country's top Cardiologists and a private room over the 7 days I was in hospital...my wife the previous year had heart surgery with her private Cardiac Specialist...She paid an excess of $2000 on his Fee, and I paid $0. Good system", '"Canada...long waiting lists, say up to 8 months, even 2 year wait to get a hip replacement. In 2006 an Ontario judge opined: The Canadian system does not guarantee care. It only guarantees a place in line." As a Canadian, I find this statement very misleading.
