In Canada, if you have a life-threatening condition - for example, stabbing chest pains, coughing up blood, a sudden lump  --  you are immediately admitted to hospital for every possible test for every possible condition.   Hip replacement is not life threatening, so is not given priority. Sure we complain about waiting, but we generally understand that someone with a more urgent need has gone ahead. Personally, I have never waited 2 years for non-urgent health care.   Canada\'s universal health care isn\'t perfect, but we would rather work on improving it than go back to the old days. It\'s nice to know children aren\'t dying because their parents can\'t afford health insurance. No politician here is arguing that limiting insurance to the upper-middle and wealthy classes is a solution to wait lists.  Universal health care has allowed Canada to move beyond the endless tinkering with insurance programs that our American friends are mired in now. We can focus on prevention of health problems from prenatal on, reducing the need for costly crisis intervention, thus reducing wait times. Also, moving non-acute patients out of hospitals and providing home care reduces both costs and wait times and improves patient recovery.', 'Reply to KS from Colorado: "Canada...long waiting lists, say up to 8 months, even 2 year wait to get a hip replacement....The Canadian system does not guarantee care. It only guarantees a place in line." As a Canadian, I find this statement very misleading. In Canada, if you have a life-threatening condition - for example, stabbing chest pains, coughing up blood, a sudden lump -- you are immediately admitted to hospital for every possible test for every possible condition.  Hip replacement is not life threatening, so is not given priority. Sure we complain about waiting, but we generally understand that someone with a more urgent need has gone ahead. Personally, I have never waited 2 years for non-urgent health care.  Canada\'s universal health care isn\'t perfect, but we would rather work on improving it than go back to the old days. It\'s nice to know children aren\'t dying because their parents can\'t afford health insurance. No politician here is arguing that limiting insurance to the upper-middle and wealthy classes is a solution to wait lists.  Universal health care has allowed Canada to move beyond the endless tinkering with insurance programs that our American friends are mired in now. We can focus on prevention of health problems from prenatal on, reducing the need for costly crisis intervention, thus reducing wait times. Also, moving non-acute patients out of hospitals and providing home care reduces both costs and wait times and improves patient recovery.', "Wouldn't pre-existing conditions be covered under the ADA and, if so, how can insurance companies get away with this kind of discrimination? How can they discriminate against people with chronic conditions?", 'I think even the most fervent informed Trump supporters have to feel a little queasy when they contemplate the impact by income graph in the article.  They know the short term reaction by their base might be "great, we fixed that", but the realization will slowly dawn that they\'ve been had.', 'Especially those Trump supporters in red states who will be adversely affected (dead)! #Oopsie', 'Every day it becomes increasingly clearer that the immutable laws of economics mean that unless the Republicans want to allow medical underwriting, that is where insurance companies can reject applicants with preexisting conditions, something very close to Obamacare must be retained. Demand for medical care is inelastic. Controlling prices charged by doctors and hospitals via the use of monopsony like the rest of the developed world does is an anathema to Republicans. Monopsony, meaning "single buyer" is the flip side of monopoly. A monopsonist sets prices below free market equilibrium. It does not matter if there is an actual single payer or many buyers (or payers) whose prices are set by the government or by insurance companies in collusion with each other. see: Obamacare And Beyond: The Outlook For The Healthcare Sector.     http://seekingalpha.com/article/1647632 As it is dawning on the Republicans, any system that does not explicitly control prices must have mandates and subsidies similar to those in Obamacare. Otherwise, most individual insurance policies would be far beyond the reach of middle class Americans since, without medical underwriting insurance companies would have to price their policies based on the assumption that the applicant has a costly preexisting condition..." http://seekingalpha.com/article/4042715', 'I am challenged to understand, item by item, elements of the ACA that are fundamentally problematic to the GOP and what alternatives they propose.  "Federal overreach!"? Ok - so what are the manifestations , and proposed solutions.  Who loses with those solutions?  As a physician, as an executive in an ACA supported organization, and as a witness to the marked improvements associated with the ACA - and its flaws-  I would appreciate a real, data-driven, adult conversation already.', 'This comment shows what news source this person uses: "Well how about also projecting what will happen to Obamacare if left alone. How long until it implodes? How many lose coverage when no providers participate. Tell the whole story!" The writer assumes he knows the "whole story" and assumes, for no doubt he\'s been told (by Fox?) that the ACA will "implode." That\'s only true if the G.O.P. sabotages it, but given that, it may be a self-fulfilling prophecy. But the main idea here is brainwashing is happening and it\'s frightening.', 'In your dreams, Paul.', 'GOP Zombie health plan.  And just as brain dead as actual zombies.', 'No piece of legislation in it\'s original form is perfect. Everyone associated with the passage of the ACA admitted that it was not a perfect piece of legislation. Why the constant drumbeat on the part of the GOP to "repeal and replace"? How about finding a way to make it better? One of the most precious elements of the existing ACA is the provision to insure dependent children until age 26. That was an addition by Senator Susan Collins of Maine. It can be done, just requires some cooperation on both sides.', 'Well how about also  projecting what will happen to Obamacare if left alone. How long until it implodes? How many lose coverage when no providers participate. Tell the whole story!', "Why?  This isn't about ACA, it's about what the Republicans are trying to get passed and the pros and cons are presented to help us understand why it's not a shoe in, so to speak.  I don't think this article was trying to pit this against ACA.  I'm sure there are many sites that do just that.", 'Since these numbers are in comparison to having AHA (i.e. Obamacare), they already show AHA is better. Now, these numbers are in total for the country. In some areas, AHA is not working well such as Wisconsin. So, a state by state chart may show a better picture.', 'Talk to your Republican governor and state legislature abou the implosion. States that supported the implementation (MA, CA) have systems that are working fine and are not imploding.   If you will it to implode (as in many Republican controlled states) Obamacare will implode -- surprise, surprise!']
summary: Commentators universally heap scorn on Republican healthcare policies. Numerous commentators point out the cruelty that "TrumpCare" would inflict on low-income or high-risk people. Several commentators call the Republican plan impractical. Several others call it expensive. One commentator advocates for socialist healthcare provided by the government. One commentator gives a story of how Obamacare helped her. One commentator writes a very, long praise of other countries' health care systems.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Health Insurance and Managed Care; Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010); House of Representatives; House Freedom Caucus; Republican Party   Snippet: A look at what the health bill would do, who it would affect, and how it changed to get more lawmakers to yes.
subreddit: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'House of Representatives', 'House Freedom Caucus', 'Republican Party']

query: There are only traces of Underground Railroad history at Prospect Bluff and Fort Mose. But their stories are impossible to forget.
comments: ['I loved reading this story of Black resistance and freedom prior to the Civil War. The "Red and Black Alliance", consisting of Seminole Indians and Black runaway slaves who resisted in maroon communities, is such an undersold story. This narrative needs to be integrated into public school social studies and history curricula.', "My elementary to high school education (1957 - 1969) in the then-unaccredited public schools of Jacksonville FL included no mention of either of these places, but then, it wasn't until 1967 that the schools were desegregated. So much for 'with all deliberate speed' from 1954... These past few years there has been a lot of kvetching about revisionist history, but those pieces of crap-between-covers used as history texts in far too many public schools desperately need revision, with a wider perspective on the crazy quilt weave we call American history. Stories like these are great examples of what needs to be added, if there's any money left after bearproofing the schools...", 'This is American history we don\'t hear about.  Making a conscious decision to escape the cruelty of human bondage should not be described as a "runaway" slave.  Slave owners and catchers used that language to put the action in a context as if escaping this cruelty was errant.  They should be exalted as the members of a resistance movement and Freedom Fighters. Thank you for this series of articles and as another reader expressed...More of this, please!', "If not already evident from Rosalind's characterization of the Apalachicola area, the story of Fort Gadsden is absent from the cerebration of our history. I went through my entire education in Franklin County never hearing mention of the largest free black settlement of the 1800s. I have always just assumed that the racial stratification in the area was the product of 20th century segregation, so it's empowering to know that the true reason comes from a history of liberation. I hope more people from my community read this so that we can resist the alienation that comes from being a person of color in the rural South. I would love to see this become the new narrative of Franklin County (and less focus on Camp Gordon Johnson).", 'I love New York Times articles like this one.  They bring to light unknown and forgotten history that is important to us.   As a Florida resident for 71 years and the daughter of Florida natives I find the history of Florida fascinating.  From the beautiful Gulf beaches, high bluffs and woods of Pensacola, the sparsely inhabited rural areas of the Panhandle to teeming south Florida coastal cites the state offers so much. For this we owe a lot to the early inhabitants, whether Native Americans, Black slaves seeking freedom or immigrants from Spain and Europe looking for a better future. Please continue publishing these stories!', "In this period of 'Trump' history, we can celebrate this NYT piece about Resistance and Freedom from another time. I live in Florida and I want to celebrate these places.", "Great Article. I miss Jupiter Fl. It's to cold up here.", "A 3rd-generation Floridian (whose entire 4th grade year in a Seminole County public school was devoted to Florida history), I never knew of the existence of the Negro Fort until I attended a conference seven years ago. There I heard about the fort and an eccentric Irish officer in the British Army, Edward Nichols, who recruited runaway slaves and members of Creek, Choctaw, Cherokee, and Seminole tribes and commanded the fort during the War of 1812.  Since moving to the Big Bend area, my family and I have made several pilgrimages to the site, making sure that my daughter's education in Florida history is more broad than mine was. One of the more fascinating lessons we've learned about this place and time in US history is the way that enslaved and indigenous people's lives and rights were used in increasingly cynical ways to forward the ambitions of competing colonial powers. Andrew Jackson's role in such strategies and ambitions should also be emphasized: the Creek allies that Ms. Bentley mentions as helping the Americans destroy the fort were members of a once-sovereign nation divided by federal policies of expansion, exploitation, and extinction; Seminoles and Red-Stick Creek Indians fought against the Americans alongside self-liberated slaves from Georgia and the Carolinas. Fortunately, articles like this, books like Adam Wasserman's A People's History of Florida, and historical literary fiction like Skip Horack's The Eden Hunter, are bringing such history to light.", 'I had no idea of this important history - thank you.  I wish there were a set of books that covered all of this.  Thank you, NYT, for this focus. Please do more.']
summary: Many of the commenters lament that they were never taught this history in school, with several saying they didn't know of the history until reading this article. Some of the users talk about being from the general area in Florida the article talks about, with some of these saying they find Florida's history interesting and unique. Some of the commenters talk about the article itself and how the history between different groups of people of color is important, and several express hope that the New York Times will post more articles like this one.
short_title: Headline: Shadows on the Path Out of Slavery When It Ran South   Keywords: Blacks; Historic Buildings and Sites; Slavery (Historical); Travel and Vacations; Florida   Snippet: There are only traces of Underground Railroad history at Prospect Bluff and Fort Mose. But their stories are impossible to forget.
short_question: ['Shadows on the Path Out of Slavery When It Ran South  ']

query: People lust after everything from actors to new consumer goods. A vast marketplace caters to some of those desires, and exploits others.
comments: ["I find myself in the odd position of standing up for Blake Shelton.  Last year I was walking through Disneyland with my teenage son and my sister.  We saw a small group moving through Tomorrowland with bodyguards and the Disney tour escort (not unusual here).  The man was absolutely mesmerizing and many fellow Californians stopped to stare at his blazing smile, long limbs and shaggy hair.  I had no idea who he was.  I soon realized that Gwen Stefani was part of the group.  I recognized her, but she was a muted presence beside him despite her full hair, make-up and shiny black boots.  That man will electrify you in person.  Consider also the Blake Shelton references in the Amy Schumer episode that parodies 12 Angry Men.  I seldom see People magazine, but I'm all for women disputing their judgment of sexiness.  On the other hand, seeing Blake Shelton in person might change anyone's mind!", 'Women do not owe men their beauty.  I have said for years that if women just stop spending their income on the unattainable demands of men they will reap the world.', "While it may be true that women's curves often define sexy, I disagree that men's faces define their sexiness. Mark Wahlberg is not sexy because of his face. And when any lead male not in a comedy takes off his shirt, it is expected he should reveal a chiseled triangle shaped chest close to washboard stomach, and in America it should be hairless. There are expectations for men's bodies too. And it is a Michael Phelps Ryan Gosling Brad Pitt He-man chest. (Even the photo of Jeff Bezos in this Sunday's newspaper features a triangle chested man who looks like he would would look good with his shirt off.) Sorry but Seth Rogen will never get to play Darth Maul. If the dad body is having his day so too are the voluptuous figures of Mindy Kaling, Rebel Wilson, and Melissa McCarthy--all comedy.", 'It is interesting to me that for all the talk about "The Male Gaze" and objectification, on and on, that it is women who buy make up, who buy sexy dresses, who buy high heels (which have to be even more torture than neck ties), who support dozens of publications on everything from how to be the perfect housewife to how to catch and hold your man.   Can we agree that no woman should be forced into sex or a relationship she does not want?  That respect for each other is the foundation for good business and friendship, that teaching the incoming generation is good for the organization and must never come with conditions. Can we also agree that pushing sex into the shadows rather than celebrating it as a glorious part of life is the cause of much of our problems?  That if this were something that was part of everyday life, that much of the coercion, would go away? Our existing way of dealing with the relationships between men and women in the public sphere does not seem to be working.  Perhaps its time we looked at the underlying assumptions.', 'The sad fact is that "sexy" often means reduction to object.  Although the article focuses on the curvaceous body image, one has only to pick up most any "women\'s" magazine and one is struck by the anorexic, in some cases opiate addicted mimic, body form in ads for clothing, cosmetics, travel, etc.  Men are similarly judged, though a lot more is forgiven the wealthier or more "powerful" he is.  Thus, the origin of arm candy.  In America ads from my childhood emphasized the sunny tan (ignoring the melanoma that results); still does, but with some limitation.  In Africa, skin lighteners are sold, products which contain carcinogens and other toxic chemicals.  Brown up in America, lighten in Africa.  The objective is to create dissatisfaction with who we are.  We need to accept people as they are, not how well or poorly they fit into some ridiculous stereotype of what is beautiful, or handsome, or strong.  It is a sickness that infects the whole of our assessment of our fellow human beings.', 'A bisexual friend\'s take on this (discussed a couple of years back): Straight men\'s arousal tendencies are pretty standard: Take apparent youth, a fertile appearing body, and whatever fetish(es) that the guy possesses and you\'ve pretty much got it.  Straight women have far more varied tastes and desires. Post-adolescent youth, good hygiene, a deep voice and not too short seem to be commonalities but after that, anything goes.  The point made was that most straight men find very similar women desirable but straight women views of desirable (discounting power and money, which when women posses them, don\'t appear to be aphrodisiacs for men) are all over the map.  Personally, this straight woman finds most of the supposed "sexiest men" not that attractive (especially male models who look bizarre to me). So I may be part of the proof that our attractions are all over the map.', 'No matter what is being called "sexy" male, female, automobile or home, it is always for the male gaze and that irritates me very much.  Blake Shelton is non-threatening. He\'s the guy next door that you hardly notice. And that is so men won\'t feel threatened.  It\'s as if women and what they want doesn\'t exist. It\'s as if women don\'t have jobs and money of their own.  The advertising/entertainment industry is odious.', 'Sexiness is an energy that comes from within. I think it is total complete confidence in one’s sexuality, self, abilities etc and perhaps it is being one’s true authentic self. Case in point, about a decade ago, myself and some girlfriends took an intro to pole dancing class. The instructor comes into the room. The instructor was a “voluminous” woman, think Venus of Willendorf with 20 extra pounds. I thought I do not want to watch a fat person pole dance. This was back when I was younger and thought I knew everything. Well the woman got on the pole and proceeded to move in a way that could only be described as true, raw, unadulterated, authentic sexiness. While I didn’t learn to pole dance that night, I did learn that outside appearances do not create sexiness. This woman had proved my belief that outward appearance determine sexiness untrue. If it doesnt come from outward appearance (this woman was overweight, may have been borderline obese and was not a shape i considered sexy), then where does it come from?? Its an energy that comes from within. Most people are a long way from accessing this from within themselves, which is why marketing sexiness is successful.   Regarding sexiness, marketing resonates with and exploits the self doubts and unassuredness “baggage” that block that beautiful vibe called “sexiness” that is in inside of each and every one of us. Until people look within for sexiness, there will always be a market for lipsticks, push-up bras and Rogaine.', 'The interesting thing about all this is the unstated assumption that "sexy" is mainly a visual thing. Understandable, given that celebrity culture is overwhelmingly visual, but probably deeply misleading, given that more and more research suggests that visual stimuli are only a small part of what determines sexual attraction in humans, smell and sound being apparently at least equally if not more important. Some research suggests this is particularly true for women.  In other words, if we really wanted to find out who the sexiest man or woman alive is, sniffing them would probably be more useful than looking at pictures of them.', 'Thought experiment...is a process of defining masculinity and "acceptable" masculinity going on in a manner now that mirrors the definition of feminity and "acceptable" femininity that we have been unwinding for that last 100 years at an accelerating pace. Another thought experiment...is masculinity in contemporary culture being cleansed and purified with the same frenzy as heresy during the Inquisition. Is the male now to feel guilty for having a male gaze? Should males look at women with the female s3lf-reflexive gaze alone?', "Looking forward to a world in which comfortable shoes and clean plastic-free faces are the norm. It'll be quite a revolution.", 'What Ms. Roberts seems to say is that women want something other than sex (wrong: women want sex too). Women have always more--sex and spirit and personality (not to mention intelligence). It is only that women have recently achieved political and economic power such that those choices are more readily recognizable.  What Ms. Roberts seems to be describing in hopeful terms is what the market will ultimately serve up so long as women continue to gain that power. Is it any wonder that all those iterations of the male gaze were on billboards, screens and commercials when female labor participation rates/compensation parity and political representation were and are still lopsided? We have a long way to go, baby.', 'There is a major difference in what drives straight male sexual arousal and women based on my experience. Most men are visually oriented and enjoy viewing attractive women. This is a major turn-on. From what i can tell, women\'s arousal is way more complex and the visual is only one factor. Not all of us are sexual predators, "undress" women in our minds or have rape in mind. We like looking at attractive women solely for sake of their appeal. I think this can interfere with women\'s equality in the work place. We males have to be conscious of separating out our emotional bias in dealing with ladies.', '>>> We can imagine deifying different bodies or a wider variety of them; we might even imagine a post-gaze society, where we lust after personality and spirit rather than external appearance. But all of this would require reimagining centuries of culture — and reconfiguring the billions of dollars of powerful market forces built atop them. Good luck. All of this would require rewiring basic human male biology.', "sexy - a Hollywood construct - the way Marilyn Monroe could turn on 'sexy' breathy voice and wiggly walk ? cultural differences - I recall when most people in India were hungry, their female movie stars were mostly 'plump' - ooh, I want what she's having ! (more food) hormones and DNA drives - young males may walk around lusting after anything that moves - as an old guy my lower testosterone has me appreciating beauty without the pressure to score. sexy advertising - I recall tyre shops with pix of lingerie-clad females draped across the tyres - that got males attention - feel like you want some of this ? - yeah ! - one set of tyres please ! advertising in general - create an urgent desire ? - for the spend-most 18-35yos - sex can help - or at least it did in my youth - not sure about free internet porn's influence on reduction of unrequited lust these days. create anxiety ? - 'imagine' these beautiful people - you're not one of them - right ?  Maybe if you buy some of these shiny new expensive toys ? to which my frugalista recalls - 'most people driving shiny new cars are not millionaires - most millionaires do not drive shiny new cars'", 'Anna Wintour seems to exercise a significant amount of influence over these matters.  How do you think the patriarchy controls her?  Blackmail?', '"Sexiness" has basically become an advertising construct having little to do with actual sex and more to do with an idealized vision of sex and, as Naomi Wolf would observe, our frustrations at not being able to attain it. Sexiness is used to manipulate both women and men.  Men, because we swim in testosterone (at least during that period of life when we are a \'target market\'), may be more easily manipulated by images.  Women, because they\'ve been taught to be insecure, may be more easily manipulated by the dream of making themselves more attractive. Far from limiting the influence of sex, sexual taboos have made us more vulnerable to that sort of manipulation.   We are a society in flux--maybe permanent flux.  Technology (birth control, communications, etc.), changes in life styles (from agrarian to urban), and the influence of multiple cultures have all called into question our sexual mores and roles.  We will continue to struggle with this, I suspect, until more mature attitudes develop, if ever.', "So what is the patriarchy holding over Anna Wintour? Honestly, the rest of us have figured out that folks like you don't even really care about whatever issue you're riding.  It's all about attention, social and professional ambition, and the psychological relief of redirected self-judgement.", 'Ms. Roberts, the female gaze does exist, has gained force in the digital age. Head over to Tumblr and type “Benedict Cumberbatch” into the search box. Or another appealing male star. Enjoy the rabbit hole.', 'What is sexy matters most to unrequited, fanciful imaginations seeking assurance of normality. Rubbish, you say.  Indeed, its on the DNA and nakedness is practically a universal norm.  Besides, what would the world be like without Madison Avenue and slick advertisements.', 'To paraphrase United States Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart, you just know Sexy when you see it.', "Advertisers decide what is sexy in that they try a bunch of things and see what works best to sell garbage to stupid people. Hollywood knows what is sexy in that they try a bunch of things and see what works best to sell garbage to stupid people. We are only consumers to those that work in the manipulative industries. We are not even human beings. Of course, many people think it's their duty to be a good cowed consumer of garbage. Their belief that they are patriotic in their consuming is confirmed for them by the manipulative industries. The question is rather childish and insulting. But then childish is what most people have been trained to be. I guess you were talking to them because you have some garbage to sell."]
summary: The comments talk about how sexuality is almost always from a male point of view.   One commentator says that our concept of sexy comes from centuries of a culture that values physical appearance more.   Other comments say that "sexy" has more to do with the energy that emanates from inside the person than their appearance.   Another commentator says that each one considers sexy has to do with their culture.   Another comment speaks of the importance of accepting ourselves and other people as we are, without letting that cause us anxiety.
short_title: Headline: Hot Property   Keywords: Sex; Advertising and Marketing; Women and Girls; Men and Boys   Snippet: People lust after everything from actors to new consumer goods. A vast marketplace caters to some of those desires, and exploits others.
subreddit: ['Sex', 'Advertising and Marketing', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys']
short_question: ['Hot Property  ']

query: Martín Zimmerman’s play, starring Marin Ireland, approaches the subject of American gun violence from a startlingly original perspective.
comments: ['This play is about, among other things, a mass murder committed using a gun - something that happens, on average, every single day in only one country - this one. In the country where the irresponsible legislators misinterpret the Constitution and permit guns everywhere - oh wait - not everywhere - everywhere except where they work - like the Capitol Building or the inauguration of the current president.  Irresponsible hypocrites. If not for their inaction, this play would not exist.', 'Wow, and they call us kneejerk liberals? The reviewer never said AR stands for assault rifle. Yes they are referred to that in common parlance, or as our friends would put it, by the "fake" media.  That aside, I saw the play last night. Quite an intelligent piece of writing, and not overtly political, although any play focusing on the mother of a victim of a school shooting, is bound to hit buttons on either side of the emotional issue.', "I love how all these people who have never seen this play are so offended by the idea that a grieving mother would become obsessed by a detail of how her son was killed. The review seems to say the play is exploring the idea of grief and the human mind... not necessarily some agitprop attack on guns. But - you know - it's important to degrade things you never get to see when they appear to disagree with your world view.", "AR stands for Armalite Rifle. Typical emotional-based liberal attack offering no solutions. Fact is, 90% of the gun violence originates in liberal, democrat controlled cities such as chicago, balltimore, NYC, Detroit. Removing these stats from the overall gun violence and America's gun violence drops precipitously. un violence is about hate and lack of good parents, and spiritual guided lives. Rubbish from the living in fear liberal sides of life.", 'But what did you think of the play? Have you bothered to see it?', 'I understand what you\'re saying to, or trying to anyway.  I stand in a middle ground area on this issue. You make good points.  But don\'t you think it\'d be wiser and more helpful if you calmed down before you wrote and left the insulting comments about your readers aside ("typical etc...") and approached "the other side" as intelligent people whose minds you might even change. You are writing to the NY Times after all. I\'m an old man now and I understand that it\'s the way now to simply attack those who don\'t think like you do with names and emotion. It\'s not the way it used to be and it\'s not how anything\'s going to change. So relax. No one\'s going to take your guns away and maybe they shouldn\'t.  But please let\'s all of us understand that talk and discussion must be returned to a civil level. As it is, it\'s ironic that your somewhat unhinged attitude might do more to frighten people about guns in others\'  hands than anything you write. Take a walk. Relax.', 'Assault Rifle! OMG another clueless snowflake liberal ignorant of firearms and hiding behind irrational xenophobia. AR stands for Armalite Rifle and is no different from a circa 1800\'s six shooter.  Read John Lotts "More Guns Less Crime" and start living in the reality that guns are NOT the reason for crimes. HATE and FEAR and LACK OF "GOOD PARENTS" are the reasons for the shootings plaguing the always democrat-controlled cities in the  USA.', 'In the Marine Corps we broke down our M16 "assault rifle" to its component parts and reassembled it blindfolded, plus cleaned it obsessively whenever we even looked at it in a mean way.  Familiarity breeds boredom.  To me a rifle is about as exciting as a lawn mower.  I cannot understand the fascination and obsession of so many people in this country, from all shades of the political spectrum, with these weapons.', 'The fact is that democrats/liberals want to disarm good Americans for a variety of reasons whether insidious - many in office and media are antiAmericans and want submission to government control in all areas of our lives -  or even with good intentions - save the kids - albeit misguided.', "I'm wondering what you thought of the production?  Or did you come here just to insult people who may have a perspective different from yours?  Aren't people who don't think like you just so darned dumb?!", '"On the Exhale,"  a one-act play by Martin Zimmerman, featuring Marin Ireland as  Woman who lost her son in tthe massacre in Sandy Hook, Ct. in 2012, reviewed by Ben Brantley, Feb. 19, 2017. This play arose from the anguish, pain, and anger over the senseless horror that was visited upon 26 hapless children in Sandy Hook. However, in centering "On the Exhale" on one mother\'s loss and grief, the play reduces a tragedy of universal magnitude into a private nightmare that almost unhinges an individual mother. Deaths by gun violence are becoming a daily occurrence  in our streets, schools, restaurants, theaters, offices, picnic grounds, and even mosques. Gun manufacturers and gunrunners are making huge profits. More and more people are beginning to view guns as symbols of liberty because of  a carelessly-worded Second Amendment in the Constitution of the United States. To write a play or a novel  that would evoke  the moral horror of this human tragedy, we need a playwright of Brechtian or Beckettian dramatic genius. Nevertheless, I applaud Martin Zimmerman\'s painstaking effort to delve deeply into the tortured mind of a mother who lost her only son to gun violence.', '"Since she is not allowed access to the shooter or his family, she comes to focus on a weapon he used, an assault rifle. " Yes, an all too common theme is America today.  No one is responsible for their own actions so we blame either the inanimate object or society as a whole.   Is it any wonder we are nearing the bottom of the swirling toilet bowl in our demise?']
summary: A couple of commenters argue that AR stands for Armalite Rifle and that liberals are ignorant, while others argue that the reviewer never said AR stands for assault rifle and that the conservative commenters need to calm down. Several commenters say that the pro-gun commenters need to actually watch the play to understand the article's discussion about assault rifles. Many other commenters argue back and forth about gun control.
short_title: Headline: The Irresistible Attraction of an Assault Rifle   Keywords: On the Exhale (Play); Theater; Roundabout Theater Co; Ireland, Marin; Zimmerman, Martin (Playwright); School Shootings and Armed Attacks   Snippet: Martín Zimmerman’s play, starring Marin Ireland, approaches the subject of American gun violence from a startlingly original perspective.
subreddit: ['On the Exhale (Play)', 'Theater', 'Roundabout Theater Co', 'Ireland, Marin', 'Zimmerman, Martin (Playwright)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
short_question: ['The Irresistible Attraction of an Assault Rifle  ']

query: Is it necessary to disclose tentative plans for a home office during a co-op interview?
comments: ['Contrary to what the writer said regarding condos, in Manhattan most Condo boards do need to approve purchasers. Sometimes there is a "right of first refusal" clause in the package.  Sometimes the package is basically a non-event, where the board simply makes phone call inquires to a bank, stock-broker or accountant, in order to verify the buyer\'s assets.  At other times there is a full board package similar to that of a coop. Now there are also disclosure forms so that money-laundering is prevented and buying by \'unknown" people doesn\'t fly either.  Restrictions are in place limiting the type of businesses conducted out of the condo also exist.  I would suggest having your broker inquire about what businesses already exist in the building before applying and finding out after the fact that no business with patients are allowed. Marji Wollin, broker avery new york', "Please: Be a mensch and rent some office space; the good news it's a tax-deductible business expense, and you will avoid a lot of worry and extend you life and improve your health. Or be a sneaky person and try to get away with stuff; people will know something about you is unlikable but won't exactly know, but we will.", 'Very simple.  Say nothing.', 'Just seeing the title of this article made me grateful I bought a house.', "(1) Don't lie (2) Don't volunteer (3) Don't speculate = (4) Read the bylaws (5) KNOW the bylaws = (6) Ask your realtor about the building's practices; make this an inquiry about your future neighbors = (7) Condos often exceed their authority; mine did; I sued, I won, there is a large case law on this and a few semi-specializing lawyers. One should assume coop boards do also. (7a) Litigation is ruinous, but comes the territory = (8) familiarize yourself with streeteasy.com, for your building. = (9) As noted, is your biz one with traffic?", 'As a lawyer, I find pushy and nosy neighbors to be a nuisance and who sometimes step over the red line of harassment.    I live in a condo that has parking designated for compact cars.  My sister parked her mini suv in compact car spot next to the loading dock to pick something up.  A lady came out and said that the suv was parked in the wrong space.  I told her we would be there a couple of minutes, even though the card was arguably a compact car.  She became aggressive and said she was going to call the security or the police.  I told her to go ahead and she then said she worked for the FBI.  At this my sisters started laughing and ignored her.  The point being is that she has no enforcement power other than being able to complain to the management.  These appear to be the type of  busy bodies that populate coop-op boards and make me glad that I don\'t have to deal with them.  Please, "Get a life."', 'When I find someone parked in my assigned parking space, I call the towing company with which my condo has a contract.', 'From his description, it sounded like an unassigned spot.', 'In our modern society, it would be difficult to find people who do no work whatsoever in their home. Online, on the phone, or perhaps the very occasional visitor. On the other hand, multiple clients trooping in and out? Business- related sounds, sights, smells or vibrations? No. Certainly there are many occupations where the neighbors would say 10 years later- I had no idea he was a such and such.', 'You should be a considerate neighbor. That is: does your business make noise that people in the building can hear? Does your business require that many complete strangers have access to the building? Does your business create smells that others in the building can smell? Vibrations? Do you do any of these things on the weekends or at night? Etc, etc.  My attitude is that once your behavior starts to negatively affect other people, you should compensate them. But people cannot be trusted to do the right thing, so we are forced to "zone" for commercial and residential. So yeah, be sure you aren\'t being a bad neighbor. And if you are, make up for it.', 'Many people work at home or operate a small home-based business in ways that are non-intrusive and non-disruptive, including people who are employed full-time but tele-commute at least part of the time.   I know many people who are writers, researchers, web developers or consultants, or who operate small businesses that don\'t entail meeting clients at their home. In my building, there are several tenants who work at home in these ways.  If the "coaching" in this case is something such as career or life coaching, it certainly could be done very discreetly from home, perhaps meeting the clients at their own homes or offices or coaching them via phone, email, or Skype.  Another option is to rent a "virtual office" from an office suite firm - you use the office suite address as your business address and arrange to use a conference room when you need to meet with clients - but otherwise work from home. The freelance workforce is huge and growing. Most of this work is quiet and "invisible" to fellow residents, landlords, and co-op boards - not the kind of business that entails noise, intrusive traffic, or other nuisance.  Zoning laws and rental, co-op, and condo rules need to change to reflect this.', 'What are you "coaching"?  If whatever it is causes noise, you are not going to get away with it.  Every coop I have been in has a boiler plate clause in the proprietary lease, by-laws or house rules that prohibits running a business from the apartment. Nevertheless, I have visited various professionals in their apartments in residential coops where they live and work (not on the first floor): physical therapist, psychologist and lawyer.  None of these cause much noise at all.', "In today's world, about 95% of 'work from home' consists of logging onto your company's VPN, and making phone calls.   No board is going to tell you what you can or cannot do on your computer, or what kind of phone calls you can make.", 'I would check the prospective lease very carefully.  In my co-op, it specifically restricts apartments to "residential use only."  This is partly due to the certificate of occupancy issued by the city which can be unexpectedly strict.  For instance, a medical office cannot be used as a business office without an official change in the document.', 'The nature of the business is fundamental in determining if it is acceptable. For example, if you are a writer, that isn\'t an intrusion, noisy job. But having clients in or out of the apartment all day, may be seen as disruptive. The flow of too much traffic from your apartment could make people feel they are living in a commercial building instead of a residential one. You mention "coaching purposes". What do you mean: is it  IT work or is it singing, dancing, etc.? One is quiet and the other might have the neighbors complaining. Consider most people would not want a Tuba or singing coach as their neighbor.', 'The NYC Zoning Resolution refers to this as a "Home Occupation."  The definition of this term is provided within the pdf linked in the article.   Home occupation (2/2/11) (a) A "home occupation" is an #accessory use# which: (1) is clearly incidental to or secondary to the #residential use# of a #dwelling unit# or #rooming unit#; (2) is carried on within a #dwelling unit#, #rooming unit#, or #accessory building# by one or more occupants of such #dwelling unit# or #rooming unit#, except that, in connection with the practice of a profession, one person not residing in such #dwelling unit# or #rooming unit# may be employed; and (3) occupies not more than 25 percent of the total #floor area# of such #dwelling unit# or #rooming unit# and in no event more than 500 square feet of #floor area#.', 'Rarely enforced against violators. A lawyer bought a 2-family house on my block and ran a business (not his practice) out of the house. He had 3 employees and occasional visits from clients. A very quiet operation and no one ever complained. Helped that the lawyer is a very personable guy who got along with everyone on the block. But he was violating the R3-1 zoning and he knew it. Later he sold the business and the house, which is now a residence again.', "What has what's allowed in a 2-family house got to do with what's allowed in a co-op?  With a house, it's a Zoning issue.  Houses and co-ops are entirely different.", '"If you are concerned that a co-op board might take a dim view of home offices, consider buying in a condominium, as condo boards generally do not need to approve purchasers. That way, the board would never have an opportunity to inquire about your plans and you could get right to work." While a condo board\'s approval of your purchase may be little more than a formality, there could be restrictions on home offices written into the condo\'s Rules & Regulations (as there are in mine), so it would be wise to review the R&R before entering into an agreement. How vigorously the Board enforces those regulations varies from condo to condo; certainly, prominent evidence of work activity (e.g. clients waiting in the lobby for their appointments, as noted in the article) would be an invitation to an injunction.']
summary: Some commenters focus on the laws in particular, while others focus on what the user can "get away with." The ones that focus on the laws say to read everything carefully to see if their rental agreement has clauses such as "residential use only." The other commenters talk about being discrete and not making a lot of noise; in fact, many of the users mention that the appropriateness of telling or not telling the co-op board depends on if they will make a lot of noise or if people will be coming in and out a lot.
short_title: Headline: If I Want to Work From Home, Should I Tell the Co-op Board?   Keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential); Cooperatives   Snippet: Is it necessary to disclose tentative plans for a home office during a co-op interview?
short_question: ['If I Want to Work From Home, Should I Tell the Co-op Board?  ']

query: What risks, sacrifices or special equipment are necessary to pursue your favorite activity at night?
comments: ["Anyone brave enough to embrace the insecurities of riding out on a wave in the pitch dark knows what they're doing. I'd say that if I knew what I was doing on a surfboard surrounded by shark infested water, I would surely attempt to embrace this festivity during night hours. No one can blame these surfers for trying to do this, as surfing spots during the day become harder to find with ease, that glorious wave turning over on the reef becomes ever harder to find. At night it's different, only the bravest and most daring surfers attempt to surf the waters, but they do it because they enjoy it. They enjoy the peacefulness at night, with no human body around to surf in the way of their big wave of a dream. These night pastimes are very common throughout society, even with myself. At night, the stars open up, and I find myself gazing up at them for hours upon end. I love taking unique photos through my camera, and even better yet at night. I seek out very dark desolate places, such as Eastern Oregon, where lights seldom brighten up the sky. It is so peaceful here, with only the stars to look up at, and a camera at my side. It may only take time and a place for you to rest your eyes upon the darkness of night for yourself.", "After reading the article, I don't blame the surfers one bit. While surfing at night is dangerous due to there being no life guard to watch over them in the dark, I don't blame them because they have the strong motivated desire to do what they love. I personally like to exercise such as lift weights and do calisthenics at night in my back yard. Although the mosquito's get the best of me during summer nights, in the winter and fall I very much enjoy exercising at night because it is very peaceful. Luckily my form of work at night doesn't pose any risks or dangers but the only thing that can hurt me is myself in regards to the weights.  I admire the surfers for taking on such dangers to pursue what they most enjoy, and the fact that they choose to do it at night increases the danger level which makes my respect for them that much greater.", 'I can definitely lose sleep over some things in life, namely my passions such as chess. Chess is an obsession for me, something that has driven a lot of my goals in life. It has changed my way of thinking and made me into who I am. I would most definitely lose sleep over chess; I already have. I\'ve stayed up memorizing strategies and tactical positions in order to get a better grip on an opponent, or just for the fun of learning it. I\'ve stayed up for over 3 hours in an intense chess game that culminated in my success. So, yes, I would stay up for chess. I respect those surfers who brave all of the bad conditions in order to pursue their passion. What they are doing is not letting the norms define them. That is something that I can get behind, and it is something that I respect as a person. That being said, as a person I am relatively conservative, and I would not throw my life away for a simple chess game. That is where I draw the line. But I can understand the reasoning behind the simple passion that drives these surfers and their "eccentric" behaviors.', "I believe that the nighttime surfers are very brave to go out at night and surf. They suffer many challenges that day time surfers do not. One, the low viability at night makes it hard for the surfers to see what they are doing. Although they have made LED boards, this doesn't completely solve the problem. They also must deal with sharks. Although the chance to encounter a shark is low, they are still a risk and night time surfers need to be careful. Also, if any of the surfers get hurt, there are no lifeguards to help them. If i were to do a nighttime sport, it would be night skiing. I believe that it would be a very different experience from day time skiing and would be very fun.", "I really admire and respect those who are willing to risk their life just so they can do that one special thing they love. It's dangerous to go night surfing with sharks, low visibility, and a lack of lifeguards, but I see why these people do it. When you get that rush of doing something you love, your worries sort of disappear. When I need to clear my head, I really like walking around outside on nights when it's raining. It's relaxing hearing the rain drops lightly plop against the umbrella. I also really like cold temperatures, so having that ice cold air brush against your cheeks is great. The only things you need to be careful of is, firstly, the sidewalk. The sidewalk where I live is not even at all, so you have to watch your step. Also, combining the darkness of the night hours with someone who loves dressing from head to toe in black isn't always the best idea, so you have to make sure cars see you when you're trying to cross the street. These things are a simple fix because all you need is a flashlight to help cars see you and to light up the areas on the sidewalk that are uneven. My favorite activity isn't even close to being as life threatening as  night surfing, but I still can understand why people can so easily overcome those dangerous obstacles for their own pleasure.", "I am amazed at how these people are willing to risk their lives for something they love. It takes great courage to be able to face the dangers of surfing at night. Personally, I believe night surfing is a crazy idea because of sharks, low visibility and lack of lifeguard support. If something were to go wrong which is not unlikely, they surfer could be in serious danger. I don't think I would ever be able to risk my life to go night surfing. However, I do love swimming at night. But not in the ocean. I prefer the safety of my own pool where there are no sharks to worry about. I love looking up and seeing the stars and the utter silence except for the soft rippling of the water. There is something so peaceful about just relaxing and swimming in the cool water. I understand why these surfers risk their life, but I don't think I would ever be able to do the same.", "The surfers who risk their lives to surf at night are inspirational if u look at the bare aspect of what their doing. It may seem like just a hobby to readers like us, but it is a part of their life they are willing to take drausitic measures to achieve. Most people know the saying you only live once, and that's exactly what their doing-- living. It may seem crazy, but to these people it's worth the risk to feel alive. I think this is inspirational. In the summer i like to run early in the morning or at night, the sunrise and sunsets are beautiful and that feels cool for what feels like the first time in months. it's one of my favorite feethings. Also i like to walk on the beach at night in the summer. The sand cools down and the waves are such a good background noise. My favorite activities at night don't differ equipment wise from when they occur in the daytime, except for maybe a light to run. — What sort of special equipment or adaptations would your nighttime activity require? Are these available now, or could they be invented? Why or why not?", "I think that someone who is willing to risk their life for something important is brave and courageous. If you run into a burning building to save a life then I have a lot of respect for you. But if you just risk your life to go surfing, I consider that to be a form of stupidity. But that's your choice to make, and if your really that passionate about something then by all means go for it. Personally I would love to play airsoft at night. The combination of zero vision and tactics make sure for a very interesting game. However to properly play, pyrotechnics and NVG's would be required, and both are expensive and the first shows great promise of starting a wildfire.", 'I respect those who are willing to risk their life to do something they love, but personally I think it’s crazy. Sharks, low visibility and lack of lifeguards are all a recipe for disaster. Although night surfing in my opinion is crazy & dangerous, it sounds like a lot of fun & would be something I would like to try at some point.  Even with its risk, I understand why people like surfing at night.  When I play tennis, I love to play in the evening. It is cooler outside at night, and the lights shinning down on the courts create an awesome atmosphere. The only difference is there is a 0% I will die from drowning, or from a shark attack.', 'I admire the people who take the risk of surfing at night. This shows how passionate they are about what they love, no matter the potential danger. I would like to try night surfing at some point, I think it would be exciting. I generally have more energy at night, and I like nighttime better, so I typically enjoy doing things at night instead. For instance, if I planned to go for a run, I would rather do it at night than in the morning or the afternoon.', "Personally, I think the people who endanger themselves by surfing at night are crazy. You could pay me a million dollars and I wouldn't go out surfing at night. Correction, I would most certainly go surfing at night for a million dollars, but a hundred dollars wouldn't cut it. Maybe the only thing I would stay up so late for would be riding a dirt bike. However, the dirt bike in question would have a headlight, and there would be no sharks in this hypothetical excursion.", 'I commend the bravery and ambition of those who risk their safety to do what they love, but the peril that accompanies this specific activity seem almost definitive of its purpose. I fear that one would lose their life like Cooke, while, yes, doing what they loved, but also doing something that could just as easily have been done during the day. I believe that doing what one loves is worth losing sleep but not risking their lives. I would be willingly eager to lose sleep to do things that I love. This ambition comes from doing what makes me happiness. I would willingly lose sleep if that meant I was having adventures with friends or being a night owl at Starbucks reading a book. For some odd reason, I find motivation to grind out assignments in the middle of the night while. I feel this sense of advantage over those who are asleep. Of course, this motivation is only apparent if I happen to feel the energy to stay awake or am not able to sleep. At any level of energy, I am able to find another night owl to go on adventures with to 24hour donut shops. These activities require the sacrifice of my sleep, of course, but it opens my eyes to a new realm of the world. When it comes to equipment, I do not think that writing or driving to a donut shop requires any special equipment. However, I am always open to new types of coffee that truly are able to drive me forward. Coffee is the gasoline of life at times, and this becomes true when one decides to extend their day into the night.']
summary: Many commenters feel that people who risk their lives to surf at night in the dark are very brave and inspirational in doing what they love. Several commenters discuss their own passions, such as chess and calisthenics, and understand how people can become so driven to do things like that despite the risks. Some commenters disagree, feelings that risking one's life for a hobby is stupid.
short_title: Headline: What Work, Sport or Pastime Do You Like to Do at Night?   Keywords: Surfing; Reading and Writing Skills (Education)   Snippet: What risks, sacrifices or special equipment are necessary to pursue your favorite activity at night?
short_question: ['What Work, Sport or Pastime Do You Like to Do at Night?  ']

query: The return of a founding partner makes members of the firm question what they’ve come to represent.
comments: ['The show sounds interesting. I wish I could watch it.  Any indication on when it will come to Netflix?', 'I find the Maia story and her family tedious and boring. Yes, they are the reason that Diane couldn;t retire to Europe. But, I think it detracts from the rest of the show,', 'This analysis seems to forget the central character and main interest of this series: Diane. The building up of Marissa (whom I found merely annoying in The Good Wife) as a major character is making her part of a potentially riveting detective couple with all the vitality that the Luca story line lacks.', "Guess what? It's a show about white privilege. Except it doesn't seem to know which side it's on. I'm increasingly uncomfortable with Diane, Maia and marissa so obviously the only whites in the firm and such saints! By the end of the series, they'll have saved the firm with all their perky smarts. How did Colin turn out to be such a normal guy with parents like these? All this coulda been written by an alt-right scripted. Yep, all the stereotypes are on display but with such great dialogue.", 'what re we supposed to think about Lucca, though? She and Colin seemed to have a relationship of convenience, not a love affair and she believes the most cynical definition of their relationship without explaining herself to him....but then starts sobbing after she breaks up with him? Hot sex but no emotional honesty?', 'I had the same thought regarding Henry\'s "suicide" attempt.  I am not convinced he would have gone through with it even if he had been able to reach the rope.  this show is great, but it is suffering from the same problems that The Good Wife had.  Too many characters and plots.', 'Poor Lucca is getting "Kalinda-ed." And at least Kalinda had a chance to shine before pushed into a corner in that grotesque subplot involving her ex-husband. The Kings need to "recuse" themselves from Lucca and have someone write her back onto the show as a featured player.  Ms. Jumbo\'s acting is growing on me and she deserves better.']
summary: Most commenters do not seem to like the show. Some commenters talk about how they do not like the show and the problems with the plot. One commenter talks about how the show glorifies white privilege. The last commenter says the show seems interesting and that they want to watch it.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Television; The Good Fight (TV Program)   Snippet: The return of a founding partner makes members of the firm question what they’ve come to represent.

query: Led by Sergio Garcia of Spain, golfers from Europe occupied five of the first eight places.
comments: ['"with the pair wielding their putters like daggers".  In fact, it was shot-making, not putting, that was the story.  Their putting was somewhat mediocre.  However, once Garcia punched out from the hazard on the 13th, every subsequent full swing of his was pure, when even a single wayward swing would have cost him the title.  Yes, people tend to remember putts the most, but Sergio\'s ball striking down the stretch is some of the best one will ever witness.', "I think Freddy Couples made a 7 on the 12th hole at Augusta in '92 in the first or second round and went in to win.", 'All pars for Fred on #12 in 1992.  Had one double bogey on #14 in Round 2.', 'Golf is international and players outside of the U.S. continue to improve their skills and scores.', "the europeans, in this case, have shown with their dominance in the ryder cup in recent years that they're at least equal to the americans.....", "Fowler will wait awhile for his major, unless it's a PGA, doesn't putt well enough for either a Masters or US Open, and his slashing swing style really isn't an Open approach you need, to wild that will some point get one in real trouble. Lucky go free attitude needs to be reeled in before a major is in his trophy case."]
summary: One commentator notes that the article focuses on putts while the big shots were the real story, including a string of perfect hits by Garcia. One commentator observes that Fowler needs to improve his skills before getting a Major trophy. Another commentator sees that foreigners are improving their game and are on par with Americans. One other commentator tells the story of Freddy Couples' come-from-behind victory.
short_title: Headline: A Leaderboard With European Panache   Keywords: Golf; Masters Golf Tournament; Augusta National Golf Club; Garcia, Sergio   Snippet: Led by Sergio Garcia of Spain, golfers from Europe occupied five of the first eight places.
subreddit: ['Golf', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'Augusta National Golf Club', 'Garcia, Sergio']
short_question: ['A Leaderboard With European Panache  ']

query: Thursday: A meet-and-greet with Staten Island Chuck, bodegas shut in protest, and Prairie Dog Day.
comments: ['"\'Punxsutawney Phil is the only true weather forecasting groundhog,\' the rodent’s website says. \'The others are just impostors.\' Well, Pennsylvania: We, in New York, politely disagree." I don\'t.  It\'s a silly publicity event.  Who cares? It\'s too bad Staten Island can\'t find other way to garner some media attention.', 'Nice digs, but the solar panels are kind of over-doing it.', 'First of all. Nice close-up of the Groundhog. The nails are especially impressive, which is probably why it appears to be in a glass cage...with lots of food. I actually had no idea it had so much company (Holtsville Hal?, Maleverne Mel? Dunkirk Dave??? ---Wow!) Anyway, the lady has a really nice house. Thanks for the weather report.', 'NYT continues her feverish quest to eradicate the masculine  pronoun Bravo!', 'Knicks bocker Nets', 'She is also the cutest!', "I'm for Prairie Dog day. This would bring attention to the fact that the Black Footed Prairie Dog is being poisoned by the tens of thousands by ranchers.  And the maker of the poison? None other than Monsanto, which seems determined to wreck havoc on our environment one way or another. The poison is particularly painful to these little creatures because it causes them to bleed internally for several days until they die. When they are hunted by hawks, owls, coyotes and other natural predators, Monsanto's poison spreads throughout the ecology. So give Chuck a break and send a message to Monsanto--stop poisoning our environment.", '"An elegant public appearance". Yay, another excuse for a Hello Dolly tune! Tune of "Elegance" Hey New York Appearing here Showing if spring is nearing here While we watch her suave demeanor We note her nails could not be cleaner So will she be high fiving soon Telling if spring is arriving soon See how elegant Chuck is smooth and elegant As she says if the long winter is off.  On TV Behold at last Forecast will soon be told at last From the class we call rodentia (though the mayor is in absentia) Are we in for luck, we blog Soon we\'ll learn that from Ms Chuck G Hogg And she\'s elegant Every move is elegant And we all hope a long winter is off!', "Whistle pig? That's a new one--you truly do learn something new every day. Up where I live they are referred to as woodchucks. There are two living in a hole on my property, and my goodness, they are heavy little devils. If you don't mind a few holes, they are welcome guests. It is enjoyable to see them come out, lift and wrinkle their noses, and enjoy the sunshine during summer months.", "As long as the holes don't damage your house foundation! Got rid of one under chimney after trying everything; cat feces finally did the trick!", "me-- Thanks for the advice; the hole is actually against my house. I have two cats and plenty of feces, so in the spring I'll give that a try. The woodchucks are welcome, but perhaps a bit away from the house itself."]
summary: Several commentators comment on Groundhog day, ranging from posing a clever poem to entirely discounting his weather forecasting abilities. Some other commentators discuss alternative names and holidays such as "Whistle Pig" and "Prairie Dog Day." A few other commentators give seemingly random comments about things such as solar panels, a cute person, sports commentary, and NYT's ques to "eradicate the masculine pronoun."
short_title: Headline: New York Today: A Groundhog Has Her Day   Keywords: New York City; Groundhogs   Snippet: Thursday: A meet-and-greet with Staten Island Chuck, bodegas shut in protest, and Prairie Dog Day.
short_question: ['New York Today: A Groundhog Has Her Day  ']

query: At a yakitori restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen, each bit of the bird, cooked separately, has a different pleasure to offer.
comments: ['One reader commented on the terms "sansho" and "shichimi" being dropped without explanation, implying some elitism on the part of the reviewer. Have no fear, since the author uses the term "soy sauce", and not to just to readers but to the chef! That condiment is called shoyu.', 'I see a form of logic in the author\'s choice of words. "Soy sauce" is an accepted English appellation for "shoyu." Yes, ideally, he should write "Japanese soy sauce," to differentiate from other types, but given that this is a yakitori restaurant, that\'s rather implicit. It\'s like saying "fish sauce" instead of "nuoc mam" or "nam pla." But there is no English name for "sansho" and "shichimi," which validates using the Japanese terms.', 'No mention of what is - in my opinion - the best part of the chicken for grilling yakitori style... the skin! Had it once in Kyoto, and have been craving it ever since.', "I am a meat lover but this goes a little too far in the worship of meat-eating. 'Livers, of course, are seared very fast so they don’t get leathery. The rich, red insides are as soft as yogurt. They take well to a few grains of ground sansho pepper, enough to spark a slow buzz on the tongue. So do the hearts, done medium-rare, like steak.' Good Lord. This could be sample dialogue from 'Hannibal', the TV show.  Somehow, all the sins of meat-eating that are constantly preached against by intellectuals are wiped away when the cook is Asian, or any culture other than American. Eating chicken hearts made rare like steak?? Barbaric.", "How is eating the liver or heart any different from eating the leg?  You may not like the organ meats but that doesn't make them barbaric.", 'Torishin is awesome!  So delicious.', 'So, I know you need to be a little snotty in these reviews, but what are "sansho and the spice blend shichimi?"', 'Sansho is similar to Sichuan peppercorn; it makes the tongue tingle. Shichimi is a blend of ground red chile peppers, usually some sansho, sesame seeds and other seasonings that can vary from mix to mix. You often find it on the table at places serving soba or ramen.', "Ok, I have to ask-- what's snotty about mentioning the specific, easily-searchable name of an ingredient? Is it just an American thing that talking about non-Western spices is snotty?", 'hmmmm. I usually expect a 4 or 5 paragraph nebulous essay (a la Dargis) before getting to the review.  Not this time.....very nice, thank you.', 'I have lived in this neighborhood for decades. Had you told me it would someday offer a $150 dinner of chicken giblets, I would have choked on my cold sesame noodles (free with every order!)', "The $150 menu isn't giblets, though—it includes pricey ingredients like spring ginger, octopus, and king crab—and the giblets aren't $150. I get it, the neighborhood has changed, but there have always been special occasion meals on offer here and there, no?", 'And you wonder why Trump was elected. This article is incomprehensible to most citizens in Oklahoma City.', "And this restaurant is not in Oklahoma City.  What's your point?", "The opening paragraphs are a playful pleasure to read. May I repay: Susie Asado gives up sweet tea and heads to Hell's Kitchen for yakitori.", "I'm glad there is good yakitori in New York but the same thing in Tokyo is a fraction of the price. Sashimi is a different story.", 'you are lucky  tokyo is dining heaven, no?', "If the flavors and textures match Pete's words and the pictures, I'm all in. I'll start with the livers, the oysters, the mushrooms and a crisp saki, please. Solicitous servers? Wonderful to hear, since I may be here awhile.", 'Three stars? This place sounds good but three stars? The last few restaurants you reviewed you gave a barbecue place you raved about two stars, you gave a place where you seemed to like almost everything one star and you gave a place you seemed dissatisfied with two stars and this restaurant gets three stars? Really? Three stars? Really?', 'Good comment .For years and years Wells always gives too many stars', 'Why is nothing mentioned about where the chickens come from? Supermarket, a chicken factory in N. Korea, organic farmer, what did it feed on, age, etc? I need some chicken guarantee about pedigree before I go there.', '"I need some chicken guarantee" Does that chicken guarantee cover labor or just parts?', 'agree, I expected to read something about their purveyor, source, free range, hand fed, yardbird, etc. etc. interesting omission or what Mr. Wells.  Please weigh in.', 'They only do that in Portlandia.']
summary: The commenters talk about the different ingredients that are mentioned in the review of Torishin. Some are excited to try all of the different parts of the chicken, while others want to focus on why the review's author uses Americanized terms of Japanese food rather than keeping it uniform and using Japanese for all of the ingredients.
short_title: Headline: Where a Chicken’s Parts Are Greater Than the Sum   Keywords: Restaurants; Torishin (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant); Hell's Kitchen (Manhattan, NY)   Snippet: At a yakitori restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen, each bit of the bird, cooked separately, has a different pleasure to offer.
short_question: ['Where a Chicken’s Parts Are Greater Than the Sum  ']

query: How are readers benefited by seeking out, and finishing, books they dislike?
comments: ['I don’t think that reading books we hate is productive. If we read books we dislike, our minds will not be able to absorb much information and this will make reading inefficient. In our lifetime is gold and I’d rather read more books that I like than reading books that I wouldn’t want to. However, in the future, I would try to read different types of genres and start liking them so I can have a wider range of books I can read.', "I read a book which name is never talk to Stranger and I disagree with Anne Marie Pace. I think we have all read books. During my spring vacation I read even though I don’t like to read.  I disliked it, because that's my way. I will get a book and dislike it and, generally, I still finish all books I start unless I find them objectionable or completely out of my range of interest and boring. There are books I have come across in my life, however, that I have not been able to finish I always put it down just can't get through it and I won't force myself. With life being so busy, and having limited time to read.", 'I think the book is magic because the book is another world, for this reason I prefer to choose the books. The minds are so different and for that reason there are different types of readers and when teachers give me a reading for the book they usually do not finish reading because this person has a different preference. I understand that the teacher something needs to put a specific book for the student, but can motivate the student a look with activity as one day the student can talk about his favorite book because the book help people.', 'I think the book is magic because the book is another world, for this reason I prefer to choose the books. The minds are so different and for that reason there are different types of readers and when teachers give me a reading for the book they usually do not finish reading because this person has a different preference. I understand that the teacher something needs to put a specific book for the student, but can motivate the student a look with activity as one day the student can talk about his favorite book because people help people.', 'Well if I ever took a book that I did not like for anything but I think when one picks up books they should interest them because the books and the readings teach us a lot to learn and keep the mind busy. Good will benefit a lot because there are times that You do not like the books but already at the end of the book it becomes interesting and you like the end but not the beginning of the book they benefit a lot because they learn a lot.', "I prefer to read a book that I like than the one i do not like.Even i start read ,it is not possible for me to continue at the end of the book. Because I won't understand  the reading , so there is not benefited. Read a book is a pleasure  than it help you to prove your skill in language. I have hell  of a my time to read a book i like instead of the one I dislike .", "I usually pick book that has good reviews. Also book which is less denser, because I can't stay on focus if the book is too long. When I don't like a book I stop reading that book. Even though it's not a good idea to stop reading at middle of a book. We never know what interesting information we might get if we finish that book we hate. Also it can give us more knowledge and help us to establish new ideas.", 'Always think reading is similar to a magic, because we never know where or when it will give us benefits. Reading books you hate can also help you to think more and develop different opinions and points of view about the topic the author is talking. Months ago I read a book Claudette Colvin which I did not other books, but I finish the book because I know the by the book about racial segregation. I think reading can help us to get more knowledge. Sometimes we hate to read some books, but every book has some knowledge that we can achieve.', "People with poor reading skills cannot absorb knowledge and new information at a satisfactory pace. When a person doesn’t have the right reading skills they don’t get to benefit from reading as much assomeone who has good reading skills can.When people read at a very slow pace, this troubles and frustrates them. It makes them feel incompetent. For these people, reading just looks too time consuming and counterproductive to even bother with. Personally I like to read any kind of book because it's giving me lots of knowledge and this is my benefit.", 'First of all, reading book is a fun. With the large variety of style, there is something for everyone. I think reading is learning. Whatever you read, whether it is a scientific article, you always obtain new information. Reading can give us to get more knowledge and proficiency. One day it can turn out to be effective. When I read something, I try to understand it. I think we need to read a book that we like. When I read a book which is not attracting, I cannot motivate myself to finish it. But reading books which I don’t like can also be helpful because it can tell me about those topics that I know nothing.  It can give me more information and developing different ideas. I think that reading is similar to a magic because we don’t know when or where it will give us benefits. In future, I would like to read books which I enjoy and motivate me to continue reading. Besides, being well-read, working on knowledge and intellectual capacities also makes me more self-confident.', "Though I have not voluntarily chosen any books I disliked, I have come across them a couple times. Book I expect to be a certain way, perspective or style ended up being the complete opposite. But at the same time I couldn't put it down, until I finished it, I had to force myself to read it wanting to give up and toss it half the time but yet something about it still held me captive. I later realized that when I read book I like and have been always reading, I don't notice the extra details and the unique style some authors try to tweek in, reading a book I disliked helped me in realizing what exactly I loved about all the books I did love to read. Plus, I also have to read books for school assignments and research papers that I don't always enjoy, but always end up learning new information.", 'Whenever I read books, I never keep down no matter if it is boring or confusing. Instead, I continue to read and finish it. Some books are start very confusedly in the begin but a couple of pages or chapter it floats in a very interesting way. Another hand gives us an opportunity to wrestle with its ideas. Maybe we argued with the author and gather opposite evidence. It may help you to develop a point of view.  Every book offers an exciting journey and some books even when we hate them tells us a moral or a lesson in life we can learn from or relate too.', "I think it's difficult to read an entire book that you do not like, either it's because the ideas or the content seems boring. But, it is not impossible even if you think that it is impossible, finish a book you hate. I think the benefits that you can get from a book that you hate is the same that you get from a book you like and It is any idea or feeling that the author is showing us in order to get into its world. Moreover, people would rather read books they like instead of reading books they hate and which would stop them reading easily. Personally, as a non-habit reader, I would not read a book I do not like for the simple fact that I would not end it.", 'When I read a book that I don’t like I don’t finish it just I read one or two chapters, Because it does not benefit me at all. I will not understand anything. I think that we need to enjoy reading to learn more.', 'Reading a book you hate to me there are not any benefits because when you read a book you hate you don’t pay the same attention that you will pay to one that you like to. Doing something that you don’t like to do don’t give you any benefit because nothing is done by force.
