When you read a book that have the content that you like it give you more motivation to continue reading.', 'When I started to read something, I try to understand that. Sometimes I feel bored to read, but if I motivate myself to read that, I enjoy it. I think reading can help us to get more knowledge. Some times we hate to read some books, but every book have some knowledge that we can achieve. I always think reading is similar to a magic, because we never know where or when it will give us benefits. When we read books, we should learn good things not bad things. If we pick good advice from a book, it can change our life in a good way.', 'Reading books which you don’t like can be boring but at the same time, can be very interesting because it might tell you about topics you know nothing about, and it might also change your opinion about these topics. Moreover, reading books you hate can also help you to think more and develop different opinions and points of view about the topic the author is talking. Months ago, I read a book called The Liars Club, which I didn’t like but I finished reading it anyway. In my future reading life, I would like to read books I enjoy and encourage me to continue reading.', 'When I start to read a book and I see that is not interesting I do not keep reading because I do not have the same motivation like when I read books that I like and I think that will be bored but I am wrong because sometimes the books does not even need to be interesting to read it because we also learn that books that are not interesting.', 'I think when you read book that you hate that’s mean this is not a good idea but if you put yourself in the mind that you have to read a lot of book that you like or hate you have known new vocabulary, new words and new information about another’s book and obviously you will be become a smart person because you more achieve information in your mind than the others.', 'I think we need to read the book that we like, because when we read a book that is not an interesting I think does not have the same motivation for read and we can’t finish and probable we drop the book and buy another more interesting to read. I do not think that read since the final to the beginning it will be more interesting the book. Even though when we are in school we have to read a book that we don’t like and when we finish reading nobody pick this kind a book for read again.', 'I remember that some time ago I chose a book that when I started reading it I did not like it. I did not like the book because I had difficult words to understand and because the style was not mine. After reading this article if I would like in the future to choose a book that I think I will not like because in this article says that when you read something you do not like, you value more what you usually read. I also want to know that I learn by reading something I do not like.', "I'd rather read a book that I enjoy rather then forcing myself to read a book that I hate. Reading books that you like have the same benifits as reading books that you don't like.", "I have not read an entire book that I have not liked. I only would read a few chapters of a book that I didn't like.", "I read Haruki Murakami knowing I will hate it. It is actually a masochistic exercise but I can then openly criticize his ugly language and his totally self erotic contents. Reading his books I can confirm further that his writing did not improve at all over the years and can get angry that he uses classic master's images to sound important. Yes, I benefit from reading books which I hate before and after reading...", "i don't think there's any benefit to reading books you hate", "I read Pamela Paul's article and I largely disagree with her.  I think we have all read books that we would otherwise not be interested in, particularly during our school years.  But....I read very book I was assigned in school, even if I disliked it, because that's my way.  Raised Catholic, I followed rules.... From time to time, now, in my adult life, I will get a book and dislike it and, generally, I still finish all books I start unless I find them objectionable or completely out of my range of interest and boring.  I read voraciously - my husband says I devour books, and he's right, I do.  There are books I have come across in my life, however, that I have not been able to finish, no matter how hard I've tried - David Copperfield is one of those.  I've tried five times and I always put it down.....I just can't get through it and I won't force myself.  I'm also not a fan of poetry for some reason, although I read almost all genres, love historical books and novels, and even books on psychology.  With life being so busy, and having limited time to read, I will not force myself to finish some books.  It's just not worth it.  Reading is my passion and I don't want my passion to be unpleasant."]
summary: A lot of commenters seem to agree that reading books you hate may have some benefits. Most of them also say that they will still not finish books that they do not like. A few commenters say that they will finish every book they pick up no matter what. One commenter says that books magically take you to another world, and they prefer to pick what world they are going to.
short_title: Headline: Is There Any Benefit to Reading Books You Hate?   Keywords: Reading and Writing Skills (Education)   Snippet: How are readers benefited by seeking out, and finishing, books they dislike?
short_question: ['Is There Any Benefit to Reading Books You Hate?  ']

query: They’re tiny, colorful and harmless-looking, but these little pellets are being blamed for causing big problems.
comments: ['Some time ago when the issue came to light, the manufacturers said they were eager to replace plastic micro-beads with one of several biodegradable alternatives. The last such product I purchased had a message on the label: "Does Not Contain Plastic Micro-beads."  I don\'t know what they replaced them with.', 'This is an unnecessary product! For those who think these scrubs do a good job exfoliating your face: you can do much better with just a washcloth and a mild soap. I had skin issues for many years and was sold all kinds of pricey products — lotions and potions and scrubs — by both dermatologists and estheticians. The scrubs just made things worse by breaking capillaries and causing general irritation. They did not remove all of my sunscreen, either, which caused pore clogging. When I switched to just soaping my face with a gel cleanser and wiping that off with a clean (use a fresh one every day) washcloth, I had no more acne. None. So go buy a pile of cheap washcloths and save your money and the environment at the same time.', 'I feel for the next two generations...', 'All I can say about the ‘Microbead-Free Waters Act of 2015’ in the USA, is that there it appears that there is no penalty for continuing to use Microbeads in commerce after July 1, 2018. So where are the teeth in the regulation? Best, --Keith @KeithDPatch', "Grand news. Just pray Scott Pruitt's next job isn't in England.", 'God. I thought micro-beads were outlawed everywhere a couple of years ago, when studies surfaced as to how dangerous they are.', "Many local towns where I live have banned plastic shopping bags, and so far there have been few if any complaints of inconvenience.  When I lived in Oregon,  I was happy to pay the 5 cent deposit on cans and plastic bottles; returning them wasn't always convenient, but you rarely saw them littering the landscape because low-income or homeless people, as well as a lot of enterprising kids, were happy to pick them up for the extra change.  Even degradable plastics can last for years, if not decades - limiting the use of non-recycled plastic is the only answer.", 'Tiny particles of plastic are showing up in bivalves as well, ones that we eat like oysters and clams. Our entire seafood resources could potentially end up being contaminated. The disintegration of plastic materials have been found in many living creatures both aquatic and avian. It is only a matter of time for it move up the food chain. One of the largest studies of plastics in the oceans has been done by students at Sea Semester out of Woods Hole, MA.  www.sea.edu/sea_research/ocean_plastics_marine_pollution', "Id all of these harmful products for the environment were banned we would make a big fuss about it and then forget once they were a need...  But, it's a need for us to keep making those companies richer and richer...", 'It is good to hear of progress being made in this area.  The plastic casually being discarded all over the world is a nightmare.  This is just another story of corporations needing to be regulated to do what is right rather than what makes the most profit.  Thank you UK for doing the planet a favor.  Keep up the good work.', "We'll know when those things are banned here when the entire cosmetics industry protests.  There has to be something better to use than microbeads.  Given that these things can be ingested by the bottom of the food chain I'd hate to see what happens as they aggregate on the way up, i.e. as the larger animals eat the smaller ones.  Let's hope we caught it in time and we don't wind up the the equivalent of what happened with DDT and various birds and their eggshells.", 'A significant problem is lack of accountability. In most if not all cases of potentially toxic products, corporate scientific and medical advisors should be well aware of the risks, to the ecosystem, fetus, child, or adult. Despite knowledge of potential human toxicity, often-unnecessary toxic substances have been incorporated into consumer and industrial products, continue to contaminate our ecosystem, and will become the legacy for future exposed generations.', 'If Obama banned the microbeads, get ready for Trump to lift the ban. Why? Because Obama did it.', 'Good news.  There is a long way to go with regard to plastics and other waste. Disposable shopping bags, drink containers and other single-use items have no legitimate place on a planet of seven billion people.  Another big environmental problem is the presence of estrogenic compounds in personal care products, fertilizers, pesticides, industrial compounds, pharmaceuticals and other products.  These endocrine disruptors are ubiquitous and very bad for a wide swath of organisms, including children. While the EPA has been hijacked by industry for the next few years, there is still much we can do.  Lawn fertilizers and weed killers are unnecessary, as are many so-called health and beauty products.', 'Glitter should be banned next. As fun as glitter is it’s just teeny tiny bits of plastic.', 'Scrubs using sugar can be just as effective.  The spa where I go for manicures, etc., uses sugar scrubs.  No need to use microbeads.', 'Had most of the micro beads been 5 mm or 0.2 inc the problem would be more manageable, but in fact they are 1/10 the size. In other words they easily enter the entire food chain. There is no reason that most plastics could not be made degradable just as some plastic bags are being made now.  Science is not just be how to solve problems it’s how to prevent problems in the first way', 'Unfortunately your article completely missed (skipped?) the primary reason that microbeads are so bad, which is that they absorb other contaminants in water that are "hydrophobic" and would rather partition to something oily/plastickey than stay dissolved in water (there are technical terms for this, but I\'m not using them here).  Of particular concern in this class of contaminants are steroid hormones, which are in wastewater because people taking hormones (birth control, other uses) pee in the water, and the hormones aren\'t removed by the wastewater treatment process, either.  Therefore, microbeads become a delivery system for these contaminants, which are taken up by aquatic life at the bottom of the foodchain.  Because these contaminants (hormones, etc.) are often also bioaccumulative (they aren\'t broken down in the organism that eats them, instead they get concentrated in fatty tissue), the dose increases as animals further up the food chain consume their prey.  Of course this long explanation is too long for your article, but you should have at least mentioned this.  If the only problem were that aquatic organisms were eating plastic, that wouldn\'t be a problem-- the problem is what\'s attached to the plastic that they\'re eating.', "I was given bath products with micro beads a few years ago as a gift, I had read something then about this issue, so I chose not to use the products, but I don't know what to do with them. I don't want to give them to anyone who will use them, because then they go into the water. Likewise, I don't want to put them in the trash.. because they could end up there that way. So, these bottles sit on a shelf gathering dust. Meanwhile if I want exfoliation, I use sugar, salt or a rough cloth.", 'Hi Ellen-- If your municipality incinerates the non-recyclables (all but aluminum, glass, plastic, etc.), then it would be safe to throw them out. If it landfills them, it would be open to speculation... Best, --Keith @KeithDPatch', "You don't need these products. You can get better exfoliation by using  a 3-M Buf-Puf with a mild soap.I'm in my mid-70s with no wrinkles. Really.  Try Buf-Puf, you will love it.They are in pharmacies and last for months.", 'Other options for excellent exfoliation for face/ body: ground coffee, baking soda, oatmeal flakes (for finer flakes, use your food processor; oatmeal is also anti-inflammatory), loofah sponges (better than a rough cloth), and pumice stones (for feet), finely ground up almond kernals/ walnut shells/ uncooked rice. No need to rub plastic beads.']
summary: Some commenters point out that these micro-beads could absorb other pollutants and then poison organisms that consume them and describe the ease with which these beads can enter the food chain. Another poster wants to ban glitter next. One commenter wonders how to properly dispose of products containing micro-beads, while others mention several alternatives to these products. Some posters describe the bigger problem of plastic waste of all kinds and talk about banning them too. There are also several comments critical of the politics behind the bans and the inability to enforce them.
short_title: Headline: Britain Has Issued Ban  On Microbeads. Why?   Keywords: Plastics; Oceans and Seas; Politics and Government; Great Britain; Cosmetics and Toiletries   Snippet: They’re tiny, colorful and harmless-looking, but these little pellets are being blamed for causing big problems.
subreddit: ['Plastics', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Politics and Government', 'Great Britain', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
short_question: ['Britain Has Issued Ban  On Microbeads. Why?  ']

query: How are scientists tracking the tons of plastic garbage floating on ocean currents? Where will it all end up?
comments: ['I believe that the effects of plastic pollution will not be greatly felt in this generation but rather in the next one. Which contributes to the lack of interest in stopping the problem today because people are so caught up in only fixing the problem when the effects are being seen. My predictions on the effects of plastic pollution are, loss of some marine life, coral reefs may be completely lost due to water damage, and much more.', "I'd be interested in knowing if the plastic is being monitored by satellite observations using say back scattering and maybe machine learning. Also If the land/sea sampling was partly at least a calibration/reliability exercise for those satellites. Purely for interests sake, I'm just now finding out about this stuff and a probably faulty light bulb went off when I read this.", 'Is there an international equivalent to Superfunds?', "The earth is like a giant fish tank with lots of fish in it that mess up the water.  Guess what happens when you can't filter or change the water?", "Some retailers employ more cardboard packaging.  However, six-pack rings of plastic, shrink wrap of all pallets, plastic bottles for every liquid - booze, shampoo, bleach, detergent, et al. reigns. We need education and agreement among manufacturers - but how? A discouraging problem, but our health and the planet's health depend upon a solution.", 'Plastic bags, in cereal boxes! Wax paper was phased out, because of its weight/cost of petrol for transport? The same could be asked of glass bottles, whose production energy costs are likely up there as well. So much (including sustainable development) depends on the stability of major economic sectors, which too fuel global overdevelopment. We often confuse stability with growth, resulting in unsustainable dependencies.', "That is one of the most beautiful photos that I have seen.  I am sorry that it for plastic polluting the Southern Ocean.   Can't Dupont or one of these companies invent a biodegradable plastic?  Surely it is not an impossible or unreasonable task.", "Companies such as Dupont will be marginalized, if they don’t usher in such changes. When an environmentally friendly material is able to take the place of traditional plastics, on a large scale, it will have to be affordable. Maybe Dupont can learn from IST's economic models, on how to accomplish profitability. Or is that lesson grounded in bubble blowing?", "The Tom's of Maine toothbrush handle made of castor oil seems great. Is it biodegradable? Am not convinced of the bristles.", 'Sadly, expecting the general public to willfully surrender their conveniences is unrealistic.', 'Every day for years and years  the convenience of a throwaway world has brought pile after pile of trash and what has MAN done dispose of it in water land fills or burn it , commercial packaging is a great problem. My simple suggestion would be people bring there own containers to a bulk store to fill there food either by an employee or on there own.', "In Italy, some bring large empty laundry detergent jugs to be refilled with wine. For bulk goods sold by the pound, it might be helpful if scales were made to easily subtract the container's weight."]
summary: Many commenters list off items that are contributing to garbage polluting the oceans, including plastic bags, glass bottles, and commercial packaging, most of which is the result of public convenience. Others feel that the effect of plastic pollution will affect the next generation and are curious if this pollution is being monitored. Several commenters discuss why companies cannot create biodegradable plastics and the economic hurdles associated with them.
short_title: Headline: Questions for: ‘Trillions of Plastic Bits, Swept Up by Current, Are Littering Arctic Waters’   Keywords: Plastics; Oceans and Seas; Water Pollution; Reading and Writing Skills (Education)   Snippet: How are scientists tracking the tons of plastic garbage floating on ocean currents? Where will it all end up?

query: Getting acquainted with a neighborhood pet.
comments: ["Please, leash people. It isn't likely that a  lumbering old dog is going to dash anywhere. You sound like helicopter parents.", "You'd be surprised at the energy an old or sick dog can muster when it catches sight of a squirrel, bird, cat or other dog.", 'This made me smile, our bulldog is old, and slow and has back trouble, so we let him take the block at his own pace. In the winter he wears a red plaid coat and sometimes people will ask me \'is he with you?" and I think to myself, \'no, he just put on his coat and decided to take a stroll by himself!\'.', "It's incredibly stupid to have a dog off-leash.  They could suddenly dash into traffic when they see another dog or a squirrel, and be hit by a car.", 'Dogs should be on leashes!!! All the rest is idle chatter!', "I see we now have the writer's name again.  Really sweet story.  Love bulldogs.", 'There is just no need to ever have any dogs on a leash and under control in a big city -- let them roam free, much to the delight of all adults and children alike.', 'My sister worked at Animal Medical Center on the upper East side. The number one cause of injured and lost animals? Breaking the leash law. Loose animals beat up others, get hit by cars, and run off.', "The story clearly states that the woman was holding Zelda's poo bag in her hand.", "I couldn't agree with you more.  It seems that the very point of my original post (despite its pure irony) -- how fraught with risk the situation was for the dog, her owner and the community -- was a bit too subtle to be noticed.", 'Awww.', 'What a sweet, sweet piece! And a sweet dog! Run this article through a word cloud. It will charm you even more.', 'My mother would have loved that story. Her name was Zelda.']
summary: Some commenters have very warm, friendly, and supportive comments about the piece. However, others are critical, saying how foolish and dangerous it is to allow dogs to be off a leash, citing this a big cause of animal injury and loss. One suggested that a word cloud could have improved this piece's charm even more to the readers.
short_title: Headline: A Bulldog on Court Street   Keywords: Dogs; New York City   Snippet: Getting acquainted with a neighborhood pet.
short_question: ['A Bulldog on Court Street  ']

query: Tallying a morning’s worth of caffeine.
comments: ["I used to have all of my coffee at work. Doing so saved me some time getting ready and my employer always had good coffee available at the 4 coffee stations we had. It was the second cup that was always the best as I could actually savor and take the time to enjoy it. The first cup was to start the motor running and was usually consumed in an 8:00 o'clock meeting. 'Nuff said... Now retired, I have the first cup as I read the on-line NYT AFTER a light, leisurely breakfast. This first cup was worth all the others getting here...", 'I love really good coffee and as a result only drink the coffee I have roasted, ground and brewed at home.   My favorite is Geisha from the mountains of Guatemala.  This coffee is originally from Ethiopia, the home of coffee.  A few coffee roasters are now selling this coffee.', '"My favorite of the four was the first cup. It’s always the first cup." Economists call it the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility.', 'Why is it that some unfortunate people get "mugged" but never "cupped?"', 'I hope you use a reusable coffee mug for the last two coffees. recycle! reuse!', '8:24am - Waiting for the streetcar my 2 yr old points to Starbucks and says, "Mama, buy coffee pllllllleeeease".  Unfortunately I cannot grab a cup-to-go with her and my work bag.  Not enough hands.  It has to wait until I drop her off and then get to work when I can sit and calmly drink a cup. Love the article.', 'Hello Kat in Toronto.  I wish I had a \'streetcar", aka trolley, to wait for. Instead, I must endure the bus and subway service here in Crooklyn.  I am envious.', "I believe that people would feel sooo much better if they didn't depend on caffeine to wake them up. Drink coffee Monday, you're going to need it Tuesday to feel awake. I know. I've given up ALL forms of caffeine. What a relief.", 'Wish I could. I aim for seven to eight hours of sleep a night, but without caffeine, I am still way too tired.', 'I note that you say "cup" when you mean "mug", and a mug is two or more coffee cups. While researchers measure coffee intake in cups, who drinks coffee by the cup anymore? Nobody, because coffee is awesome.   I just wanted to point out that we drink twice as much coffee as we used to just by supersizing the container.', 'I was thinking about that!  I drink a 20- ounce cup of coffee at work, and go for two mugs at home on the weekends.   But when I go to certain restaurants for brunch, I limit myself to 3 cup-size cups or I get too wired. What is funny is that I can drink as much caffeinated tea as I like and never get wired.', 'Yes! The first cup is always the best.', 'Hope you get the job!', 'I work with a group of Australians. they constantly ask me about my coffee drinking, hoping to entice me into saying "cau-fee", which they find hysterically funny. Like many New Yorkers I\'m good for a half dozen cups a day. Of course I\'d drink 10W40 from our cafeteria if it was hot and free.', 'Was your first cup your favorite because you enjoyed it with your fiancee?', "To JKF - what a lovely inspiring thought Tune of You're the Cream in My Coffee You're my first cup of coffee You're what helps me get through You're who I adore Life would be a chore If it weren't for you! You're that shot of espresso On that job interview You perk up my mind Life would be less kind If it weren't for you! There's no mistakin' When I awaken That pot we share dear Tells me you'll be there dear You're the froth on my latte You're my best mug of brew Since we set our date When I caffeinate I'd be lost, yes it's true If it weren't for you!", 'Fun. A worthwhile topic.', 'Yes, that first cup in the morning!!! it sure hits the spot.  But make mine a cup of strong tea--with milk, no sugar.', 'I\'m drinking my first cup at about 6:45 AM as I read this piece.  It always is the best. My sister told me "I used to think our mother was a coffee fiend.  Then I became a nurse and now I understand!"', "Cute story! I have four cups a day, too, but it's all from the same cup. The coffee I get in the morning at the deli gets sipped at and reheated in the microwave multiple times per day. By dinner time, the milk is all squanky but the coffee flavor is nice and concentrated. Perfect!", "I know what you mean about the first cup.  Before I go to bed every night I get the coffee ready for the next morning.  I so look forward to the first cup that I wish it were morning already.  To heck with sleep, let's just have that first cup.", "I have a Stanley thermos. It holds 2 quarts. Each day I grind fresh beans, brew a pot and fill it up. By the end of the day, most of it is gone, sometimes all of it. Sometimes a fresh brewed cup after dinner, too. Coffee...it's just that awesome. Especially, that first cup.", 'So happy your first cup was the best. But was the 4th cup truly your last of the day? And if so, did you switch to water for the p.m. hours?', "Carl David Birman - you're very good looking.  Are you married?   Judy Kurland, Pomona, NY", 'GET IT']
summary: Many of the commenters agree with the author, saying the first cup of coffee each day is the best one, with one commenter claiming that the first cup "sure hits the spot." Many of the commenters discuss their love of coffee, and how often they like to drink it, one commenter even describes themselves as a "coffee fiend." One commenter discusses the fact that Americans now drink twice as much coffee as they used to because of "supersizing the container." A couple of other commenters wish the author well in the job interview that was mentioned in the article.
short_title: Headline: Four Cups of Coffee by Noon   Keywords: Coffee; New York City   Snippet: Tallying a morning’s worth of caffeine.
short_question: ['Four Cups of Coffee by Noon  ']

query: Think you know your racial background? A communications studies project involving ancestry DNA testing has led to interesting conversations on identity.
comments: ['"Race" doesn\'t exist in biology; no such thing. Black cats and white cats are still cats. If you tortured black cats and coddled white cats simply because of the color of their fur most people would think you demented, and they would be right. If only we were as wise dealing with each other. We all have complicated heritages, mostly mysterious -- and everyone alive springs from the same ultra-mysterious ancestral great-great-grandmother  50,000 times removed or even more, a proverbial "Mitochondrial Eve". "Eve" is theorized to be a group of sisters who lived between 100,000-170,000 years ago -- if geneticists who study cellular mitochondria are correct. Well before the wave of African migrations that slowly spread our ancestral species across the entire planet. That fact alone makes us all Africans. Hitler would have been appalled. I wish we could move beyond this scientifically bogus concept of "race", a relic of empires, a poisonous social tool used by one group to economically exploit and socially oppress another based on nothing more than mere appearance.', 'I tend to agree that race has no clear or distinct meaning biologically.  However, it seems to have immense power as a social/ cultural issue, and will be hard to get rid of.  Obama self identifies as "African American" and is widely perceived as African-American, despite his clear biracial background.  The idea of racial identity won\'t go away for a long time yet.    Given a long enough time, and enough mobility, we will likely all be various shades of light brown, and then perhaps it will be less of an issue, but I wouldn\'t be surprised if people just cut the  racial lines based on more subtle hues and facial shapes....', 'Brilliant. Love this.', 'Who does the DNA analyses? Many of the results cited are ridiculous. http://www.wcupa.edu/DNADiscussion/stories.aspx#paigeStory', 'Each geographic area (or "race") is genetically heterogeneous because genes flow across all geographic boundaries.  So the "answers" depend on rather arbitrary assumptions and don\'t mean much more than you might guess by looking at faces. There is a reason the national motto is E Pluribus Unum.  Stop talking about what divides us and focus on what unites us as Americans.', 'Re the person who tested as mostly Asian but partly Pacific Islander:  Could the "Pacific Islander" part represent an element in the Dravidian population that descends from early migrants out of African some of whom certainly passed through (and settled in) India and some of whom moved on to, for example, New Guinea and Melanesia?', "How are they coming up with hispanic as a DNA marker? you don't have to be a scientist to know that hispanic is not a race but rather a cultural identity. Hispanics are made up of a multitude of races just like Americans or Canadians are; Indigenous, European, African, Asian.....", 'According to Ancerstry.com, "trace regions are regions where the estimated range includes zero and does not go above 15%, or where the predicted percentage is less than 4.5%. Since there is only a small amount of evidence that you have genetic ethnicity from these regions, it is possible that you may not have genetic ethnicity from them at all."  This means that a persons who DNA profile show less then 4.5% of Middle Easter ancestry probably has no Middle Eastern ancestry. The same applies to other ancestry groups.', 'Bernard:  "my skin is light, but my politics are as black as night. Today, I don’t identify as mixed. I reject my white privilege in a racist America. There is no way that I or my kids will identify as anything other than black." Bernard, you are of course free to choose your politics, values, and even your self-identification, and stand proudly with those, which include rejecting white privilege.  However, there is a great difference between your choices and scientific fact, and by refusing the latter-- if I understand your comment correctly --  you place yourself in the same camp as those who prefer "alternative facts" and their "beliefs" to science. Who you genetically happen to be, with all the attendant familiar distress and upset you mention, has nothing to do with who you truly are, which is about your fine values and behavior in this world.', "As stated. very little of our DNA is different than another's. Depending on whose figures one chooses it can be as much as  0.5% or as small as 0.1%. None of it determines 'race' (an artificial construct which never existed) or 'ethnicity' (also an artificial construct), but rather determines where our ancestors originated and how they migrated from Africa (and sometimes back again into the rest of the globe) out of Africa. If autosomal DNA is tested. only modern human basis will be compared with a particular data base of similar characteristics. If mtDNA/Y-DNA are tested, one's earliest ancestors and their earliest migrations can be determined.  The percentages are speculative not scientific, and defined by a particular protocol measure against a percentage of clients matching them in a specific data base. The sad thing about this NYT report is the continuation of the MYTH called race.  Physicality is based on one's genes and locations on this earth; skin tones are also dependent on DNA-specifically in the gene SLC45A2 which regulate melatonin levels-levels which increase of decrease with relation to the distance between an individual and the equator. As the actual science of genetics evolves we will learn more about our ancestry and its travels. In the meantime, adoptees will be able to find some sense of who they are--- and may find a cousin or 2M; only 2% of these will find a parent or a whole sib or grandparents; 1st-3rd cousins may be able to help in the search.", 'Is there a conversational program, that non-student laypeople can participate in, focused on migration patterns, and how migration history drove, and is reflected in, cultural and social practices, and racial biases.', 'It is "communication studies," not "communications studies."  Yes, it matters.  The plural means a collection of messages, while the singular is the name of the process.  Please get the "s" out!', "I want to see more of these predictions/results! I think I'm 100% European (English/French) but haven't been tested.", 'We undergo this DNA testing only to discover the great truth that there is only one race:  human.', "correction: hominin! h Sapiens; h Neanderthal; h Denisovan -the latter have left some of us their DNA---and none are 'race'-only cousins of one another."]
summary: Many commentators rail against the idea that genetics can determine a person's race, including one who says that race doesn't exist in biology and that we all have a common ancestor. A few commentators love the article and want to see more of the same. One commentator cites some statistics on "trace regions." One commentator calls the results "ridiculous," and another criticizes a missing space in the word "communicationsstudies." Another commentator muses about the origins of Pacific Islander in someone's results.
short_title: Headline: DNA Tests, and Sometimes Surprising Results   Keywords: Race and Ethnicity; Genetics and Heredity; West Chester University; DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid); Genealogy   Snippet: Think you know your racial background? A communications studies project involving ancestry DNA testing has led to interesting conversations on identity.

short_question: ['DNA Tests, and Sometimes Surprising Results  ']

query: Before the season, the Mets were regarded as the team of today, while the Yankees were seen as building for the future. So far this season, it has not worked out that way.
comments: ["Unnecessary narrative when window opens for Mets: IT'S THE METS' TOWN!! Which, in turn, when Mets (predictably) fail requires narrative retraction. As soon as the Mets win more than one World Series in a three-year period you can run the former, otherwise, don't bother with the former and you don't need to run the latter.", "Before we start comparing current Yankees to the greatest switch hitter of all time (you know who), let's remember; it's not how you start, it's how you finish.", 'I have been to old stadium four times   Got #7 to sign his book I am thrilled doing hoorahs at the mix of young and veterans. When Sanchez returns look out as the pitching is the strong point to date', "The Yankees will benefit by going the route of patience with young talent. This team's new strategy of resisting a quick fix is no guarantee of success. But there are no guarantees in baseball aside from pitching and defense keeping a team close enough to win. But this sport is not a sprint. How a team knows how to lose, which inevitably happens, is as important as winning. It is during those trying times that a team learns to believe in it's winning potential.", 'The yankees are back !!!!!', "Steal???? They never owned it. The Mets are supposed to be contenders now and they can't even keep their team together. The only time the Mets slightly owned NYC was the mid-80s. Other than that this is a Yankee town", 'Headline should read Yankees take back the Thunder.  Seeing this team this year is exciting and fun, something lacking in the Yankees for the last several years.', 'It\'s great to be a Yankee fan once more! Last year my wife and I called Aaron Judge "Frankenstein" because he seemed so huge in size, and mostly just struck out at the plate. But this year he\'s blossomed into a great slugger who\'s also a fine fielder with a great arm. Then "tiny" Torres has performed superbly in Didi\'s absence, and the new outfielders have shown some great talent, and Romine has been wonderful, although we still look forward to the return of Sanchez. All and all, it looks like a great renewal for our beloved Yanks, and we thank Cashman, Girardi, and Steinbrenner for pulling so many rabbits out of their hats. It\'s fun to see this team play again. Let\'s hope it continues!', "Cespedes has history of leg and hip problems. The Mets say they did not rush him back. Just sayin. You don't go to the restroom when Aaron Judge is up.", "It was said about Judge's second home run, in the lead article, that it appeared if the short stop jumped, he may have caught it. I saw that one time having grown up in the Bronx. I was yet to be a teenager and attended a game at the old old Yankee Stadium back in the 1960s. I recall a ball that  was hit like a rocket over the second baseman who may have been able to catch it  but seemed to freeze. The ball began to rise and shortly cleared the rail, landing way up in the right center bleachers. My fellow fans went wild. The batter - Micky Mantle.", 'Saw Yogi golf an outside pitch,maybe 3 inches off the ground first baseman jumped up and it landed in the right field seats', "Stolen. Wait until you see Dexter Fowler, Tyler Austin, Gleybar Torres Clint Frazier, and more.  Where are we going to play them all?  It's a candy store.  And you didn't mention Montgomery.  Kudos to Cashman."]
summary: Most of the commenters are mostly united in their excitement as they mostly agree with article in stating that the Yankees will have a strong team this year due to their excellence in pitching. While they agree that baseball is a long game and it is how you finish that counts, seeing the Yankee player Judd's homerun reminded one commenter of a rare catch from a game he saw in the past. While one commenter relishes the feeling of being behind a winning team again, he gives credit to the owners for smart player choices. Another commenter explains that Met's player Cespedes has some physical problems that contributed to the loss.
short_title: Headline: In Early Going, Yanks Steal Mets’ Thunder   Keywords: Baseball; New York Mets; New York Yankees   Snippet: Before the season, the Mets were regarded as the team of today, while the Yankees were seen as building for the future. So far this season, it has not worked out that way.
short_question: ['In Early Going, Yanks Steal Mets’ Thunder  ']

query: Express your affection at home with a simple dish of chicken confit and roasted potatoes.
comments: ["Valentine's Day at home -- chicken?? Yikes.  filet mignon wrapped in bacon and grilled with sauce béarnaise (Knorr), boiled Yukons and a pre-prepared salad with a wine vinegar vinagrette.   begin with oysters cheese course:something other than Brie maybe mascapone layered with something else.  Dessert strawberries with coffee ice cream and home made chocolate sauce-- Toll House morsels set in water and melted in the microwave...  No to your question  food is better-- one prefers a delicious celebratory meal.. (red caviar on the baked potato...).", "I don't feel this chicken dish is all that romantic. Having said that, I'm going to suggest to my husband we go where we've gone in the past for Mother's Day - Buff's Pub in Newton, for Buffalo wings & beer.", "V-Day, New Year's Eve, and Mother's Day. The three worst days of the year for restaurant industry people. We dread them, as they bring out the amateurs, the pickier than usual, the heightened expectations and higher stakes.  NOBODY likes working this trio of holidays, and nobody from within the biz would dream of venturing out on any of them either, given a night off.   Although I credit a Valentine's Day service many years ago with my now excellent oyster shucking skills, I had to shuck 500 oysters and nothing teaches like repetition!", 'Our experience has been that restaurants are overbooked, so a reservation might mean we have to wait only 45 minutes for our table (and have the host tell us, eyes rolling, "We thought they were leaving but NOW they\'re having DESSERT." Um, yeah. It\'s Valentine\'s Day. Of COURSE they\'re having dessert.) Then feeling rushed. Better to eat at home IF (big if) one of you likes to cook.', 'Great piece - but my favorite is the last sentence <3', "Would you brine the chicken before sous vide or roasting here? I usually brine my chicken. I haven't attempted sous vide yet, but rearing to go!", "Yes, feed your lover- but remember to go back to bed! Then desert. Sam your best suggestion here is that we'd rather be elsewhere.... though those appetites run parallel- great call out for food and play in equal measure : )", 'We never dine out on Feb 14, because the restaurants have mass-market "special" menus and the staff are all harried.  The once-a-year restaurant visitors are partly people who don\'t have any idea how to dine properly in a fine restaurant. Instead, we have our Valentine\'s Day dinner out on Feb 13, and commiserate with the staff on their upcoming ordeal.', 'Ahem, Sam, you swiped that "disciplining" of the parsley from Fergus Henderson. Actually, you kinda swiped the parsley salad from him, too, though he famously serves it with roasted marrow bones.', "Good catch! It's one of the great recipe lines. I've credited him before, as in this piece about salad ( http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/magazine/smells-like-green-spirit.html)  and will always be thankful for the command. It's the best way to cut parsley. Man that dish of his is good!", "It is indeed. But I'm looking forward to making this one, too!", "Valentine's Day dinner falls into that dreadful category of special meals that are overly priced, fraught with portent (real or pushed by greeting card companies and the like), and destined for disappointment, whether culinary or social. Or both. It occupies a place next to a restaurant's special New Year's Eve's dinner, brunch on Mother's Day or Easter, and Thanksgiving or Christmas at a restaurant or hotel.    Stay home.  Sure, you may lose bragging rights, but you also won't have your expectations dashed, at an outrageous cost.", '"Don\'t make anything complicated." Seriously? This recipe would take several hours of attention-shopping, prepping, cooking etc. And it would smell up the house (as any oven cooked dish with lots of olive oil and garlic would do). Easier, nicer, cleaner to go out to dinner.', "Hahaha!! If this is complicated, what is a lobster Thermidor? As for the smell, a medieval trick: close the kitchen door and when it's done, open the window for a few minutes", "Oh yawn....My true love of 40 years had little to do with easy, nice and clean. I will be preparing our favorite clam pizza shared so many moons ago at a little Italian place in Newark, De.  Lots of roasted garlic, fresh thyme and lemon.   Love is complicated in a wonderful messy way.  You better roll your sleeves up R. and get busy. And Sam, you still have to cook, because sooner or later you'll both be hungry.", 'Almost nobody in the US has a kitchen door to close.', "Glug. I love it as a term of measurement. I've used it in conversation but never in an article. I'll give appropriate attribution when I find an opportunity to borrow this fantastic phrase.", "The reason we don't go out to eat on valentine's day is that it is usually a total rip off and as the restaurants are also overwhelmed the service is usually lousy as well. Maybe all those tense whispering couples are really discussing the outrageous menus prices and lousy service! Yes, definitely stay home and cook but mainly to avoid being a sucker."]
summary: Many of the comments are about the terrible experience of eating out on Valentine's Day. Commenters agree that the food is overpriced and there are long wait times. One commenter mentions how it is a terrible experience for people working at the restaurant as well. Other commenters discuss the chicken recipe or their thoughts about good recipes for Valentine's Day. They believe the recipe is complicated and not as appetizing as the kind of food you would get at a restaurant. Several commenters share their perfect Valentine's Day meals.
