query: In Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, two former roommates at Louisiana State University are trying to redress the city’s lack of gumbo.
comments: ['I have to try it!', "I moved up here from New Orleans in December, and I seriously don't really care where either of these boys are from - just as long as they are planning on boiling crawfish this spring.", 'There is no po\'boy bread but Leidenheimer\'s; Leidenheimer\'s is the only bread. Btw, there are several more origin stories for po-boy sandwiches. One goes back to very early New Orleans and the Ursuline nuns\' convent; they supposedly made potato and bread sandwiches for distribution to "poor boys". And:  Dat is a Saint\'s helment, dat is.  Good grief!', "I grew up in Mississippi and have family in south Louisiana.  I've been on a search for good gumbo in New York for 13 years and finally found it when I visited the Gumbo Bros' stand outside of Columbus Circle in 2015.  I'm thrilled to know that they now have a restaurant.", "okay - here is what I have to say. A New Orleans native in Brooklyn. Can cook it all but its nice to have something from home in this town. I visited and had the Gumbo it was nice and tasty - similar to my Momma's and Grandma's. What everyone should know is that the atmosphere is nice so are the people and since Lousiana is a hot pot for food - its all good! Oh an from your Grandma's table to mine it will never taste the same but the same love is in there. So go support. I hope they get king cake for Mardi Gras", 'mmm, debris . . .', "Stop! You're all right. Creole refers to people born elsewhere. There are white Creoles in New Orleans, descended from the French and Spanish, and their are Black Creoles, mostly Free People of Color who came from haiti and elsewhere in the Caribbean. Then there are the Prairie Black Creoles, out by Lawtell and Opelousas in Central Louisiana, who are best known these days for Zydeco music. Prairie gumbo is usually chicken based; New Orleans gumbo, usually seafood (see Dooky Chase's). Go to Mamou on Mardi Gras for the community gumbo--Cajun, not Creole. Then Cajuns: there are bayou Cajuns, especially from Houma south to the Gulf, and there are prairie Cajuns, north of Lafayette in places like Grand Coteau and, again, Opelousas. Both Cajuns and Creoles are all over Southwest Louisiana. Lafayette, of course, is the center, but they fan out in both colors from Lake Charles in the west pretty much to the Mississippi River, from below Alexandria in the north to Cut Off near the Gulf. Readers would do well to check out the literature, by Barry Ancelet, Nick Spitzer, and Paige Gutierrez, among many others, and travelers should go to Bestop in Ossun, have some boudin, and just stop quibbling.", 'I haven\'t been there, but I\'m sure the "golden football helmet with a fleur-de-lis" is a New Orleans Saints helmet.   I love the NY Times, but must it become a caricature of itself?', 'I am a native Cajun raised in Lafayette, LA, and would like to correct some inaccuracies in this article. Gulf Shores, Alabama, is not "Creole country."  Creoles are people of mixed race ancestry whose origins are New Orleans. Central Louisiana is not "Cajun country." Cajuns are from the area near Lafayette Parish in deep South Louisiana. These are two specific cultures with histories pre-dating the Revolutionary War.', "thank you! I don't expect people to know much the details and it's always great to see info from someone who does.", 'when I lived in Birmingham, the Gulf Shores was the "Redneck Riviera" and I never heard it referred to as Creole or Cajun country.  West of Mobile, maybe, but not the beaches. That said- will have to make a pilgrimage for the tomato-free gumbo for sure!  Every restaurant who makes pseudo-cajun/creole in this city thinks the Holy Trinity includes tomatoes, to which I am highly allergic, and refuse to acknowledge that there is any variation allowed.', 'Cajun (French Canadians expelled from Canada [Acadiana] after France lost the French & Indian War who settled in southwest Louisiana) gumbo was learned from local Native Americans and uses filé (finely ground sassafras leaves) as its thickener. Creole gumbo was adopted by New Orleans French from the Cajun variety and was influenced by the influx of former French Haitian colonizers (with slaves from a single African locale). Creole gumbo uses okra as its thickener. There is a more than discernible difference...']
summary: Several commenters argue about the difference between Cajun and Creole culture and food, including their preparations of gumbo and where exactly in the South these cultures exist. A couple of commenters give examples of where they grew up, such as Lafayette and Gulf Shores, to support their claims. Other commenters talk about how they've been looking for good gumbo in New York and that they find the restaurant from the article to be tasty, not caring about where the founders are from but rather the food quality.
short_title: Headline: Cajun, Far From Home, at the Gumbo Bros   Keywords: Restaurants; Boerum Hill (Brooklyn, NY); Gumbo Bros (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant)   Snippet: In Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, two former roommates at Louisiana State University are trying to redress the city’s lack of gumbo.
short_question: ['Cajun, Far From Home, at the Gumbo Bros  ']

query: Thursday: World War I in New York, lamenting the transit problems, and a study on subway ridership.
comments: ["I only learned in the last few years that I lost a great uncle in the Great War, killed in France in late September, 1918. It also turns out he's buried not far from where I live, alongside his sister, who died a month later due to the flu epidemic. I can only imagine how terrible it must have been for the family during that time. Even in those days, a photo of the deceased could be placed on the tombstones. Hers is in almost pristine condition, but his unfortunately has water damage and the picture has washed away. Fortunately, photos of him in uniform were passed down to my parents so I know what he looked like. The building where his family lived at the time is also still there on W 176th St. Not sure which apartment or how big it was, but they were a family of 7. As I've gotten older, I find myself wishing I'd have asked my grandparents about the family tree. Mostly lost now.", 'OVERHEARD IN PARK SLOPE The five-year-old squirmed and screamed, Annoying his mama a bunch Until she boiled over and hissed, "Behave, or no sushi for lunch!"', 'But what does he mean by "the rush to war"? The war had begun three years earlier, in 1914. The sinking of the Lusitania occurred in 1915, and provoked many demands for immediate entrance into the war. President Wilson\'s election platform is 1916 had featured "keeping us out of war".', 'I looked up Mitchel and see that he ignored the basic advice to always lock your seatbelt.', "Regarding the city and the Great War, NYC was indeed deeply divided and I was disappointed your brief article didn't even scratch the surface. Recently arrived immigrants had deeply divided loyalties and the city's German population was actually not a particularly important factor there (unlike in parts of the Midwest). Much more significant were the attitudes of the city's large and politically important Irish population.  Most of the city's Irish Americans were bitterly opposed to US entry into the war on the side of Great Britain, the brutally suppressed Easter Uprising having occurred just a year before.  Italian Americans, by contrast, were generally in favor of US entry into the war (Italy having secured huge and ultimately quite nettlesome territorial concessions from Britain and France for joining the war against Germany and Austria-Hungary).  Add to that the conflicted feelings of the city's Jewish population (the US was joining the same side as Russia, the most anti Semitic country involved in the war, but Russia's total collapse and the Balfour Declaration would sway Jewish opinion strongly in favor of US involvement in the war) and its Polish American population (who would become enthusiastic supporters of the American war effort as Russia dropped out and as Wilson's 14 Points promised the rebirth of an independent Poland) and you have quite a story.", 'Jonathan Rice makes important points, but not to be overlooked are three additional factors:  1.  The German Kaiser ran a sophisticated propaganda effort in the States (as did the British) and promoted Irish issues in the popular publication of that time known as the Fatherland. 2.  William Randolph Hearst and his newspaper empire, were aligned with the Germans until Wilson and George Creel along with the Bureau of Investigation pressured Hearst to embrace the Allied cause. 3.  President Wilson ran in 1916 on the premise that he would bring "Peace with Honor" and "preparedness plus prosperity" was part of that promise.  His SOS, Williams Jennings Bryant was strongly opposed to direct engagement, and submitted his resignation after Wilson won reelection and it became evident to Bryant that Wilson was gearing up for war.   New York State at the time of the 1920 census was the only state in the United States where over 50% of its citizens were born elsewhere.  And most voters in NYC were at most two generations removed from the immigrant experience.  (NYC\'s population undoubtedly skewed the state\'s statistics as it continues to do to this day).', 'Troll hair--exactly!', 'Both my grandfather and great uncle, first generation German-Americans from the Bronx, fought in WW I. They were very eager to show that they were Americans now. My great grandfather, a doctor born in Germany, festooned his home with American flags to show which side he was on.', "By clicking on the link, we even got a visual with today's hair forecast!  Made me smile.  Bravo!!!", 'Jonathan...Love your hair forecast...made me laugh! Freddie, I love your musical meaderings!', 'John Puroy Mitchel, began his career young, as a fair haired, aggressive police reformer.  By 1917 when he was running against Tammany Hall\'s designee, the affable train engineer and upstate farmer, John Hylan, and the fiery Bronx Socialist, John Hilliquit, Mitchel had squarely bought into the hawkish views of Bull Moose Party Candidate, and mentor, Theodore Roosevelt.  Mitchel accused Hylan of being a German agent - and pro-German.  Mitchel oversold his patriotism to a city that was largely skeptical of the necessity of engaging "over there."  In a three-way split Hylan won a clear majority. Mitchel enlisted in the U.S. Army where he immediately pushed to become a fighter pilot.  He died before ever reaching the battlefront.  He fell out of his plane while flying upside down in a training flight.  He had forgotten to fasten his seat-belt!!  Those were the days of the open cockpit.   There is a bronze bust of John P. Mitchel at the 91st Street Gate entrance ("Runner\'s Gate) of Central Park.', 'Mayor Mitchel lost his bid for reelection and joined the Air Corps.  While on a training flight his plane turned over and, as he had forgotten to put on his seat belt, he fell out and was killed. Another NYC mayor had better luck as a WWI aviator.  Fiorello LaGuardia commanded the U.S. Air Corps in Italy. Both got air fields named after them: Mitchel Field on Long Island and you know what in Queens.', 'Interested in how our government supported and promoted participation in the Great War - see the new "Posters and Patriotism" exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York.', 'Regarding the "And Finally" section on MetroCard ridership lessons, to the tune of a classic from (of course) The Tokens - Tune of The Lion Sleeps Tonight Whee ee ee ee! Whee ee ee ee! We are on our way (2x) In the Jungle, the Concrete Jungle The riders swipe all night In the Jungle, the busy jungle The riders swipe all night (Yup Yup) Whee ee ee ee see us swipe away! Ee ee ee ee it\'s like we don\'t have to pay! From the Village up to the Cloisters The riders play at night Then they scurry to all the boroughs And sleep until it\'s light (yup yup) (4x) They dream away, they dream away They dream away, they dream away Whee ee ee ee see us swipe away Whee ee ee ee it\'s just like we don\'t have to pay Whee ee ee ee Whee ee ee ee Weekend\'s on the way Whee ee ee ee Whee ee ee ee Weekend\'s on the way', 'Outstanding once again Freddie! Clearly this soggy weather has not infiltrated your wonderful creative brain ;-)', 'right?  Freddie is amazing! & fun', 'Hear, hear!', 'On this 100th anniversary of our entry into the First World War, it is my hope that we as a people will remember to be tolerant, yet vigilant; to be fair and just and to remember that there an enormous responsibility for being a nation whose very presence is a peacekeeping tool to many unstable nations around the world. History often repeats itself and in these troubling times it is imperative that we not particular moment of history happen again. Rest In Peace to all who served in "The Great War".']
summary: Commentators tell stories of the First World War, such as what happened to some mayors in New York or their ancestors. A commentator invites people interested in how the American government supported and promoted participation in the Great War to come to the "Posters and Patriotism" exhibition at the New York City Museum. Another commentator would like the article to address how New York was, in fact, divided during the Great War due to the large number of newly arrived immigrants who had divided loyalties.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: The City and the Great War   Keywords:    Snippet: Thursday: World War I in New York, lamenting the transit problems, and a study on subway ridership.
short_question: ['New York Today: The City and the Great War  ']

query: The next time you get frustrated idling behind a garbage truck, consider what the people picking up your trash have to contend with.
comments: ['I had a 7 foot long sofa when I lived in Brooklyn. The day came when I decided to leave the state. As do many other New York residents, whatever I could not give away wound up on the curb. I got two friends to help me stagger, with that sofa, to the curb.  I was down to a few suitcases and boxes and was standing in my front window, silently saying goodbye to Brooklyn, when the garbage truck pulled up. A man hopped off the side of the truck, pick up that sofa all by himself and chucked it into the back like a soccer mom carrying a bag of groceries. Those are not mere mortal men, they are demigods.', "A rural road in Minnesota vs. W. 73rd St? You're thinking right. No room and too much garbage for it to work. You were kidding right?", "Rats: New Your City's most prolific garbage recyclers.", "I live along a rural road in Minnesota.  The garbage and recycling trucks here have robotic arms that reach out to pick up both the refuse and recycling cans. There is only one person who operates the truck.  Saves the operator from exiting the truck at each stop and also is a boon for them in bad weather.   I'm thinking there must not be room on the streets of NYC for such vehicles.", "When I lived in Manhattan in the late 60's, there was a fire station just up the street.  It was a frequent occurrence to see a sanitation truck speeding down second avenue with the workers on the side of the truck yelling get out of the way because their load of trash was on fire.  Then all buildings had an incinerator and the building guys frequently put out trash which had a lot of burning embers.  The firemen were all Irish and the sanitation guys all Italian.  The Irishmen told the Italians - now clean up that mess.", 'We don\'t have cans here. Some buildings would need 30 cans which would take up the entire sidewalk. Garbage bags pile better. Plus the "robotic arm" would have to reach up and over cars parked on the curb.', "I remember the trash cans being put out on the sidewalk...stinking to high heaven. Fortunately no rats. At least none that we could see. The garbage trucks and the men in the coveralls operating them always stunk. I didn't know if anyone was Irish or Italian. Me and the Puerto Rican kids played together.  The trash cans, the garbage trucks and the men with their odors affected all of us. Still, I don't remember anyone complains. Summer heat could really things worse. The South Bronx was never a paradise. In upstate New York we took our trash and garbage out to fire barrels in our back yards. Once a month a truck took away the ashes. Walking out to the barrels in the bitter cold of winter was not pleasant. A cat jumped out of a barrel one night and scared me to death. He was keeping warm on the ashes.", 'There once was a sanitation worker named Buck Who tossed all the trash in his truck A black rat on his shoulder Overruled the complainer, he told her And back to her car outta luck', 'NYC sanitation workers endure many more injuries than members of the FDNY and the NYPD.', "Plight? They make 6 figures. Even junior guys. Still not something I want to deal with myself - and that's exactly why they're smiling all the way to the bank - rats in tow", 'I think one day of doing their job would change your mind', 'Not true. Overtime is only allowed when there is a need for snow removal.  And then the shifts are 12 hours on and 12 hours off  Sanitation is a very hard job.', 'How many of those teachers, with their nine month jobs, would trade?', 'There are way too many self important twits living in this city who think they are far more superior than the lowly sanitation worker or the bus driver or the maintenance person. These folks are looked down upon by the snobs who think they are better than everyone else and should never be inconvenienced.  I have more respect for a sanitation worker or an MTA worker than I do for the pompous dope in a suit. Blue collar workers run this city. Think what life would be like without them.', 'I remember when I took the school bus in elementary school.  It was very exciting to us kids on the bus if we were to get stuck behind a sanitation truck in the morning.  It was the only excused lateness we were allowed.', "Which rat was bigger, the one that ran up the sanitation workers arm or the one driving the car in heels? hahahahaha I always acknowledge the sanitation worker here in CT, wait patiently for them to back and forth across the street, smile. These men are doing something that most people won't do.  Let's be grateful!", 'What causes a guess that the car was in heels? Your gratefulness is appropriate. One cannot imagine yelling at a well-paid gentleman, bona fide public servant happy-in-life. Maybe if my car were in heels.', 'They are heroes of NYC streets - from the dog poop to the rats to the stench of rotting "everything", they can\'t be paid enough. Let impatient drivers spend one day on the job with them and they\'ll never honk or yell again........', "Look before you leap!  If you see a garbage truck on a street, don't turn onto the street.  Thought that was already a NYC rule....like tuck in your side view mirrors when parking, walk on the right (not left) side of the sidewalk, assume there is dog poop on the sidewalk, and don't stop at the top of the subway steps to check your cell phone.", 'Sanitation workers pick up bags that dogs pee on.  They pick up bags that may contain dangerous substances.  I think a few years ago there was a case where a bag contained acid and it opened.', 'Whenever I pass a garbage truck and I see the men riding on the back, jumping off, running to the curb, picking up the cans, emptying them into the truck and bringing them back to the curb I think "they don\'t pay them nearly enough to do that job".', 'In fact, yesterday I was in such a line of cars on a narrow Brooklyn street, possibly for a good 15-20 minutes (there was a lot of garbage to be picked up), and I thought to myself how quietly all of the cars were waiting -- not a honk heard.  And thank goodness. Our sanitation men are the good guys in this city, with strong backs and strong noses. When they can pull over, they do.', "Best New York story I've ever heard.", 'Yup, many of the rats lost their fear of humans long ago; the humans are following suit. An uneasy coexistence.', "I am eternally surprised by New Yorkers' lack of savvy about the Big Apple Rats. When u turn on your smart phone look up 'rats'. maybe your local politician holds a 'rat academy' & make sure u attend it. Forget about 'don't feed the squirrels' rather focus on don't support a rat magnet lifestyle. Just remember we folks are just passing thru the 5 boros while the rats are the true inhabitants.", 'For an eye-opening look at sanitation workers\' daily lives, read "Picking Up: On the Streets and Behind the Trucks with the Sanitation Workers of New York City" by Robin Nagle. She is the Sanitation Department\'s anthropologist-in-residence and worked as a sanitation worker for some time, as well as interviewing many workers, as part of her research for the book.', "There are soooo many jobs where so many of us take for granted that our concerns are also the concerns of the person on the other side of the line: the gas station attendant who breathes in gas fumes all day, the server working with our table, the retail clerk trying to help with a purchase, or the janitor who takes care of our messes when we're too important to do it ourselves.  This lady is the perfect example of that skewed sense of self worth.", '@Susan - I left the GYM yesterday morning around 1:30AM and headed to a 24 hour Walgreens here in CT. There was an issue with a coupon that should have been applied with my purchase; the cashier called for assistance and a co-worker offered to investigate. I started to think about these staff who were working these late hours  - the overnight shift and wonder more about them.  It was not a bad experience for me. Hopefully I can carry this encounter with me and be more aware of my fellow Americans who are working to earn a living in various ways at all hours of the day. While I was going home at 1:30AM after the luxury of working out at the GYM, these guys were still at work.']
summary: All commenters share their support for sanitation workers. All commenters share the same negative view of people who are rude to blue-collar workers. A few share stories, like one commenter who shares about a late-night trip to a drugstore after the gym. Another commenter jokes about the "uneasy co-existence of rats and people in NY. One commenter shares the name of a book about being a sanitation worker in NY and the name of the Author calling her " the Sanitation Department's anthropologist-in-residence."
short_title: Headline: The Sanitation Worker’s Plight   Keywords: Waste Materials and Disposal; Rats; Upper West Side (Manhattan, NY)   Snippet: The next time you get frustrated idling behind a garbage truck, consider what the people picking up your trash have to contend with.
subreddit: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Rats', 'Upper West Side (Manhattan, NY)']
short_question: ['The Sanitation Worker’s Plight  ']

query: In “Georgie: My Adventures With George Rose,” Ed Dixon recalls the actor’s triumphs in the theater as well as his violent demise.
comments: ["Having sex with a child is rape of that child. I need not say why. The genders involved are of no consequence. I'm sure Jerry Sandusky had a sweet, good side as well.", 'He was a pompous, silver-tongued bore.', "George Rose was not the only rich Gay American having a relationship with poor boys from the Carribean during the 80's.  Think Haiti.  At 14 the kid was perfect.  At 18 he was to old.  Still, no one deserved his final fate.  According to Wiki, the four killers were released after a brief time in jail with no trial.  George is still buried on the island in an unmarked grave.  Will no one claim the body?", "This is one of the most riveting and complex performances on the New York stage - EVER. Do not allow Ms. Gates' surface appraisal and suggested innuendo deter you from what is essential theatre for any one who cares about the kind of work that opens a vein and reveals the emotional truth inside. That's what Mr. Dixon is doing here. This play is about what happens when dreams are shattered, and how one recovers by honestly facing the disillusion and dares to dream again. It is honest, deeply moving, and often hilarious. GO SEE IT!", 'Interesting sounding show, and actually I saw "The Mystery of Edwin Drood" with Mr. Rose as the MC, but I was 14 and really don\'t have a clear memory of it.  This sounds sort of like a similar play that will one day be done about Bill Cosby. At first, seems like a great guy, lots of talent, full of life.  Turns out, apparently, that Mr. Rose indulged in sex with children, and that Mr. Cosby drugged women in order to rape them.  Leaves one with a sense that whatever bad things happen to either man after that, they deserve them. But it also brings up the question, can one appreciate the skilled entertainment of somebody and, at the same time, dislike them for their immoral acts?  Sometimes yes, I think, I still like the works of Picasso and many movies of Sean Connery, and apparently they were both abusive misogynists.', 'Note too how some comments defended Mr. Rose against these allegations of use of child prostitutes.  Some people also defend Roman Polanski.  I myself made the mistake of defending Cosby initially.  I think history tends to get less kind to such men.', 'Your point Mr. Stockhouse is so off the mark it should probably not even be noted. You condem Rose, Cosby,  Picasso and even Sean Connery of immoral acts  and being  "abusive misogynists" without firm fact just "apparently". In any case, Rose and Cosby\'s cases are totally different. Never does GEORGIE accuse Mr. Rose of having sex with minors, just seeking their company. Although it DOES acknowledge in  the culture  and country were the relationship occurs it is accepted, never openly,  as longstanding financial necessity for the families of these boys.  Dixon, the playwright, makes that quite clear: Everybody, every age there was for sale in order to just survive and that Rose never used drugs himself or with any sexual partner of any age.  We, the audience, only know he bought the child as his heir,  gaving the boy\'s family a substantial amount of money.  The family again did not kill Rose in savage way they did because of anything to do with Rose sexually molesting anyone, but that their gravy train may be ending.  NO reason for them to beat Rose for hours, sexual molestor or not. NO one deserves that. Ever. I\'ll leave Cosby to defend when that play is written.  But I ask you this: "what did all those girls go to Hefner\'s parties for? Ice cream and cake?"', 'Apparently their defense of Mr. Rose comes down to the fact that there were no videos of him molesting poor children. That says it all. Not about Mr. Rose but about the posters.', "aren't we always left confused and disillusioned these days?  Great people so flawed.  No one gets away clean?", 'Just reading about this "show" makes you seriously wonder about the boundries of Good Taste -not to mention True Friendship.  And the phrase, "ANYTHING for a buck!" also comes to mind.  Let our Great Talents RIP.', 'Ms. Gates, must say I am a bit surprised at your lack of journalistic skills.  You should have researched the fact BEFORE writing this attempt at a review, that Mr. Rose was murdered not by the underage boy - but by the boy\'s father, and uncles.  And not because of ANY sexual relationship between the boy and Rose, but because they feared Rose was tiring of the young man and would seek the company of a younger man than their son/nephew.  A point made clear in the play. Times Editor: Charles Isherwood would never have made such a gaffe. You got rid of the wrong critic. BTW, "Georgie" is a delightfully funny tribute to George Rose, his talents and the somber reality that the Auntie Mames off the world don\'t always have happy endings.   Anyone who enjoys taking in the well honed acting of a life on stage, will thoroughly enjoy Mr.Dixon\'s tribute. GO.', 'I didn\'t leave confused or disillusioned, nor did I feel it necessary for Gates to comment that some theater-industry folk question Mr. Dixon\'s account of Rose\'s predilection.  This was a startling and thought-provoking evening of theater and I do believe the intention of the playwright was to illuminate that people are not always who they appear to be, and in the callowness of his youth it was easy to be flattered and seduced by the sheer charisma of someone like Rose, only years later to realize that Rose was a seriously disturbed man.  But also, I think, as Dixon takes us back in time to the seventies and his particular trajectory as a gay man, a reminder that shame ingrained in his generation and the generation before.    Dixon\'s honesty made this one of the most riveting evenings I have experienced in the theater and I left with the reminder that we all carry secrets that when revealed remind us of our base humanity.  A lot to think about, to be sure and certainly more than disturbing.   All that theater is meant to do.   Umbrage is also taken with your headline "His Unhappy End."  Rose was tortured and murdered, plain and simple.', "Wow, this reviewer not only manages to spoil the devastating surprises this play has in store, she fails to even think about what they mean. The darkness of Rose's death isn't a flaw in the play, it's the core of it, and Dixon has made something richly ambivalent out of his struggle to understand his friend. Both the brilliant light and the sordid blindness existed in the same complicated man, and the play is about Dixon's coming to terms with both in order to move on.", 'I don\'t know what show Ms Gates saw, but I wasn\'t left "confused and disillusioned"--nor was anyone around me.  I was left with the wonder of great artistry in acting and storytelling, and Mr. Dixon\'s recounting a friendship with a brilliant, flawed friend.  The epilogue brings us back to the present with the additional perspective of a lifetime of  experiences behind it.  Not disillusioned in the least, but marveling at his having experienced all of this, and being able to recount it in such superb detail.  Delightful and witty, dark and surprising, and ultimately uplifting and hopeful.  GO SEE IT.', 'George Rose was also Captain Hook in "Peter Pan" with Sandy Duncan... he was a treat to see on stage!']
summary: Most commenters staunchly disagree with Ms. Gates' evaluation of the play and make several corrections to her understanding of the story. Many extol the merits of the play and even reference it as "essential theatre" that "reveals the emotional truth inside." Many commenters also reference Rose's relationship with minors, but not all condemn it.
short_title: Headline: A Showman, His Stage Life and His Unhappy End   Keywords: Theater; Dixon, Ed (1948- ); Rose, George (1920-88)   Snippet: In “Georgie: My Adventures With George Rose,” Ed Dixon recalls the actor’s triumphs in the theater as well as his violent demise.
short_question: ['A Showman, His Stage Life and His Unhappy End  ']

query: Tomás Kalika, who will soon open his second Buenos Aires restaurant, is giving diaspora cooking a tasting-menu (and Argentine) twist.
comments: ["just came back from BA, and dined at Mishiguene.  Truly one of the best and most original meals we have ever eaten.  As for dessert, skip the babka (although the couple at the next table thought it was great) and have the blintz...Spectacular. Great service and Tomas Kalika and his staff were warm and welcoming and guided the jaded NYers used to Katz's pastrami well. I only wish he would open here.", 'He puts his feet up on the counter where he cooks??', 'I would also love to try some of the yummy sounding dishes but Argentina  is quite far away- Mazel Tov to Chef Kalika on his new endeavors. Perhaps one day he will open a restaurant in NYC!!', "Just great! Back to our roots and full flavor and texture. Sous Vide's a real special tool. Thanks a lot! This is the way to go. I'm on the same route.  Bravo, excellent!", 'Small world after all.', 'I was hoping for that recipe for sous-vide gefilte fish!  The search continues.', "I wish his restaurant was located somewhere closer to me.  I'd love to try it, but have no plans to visit Argentina.", "The food will surely be good. But I will show up on a Friday just for the Klezmer music when I'm in Buenos Aires.", "Why can't we have a restaurant like this in New York?  There are a lot of Jews here too, but where are the creative Jewish restaurants?", 'Ate here a month ago with our son, dtr-in-law and 2 kids, who are temporarily in BA. There was no gefilte fish available that day, to the great distress of our grandson, but the food we ate (and ate) was superb and our waiter was friendly & helpful. Although people seeking "haimishe" (bubbie-style) cooking might be confused by the mix of middle eastern dishes along with traditional Ashkenazi Jewish foods like deli pickles and bagels, or by the big slab of pastrami on top of the "latke" (which seemed to us more like potato kugel), we found everything on the menu delish, and hummed along to familiar Jewish melodies in the background. Our kids and grandkids just returned to Mishiguene with another set of grandparents. More votes of approval. Todah raba, Chef Kalika.', 'My Polish  born Bubbie would poach the whole cauliflower in water which became a soup when she dropped an egg flour mixture in it. Yum. Then she put a bread- crumb toasted in butter sauce over the whole cauliflower. And best of all it was neutral on the kosher scale - goes either way - meat or milk.', "Am I seriously the only one who commented on the fact that the photo shows that the chef's feet are on a cooking/food prep surface? Otherwise and interesting article and interesting food.", "Gefilte fish should go umentioned, even in an article about gefilte fish.  Haven't the Jewish people suffered enough?  I say this as a seventy-one year old Jew.  Of all the delicious things Ashkenazi Jews have brought to the world's table, let this dish pass from me.  Give me bialys, kugel, tzimmis, anything but gefilte fish.  The wisdom of my Sephardi and Mizrahi bretheren (and sisteren too) not to disrespect innocent carp in this way makes me doubt the intellectual and aesthetic brilliance of my own provenance.  Gefilte fish, blecch.", 'Crowdancer, just once try it made with salmon. Wild if you can get it. You may change your mind.', 'Do you mean the ghastly stuff that you buy in a jar? Or do you mean the delicate quenelles made from fresh carp, pike and sturgeon, like my great great aunt used to make?', 'Treifa', "The only mention of anything treyf in the entire article is the cauliflower that's been poached in milk being served with meat. The meat is not kashered, but it could be - so don't serve the cauliflower! Why so dismissive??", 'The article said that the restaurant is not kosher', 'We were at the restaurant for Friday night dinner in November.  The place is fabulous as is the food, the joyous welcoming of Shabbat and the chef himself.', 'Forget messing with the traditional ingredients, seeing that the chef is photographed with his feet up on the food prep table, I think would be enough to give his grandmother the nightmares...if not potential diners.', "What makes you think that's the food prep table? If it was, would it be loaded with ashes?", "Just look at the pictures, ok maybe it's a grill, or a cook top, as in where he's cutting up the cauliflower (amid the ashes), but would you put your feet on your stove?", 'I googled sous vide Gefilte fish and could only find one recipe and it seemed rather complicated so I will pass and maybe try to create a simpler one.  Since most gefilte fish is made with fresh water fish one should remember not to taste it until it has been cooked at the correct temperature/time.', 'Yes- where is the recipe for sous vide Gefilte Fish?  There was matzah in Shoprite yesterday- gotta get going on the Fish!', 'If ever in Buenos Aires, will check it out.  Was not impressed by a new Jewish deli in Berlin.  But with talk of visions, shrinks, cuts of beef, and Klezmer, who can resist?', "Sounds like great food, but what's up with that misleading headline? There's no mention of the fish here at all. Does he even make such a thing.", 'Love this place!']
summary: Many commenters discuss the absence of Gefilte fish, although one commenter suggests that that is a good thing. The commenters that have dined at the chef's restaurant agree that the food was delicious and exceeded expectations. A few commenters discuss a photo in which the chef has his feet on the food prep table, which is off-putting. One commenter was disappointed that there was not a recipe for the gefilte fish.
short_title: Headline: A Chef’s Twist on Jewish Cooking   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Cauliflower; Buenos Aires (Argentina); Kalika, Tomas; Mishiguene (Buenos Aires, Argentina, Restaurant); Restaurants   Snippet: Tomás Kalika, who will soon open his second Buenos Aires restaurant, is giving diaspora cooking a tasting-menu (and Argentine) twist.
subreddit: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Cauliflower', 'Buenos Aires (Argentina)', 'Kalika, Tomas', 'Mishiguene (Buenos Aires, Argentina, Restaurant)', 'Restaurants']
short_question: ['A Chef’s Twist on Jewish Cooking  ']

query: The Republican senator on criticizing Trump and why everyone in Congress is so nice.
comments: ['"I cannot, for the life of me, imagine what the obvious Republican-versus-Democratic answer looks like, with the divide between the two parties in trying to figure out a national-security strategy in this new age."   Add an improved educational system; balanced budget; clear air; clean water; climate change; healthcare; immigration; and infrastructure improvement.  Those issues are directly or indirectly tied to national security.  The only way to way to ensure both parties work together on the issues is lock up together the President (and his advisers) and upper and lower chamber representatives without cell phones/tablets/television/and grant only one restroom break per person. Give each person one glass of water and one baloney sandwich.  Do not allow anyone to exit unless there is a consensus on each issue.  (The New Mexican representatives can add to their sandwiches their choice of red, green or Christmas chili.)', 'Thanks for this interview with a man who could well be the Republican candidate for President in 2024 (or even 2020).  A formidable opponent to any Progressive candidate on the other side.', "I don't know that Biden would have won in a landslide or at all.  There are more than a few skeletons in the Biden closet. He probably decided not to run due to the spouse swapping going on with the younger Bidens. No one needs that negative spotlight.  There's an angry wife  (rightly so) who would welcome a media platform to air her views during a presidential campaign.", 'Yes, Ben Sasse and the other Republicans in the Senate are nice guys and polite to everyone, the same way that the white families smiling at lynchings with their families were nice people because they spoke so politely to the help even while voting to keep blacks from voting and to install thugs as police chiefs.  Sasse has leapt right in to vote to take medical insurance from 27Million Americans and to complete the destruction in the Senate of the idea that Senators are working together for America rather than their parties, all so he can install a judge who will vote to deny voting rights, workplace safety, rights for gay people and access to healthcare and abortion. Being a "nice" person is clearly not the same as being "good" person.', 'What a shock that a white guy thinks that had the Democratic nominee been a white guy he would have won. We have allowed this narrative of "it\'s who Trump\'s opponent was..." to go on unchallenged for too long.  Yes- people (mostly white and male) dislike Ms. Clinton.  The real question - the core of the issue - is why?  And for most of them it has nothing to do with policy and principles  (especially trump has done everything that his supporters claimed were criminal offenses when done to a much lesser degree by Ms. Clinton) - to do with their ingrained dislike of powerful, ambitious women.  I would have some respect for Mr. Sasse if he went on to talk about the disgusting sexism that plagued Ms. Clinton throughout her campaign (and career) or the GOP\'s making up fake "scandals\' to derail her credibility.  But no - he took the privileged white guy\'s way out - and simply alluded to her being too horrible to be elected...', "Anyone who calls himself an intellectual should have abandoned the Republican Party long ago. Sasse pretends to be a man of substance, but his only interests are Sasse and nothing else. Remember: the voters of Nebraska also think deb fischer is a good choice to be a senator, so I can't be too impressed with his credentials. Republican renegade? I think not.", "I'm a lefty liberal from the SF Bay area, but dang if I'm not impressed with Sasse every time I hear him speak.", "He's right, Biden would've won. Just my opinion.", 'Is this a new series where the Times shows just how genial and thoughtful a moderate Republican can be?  You know, the kind of guy who will reflect, really think,  about why it is important to you personally that the state control access to abortion, or allow guns for anyone, or grant further tax relief to "job creators", or (my favourite) force an antiquated healthcare system on the nation...', 'You are being generous with the word moderate.', "Not only would Joe Biden have won, but so would Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren or, for that matter, Jim Webb. With any of them as the nominee, the once-impregnable blue wall wouldn't have come tumbling down. But thanks to Debbie Wasserman Schultz and her co-conspirators at the Democratic National Committee, without any help from the Russians, the party nominated the one candidate fully capable of losing (60% of the states and 84% of the counties) to Donald Trump. Congratulations.", "It's easy to say Biden would have won. I personally think Bernie Sanders would have won. But given how little we know about what Putin did to defeat Hillary and to what extent Trump & Co. may have colluded with Putin, at this point maybe we honestly don't know who would have beaten Trump in a fair untainted election. But Trump winning against Hillary isn't the big victory and mandate Trump believes it to be.  We know that much.", 'Biden coupled with Bernie. Together.', '"the Senate is filled with really nice and well-intentioned people." the first counterfactuals that come to mind are Ted Cruz, Mitch McConnell, and Jeff Sessions. in the House, the list would be incredibly long but let\'s just name the two most odious members : King of Iowa and Gomer of Texas', "So a lean and agile businessman from Nebraska doesn't know that he's an incompetent politician with a degree from Yale in History.     I think he like's Biden because he is a man and not Hillary because she is a woman who is a professional politician up to her eyeballs.   Something that would be a good thing to have in the White House at the moment.   Sasse is embarrassed that he's a Republican and so he says that everyone does it.  Doesn't sound like a PHD from Yale but just a kid down the block trying to explain to his mother why he did something stupid.", "Anyone other than Trump should have won. The Electoral College was intended, in part, to prevent the populist ascent of the likes of Trump. How ironic! Trumpism is blatant demagoguery. Its end result, if unchecked, will be kleptocratic authoritarianism. Liberal societies strive to protect individuals against the negative influences present in any representative democracy: bias against minorities, neglect of the vulnerable, rank political opportunism, entrenched anti-democratic interests, xenophobia, abuse of power by the powerful, conflicts of interest on the part of elected officials, etc. Such societies embody a modern constitutionalism that maintains there are certain fundamental legal principles, accepted and recognized in all mature democracies, which limit and control the effect of any decision made by government, however majoritarian and representative of the people's will that decision may seem to be. The rule of law requires courts to uphold these principles and to protect the rights they articulate. In a rights-based constitutional democracy, no person is sovereign and no majoritarian decision is above the rule of law. Trump's populism attempts to bypass the rule of law and the normal institutional checks and balances of representative democracy. His chief justifications for political action is Trump's own self-serving interpretations of what his supporters supposedly want. America's status as a democratic republic is now, as seldom before, thoroughly at risk.", "Sasse doesn't know Biden. Biden can't fundraise because he has no discipline. Biden't can't keep his foot out of his mouth because he has no discipline. Biden can't stick to a script unless David Axelrod has recently told him he'll be put in a closet if he doesn't. Biden couldn't beat Hillary, Bernie. Biden got 1 percent in Iowa in 2008. Biden has never run a race successfully as big as a Philadelphia city council seat. Sasse doesn't know what he's talking about.", "What a terrible headline.  it domonstrates that white men recognize the benefits and entitlement of each other, even if they're enemies.  Throw Bernie in as well-more willing throughout his campaign to rail against the most qualified person in history to run for Pre s ident, than to direct his venom at the party of white men that has taken people's homes, lined their pockets,  and doesn't care if taxpayers go bankrupt when their families cross paths with cancer diagnoses.", 'This kid will be POTUS someday... It may not be in my lifetime (b. 1943)...although I hope so...but keep your eyes peeled.... I am serious...and NOT a Republican... I am an Independent...', 'Ben Sasse should run for president in four years. He may be one of the best men in public life around. Smart and a person of character and values.', 'Senator Sasse seems to be someone to watch closely.  It is very rare to read an interview with a politician who does not use a single Fox News/MSNBC slogan. Is he the heir to John McCain\'s and Lindsay Graham\'s role as the Republican Senators who have some independent thoughts? I wish, however, there were more references to his stances on specific issues, to give more context to his quote "I’m the third or fourth most conservative guy by voting record in the institution, and yet most of the stuff I care about is not really partisan."', "I agree with Ben Sasse that Joe Biden would have beaten Trump but I, also, think that Bernie Sanders and almost any Democrat other than Clinton could have eaten Trump. Fox News, the Tea Party, the Neo-Conservatives, the Alt-Right, and tens of thousands of bloggers had spent decades vilifying Mrs. Clinton to the point that her hard core following was smaller and less loyal than Trump's following. Biden, Sanders, Warren, Webb, or even O'Malley would have left the convention with a comparatively clean slate", "Joe Biden ran for president in 2008 and did very poorly. He embarrassed himself with gaffes and polled in the single digits. Being a big fish in Delaware didn't get him anywhere in a bigger pond. Being from Scranton might have given him more blue collar credibility but it was a Republican year with Trump actually lagging GOP landslides in the House and Senate. Hillary was a bad candidate, but there's evidence Biden would have done better. With 40 years in Washington, he represented the same old, while Trump represented Change.", 'People just needed the change from anything Obama-Hillary-Biden (status quo). That is why they flocked to Bernie. But NYT has consistently denied Bernie\'s popularity and existence, so I don\'t expect its readers to understand Bernie\'s POV and why he is so popular. It is also the reason that Bernie\'s followers don\'t read NYT (unless someone forwards them an article of interest). Good luck NYT, if you think you can appeal to swarths of populace who would have voted for Bernie if only he was on the ticket. The tired argument that Bernie is not a democrat only proves further that democrats have been an exclusive elite club of "reality deniers".', "Thank you for this article.  As a social liberal, I have lumped Senator Sasse with his fellow knee-jerk conservatives.  Your short profile interview has prompted me to look deeper into this man's pov.", 'for a "young guy" he does seem to  have a head on his shoulders that operates for more than a hatrack. The problem with congress nis that it has become TOO old, to entrenched in infighting, to fixated on "territory" and too little interest in the people. In 2018, Sass will make a great senate MINORITY leader---or he could switch parties and be one of us.', 'Biden quite likely would have won. He is not a woman. A goodly number of the men in those 3 pivotal states who voted for the current White House occupant because they thought he actually was the businessman he played on TV probably would have voted for Biden.  This is where we still are.', "Nice little interview, but I would have liked to see more drilling down into what Sasse considers to be the most pressing action items for a senator.  This talk left me wanting [much] more.  As an inhabitant of the Marxist northeast, I don't get too many opportunities to hear unvarnished talk from heartland senators - let alone one who comes off sounding like a fascinating mix of conservatism and non-partisanship.  Maybe I'm just a bit intoxicated by his anti-Trump approach...", 'He seems rational. Refreshing.', 'Biden certainly would have won. He has the decades of government experience on his resume, without all the controversy and baggage of Hillary. He has the support of establishment Democrats, as well as the respect of the far Left, without the crazy of Bernie. He\'s a working man, who had and made relatively little money compared to his fellow rich Senators. And he would\'ve had the full-throated support of Obama behind him. It\'s understandable that, due to the recent death of his son, he chose to sit out the fight. But he probably assumed Hillary would defeat everyone else. One has to wonder now whether "Uncle Joe" regrets his decision.']
summary: Most commenters respond to the article's assertion that Biden would have beat Trump in 2016, with most agreeing, but not all. Some focus on the author picking Biden, asserting that him picking Biden for that article is a symptom of white male privilege. Others see the article itself as a disingenuous plea of "moderate" Republicans trying to save face after the Trump victory. Finally, some commenters put up alternate options they consider better than Biden, such as Sanders and Warren.
short_title: Headline: Ben Sasse Thinks Biden Would’ve Won   Keywords: United States Politics and Government; Senate; Sasse, Benjamin E; Cruz, Ted   Snippet: The Republican senator on criticizing Trump and why everyone in Congress is so nice.
subreddit: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Senate', 'Sasse, Benjamin E', 'Cruz, Ted']
short_question: ['Ben Sasse Thinks Biden Would’ve Won  ']

query: Evelyn Rodriguez has been a fierce advocate for victims since her daughter, Kayla Cuevas, was killed by the transnational gang MS-13 in 2016.
comments: ['The gang scourge from Central America is more than just about gang violence. The drugs that flow across the Mexican border and are distributed by gangs like MS-13 are destroying our small towns in America. Unaccompanied minors are a concern, and to think what that permanent lack of parental guidance during adolescence  will wrought over the longer term is worrisome and must be addressed.  We need a well-funded Marshall Plan for Central Americain in exchange for the destruction of the poppy fields there and a zero tolerance for public corruption, gangs, drug manufacturing and illegal immigration into the United States.', "There is a history of bigotry towards Hispanics here on Long Island that was institutionalized by the County Executive years ago who was advised by none other that Trump's right hand girl, Conway, now advising Trump. The bigotry is rooted here deeply and several years back, a gang of White Youths murdered a Hispanic man in Patchogue N.Y. in Suffolk County. In recent years the MS13 Gang became established here and murdered several individuals, one being Ms. Rodriguez' daughter. A former Federal Prosecutor in NYC, named Sini became Suffolk County Police Commissioner. Last year, both Attorney General Sessions and Trump visited Brentwood and met with Police Commissioner Sini and other officials to bring light to the violence. Soon after  that, Commissioner Sini ran for and won the position of County District Attorney. Sini also had Ms. Rodriguez on his transition team. The anti-Hispanic bigotry is spreading fast. I hear some of it and it reminds me of the 1930's German rhetoric. I anticipate Ms. Rodriguez will be used to build further hatred and anger towards Hispanics. She's a fool for allowing herself to be used by these bigots as she herself is Puerto Rican. I in no way sympathize with the MS13 gangs but wish to bring light to the fact that a program of hateful propaganda is being perpetuated here. There are many thousands of Hispanics on Long Island and they are good and decent people like our ancestors. Trump is a disgrace for using this victims Mother. She was fooled.", 'Underfunded and ill equipped to deal with the thousands of illegal immigrants — unaccompanied minors who came in the past few years? Isn’t the obvious solution to deport them? They are here illegally, are breaking laws, and join a violent gang. The solution to deal with them is to send them back wherever they came from now.', 'All I gotta say is if you live in a country illegally you are squatting! And I absolutely believe this country needs the illegal immigrants who help grind forward our economy. Now how about that? And I’m furious about Ms. Rodriguez’s loss.', 'Look at all these comments discounting the loss and righteous anger of a grieving mother. All because she agrees with Trump that her child should still be alive. When this happens to you, politics and diatribes are empty, and you find out who your friends are. Her pain is your inconvenience. Scroll down and read a little more of what you are. Shame. Vile shame.', 'Build the wall.  Stop chain migration.  Crack down hard on gang violence.  And deport illegals so fast it’ll make their heads spin.', 'My heart goes out to you, Ms. Rodriguez. I am angered beyond belief by the actions of MS-13 gang members, who besides being inhumanely violent also sully the reputation of our community and waste an opportunity that so many Hispanics would love to have.  But as a Hispanic immigrant, I cannot believe you are allowing yourself to be used by a man who villifies us. You might not think that your presence is for political purposes, but Trump and the Republican party will use it for political gains. I hope you will reconsider.', 'It sounds as though Ms. Rodriguez is honoring her daughter and her family by working to improve her community. I hope that the State of the Union invitation brings more attention to her efforts. However, I have yet to hear of any human being who spent much time with the current White House occupant without being soiled or coopted by him.', "She should ask for better national gun laws, a way to track bullets and ammo back to their point of origin.  She says she doesn't want to be used, but she is the guest of the user in charge.", "Those children were killed with baseball bats and machetes. Why aren't you asking for better laws for those?", 'Rather silly to say she should ask for stricter gun laws when, "Both girls were bludgeoned to death with baseball bats and machetes." Try reading the article before commenting.', 'Long Island?  Why has this area become a haven for gangs from El Salvador?  It just seems far removed from foreign nationals from Central America to set up shop.  I guess with 10,000 members, no place in America is really safe.  What has become of this country?', "Ms. Rodriguez's laudable advocacy for improved resources to prevent gangs and the betterment of youth won't be heard. Instead, she will be used as a pawn in the administration's continued demonization of immigrants as violent criminals. Ms. Rodriguez, please don't let them use your grief in this shameless and cynical way.", 'Trump plays everyone like a cheap piano.', "There is no greater pain than losing your child. Please a don't put your trust in a user who laughs at her pain and will use it for his own gain.  This president cares for no one but himself.  Ms. Rodriguez has a lost that nothing will ever heal but to be active in her community and  state,national organizations to bring about change.  This president is only using her to say he is doing something. Work with the other Democrats who will be there. God give you strength and you have our prayers.", '"Both girls were bludgeoned to death with baseball bats and machetes." Illegal immigration, contrary to my fellow liberals\' proclamations, does have deleterious consequences for some Americans. Taxpayer dollars can only go so far in supporting impoverished immigrants. A cost-benfit analysis must be vigorously debated without reactionaries claiming that merely questioning our immigration policy is racist. Our neighbors to the north and most European countries have much stricter policies than the United States. Before accusing this mother of being manipulated by Trump, I hope readers acknowledge that simply espousing quixotic platitudes about the virtue of immigration and diversity does not solve the illegal immigration quandary. Most Americans want to protect the Dreamers; they also don\'t want illegal immigrants with gang ties terrorizing their neighborhoods.', "There is no pain greater than that of losing a child. But Ms Rodriguez is being extremely naive if she things her presence won't be used for political gain.  The number of Hispanic persons in the US who are being pressured to self-deport or to be forcibly removed won't bring her daughter back, won't make us safer. The Dreamers are the least likely group to become members of MS-13.  What we need is a branch of the FBI de-fanging these multinational groups.", 'You could say the same thing about being used for political game regarding the DACA recipients being brought to the State of the Union by Democratic Senators and Congressmen (or Congressperson, if you prefer)', 'My condolences to Ms. Rodriguez on her loss but my gut reaction is that she is being played by an administration which could could care less about the kids which Ms. Rodriguez is trying to help.', "How do YOU know what the Administration is thinking?  How about it's thinking that in order to keep our country safe we need to stop illegal aliens from entering and deport those who are illegal from our nation.  ALl immigrants should come into our country through the legal system.", 'How about getting rid of all the American-born white men? After all, they are the ones who perpetrate mass shooting after mass shooting.', 'Perhaps we should be doing more to deal with  our drug addicts who fuel the drug gangs in El  Salvador who come to the United States to continue their violence.  There is a chain consequence that will not be affected by any wall.  There is something very wrong with our own country that requires more than keeping out people fleeing from danger.  Why else would so many come here without the legal requirements?  There is no easy answer, but turning our backs on desperate people is certainly not.  People who rant against so-called illegals are looking for a solution that so far has eluded our shameful government.  Willy Nilly barring others will not give you a good nights sleep.']
summary: Many commenters point out that Ms. Rodriguez's personal tragedy is likely being used for political gains. Several point the finger at Trump, and one blames Republicans in general. Some commenters speak against illegal immigration, and one extolls the merits of legal immigration. A couple of commenters point out that the weapons used were baseball bats and machetes and question the logic of using this event as a platform for gun laws. Some other commenters wonder how Long Island has become a gathering place for gangs.
short_title: Headline: At State of Union, Mother of MS-13 Victim  Says She’ll Seek ‘Resources for Our Kids’   Keywords: Gangs; Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13); Cuevas, Kayle (2000-16); State of the Union Message (US); Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides; Illegal Immigration; Police Department (Suffolk County, NY); Central Islip (NY); Brentwood (NY); Suffolk County (NY); Trump, Donald J   Snippet: Evelyn Rodriguez has been a fierce advocate for victims since her daughter, Kayla Cuevas, was killed by the transnational gang MS-13 in 2016.

query: The Independent Budget Office offered 90 ways for the city to either save money it now spends or to collect some from stones unturned.
comments: ['The findings of this commission and, perhaps consequently, the tone of this article, seem to suggest that our city\'s budgetary needs could be met by cutting the wasteful behavior of its municipal workers: teachers, police officers, and bus drivers. While I cannot speak directly about the "muster time" of police officers or the exact ridership of bus lines, I\'m generally confident that police officers probably need 35 minutes to get themselves ready to face a long day\'s work protecting our city and its citizens (it\'s not helpful that the article does not indicate what this time entails), and that should there be bus routes that are under-utilized, there are certainly others that would benefit from increased service and we may benefit from a shift in service, not a reduction in buses overall. I take particular issue with the "96,000 days of teacher absences," with the not-so-subtle inference that this is an outrageously high number. Of course, the article does not state that there are 75,000 public school teachers in the city. Which means that, on average, the usual NYC school teacher is absent at most 2 days out of the year. Two. So let\'s quell this hysteria about municipal workers bankrupting our great city. There are millionaires who, for all purposes, live in this city, but exploit a loophole that allows them to evade paying city taxes by leaving town to their second home exactly enough days out of the year. Let\'s be indignant about that.', 'Solve the homelessness crisis by levying a tax of $500/mo on any apartment that remains vacant for more than 6 months unless there is a valid building permit outstanding for renovation.  Developers are warehousing, i.e. keeping empty, thousands of apartments so they can clear out entire buildings and blocks to redevelop as luxury housing.  If those apartments were on the market, there would be more housing for all.  Second idea -- dramatically raise the transfer tax on all residential real estate sales in excess of $10 mn. and extend it to the purchase of apartments in new projects.', 'NY should do what virtually every other city does and create resident parking permits. If the city charged $75 per year for a one-borough permit and $100 for a five-borough permit, it would raise millions of dollars that can be spent on infrastructure. It would allow for charging 24 hour/parking fees for out-of-town vehicles through the either muni-meter or cell phone payment. In addtiion, it would put an end to fraudulent car registration by city residents with second homes in  states with cheaper insurance. The permits would thus create three different sources of revenue, including sharing of cost by non-residents who use the infrastructure (think Jersey beaches).', 'You can tax every last breath a NY-er takes and there\'s still be a budget shortfall. The city continues to spend more money than it takes in. These small increases in fees and taxes won\'t make a dent in the debt if there isn\'t a reduction in spending. It\'s right in the beginning of the article, "more people are now on the city payroll than at any time in modern history". How about a freeze on hiring any new city employees? How about reducing and streamlining the existing workforce? How about doing away with the mantra that anyone who finds their way into NYC can get housing? The city spends nearly half a million dollars a day on hotel rooms!', "Congestion pricing for private cars would raise a lot of money AND reduce traffic and pollution. Mayor Bloomberg proposed it but it didn't pass in the Senate. Too bad.", 'Are you actually proposing having taxis replace bus service? There is no way that could be economically feasible for a good deal of the ridership.', 'Strollers, walkers. Shopping carts, and wheelchairs would probably not fit!', 'Hope much could be saved by the elimination of some, if not all, of the useless, parasitic, self-serving bureaucrats that infest all levels of government. Their primary purpose seems to be to protect themselves and their jobs rather than to serve the public.', 'How about scrapping policies which guarantee "homeless" families the right to stay in $ 300 a night Hotels?  Imagine the savings if NYC\'s Cadillac Safety Net was reduced to just temporary relief, not a permanent lifestyle for many who choose a life of dependency.  Add the savings with the elimination of ALL benefits/handouts to illegal aliens and you might find that NYC could eliminate it\'s income tax and have money left over.', 'Quite a few of these "homeless" reside in other states and come to NYC because they know how good it is.', '"John Smith"  - if I were you I\'d use a made-up name too.', "Unarmed traffic officers should be stationed at busy intersections with the mandate to present drivers who don't use turn signals with $100 tickets. This will also reduce accidents.", 'A fortune could also be raised by ticketing drivers\u200b who block the box in Manhattan.', 'According to an article earlier this week, NYC spend $400,000 a day housing the homeless, whose numbers continue to grow and now top 60,000.  Surely addressing this is a requirement.', 'Dollars to donuts more than half come from out of state.', 'More people on the city payroll, happier unions and their bosses (who will - it is no doubt hoped by City Hall - in turn fill DeBlasio\'s reelection coffers), cops who work 40 weeks a year, absent teachers - well, gosh all will work even better if we just make the taxpayers shell out even more!  Don\'t pay any attention to the bone jarring, pot holed streets, the subway that is a disaster, homeless on every corner, trash every where...hey, as long as the Mayor keeps his constituents (i.e., not the tax paying residents) happy, who cares, right? And whats with the caption, "paying $25 for the privilege" - isn\'t it a right to get married? And what costs $50 other than yet another way to sponge up tax money? But stand by in the future for an endorsement of DeBlasio and his "management" of the city by the NYT Editorial Board.  No wonder people want to leave the city.', "de Blasio the Peter Principle defined. He never met a donor he didn't like. Even if that means traveling to Los Angeles to pick up his checks. DO as I say not as I do. Election day can't come soon enough. Nice job you're not doing mr. mayor.", "The plastic bag fee would have been nice, but I guess it wasn't a tax because the revenue would have gone to the businesses. But it would have created a savings for the city with fewer polluting sewers, trees, roads, dumpsites, etc. Too bad Albany and NYC can't get along.", "Crack down on padding OT for cops, don't use 'em you lose them. Cut out the perks for municipal workers, cut out the layers of duplications of workers. Instead of taxing the working class to death.", 'Sell license plates for bicyclists and fine those going the wrong way or through red lights.  Fine motorists driving while on cell phones. And yes, we pedestrians should be fined for some of our reckless behavior as well.  Then earmark all monies collected specifically for causes such as health, homelessness and education that will all be negatively affected by the present federal government.', "Raise taxes?! For what? More big government social spending and handouts to the poor? I've got a better idea. Privatize all the schools, still requiring that all families send their children to the school run by the free market. Eliminate all those wasteful winter and summer breaks. Then, children can get a good vocational education in these schools with by training them doing work in the city now done by these bloated public sector unions. Teachers can be eliminated by having older children teach their juniors. Middle and High Schoolers will learn valuable life skills picking up the city's garbage, writing traffic tickets, maintaining the parks system, and repairing city buses. Actually, we can save even more money by privatizing the entire public transportation system. Private industry will run our trains and buses cheaper, more efficiently, safer and cleaner than the wasteful bureaucracy of big government! Elon Musk would be great at this. Self-driving electric taxis everywhere! And we can sell the Brooklyn Bridge to Donald Trump!", "Courtesy George Harrison............ Let me tell you how it will be There's one for you, nineteen for me 'Cause I'm the taxman, yeah, I'm the taxman Should five per cent appear too small Be thankful I don't take it all 'Cause I'm the taxman, yeah I'm the taxman If you drive a car, I'll tax the street, If you try to sit, I'll tax your seat. If you get too cold I'll tax the heat, If you take a walk, I'll tax your feet. Don't ask me what I want it for If you don't want to pay some more 'Cause I'm the taxman, yeah, I'm the taxman Now my advice for those who die Declare the pennies on your eyes 'Cause I'm the taxman, yeah, I'm the taxman And you're working for no one but me. Songwriters: George Harrison", "Ah, the words of a great philosopher! I, Me, Mine All through' the day I me mine, I me mine, I me mine All through' the night I me mine, I me mine, I me mine Now they're frightened of leaving it Ev'ryone's weaving it Coming on strong all the time All through' the day I me mine I-I-me-me mine, I-I-me-me mine I-I-me-me mine, I-I-me-me mine All I can hear I me mine, I me mine, I me mine Even those tears I me mine, I me mine, I me mine No-one's frightened of playing it Ev'ryone's saying it Flowing more freely than wine All through' the day I me mine I-I-me-me mine, I-I-me-me mine I-I-me-me mine, I-I-me-me mine"]
summary: The commenters suggest many ways for the city of New York to increase revenue. Some suggest ways to save money the money that is currently being spent. Cutting overtime for officers and discontinuing providing expensive hotels for the homeless at the city's expense are among the ways to save money. One commenter suggests privatizing both the education system and the public transportation system to avoid raising taxes. Although another commenter strongly disagrees with the points made in the suggestion to privatize things. One of the commenters suggests fines to landlords and bicyclists, while another suggests parking permits.
short_title: Headline: Ideas for a City Without Cash in the Forecast   Keywords: Budgets and Budgeting; Plastic Surgery; Property Taxes; Police Department (NYC); New York City   Snippet: The Independent Budget Office offered 90 ways for the city to either save money it now spends or to collect some from stones unturned.
subreddit: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Plastic Surgery', 'Property Taxes', 'Police Department (NYC)', 'New York City']
short_question: ['Ideas for a City Without Cash in the Forecast  ']

query: The notorious Aokigahara Forest looms large for Japan, with its high national suicide rate, though patrols and other steps are helping lower the toll.
comments: ['If you hang yourself from a tree in a famous place for suicides you have pretty much relinquished any claims for privacy.', 'It is time we took the onus off of suicide. Suicide committing persons are not, necessarily, "pathological" or "mentally ill". Suicide is often merely a way of assuring that one dies as one wishes to, rather than in some involuntary and often painful process, as is so much more often the case. If we really wish to reduce suicides, we need only legally assure all that a peaceful, comfortable and even "blissful" self-controlled, "delivery" is and will be available when we want it. With our drugs, this is certainly available. We do not "own" the lives of others, but we DO own OUR OWN. We are all going that way at any rate. Most of the opposition to suicide is from persons and organizations of those persons that are depressed and fearful of what suicide honestly says about the true value of a life of struggle, ending only in death.', 'We saw "The Sea of Trees" about this forest; it was not a great film, but it left me with a balanced impression of this place, albeit no desire to go there. As John said, many people who attempt suicide and fail realize that they would really rather not die after all. I wonder how many people wander into the sea of trees and realize the same thing?', 'The rate of suicide in Japan is somewhat higher than in the US, but if you take into account the rate of drug overdosing that is not counted as suicide, and where the US far surpasses any other country on Earth by a huge margin, the US comes out ahead of Japan in self-inflicted death rate.', '"Suicide is painless" happens only in movies. Of course people who resort to suicide (or homicide in some instances like suicide by cops) are in tremendous pain. It is not necessarily physical pain. Psychic pain is much more potent. Decades ago I was giving a talk about suicide at a community center and one guy challenged me asking what if a person first dope himself up before sliding his waist in a bath. Obviously, he was trying to make a case. My response was that it is not necessarily the act itself but what leading to it. To back up a bit, I was a volunteer at a hotline service at the time billing itself as a general purpose suicide prevention organization.  Anyway, the org I represented at the time had no qualm with people like Hemlock Society. There is a difference between suicide (or suicide driven homicide) and euthanasia. So much so that the goal of suicide prevention is to de-mythify it. Stuff like my suicide is a way to strike back at someone or some sort of beautiful scene after death. But in fact the act of suicide could hurt your loved ones more than your enemies. And there is nothing beautiful about a dead corpse hanging or blowing your brain out. So sure, people need to dis-associate a 1,100-year-old forest from suicide. That said, they also need to address the phenomenon like copycat suicide in high school. The topic is suicide, not the forest', 'A man who survived a plunge into San Francisco Bay from the Golden Gate Bridge reportedly said, "Right after I jumped I realized that all the problems in my life were manageable except for the fact that I had just jumped off a bridge."', "I remember him (or another survivor) saying they regretted jumping the moment their feet left the bridge.  I've thought about that often when I hear of a suicide.", 'Japanese culture both past(going back some 1,000 years) and present are famous for two things: suicide and misogyny.  One only needs to watch most Japanese movies, especially pre-2000, we see the degradation of women often with women either murdered or comitting suicide.  Those Edo and pre-Edo period films are very revealing, so too the films and TV shows dealing with life from 1870 onwards; the yakuza films come into mind along with films dealing with the daily grind of post/pre WW2 Japan.  Kamikaze planes during WW2, and of course that famous line from the 1967 James Bond flick- "You Only Live Twice", where the head of Japanese Secret Service says to Bond, "In Japan, men come first, women come second."  Films by  Kurasawa, Ozu, Naruse, Suzuki, Oshima and Imamura should englighten most Westerners on the Japanese mentality, even in today\'s society.', 'Topics like this invariably bring out cultural or social explanations: Japanese, or Asians, are uniquely this or uniquely that. Yet, the OECD data shows that Lithuania had the highest suicide rate, followed by (in order) South Korea, Slovenia, Hungary, Japan, and Latvia. Following closely are Belgium and Iceland that are often seen as happiest and healthiest places in the world. Even in places like Lithuania and South Korea where suicides are relatively very high, it still remains extremely rare (34.8 per 100,000 per year in Lithuania in 2013). Rather than looking to cultural factors or attitudes toward mental health issues, it might be more productive to examine how suicides are reported and identify specific policies that alter the rates year over year to reduce the number for a specific country. OECD data shows that South Africa and Turkey have astonishingly low suicide rates (1.3 and 2.7 respectively). Clearly, South Africans are not more than 10 times happier than Belgians (rate of 16.2) nor is South African mental health program 10 times more effective: South Africa has 15 times the murder rate of Belgium (34 to 1.9). With all this, variability in the quality of reporting and data collection make suicide data a bad place to start meaningful debates about culture and health.', "At last, a reasonable comment. Different cultures express their sadness/frustrations/anger in different ways. The desolation that produces suicide is awful. And there's no questioning the scarcity of good-quality mental health care in Japan and the reluctance of people to seek it (often enabled in their problems by their family). Americans tend to express their frustrations as violence towards others, no great thing in a country awash in guns.", "“Life is a precious thing that your parents gave to you,” the signs read. They need to change that sign. It may state what the society wants to believe, but in so doing it reveals something deeper about the social problem of suicide. Parents are the pysical generators of the body. They give you your physical essence. But many parents give nothing else which is positive. Often they are abusive. An understanding of human psychology reveals that most prisons are filled with adult survivors of child abuse. Many walk the streets freely as well. The last thing you should remind them of when considering suicide is their parents. It is possible to be life affirming and loving without parents, or inspite of unloving and harmful parents — but Japanese society clearly doesn't want to face that reality or the deeper problems behind it, hence the patriarchal bromide and command to obey family taboo (honor and obey the parents NO MATTER WHAT), chosen for the sign.", 'Arthur, I thought the same but slightly more grim ~ as a survivor of abuse & attempted suicide, that sign would push me right back into despair.', "The photos of the forest are so beautiful I would think that entering it would make one think twice, even if ever so slightly, about the decision to end one's own life.", 'If the Japanese government truly wanted to slow the rate of suicide, it would include comprehensive mental health services in its national health insurance.
