Anything less is lip service.', "Mental health services ARE included in national health insurance. The problem is that not all mental health doctors are part of the system, so options can be limited. Then there simply aren't enough doctors. Finally, people tend not to make use of what services there are. That's the biggest problem. It's still seen as a stigma, the way it was in the US in the 50s or so.", "Don't limit this to Japan or the United States.  The entire industrialized world could do far better when it comes to mental health. Here in The Netherlands, it's a documented fact that the police spend 80% of their time dealing with mentally disturbed people.  In the meantime, in the more than ten years that Mark Rutte has been Prime Minister, the government has dramatically reduced financial support for treatment and support of mental health programs.", 'Ironic that the NRA and GOP supporters says the remedy for mass shootings is mental health counseling (vs gun control), yet we know which party would most oppose expanded Health Care,', "I think a lot of the suicide problem in Japan is hinted at pretty strongly in the article, but maybe nobody wants to come out and say it. Japan has a long cultural history of considering honor to be paramount.  It's a very different mindset than in American culture; in America we tend to think of ourselves first, then family and friends, then the state, for priorities and moral guidance.  In Japan it's more the state first, then family, then one's self last. So if people feel they've brought dishonor to their family or the state, the urge to cleanse that sin with suicide is pretty strong in that culture.  In ours, it's non-existent, because of our reversed priorities; in America people generally commit suicide because of their own personal pain, not shaming their families. Additionally, Japanese culture, as mentioned, is very disparaging of mental health treatment.  People are supposed to be strong, wall off their feelings inside themselves, and not bother anyone with them.  Of course, sometimes it's impossible to be that strong, and that's when suicide starts looking like a release from an unlivable life. So fighting against the suicide rate in Japan is going to be difficult, as it will mean changing the culture around somewhat.  Luckily cultures can and do change, and in the meantime, things like the special patrol in this article can only help.", 'those relic social norms have been hard to eradicate.  The post WW2 reforms pushed forward by Gen. Douglas Macarthur were not enough, it was a starting point but with a culture based on a 1,000 year old tradition more needed to be done. This "honor" code is so antiquated, so regressive,  so insensitive and rigid, it\'s so obvious it has to go- by the way of the dinosaur, except of course to most Japanese people.  It obstructs, hinders, and prevents any meaningful cultural and societal evolution or advancement.  I would have thought that the Japanes would have seen this by now, but i guess  T.V.,  video games, and greed have clouded their judgement.', 'Mr. Paul\'s YouTube video is a despicable exploitation of the suffering of others to gain personally.  Make no mistake, this boy Paul revels in the notoriety and financial gain.  The superficial "apologies" he posted are only in reaction to widespread criticism; he would have gladly laughed all the way to the bank had no criticism followed.   The boy clearly has no sense of humanity or compassion.   But the incident will soon be forgotten, I am certain, "Bro". What\'s more, he represents the oafish, ignorant and insular person who is so common in the social media.  Do these people interact with others?  Do they understand the human condition?   What do these people really know of others or of the world around them?   For them, life is a collection of moments of cheap entertainment on the Internet, each one quickly forgotten after the next shocking video.   To me, the people who profit from these types of sites are truly the lost and hopeless.     Lastly, one sees hardly a word of the sadness that drove the desperate souls to that cold and lonely place.   May they have found their peace.', 'Yes, as RB stated so well, in all the talk of policy and data there is “hardly a mention” of the sadness that drove those people to that “cold and lonely place.” 30 people in one year is still a lot of people. Perhaps Mr Paul could demonstrate his remorse by joining those foot patrols along the base of Mt Fuji. And then putting a film of his patrol on YouTube. Such sadness, for the individuals and their families. From the article it appears that there are some very dedicated people working to change the outcome. There is always hope.', 'If Mr. Paul is really sorry for his poor judgment, perhaps he could build a chapel or gazebo or some kind of monument to HOPE near the entrance to the forest.']
summary: A commenter questions the validity of the suicide data. Another calls out Logan Paul's lack of morals for a controversial video he filmed at Aokigahara Forest. A commenter explains that suicide should be the focus and not the forest. Another says that the signs do more harm than good. Others question why people would commit suicide in such a beautiful forest. A few commenters argue that the Japanese culture and poor mental health care results in a high suicide rate.
short_title: Headline: Long Before Video, Japanese Fought Suicide in the ‘Sea of Trees’   Keywords: Suicides and Suicide Attempts; Aokigahara Forest (Mount Fuji, Japan); Depression (Mental); Paul, Logan (1995- ); Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming; YouTube.com   Snippet: The notorious Aokigahara Forest looms large for Japan, with its high national suicide rate, though patrols and other steps are helping lower the toll.
subreddit: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Aokigahara Forest (Mount Fuji, Japan)', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Paul, Logan (1995- )', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'YouTube.com']
short_question: ['Long Before Video, Japanese Fought Suicide in the ‘Sea of Trees’  ']

query: What some Bolivians with the world’s healthiest arteries might tell us about cardiac fitness.
comments: ['Very helpful rticle', 'If activity were the key to a healthy cardiovascular system, construction and factory workers in the US should be in better shape than office workers, but that is not the case.    http://www.livescience.com/47133-jobs-heart-disease-risk-revealed.html It could be that Bolivians eat something, maybe a plant with statin-like properties that protects them.   Of course I am guessing.  There are too many variables to explain these results.', "Although the author doesn't say it directly, I would say that one of the major factors is culture. Take these people and plop them down into the lives of modern day construction workers in America and I think the results would be different. Also consider how overweight many construction workers are. Look at their meals and most of them go home exhausted. They shower, gorge on an unhealthy dinner accompanied by sodas or beers, and veg out on television. The stress in the US for low income people is also probably a factor. Modern society is very stressful compared to a small and cohesive society in the Amazon. It is not just about activity and food. Feeling part of a closeknit,  traditional society that values family and friendship over television and other modern distractions has to be an important part of the puzzle.", 'You need to consider construction workers diets and what they drink.', "I am happy that these foaks in Amazon lead a very healthy life. But I would not trade my daily NYT and it's amazing Health articles for a low score of eve a 399. These anthropologists who study this tribe should also report their own scores, so we know what a difference this pseudo research makes to their hearts. While interesting to note these findings,  finding a correlation or even derive a recommendation for a daily reader like me is similar to comparing these new fangled driverless cars to human driven vehicles.", 'Well nuts, could it be in the nuts? Brazil nuts have "organic selenium" that could have anti-atherosclerotic and anti-cancer activities Macadamia nuts have "organic vitamin B-1" or thiamine that is not the water soluble thiamine hydrochloride found in our multivits Almonds have Gamma Tocopherol, as do walnuts, pecans, pistachios Do they eat nuts or seeds or consume oils high in Tocotrienols? Do they derive medicines from extracts of their flora or nuts or bark? What is the relative activity of NF-kappa Beta & Nrf2?  Do the nuts they consume enhance a healthy intracellular redox balance? Do they grow blue corn, black carrots, purple sweet potatoes or blue potatoes?  If so they could be consuming anthocyanins that explain some of these findings.', "Another small cluster of confounding factors- how much tv did you say these people watch? How often are they on their cellphones? computers? kindles? Just sayin' - and as Someone somewhere said, not considering such factors makes this study meaningless.", 'All their food is fresh, wild, local, organic. They have no chemical exposures. No modern stress. There is a lot more to this than just carbs.', "No stress like we face but they face an even worse stress, I would say, when you don't know if you can catch your family's next meal.", 'And what about the "invisible" benefits of living and working by and near water, working near the plants and trees and other specific beneficial attributes of non-industrialized land and water?', 'What about stress? There are so many possible confounding variables that it seems this study is meaningless.', 'Diet is relevant, but look to genes to find heart disease risk.  Read the comment about high rates of cardiovascular disease in the NYT article in this section about weight and heart disease.  Asians have a very high rate of disease despite a native diet that the medical community considers favorable for limiting the accumulation of plaque and subsequent illness.  Other ethnic groups, such as the Masai tribe in Kenya have low rates of disease despite high intake of whole fat diary and meat. Persons of white European descent are somewhere in between - for some, such a diet, along with added sugar foods is deadly while others are hardly affected at all.', 'This is pure bunkum. When Asians were eating their natural high starch diets supplemented with vegetables they had no heart disease just like this population and all the blue zone populations. It is only when they have changed their diet to high fat western diet they now have heart disease increases. Did they change their genes? The Masai have huge amounts of atherosclerosis as you would expect they do not have heart attacks as they are fit and die at a much earlier age from infection etc.', '@Steve: Traditional/local/native diets were on a spectrum from mostly animals to mostly plants. The percentages of carbs/fats/proteins varied regionally and seasonally. All of these populations had quite low rates of heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and obesity, regardless of whether they were on the high fat or high carb end of the spectrum. What these diets have in common is nutrient density and lack of modern processed foods.', 'As far back as the 1930s, American scientists looked for dietary reasons to explain the higher levels of heart disease and diabetes in Americans compared to people from the Mediterranean.  They found that people eating a true Mediterranean diet ate about 10-15% of their calories from fat, almost a third of what Americans were consuming.  The book, The Blue Zones, published in 2009 discussed the between various ultra-healthy groups of people.  One thing the all  had in common was that they ate a largely plant-based diet, low in fat. I am not sure what is driving the continued debate about the importance of a low fat diet.  The evidence does not seem controversial.  As for inflammation, we need to stop looking at human biochemistry and physiology in a reductionist manner.  It is an intricate, complex set of innumerable chemical reactions.  Too much inflammation is bad, too  little is bad.  You need both omega 3 (inflammation suppression) and omega 6 (inflammation promotion).  There seems to be an ideal ratio of 4 to 1 to 6 to 1 of omega 3 to omega 6.  Again eating an unprocessed, whole grain, low fat, plant-based diet helps one achieve the right balance.', "The original so-called Mediterranean diet of the famous study was actually the diet of Crete, which is heavy on green and other vegetables (some wild), but certainly not vegan. I don't think any tradition has ever developed a vegan diet - and no wonder, vegans need supplements. (Yet the Inuit lived almost exclusively on what they could fish and hunt.)", 'Pooch, you can knock the studies if you want but they were done by the National Center for Biotechnology and they do show that your research is incorrect, if you can state, "No protective effects whatsoever of a low fat diet on heart disease, cancer, obesity, diabetes, overall mortality."', 'you should write a book on this subject!', 'Unprocessed + Constant Movement = Healthy Heart.', "Very poor science. I didn't read that anything was done to exclude the good possibility that the observations in this study were mainly due to a homogeneous  genetic endowment in this closed population that protects them from coronary artery disease.  The protection could also be due to some other unknown and unmeasured factor present  in the population's environment.", 'I am so pleased you discussed the issue of exercise. The first accounts of this study discussed only the diet of the Tsimane. It really is the problem with these type of studies in that it close to impossible to isolate the reason(s) for their outstanding cardiovascular health.', 'From personal history, I know how a diet can impact health status. As a medical doctor, I have always been specific, no one diet can fit all. I worked extensively on Japanese and Mongolian diets comparing with the centenarian we had in France. Atherosclerosis is supposed to start with life, maybe not if the mother breastfeeding the children and have a diet to help. In any study, moving is important, may we mention the lab test to apply sheer stress on the surface of endothelium cells, we can see, obvious changes of shape and change of secretion. I made a device to grow vessels in tubes, the endothelial cells were growing only with additional movement of the tube. We have to work more to determine what makes our life healthier at an individual level, at the public health level.']
summary: Most commentators talk about the efficacy of certain dietary practices. This includes Brazil nuts, plant-based diets, organic food, and omega-3/6s. A good percentage of commentators discount the study, saying that it didn't account for outside factors. Several commentators point to genetics as a major factor, while others look at stress, the environment, and TV time.
short_title: Headline: Heart of the Amazon   Keywords: Heart; Arteriosclerosis and Atherosclerosis; Archaeology and Anthropology; Carbohydrates; Diet and Nutrition; Age, Chronological   Snippet: What some Bolivians with the world’s healthiest arteries might tell us about cardiac fitness.
subreddit: ['Heart', 'Arteriosclerosis and Atherosclerosis', 'Archaeology and Anthropology', 'Carbohydrates', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Age, Chronological']
short_question: ['Heart of the Amazon  ']

query: A family restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, serves the pungent cooking of Koryo Saram, descendants of Koreans who were exiled to Central Asia.
comments: ['This food in this restaurant is the real thing', 'I\'m not sure using the word "exodus" in the title of  this article is accurate or appropriate. As I understand it, this was a mass forced relocation based on ethnicity.', "The history of Koryo-in (Uzbeks of Korean descent) is very sad. The country (Chosun dynasty) was not able to protect them from imperial powers, and lots of Koreans had to leave their home to void them. In Korea, people still try to share and bare the sorrow of those who had to leave their homeland. Their food seems to express that tragic history. But it is very interesting to see how Korea originated food has developed with Uzbek and Russian culture, and it's amazing to find it in NY. :-)", 'Love your reviews. This, about a culture partly transplanted, is pretty special. From a few words about history and food and people, a whole society can be imagined. Thank you.', "This is more than a restaurant review: It's a (timely) reminder of how wonderful this country is! I had no idea of a Korean-Uzbek history — of any connection at all, for that matter — and that people such as the Pyagays are now here in the United States, adding to our culture and dining enjoyment, thrills me."]
summary: The commenters enjoyed the review for not only discussing the restaurant's food and culture but also explaining Korean-Uzbek history of mass forced location. One commenter says that the history of the Koryo-in (Uzbeks of Korean descent) is sad and filled with sorrow and can be expressed in the food. They are thankful that the food is now in New York.
short_title: Headline: Korean Dishes That Recall an Exodus   Keywords: Restaurants; Korean Food (Cuisine); Bensonhurst (Brooklyn, NY); Cafe Lily (Brooklyn, NY, Restaurant)   Snippet: A family restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, serves the pungent cooking of Koryo Saram, descendants of Koreans who were exiled to Central Asia.
short_question: ['Korean Dishes That Recall an Exodus  ']

query: Just when all seemed lost, a different perspective saved the day.
comments: ['Once my wife lost a contact lens that fell down the sink drain.  We pulled out the stopper and spotted it WAY down at the bottom of the drain.  I dabbed a bit of toothpaste on the end of a toothbrush handle and extended the handle down the drain.  Gently tapped the lens with the toothpaste and got it to stick to the handle.  Lens Rescued!', 'Great anecdote and story!!!', 'Metropolitan Diary is the best.', 'A different angle, oblique lighting...try a "true" flashlight (not just a cell phone) with a lens, lie it on the floor/ground and sweep it back and forth. It may need to be moved to a different quadrant of the "search" area, but it does work well.  So much better way of finding a pin or needle than with one\'s foot!', 'This anecdote and all the others offered by commentators show that New Yorkers are a helpful lot, contrary to the image held by the ignorati. And, is this the beloved Joe Brostek of Queens College fame? Hi, Joe!', "Any tips on how to find a dropped gray sliver of O.9 graphite for a mechanical pencil? I've been shining a flashlight on the floor but that tiny toothpick is expert at hide and seek.", 'I admire your innovative solution. One of the best courses I ever took was on problem solving - where we learned to look at things from a different perspective.  Which has led me to create solutions such as unscrewing a jar from the lid instead of the other way around.', "I can only hope the lens owner discarded it once out of view of her saviors since  I can't imagine any amount of cleaning could make a lens retrieved from the sidewalk safe enough to wear!", "I've used them after they've fallen in some pretty unsavory places. You do what you must - and back then, they were expensive (not the disposables of today).", "Sometime in the late 1960's I was hurrying along after work to Penn Station and suddenly realized I had lost one (hard, uncomfortable) contact lens. I stopped and began to pat the sidewalk, and in a New York minute, several people were gathered around me also patting the sidewalk to help find it. No luck.  After a couple of minutes I noticed that my contact-less eye was hurting more than usual and had a feeling the lens had migrated northward to lodge under the eyelid, as it sometimes did. Oops. I was too embarrassed to tell those nice people they had been wasting their time, but stopped them from further search by pleading that, lens or no lens, I needed to catch my train home, and thanked them, and scurried off.  Sure enough, once I got to Penn Station, with no crosstown wind and no disgustingly dirty air (pre-EPA) to further irritate my eyes, I was able to dislodge it back down. I've been embarrassed ever since.", "A similar incident happened to me.  Years ago while enjoying the Submarine Ride at Disneyland with my young son, I declared that I had lost my contact lens.  When we returned to 'port', the crew voluntarily emptied out the other passengers.  They then took my son, husband and me on a solo journey!  Throughout the ride we all were searching on our hands and knees (including the crew) .  A few minutes into the private ride, I realized the lens was displaced on my eye.  Like you, I did not have the courage to admit it.  At the end of the ride, I graciously said thank you to everyone for helping and I  would manage the rest of the day as is.  When the three of us exited the submarine, there was a very long line of people staring at us...probably wondering who were these people who kept them waiting.  Only then did I admit to my husband all was good.  I still feel sheepish about not 'fessing up'...I just could not imagine sitting all alone on that empty submarine, staring through the portholes, with the crew glaring at us!!", "I have found my wife's contacts many times, even in snow and in the Arizona desert. The secret is oblique light.", "How wonderful. I just read the entry about finding a lost contact lens in NYC in the late 1970's.   As it happens , I lost a hard contact lens near a phone booth inside a subway station in  NYC one day on my way to visit a friend.   It fell out while I was making a call and I could not find it. Several people, including a sweet couple and a man who was sweeping up the station looked with me. No luck.  I went on my way and my way back through the station several hours later  I stopped at the booth and there, carefully placed by the phone, was my contact lens.  What?  I never knew who found it, but it was one of the most thoughtful expressions of kindness that I have experienced.  To the person who found my lens, if you are reading this, thank you for a gesture that has helped to sustain my faith in people and belief in little miracles all these years.", 'Bravo!', 'Well done! Indeed, a different angle is often the key.']
summary: Commenters generally praise the practicality of the anecdote. Others explain how oblique lighting and the difference in angle help one see the object more easily. Still, others share touching experiences of also losing and finding a contact lens. One commenter asks for ideas on how to find a piece of mechanical pencil lead.
short_title: Headline: Looking for a Contact Lens in the Dark   Keywords: Eyes and Eyesight; New York City   Snippet: Just when all seemed lost, a different perspective saved the day.
short_question: ['Looking for a Contact Lens in the Dark  ']

query: Daniel Berehulak’s gripping coverage in The New York Times of state-sanctioned killings in the Philippines and E. Jason Wambsgans’s chronicling for the Chicago Tribune of a 10-year-old gunshot victim’s recovery were awarded the P...
comments: ['Thank you for sharing the landscape humanity and inhumanity at the same time.  Congratulations on a well-deserved prize.', 'Friend Eddie Adams is smiling in awe.  Unique talent.  Fascinating.  A masterpiece.', 'Phenomenal, eye-opening work that will endure.', 'Thank you. The media is what keeps America free, and you are heroes to many of us.  I know how dangerous this work can be.  One of my best friends as a child was Myles Tierney. He was killed in action in Sierra Leone as a news producer.', "I knew this would be the one!! The first time I saw it, my gut said this is getting a Putlizer.  That was confirmed by two people whom I forwarded the article to. They never read newspapers, and got their information from Apple's news aggregator app. Not only were they blown by the article and photos, they both signed up for NYT as a result of it. People who think all you need is Reuters or BBC are sorely mistaken. The NYT and WaPo regularly churn out top-notch journalism, and are easily worth the cost of Netflix/HBO streaming for the digital version alone.", 'I was sooooooooooooo happy when I saw this photographer win for this story. When it was first published, I told all my friends and co-workers about it. It is by far the best piece of visual work/reporting I saw last year. Congrats!!!!', 'Our better angels thank and laud you for the selfless work you do.', "Well deserved. As a reader, I can't tell you how moving these images were. The images from the Philippines had such an impact--they moved me to make calls to my senators asking them to do something, to pressure friends who were planning a trip to the Philippines to cancel their trip and go elsewhere, and most of all, to feel the need to DO something to help these people who suddenly did not seem so far away--and to think of how fragile freedom is, whether in the Philippines under Détente or here at home, under Trump.", 'Same planet, different reality. Thank you for reminding it to all of us.', 'Congratulations to all awardees - but mostly, I thank you for your contributions that keep our democracy alive and well, and create awareness for less fortunate parts of the world that deserve our attention.', 'This story moved me to tears.  The humanity and dedication of the photographers.  Their bravery.  The bravery of their subjects.  The senseless violence they present with such compassion.  Looking beyond the bare facts to the human beings involved. Thank you! How I love our Free Press!']
summary: A commenter praises journalistic heroism, and one praises the NYT and WaPo specifically. A commenter is ecstatic that Daniel Berehulak and E. Jason Wambsgans won, and others praise their powerful photography. Several commenters congratulate and complement the photographers for their awards.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Photography; Pulitzer Prizes; Berehulak, Daniel (1975- )   Snippet: Daniel Berehulak’s gripping coverage in The New York Times of state-sanctioned killings in the Philippines and E. Jason Wambsgans’s chronicling for the Chicago Tribune of a 10-year-old gunshot victim’s recovery were awarded the P...

query: Add fresh crab meat to this French cafe classic, a hot ham and cheese sandwich adorned with an egg.
comments: ['Croque-monsieur appeared first to me on a menu in the Southern Tier of western New York. Described to dad a native of Jersey City, but transferred to North Carolina, he exclaimed "Oh, a Monte Christo!"', "I guess my first attempt (Sunday) got lost or did not make the cut.  In short. Mr. Tanis has nailed it yet again.  I think we are faces with ja culinary genius.  OK, so a simple, elegant crab sandwich.  Perhaps I'm a spoiled brat, but living only 40-50 miles from several excellent crabbing waters, I catch my own (Dungies, of course) and use the fresh meat in countless ways.  My only objection to the open sandwich is the obvious use of that square, pressed deli ham.  (A NYC Thing?)  for God's sake, include a little ham here, but please, do whatever it takes to acquire a bit of truly good ham.  You will not be disappointed and the quantity required will not break you bank.  If you are forced to purchase crab meat, that bit (or more?) of real ham will still cost less than the crab meat.  Above I mentioned catching my own Dungies.  Catching these critters is NOT difficult and anyone within a reasonable distance from cold salt water should consider crab catching.  The necessary kit of gear and a Crab Killing License can be had for ~$50.  At least in Oregon, the daily haul is limited to a dozen keeper sized (male only) crabs and so help me, the experience is fun.  Multiple times I have trapped limits with a single soaking of the allowed three traps. got them cooked and cleaned, all within about two hours.  At least for lefties, why pay the monger's prices when you can catch your own and b ne eating within two hours?  In '14. my loaded cost was ~$1.48 per pound of whole crab.", "Hi David, You may indeed be living under a rock, but if so, mine is much, much deeper. I'm not cultured enough to ever have had a croque-monsieur (can't even pronounce it), but yum, some variation sounds good. Gonna give it a try, thanks!", "I think it's the Times' (or at least formerly) Mark Bittman who suggested cutting a hole in the top slide of bread into which you crack the egg and then cook the whole thing on a panini press.  Extremely satisfying.  But I'm going to try the crab as well.", "I have not tried making Croque with crab meat but why not. The tried and desired is made on, yes, homemade sour-dough. A bit of Maille mustard one slice, spread scant. Thin slices of ham next. Beaufort cheese is to die for so that comes next, of course thinly sliced, and then a couple of thinly sliced tomatoes that have been dry pressed between two paper towel. A bit, a little bit, of grated emmental to glue it together and top it with mated slice of Sour dough, but not before topping it off with a couple of 'secret' spices. Then I scantly butter the press and press and fry. The French here are quick to tell me that is not Croque-monsieur and I briefly bow my head in reverence to their knowledge. Then I remind them Je suis américaine, pas traditionnelle. My husband and his family seem to prefer my variation to the original and I have a tendency to believe them not only because they ask for it when I give them a choice but because when have the French ever been obligated to approve any cuisine that is pas d'origine française et tenue à la norme française? I will try your recipe, but with a few changes.  Oh! and I have trained my guests that tasting one's fingers are excellent manners as compliments to the chef!", "I'm French-American also.  No way I will spoil good crab meat by putting it on toast with cheese, what a waste !!", "The Cadillac of crab toasties!  made this today, omitting the ham, because who wants to alter the taste of dungeness crab with ham?  Would make a great brunch dish. Could do the toasts ahead, adding fried or poached egg right before serving and after gently reheating toasts. A keeper. Can't wait to share with our crabbing buddies.", "Friend, a crab toastie is actually a crab melt, available pretty much all round the Chesapeake Bay. Fresh backfin topped with cheddar on a split English muffin, except with Old Bay. The Louisiana version does use Cayenne and often Swiss rather than cheddar. It's all about the crab, however. If that's good, so is everything else.", 'A "croque-madame" has an egg because....women carry eggs!', 'Absolutely!', "KInd of a no-brainer, isn't it?", "I  love Poilane bread and if I were younger i would start selling my interpretation in rural Ct  I first discovered the source on rue du Cherch Midi in the 1980s and would pick up a loaf flown in to  Bloomingdale's when possible. When I stayed home long enough to workout a good facsimile. with Jim Lahey's help, it became a routine. I make many types of bread and have to buy almost none . And wish i were your age and could offer it widely. i think there is a demand somewhere here.  i can recall the american Tea room variation you describe with bechamal and white bread - at the time it was really  divine.", 'A highly innovative idea: crab meat on croque madame, provided the crab meat is real. One may extend it to lobster meat, but on white bread only. Perhsaps this may be adopted by summer roadside eateries in Maine that serve lobstrer rolls.', 'There is a tarragon problem. French tarragon, with it\'s thin leaves and delicate slightly licorice taste, has been replaced by an entity named "Texas Tarragon". The leaves are fat and coarse and the licorice taste is overwhelming to the point that this Texas variety will ruin a dish.', 'One of the ingredients that you list is thin slices ham or prosciutto cotto. Ham or prosciutto cotto is the same thing. In Italy we ask for prosciutto crudo, which means raw and is what we usually ask just prosciutto in the USA; we ask for prosciutto cotto when we want sliced ham. So, in the ingredients that you list just ham is sufficient. Great Recipe.', "Not ghastly. Formidable! My introduction to this delight was in 1973 from a native Californian who had never been far from Malibu: Toast a buttered split English muffin in the broiler, top with crab, paprika, then  Colby cheddar, then broil again until the cheese has melted and browned. Even better than my Missouri-bred mother's toasted white bread and American cheese-and-tomato-topped grilled cheese!", 'What a ghastly idea!', 'Indeed so! No way any poor little crab could survive that appalling onslaught!', "Ghastly? Really? It's most creative and sounds great. I can't wait to try it, and BTW I'm French-American.", "So?  Lots and lots and lots of Americans (and others) eat at MacDonalds, BurgerKing, etc.  Doesn't mean it's good."]
summary: Commenters comment on different variations of a croque-monsieur. Some of the commenters talk about the addition of crab in it, with some pointing out that it needs to be real crab used and others pointing out that crab shouldn't be on a croque-monsieur. A few commenters remark on the fact that there is ham on a crab sandwich, with a few debating the choice of ham used and to upgrade the choice to a better cut of prosciutto.
short_title: Headline: A Croque-Madame Dressed Up With Crab   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Sandwiches; France   Snippet: Add fresh crab meat to this French cafe classic, a hot ham and cheese sandwich adorned with an egg.
short_question: ['A Croque-Madame Dressed Up With Crab  ']

query: Patients in a fee-for-service system were 63 percent more likely to have surgery than those in system where doctors got a salary.
comments: ["This seems like a very big, angry conclusion from a study that leaves me with a lot of questions. I'm curious how many vascular surgeons were available at this military hospital? I just had a long talk about medical management vs PCI of NSTEMIs with a VA internist, and while medical management can have equivalent outcomes for very specific patients, her enthusiasm for it was no doubt influenced by the lack of a vascular surgeon at her hospital. And even when various procedures are available here, there is often a long wait and scheduling difficulties that factor into the decision of whether or not to plan a surgery. Did this study control for differences between the study populations? Were outcomes recorded at all? My fellow commenters seem eager to start pointing fingers at greedy doctors, but in my training I really have yet to see a surgeon or any doctor who didn't truly want what was best for their patients.", 'The pendulum is swinging and for all of the problems with fee for service, the compensation model is moving toward higher pay for providers who spend less money per patient - meaning, they are rewarded for ordering fewer tests and procedures.  That model failed in the 1980\'s with the perception insurance companies had denied approval for appropriate procedures, etc. which ultimately resulted in harm to the patient.  Patients and doctors were really angry with that "system" 35 years ago.  People are angry now at what they perceive as a model that doesn\'t give a flip about their health or finances - just wait until they find out their providers are getting paid more for doing even less than they are now ! What could go wrong ....', 'This article depicts far from the complete story. Who  here would prefer a cane or walker and bottle of ibuprofen as the "meds and lifestyle modifications" when they could have their hip or knee surgically replaced- with a 95% good to excellent outcome? And who would prefer to wait for a year while in pain for treatments that could take place immediately- restoring health, vigor, and ones contributions to society? I find it comical that the same American healthcare consumers up in arms about  this article would be screaming from the rooftops about the delays and rationing of a VA type system. But remember when it finally happens- you\'ll be getting the exact type of healthcare you deserve.', 'Duh! Of course money is a huge driving force behind healthcare as t is behind everything else in our greed dominated American society.  We Americans have accepted the right wing view of "everything is fair game for a buck" and now that those greed-driven people are in charge, just you wait.', 'RosieNYC, You are right in that money and greed drive much of society, but you are seriously mistaken to attribute that to the "right wing view."  You should be more careful to attribute that to individual character and avoid stereotypes.  I am quite sure I stand far to the right of your position, but you would find me, and most of the many like me to be more caring, patient centered, cost effective and self-abasing and charitable than many of those I know to the left of me.  I could easily make 50% more than I make now by not making the best choices for my patients.  Neither my patients\' or my geography, race, or gender having any bearing on my choices. My internal compass, my beliefs about others, my ethics and my upbringing that drive me both to the right and to the practice patterns that I hold.   They are not mutually exclusive as you presume.', 'Suprise! From a doctor who practised in both systems - the British National Health Service and the Canadian Fee for Service system.', 'A shocking "medical heresy" was quietly stated in a mainstream medical journal.  “Less health care is better than more health care”, says  Dr. Deborah Grady in her editorial in the May 10, 2010 Archives of Internal Medicine which is critical of mainstream medicine.  Dr Grady cites specific examples.   The first is synthetic  hormone therapy used by the mainstream medical system found to cause cancer and heart disease in the 2002 Women\'s Health Initiative study.  Dr. Grady\'s second example is the discredited practice of arthroscopic surgery for osteoarthritis.  Millions of these useless procedures were performed in the late 90\'s until abandoned after randomized trials showed no benefit.  A third example is the case of SSRI antidepressant drugs offering little benefit for patients with mild to moderate depression.   A fourth example is screening mammography.   "The adverse effects of mammography—false-positive findings, biopsies, anxiety, and over diagnosis and treatment of latent cancers may overwhelm the benefit." Dr Grady\'s final example is the over-use and misuse of antacid drugs called proton pump inhibitors (PPI\'s).  When our health care is based on the profit motive, the end result produces more harm than good. Hence, the advice, “Doing Nothing” is frequently the best treatment plan.  for more see:   http://www.bioidenticalhormones101.com/Less_Is_More_Jeffrey_Dach.html jeffrey dach md', "I couldn't agree more with you. I just moved to the US from Italy where, besides an uncertain economy, health is not privatised. Everybody is entitled to free health care (even illegal immigrants from the coast of Africa) and guess what: a good Mediterranean diet and doctors who are motivated by the Hippocratic Oath and not profit lead to longer life expectation (rank #6 against US rank#31). The United States is not a Country, it's a business. Everything comes with a price tag. I just learned that you can get a more comfortable cell into the privatised incarceration system. Sorry for the rant...", 'Doctors  get paid for what they do to patients, not what they do for patients. As an orthopedic surgeon in private practice for 32 years I have seen how technology and a changing medical ethos has allowed surgeons to harvest patients for profit because of the perceived " better, slicker, cutting edge" hardware. The findings of this study are not surprising to me at all.', "In reality, choosing appropriate surgical/procedural candidates is a complex process involving the patient's medical history, co-morbidities, skill level/procedural comfort of the physician, and the patient's wishes.  Of course, the patient's wishes are the most important.  Any idea how many patients opt for non-necessary interventions because they believe more is better and want the most definitive treatment option available?? A LOT.  Many times talking a patient OUT of a procedure, or simple antibiotics, is a real challenge. They are anxious, want something done, and want the problem fixed ASAP.  And for the physician, failure to provide care is a lot harder to defend than overtreatment, so they go along.  Until patients can accept the medicine is an educated guess (bad outcomes will happen) and doing less IS an acceptable treatment option,  the most definitive and thus costly treatment options will dominate.", 'In my training as an orthopaedic surgeon I recall a spine surgery rotation at a prominent  community hospital in the NYC area.   The spine surgeons were excellent.  One day they performed a discectomy on a 16 year old girl with less then six weeks of pain in her leg and a positive MRI for a disc herniation.  I asked why they did not suggest the patient wait longer before having a surgical procedure.  The literature supported that for most patients in her age group with similar medical findings, the symptoms resolve in a few months without long term residual problems. His responded that if he did not do the surgery, someone else in the community would, and he could do a better job. My medical practice was a Kaiser Permanente, where the physicians are salaried and not paid on a case by case basis.  I found there was not financial competition between doctors, allowing for better communication and sharing of patients.  My medical training included rotations all across the country - and I never found a better healthcare delivery system than Kaiser Permanente.', "Kaiser may be great for members but not for others. By law, COBRA, any hospitals with ERs are required to treat all comers. Twenty-five years ago my wife and I were rear-ended north of LA enroute to La Quinta. My wife with six fused vertebrae experienced severe back pain above the fusion. The closest ER was a Kaiser facility. We stopped and were eventually seen by a Kaiser physician. He essentially gave us the non-members' bums rush refusing to even order an X-ray to look for possible damage from the accident. I offered to pay by credit card or check for the X-ray. No go. Frustrated with not knowing the area and local medical facilities, we drove on to La Quinta. My cousin, a retired ENT, immediately took her to an ER where an X-ray showed a compression fracture above the fusion that led to the terrific Betty Ford clinic and back to Pittsburgh. It's good that Kaiser doctors can communicate well on patient well-being and share patients rather than participate in the medical money scrum. Maybe one day they'll comply with the law and the Hippocratic Oath.", 'Surgery or drugs? The answer is not that simple.  Patients are normally referred by their primary care doctors to surgeons. Of course, initially internists will advise drugs and life style changes to their patients and wait for a period of time but they are not going to take the malpractice risks , it is easy for them to send the patients for surgical evaluation and not being worried about malpractice risk Once patients go to surgeons, what do you expect other than surgery.?', 'We pay TWICE the amount on health care as a percentage of GPD than most of our direct competitors, such as Germany, Japan, Great Britain, etc.  The most important reason is our pay-per-service model (although there are other factors).  Note that our health outcomes are NOT better than these countries, and in many measures are worse. Obamacare did include incentives to move toward s pay-for-performance, but these need to be strengthened. Imagine how the debate over replacing Obamacare would be changed if we could cut costs in half.  Why is the current debate in Congress and in media not about cutting costs???', 'Our health care outcomes are not better than other countries NOT simply because of our health care system but in large part because of our societal problems which are beyond the control of our health care system such as violence, lack of exercise, crime, obesity, smoking, drugs, etc.', "But you didn't tell us how the patients did. Were surgery outcomes better or worse?", "This is oversimplified. For over 20 years I have been getting drug prescriptions to deal with migraines. The drugs were never effective long term. Last year I had surgery to implant a Neuro stimulator. The effect is amazing. I don't know why the surgery was never recommended to me.", "There is no denying there are physicians corrupted by profit motive but they are a minority and the overall effect on health care spending is not nearly what this report would lead one to believe. Whether the clinical problem is carotid stenosis, coronary artery disease and the use of stents, back pain and choice of surgery or physical therapy, prostate cancer, thyroid nodules, breast calcification on mammograms. Each clinical scenario and each individual patient presents a unique circumstance and clinical decisions are nuanced and influenced by so many factors including insurance coverage as well as patient preference and everything in between. I can't wait until US healthcare finally arrives at it's ultimate destination, a national health system and watch the cultural revolution that will be necessary for patients and their families adapt to the change.", '...and to a hammer, everything looks like a nail. Why is it Docs hate referring to other specialties? Not just profit motive.', 'This is hardly surprising. It is inevitable that some of what drives how healthcare is administered in the U.S. is distorted by the effects of profit motives. You hope that compassion and doing no harm still remain among the biggest drivers of healthcare but the Republican alternative to the ACA and Medicaid drag health care delivery much further away from the laudable goals.', "When we have a big problem with expanding health care costs, research which points towards saving money in health care delivery ought to receive a lot of attention.  It is unlikely that it will however, since the problems currently being addressed by the debate on health care reform have little to do with saving money and more to do with the rich trying to avoid having to pay more for the country's health care than the middle class or Medicaid population.   Also, what this study misses is that medications and surgery are only 2 options for treatment.  How many doctors opt for none of the above?", 'This condition is serious and requires treatment. None of the above? Not an option.', 'i have been telling people this for years  dealt with many surgeons as a medical pharmaceutical sales representative  the money incentive cannot be ignored in the current health care system  it also contributes to excessive medical costs in usa  we need a national health care plan that offers a base of services similiar to the nhs in britain and if you have extra money you can go see a specialist on their famous street', 'So if the Koch brothers succeed in privatizing the Veterans Affairs system, we should be having more endarterectomy surgery.']
summary: Several commenters are critical of the pay-per-service model and see that as encouraging doctors to over-treat their patients, while other posters counter that greed and profit-motivation really play a small part in these choices and that the patients themselves often prefer the surgical option over slower acting options. A poster points out how fear of malpractice may prompt doctors to favor surgery, and another relates an anecdote where a young patient was given surgery, which may have been unnecessary simply to prevent them from receiving it from a competitor. One doctor gave a personal anecdote of a class of complaint that seems to respond better to surgery than to medication, and one respondent wants to know which method, surgery or medication, has the better outcomes.
short_title: Headline: Doctors; Pay Drives Decision to Operate   Keywords: Surgery and Surgeons; Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates); Wages and Salaries; Doctors   Snippet: Patients in a fee-for-service system were 63 percent more likely to have surgery than those in system where doctors got a salary.
subreddit: ['Surgery and Surgeons', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Doctors']
short_question: ['Doctors; Pay Drives Decision to Operate  ']

query: Their resilience shows the limitations of the web as a place to nurture young creativity.
comments: ["I'd like to know more about the business model - how do Zines sustain themselves?", 'Small press journals sustain themselves through reader support and subscriptions if they are not fully funded by the producers. The Blue Collar Review is published by the not for profit  http://Partisanpress.org It was initially supported by the editors but has been supported by readers for over a decade.', "They're fairly cheap to print, so making your money back isn't always a massive necessity. A lot of people trade zines anyway, so you aren't really 'paid' in currency. As the publisher of a small photozine publishing concern, the limited audience (generally other photographers and zinemakers) is a bit of a worry - it's something pretty rare and Zeitgiesty that'll break out.  And the zines themselves might be a physical object, the marketing of them is very much digital - would sell a lot less without social media and online sales. Actually, online sales make up 80% of our sales.", "I put out a zine in the mid-90s, and it was  read by probably two dozen people who ordered it from Factsheet 5, the zine review that we all gobbled up whenever it appeared. Zines remain my greatest writing teacher, because they showed me that I can write about anything I want - whether it's the secrets of packaging duck sauce or poignant, enraging, puzzling encounters I witnessed on the streets of NYC (and was sometimes a part of). I'd like to give a shoutout to Aaron Cometbus, publisher and writer of the best zine ever, Cometbus, which is still going strong after a couple of decades or so. Thanks, Aaron and all the others out there who provided me with hours of entertainment and teaching and made me realize that true creativity can be found in ballpoint pens and blank white paper.", "Great article! It's important to look at how Zines still offer a deeper study than the internet. As they (I) say, the web is wide and shallow while zines (and books) are narrow and deep. Zines have a particular importance in architecture and design culture, where new ideas and speculative thinking have been done for a while (since the 70s at least) while design on the internet usually involves generic coverage from ignorant, non-expert critics who don't really have interest in the subjects. Zines are usually written by experts with a deeper level of love.", 'Without small press journals, even going back to the 1920s, most American poets would never have made it to print -- and most are literary. This continues to be the case. Though internet sites," e-zines," are cheaper to produce, the quality of attention and reading are very different. They call it virtual for a reason. An actual, paper in your hand publication, requires not only more commitment on the parts of both producer and reader, it requires more focus than browsing a screen. The average website visit can be measured in seconds and is usually under 2 minutes. In a book one reads and considers, then turns the page. Arrangement and presentation matter more as well. Actual journals in print are also more permanent with lives of their own. They are saved or passed around, need no internet connection or batteries, they continue to be read for years. The internet and the language of programs are passing fancies dependent on particular conditions and limited in access unlike books and journals in which our words will outlive us.', "So, in other words, zines thrive because, unlike the Internet, they are relatively troll-proof. That's reason enough for me.", 'Thanx to the previously posted comments for reminding me what a zine once was. Greedsters killed the World Wide Web. Starting with Microsoft who killed Netscape. It can be argued that it was evolutionary but those good ol days when the web had promise have become quaint. The internet seems to be all about pay to play. Fanzines and web crawlers are the one reel silent shorts of their time. Honey! Where did I put my notebook and pencil.', "Social media killed interest and hobby based discussion sites and forums on the web. Social media sites tie into your real life identity so users don't want to discuss anything that could be controversial or come back to haunt them. Social media sites thread and display ongoing discussions very poorly. Online communities were much more vibrant and interesting being based on interests and hobbies, and not our material networked identity. Why would I want to communicate with the same social network online as I already do in real life? Boring! I want to meet new people based on my interests and hobbies, and far away from my existing social networks.  Also cookie cutter web design and dull user experience of social media sites and WordPress killed communicative creativity and innovation. Flash sites may not have always been pretty but some people did some really creative designs and experiences through a website using Flash. Now it's the same HTML5  template over and over again. Sad!  But, yes, long live the zine!", "Oh, my goodness! Where's the research? Where's the historical background? Zines -- or more fully, fanzines -- did not appear spontaneously in the 1990s. Science fiction fans (which meant, in the beginning, people who read books and magazines) were doing so as far back as the 1930s. I myself began pubbing my ish (more fannish lingo, which I'm sure you can understand by context) in the late 1960s. Some fanzines were crude things, produced on hectos (hectographs), dittos (spirit duplicator), or mimeos (mimeographs), while the more serious among us sometimes went for a more professional look with printing presses and Xerography. Ray Bradbury and Roger Ebert, among many others, pubbed fanzines. When the small press phenomenon of the 1990s was gearing up, the purveyors thereof were following in the footsteps of decades of pioneers. In other words, sorry, cool kids, but we geeks and nerds beat you to it, by a long way.", "What he said. I published ALGOL, my first spirit duplicated fanzine in 1963; that eventually became mimeographed, then offset. I bought a Selectric so I could produce good, clean text. Eventually, it went typeset, offset, then had full color covers. Mailed it out to dozens, then hundreds, then thousands of subscribers, and sold it through bookstores. It won a Hugo award in 1974. And I have fanzines published in the 1930s. Was active in the small press movement in the 1970s and 80s here in NYC—worked on several Small Press Fairs here. There are still small press fairs held every year, in NYC and so many other places. Every generation, people seem to forget that stuff came before them, and they think they're inventing the wheel. Not so: they're re-inventing wheels that have been around since Amateur Journalism in the 1890s, and political pamphlets during the American Revolution. I suggest you check out the hundreds of science fiction fanzines available for viewing at the website efanzines.com", 'And they were called APAs (Amateur Press Associations).', 'What a disappointing little article. To begin with, the term "zine" is itself  diminutive and insulting given the labor and dedication required to publish a small magazine. The emphasis on subculture is odd as well as most small publications do not fit that mold. One journal mentioned here, the Blue Collar Review has been around for decades and has published such notables as  Simon Perchik, Jim Daniels, Mary McAnally, Marge Piercy, Antler, Martin Espada, Tim Seibles and many more including many lesser know but equally talented working class poets and writers. It would have more appropriately been covered in the most recent Sunday New York Times Magazine given its working class focus.  other important small press magazines include Nerve Cowboy, the Black Bear Review and Barbaric Yawp. Better coverage of one example, the Blue Collar Review can be seen here:   www.everywritersresource.com/literarymagazines/blue-collar-review-2/', "Thanks for pointing this out. In fact, the 90's and early 2000's was a wonderful age of a pre-digital media revolution including mix tapes, zines printed at 24 hour copy shops, independent movie festivals, and TV shows for local cable (like Wayne's World).  Glad to see it still exists out there!", 'Do straight people write Zines?', "I moved to San Francisco in 1994. I remember picking up zines in coffee shops and bars.  Hand drawn and hand written and photocopied. I'm glad they're making a comeback.", '"Each social-media platform tends to reward certain behaviors and styles of posting, all in the interest of building fans and followers who are invested in the performance of a persona (maybe even more so than the Geppetto-like person orchestrating it all)." With this column as evidence I would suggest that the NY Times now fits this description perfectly.', "While there are many queer zines, the focus of this article, I'd just like to point out that there are a ton of other great zines out there on any imaginable subject, as any visitor to PS1's annual NY Art Book Fair will know. And it's never been easier to start making your own zines!  Here's a quick primer: http://carnagenyc.com/home/2015/5/11/so-you-want-to-make-a-zine", 'Thanks for this! To see "zines" on the NY Times gave me goosebumps. I\'ve always loved zines, and got into them via the Salt Lake City zine library. I did a few black and white ones, and then started The Climbing Zine. We focus on print, and its really been to our benefit.  word, Luke Mehall publisher, The Climbing Zine www.climbingzine.com', 'There\'s a false dichotomy that many non-technical people tend to stumble into: namely that publishing on the Internet consists of some "social media" site or nothing at all.  The thing is, the Web was envisioned to be more like zines than the way so many people us it now.  Stand alone, simple web pages are a wonderful way of reaching a lot of people, all on one\'s own terms.  No corporate gatekeeper, no money, and very little technical know-how is needed  to create web sites the way the Web was intended.']
summary: Several commenters talk about the history of "zines," with some pointing out that they existed in print media before computers were widely in use. Some of these commenters talk about buying zines on the streets of New York City in the '90s.  Other commenters lament that internet zines aren't as good as they used to be, with one attributing the decline in controversial discussions on the internet (including some zines) to social media, where people cannot make their comments anonymously.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Blogs and Blogging (Internet); Tumblr; Twitter; Facebook Inc   Snippet: Their resilience shows the limitations of the web as a place to nurture young creativity.

query: The debut of Michael Barbaro’s “The Daily” audio show is a reminder that The Times has been broadcasting the news for 76 years.
comments: ["I don't think it was a football game between the NY Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers was it? Was there ever a football team called the Brooklyn Dodgers? I would say they meant baseball but it was December so it must have been football.", 'If Trump really wants to impress his friends, he should do a reverse "Day of Infamy" and jet to North Korea on Korean Airlines, his plane surrounded of course by numerous American jet fighters, as down below lurked an American aircraft carrier or two in case things got crazy, backed up by all of America\'s nukes currently aimed at North Korea. And when Trump landed in Pyongyang, this of course would drive Kim crazy and suddenly the world would have one less enemy. You\'re welcome.', 'I grew to love newspapers as a child, but I rushed into broadcasting, doing my first "on-air" announcements at the 15. Broadcasting had an excitement and a reach that newspapers could not match. Besides, no newspaper was going to give me any job while still in high school. At 16 I was hired to be a "leg man" for an aging, sometimes drunk radio reporter in Reading, Pa., but I was quickly fired, lacking all of the necessary skills, including typing (yes, broadcasters write stories). 1 year later, I was re-hired by the same station and never looked back, moving into television news in Texas at 20 while still in college. I mention this to say that it was readily apparent that "print guys"more or less hated television. Back when radio and television were new, newspapers made efforts to try to lock them out of news sources and events, including refusing  admission to the press galleries in Congress, the work areas for reporters. Eventually, comprises were reached and print came to tolerate, while still loathing, broadcasters. The threat was real. The shrinking of newspapers down to one per city is directly due to television taking away ad dollars and to the rise of the evening newscasts. Radio was generally a failure for print companies because it didn\'t offer anything like the huge revenue streams of print ads, so the executives didn\'t really want to stick with it. Had print organizations been more aware, they could have owned cable news and spread their influence world wide.', 'I have read that the first person to report the attack was Webly Edwards, later of "Hawaii Calls" radio fame.  Webly was originally from Fossil, Oregon.  FYI', "Big difference. Pearl Harbor, where 2,500 Americans were killed, united the country. 9/11, where nearly 3,000 innocent Amercans were killed, divided us as we have never been divided before since the Civil War. After Pearl Harbor, it took a united America less than 4 years to defeat both the Empire of Japan and the Third Riech of Germany - both of which were the most militarily powerful nations on earth in 1941. It has been 16 years since 9/11, and we're been fighting ragtag militias in the Middle East even since, and there is still no end in sight to this present conflict - which has now lasted longer than Vietnam. We can't even agree on who our enemy is, even though it is has been apparent ever since 9/11. I guess the disinformation campaign is working very well - for our enemies!", 'Those of us who remember this day soon had them sharpened by events. We knew  what would happen soon after the soon to end High School JGAIA-', 'I absoultely love the new section of the NYTimes , "The Daily".it is current, media interactive, and very engaging. I am actually having my students listen to it as weekly homework! congrats, and thanks Micheal Barbaro! love your daily news show!', 'The Times needs a Video Presence on the Internet with an app for Apple TV, Roku TV, Amazon Fire TV and Google Chromecast. You are already producing a significant amount of video and putting it up on a dedicated Video App would allow users to see it and would also allow you to stream live video whenever you saw the need to - for breaking news or a large event.', 'Ah, but Spielberg\'s movie "1941" was terrific, and the comedy is still hilarious to this day.  No offense, but while my grandfather served in WWII, I am fairly well over it, and more concerned with what\'s going on right now.  Clearly a fascist takeover of Germany was bad, and that was an impoverished, landlocked little nation made up of dozens of principalities.  A fascist takeover of America is far more concerning right now, though if we get through it, the comedy movies afterwards are probably going to be even better this time.', "I may have heard that broadcast. I was only 4 years old at the time, but I vividly recall how excited and angry my Dad became one afternoon around that time while listening to the radio. I don't recall what he was shouting about but he was so outraged that my Mom couldn't calm him down.", 'While true there is no need to make news "more exciting than it is", recognizing the fact none of us asked to be put on this or any other planet (unless we are actually trying to bring some comforting sense of order to the universe we inhabit) there is also no need to report news other than as we think it is. While it may make a difference in the long run, no one does or will make sneakers built for that haul. The question then asked is why bother? Simply stated because we die and future generations are left with our errors. Our responsibility as thinking creatures is to use our ability to determine and assess problems while implementing strategies which disarm them both for us, but more importantly the generations which follow. Understandable, but unfortunately deniable. We all acknowledge the truth of life, but most of us deny it. Lying about anything doesn\'t help one iota and a lot of people who know better are lying.']
summary: Some commentators share stories about the radio broadcast or broadcasting during that time period. One commentator suggests flying Trump into North Korea with weapons backing him up to take them out. Another commentator observes that 9/11 divided us while Pearl Harbor united us. A third commentator gives a lengthy speech about life. One commentator randomly asks sports-related questions. Another commentator enjoys the new section in the paper.
short_title: Headline: 1941 | On a Day of Infamy, The Times Is On the Air   Keywords: Radio; WMCA-AM; Sulzberger, Arthur Hays; New York Times; World War II (1939-45); Newspapers; WQXR; Barbaro, Michael; Bernstein, Nina; Pearl Harbor (Hawaii)   Snippet: The debut of Michael Barbaro’s “The Daily” audio show is a reminder that The Times has been broadcasting the news for 76 years.
subreddit: ['Radio', 'WMCA-AM', 'Sulzberger, Arthur Hays', 'New York Times', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Newspapers', 'WQXR', 'Barbaro, Michael', 'Bernstein, Nina', 'Pearl Harbor (Hawaii)']
short_question: ['1941 | On a Day of Infamy, The Times Is On the Air  ']

query: People, especially minorities, who are at a “healthy” weight may still be at increased risk for diabetes and heart disease, a new study reports.
comments: ['The paper this article is based on is not news worthy.  The Brits have already done this work and published new guidelines for Asians. However, the real problem is the improper use of the BMI as an individual metric.  There is too much variability in the relationship between risk factors and BMI to be usefully applied to individuals. This is well documented but for reasons I don’t understand, the medical community still misapplies a population metric to evaluate samples (i.e. patients).  And lastly, why is the medical community still looking at BMI when science-based evidence demonstrates that it is abdominal obesity and not overall weight that is the problem.', 'Personally, I have found that my numbers are influenced by my diet and not my weight.', '"Normal weight" is a definition that has changed over the years.  When I finished college my BMI was around 17 or 18, same as it now is decades later.  I was called \'lanky\' or \'wiry\' or, in my family circle, \'just like your dad\' but nobody seemed to think anything abnormal was going on.   This changed when I moved to the USA and applied for health insurance.  Overnight, I became emaciated.  My agent suggested I put a couple of bricks in my pockets and "correct" my forms or there might be a problem getting coverage.  Doctors have checked me for thyroid problems, parasites, you name it.  Skinny is treated like a disease down here. My point is, human variation exists.  What\'s right for me might be sinister for you.  So get to know your own body and stick with a doctor you trust.', 'Dr. Ronald Krauss,  a leading cholesterol researcher at UCSF, has developed NMR LipoProfile Test for the analysis of LDL particle (LDL-P), number and size because the traditional cholesterol test (LDL-C) is not accurate to estimate our cholesterol problem. He has been warning for many years that small and dense LDLs made from carbs (plus protein) are major cause of heart attack and stroke. Recently his theory is accepted by the large number of researchers. Asians, Hispanics and African-Americans tend to eat lots of carbs, and this is the reason why a large number of them suffer from metabolic syndrome such as high level of cholesterol (LDL-C), high-blood pressure, diabetes, fatty liver etc. Dr. Michael Murray, a leading diabetes physician, mentions that many thin persons with high level of cholesterol (LDL-C) also suffers from diabetes or pre-diabetes because most of them have low level of AMPK, an enzyme that facilitates glucose uptake for the energy production by mitochondria. He recommends cutback of carbs intake for those people (toward healthy fat intake).', '"small and dense LDLs made from carbs (plus protein) are major cause of heart attack and stroke" Lipoproteins are comprised of fats and proteins (hence the name). Not sure why you dragged carbs into the mix.', 'Ess, Study on "lipogenesys" or "de novo lypogenesys".', "Thanks. I'll check it out. In any case, from what i understand this would only occur if one consumed more calories than they need (excess)", 'Are you alive? You may be at risk of death.', '@ Margaret Peterson, I look at it the other way around. The only way NOT to be at (future) risk of death is to be nonliving already. Paraphrasing the poet, "It is better to have lived and died than never to have lived at all."', "Suddenly virtually health report focuses on studies which divide people by so-called race, and any gains in knowledge are vitiated by a false sense of division between human begins. For example, this article bizarrely ignores diet, although South Asians are thought to have high rates of diabetes and metabolic syndrome because of a starchy diet, with much rice and sweets. I'd like to know if and when the New York Times will again become capable of writing about ANY SUBJECT -- health, arts, sports, academics, without divisively obsessively injecting race. (Compare the Times obituary of Don Rickels with the WSJ or WP or any other publication; the differences are quite striking.)", "Did you even bother to check the study or use your dwindling reserve of common sense before you spewing out that disparaging comment? The primary focus of the study was on race & ethnicity! And FYI, the south Asian diet varies considerably by region and is not mostly rice and sweets. Either you're just plain ignorant or need to find a different set of south Asian friends.", '"They found that compared to whites of normal weight, South Asians of normal weight were twice as likely to have abnormal readings in two or more of these risk factors."      South Asians have the highest incidence of heart disease in the world, even though many of them are "normal weight" and BMI within normal range and many of them are vegetarians. BMI is a poor predictor for South Asians  who often show a “thin-fat” syndrome where they fall within BMI standards but have more visceral fat—abdominal fat that is more likely to lead to a cardiovascular event. Waist circumference or waist-to-hip ratio may be more predictive measurements for this group, More than one third of South Asian men and 17 percent of South Asian women have metabolic syndrome, a cluster of conditions such as high blood pressure, high blood sugar levels, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Although South Asians have levels of LDL cholesterol comparable to other populations, LDL particle size tends to be smaller. Small LDL particles,are more atherogenic than larger particles.', 'My physician told me that the feast or famine physique (by ancestral life conditions, not current life circumstances), among South Asians is to blame for hypersensitivity to sugar. Would that not count for those with European ancestry as well? Some in the medical community have said that the high rates of diabetes among South Asians, despite normal range weights, have been baffling. About 30% of South Asians in the US are diagnosed with diabetes by the time they are 50. I do not know. Although anecdotal, eating organic and Non GMO has stabilized my blood sugar levels, along with medication and exercise.', "South Asians have very low HDL in general. This is genetic. More than the actual LDL numbers in milligrams/deciliter, the ratio of total cholesterol, LDL + HDL + VLDL, to HDL is considered by many physicians to be a good measure of proclivity to heart attacks. This ratio in South Asians tend to be large, as large as 5 as opposed to the ``ideal'' number of 3 or less. It is difficult to raise the HDL number to the desired number 40 mg/dl. Diabetes in South Asians is perhaps not genetic but due to sudden change in lifestyle at all levels. People are able to afford more sugary foods and exercise has never been part of the South Asian lifestyle.", 'This should not be news. The BMI is one of the most imperfect measures out there. You can have a normal BMI and still have plenty of fat around your mid-section, or you can be classified as overweight (as my husband is) simply because you are very muscular with absolutely no mid-section fat accumulation. Why do we keep looking at BMI. Waist-to-height ratio seems to be a somewhat better measure and that has been known for a while.  http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/6/3/e010159', 'This begs some questions: what is a nomal weight? Is "normal" healthy?', 'Maybe "normal weight" needs to be redefined. Why is white normal considered the universal normal? I\'m no statistician, but it looks like the white American BMIs are the outlier of the other non-white American groups', 'Yes, to me this is the most glaring problem with how this study is described. Clearly  the stats for "white [likely male] person" are being cited as "normal" and everything else is measured against that. And are we talking about South Asian Americans? That fact is not stated. Research has proven that the immigrant experience negatively affects health outcomes, and that African-American health is negatively affected by the stress of discrimination. Stating "Race is a factor in the risk for heart disease" without these qualifiers implies that non-whites inherently have poor health.', 'The DNA control the metabolism of any individual. It is the reason one diet does not fit all. In a family eating at the same table, few changes have to be addressed to support healthy digestion.For heart diseases which are linked to atherosclerosis, they are also linked to environment, diet, and lifestyle. To find the right prevention for cardiac diseases, a professional has to harvest the personal and familial history of an individual, then to set an equation figuring what is the hierarchy of the nutrients responsible for this patient to increase the risk of cardiac diseases. The BMI may be just an indicator of the connection with some nutrients. If you increase your weight when taking some supplement supposedly good for something, you have to stop because taking weight fast from a nutrient means a retention of water, means a toxicity for your body.  We may multiply the examples. I always ask people, friend and family to not adopt the remedy of your neighbor until you ask a professional.', "I wonder when researchers use more updated and most reliable method to analyze so-called LDL cholesterol problem. NMR LipoProfile w/lipids test and Cardio IQ Lipoprotein Fractionation test are two major tests to analyze size and number of cholesterol P (Particle) instead of cholesterol C (cholesterol itself). Conventional LDL cholesterol test is outdated and erroneous for the analysis of cholesterol problem. However many doctors still use this old-fashioned test and push statins to patients in order to lower cholesterol level,  though they know that a great number of risks caused by statins such as diabetes, heart attack, Alzheimer's or permanent damage to muscle. Large number of Asians, Hispanics and African-Americans eat carbs-based diet that produce numerous small and dense cholesterol that is most toxic and causing atherosclerosis formation and also produce excess (above 100 mg/dl) level of triglycerides. Diabetes, heart attack and stroke, Alzheimer's and dementia, fatty liver, cancer are all deteriorated by the excess blood sugar produced from excess carbs-intake.", 'I did the Cardiac IQ test and nearly all my results fell in the "High Risk" category. I\'m a lean, non-smoking, vegetarian lifelong runner who, at age 62 has already outlived her mother and both grandmothers, all of whom died from heart disease, but were also sedentary overweight smokers. Since inflammation has been shown to be a better predictor of heart disease in women than any cholesterol measurements, my doctor is unconcerned about my lipid panel numbers, as my C-reactive protein level is close to zero. And about half of heart attack patients do not have high cholesterol, period.', "Dear alterego: How are your homocysteine, A1C, vitamin D levels? I am personally curious how vegetarians manage these biomarkers. Are you taking supplements like B, D vitamins? I am most curious how vegetarians manage glucose and A1C under safe levels. By the way, I have never heard that inflammation is a better predictor of heart disease for women than lipid panel numbers and LDL sizes. What is the research base for your doctor's claim? I have a feeling that you are mislead.", 'If you take a minute and a step back from bashing carbs, you might see that there are many factors at play in the generation of chronic disease. In any case,  what do you think is the ideal macronutrient ratio  for a lifetime of good health? AlterEgo - what test did you undergo to determine your CRP levels? What do you consider an ideal ratio of macronutrient']
summary: Many of the commenters question the validity of BMI when determining if a person has a healthy weight. One commenter even states that BMI is a very "imperfect measure." Another commenter suggests that BMI should be adjusted for different races and gives an example that Southern Asian's at a healthy weight "were twice as likely" to be at risk for poor health. Another commenter provides a self anecdote stating that in his home country, he was considered skinny, but once he came to the USA, he was described as "emaciated," and people treated him like he had a disease.
short_title: Headline: Heart: Race as a Heart Health Factor   Keywords: Blacks; Chinese-Americans; Heart; Weight; Minorities; Cholesterol; Hispanic-Americans; Diet and Nutrition; Diabetes   Snippet: People, especially minorities, who are at a “healthy” weight may still be at increased risk for diabetes and heart disease, a new study reports.
short_question: ['Heart: Race as a Heart Health Factor  ']

query: The move closes a fraught chapter in the country’s economic history, but Iceland faces new challenges as growth rebounds — some say too quickly for its own good.
comments: ["Iceland is a role model in how to stop the fraud and extortion by the major banks controlling an economy. They imprisoned the major thieves, restructured the economy to protect the population, and have rebuilt their economy on a solid and transparent foundation.
