query: Do you like Valentine’s Day? What memorable things, good or bad, have happened to you on this day?
comments: ['Valentines day is great for the lovey dovey couples but for us single people thinks its gross. How the couples are all up on each other it gets a little uncomfortable like you wanna say get a room but you cant cause it\'s "Valentines day." I believe it\'s silly, ridiculous, and idiotic that people spend over $100 for there girlfriend/boyfriend. Yes i understand that you want to show them you love them or make them feel important but if I\'m being honest, I would much rather you bring me flowers and chocolate no where near Valentines day because you want to not cause society says you have too. Overall Valentines is great when your are in a relationship but it sucks for us single people.', "Valentine's Day is wonderful; a day where you can rip your heart out and put it in your sleeve. Expressing your feelings through candies and cards and maybe even a teddy bear. For some it's a fun time, for others it's a reminder of loneliness and an excuse to watch The Notebook with 3 pints of Ben and Jerry ice cream, with a side of tears and hiccups. I personally love Valentines day. I think that you should go out and buy cards for everyone and their second cousin. It's such a cute holiday.", "I love valentine's day. Because this is a day for everyone to express their love. It doesn't only for couple. We can express our love for our parents, friends etc. In every valentine's day i'm bringing gift for my mom and my best friend. I always get gift from them. But love is not for one day. But many people thinks that it's just for a couple. but yes I think that it's very special for couple but it doesn't mean that its only create for couple. I had also a many special experience in this day. After all I really love this day.", 'Today is February 14. I am not mad with you if you forget this day. This is Valentine’s Day. I will not wait for tomorrow to meet you baby .this is very pink day. I would like to celebrate this day with you my love. This day for people is falling in love. I want you to stay near me baby to celebrate love. I want you every single minute. My heart is open for you every single minute baby. I cannot wait   to see you to come to celebrate love with you. This is a pink day for us.my heart is very hot not my love because you live inside the heart baby. Please coming baby.', 'I love Valentine’s Day. In this day people express more vividly all the love they feel for others. Yes, we might do this all the time but I think we need this day to do something different for that special person. People that say they do not like Valentine’s Day is because they might have had bad experiences. In my instance I have beautifully memories about the day of friendships and love. I am married. My wife is my first and unique love that I have had in my entire life. I love her with all my heart and I surprise her with many present all the time. I have had the most wonderful experiences at her side.', 'well I usually hear that lots people celebrate this day, but I see this day like other single day. I think that if someone really loves to other person, does not need to wait for this day to give a special gift or whatever he or she wants. I do not say that this day is bad, for me is good also but I think that not only today we can celebrate.', 'Oh Valentine’s Day! I remember when I was a teen how fun Valentine’s Day used to be.  In my school, we shared little handmade cards, lollipops and paper hearts. Come to my mind the image of a girl expecting too much of her future, wearing a red t-shirt and enjoying the day with her friends.', 'Valentine`s Day is an especial day for the lovers, they have the opportunity to celebrate and they have a good excuse to do something especial with their couple. There are some good and bad memories that everyone has especially for this date, because all of us always remember their first love, the unforgettable one and the worst one. My favorite thing to do for valentine`s day is given to my couple her favorite flowers and chocolates. Showing her that this day ends as others, the flowers do it too but the love will never ends.', "I don't like Valentine's Day because love is not only one day. It  makes people suffer more in their life. They show their love and affectoin for one day. This is hypocrisy.", 'Although love\'s day is everyday, we need one day to celebrate it. This is Valentine\'s Day. I like 50% and dislike 50%. Why? because we have focused more in a commercial day than love\'s day. Each love couple feel that this day is so special for them. Seven years ago, I wrote a song to a friend who liked me in that moment he he. It was so special to us. She was very happy and gave me a smile of her pretty lips. This date reminds me a song that says "I... waiting for supposed real love, I\'ve already been single six Febrary 14th" This is my story about Valentine\'s Day. I\'m wait for changes.', "i like Valentine's day because is a good or special moment to share with your girlfriend,wife or friendship. It's a good opportunity to demostrate or to say what a person feel for another person or other people. I like so much because the most people are or feel very happy in this day.", 'Well, I like Valentine’s Day because I always get gift from another person, and not only for that have I like Valentine ’s Day because it’s a day where everyone are in love and like to do something for their couple.', 'Yes, I like Valentine’s Day .I had a strongest memories in the past was my dad have given surprise to my mom by having dinner with her. That time she felt so happy because it reminded to her first date with a dad. A vegan cake is made without the enrichment of butter and eggs. With its lavishly decorated red velvet cake and cupcakes, Vegan Divas on the Upper East Side provides a satisfying Valentine’s Day delight with a new twist. For the reddish color, beets have replaced food coloring. Though the cake is not gluten-free, it is made with spelt, not wheat, flour.', 'Well, valentine’s day for me is like a common day because in my opinion if you want to express your love for someone you have to show her/him everyday not just one day I know is a special day and someone case this day can turn in a wonderful day, but another can be the worse day that they have ever had, anyway many people celebrate this day with very emotion but is up to everyone how celebrate this day and I think we should respect each one. And I have just one memory of valentine’s day was a beautiful day that I past and I will keep it in my memory.', 'Despite of being a commercial day, I like Valentine’s Day. I think that it is an especial day. We can smell the love in the air. This is the celebration of love and everything that shows love, for me is perfect. I don’t know anything about baking cake but I would like to know how make vegan red velvet cake. It looks great!', 'Actually we do not celebrate Valentine day in my country . I really surprised when i came to U.S.But i like the way how they celebrate .Its fun and  people some times need different way to express their feeling in different ways .', "Yes i like Valentine's day. Everyday was a Valentine's day for us, but one of my strongest memory about Valentine's day was when he asked me to marry him. he is everything you could want in a man, he does everything for me, without me asking.", "I think valentine's is a special day for people that understand nature around them in there life time. because, it's a day of love, unity,  togetherness  and have things in common for good.  when i was in high school, i used to share gift with my classmate at valentine's day. this refers to how much love we have for each other in our life time.", 'Valentine’s Day is a day for every friend and love that we have in our live. Our lives without love or friends it will be sad because without those things we will be people with full life of sadness. Love and friendship are important to all of us. In Valentine’s Day is the day when we have a special appreciation to all the people who make happier our lives. We need to remember that without love, we cannot be happy.', "yes i do like valentine's day because it is a day we celebrate love we share our feelings .Five years ago i say yes to my dream love that is my strongest memories.", 'In my opinion, this day is not only reserved for couples, but for everyone who professes love for other people, whether it’s family or friends. Valentine’s Day is the perfect excuse to show love and compassion in a world that needs it, only to forget, at least for a while, the hard reality we are forced to face sometimes.', 'I think Valentine’s Day is an important day for those who are in love whether it is with their lovers or with life on its own, it’s a cute way of going through the year and everything that comes with it. There are some people who don’t like it because the find it mean less or dumb or even unnecessary, I think it’s up to you and it is your decision. But still is a good thing.']
summary: Most people enjoy Valentine's Day. They consider it a great day to express their affections through food, gifts, and activities. A fair number of commentators treat Valentine's Day like any other day. A few commentators mention how it has been commercialized. One commentator goes on a rant about how single people suffer on that day. One other commentator posts song lyrics to a love song.
short_title: Headline: Valentine’s Day   Keywords:    Snippet: Do you like Valentine’s Day? What memorable things, good or bad, have happened to you on this day?
short_question: ['Valentine’s Day  ']

query: For 30 years, black travelers navigating the swamp of Jim Crow laws relied on guides to find safe places. Derrick Adams conjures their experiences in art.
comments: ['I obtained a copy of the Green Book 2 decades ago.  Fascinating.', "The first time I visited Washington, DC, as a white adult, I became aware of how difficult life was for black people in a supposedly northern city. Years later I discovered that cabs there were also segregated, and that black people couldn't just hail any cab. How far we have come; under Trump, how far we have to fall...", "It's interesting to consider this work and the guides that inspired it in the context of the NAACP's recent warnings to African Americans about traveling on American Airlines, which for many Blacks in the U.S., the Caribbean and Latin America had already been an open secret for years.", 'As an African-American traveling by motor vehicle across America we still have some issues.  If your family is in a late-model SUV, you will get pulled over on the interstate for a few "questions" i.e. "are you carrying drugs or large sums of cash?"  And it\'s not just in the Southland.', "I first learned of the Green Book recently from an episode of Mysteries At The Museum on The Travel Channel.  On the two car trips we made to Detroit in 1958 and 1964 we always took our own food.  However, on the way in 1964 we stopped at a restaurant called the Wagon Wheel.  My father went in to buy sandwiches for us to eat in the car, but they said they didn't do take out.  We went in, ate breakfast, and nobody bothered us.", 'As a child in Detroit in the early 1950s, I remember how the high schools were segregated. Some of the biggest race riots in the USA were in Detroit in the 1940s.', 'Fascinating... And a reminder that while times do change, people do not.', 'Thanks.  Very insightful.  btw - the book cover says "The Negro Traveler Green Book."', 'Thanks. Around 1952 Victor Green changed the name from "The Negro Motorist Green Book" to "The Negro Travelers Green Book" to reflect that travelers were also moving around by airplane and train.', 'See:  http://taylormadeculture.com/the-green-book/  for a comprehensive and powerful exploration of the Green Book. Candacy Taylor describes her project this way: "I have cataloged nearly 9,000 Green Book listings, scouted over 3,200 Green Book sites in 48 US States, and photographed over 150 Green Book properties. I have discovered that less than one-third of these sites are still standing and fewer than 5% are still in operation. The fact that we have these buildings as physical evidence of racial discrimination is a rich opportunity to re-examine America’s troubled history of segregation, black migration and the rise of the black leisure class. This extensive field research will be incorporated in my upcoming book, traveling exhibition, digital interactive map, board game, mobile app and virtual reality platform."', "I'm in love, Derrick Adams! All best wishes from Seattle. (Will someone please get over to this exhibit for me?)", "Facsimile editions of the Green Book are available on eBay for about $12-15 for the motorist or travel versions. It's somehow not the same as holding the real thing in your hands, but the books provide fascinating insights into the African-American experience.", "I have taught middle school students about the Green Book with this interactive learning activity:  https://tinyurl.com/yav3h2bt Can't wait to see this exhibit!", 'Notice that these books were still being published as late as a century after the Civil War.', "When I was a teenager, I was reading Lang's books of fairy tale (The Red book of fairy tales, the Blue book of fairy tales, etc.) and came across the Green Book in a used book store and thought it was a book of fairy tales (it was a edition from the 1930s and so had a green cover with scroll artwork).  Got it for a dime. Brought it home and found out it was a travel guide. Read it anyway.  For years and years I was the only person I knew who had ever heard of the Green books of motor travel.  Glad to see them get more widely known.  Thanks, Mike McUsic, for the information in your comment.", "When I was growing up in the 1960s and 70s, the car trips I took with my family were prefaced by a long consultation between my older male relatives( my grandfather and his brothers, older cousins) and my parents about which route to take from one destination to the next. It wasn't until I was well into adulthood that I realized the maps spread out on the table the night before a trip and the sober conversations that took place while poring over them, were not about so much about avoiding construction detours or traffic delays, but about avoiding the dangers of 'sun down towns,' about finding hospitable rest stops-- about my family's safe passage from one part of the country of our birth to another.", 'This makes me very sad. I’m sorry for your experience, blueveil77, and will remember your comment.', 'I have a 1952 Southeast US road guide which automatically assumes that travelers are white and, presumably, Christian. I suspect Jewish travelers—think "Gentlemen\'s Agreement"—had some of the same difficulties, but nothing like what you experienced.', "It's sad that these guides were ever needed at all.  I had never heard of the Green Books.  Beautiful work, Mr. Adams.  And please keep the information flowing to you readers, NYT.", 'Seconding Robin’s thoughts and feeling so sad that other humans had to endure the bigotry and discrimination of those times, recognizing it never seems to end but only ease a bit over decades.', 'Readers may also be interested in a digital humanities project by independent scholar, filmmaker, and documentarian, Candacy Taylor, whose Green Book project:  http://taylormadeculture.com/the-green-book/  is well worth exploring.', 'This is awesome, I had no clue.  Rare do I connect with modern or post-modern art...it is beautiful on its own and it is informative of something I knew nothing about.  Another barrier that I, as a white guy, just really hadn\'t thought about, and another enterprising way around, or through it, that I hadn\'t considered to be a part of the black American existence. Some days I think I overreact to "political correctness" and find myself in a reactionary, white, defensive position.  This reminds me that I really don\'t have the experience to even have an opinion much less an argument.  I haven\'t had to argue, or fight, for my way of life. Great profile.', 'The Green Book continues to be a source of inspiration and resilience as well as a reference point in history. We are all “Green Book Travelers” in our way. Our project collects stories and photos from Green Book Travelers. If you’d like to find a Green Book site near you, here’s a link: https://www.historypin.org/en/testtest-12/geo/36.224916,-95.553322,3/bou...', "--------- this should've been attached to mike's submission:  sjs Bridgeport, CT 1 day ago When I was a teenager, I was reading Lang's books of fairy tale (The Red book of fairy tales, the Blue book of fairy tales, etc.) and came across the Green Book in a used book store and thought it was a book of fairy tales (it was a edition from the 1930s and so had a green cover with scroll artwork). Got it for a dime. Brought it home and found out it was a travel guide. Read it anyway. For years and years I was the only person I knew who had ever heard of the Green books of motor travel. Glad to see them get more widely known. Thanks, Mike McUsic, for the information in your comment. Reply 6Recommend", 'Fantastic work, fantastic article. It is terribly important to keep alive information about what life was like in America before the victories of the civil rights movement so that we always remember how tenuous Freedom and Equality can be. Those who speak of making America great again ignore the full color spectrum of America.', 'This article is extremely informative. Most white people have no idea about the Green Books. How did we not know until now? Also beautifully written. Thank you NYT.', "Facsimile editions of the Green Book are available on eBay for about $12-15 for the motorist or travel versions. It's somehow not the same as holding the real thing in your hands, but the books provide fascinating insights into the African-American experience."]
summary: Many of the users praise the book the article is describing as historical and helpful in understanding how the past was for African Americans. Two self-identified white readers lament that they had no clue the author faced such hardships when traveling as a Black person. A few commenters talk about discrimination Blacks still face when traveling and how they used to have to strategize how to travel as Black people to avoid "sun down towns" where Black people were likely to get attacked at night.
short_title: Headline: Of Guidebooks to the American Dream   Keywords: Adams, Derrick (Artist); Art; Museum of Arts and Design; Travel and Vacations; Blacks   Snippet: For 30 years, black travelers navigating the swamp of Jim Crow laws relied on guides to find safe places. Derrick Adams conjures their experiences in art.
subreddit: ['Adams, Derrick (Artist)', 'Art', 'Museum of Arts and Design', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Blacks']
short_question: ['Of Guidebooks to the American Dream  ']

query: Monday: Seder table conversation, spring recess activities, and urban mysteries.
comments: ["What's the deal with egg?  Is it preserved?", 'An egg is an age-old symbol of spring. Hens lay fewer eggs during the winter darkness (they may stop laying altogether) and resume in the increasing daylight of spring. Other religions with a spring holiday also use this symbolism...', "Yes. The young man who said 'hunger' got it right because it encompasses the entire message.", "As this Asian-American understands Passover, the plagues manifested God's wrath at the enslavement and oppression of people -- terrible, divine social justice -- targeting the oppressor and the machinery of oppression.  At Passover, I remember that coming to America, my family was liberated from dictator Park Chung Hee. Associating the death of the first born to the horror visited upon the Syrian people confuses me.  The powers that be do not suffer this plague.  Instead it visits those who have been oppressed by an authoritarian regime.  And even more confusingly, that autocrat had suppressed religious conflict.  So my Christian friends from that area bemoan the pursuit of democracy at the cost of the safety of their families. Instead of plagues, perhaps we should spend more time thinking about the modern forms of human bondage and focus our wrath on the inequalities that put people on the street and trafficks in sexual and labor slavery.  We might consider the bondage of ideologies that threaten to leave millions more Americans without healthcare and make the bonds between plutocrats stronger than compassion for those without wealth or work to earn a living.  And we might take on the religious dogmatism that uses past suffering as a shield to deflect criticism for violence, rejecting the more fundamental call of the faithful to compassion. Then, using the righteousness of our arguments, actions, and protests, set all people free, to defend peace in a more just future.", 'POP UPS -a virulent plague. Moses where art thou?', 'Thank you for sharing this. So very true. Blessed Passover, to our Jewish communities!', "“Darkness, the ninth plague, continues to envelop us,” said Yona Shem-Tov,....  I'm for darkness,", "You don't need a Seder to know there are plagues. That said. L' Shana Tovah.", 'I was hoping that New York Today would list some activities open to non-Jews who wish to learn more about Passover.  I believe that there are some Seders open to the public. Maybe next year.', 'In Jerusalem or not.', "Shem Tov 'S comment in the article is a good one.", 'It\'s worth noting that there is no historical evidence that the Jews were ever enslaved in Egypt much less that any of those plagues happened, that Moses parted the Red Sea, or that he got 10 or any other number of commandments from a deity.  There may have been some true events that suggested these but these had scientific explanations and ignoring them for some hocus pocus is like ignoring scientific explanations for global warming In the immortal words of the now disappeared KellyAnn Conway, the Haggadah is filled with "alternative facts."', "What's your opinion of the Easter Bunny?", 'I agree with everything LeslSmore says with one small correction. The Hebrew for Jesus is Yeshua; whereas, Joshua in hebrew is Yehoshua', "LeslSmore: I didn't get the impression that Steve was excluding Christianity, or the myths and traditions of any other religion. I have to admit, I've never actually thought about Passover as a myth. I'm glad Steve made the point, although comparing Judaism to Kellyanne Conway is a Schande!", '"Nearly two dozen graffiti artists are suing the landlord of a Queens complex, hoping to establish street art as worthy of protection." In what universe are we living when vandalism becomes a protected activity? Yes, I know that things are not going well. Citizens United upended what we thought was the proper order of things (i.e., corporations are not people); Donald Trump\'s becoming president of the United States has blown the mind of any New Yorker who has kept even loose track of his coarse shenanigans over the years; and spring arrives increasingly early because February thaws last far longer than ever before.  I am not resigned to the vandalism of our politics and of our environment by the powers that be. Not in the least.       But the mindless scrawling on building walls, roofs, and subway platforms all over the city is really another assault on us all. It affects our walks to work and the views from our homes: concrete evidence of the breakdown in how we treat one another.', "Right on, B. Graffiti may be art, but it doesn't belong on building exteriors. Else the architects would have put it there. Graffiti as art should go where other art goes: on canvas or paper on gallery walls.", 'Islanders nuclear option Senators', 'Undoubtedly, the greatest plague we face today as a society is authoritarian "progressive" philosophies.  The left will be our undoing.', 'Trump Breitbart and Bannon Fox "News" NRA McConnell and the Nuclear option Koch Bros Dark money xenophobia ISIS Limbaugh, Beck and O\'Reilly', 'blood, frogs, lice, flies, pestilence, boils...sounds like some present day third world countries.  What makes you think people didn\'t have such things on a day to day basis back then? as to street art, OMG not this again.  In the 60s people wanted to leave the graffiti on the subway cars as "urban art". Let\'s not set that precedent again. It\'s childish and ugly.', "Diet rules and the accompanying guilt that goes with. And the endless plague of weight management. And yes, I'm a dietitian.", "Today's plague, IMHO, is GUNS, those who own them, purchase them, use them and defend them.", 'Trump, Bannon, Flynn, DeVos, Manafort, Sessions, Spicer, Greed, Big Money, Xenophobia.', 'How exactly is that relevant?', 'anonymous ~  Plagues do you read the article??', 'Elias Kirshner understands something that many adults have yet to grasp.', 'You start the article off with a phrase from Israeli Hebrew.  Except for the thousands of Israelis living here, few American Jews would understand this sentence. Older Jews and many orthodox ( a rapidly growing community in the NYC region) know at least enough Yiddish to recognize, A gut morgn alemen. Anyway, a great pesakh ( Passover) to everyone. I enjoyed this piece. Thanks.', 'Full marks to Allison Costine who nailed the modern plague question. Shalom', "A very very light testament to the (intentionally?) sillier of the modern plague choices.    Tune of Hey There Seder! You with new plagues on your mind What things today seem cruel to you? What odd things will you find? Seder! People who walk while they text? Spring days that seem too cold to you? Or grammar that's uncontrolled to you? Have some cha-ro-ses Apples chopped up with red wine Mix it up with those bitter herbs See, now those herbs taste fine.   Whether you cook yourself or get someone to cater Just have a cup of wine and repeat. Then recline way back in your seat And then please don't forget to tweet About your seder."]
summary: The commenters mostly focus on the article's depiction of current-day problems as similar to those in the bible (like hail being climate change and locusts being mosquitoes with Zika), with some agreeing, some calling it silly, and one writing about how none of it really happened, Jews were never enslaved in Egypt, etc. One person focuses on the vandalism mentioned in the article, calling it ridiculous that people are trying to get street art recognized as a protected activity. Others comment on plagues they think are going on now, and one user wishes the article was more focused on the holiday itself.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: Passover, and Our Everyday Plagues   Keywords: New York City   Snippet: Monday: Seder table conversation, spring recess activities, and urban mysteries.
short_question: ['New York Today: Passover, and Our Everyday Plagues  ']

query: Eugene Richards will have his first retrospective exhibit at the George Eastman Museum in Rochester, spanning over 45 years of work.
comments: ["Took Eugene's course at Maine Photographic Workshop a hundred years ago. Been photographing ever since with his teachings in mind. Followed his career religiously. He just can't be beat both as a photographic and a human being. Congratulations on your new exhibitions!", "Gene Richards thinking that his writing might not be good enough reminds me that Eric Clapton was early on in his career absolutely convinced that he couldn't sing. The text Richards wrote for Red Ball of A Sun may even be better than the photographs, and the photographs are quite outstanding. There are few, if any, other photographers working today who so obviously care more about the people in their images, and the struggles of those people, than they care about the images themselves.", 'They don\'t come any better than Eugene Richards. The whole debate about the "art thing" is as old as photography itself. It\'s too bad photographers have to deal with it, but gallery owners and museum curators are rarely in a position to break with the tradition of their business or institution. I\'m glad Mr. Richards is having a retrospective and receiving the recognition he deserves.', 'I have met Mr. Richards three times in my life; twice in Maine and once at Ohio University, in Athens, Ohio.  I have always been mesmerized by his work and sense of moment. The roughness is one of the main aspects because the subjects he covers demand it.  I also wrote my only fan letter to him and he answered. I thought that very respectful. You deserve this show.', 'I remember being in the Soho Photo Gallery on 13th Street in the early 1970s when Richards came in with a copy of "Few Comforts and Surprises" along with some of the original prints from the book one of which was the "doll\'s head".  My recollection is that the gallery declined to show them.  I left the gallery, bought the book, and let my membership lapse.', 'Great interview and some keen insights.  I was particularly impressed with his view that photographs are memories.  Simple and yet overlooked by a lot of photographers.   The other thing that impressed me, because I and many others are the same way, was his description about memory of things and yet being able to be very precise about the feelings when taking the photos.  I can instantly recall almost everything about the person, place or thing, the timing, the weather, all of it.  And yet I have to seriously think of what my phone number or address is.   And his photos are stunning.', 'One of the most salient photographers, and most productive as well.  Glad he is getting this nod, love the work Eugene!', "What a dedicated artist to sift so openly through his doubts.  It's in the mix where his strength lies.  A brilliant professional, an honest life.  How much he's achieved!", "These are amazing, simply amazing images. The photos of the girl with the doll's head, the mother and her son, and the pastor and his wife all resonate with care and humanity.", 'Remember his images on the walls at Ashmont Station in Dorchester (boston) - loved them.', 'I met Mr. Richards at the Bronx Documentary Center and was amazed by his warmth and humility. If his sensitive photography is "rough and more emotional" than art photography today, it is also a more powerful reflection of his unique vision.', "I'm just stunned by these images. I went to your web site and couldn't stop looking. Yes, you belong in museums."]
summary: Most commenters admire Eugene Richards' photography, finding it both stunning and admiring while also reflective of powerful memories. They are proud that his work is getting the recognition it deserves. Several commenters reminisce on when they met Richards, and one commenter describes Eugene as caring deeply about the people he photographs.
short_title: Headline:    Keywords: Photography; Richards, Eugene   Snippet: Eugene Richards will have his first retrospective exhibit at the George Eastman Museum in Rochester, spanning over 45 years of work.

query: The league weighs, measures and pokes its aspiring employees, whose medical histories and genes are analyzed as if they were Wagyu cattle.
comments: ["As a resident of a former slave state and Tuscaloosa, home of the Crimson Tide, I must admit that a one-time viewing of combine activities, especially the measuring of candidates on stage, struck me as the modern equivalent of what a slave auction must have looked like. The color of most athletes' skin contributed to this feeling. While I realize the athletes who submit to this treatment have big, life enhancing paychecks in mind, the parallels are disturbing. Thanks to Powell for describing in gruesome detail the rest of the story.", "There are a minority of players who chose to skip the scouting combine and the NFL Draft party, and still play in the league.   A player has more volition than this article presents. If you have excelled at the college level, you may simply have the NFL scouts and coaches come to your school on a pro day, and go through some rudimentary drills like the 40 yard dash.  No colonoscopy required.   Almost every Division l university has a pro day.   Then on draft day you may wait for your phone to ring wherever you wish to be. It's a risk.   You may not get as much money if you are not selected on the first or second day of the draft.   However, it's not as big a risk now as draft picks have their money limited by the latest collective bargaining agreement.   The really big money comes in free agency after the initial contract.   (Ironically, it is sometimes better for a player not to be drafted in the late rounds, because as a free agent competing teams bid up the money for the player's services.) These guys go to the scouting combine on their own free will.   Is it a bit impersonal?   Yeah.   But they want to enhance their chances of making it as  a professional. I would say the exploitation of players at the college level by coaches and athletic directors receiving millions is a much bigger scandal.", "Football has a free training system of junior leagues, high schools and colleges. The NFL has failed to protect players from deadly head injury and it is well documented that they even employed shill medical professionals to attempt to discredit Doctors who discovered chronic traumatic encephalitis of the brain and its causes. From early on these boys and men are used solely for their athletic potential and prowess. As quickly as that ability fades or crashes, the NFL and colleges jettison them.  There is no doubt that they are treated as commodities and that the NFL shows no common decency or humanity in treating them as such.  Attend a stock trading show and you will see so many parallels to the 'combine' that it will sicken you. The NFL represents the worst instincts of our society and of business interest in the way it conducts it's business with players. And other sports are following suit.  As it trickles down to youth soccer programs, little league baseball and many other activities, it infects a society with a joy draining manic push for generations of young people.  If you watch the NFL, pay for the swag and promote it with your interest, you are part of the problem.", "Stupid article. No one is forced to play pro football. All the the screening is vital to the organizations that are about to commit 10s of millions of dollars that can't be taken back as sign up bonuses and guaranteed payments to 22ish, high T young men who may or may not actually make their team, be quickly injured and unable to perform, or just lose all motivation when becoming overnight multi millionaires. Given that environment the teams try to cover their bets as best they can. The measurements and tests are agreed to by all and enthusiastically undertaken by the candidates who are potentially set up financially for life by the results. They celebrate the results! Criticize football for violence, potential permanent damage to participants, twisted values, whatever, but get off the politically correct, rights angle.", 'Great article, poor conclusion.  That the cynic sees these young men as modern day gladiators, primed by their teams to prepare for the Sunday at the coliseum in front of the mob is not that far from reality, with the disclosure that head injuries are a byproduct of the NFL. Five years ago, watching college football, it dawned on me that the epidemic of piling on by the defense was rampant, and had to lead to more running back injuries that necessary to have a real football game.  Now we have a state of denial by all things football, but the league is worth $50 billion dollars and owned by essentially 32 partners.  Television has aided and abetted all of this, making more billions from the gladiators on the field.', 'This story should be told, but is anyone surprised in the least? Players are just interchangeable bodies with varying capabilities and capacity.', 'The author is clueless.  Anyone with any economic common sense would understand that the current process maximizes the utility function of both the potential employer and employee.  No one is entering into this relationship against their will.', "gee, what oppression. men in their early 20's blessed with athletic abilities after 3-4 years of college get to to earn more money in 2-3 years than doctors make over their entire lifetime after going to school and training for 10 years are turned into instant celebrities and never have to pick up a check again. 99% of the public would trade places with them in a moment. The author should be sacked for taking this tone in his article.", 'Shame on the media for the coverage of this manufactured event (I am not referring to this article).   As much fun as football is to watch, in the end it is an inhuman meat grinder. Says something about us.  Better to devote the ink to baseball.', "If it's degrading to the players, then they don't have to do it.  It makes sense before a team invests millions that the players are healthy, not on drugs, and reasonably sane/intelligent.  Most employers don't make physicals part of the interview process, but most jobs are behind desks, not smashing up against the roughest, toughest group of people in the US outside of prison or the army.  It's just a debutante ball for young men.", 'I visited the slave market in Charleston, S.C., it closed over a hundred and fifty years ago, or did it?', "Maybe not, but the NFL draft is not a nightmare to a young man like slavery in the U.S. was, it's a dream realized.  Big, big difference.", 'The dream ends between 22 and 40 years old. Then the crippling  pain begins. But , hey, did you see that touchdown?', 'Thank you for really telling it like it is and exposing this sham.', 'They are treated as pieces of meat, but all "human resources" are treated the same way.   Most of us get a lot less money for being a "resource" why paying tax dollars to give NFL owners new stadia.', 'I dream of the day I am poked and prodded before being paid millions of dollars for doing something I love.', "the problem isn't in the doing...the problem is in the remembering what you did when you reach your early forties...the problem is in not being able to lift your daughter over your head with her laughing in joy... the problem is in being kicked out of your home for battering your wife in a rage and not remembering why...the problem is in dying alone, homeless in an old truck in an abandoned  Pittsburgh  lot...", "Michael Powell requires a stiff drink tonight. Our farmhouse is dry. We delivered 10 of our best to slaughter this morning. A top flight college asked. Tomorrow the ten will be cooling on a hook awaiting the cut room on Monday.  NFL prospects will not be cooling. The battering coming that will leave their meat bruised and unsalable. Our beef is fed only grass. None of that GrassFed GrainFinished stuff - with tetracycline in the water to address illnesses imagined or real and spur fat. We read of the Blaser MicroBiome. Missing Microbes. Ours take 28-30 months. With tetra and grain, it's white fat and 12. And Marty says illnesses spreading. Martin J. Blaser MD, NYU.  The NFL linebackers and linemen are an old story. Beef eaters. The QB is well paid and protected and valued. Expected life of a lineman? Don't ask. No chance of an injury free career in NFL football.  NFL head injuries? Of course. And Joe Louis? Casius Clay? Dozens are beaten to a pulp. Parkinson's is but one. The gladiator society. We want our meat rare and fast. Tenderizer can soften up the worst of it. Who cares what's in it?  Ty Cobb filed his spikes. Bean balls hit cotton caps. Players hurt. Soup bone the term used for the arm of an aging pitcher. Walter Big Train Johnson pitched a Double Header. 18 innings.  And Michael Powell?  He may be the best investigative reporter writing at The New York Times.  For Powell to cover this butchery is butchery itself.  Honestly, who is surprised. Who cares?"]
summary: Numerous commentators say that NFL players are treated like pieces of meat and are more comparable to slaves and gladiators than humans. Several commenters say that the article is stupid, whether it's for its comparison of the NFL to slavery or that everyone already knows about it. A few commentators focus on the high pay of players, saying that comparison to slavery is foolish. One commentator remarks that some players escape the scouting routine and make it in the NFL.
short_title: Headline: You’re No. 1 (2, 3, 4, 5, 6 ... )   Keywords: Football; Draft and Recruitment (Sports); National Football League   Snippet: The league weighs, measures and pokes its aspiring employees, whose medical histories and genes are analyzed as if they were Wagyu cattle.

query: Groups asked to ban chlorpyrifos from food within 30 days if the Environmental Protection Agency cannot prove it is safe.
comments: ["In Canada where we understand and respect laws about poisons in our food, because of our colder climate we import fruit from the US.  Now that we can no longer depend on the US to send us clean and unpoisoned fruit, can we please get a list of all the companies who use chemicals like this, so that we can read these chemicals' names on the boxes of strawberries so we can NOT buy them? I hope those  Republican families who voted for this idiotic and ignorant so-called government come to their senses and do something about this dope and his stooges.", 'While our children get sick, Dow Chemical, golf course lobbyists and Big Food get rich. Sounds like a typical Trump plan to me!', 'Another reason to join the DC and local marches for Science (April 22) + our Climate (April 29). Need a seat on a bus? Many groups provide them with sliding scale tickets. One is:  newyork.peoplesclimate.org', "Our present government now sheds tears over the children of the mideast. We all shed tears, as we should and must. What else can we do? But what about the children here in our own country? We seem willing to poison them with pesticides...for profit.  The article says that children are exposed to 140 times the safe levels. What happens to these children? Are there photographs? What might touch our hearts here? Roundup or similar has been in most of the country's garages and on their lawns for decades. Our children (and of course we ourselves and our spouses and parents and friends) eat apples and also oranges sprayed with chlorpyrifos: what happens to us? Can you post photographs that might reach our president and our present head of the E.P.A?", "And then these poisoned American children's families will have to use their almost non-existent health care at huge cost to them, and probably have to buy medications to counteract these chemicals' effects.  What is Pruitt thinking?   Let HIM eat the berries.", 'Further endangering our water supply with these contaminants is asking for more problems in how children learn. Children are the target group that is more susceptible to these neurological affects from chlorpyrifos. Since King Trump does not care about his children, evident by the strangeness and distant relationship he has with them, he cares not for other children. It is in the water is no joke. Flint Michigan children are dealing with lead. If we value our future generation, we need to put a stop to this immediately and boycott these foods from farmers who use this pesticide.', "Clearly, sensible regulation of this pesticide will not be driven by science or even a sensible policy process, given current national and EPA leadership. Unless these noble advocates for a chlorpyrifos ban similar to the EU's can make the producers of the crops upon which it is used sacrifice financially for their choices, nothing will happen for the foreseeable future. As witnessed with Trump's tarnished electoral victory, progress on issues like this cannot be made only by debate among elites, but may be advanced through a climate of public fear. A sustained broad- and fact-based sharing of information about where such pesticides are used would be a good start. Thanks to the NYT for giving the dialogue momentum.", 'Another view of EPA and chlorpyrifos -- one that is not driven by the misrepresentations of radical NGOs:  http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/energy-environment/321764-epa-pest...', "A huge shout out of gratitude to these representatives listed who are working so diligently behind the scenes on our (the consumers) behalf to ban these two extremely toxic and overused agricultural chemical compounds from wide industrial system use.   I can't imagine however,  that by our erroneous electing of a billionaire, golf course building proponent such that the Trump family is,  they will be successful but,  nonetheless,  I am with them 100%.   Keep up the good work.", 'One should perhaps note that chlorpyrifos was banned in the EU with effect only last year.  The EU authorities operate under much more stringent rules than does the US.  So this delay is hardly egregious.  More generally: 1) Environmental groups are demanding the product be "proved safe."  Under general toxicological guidelines, it is difficult to "prove" that water, salt, or sugar are "safe."  Ditto many of our food products. 2) In the final paragraph, the ag industry is accused of "political meddling."  Since the environmental lobby does not sponsor or conduct the very expensive toxicological tests or review, one could say that they bring nothing objective to the table.  Their entire posture is, in fact, "political meddling." Disclaimer: I was in ag chem research for ~25 years, in a position to see both sides of this issue.', 'Mr. Pruitt, I recommend that you switch to a more healthful diet full of apples, oranges, strawberries, broccoli, almonds, walnuts, cherries, peaches, pears, corn and wheat.', "I wonder if he eats organic, or the food sprayed by all the pesticides he's deemed are safe for consumption?", 'Good luck and thanks to those public interest groups fighting in the courts. We can also fight for regulation at the local level. Public land managers are increasing the use of pesticides in parks. They are doing this with taxpayer money. People can organize to fight this  locally and demand a no pesticide policy.', "Wow, there already was a decade-old pending federal court case that had issued an order to the EPA to rule upon the petition to ban chlorpyrifos by the end of March? And newly appointed EPA Sec. Pruitt just brushed off the issue with a blanket, undetailed denial? These folks don't have much respect for the courts, judicial process, or even law.  Sad!  (Actually, tragic for our country.)", 'AMEN ! ~ Our children and farm workers are expendable. And- who needs Science anyway ??', "When did Scott Pruitt, head of the E.P.A., and the Republicans ever get the idea that the environment is a platform for the denial of science or for the outright destruction of the natural world and high-risk policies involving chemical agents of whatever stripe is justifiable? We are the environment and it is us; when we poison it, we poison ourselves.  Oh, darn, I forgot the politics of self-immolation. Profits first, planet second. I'm sure the grandkids will love us for it.", 'They are all indebted (literally) to the Kochtapus.  Read "Dark Money" by Jane Mayer--a very important work.  Trump\'s interests overlap but are not entirely equal.  Lots of very, very wealthy, powerful connected people have various agendas (and it\'s all about money and power and *not* about the good of America or it\'s citizens).', 'This obviously political decision exemplifies the Trump administration\'s approach to everything: deny science, ignore the vulnerable (which is almost everybody), and pile up the benefits to anyone contributing to their interests. Our vocabulary is being tested: "despicable" and "shameful" and "appalling" are used with such regularity that they don\'t seem adequate. All these chemical neurotoxins and endocrine disrupters have been demonstrated conclusively to harm people and other elements in our complex intertwined ecosystem. Along with other horrifying legacies such as the melting of Arctic ice and inundation of coastal areas, the wanton use of such chemicals in OUR FOOD is going to seem absurd if there are any humans left to contemplate the twentieth and twenty-first centuries', 'Thank you NYT for doing stories like this. Food safety in a country of mass produced food is vitally important and consumers will care.', 'The science has been in for some time.  We now know that some organophosphate pesticides like Chlorpyrifos are exceptionally toxic to fetal brain development. In California’s agricultural Central Valley, for example, mothers in the highest fifth of organophosphate exposure had children with an alarming IQ deficit of 7 points compared to the lowest fifth. These same women were only about twice as exposed to organophosphates as the rest of the country.  This IQ damage is larger than current childhood exposures from lead. We should have banned lead far sooner than we did. Let’s not feel the same way twenty years from now about Chlorpyrifos.', 'That is some back breaking work.  The people doing the work and/or their representatives should be listened to, also.', 'Forget everything else for today. The most important thing today - Thursday, April 6, 2017 - is that the traitor Senator Mitch McConnell plans to change OUR United States Senate rules so his bare majority Koch brothers/ Russian-backed buddies can put an EXTREME CONSERVATIVE on OUR United States Supreme Court.  The nominee will do all he can to OVERTURN ROE V WADE and will take America one step closer to being a RADICAL CHRISTIAN nation by further eradicating Separation of Church and State. WE MUST NOT LET THEM GET AWAY WITH IT.  It is time for #US TRAITOR SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL - NO GORSUCH -  to be sent to him, Chuck Grassley, John McCain and every other "conservative" Senator and traitorous Democrats who intend to vote for the nominee. WE must also call, e-mail, show up in person and RESIST and OBSTRUCT in every way - TODAY!!! Only WE - THE PEOPLE can save democracy in America.  LET\'S DO IT!!', "I guess Pruitt's kids are not going to be exposed to this poison, so why should he care?", "I think we'd all be more assured of it's safety if, say, a large quantity of the chemical made it's way into the drinking water of Congress...", "Pruitt's kids are never going to eat apples, oranges, strawberries, broccoli, almonds, walnuts, cherries, peaches, pears, corn or wheat?  Does he not have kids? Even if his kids are grown, they could endanger kids they may themselves have.    Like many members of the Trump cabinet, Pruitt is only determined to further policies that are contrary to expert consensus or any public good, if they enhance corporate profits, and thus further his own career, without regard even to his own family. That is pure viciousness, which seems to be the primary requirement for a Trump appointee."]
summary: Commenters agree on the relevance of the piece. Others lament the tragedy of allowing poisonous chemicals because of their profit. Several harshly criticize Pruitt's response to the issue and also cast significant blame on the Trump administration. In apparent support of democracy in the USA, another interjects, saying that if it is of great importance that McConnel wants to change the Senate rules.
short_title: Headline: Groups Seek Court’s Aid in Banning a Pesticide   Keywords: Pesticides; Water Pollution; Fruit; United States Politics and Government; Environmental Protection Agency; Dow Chemical Company; Earthjustice   Snippet: Groups asked to ban chlorpyrifos from food within 30 days if the Environmental Protection Agency cannot prove it is safe.
