short_question: ['Groups Seek Court’s Aid in Banning a Pesticide  ']

query: This month’s spotlight is on constructor Patrick Berry.
comments: ['It is funny to hear Mr. Berry say that cluing is a tedious process.  His cluing ability is other-worldly.  Witty, subtle, but after you get it, you realize the clue was always fair.  My favorite constructor, themed or themeless.', 'I love this feature! Would be great to see a profile on David Kahn!', "You created Rows Garden?! That's my favorite puzzle and the sole reason I subscribe to Games. I wish you'd do one for the Sunday NYT. So much fun, so challenging... but mostly so much fun!", "I'll join in the chorus praising Berry. Long my favvorite constructor, I feel like I'm in good hands when I'm working on a Berry puzzle.", 'I’ve tried to find out more about PB in rhe past because I love his puzzles and am glad to have this feature. PB always seems ro have fresh clues and so I’m surprised he doesn’t like writing them! His puzzles are seemingly effortless - I don’t ever recall him using weak fill ro squeeze in a clever word. And glad to know he is nearly a neighbor! Come see us in the ATL!', 'Patrick Berry is simply the best; take it from one who has not missed a NY Times Crossword in over 30 yearsI don’t look at the creator before I start', "Sorry, the above was sent before I completed it.  I can generally tell when I’m working on a PB puzzle when I get halfway through it.  His style is unique and his clues are always so precise and clever.  Sometimes puzzles are tedious but never his.  As I said above, he's simply the best.", "Although a mere dilettante, I'm continually grateful for Mr. Berry's variety puzzles. His NYT crosswords, of course, are nonpareil.", 'Thank you for introducing this new feature.  I always want to know more about individual constructors, and Patrick Berry has long been a favorite of mine.  I am eager to read his handbook on construction.', 'What crossword construction software is recommended for Mac?', "Hi Sharon, I've used Crossfire, by Beekeeper Labs:  http://beekeeperlabs.com/crossfire/ Also, if you are on Facebook and would like to learn more about the art of constructing, I highly encourage you to join the Puzzle Collaboration Directory group, which matches aspiring constructors to veterans who can help them learn the ropes:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/1515117638602016/", 'Thank you, Deb!', "Very interesting to learn about the process of puzzle construction. I'll bet there are as many different approaches as there are constructors. This is a great feature and I look forward to meeting more of the personalities behind the puzzles we enjoy.", 'Excellent profile - equally entertaining to fans and prospective constructors alike. I look forward to future ones.', 'Thanks for the photo of Patrick Berry!  He is my favorite and best crossword puzzle constructionist to date.', 'Patrick Berry rocks.', 'I purchased Patrick\'s "Constructor\'s Handbook" about a yer ago when I started dabbling in puzzle-making. I must say it\'s an excellent resource; I find myself going back to it time after time. And the puzzles that come with it are awesome! Thanks, Patrick, for writing such an invaluable book!', "It goes without saying that I'm a big PB fan. I had been reviewing his puzzles in detail recently. One thing that jumped out at me was that he hasn't had a 15 letter entry in a non-Sunday puzzle in almost four and a half years (that's his last 36 daily puzzles).  Recently he's done a lot of central staggered-stacks. 13, 11 and 10 letters being the most common. There has to be a reason for that change in focus. I don't suppose there's any chance he'd come back and comment on that.", 'Nice new feature.  I am looking forward to many more.', "I have often thought that it must be harder to construct a puzzle than to solve one.  I'm delighted to meet the ingenious and creative puzzle constructors who have given me so much pleasure (and pain)!", 'This is a great new feature! Thank you so much!']
summary: Most commenters can agree that Patrick Berry is one of the most talented puzzle constructors. They praise his unique and challenging style. Some of them speak highly of his handbook, and others are eager to read it. Everyone is happy with the new feature, and others state their eagerness to read the next ones.
short_title: Headline: Who Made My Puzzle?: Patrick Berry   Keywords: Berry, Patrick; Crossword Puzzles; Puzzles   Snippet: This month’s spotlight is on constructor Patrick Berry.
short_question: ['Who Made My Puzzle?: Patrick Berry  ']

query: The top-rated Manhattan restaurant will close for three months of renovation and open a more casual version in the Hamptons.
comments: ["My wife and I had a memorable meal here - but it didn't have the stuffiness of a restaurant just voted #8 in the world - here are some of the dishes we had -  https://johnrieber.com/2016/05/16/eleven-madison-park-worlds-best-restau...", 'They can now offer a 64 course tasting to the hedge fund Hamptonites', "EMP used to be my favorite restaurant, back when Danny Meyer owned it and Daniel Humm was just beginning to make his mark. Like most Meyer restaurants, EMP was intended to be the kind of place that you went back regularly to. While it's never been cheap, it wasn't horribly expensive (lunch was a steal at $28). The last time I went was 5+ years ago, when EMP had just changed hands, and it was clear that the Danny Meyer touch - that mix of friendliness, efficiency and the feeling that the restaurant was emphatically of its neighborhood - was fading. I could sense the transition into a THREE STAR MICHELIN restaurant beginning. Humm is an insanely talented chef, and his success is warranted, but I miss the old EMP. BTW, that $28 lunch included one of the best lamb dishes I have ever eaten (I think it was called lamb 3 ways, with three different cuts of meat in the most flavorful broth I have ever eaten). Oh well, all flesh is grass...", "Please, don't bring the pig's bladder.", "I also have to admit that I don't feel the vast amounts of critical praise for this place are justified. Been there twice, both times just seemed like staff was going through the motions. It was good, no question about that, but there are a lot more exciting options in and below this price point", 'Just remember, at either place, if you have to ask the price, you can\'t afford it. I\'m not impugning the owners at all.  Just pointing out that we\'re back to Reagan\'s "Greed is good", led by the greediest one of all.', 'I wonder how many of the patrons each week are from out of town?', 'Eleven Madison Park remains the most overrated restaurant I have ever eaten at. The service was rude and the food was meh. I was even told that I had to straighten my seat out to align w the table. PB', 'There are farmers/vintners on the East End raising/growing quality animals, produce and grapes.  A slew of products within a 30 mile radius for EMP to take advantage of. http://www.edibleeastend.com/2012/08/01/long-islands-livestock/', 'Sounds different from the NYT review of March 2015. That piece pilloried EMP. https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/18/dining/restaurant-review-eleven-madis...', 'As our industry matures, it is great to hear American restaurateurs taking care of their staff as they take care of their businesses. Congratulations on an exciting plan', 'Actually that is pretty common out east for seasonal f&b operations.  A lot of places rent large houses where the staff lives Real World style together.  Most charge the staff rent and act as the "landlord" to keep liability down.', "There's always Riverhead.", 'they rented multiple houses for their employees actually', "Although not a New Yorker, I applaud the owners' decision to move to the more pleasant and estival atmosphere out of town. To hope, there will be umbrellas to provide shade to the clients and the incorrigible smokers will be able to persevere in their addiction outdoors."]
summary: Many commenters think that the article's restaurant is overrated and doesn't deserve the vast amounts of critical praise it receives since it has rude service and just decent food. One commenter thinks that the restaurant has gone downhill because it changed ownership. On the other hand, a couple of commenters are excited that the restaurant is taking a new direction to move out to the Hamptons.
short_title: Headline: Eleven Madison Park Goes to the Beach   Keywords: Restaurants; Relocation of Business; Eleven Madison Park (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant); Guidara, Will; Humm, Daniel; East Hampton (NY); Manhattan (NYC); Cloepfil, Brad   Snippet: The top-rated Manhattan restaurant will close for three months of renovation and open a more casual version in the Hamptons.
subreddit: ['Restaurants', 'Relocation of Business', 'Eleven Madison Park (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant)', 'Guidara, Will', 'Humm, Daniel', 'East Hampton (NY)', 'Manhattan (NYC)', 'Cloepfil, Brad']
short_question: ['Eleven Madison Park Goes to the Beach  ']

query: What trade offs do you make to pay for what you need and want, now and in the future?
comments: ["It is best to save money instead of spend it right away. Whenever I get cash in my hands, the first thing I do is put it in a bank account. Lots of people these days don't understand that emergencies can happen, and you never know when you will need money to back you up.", "I like this reading especially when the author talks about some particular stories about people life. On of the stories that really impressed me is that, when the author talks about single mother Natalie Davis. She actually sacrifices all of her life only for her children. I don't think it's easy to work less and handle the whole family budget as a single mother,but she show us. Even\u200b thought money is important to fulfill our desire but family time is more important then that. For me I think we all should balance our time for work and family. Also we should choose the work we like the most not the work that only fulfill our unnecessary demand.", 'Money is a peculiar thing that life seems to be focused around. Everyone wants to earn money because it drives the world. Without making money it is difficult to live well. People need money to buy things to fulfill both necessity and desirable. People have many ways of making money but it depends on what way they choose to earn that money. They make money to live a better and secure life in the future. For that reason, people ignore their family sometimes. To me family is more important than making money. I think it’s not right to earn money while ignoring one’s family. On the other hand, it is essential to save money for future life security. When people make more money than they need, they spend money on unnecessary things. In my opinion, people should be more careful on how they spend their money. People should be more attentive towards their family than making money.', 'In our society money has a great value for our lives. We all worry about saving money for our future, and one way in which I save money day by day is by buying only the necessary things that I will use in a week. I prepare food at home every day. I do not have cable service. I watch movies in Netflix.  I believe that we should think about our future and save money for an emergency. But we should not forget to enjoy our present lives with our families, because money is very important but it does not give us happiness.', 'Money is important in every step of life. Now a day’s people run after earning money. Moreover, most of family both parents go to job for earning money. They do not have much time to give their children, relative, friends. Sometime we see they are not affectionate with their children. Most of time people get affected to many things and they buy it though it is unnecessary. Obviously money is important but we should not give up our family, children, relatives because of money. In my opinion we should always remember Happiness, love, affection is more important than money', 'I believe when we are consistently making money we are not investing enough time with our children. When both parents go to make money we do not have time to spend with our children. We need money to survive, but we need to take the money and manage it by cutting unwanted spending and use it to make time with our kids. I cut all unwanted spending and do not use it to further my education because of my children. I want to stay with them, make sure they are healthy, help them with their homework and make sure they focus on their school work. I know, some parents go to work to make money for their future but after doing so, that parent does not have money and nor does their children. By spending so much time working, when it is time for them to actually spend time with their kids, it is too late because they no longer want to spend their time with their parents. They instead spend time with their friends or anyone else except their parents and their excuse is that since their parents weren’t there when they were younger or when they needed them, they no longer feel it is necessary now. To me investing time with my kids is like investing money in the future.', "Some of the choices I make about money on a daily basis is when I'm grocery shopping, or buying new clothes or spending leftover money from bills to buy extra things. Sometimes I have to buy things that are more useful and helpful in my life, so I need to save money from buying extra clothes for example. Sometimes my children want to eat a lot of different stuff but I can't buy all of them at the same time, so I buy one or two and buy more next time I get my paycheck. These are the kind of things I trade of when deciding whats necessary right now and what can be bought later on or what isn't really useful. I can't always have everything I want, and sometimes my children are young so they don't understand, so they ask for a lot of stuff, so I trade-off what I want in order to buy the things my children want or need.", 'In my opinion, we should do work hard for a better future. To get a better life we need money. People have many way to make or earn money. But, it depends how they earn money. It could be good or bad both way. Everyone want to be  financially strong, for that reason many time people ignore their family. I think, family is more important than money. Also, when people get much more money they keep continue their expense unnecessary, but people should not spend money unnecessary. Overall,  every people should be more careful to earn money in a good way and also to spend their money in a proper way.', 'In my opinion, we should do work hard for a better future. To get a better life we need money. People have many way to make or earn money. But, it depends how they earn money. It could be good or bad both way. Everyone want to be financially strong, for that reason many time people ignore their family. I think, family is more important than money. Also, when people get much more money they keep continue their expense unnecessary, but people should not spend money unnecessary. Overall, every people should be more careful to earn money in a good way and also to spend their money in a proper way.', 'i Reading this article What Choices Do you make about money every day?  I think that we must work hard for a better future. To use our money in things that we really need.life now is very expensive to throw in the garbage the money that we earn day by day in very hard jobs. Thinking about growing is thinking about improving our lives and that of our family money is important as long as you know how to manage.', 'Money is everything in life. All people want overcomes financially. Many times people choose money over family because everyone thinks that money it’s everything. Many times we do whatever it is to overcomes that’s why many people makes decision that changed they life for money. I have left personal think for money and is has changed my life.', 'I think that in many case the People use money in a bad way, sometimes we buy things that we do not need or being able to save or invest in something that can help us to grow. Sometimes money management has to do with the lifestyle one has, that we need to thing how the money that we are waste can help us in the future things like buy a house etc.', 'While reading the article I understand that sometimes parents as Martin and Raquel have to decide that one of them should stop working in order to spend more time with their kids. I also agree in the quote that Martin says that the time he and his wife invest in their children means more than money because one of the most important things is to share and make good memories with your loved ones and that worth even more than money. One of the choices I make about money is not buying things unnecessarily because sometimes we buy things we neither want nor use them. Other choice I will make about money is that no matter how much money I’ll earn as a professional, I will prefer to have a job that I love and enjoy.', 'For me money has become for many people fundamental to be happy, that is why many times the management of money reflects the rhythm or quality of life of people. For this reason that all people have to set goals for the future because that way many times we can avoid wasting money on things that are not worth the penalty, but nevertheless for many people it is important to prove that they have money and for  this reason  so Waste money without thinking about the future.', 'According to the statement "what choices do you make about mony everday". There are many ways to make money in the world. It\'s all depeneds on people how they want to make and follow the requirment if you are elegible to make it happened. For example teacher, professore,police, investigate officer, judge,lawer,businessman and banker. If i choise one of them i would be a police offer,investigate offficer, and judge. Because of i can be make money everyday with respect and honored. I wiil be happy with my decision how i learn in good way. So, i think is good way to make money everyday with honored in society.', 'As someone who has to cover all his own expenses, I’m very careful when buying something I want or like because I have to carry a monthly expenses plan where I separated the personal expenses from the bills which are the most important. So, when I trade-off for something I want, I always make sure that all my bills are covered. I think the most difficult issue that I have to face with is the food, because I don’t have enough time to cook so I have to buy outside, but this expense is something I can manage into my monthly plan. The way you handle money can even save your life, at least to me.', 'I think how to spending necessary thing and make smart choices. I invest in something that can give me a future like about investing in a certificate of deposit (CD) or something that later your money can grow. Buying house, I am going to school, pay my insurance, and save Money   for my retirement. If I’m going to somewhere I try to find something out how much it is going to cost for everything that I want to do.', 'The choices to make money every day it depends how you manage your life. Every day, in the evening  you need e little time to think about  tomorrow, and at the end of the day you will be able to calculate the result of your day about what you did and how much money its cost. In my opinion, one of the best ways to make money every day is to have a daily schedule about your life, avoid going to the stores frequently. Avoid going to much to the expensive restaurant just to save money, and buy exactly what you need. Another one is to be focus by thinking about your study or your work. More you think about your work and your study; most you improve your skills and become better for making money every day.', 'In term of money, there are many factors that contribute in people economic. Some of them are related on how many jobs do they have or their average of income they earn, it could be also the amount of expenses under their responsibilities. Another factor that contributes in putting people into financial problem is lack of financial education. For instance, we can mention three categories of income level in society where people may fall; these are low, middle and high income. One family composed of three members, with a yearly income of $15,000 dollars, is considered a low income family, and has more limited options to supply it needs. In my personal case, I use the practice of income and expenses, that way, I realize on how I will spend money every day. I recommend people to be more educated in term of their financial level and be more careful on how they spend their money.', 'In my opinion I make decisions to save and not spend unnecessary money, I take a list of the things I need most and I see the budget of what I have to spend or save myself every day. I make my decisions for good for me, because if you do not save or you do not know how or what to spend your money you will never have anything that can get you out of debt. I make the decisions that I have to make. If I think my options are good and I learn how and when I can make the decision to pay something, I would improve in the morning a woman who knows how to make good decisions and knows how to spend the money, do not waste it and change to have good credit.', 'In this article I do not sympathize with any of the people profiled. The choices I and my husband make about money each day are very important because it is very important for us to save for our future. I am very careful at the time of making unnecessary expenses and I think that if I am very good at handling money, modesty aside that my husband likes very much the way I take care of the savings we make. On the other hand I think it is very good to save and be careful with the handling of money, but also I think that not everything is money and from time to time it is good to enjoy that money to do simple but important things such as travel in Family and get out of the rut from time to time. A nice sentence that I listen to and it seems very good to share, as I agree with the following. "You live to make money; oh you make money to LIVE."']
summary: Commenters mostly talk about the trade-off between earning money and spending time with family, with many concluding that money is important, but earning money at the expense of familial relationships is bad. Others talk about how investing time with their children is also a type of investment, just like money can be invested. Other commenters talk about their personal habits of spending money on themselves and their kids or saving for the future.
short_title: Headline: What Choices Do You Make About Money Every Day?   Keywords:    Snippet: What trade offs do you make to pay for what you need and want, now and in the future?
short_question: ['What Choices Do You Make About Money Every Day?  ']

query: Tracing the roots of a significant relationship to a chance encounter with a spiritual leader.
comments: ['Kismet/Karma...', 'His Holiness the Dalai Lama brings hope, happyness, peace and inner understanding and awareness. https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2017/04/406461/inspired-work-dalai-lama-eve-ek...', 'China has always put forward illegal territory claims: Arunachal Pradesh state, a so-called disputed stretch on the China-India border, just like the so-called disputed state of Tibet and the so-called disputed state with other countries like Japan,Thailand, and philipines. As far as the country of Tibet is concerned, China forcefully invaded that country with another deceitful story: Chinese troops marched into Tibet and took control in 1950 in what Beijing calls a peaceful liberation. Troops crushed an uprising against Chinese rule in 1959, when the Dalai Lama fled into exile in India. What Chinese rule in 1959?  China invaded Tibet and there was no provocation by Tibet, nor did Tibet ever invade or take any territory from China.  If there were clashes then China is to blame for those clashes between China and Tibet. China is making false representation of many territories nearby China.  If China is out of livable estate, then they should consider alternate societies in rivers, oceans or perhaps the moon.', 'Was she a meditating Rockette?', "Something profound also happened to me. I had gone to a lecture by the Dalai Lame. I left for a few minutes and on the way back into the hall, His Holiness passed me in the hallway that led to the rest rooms.  I bowed as he was walking by.  He stopped and blessed me and then put his hands on either side of my face and really looked at me, at first very seriously and then he smiled. Big surprise - 1 day later I was in the emergency room bleeding to death.  I had an ulcer but hadn't known it.  The doctor who was going to operate on me told me he would try to save my life. When I woke up hours later, the doctor told me he had done his best but that I should call my family because I had lost over 40% of my blood & had a wound he couldn't completely repair. I spent the next 5 days thinking about the Dalai Lama and his blessing.  I heard from a number of people on the medical staff I probably would not live. I felt that blessing very deeply and it calmed me.  I felt that I could accept the bad turn of events and die being grateful for all the good things in my life and not focus on regrets or fear.  I was surprised by this but it was a great feeling.  I've never felt so peaceful. I lived. I chalk all this up to His Holiness.  Thank you, Your Holiness.", 'I like this one! Happy for you.', "That's a Wow!❤️", 'Love to read this section. The stories brighten my day! Thanks for sharing.', "Thank you. I love stories like this.  Here's mine: One night I invited my good friend over for dinner. As we tell it, she never went home. We were married two weeks later. That was 32 years ago. But it was not the Dalai Lama's blessing. It must have been something in the stir-fried shrimp that I made for dinner.", 'Ah......! Although, I could quibble and offer some legal nitpicking and malarkey about the distinction between a necessary and a sufficient condition, my heart is moved, Michael Hayes. I say "Congratulations!" to both you and to your bride, and a tip of the hat to your intelligence.', "Forgive me if I'm incorrect, but here in Texas the Kadampa Center is linked to an elderly Tibetan Lama in London who does not support the Dalai Lama as he believes that he does not uphold traditional values and traditions of Tibetan Buddhism.", '@Tess:  I know nothing about Kadampa, but I *do* wonder about everyone\'s reading comprehension, b/c Mr. Hayes says he met the Dalai Lama completely inadvertently/accidentally as the Dalai Lama was coming out of a door at Radio City. Separately, "3 months later" a friend asks Mr. Hayes if he meditates, and suggests they meet & meditate at Kadampa, which presumably Mr. Hayes was not familiar with. There is NOTHING in this story that equates the Dalai Lama with the Kadampa Center at all, so I don\'t know why multiple people are conflating the two.', "Tess is quite correct. The Kadampa centers are under the aegis of Kelsang Gyatso, a lama who has opposed the Dalai Lama for decades in a dispute over His Holiness's objection to the worship of a particular Tibetan protector deity; on numerous occasions, Kadampa center members have picketed at venues where the Dalai Lama was speaking. It's hard to imagine H.H. guiding Michael to the Kadampa Center, but, then, karma does have its ironies.", "I like your story also. It's great to read something soft and gentle with a touch of mystery and of course love.", 'Dear Manhattan diary writer,  Like you I am not a Budhist but have always been intrigued with His Holiness The Dalai Lama.  Intrigued as a child, Yes. But more now than ever it is more than a simple intrigue or infatuation.  I have complete faith in the 14th Dalai Lama that he will lead his people out of chains and shackles from the oppressor regime(s of China.  I too look forward to meeting the Dalai Lama and just a simple nod from him or body language or the holiness looking straight in my eye will be the blessing that I seem to want so much.  Recently he has been talking about his departure to create a way for the new Dalai Lama, the re-incarnation of himself with different parents.  And those holy men entrusted with the search for the new Dalai Lama will have enough signs to know the real Dalai Lama child.  When the 14th Dalai Lama passes away China will launch a campaign to impress that they have found the child to be the Dalai Lama.  Nature in its infinite wisdom will frustrate China from creating a dummy Dalai Lama. There is profound faith in the Tibetans and their victory to continue their faith without political intervention will be my victory too. Tibet and China are two different nations.  Tibet will never ever surrender to China.', "Going with the flow is a really good way to live. You never know what you'll find, but it might fulfill your wishes.", "Going with the flow can certainly be appealing - as long as you don't fall into the tempting trap of magical thinking along the way., complete with benevolent blessings & tasty pie-in-the-sky. For whether you choose to immerse yourself passively in the flow of a loving religion, or lose yourself  in a religion filled with fear & anger & hate, or seek no religion at all, we must have the courage & strength & independence NOT to go with the flow as well. Going with the flow is surely comforting, like wanting to remain floating, suspended in the security of our mothers womb. But  to borrow a phrase, we must be born again to truly fulfill the human potential in each of us. But for me that means not living our short precious lives through someone else's eyes, nor with their pre-packaged answers and choices, nor by  following their “sacred” commands. It means believing in ourselves instead of them.  It means living our lives instead of theirs. It means standing up - against the flow - like the proud Men and Women that we truly are, and choosing to live our own lives on our own paths. with our own meanings and mistakes and methods. It means breaking the chains of dependency, religion, conformity  and magic, and breathing the fresh and healing air of true freedom: \xa0deeply …fully \xa0… finally. Our species needed to leave the deep, enveloping, flowing oceans in order to become human.", "I always wonder about that moment when your deepest desires meet the blessing..then I go to mass often, pray more than often, and mostly pray so my deepest desires match God's desires for me..", "That's a very odd story considering the Kadampa's (if it was a New Kadampa center) profess to hate the Dalai Lama and accuse him of innumerable falsities.", 'We are all inter connected in invisible ways. Sometimes whom we meet, by accident, turns out to be no accident after all. I have a lot of fun un raveling hidden connections between people I know. Talk about six degrees of separation...no...its ways less than that, if you care to dig deeper. In Buddhism, there\'s a prayer May I develop "bodhicitta -- a spontaneous and continuous state of the mind that seeks enlightenment solely for the benefit of all sentient beings. The six causes are as follows: a. Recognition of all sentient beings as one\'s mother b. Remembering the kindness of all mother sentient beings c. Repaying this kindness d. The development of affectionate love e. The development of great compassion f. The cultivation of the superior intention." At some time, place or other, all sentient beings have been our mother (that is how many times we have recycled all over the Universe)!', 'Assuming that your wife will be reading your dairy entry, you are wise to have referred to her as a "beautiful woman". I may not possess the mystical powers of the Dalai Lama, but I predict a long and happy marriage.', 'Beautiful story, love it. Thank you --', 'Me too!', 'Your friend did play a part in bringing you together, though unwittingly.']
summary: Many commenters really enjoy the article and state this. Others share similar stories or hypothetical situations in which they might have to choose between "going with the flow" and doing what they typically might. Other commenters discuss the Dalai Lama and his origins. They describe the history of China and other states and how ideologies have been affected by these events.
short_title: Headline: The Dalai Lama’s Blessing   Keywords: Dalai Lama; Manhattan (NYC)   Snippet: Tracing the roots of a significant relationship to a chance encounter with a spiritual leader.
short_question: ['The Dalai Lama’s Blessing  ']

query: This romance illustrates the struggle for African independence from colonialism, under the shadow of apartheid.
comments: ['David Oyelowo and Rosamund Pike are a force to be reckoned with in this important film. We need more films like A United Kingdom to remind us that even though opposing views are strongly presented, somehow truth and wisdom can win the day. It drew tears and optimism in me at a time when I feel overwhelming disillusionment with our government.', "I also saw Mr. Oyelowo with Daniel Craig in Othello.  My initial interest was in seeing Mr. Craig, who performed the role of Iago admirably, but in the final act of the play I was utterly transported by Mr. Oyelowo's riveting portrayal of the heretofore great king after realizing he had just murdered his sweet, innocent Desdemona based on a stack of lies. Mr. Oyelowo conveyed Othello's grief with such truth and gut force of emotion that I found myself crying as if he were on the stage of the Globe in 1604 and I was in its audience.  Now that was a performance for the ages! I will never forget it, nor will I ever fail to see him in any of his future performances.", 'A college roommate, the now late Dr. Thomas Tlou, who became Botswana\'s seminal historian, UN Ambassador, and then administrative university head (and along the way one of the exemplary men in Alexander McCall-Smith\'s Botswana novels), held up Seretse Khama and Ruth Williams\'s partnership as a principal contributor to Botswana\'s coping with the corrosive effects of colonialism. I\'ll be watching "A United Kingdom" with Tom\'s genial but ever rigorous spirit beside me.', 'Seretse is remembered with admiration by my favorite Precious Ramostwe of "The Number One Ladies Detective Agency" series by Alexander McCall-Smith. I knew nothing of him; but if Precious admired him, I place him among history\'s worthies.', 'white people never get it. Black people are fighting to be a free and sovereign people again, not to chase and fall  in love and live with  white people--except for the few that white apologist always seem to find a poster.', 'Interested in seeing how well Pike can rise to the challenges of playing against a very talented co-star and having the benefit of strong director. Pike has had commercial success in weak combos, but think she has unrevealed abilities.', "just put this in my Netflix Q- looks excellent! Mr. Oyelowo  always gives a wonderful portrayal of any role he takes on,. Can't wait to  see this.", 'Saw David Oyelowo in "Othello" at NY Theatre Workshop with Daniel Craig as Yago a couple of months ago and he was simply riveting.  So looking forward to seeing this.', "Boy, that's a combo I wish had been filled for those of us out here in flyover land!"]
summary: The commenters generally enjoy "A United Kingdom." Many of the commenters praise the actors, including David Oyelowo and Rosamund Pike. Several commenters mention past works that Oyelowo featured in, including a play with Daniel Craig, that was very impressive. One commenter dislikes how the movie focuses on a Black person falling in love with a white person.
short_title: Headline: Not Your Typical Fairy-Tale Romance   Keywords: Movies; A United Kingdom (Movie); Oyelowo, David; Pike, Rosamund; Asante, Amma   Snippet: This romance illustrates the struggle for African independence from colonialism, under the shadow of apartheid.
short_question: ['Not Your Typical Fairy-Tale Romance  ']

query: Maia finally finds the boldness to start making her mark. Her father doesn’t lack that trait.
comments: ["this is a great show I just binge watched.  And sadly it was only ten episodes!  I love the strong women on the show, and the diversity too.  I do miss the Felicia character, however the mention of her is enough, I don't miss her enough to have her back.", 'This is the best new show on TV; from the exploding of everyday objects in the title sequence (with increasingly Russian-sounding music building in the background) to the terrific writing and acting, I find it reinvigorates me each week. For those of us needing sustenance to sustain our Resistance efforts, this serves a vital role.', "Thanks to the NYT for recapping this show. Maybe CBS will add it to their network lineup and give up on the online pay model. Don't we pay enough already?  I also disagree that Barbara is a marginalized character. She clearly loves Boseman and it is unrequited.  She also is not one of the leads, period.", "I am a huge Christine Baranski fan - I love everything she stars in. Ms. Baranski is an extremely talented actress. The Good Fight is fantastic.  Quality actors with quality story lines.    I like the character of Maia, so I'm not sure why so many don't.  I understand her personality, as that was me 30 plus years ago.  Don't count her short because she's not a ball buster.  She will prevail in the end. (Crap father and all). Looking forward to Season 2.", 'Let readers know when Good Fight shows up on Amazon or Netflix or Hulu. Ditto the other comments above re: CBS\' hubris about this "pay to view" set-up.', 'The Good Fight has not only the hurdles of any new series, but pay to access as well. It may be too high a burden. The hubris that CBS feels we would purchase, above and beyond for merely one or two series (of 10 Episodes?)--', 'It is a shame CBS does not broadcast " The Good Fight" on television. Most of the television programs are not worth turning on the TV for, too many doctors, silly comedies when one is forced to laugh. Christine Baranski is a great actor particularly as Diane in Good Wife while Alicia Florrick became more and more boring. Anyways I have not watched a single episode of The Good Fight, unless it comes back on DVD but I am not going to hold my breath.', "I have found other ways to watch The Good Fight ( a friend with CBS All Access records for me). Yes, the creators & producers, considering their long relationship with CBS, ought to be mighty POed that this great adult show is shoved to one side for lessor shows on the broadcast network. Christine & Cush ( loved her in Vera) are doing great work. I do sometimes wonder about Rose's characterization of Maia, she can be pretty wimpy, naive & annoying at times. I look forward to a 2nd season. Yeah, more Kurt & Diane!!"]
summary: Commenters generally are responding to this review of The Good Fight with their own reviews, praising the show itself and the actors. Some lament that it is not more widely known and that it only has ten episodes. All of the users who comment on quality endorse the series as good, with one calling it "the best new show." Several users comment about how you have to pay to watch the series, above the normal fee to watch CBS, which they consider ridiculous.
short_title: Headline: 'The Good Fight’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Trojan Horses   Keywords: Television; The Good Fight (TV Program)   Snippet: Maia finally finds the boldness to start making her mark. Her father doesn’t lack that trait.
short_question: ["'The Good Fight’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Trojan Horses  "]

query: In a touching tribute to his father and the tradition of reading aloud, Mr. Lithgow recites two classic tales of deception and comeuppance.
comments: ["This review is WAY off base.   I love John Lithgow, and am a long-time subscriber of the Roundabout, which generally does great work.  This was one of the worst shows I have ever seen, at the Roundabout, or frankly, anywhere.  It was nearly impossible to stay awake.   Where's John Lithgow when I'm trying to get back to sleep at four in the morning?  This show is better than ambien.", 'He is a wonderful actor and charming personality,  but the first story he recites is boring, dated, much too long and mocks women and the mentally disabled. I had never seen so many patrons leave a Broadway preview at intermission. The second half is much better, but far from riveting.', 'Oh my, you totally missed the point of the first story!  That dated old-fashioned quality is what makes the denouement so dynamic and horrifying.', 'So glad you were able to enjoy this "old-fashioned" performance.   My goodness; old-fashioned!  What a travesty. Refreshing to say the least.', 'John Lithgow is brilliant, inspiring and deserves all off the accolades for this thoughtful, sophisticated, heart warming homage to the short story, theater and his father Arthur. The stories, when told by John from his heart, expose the spectrum of complexity of human nature at its best and worst, and John flawlessly takes us on a journey into the depths of each character while lighting up the stage with his extraordinary talent. The performance demonstrates what is possible with great effort and determination after a lifetime of preparation.', "Simply put, one of America's finest all-around (stage, TV, Film) actors!", "i can't believe that your reviewer missed one of the main point of the show, viz. the key q he asks at the beginning: WHY DO PEOPLE NEED STORIES? to give you his answer is a spoiler.", "Earlier a playwright and his wife, a teacher of theater, were here for a visit, and I hope they made it to 'The Post' in time.  The latter knows her French actors, and I asked her to guess which famous one had opened a theater.  Gerard Depardieu (no), Alain Delon (closer), and finally I gave her a clue beginning with the first name Jean.  The answer is Jean Belmondo. They left in the bitter cold, careful not to slip on a thin sheet of snow, and I remembered that I have a preference for theater productions with a small cast, the last one starring John Lithgow.  There was a brilliant British actress who reminded me of a relative that I care for, and it had the word Russia in the title?   'Sink my ships', but it was 'Retreat from Moscow' with Eileen Atkins and a young actor, Ben Chaplin, who was very fine.  All to say, glad to read this review of Jesse Green of some lessons from John Lithgow, and it comes as no surprise that it promises to be well received by the audience.", 'Saw it in preview and adored it! Our young adult children were mesmerized as well. Kudos for keeping this goingbJohn! Go see it, for sure.', 'also, i contend that though the first 1/2 does go on, the 2nd 1/2 where he plays a dozen characters, INCLUDING A PARROT, is about the best theatre i remember.', 'I recall John Lithgow from a "Great Performances" play "Secret Service" from 1977, a play done in antiquated style. (Also had Meryl Streep). He has great breadth as an actor (or actress as in the case of "The World According to Garp). Please bring the play within striking distance of Tucson or produce a video. Videos would have been nice of Robin Williams in "Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo" and Al Pacino in "Merchant of Venice." Just because we live in the sticks doesn\'t mean we have a sticks mentality.', 'Like Jesse, I wasn\'t expecting to be so moved by such an "old-fashioned show" When I saw it a few days ago...but by God, moved I was. John Lithgow is a gem, an American treasure and not to be missed in this wonderful performance.', 'When I die, I want to come back as a New Yorker, so I can see brilliant performances like this all the time. LA is pretty darn good, but oh, New York, how I envy you!', 'There are ticket services that paper the house.  Look them up.', "Be sure to come back as a wealthy New Yorker (though increasingly those are the only people who can afford to live here), or you might be extremely frustrated by all the great shows you can't afford to see.", 'Maybe New York theaters should follow a policy similar to the Met: different pricing for New Yorkers vs out-of-towners.  Make it more affordable for those who live here.  We would then go often enough to make up in volume what they lose in per-unit cost.', 'The review understates Mr. Lithgow’s brilliance in the second act, where he recites “Uncle Fred Flits By”. He performs seven different characters — and a parrot — with a dizzying array of vocal affects and facial tics. The audience was kept in stitches throughout.', 'i do thoroughly agree with this statement and described my feeling about this magnificent 2nd 1/2 below.', "Saw this show 10 years ago at Lincoln Center and was in enthralled by it I've been a Lithgow fan ever since.", "I had the good fortune to know Arthur Lithgow.  He was one of my teachers in the theatre school at the University of South Florida, and he later managed a small theatre company in Tampa where I worked as an actor.  He was a kind and generous man, and he had many a story of his own from his life in the theatre. I would go so far as to say that P.G. Wodehouse had nothing on Arthur Lithgow when it came to telling stories.  I saw John Lithgow's show in its earlier version at Lincoln Center.  It was a great pleasure to see John's performance and to hear the memories he shares about his father and his mother, Sarah.  Arthur was a jovial rock of calm to me in my confusing and tempestuous twenties, and I treasure my own memories of him.", 'I too had the privilege of having Arthur Lithgow as a teacher.  He taught a few classes in the film department at Ithaca College.  He was, as you say, a lovely person, and like you, I remember him fondly from a time that was otherwise very difficult for me.', 'We saw this wonderful program in Los Angeles ?5 years ago - hearing about it brings back fond memories of the show.   I hope a video version is around for the next generation.', 'I was one of the fortunate few that watched the show. The review is right on the money but , apparently, the reviewer did not experience the same magic I did. Basically, as far as I am concerned, Mr. Lithgow and I were alone in the theater. I was not, after a few minutes, aware of being in a theater but rather it felt as if he and I were alone in a room and he was talking directly to me. This has never happened before in my long experience as a theater goer. It was simply amazing. Highly recommended', 'I\'ve thought Mr. Lithgow brilliant since I saw him, on a high school class trip, in "The Changing Room" at the Morosco.  I was def. planning to catch this as I\'ve seen pretty much everything else he\'s done since "Rom" (including "My Fat Friend").  So incoming bad weather or not I\'m in.  The review brought to mind the similar sounding "Shakespeare for My Father" written and performed by Lynn Redgrave (Mr. Lithgow\'s "Fat Friend" co-star).  That piece was one of  my top theatergoing memories  for that season. Here\'s hoping "Stories" is for this one.', 'Saw this in Cleveland a few years ago.    His performance pulls you in and gives you an emotional ride.   A lovely way to spend an evening.']
summary: Almost all commentators heap acclaim on John Lithgow's abilities and performance. Many of them recall fond memories of John's previous performances. Some commentators recall his ability to tell stories, including one where he plays a parrot. A few commentators directly praise the second half of the show. One commentator criticizes the first half, saying that it was boring.
short_title: Headline: Let Me Tell You A Story   Keywords: Theater; American Airlines Theater; Lithgow, John; Sullivan, Daniel J; Lardner, Ring Jr; Wodehouse, P G; John Lithgow: Stories by Heart (Play); Roundabout Theater Co   Snippet: In a touching tribute to his father and the tradition of reading aloud, Mr. Lithgow recites two classic tales of deception and comeuppance.
subreddit: ['Theater', 'American Airlines Theater', 'Lithgow, John', 'Sullivan, Daniel J', 'Lardner, Ring Jr', 'Wodehouse, P G', 'John Lithgow: Stories by Heart (Play)', 'Roundabout Theater Co']
short_question: ['Let Me Tell You A Story  ']

query: Steven Levenson’s comedy-drama explores multiple and contradictory dimensions of self-perception through its portrait of a family, the Fischers.
comments: ["I saw If I Forget this afternoon. I thought that the acting was superb especially the lines delivered by Sharon and Michael. The young son also added to the playfulness of the script. As per usual, this play depicts sibling rivalry and inheritance issues. The family wasn't particularly religious, but they did seem to have inherent Jewish feelings and identity. I thought the ending was significant noting for if we don't practice some sort of religion and traditions, all that has happened will dissipate and become consumed by the sand.", 'I definitely enjoyed this play and found it thought-provoking. Moreover, I am still thinking about it, unlike so many things which are immediately forgotten. The complexities of families, where love is intertwined with jealousy and resentment, was well depicted. The sadness of adolescent mental illness was a theme of significance and the emotional response of the young cousin to his "only cousin\'s" illness was touching and poignant. The relationships of the three siblings were complex and meaningful and their varying responses to Judaism made for an interesting intersection of opinions. I was glad to have been exposed to the Fischers in all their various permutations.', 'Saw this today and thought it was terrific.  The entire cast was wonderful, with Jeremy Shamos the standout.  Like a couple of other commenters here, I, too, was reminded of The Humans, another play that presented a heartrending moment in which an ailing parent, unable to clearly communicate, cries/lashes out in anguish.  I would have enjoyed attending a performance with a talk-back afterword, as there are so many things to discuss.', "after reading his NY times article about protesting, I have my doubts about this writer.  He seems pretentious, right off, and that always sends a red flag my way.  I know, you won't print this in the comments section.  Keep it safe right?", 'Completely disagree with your assessment. I thought the review was wonderful. And the journalist is a woman, by the way.', 'The letter writer is referring to the playwright ... last month, in the NY Times, he wrote something about going to his first protest. I agree with the letter writer.', 'Saw this in previews:  REMARKABLE!  Do not miss On par with The Humans--which grabbed my Irish/Catholic side, and this play--which captured my Viennese Jewish heritage.  With the desecration of Jewish cemeteries, and bomb threats arriving at Synagogues,  what could be more timely?', "2 1/2 hours and then Oxymandias.   Bleak, without the style of a Beckett.  No warmth, no hope.    Some laugh lines but they're bitter.", "The review is accurate.  Good moments, but filled with moments that serve the drama, but are inexplicable, such as a bright professor publishing an incendiary book BEFORE he's obtained tenure.  A character flaw not explained.", 'I loved this play. Yes, there is some clunky plot points, but for an evening of laughter AND introspection, this piece is worth experience. The actors are simply magnificent.', 'I read this with interest and sadness. I\'m Jewish and from a typical dysfunctional American Jewish family. My brothers and sister and I are from the last century. Our parents, both are veterans of World War II were good Jews. But, our kids are a mess.  They don\'t understand who we are or why. I wish I could write a play about our family. Strained relations is more than just words. My son announced earlier this week that god and religion are bogus. He also said he doesn\'t want to give his two boys bar mitzvahs. He\'s a Penn graduate, an attorney of intellectual property in organic chemistry and pharmaceuticals earning a small fortune.  I don\'t get it. I think my play would have more drama. There is a "great rift" between us. Anti-Semitism is real for me.  It is abstract for my children as is the Holocaust. What should we remember? What should we forget? How do we reconcile the generations and preserve our history and traditions? I don\'t know. I\'m looking forward to seeing this play. "If I Forget" may end in "magical realism" but there is no magic for real families.  No one would embrace my family. There are too many "layers of injury and devotion."  Still, I\'d like to see how the Fischer\'s do it.  I wonder how my grandkids will accept and practice Judaism. We\'re a real family  "unable to agree on pretty much anything, yet still somehow in unison."  Maybe we can all see this play. Maybe we can solve the problem of how to love and who we should be.', 'Your synopsis of the play was so compelling I shot the locks off my wallet.', 'Moving, funny, provocative...yes, a "kitchen sink", but one you would happly add to your top of the line domicile. The first act is absolutely first-class.', "This is one of the best American plays I've seen in years.", 'Superbly written review for an excellent play. Does this mean that Ms. Soloski got the job?', "There's a good play in here, but only if it is cut by half. Playwrights need to learn that less can be more. Life is short!", 'Brilliant play, superb cast.  Ranks with The Humans and in some ways is the Jewish August-Osage County.', 'Saw it last night. Your comment is spot on! I\'d especially have lost the last little 5 minute riff which gives us the "magic realism" ending.']
summary: Many of the commenters describe how much they enjoy the play "If I Forget," and one commenter described it as "thought-provoking" and how they are still thinking about it. Several other commenters were more critical of the play - one person describes the play as "bleak" and without style and warmth. Other critical commenters imply the play was too long and that "less can be more," and that there were some of the plot points were "clunky." One commenter mentions that he feels the writer is "pretentious," which is off-putting.
short_title: Headline: Bitter Battles in a Family, With Love   Keywords: Theater; If I Forget (Play); Levenson, Steven; Sullivan, Daniel J; Walsh, Kate (1967- ); Roundabout Theater Co   Snippet: Steven Levenson’s comedy-drama explores multiple and contradictory dimensions of self-perception through its portrait of a family, the Fischers.
subreddit: ['Theater', 'If I Forget (Play)', 'Levenson, Steven', 'Sullivan, Daniel J', 'Walsh, Kate (1967- )', 'Roundabout Theater Co']
short_question: ['Bitter Battles in a Family, With Love  ']

query: Behrouz Boochani would record a handful of videos, then travel from the refugee detention center to a nearby town to connect to the internet and send them.
comments: ['What a bunch of inhumane hard arses our government has become.  Even ppl who have done abominable things serve less time in Australian prisons and are always given end dates  to their terms of incarceration. This goes against laws of reasonableness and human rights to leave people swinging. Absolutely disgraceful . Please don not give up Mr  Boochani- your work is invaluable . I apologize for  our so called leadership - a bullying and coward example of repulsive behaviour. Many of us are behind you.', "An Iranian refugees who followed the same refugee path brought Australia to a halt a few years ago after he staged a hostage situation in the middle of Sydney ( Lindt cafe ) which ended when he shot the cafe owner in the back of the head after asking him to kneel. The Police special forces stormed the cafe and another mother of three was also killed in ricocheting bullets. This event occurred after he bashed the skull on his wife in with a bicycle frame and then set her alight leaving her to burn to death in a stairwell. Yep, he got bail in Australia.. You will see from a map that Iran is not very close to Australia. Indeed it requires that you travel through Pakistan, India, Myanmar, Thailand, Malaysia and then finally to Indonesia before you meet with people smugglers to overload you on a boat to Australia. On the way, the asylum seekers ( legal definition ) discard their passports and all other documentation to increase the probability they are accepted. Why do they do this ? Because the receiving country ( Australia ) is bound by many conventions to receive these people. Australia has a long history of receiving refugees, similar to Canada. Australia voted in a new Abbott government in 2013 to address these arrivals. Most Australian's saw them as economic refugees. The easier path is to fly to Australia but that requires you arrive having submitted an immigration application and a passport versus no passport, papers or anything else but a story..", "Wish I were writing this sooner, because I need to express my gratitude to Mr. Boochani, to you and NYT's for this important documentation. Looking forward to Mr. Boochani enjoying full freedom, and to Mr. Trump being extremely vetted for treason prior to his passage to Guantánamo.", 'people dont understand  compassion and true love nowadays. We as free people, We as a nation should not look down on them as if they are animals. Sure we fear our safety when it comes to the few immigrants who opposed harm on us but we cant just say no to those whom need our help. We have so many resources that could help them, but we waist them. Look how much water we waste just by letting it run over frozen meat or when we brush our teeth. Other countries have nothing and it should hurt our hearts to see a "human" going through something so vile and disgusting. I am not a republican but i agree with some of trumps views. However, to just say no you cant come over here and create a better life for your family and you is so wrong. Why shouldnt they have a chance at a better life? Most of them shouldnt be blamed for where they were born and raised. We shouldnt just cut them out because lets be honest, growing up in poverty, you seem to learn more of life. You strive for greatness to be a better person and thats something our generation in america lacks. We are lazy nowadays, and people that come from over seas end up excelling in school over here. That wanted it so much that they go beyond and in their future end up helping our country with needs like medicine or discovering cures. We shouldnt just say no! Humanity shouldnt be based on where you\'re from or if we can benefit from them, it should be because everyone deserves a better life. A free life.', "This episode will go into the annals of shame for our indifference and the thrashing of justice and compassion. As it has been said, repeatedly, the U.S. (and no doubt Australia) doesn't have friends, just interests; it certainly helps in sidestepping human rights with impunity, if other narrow interests become the only play in tow. And if so, looking the other way, as any hypocrite worth its name may attest, is the way to go. Who are we, drowning in our own complacency?", "This piece provides insight into a tragic crisis affecting war refugees. It's a shameful situation, and my heart goes out to these vulnerable people.  Complacent ignorance contributes to inhumane disregard for victims of war. I will do my small part to speak out and raise concern, and I thank all of the journalists involved who are working to bring this to the attention of the American public.", 'What I take away from this is that Australia doesn\'t want refugees and tried to passing them off to America.  I somehow had the impression that Australia took in some refugees and was sending us an "overflow" as part of a humane agreement.  But no, Australia does not want them.', 'At this stage the only remote likelihood of a new life for these so called "queue jumpers" resides with Trump and the vetting process currently underway. One can only hope the US will show the humanity Australia has not found it in its heart to extend and offer a new life to those who have suffered enough and have been so damaged by their experiences.  Regardless of when and where they are allowed to settle down, people like Behwrouz  Boochani and so many others like him will have to live with the consequences of their lengthy and cruel imprisonment.', 'Thank you telling this important story. I pray Mr. Boochani and the other brave and innocent refuges from the shameful Austrailian prison are allowed to rebuild their lives in our beautiful country. If you read this Mr. Boochani, know that the majority of Americans will welcome you with open arms and open heart.', 'Ralph, I believe prison is his metaphor (and reality) but it is a refugee detention center, civil detention. One is not necessarily stripped of belongings as happens in civil immigration detention in U.S.', 'Many towns in California have looked like refugee camps for decades, so please send the new ones to another state.  We are full, schools full, roads full, parking full, jails full, asylums full, hospitals full, homeless camps full.', "'Keeps them at arms length from reporters.' Let's see WhatsApp, Facebook, telephone' email. Did you want him dropped off at a convenient coffee shop?", 'The story of Boochani is certainly troubling.  However, I can\'t help feeling that the entire story is not being told. First. consider the use of the word "prison". He is not being held in a prison. Otherwise, how to explain his ability to access the internet and go into town. Yes, he is being detained in a remote area, but in a camp that allows many more freedoms than a prison. So if facts matter, and the NYT is always saying they do because Trump thinks otherwise, then let\'s be clear, Boochani is not in a prison. The second issue is why the Australian government resorted to this policy: a large rise in migration. Much of this migration was actually due to human trafficking and sex slavery. By taking stiffer action, the government has reduced this activity, which in turn has saved lives. Why didn\'t the story provide this background? Actually, Boochani may owe his life to Australian policy. His first boat sank and then the authorities found the second one which had been lost at sea for a week. Just letting everyone in who comes is not the right solution for many reasons. Let\'s hope Australia can improve on the current treatment and that Boochani soon finds a place to live. But don\'t paint the Australian government with the same brush you do Trump, or assume that open boarders for all is some magical solution to a very complex set of problems.', "Truly demoralizing to read these stories.  All these people are fleeing for their lives and the leaders of many democracies just ignore their pleas for help.  The Australians call it “queue Jumping”. They're refugees from war torn countries or dictatorships pleading for asylum, not the normal immigrant requesting permanent residency.  President Obama did the right thing when he agreed to accept those 1250 refugees from Australia. Trump is an entirely different story. It seems the only hope left is Angela Merkel and Justin Trudeau.  I still hold out hope for all those trying to escape the horrors of war and do ask that the authors and the NY Times keep vigilant and continue to tell these stories.", 'How does a prisoner in such a hell-hole have so much access to the outside world and other journalist?  Does the prison want his story to get out?', "Because the Papua New Guinea Supreme Court in April 2016 ruled that it was illegal to detain asylum seekers on Manus and ordered the PNG and Australian governments to immediately take steps to end their detention. The detainees are now permitted to move around the island freely, but they are still based at the prison and stuck on the island. The US deal was the Australian government's expected solution. In return for the US taking those men from Manus who have been proven to be refugees, Australia was to settle a reciprocal number from the US, reputedly from Central America.  http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-26/png-court-rules-asylum-seeker-dete...", "The men detained on Manus have been able to trade with locals to obtain mobile phones which were not allowed and so kept hidden until last April when Australia's detaining of asylum seekers on Manus was deemed unconstitutional and therefore illegal.  Since that time they've been freely allowed to use their phones. http://mobile.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-26/png-court-rules-asylum-seeker-d...", 'Technically he is not a prisoner. But it is correct that the Australian government and the governments of Papua New Guinea and Nauru have done all they could within the limits of the law to prevent access and information.  The high court of Papua New Guinea has recently ruled the manus island detention centre unconstitutional. The "pacific" solution is therefore on borrowed time. Second, the Naura government - another tinpot failed island state of the pacific - has been far more successful in keeping information from leaking. And that centre has been - by all accounts - far more brutal.  As an Australian I have consistently voted against this policy and I am ashamed of my country in this. We have enough room - and we need - more big cities in Australia. I would like to see the world, including China and the USA help us build new, environmentally sustainable cities in which these refugees could be housed and processed while getting on with their lives. On the proviso that the world will eventually take a fair share of them (on the assumption that, for the foreseeable future, refugees are going to keep on coming). Despite what some people say, Australia needs and can handle far more people. We have an opportunity to be an outstanding example to the world and break a lot of barriers, something that Australia has always excelled at. Instead, for the past 15 years we have, in reality, closed our doors and turned our back on the world. America should not make the same mistake.', 'Thank you for reporting on the sad fate of Mr. Boochani and others on Manus Island.  I have faith that he and they will ultimately end up in the United States.']
summary: Many of the commenters are sorrowful about what Mr. Boochani and other refugees at Manus Island have been going through. They wonder how Australia and the United States got to a place where they can justify turning these people from war-torn countries away. Some of them discuss President Trump's role in allowing or disallowing them entry into the United States. A few wonder how Mr. Boochani has been able to send photos and access the outside world while a detainee.
short_title: Headline: How Texts From a ‘Hell Prison’ in the Pacific Led to a Powerful Video Diary   Keywords: Refugees and Displaced Persons; Iran; Australia; Manus Island (Papua New Guinea); Executive Orders and Memorandums; WhatsApp Inc   Snippet: Behrouz Boochani would record a handful of videos, then travel from the refugee detention center to a nearby town to connect to the internet and send them.
