short_question: ['How Texts From a ‘Hell Prison’ in the Pacific Led to a Powerful Video Diary  ']

query: Tuesday: Remedies for the morning after, deplorable weather, and blossoming cherry trees.
comments: ['Hangover prevention... Two charcoal tablets before bed with a large glass of water.  Two more upon waking, if necessary.  It works!', 'The best way to ease a hangover? Use cannabis instead.', 'Let\'s visit the weather again for a moment, shall we? In Germany we have a saying: "April, April, der macht was er will!" (transl. April, April, does what it will!) A shot of "Underberg" for hangovers -- made from herbs, good for indigestion...Prosit!', 'Try not drinking.  There are no side effects.', 'Add ibuprofen and milk thistle to the hydration routine. Ideally take it before going to bed. Does wonders.', 'Mets bravado Braves', 'Whoever did the weather report deserves a raise.', "An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.  Either drink less or, dare I say it, don't drink!", "Want your hangover gone in 20 minutes? Get an IV. I've tried many of the services, Nutridrip is by far the best (nurses, product line, etc.) and most reliable. It's not inexpensive ( around $200) but affordable, and if you have a big day that you can't be hung over for there is NO substitute. Get a Nutridrip!", 'Probably not what the Times will suggest people do, but a small amount of marijuana will completely rid you of any hangover nausea.', "For cherry tree viewing in Manhattan, don't forget the Conservatory Garden in Central Park. Enter on 5th Ave between 104th & 105th. They usually have a great spring display of daffodils and tulips as well. http://www.centralparknyc.org/things-to-see-and-do/attractions/conservat...", "Hang over cures? don't overindulge. Moderation is the key. If there's non-alcoholic beer in the party, would prefer that.", "On the theory that everything, including hangover advice, goes better with the traditional NCAA March Madness anthem.   Tune of One Shining Moment The ball is tossed, abandon hope Your team has surely lost, and you drink to cope Your jaw now drops, you feel the fear They pulled out all the stops, you get one more beer That one Tar Heel moment The winner is crowned That one Tar Heel moment Your sorrows get drowned Now you wake up, blood sugar low Forget that coffee cup, tea's the way to go! Your stomach aches, your shakes increase Skip fat for goodness sakes, try an egg, no grease That one Tar Heel moment The winner was crowned That one Tar Heel moment Get up off the ground One Tar Heel moment!", 'Somebody had a strong cup of coffee and their Wheaties this morning!']
summary: Most commenters talk about their own hangover cures, which include continuing drinking, getting an IV, and Ibuprofen. Some commenters say people should just not drink or drink so much they get a hangover. One user posts song lyrics that are instructions on how to recover from a hangover.
short_title: Headline: New York Today: How to Ease a Hangover   Keywords:    Snippet: Tuesday: Remedies for the morning after, deplorable weather, and blossoming cherry trees.
short_question: ['New York Today: How to Ease a Hangover  ']

query: Is The Times drowning readers in Trump coverage? Or does the capital turmoil merit the coverage? And was a real estate story not skeptical enough?
comments: ['Quote:  "I found it interesting and informative that Stephens, a Jew [...]" Too bad you didn\'t find it interesting to note that his name is Stephen Miller.', "Good catch. The PE has made a stealth edit correcting Miller's name. More about stealth editing here: Taking the Stealth Out of Editing by Liz Spayd SEPT. 24, 2016 https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/25/public-editor/liz-spayd-new-york-time... 2017-02-20 22:56:21 UTC", "@A. Gideon, Yes! As I said in a comment before, about the same quote: What's allowed to Trump is not allowed to the Public Editor :)", 'One of the less overt but still clear-as-day anti-Trump editorial slants I have seen in the NYT -- especially during the campaign -- lies in the choice of photos you run. You seem to choose those that highlight the man\'s natural lumpishness and teeth-gnashing reactivity. And for that I thank you. I think the NYT has shown great restraint in not covering the front page above the fold with a 9/11-size headline screaming (lamentation and tears), "What Hath God Wrought?". Especially after that shocking "presser" the other day. My jaw was on the floor.', 'There\'s no such thing as too many stories about this administration\'s authoritarianism, racial prejudice and antisemitism, ineptitude, sabre-rattling, scaremongering and general anti-Americanism. It\'s The Times\' duty to write a story about each and every one of Trump\'s missteps, miscalculations and deviations from traditional American (or general human) standards of decency. There is no quota on stories about hatred and stupidity from the top. The only way the NYT can actually serve as "the enemy of the American people" is to back away from this responsibility.', '"... this administration\'s ... antisemitism, ..." Please cite a Times article showing "this administration\'s" "antisemitism".', "people keep saying 'racist',  'anti-semite' but offer no specific examples.  Put a sock in it, already.", '@Sixofone, Trump was right in defining the media as "the enemy of the American people". With all that harm that media brought to the country with all their propaganda, convincing people with their disinformation, distraction and obstruction - they really are now the most dangerous threat to a normal society. For pushing their agenda the media sacrifice anything - people\'s beliefs, people\'s trust, people\'s knowledge of the real state of matters. Immigrants = illegal immigrants; the silence about outrageous Jill Stein\'s attack on the very basics of our democracy; ignoring the fact that Black Lives Matter was born out of the lie of "Hands up, don\'t shoot"; cooked over-sampled polls; endless gossip and unproven accusations starting with lying about Trump\'s mistress and her bathing suit and continuing to BuzzFeed\'s garbage; endorsing the awful and absolutely un-American cries of "Not My President" when there\'s a urgent need for explaining the complete wrongness of this slogan... And, and, and. And all that with the powerful brainwashing effort to claim the media\'s own creation as reality. Of course, the current situation is grave, and threatens to get even worse. The media, please, stop. You\'re ruining the nation.', "Reader RKD wrote: 'I look to The Times to verify Trump stories I've come across elsewhere . . . . It's a main protection against faux news & alternate facts.' Unfortunately, the Times has been caught itself as a purveyor of faux news...I really don't trust NYT coverage, particularly as it concerns politics.", 'I sense the tabloidization of the New York Times is beginning to wane, that it is entering whatever the stage of grief it is that regrets its hysterical reaction to a nomination it felt complicit in bringing about, and then to a disappointing election it did its best to prevent.  Thomas Friedman\'s frantic allusions to Trump\'s election as a Pearl Harbor or a 9/11 represent, I hope, the high-water mark.  The NYT may be feeling the tug, a desire to return to its hard-earned stance as the paper of record. Still, though, there are daily and hilarious slippages, the latest being the enticing headline "Is It Time to Call Trump Mentally Ill?" which, alas, leads the reader into Richard Friedman\'s excoriation of the armchair psychiatry being applied to our, er, colorful new president.  A sensible article with a nutty headline!', 'And of course, the Public Editor takes no issue with any of the proffered explanations, except of course, the one where the NYT was not harsh enough on Trump. In her new role at the Washington Post. former Public Editor Margaret Sullivan has demonstrated that she is just another partisan liberal, Methinks we will learn the same about Ms Spayd in her next job.', '"... and she agreed that both the headline and the bullet summary lacked the necessary clarification of Trump’s intent. Though the tight space makes doing so difficult, she said, it is necessary nonetheless." "Those the tight space makes  doing so difficult...." Who so? It is the "Same" space that would be utilized to run an accurate  Headline and summary. It seems, Jill Taylor has used the same excuses (tight deadlines; tight space) in previous questions about inaccuracies. What is her job exactly when-if she cannot catch vital information like framing an accurate headline to fit the information that follows?', 'Yawn...what else is new? Times editors say everything is journalistically just right. Liz says, "Yep, I pretty much agree." And the commentors\' concerns are rendered editorially of little to no value. Why even bother to write the PE?', 'I know many Americans are in great pain. I think it is time for the gallows humour of a Swift or a Twain. It may be to late to avoid the iceberg a rousing chorus of nearer my God to Thee would be welcome relief.', '"A Trump overdose is a potential hazard to all of us, but this week offered some pretty exceptional journalism. Cheers to the Washington scribes."  Terrific analysis of reader concerns - totally ridiculous. "What’s clear to some readers won’t be to others. In this case, I’m with Thrush."  Only reporting Phil Corbett\'s take and no real discussion of the matter at hand, so once again, little analysis of readers\' concerns. Some public editor.', "What readers are drowning in is the Trump vitriol. Apparently, it's not news to analyze the 23 OTHER executive orders he signed when he issued the travel ban, their intended effects even if the editorial view can't help but intrude to inform us how we all know what the road to hell is paved with. I'd be happy to get honest analysis here instead of needing to go elsewhere for it. The same could be said for legislation being worked in a Republican Congress, on funding, on taxes, on regulation -- instead of this 24x7x52 inundation of anti-Trump invective.", '"... the 23 OTHER executive orders he signed ..." Trump has signed at most 12 Executive Orders. Please explain where you got your number. The White House lists 12: https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/executive-... The Federal Register lists 11: https://www.federalregister.gov/executive-orders/donald-trump/2017 (The missing EO appears to be EO 13772: "Core Principles for Regulating the United States Financial System".) 2017-02-18 02:08:00 UTC', "So you missed the leaked draft executive order drafting the National Guard to be his deportation force in every state om Louisiana to Oregon? Don't worry about that Posse Comitatus stuff. Make America Great Again. We will accomplish that by pushing the price of strawberries to $20/lb. And the first law gotten through Congre$$ is the one rescinding regulations prohibiting dumping of coal ash in rivers. Fortunately for us, it won't impact the Hudson, the Passaic or the Peconic. But those people who voted for Trump are going to be asking for help when, not if, rivers used for potable water sources are fouled as they were in WV and NC. So we the taxpayers will pay the freight for cleanup? You betcha. Where are the wails of socialism? In the Middle East, it's one state, two state, red state, blue state. The master dealcutter will leave it to Bibi and Jared to figure it out. One state? So either Israel disenfranchises the eventual numerical majority of Palestinians, or Israel is no longer a Jewish state. Those options will cause Bibi to pine for the two state days. Trump's gonna cut a deal? Good luck with that. Those evangelicals plumping for the rapture have a leg up.", 'Well, at last some welcome news. And if Chozick needs more time away from writing things in the Times, please be sure to make sure has as much as she needs.', 'One of the problems that I see with the media today is the laser-like focus of the media on all of those things that have little of no news value other than gossip and backstabbing. The NY Times has been one of the leaders in this nonsense. Remember, that "news" is something that affects the lives of people in the present.  Trump discussing pressing matters with his advisers at a shindig at his Mar-la-go mansion in Florida... ...As if Obama or Bush or Clinton or any other president didn\'t discuss state matters at parties and dinners during their terms. I think it is important that the Times\'s staff,  writers, editors and managers alike reacquaint themselves with what their role is supposed to be and ditch all of the snarky overtones and smarmy undertones that have suffused the material that has been published over the past few years. And while the paper is fully entitled to its liberal bias, not presenting the news as news is about as far from journalistic integrity as it gets.', "I'm quoting the consensus of the journalist guests (four of them) at a dinner party immediately after the publication of the Pentagon Papers. Two of the guests were masthead members for their respective news organizations; the other two were house-hold names to most of America. I would more readily take their opinions than yours.  And if you think carefully, the definition I have given is a merely a slightly more precise definition than the Oxford Dictionaries give. You are presenting differences without distinction... But you knew that already and posted anyway.", 'The Owl, where waiters also privy to the discussion about political matters and where aides using their cell phones to get pictures?', "It was a sit-down dinner in our home.   No waiters...well before cell phones.   And these journalists didn't use aides and secretaries to do their work.", 'PE quoting Times reporter Thrush: \'“Do you think it would be appropriate NOT to reference his religion considering Mr. Miller’s relationship with Mr. Spencer, a known white supremacist?” Thrush wrote. “Why deny a reader the important context about Mr. Miller?”\' The Times should require its political reporters and editors to take a course on critical thinking. According to the article, Miller knew Spencer BEFORE Spencer "became a prominent white supremacist". Miller\'s being Jewish is irrelevant AT THE TIME that Miller knew Spencer, because the Times fails to show that Spencer was anti-Semitic AT THE TIME or that Spencer\'s association with Miller CAUSED Spencer to become anti-Semitic. Further, the Times fails to say anything about their current association. All that leads to one conclusion: The Times should not have published the sentence mentioning Spencer. BTW, the Times also fails to say whether "white supremacists" are always anti-Semitic. For the record, this is the article: Stephen Miller Is a ‘True Believer’ Behind Core Trump Policies By GLENN THRUSH and JENNIFER STEINHAUER FEB. 11, 2017 https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/11/us/politics/stephen-miller-donald-tru...', 'Once again, we see two features that are the hallmarks of this public editor. The first is her conservative bent toward Trump. Here we see the public editor making the bizarre and unexplained claim that, "A Trump overdose is a potential hazard to all of us." What "hazard"?  Is Spayd trying to tell The Times not to cover Trump?  Or is she wishing for softer coverage of Trump\'s emerging authoritarianism?  In any event, stating that too much coverage of the Trump administration poses a "hazard to all of us" is ludicrous. Indeed, that claim is so strange that Spayd should publish another column explaining to Times readers exactly what she was inferring. And yet again, we see the public editor doing what she always does: pandering and defending Times management: "...this week offered some pretty exceptional journalism. Cheers to the Washington scribes." "In this case, I’m with (Times reporter Glenn) Thrush." Defend, deflect, move on.', 'It is hard to cover such a fine tuned machine as it sows chaos, but sometimes the Times does itself no favors. The "live analysis" featuring Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman was appallingly bad. And they sat there and made junior high school level snarky comments as a press conference blew up like a poorly regulated pressure cooker. The Times needs to make sure that its coverage is not a profligate waste of readers\' time, as that was. Why not some real time fact checking? As for the citation of the "ten most read articles," all being Washington stories, it\'s a case of self-fulfilling prophesy. If everything across the top of the digital front page is on that topic, it is hard to imagine that those wouldn\'t be the most read articles. There\'s also a question as to how many of those end up on Times listicles under the rubric "recommended for you," or "trending." If there is one book I have no intention of ever buying, or even reading, it would be Amy Chozick\'s account of her 45 month Long March dutifully trudging after Hillary Clinton. From breathlessly chasing the "Scooby van" in Iowa, to being sold a bill of goods by Evil Queen MoDo about Joe Biden challenging Hillary for the Democratic Nomination to fulfill Beau\'s dying wish, there is nothing to recommend this to me. Saving stuff for a book? How about Jim Risen having the warrantless wiretapping story (eventual Pulitzer) spiked by Bill Keller until after W was reelected & Risen told Keller he would break the story in a book?', '"The public editor’s take: The Times stylebook states that “The religion of a person in the news should be mentioned only when it is pertinent and its pertinence is clear to the reader.” Unfortunately, that’s a bit vague. What’s clear to some readers won’t be to others. In this case, I’m with Thrush. As a reader, I found it interesting and informative that Stephens, a Jew, was at one time friendly with a man who emerged later as a white supremacist. " What\'s allowed to Trump is not allowed to the Public Editor.', "I look to The Times to verify Trump stories I've come across elsewhere &, if anything, want more rather than fewer.  It's a main protection against faux news & alternate facts."]
summary: Commenters are skeptical of the Times accusations of the Trump administration being antisemitic and their constant Trump-bashing. Others accuse them of being disassociated with their readers and say the media is the enemy of the people. A commenter defends the Times hateful Trump rhetoric, and another praises their facts.
short_title: Headline: Friday Mailbag: Pink Slip in Washington, Sweepstakes in the Catskills   Keywords: Executive Orders and Memorandums; Immigration and Emigration; Refugees and Displaced Persons; United States Politics and Government; Contests and Prizes; Terrorism; Newspapers; Jews and Judaism; Fringe Groups and Movements; Espionage and Intelligence Services; Frauds and Swindling; New York Times; Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla); Chozick, Amy; Clinton, Hillary Rodham; Trump, Donald J; Spencer, Richard B (1978- ); Miller, Stephen (1985- ); Catskills (NYS Area); Washington (DC)   Snippet: Is The Times drowning readers in Trump coverage? Or does the capital turmoil merit the coverage? And was a real estate story not skeptical enough?
subreddit: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Terrorism', 'Newspapers', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'New York Times', 'Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla)', 'Chozick, Amy', 'Clinton, Hillary Rodham', 'Trump, Donald J', 'Spencer, Richard B (1978- )', 'Miller, Stephen (1985- )', 'Catskills (NYS Area)', 'Washington (DC)']
short_question: ['Friday Mailbag: Pink Slip in Washington, Sweepstakes in the Catskills  ']

query: Andre Twendele survived a firing squad and years in a refugee camp. He won a visa and left his wife in the camp to prepare for her arrival in America. Then Trump was elected.
comments: ['Perhaps he should have taken his wife and gone elsewhere?', 'And why does the Villacas family , profiled in another article,  have to leave?They are contributing greatly to our economy. How does the deportation of the parents make anything better for anyone?', 'Mr Twendele sounds like he\'d be an asset anywhere in the world. I wish him well, & hope he changes him mind about 8 children. But it\'s disingenuous for the media to keep repeating the very carefully-worded claim that this article makes:  "...since the current vetting system was put into place in 1980, no refugee has committed a deadly terrorist attack on American soil." That\'s true but only in the strictest sense.  Though no deadly terrorist attack has been committed on American soil by anyone who has come into the US as a refugee under the umbrella of the UNHCR-USRAP (the official United States Refugee Admissions Program), deadly terrorist attacks on US soil have indeed been committed by de facto refugees who\'ve come to the US other ways.  For example, the Tsarnaev brothers, who bombed the Boston Marathon, came to the US as kids with their parents, who had tourist visas.  Once here, the family applied for asylum.  Most people would call them "refugees" even though they are, strictly speaking, asylees. Children of people who\'ve come into the US as, broadly speaking, refugees also have committed acts of deadly terror in the US. Omar Mateen, the terrorist shooter in Orlando, is the son of an Afghan who came to the US in the 1980s under unclear circumstances.  But, broadly speaking, dad was a "refugee." And there\'s been many cases of terrorism OVERSEAS involving people who are either USRAP refugees themselves, or their parents are - especially among Somali refugees.', 'Great reporting on a most touching story.  It is pure hubris for Trump, Kelly, Miller, et al., to think they are morally superior to such people.  I pray that Mr. Twendele is swiftly united with his wife.', 'Eight children? Do they not realize that the reason there is so much poverty and lack of opportunity in their own country is why they are refugees now? That an uneducated citizenry cannot adequately educate those who follow and will always be dependent on the dictators who only take care of their followers? We have a responsibility to care for our own citizens first!', 'Please try to remember: "Whatsoever you do to the least of my brothers, that you do onto Me."', 'He was studying law in Africa and has a degree from Regis University in Denver.  I would not consider that uneducated.  Sadly he is working in a fish market; work that many Americans are not willing to do.', "I cannot help but to compare Mr. Twendele coming from a country that Trump has another name for to followers of Roy Moore were that same name slang name could be applied to. Immigrants are what has made this country great all races, all ethnicity and from all the lands of the earth is America's wealth. Sure there is the occasional bad apple like Trumps family coming here but by and large immigrants through out our history have and will make America great again.", "So the solution to poverty and corruption in  Africa is massive immigration to America.  This is not a tenable solution.  America is already the third most populous country after China and India. Immigration cannot solve the world's problems.", 'The list of "Most populous countries" is a list of absolute population numbers, not population relative to square miles.  You went from the intimate portrait of the single couple portrayed in the article to "massive immigration to America".   We may not be able to solve all the world\'s problems but if we can solve some of them, we are ethically required to do so.', 'Mr. Katz is an amazing writer. This moved me. The times could use some more well rounded writers. Please feature more of his articles.', "I'm not really interested in the problems or life story of Mr. Twendele; there are over 7 billion stories in the world and the only ones I care about are the 320 million or so native born American ones.", 'God bless you, Mr. Twendele.   Thank you for coming to America!  We look forward to you and your beautiful wife becoming American citizens.', '8 kids on an $11 an hour wage. Yeah, that’s a good plan.', 'He may not stay an "$11 an hour" worker - his academic record shows a hard worker and a college degree.   And I think the "8 kids" was aspirational and an expression of love and confidence in the future, and not necessarily a plan.', 'Thank you for this touching, terrifying, and important article.  I recommend a wonderful film about refugees to our country trying to build a new life:  The Good Lie (2014).', 'May your dreams come true, Mr. Twendele.', 'Whatever happened to the "city upon a hill", with "the eyes of all people" on us? Why do Americans feel satisfaction or even pride in what Trump says about immigrants from Africa and Haiti? Wait, don\'t answer that!', 'Mr. Twendele is exactly the kind of person we need in America.', '"Ms. Lukoji longs to leave not just to reunite with her husband; her health depends on it, too. She has blocked fallopian tubes, a painful condition that has left her infertile, according to a gynecologist whom she sees in Lilongwe, Malawi’s capital. Their hopes for children — Mr. Twendele wants as many as eight — now rests in the United States, with in vitro fertilization." So a few days ago, we had the lady with the seven children and a heart condition, now we have a man who wants eight children and fertility treatments.  Give me a break NYT\'s.  Let\'s treat the kid in Chicago with asthma, and the retiree in Florida, before we allow another refugee in.  There are a million Mr. Twendele\'s, it is unfair to all of them that he gets in and they can\'t.   Further, "The job of resettling new Americans falls on designated nonprofit agencies like the International Rescue Committee, which the State Department pays $2,125 per refugee to cover resettlement expenses, like a security deposit for an apartment and a few days of food in the refrigerator, as well as administrative costs...The I.R.C. also holds classes to familiarize refugees with the complexities of New Jersey Transit and the welfare system." I don\'t think homeless people in my state get resettlement expenses or help with  the welfare system and they are Americans.  These articles are ridiculous.  This isn\'t 1872 or 1945.  There are 7 million souls on this planet who have too many children that they can\'t afford to feed.', '"The job of resettling new Americans" These are not "Americans". They are foreigners living here with government permission. Americans are citizens. When I go to the Congo for business I am an American visiting the Congo not a Congolese.', "Mr. Twendele, you have accomplished the first step and made the voyage to America.  In Ancient days of Greek Mythology, there was a hero, his name was Ulysses, and your story in some ways is similar to his.  You are stronger than you realize, more resilient than many of us, you speak a second language, you are still young. As you know from experience now, America has a large African Community, and let us remember, as a friend from Ghana, and another from Western French Africa, both young grandmothers reminded this American recently, this president will go. A friend from France when she was your wife's age took her religious vows and became a doctor.  She has her clinic now and the program is to help couples who wish to have a family.  I bring this up, because it is to show that there are often links to be found, bringing us together. Bien a vous, Mr. Twendele, and to your wife, wishing you many bright dawns on your continuing life travels together.", 'Beyond heartbreaking, and beyond belief that human beings in the 21st century are forced to live in this manner.  Their personal courage in the face of unspeakable horror shames the spineless majority of the American Congress.', "They aren't forced to live in this manner, they choose to live that way because they produce too many children that they cannot feed, house or educate. Why should we allow them to come here with these notions and turn our country into the same places they left?"]
summary: Commentators are split between pro- and anti-immigration stances. Many commentators praise Mr. Twendele and his courage in raising such a large family. Many other commentators come out swinging against him being in the country, basically saying that we should take care of our own first before giving money or space to foreigners. A few commentators note that Mr. Twendele is poor and shouldn't have so many children that he can't care for. A few other commentators fight back against the anti-immigration commentary.
short_title: Headline: Leaving Africa, and Living in Limbo   Keywords: Immigration and Emigration; Visas; Homeland Security Department; Trump, Donald J; United States Politics and Government; Elizabeth (NJ)   Snippet: Andre Twendele survived a firing squad and years in a refugee camp. He won a visa and left his wife in the camp to prepare for her arrival in America. Then Trump was elected.
subreddit: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Homeland Security Department', 'Trump, Donald J', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elizabeth (NJ)']
short_question: ['Leaving Africa, and Living in Limbo  ']

query: Rail bosses have sidelined the Teesside Airport rail station for years, but retain the zombie station that symbolizes the dysfunctions of Britain’s transportation network.
comments: ['For those interested in the really esoteric side of UK transport, I have two words: Mornington Crescent.', "Holy cow - I can't believe I made a mistake like that.  Thanks for correcting my geography.  This is what happens when someone like me takes a bus tour - not really paying attention to the town and scenery, per se, just the destination (i.e., Leeds Castle).  Thanks again for the correction.  Much appreciated.", 'I passed this station many times on the way to Darlington, even before the airport opened and the station was Middleton St. George.  The "airport" was a converted RAF base that had only done general aviation and air shows before the Great Amalgamation of the local towns into "Teesside".  Gotta have an airport, right, even if Newcastle and Leeds are going to be only an hour\'s drive away once the motorway is complete.  Teesside bit the dust and the airport followed suit.  Ironically the main destination for flights was the sunny Mediterranean, thus helping to impoverish the previously healthy coastal resort towns nearby.  Steel and chemical industries died out, and even North Sea Oil couldn\'t save this part of the country (London sucks up all the wealth anyway).  The main objection of the locals now is that they don\'t want to be the dormitory for Darlington.  That\'s life.', 'I wonder about the tower operations and what kind of tower they have for landing aircraft on that long runway: The infrastructure for a long runway most surely overwhelms The complexity of measly train stop; runway lights that need to be replaced, automatic equipment maintenance that is prescribed by most aviation rules.  Even though this tower may be automated, standalone so that a single aircraft pilot simply triggers his microphone button a couple times, This is expensive equipment that needs routine Scheduled maintenance; Where does the money for this come from?', 'Unused land worth a fortune if turned into housing, but lot of people to fight against it… Alongside mismanaged and decrepit infrastructure that is also quite classic UK. I wonder how the country would be doing without its oil and gas resources (about half its consumption) and without its fiscal/legal havens (from the City to the more obvious oversea territories). Not that it is so brilliant currently.', 'Here is an amusing story about my friend (and teacher) Georg Kreisel.  He used to teach at the University of Reading and used to take a train to London.  But somehow the schedule was changed and Reading was no longer officially on the schedule. However, the train did stop in Reading to take water, and Kreisel made it a practice to get on the train as before. On one occasion, the ticket conductor said to Kreisel, "You are not supposed to be here."  The ever so cheeky Kreisel said, "Then I am not  here."', 'Subtle British humor… I’m still folded over bellowing laughter!', 'Excellent article. I had not heard about this station, but now I have it seems typical of the somewhat erratic and incomprehensible thinking behind railways by successive governments. Whereas other counties and towns cry out for improved rail services (to undo some of the now-superseded logic behind the Beeching Axe), this humdrum, lonesome station remains. But, it is best if one keeps it succinct, as it’s best not to get started talking about railway ownership and ticket prices as I shall be here all day ranting away.', 'Conductor has a good sense of humor. (humour over there).', "It's the North.  You have to have a sense of humo(u)r up there.", "“Teesside Airport station . . . facilities are minimal — two platforms, linked by a footbridge supported by scaffolding; a shelter; and a pay phone, a relic of the era when this station was used regularly.” I did not spot one pay phone in any of the iconic red phone booths while in London and yet, one still exists and apparently works at this rail station.  Who even carries change in their pocket anymore and more importantly, who can recall one single phone number without the assistance of their l-phone? Conductor Sally Holtham's sense of humor was priceless when she asked that pointless question of “Would you like a single or a return ticket?” the first time she sold any tickets from Teesside Airport.    After reading this article, it makes me wanting to return to my husband’s homeland, stop at Leeds, see the castle and then take this wonderful little train expedition.  If this scenario doesn’t speak of one of England’s more enchanting excursions, what does?  And I’m not even a rail enthusiast.", "Er, Leeds Castle is in Kent!  But you could go to Castleford (which doesn't have a castle either).", '"Yet the various rail authorities cannot agree to close Teesside Airport rail, preferring to retain a zombie station that has come to symbolize some of the dysfunctions of Britain’s transport network." But couldn\'t one also way that the dysfunctions of Britain\'s transport network pale in comparison to the dysfunctions of our transport network, especially our rail "network?"', "I suspect your point was so obvious it wasn't worth bringing up.", 'The difference is that the UK is much denser, cities are not as far apart, and gas is much more expensive, making it much easier to have an efficient network competing with driving your car (or taking a bus). Also the UK inherited a wide network from its old times. It should be much cheaper to renovate old lines than to build new ones (if only because you already have the land). The problem is that the public management of the network was incredibly bad (and remember the UK used to be pretty much a socialist economy before Thatcher); and unfortunately people who are bad at managing a network will also be bad at designing a system where the private sector will act in the public interest (which is tremendously complicated). They just replaced one bad for another, but I wouldn’t bet the new one is worse than the old one.', 'Unlike a properly funded government, the private sector does not act in the public interest. The privately operated railway in the article is in business for profit and thus does not wish to devote any of its resources to serving a small town, due to the declining number of paying customers.', 'How did I miss this gem?? I just finished spending 6 months last summer and fall in beautiful England. With time on my hand, got to travel length and breadth of this beautiful country. And the railways were a large part. Sure, the red are issues, but for the most part, all lines except the Southern Line are wonderful to ride. I also liked the Virgin trains - they are fast. My only issue with Virgin is their compartments remind you of an airplane - cramped. The other annoying thing was the "quiet" zones invaded by parents with small children. You cannot blame the kids but these parents, what are they thinking?? It\'s almost a child abuse to expect them to keep quiet. Some railway stations are so beautiful maintained with flowers and colors - almost to come out of some Hollywood movie. One thing you must try are toilets in Virgin. You should read what it warns you about NOT discarding in the toilet. Only Brits can have that sense of humor. Provided you can travel off peak and if you have a Senior discount card - it\'s almost a crime to drive there.', 'You probably missed the Will Ferrell instructions which started playing in Virgin train loos before Christmas. A little bizarre! As you unlocked the door, he says, ‘The door’s unlocked - go! You’re free!’', 'The name "Virgin," in Virgin Airlines, refers to the Virgin Islands tax haven which Branson and other kleptocrats use to offshore their wealth and the profits of their businesses. Nonpayment of corporate taxes is having the effect of defunding public services, such as railroads and the NHS, thus subjecting them to selloff to private owners, such as Branson.', 'Entirely untrue.  Read the history of Virgin Records.', 'Nice try, but Branson got his start selling vinyl records by mail-order under the name "Virgin" long before he qualified for the zillionaires club.', "I lived in that part of the world in the 60s,when Imperial Chemical Industries, ICI, now defunct, was one of the major employers in the area, as well the major steel producers, The late Prime Minister of britain, Harold McMillan, was once the member of parliament for Stockton on Tees, the nearest town.  My memories of the airport are when it was an RAF station, having been an airport since the time of the war. When it was first converted to civilian use the officers mess was the passenger terminal. Nearby was one of the better golf courses in the area, well used by RAF personnel. I never did understand why the railway to the airport was created. Lord Beeching, ironically an ex-ICI board member, had close almost all the small line in the 60s. In addition, the creation of the airport was seen as a means of getting to the area, by air and car, not by trian.  Interesting article, chimes well with the other item in today's edition, about the mess that privatisation is in in the UK.", 'And former Prime Minister Tony Blair was MP for the constituency of Sedgefield - which just happened to encompass this very location.', 'If there was better service people would use it. Instead of lonely possibly underused is a better word. There are lots of other even smaller more remote stations in the UK that have one train a week so that private rail companies can keep their service contracts. Its really sad that England has let rail disintegrate.', 'I fondly remember BritRail, in those heady days before Maggie Thatcher.  Pretty-much the equal of present-day train service on the continent (yes, slower), you could get conveniently to almost any part of the UK.  And then the Privatization Bug hit.  Just like the airlines.  Sigh.', "Rose colored glasses at their best.  Basically if you wanted to go somewhere via London you were in great shape.  Getting from the east coast to the west coast was a different matter, not helped by the topography.  London to Glasgow could be so fast you could almost use it to commute, but anywhere in between and you'd be stopping at every lamp post.", 'Having used a $600 Eurorail pass at The time of fissionable Chernobyl, I managed to get away to anywhere I did/didn’t want to go on the continent; Hop on, flash the pass, and sit down for the comfortable excursion to… Wherever (south France to n.. Sweden & Ireland), and had a seamless experience traveling on rail/ferry boat services of every country, except private lines in Switzerland.', 'oh yes, I experienced a strike in Holland: it was a five or 10 minute strike that involves all the conductors and other personnel to walk out and assemble outside Central Station for few minutes of Speech and protest, and then hurry back to work to get the next train on it’s way; This was called a “strike”']
summary: Commenters' perspectives on the story are split. Some commenters revel in the nostalgia of the rail system of Britain, while others see it as a relic of a foregone era that should be done away with. One commenter tells a story about a teacher getting on the train at Reading, despite it not being on the schedule anymore.
short_title: Headline: Zombie Station Lacks Trains but Attracts Enthusiasts   Keywords: Railroads; Infrastructure (Public Works); England; Great Britain   Snippet: Rail bosses have sidelined the Teesside Airport rail station for years, but retain the zombie station that symbolizes the dysfunctions of Britain’s transportation network.
short_question: ['Zombie Station Lacks Trains but Attracts Enthusiasts  ']

query: An error in a politics story and anonymity in a story about The Metropolitan Museum led to emails from readers.
comments: ["Aren't pop-up adds tailored to the browsing history of the person reading the web page. Is there something Don and David would like to tell us?", 'PE: "... images of barely clad women ..." Not to defend the ads, but the "bride" appears to be fully "clad" by modern standards. See the second photo in this Times Wedding Album: Dresses Our Brides Have Worn By CHARANNA ALEXANDER APRIL 4, 2017 https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/fashion/weddings/dresses-our-brides-h...', 'PE: "... readers ... questioned the reporter’s understanding of basic Senate rules." The PE\'s office is repeating another mistake. The US Constitution specifies that the Vice President breaks tied votes in the Senate, not a "Senate rule". Perhaps everyone at the Times should be required to read the US Constitution. Article I, Section 3: "The Vice President of the United States shall be President of the Senate, but shall have no Vote, unless they be equally divided." https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/constitution-transcript', 'very gallant of mike tackett to take full responsibility for the mistake regarding pence. however, if the reporter had not made the mistake he would have nothing to take the blame for. odd that the reporter is not named or quoted.', 'Estimates are that 70 million people use ad blockers.  With even "serious" sites like the NYT using so called programmatic ads that number will only be going higher.   Time to find a different revenue model than half naked women on the front page.', 'A couple of questions, Ms Spayd.  First, you have refused to answer the question of whether you actually read emails coming into the public editor\'s email, or whether you read only those emails that are "surfaced" for your attention by your assistant.  Times readers deserve a response and a clarification.  We are, after all, the people whom you are charged with representing to Times management. Further, this "Friday Mailbag" includes a response to emails coming in from "conservative news outlets."  You give the appearance, Ms Spayd, of paying inordinate deference to conservative media, including recently those generated from alt-right conspiracy theorist Mike Cernovich, but little attention to the concerns of those who are not conservative.   Please tell us why. Last question: Why are you wasting space with a column on sports coverage when there are far more important topics for the Public Editor to cover?  Is this more fluff in lieu of substance from the PE?', 'The Met story was just another of the zillion Times "last resort" use of anonymous sourcing. So was the Pogrebin story linked to in the one in question here. “If you’re not on the executive committee, you don’t know anything,” said a trustee, who insisted on anonymity because board members have been warned against speaking publicly. “You’re expected to work and give, but not to question what goes on.” Most of the Board members are rich philanthropists. Do we think they would really be tossed aside if they went public in their criticism? Times standards supposedly say "We resist granting anonymity for opinion, speculation or personal attacks." What would remain of these two articles if those standards were ever upheld? Do Times editors never learn to cast a skeptical eye on sources with an agenda seeking anonymous cover? Seemingly not.', 'Quote from article: "... said a trustee, who insisted on anonymity because board members have been warned against speaking publicly." That rationale has another problem -- it doesn\'t say who "warned" the trustee "against speaking publicly". That makes it a double-anony. :-) Quote from article: \'Another trustee said, “Few people have spoken up in a meeting for about 40 years.”\' In addition to being vaguely sourced, that quote is absurd. How old would a trustee have to be to remember meetings from 40 years ago?', "There are a lot of old money New Yorkers who are multigenerational charitable board members. How old? Didn't Brooke Astor live to be 105?", '"These embarrassing ads are called “programmatic” which means that computers and algorithms conduct the transactions between advertisers and publishers like The Times, rather than real people. This means the advertising department doesn’t see the ads until they’re up on the site." So is there a reason why the Times feels like it must go along with not seeing ads until they\'re, um, busting out all over? The Times seems blissfully unaware that it can set the parameters for ads in its own digital space.  As for not knowing the rules surrounding the Vice President\'s role as a $enate tiebreaker, only one editor was there to take ownership? Did the story get by a copy editor? My brother has done that for 40 years at the Baltimore Sun, and I guarantee he would have caught the mistake. Let\'s go back to Spayd\'s column of early February about the coming brave new world of Times editing, and how many fewer eyes will sçan a story. Can we say that this was an entirely foreseeable consequence of a benighted business decision? As I said then, view editing not as a cost without tangible benefit; see editing as an investment in quality assurance protecting the Times\' reputation. That can actually be seen as an asset line on a balance sheet, often labeled as "good will." The Times willingly destroys its own reputation and concomitant "good will." Just stop that, OK?', 'Maybe the Times should put one of its excellent investigative reporters on this banner ad problem. Get the crew who cracked the medical coding system.  Surely they can get to the bottom of why "programmatic" advertisers are unable to write algorithms that align with Times publication standards. The lede could point out the Orwellian flavor of "programmatic," that would be a nice touch.', 'The handling of the politics story regarding the VP\'s vote in the Senate was simply appalling all the way around. Let me count the ways:  1) It is INEXCUSABLE that a Washington correspondent for the NYTimes not understand the role of the Vice President in the Senate. The reporter is ignorant of US constitution/government basics. Why should I believe anything he writes dealing with government/legislation?  2)  The reaction of his boss, deputy bureau chief Tackett, essentially dismissing it as \'my bad" is also utterly UNACCEPTABLE. He\'s a manager in the Washington office of what is supposed to be one of the premier US newspapers. He didn\'t catch the error? It should have leaped off the page at him. More ignorance.  3) The PE\'s reaction, \'a civics lesson for all...\' is also unacceptable. She should have taken them to task for not knowing/understanding 5th grade US history. It\'s not something to laugh off. It\'s really pathetic.', 'What about the use of the verb "swept" in the piece about Pence?  It has a negative connotation compared to, let us say, "entered". I write this not as a fan of Mike Pence (I loathe most of his policies) but as a fan of the NYT (I love most of its reporting).', 'No coverage here about the appalling Eduardo Porter article which buys into the wishful magic thinking that climate can be fixed by making things worse. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/business/economy/geoengineering-clima...  "To Curb Global Warming, Science Fiction May Become Fact" Eduardo Porter, April 4, 2017 He\'s worried sick - as he should be, and as I am - by climate inaction, but the "solutions" posed by popular geoengineering wishful thinking and other futurism excuses (we\'ll all get rich and we can fix it then, hooey!) and idealism about nuclear (yes, we need nuclear, but people are afraid of it and it costs a bundle, let alone we\'re way behind with it even it was practical) and carbon capture (way expensive, and pilot projects aren\'t going well, just think of the volume) are not helping. For a skilled review of the problem, here: "Climate Hacking Is Barking Mad: You can’t fix the Earth with these geoengineering proposals, but you can sure make it worse"  http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2015/02/nrc_geo... RayPierre (the author, "hacking" and "barking mad" nails it in a nutshell) is a well respected climate scientist. I have it from a friend more skilled than myself that the conference Mr. Porter was a fringe group of enthusiasts and the "research" wasn\'t properly vetted. Mr. Porter reported their conclusions without sourcing them properly, as if they were fact.', 'The public editor has swept out some of the debris in the corners of the paper, but surely there are some more significant issues with Times coverage (lack of coverage) than a few misplaced ads and poor word choices?!??', "The advertising department doesn't see the ads until they're up on the site.  How are you sure it is only a few misplaced ads?  By design, no one knows what is in the ad pipeline.", "Hi Lynn: I don't know how many ads were involved or how pernicious they may be. I simply think the Public Editor is dwelling upon minutiae here, and in fact most of the time,  and not upon the execution of the very important mission of the New York Times as an informative and in-depth purveyor of important news.", "The error regarding Pence's function is significant because it looks like he will be called on often to perform this task. (And NOW maybe some readers are reminded that there is more to the federal government than the presidency, and why it's important to vote in those down-ticket races, not just for 'the first black president' or against Trump or to cast a third-party protest vote.) The reporter's slip is therefore distressing; it's vital that readers understand what hath the ballot box wrought, and, in a House so evenly split, just how much de facto power the eminence grise Pence stands to wield. The popular understanding of civics is deficient as it is, without casual readers stumbling on an error in the NYT and possibly internalizing it.", 'If Thomas Campbell had been running this greatest of cultural institutions -- in my mind, superior even to the Louvre and the British Museum -- as it should have been run, I think no one would have minded that he had a relationship with a female employee.  But anyone who\'s visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art in recent years has sensed that things haven\'t been going well. Between the Met Breuer, an unnecessary expense given that New York City boasts the Guggenheim, the Whitney, and MOMA; silly new signage ("Masterpieces of Native American Art"; well, what else would the Met show? The worst?); even a decline in the quality of sandwich and hors d\'oeuvres offerings in the American Wing and the balcony; as well as guards often clustered about talking to one another -- a sure sign of dysfunction at the top -- it\'s obvious that something\'s afoot.  Mr. Campbell was probably a good tapestry curator, and his boyish, British good looks might have suited some of the Trustees; but he had no experience running an institution -- any at all, let alone the biggest and most complex cultural institution in the country.  (Let\'s just hope that the Trustees do not select, this time, someone like the Brooklyn Museum\'s Arnold Lehman or its new head. This once splendid museum has become a glorified community center, its great works of art stored to make way for hip-hop displays, craft shows, and desperately jumbled "blue" exhibits. No wonder attendance has been down.)', "As far as the museum piece goes, what struck me was not the issue of the tabloid nature of some of the writing in the article, but the underlying issue of incompetence that routinely crops up in articles about museums of this size. They have all had their scandals with directors and boards, for different reasons. What is it about high-end museum culture that makes it such a victim of the Peter Principle? Why aren't boards hiring the right people? That, to me, is where the story lies. The failure starts at the top, with aging, entrenched, wealthy board members who don't know squit from squat.", "Keeping abreast of all the news that's fit to print."]
summary: Several commenters highlight that there are some serious issues in hiring of management, which show themselves in the advertising as well as the quality and content of the writing. Another suggested that mismanagement of the museum was also contributing to public opinion about it. One suggests that such stories are a desperate attempt for attention, regardless of the sources' motives.
short_title: Headline: Friday Mailbag: Senate Votes and Museum Drama   Keywords: Online Advertising; Computers and the Internet; United States Politics and Government; Newspapers; Transgender and Transsexuals; Privacy; Libel and Slander; Museums; Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US); Correction Stories; News and News Media; Metropolitan Museum of Art; New York Times; Rose, Isabel; United States   Snippet: An error in a politics story and anonymity in a story about The Metropolitan Museum led to emails from readers.
subreddit: ['Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Newspapers', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Privacy', 'Libel and Slander', 'Museums', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Correction Stories', 'News and News Media', 'Metropolitan Museum of Art', 'New York Times', 'Rose, Isabel', 'United States']
short_question: ['Friday Mailbag: Senate Votes and Museum Drama  ']

query: In this podcast, investigative reporter Matt Apuzzo talks about how he reported a story about a cigarette smuggling scam that involved government agents.
comments: ['Gender  bias in Dallas is their latest !!!!!   Too bad this is approved.  Who can you trust?', 'The ATF needed to be reorganized after the debacle in Waco with the  renegade religious group in  which 4 ATF agents were killed in a botched raid.  They then laid siege on the group for nearly 2 months  until the ATF set fire to the compound and there were many deaths of the group .  For those who are unaware of history google  Branch Davidian. Stunts like this to raise money for who knows who indicates something very fishy in this governmental agency. Donald, you  should have the FBI and an Inspector General look into this. Maybe the Federal Reserve  needs to look also if illegal bank accounts were used.   As Deepthroat said in Watergate : FOLLOW THE MONEY   !!', 'A bunch of people (farmers ..manufacturers and retail stores in particular) who spend their entire day trying to figure out how to make more money sickening and killing people .. not a very sympathetic class.', '"“It’s totally illegal," says Apuzzo. “But it’s a great way for criminals, terrorists and mobsters to fund their activities — so great, in fact, that the A.T.F. said we should maybe do the same thing.”"  — Wait, so a law enforcement agency suggested breaking the law? Did I read that right?', 'Does this even REALLY surprise anybody?  These are all money-grubbing, elected or employed government employees......it is all they know how to do.  Go back and read the history books and you will see that such conduct is more commonplace than not.   "government wrong-doing" seems to be such a common phrase nowadays.....is there any other kind?', 'Yes, there is.  Big Business wrong doing.  To the tune of billions.', "Aren't they kinda on the same team. Didn't Dennis Hastert make millions coaching a high school wrestling team? Bidness and guvment. Paul Ryan doesn't have that spring in his step because he's cuttins taxes on po folk, It's the jingle in his pocket from cutting taxes on the rich. Bidness and guvment."]
summary: Several of the commenters criticize the ATF or disparage government employees more broadly. One of these says the ATF should have been reorganized after the Waco "debacle." The user who disparages government officials call them "money-hungry" and mentions Paul Ryan, saying he is making money on giving rich people tax cuts. One even ties this to farmers, manufacturers, and retail stores overall, saying they are "not a very sympathetic class." One person also mentions gender bias in Dallas.
short_title: Headline: Matt Apuzzo: How an Investigative Reporter Got His Story   Keywords: Smuggling; Smoking and Tobacco; Podcasts; Virginia; Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms; Frauds and Swindling; Racketeering and Racketeers; Burger King Corp   Snippet: In this podcast, investigative reporter Matt Apuzzo talks about how he reported a story about a cigarette smuggling scam that involved government agents.

query: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon reveal a miracle.
comments: ["Very late to this acrostic, and it's just as well, as I wasn't on its wavelength AT ALL! and had very little on the first pass--DREYFUS, ASPIRIN, GEOMETER. I wanted CORPSMAN instead of CHAPLAIN and should have known the Roy Orbison but just couldn't think of it. I ended up revealing four (count 'em, 4!) words and it was still a slog. So I guess I had a big blind spot on this one.", 'A lovely acrostic that – in retrospect - was harder for me than it should have been. As usual, I was short on gimmes: only DREIFUS, MACARONI and GUTLESS and the partials: FEET (I wasn’t sure about ITCHY) and NITY (which could have been preceded by INFI as well as ETER). Moreover, I guessed BADMINTON before TRIATHLON and CYPRESS before ARBUTUS.  I needed a look-up and chose Clue  N: (ITS OVER) which I knew would be out of my wheelhouse. Returning to the citation, I saw a possible EYE and then BLIND. This gave me confidence that both of the long words were PERCEIVING. From then on, toggling between clue list and answer grid sufficed to correct my bad guesses and complete the solution.', 'To all who are looking for the variety puzzles and answers: From your computer or device, you can go to the NYT puzzles website at: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/index.html?page=home&_r=0 There you will find links to the most recent variety puzzles which include the Spelling Bee and other fun stuff. When you click on the one of your choice, it will give you the option of getting the puzzle or the answers (published the following Thursday, I believe).  It will take only a little effort on your part. I find it easy. For the fastest access, you can bookmark or get the app icon on your desktop or device. Enjoy.', 'Thank you, Beejay.', 'I expect that the folks asking for the puzzles are not digital puzzle subscribers, and so they cannot do this (not that I think they should have free access to the puzzles in the first place). And the folks asking for the answers probably are digital puzzle subscribers who hope to see the answers the print subscribers have already seen.', 'I\'m sure that what they do in Hogwarts is "apparate" - so is the process "apparition" or what I had for a long time, "apparation"? After a long time away from solving Acrostics online, I tried it again for this puzzle. I find the navigation process tedious and the solve unsatisfyingly quick / automatized. I realize many solvers have posted here about loving doing the Acrostics online, and for the same reasons that they love it, I really don\'t. I\'ll continue doing these on paper, it is so much more satisfying to watch things unfold.', 'I was just about to post on the "APPARITION" matter, but you beat me to it! I filled in "APPARATING" which turned out to be wrong by 3 letters....but only if "APPARITION" is what the professors at Hogwarts actually called it. You can see an apparition, but if you disappear suddenly and travel to a new place, you have not traveled by apparition -- you have apparated.', 'This quote solved very quickly for me. I started with DREYFUS, APPARITION, VIEWPOINT, and TRIATHLON. Then in the quote, blind spot came very quickly as did the your, you, and you\'re words. I must have been in the "zone" for this one. Most of the word list came to me soon as well as big chunks of the quote.  Did not know ARBUTUS and EREWHON, but they filled in. The power of the brain is so interesting. Thanks for this quote.', 'gimmes include itchy feet, Dreyfus, observant, on fire, and luch hour. got the yous right away. took longer than usual for some reason.', 'My gimmes were DREYFUS, EREWHON (which for about 50 years I\'ve promised myself to read), ON FIRE and NEOPHYTE. Had to Google for Death Wish, geometer and It\'s Over. Several "your" words in the answer helped. Very good puzzle.', 'I continue to wonder why the Spelling Bee answers are not listed anymore. Have I missed an announcement/explanation? Thanks!', 'Yes, Deb explained that those posts will be discontinued as the amount of work they took each week was not justified by the scant attention they received. If you want to know what words you might have missed, this site works well: litscape.com/word_tools/words_made_from.php', 'Thank you!', "Can someone please explain the vowels out puzzle to me? I don't understand the explanation given. Usually I find the explanations easy to follow, but this time I'm left completely flummoxed as to what I'm supposed to do...", 'The answers are strings of consonants. The same string of consonants is an answer to two different clues. "current month" & "danger" would both be answered by PRL, for example, fleshing out those consonants with different vowels in different places. I hope that helps.', 'I totally missed the fact that we have to come up with answers to the clues, which then get reduced, rather than directly reducing the clues themselves. I know it said that in the instructions but just totally missed it. Makes sense now. Thanks!', 'Nicely challenging Bee!', 'DREYFUS and TRIATHLON were my only gimmes.   I had travel bug for ITCHY FEET (perhaps caused by a travel bug).  This took me almost twice my typical solve time.  It was a nice workout.', 'VOWELS OUT caused some consternation. Kept thinking "dinnerware" and "lunch hour" before giving up.', '[SPOILER ALERT] SPARE TIME/ASPARTAME PORCELAIN/PRICELINE (DINNERWARE has 10 letters; the clue said 9) I also was not able to get ASPARTAME and PRICELINE without searching. What a coincidence regarding LUNCH HOUR! It was one of the Acrostic answers.', 'Tried juniper before the correct answer filled itself in.  EC & HR are amazing.  NOWHERE else can you have such such a good time.', 'Jerrold, could you post the spelling bee letters and target scores?  Thanks!', 'Never mind, found it on the other blog comments: U in the center A E I M R T in the surrounding circle 9 good 16 excellent 23 genius', 'Vowels Out was a “middle” puzzle that was new and different, reminiscent of the Vowelless Crosswords. [SPOILER ALERT] My first few answers were gimmes, but then I had to search for ASPARTAME, PRICELINE and BOOGIE BOARD. (For the latter I first got MALIBU BOARD on my own, but then realized that it had six consonants.)', 'I have already communicated with Deb about the apparent major glitch on Thursday night. The puzzles did not go up until the next morning.  [MAJOR SPOILER ALERT] My gimmes this time were DREYFUS, NEOPHYTE, GEOMETER and CHAPLAIN. I searched to find APPARITION, NAUTILUS, IT’S OVER, TRIATHLON and ASPIRIN. (The search for the last one also gave me SALICIN, which I tried at first on the idea that maybe ASPIRIN was too easy.) I first had CHICKEN for the “cowardly” synonym. I should have realized that that was too childish. There always has to be at least one trick. “Tubes”, yeah! Sometimes filling in the grid has its own pitfalls. For awhile I had “Your brain gets no information from ………” instead of “Your brain, WITH no information from ………”.', 'Jerrold,  My gimmes were exactly the same as yours!  Plus ASPIRIN, which I misspelled as ASPERIN, duh. No lookups today.  Thought it was pretty easy, with repeated words in the quote.', "The PDF puzzles were there Thursday night, but the on-screen links to them were not.  I just edited the links for last week's puzzles to change Mar26 to Apr02 and was able to retrieve and print them out."]
summary: People are commenting on the results of their puzzles, some saying it was difficult to get the words right. One commenter suggested the NYT puzzle website, which also has an app, for those who wanted a greater variety of games.
short_title: Headline: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles; Acrostic Puzzles   Snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon reveal a miracle.
short_question: ['Variety Puzzle: Acrostic  ']

query: A restaurant in Woodside, Queens, trades in the keyed-up spicing of the Himalayas.
comments: ['Kool. I see these dishes are not cheese deprived. :)', 'This was so fascinating. Makes me want to go and also to learn more about Bhutan. Excellent mix of restaurant review/travel writing (w/in NY!)/anthropology. Thank you!', 'Great review.', 'Ms. Mishan, Oh, where did you find this special treat?  While perhaps not a fan of pool or Snooker, the food appeals to my palette.  Is it too hot for our tastes?  No, and more can be added.  Further, save for the best of the starred restaurants, this eatery has charm and appeal.  After all, it is about the food, first, no?  Well aware that you do not award stars, I like the one "$" generic price tag and I can easily see multiple trials during my next visit.  I am not intimately familiar with these foods, but I can learn.  The pictured chicken dish, especially with a bit of rice (or noodles) available, sings to my soul.  Thank you so much for the outstanding review.  Without you help that that of your colleagues, how would we ever know about these places.  Thank you for the effort.', 'To Ligaya Mishan: Thank you for your excellent work writing this column. I always look forward to your reviews. I may now live in northern CT, but more than anything else, your reviews remind me of what I miss and what is special about New York City, where I grew up. Keep up the good work!']
summary: One commenter says that the restaurant is charming and that they'd like to try it. He says that the chicken dish shown in the photo calls his attention. Another commentator said he wanted to visit the restaurant and get to know the country of Bhutan. Others praise the article, saying it was very well written.
short_title: Headline: Tables for Snooker and Bhutanese Food   Keywords: Weekender Billiard (Queens, NY); Billiards; Restaurants; Woodside (Queens, NY); Bhutan   Snippet: A restaurant in Woodside, Queens, trades in the keyed-up spicing of the Himalayas.
short_question: ['Tables for Snooker and Bhutanese Food  ']

query: An estimated 65 million people have been displaced by conflict. How many can we help reach safety?
comments: ['Who gets to decide who lives or dies? In the short film, "An impossible choice" records history of the rescue mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The united states government could not help every refugee escape to safety. So instead they approved for 112  refugees on the list to be helped. I found this to be so tragic, thousands of good people trapped and begging for help to save them, wishing someone could save them. Then two people, come saying their here to save only 112 refugees on the list. Who decide whether someone lives or dies? Last time I check we all shed the same blood no one on this earth has the right to decide if someone lives or dies. I find this video to be inspiring that Sheikha Ali knew the risk of add more than 112 refugees but still added them, that took real guts. Meanwhile i was every suprise with how Sasha Chanoff a man who seems to go by the book actually decided to break the rules knowing the risk that may come behind it. However I still don\'t believe they had the right to decide this major decision. For this is life or death, if they don\'t get on the plane who knows how long they may lie in those conditions. I feel very strongly on this subject because no needs to live like the Democratic Republican are living. So again I ask who gets to decide whether people live or dies? What gives them the right to decipher this huge decision?', 'The Tutsi are a people of the Democratic Republic of Congo who are being persecuted by their own government who is basically committing genocide. This documentary is sad because two humanitarians, Sasha Chanoff and Sheikha Ali, comes to Congo to rescue 112 people and put them on the last flight out of the republic but while there they encountered mothers and children who are malnourished and are in need of desperate help. The impossible decision to make between saving the 112 or taking the women and children ultimately came down to the women and children which i think touched but saddened many of out hearts. What stood out to me was while Sheikha was analyzing the situation she encountered a Tutsi girl which to Sheikha seemed as if it was a doll but in truth it was actually a human infant. This surprised me because i could have only guesses how malnourished that child was. In the end i think the lesson learned from this story was that depending on your decisions and actions you can save and alter the future.', "What stood out to me was how we don't have to go through the daily struggles that they have to go through. In the US we have many benefits that we don't even think about and take for granted so watching this film made me think about how I can make the world a better place how they did.", 'The moments that stood out to me in the film was how unhealthy the Tutsi people were when Sasha and Sheikha flew into the Democratic Republic of Congo. I was quite surprised when Sasha agreed to help Sheikha because he seems like he is a "by the book" type of person. The film club ignited sadness in me because of how hopeless the people were. Even if they were able to flee for refuge, the people were leaving family behind. Some of the questions that I still have are how the other people doing and did any of them take advantage of the opportunities in America like free education.', 'I was shocked at how malnourished the Tutsi refugees were, they did not have enough foods and water. The living conditions is horrendous, the area look crowded and lack sanitary. The people lack many basic necessities, the situation appear hopeless. I admired the humanitarians efforts to help these people escape, it was a difficult decision to take the women and children with them. I was also surprised that they choose to go against their instruction because they are risking many lives. It is sad that they have to leave their friend and family behind along with their old life but they now have the opportunity to have a better life.', 'I totally agree with Iyanna Brown statement "I was quite surprised when Sasha agreed to help Sheikha because he seems like he is a by the book type of person." In my opinion I assumed Sasha Chanoff was a women who was a humanitarian involved in helping rescue the Democratic Republic of Congo in the beginning. However it turns out Sasha is actually a Man. I had to watch the video twice to figure that out. Anyways in the beginning the audience felt that Sasha is a trustworthy man so is "by the book" but toward the ending with a little convincing from Sheikha Ali. Sasha turned around and disobeyed the procedure, which gave them the ability to save more than 112 refugees. I found that part to be the most shocking, just like Iyanna Brown.', 'The Tutsi people, an ethnic group, in the Democratic Republic of Congo suffered from persecution, they are killed or attack by the government and the other ethnic group. Sasha Chanoff and Sheikha Ali are two humanitarian workers who help refugees flee to other countries. I was surprised when the humanitarian workers decided to help the women and children not on the list because this was an important and risky decision. They are debating if the possibility of saving those people is worth the risk of endangering everyone else. The moment that stood out to me was when Ali state she mistaken a human baby for a doll because it really emphasize the terrible condition that these people are living in.', 'It was very sad to see a specific tribe targeted and killed for such foolish reasons. I also agree that the fact that the baby was as small as a baby doll was very saddening and it made me take much pity on the Tutsi people. I think that Sasha and Sheikha are good representations of what being a humanitarian is all about. Sasha and Sheikha took risks to save the life of numerous people of the Tutsi tribe.  Although the moment is still bittersweet because they were taken away from their family and the life that they have always known. The video shows that it is only right that we assist and help out people who are less fortunate than us because it is the human and morally correct thing to do.', 'I agree with the bittersweet part because they are being torn apart from their family but it is the right thing to do in order for them to live a better life.', 'This is heartbreaking.', 'Judy Fedorchak i totally agree with your statement that this documentary was heartbreaking. I cannot fathom in a million years how any human being can go through was the great and resilient Tutsi people have gone through. This is because no one human being to be subject to persecution from their government which has a duty and obligation to protect and defend their people not to criminalize and kill them such as the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Even through all of this darkness there is light at the end of this dark tunnel and that light is Sasha and Sheikha. These two outstanding individuals who helped to mend the sorrow and heartbreak in the Tutsi people are due credit for their handling of this situation.']
summary: The commenters describe the documentary about the Tutsi as sad, tragic, and heartbreaking. Commenters cite scenes that moved them, including seeing malnourished children, the risks people took to save refugees and the lack of food and sanitation. Several commenters also acknowledged the fact that since they are in the US, they do not have to go through these struggles and thus have many things they take for granted.
short_title: Headline: Teaching With: ‘An Impossible Choice’   Keywords: Refugees and Displaced Persons; Documentary Films and Programs; Reading and Writing Skills (Education); Chanoff, Sasha   Snippet: An estimated 65 million people have been displaced by conflict. How many can we help reach safety?
subreddit: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Chanoff, Sasha']
short_question: ['Teaching With: ‘An Impossible Choice’  ']

query: The decision to move the Raiders to Las Vegas from Oakland presents conflicts for a league that has long opposed gambling.
comments: ["Money has corrupted sports at least down to and including the college level. It would not surprise me that it's already deep into high schools. Gambling is one aspect of this but so is the amount of money paid to coaches and to recruit players as well as other costs of different sports. For the most part people seem to see nothing wrong with this, especially if it has to do with the team that they follow or support. At the professional level one of the saddest things is how money even controls where teams call home. It has nothing to do with the fans and the tradition that the people of a city find important. It boils down to what the sports oligarchs happen to decide, like Jerry Jones of Dallas being a prime backer of Oakland's move to Las Vegas. Just another aspect of American life where real people are ignored by the 1%.", 'The NFL scheduled four games in London in 2017. You can literally walk around the corner into a betting shop and place different types of wagers on a game. Teams are flown to London many days before a game.  The NFL has been scheduling games in London for years. Roger- It seems strange to me you have encouraged a larger footprint in London if you are so opposed to gambling on NFL games.', "There's gambling and gamblers in every city and state. Las Vegas is at least open about it and has government regulation as opposed to New York and New Jersey where sports gambling is run by the mafia and where the Giants and Jets play. The notion that sports gambling only occurs in Las Vegas because it is legal there naively ignores that New York is the gambling capital of the US. Oakland, however, has the league's worst stadium and although the Bay Area is rich, local politicians are too cheap to build a new one. The 49ers are sufficient pro football for the Bay Area.", 'Only question is: Does the Mob still run Vegas. The answer to that will determine how all of this will shake out. Stay tuned...', 'Greed.... one of the 7 deadly sins...', "The NFL is headed in the direction of English Premier League soccer. Not only is betting on matches perfectly legal, many of the teams' jerseys feature prominent online gambling sites. It's just too much money the NFL is leaving on the table.", "I'm reminded of the old saying that money is the root of all evil.  Mass sports entertainment is taking another step in the long process of transformation from sports as a popular recreational pastime into something that will be ugly and unrecognizable.  Each step has its own logic, but already the outcomes include FIFA corruption, PED scandals in Olympic sports and cycling, absurd player salaries, brain damaged ex football players, under-the-table payments to college athletes, publically funded subsidies to privately owned franchises, fantasy sports gambling, the WWE and more.  It will get worse, not better.", 'Raiders New Slogan.........Just Cover Baby !!!!!   Stick that in your pretty pink skirt Rodge !!!!', 'Given what NFL players make and the fact that most of them make it for a couple of years on average, there\'s little chance of another black sox scandal happening. The revolution in labor rights in professional sports that started in baseball from the 1970\'s and has made it to all sports in one form or another thus acting as a check on the kind of thing that all pro sports leagues rightly fear. There would be enough of a disincentive in the form of lost income, lifetime bans and long term suspensions to keep NFL players on the level. As usual with this league, the issue is more "how much of the money can the business keep for itself" more than anything else.
