Love or hate Roger Goodell (and like most New Englanders I\'m not a fan because of the way he tried, in my opinion to shift the public\'s attention away from real outrageous behavior by some of the leagues players onto the team everybody outside of five and half states loves to hate) but he\'s done a good job of making money for them and keeping the damage to their brand from a host of issues minimal until a couple of years ago after which the national lessons about climate and physics in New England began, the league sacrificed its credibility for most folks in five and a half states but won the national headline war, ate up time and thus salvaged its brand from the fallout of real scandals. Roger\'s focus on getting all the money for the principals not the players or the states fits perfectly.', 'For a non gambler, it is staggering to go to a Sports Book in Las Vegas.  It will only be a matter of months before an official takes a nice chunk of cash to "just give me one call."  Officials are not full time league employees and Las Vegas will offer many "opportunities" to make a few extra bucks.', "The reason they want a national policy and national regulations is because it's pretty easy to grease 51 Senators so that the law, when enacted, will require a cut of the gambling money go to the league. It's pure greed, as always.", 'We have to make sure that we continue to stay focused on making sure that everyone has full confidence that what you see on the field is not influenced by any outside factors,” Goodell said last month. “We will not relent on that.” Wow. What a bold stance, Roger. Making sure your games are on the up-and-up. That\'s like a auto maker saying, "We will continue to make sure the brakes in our cars will stop you when depressed. On that we will not relent."', "I think the NFL's relationship with gambling (official or otherwise), has gone well beyond the thin edge of a wedge.  I suppose it was inevitable.  Pity.", "Everyone from the old school knows that before television, the main driving force behind football was gambling - all of it illegal save for the books in Nevada. It is a sad fact that the United States has gone from a manufacturing society to one based on services.   And one of the most lucrative services is gambling. Should not the NFL be part of this society with a franchise in Las Vegas?   Will there be a greater temptation to fix games with the Raiders in Las Vegas, or lesser since bets on the home team will be more closely monitored? To me, it just doesn't sound right - Las Vegas Raiders.   Let me tell you, during law school I knew a bookmaker who would literally make a valise of money after an NFL weekend.  The Raiders only play 10 dates a year, counting the exhibitions.   Are they going to have lines on those games?  If not, revenue at the sports books will suffer because the bookmaker makes money from the juice on every game -  no matter who wins. NFL football is still king, and the Raiders will have more revenue with this new stadium - as well as support from casinos who will buy tickets. I'd have to think the Raiders will hurt the Vegas Golden Knights NHL team - which will play many more dates without benefit of an ice hockey heritage in the desert.   Heck, their name should have been Black Jacks or Aces - why beat around the bush about Las Vegas and gambling?", '"we continue to stay focused on making sure that everyone has full confidence that what you see on the field is not influenced by any outside factors,” Goodell said last month. “We will not relent on that.” So many NFL fans would laugh out loud if they simultaneously read that statement that the "Beast Quake" would pale in comparison. Ex-pats in Tokyo might feel the tremors. I\'ve been following NFL football (via my hapless Detroit Lions) for over 1/2 century. Goodell\'s claim is hilarious. There are more "outside factors" affecting the league than I can count, including the fact that the NFL lied about knowledge of the dangers of playing professional football for decades in its quest for ever greater profits. Do I still watch Lions games? Yep. Is that cynical of me? You bet. It\'s people like me who keep the NFL profitable. But seriously, Roger ... don\'t ever think that my cynicism means I\'m blind.', "It's only a matter of time before the league confronts a gambling scandal. Look at the vulnerabilities. Low-paid game officials who are not fulltime professionals, lots of rank and file players without guaranteed contracts. And Vegas hasn't really changed at its core, it's just gotten an image makeover. But then again, the NFL is all about image.", "Seton Hall should have queried whether Vegas was tarnishing it's reputation by letting the NFL in.  The NFL is only opposed to sports gambling because they haven't quite figured out how to monetize it yet.", "Principles be damned, there's money to be made", "Pretty sure that's right there in the Constitution.", 'This is a business that has tacitly encouraged the use of the line and game odds for decades. Sportscasters and announcers routinely indicate who is favored and by how much, the line is published in every newspaper, the once sainted Brent Musburger, formerly the face of the league is a front man for a sports book and the interest in the league is overwhelmingly high because of the desire to gamble and the millions of dollars bet each week. The NFL in Las Vegas? The real question is what took these hypocrites so long to move there?', 'Excellent post!']
summary: Commentators largely agree that the NFL's gambling issue has existed for a long time and that a move to Vegas won't tarnish much of anything. Several commentators point out that many NFL employees are not paid well or aren't guaranteed contracts and are easily tempted to sell out. A few commentators note that the NFL officials' words about integrity are empty and hypocritical. One commentator goes so far as to surmise that the mob is somehow involved.
short_title: Headline: Move to Las Vegas Exposes N.F.L.’s Paradox on Betting   Keywords: National Football League; Gambling; Casinos; Football; Oakland Raiders; Las Vegas (Nev)   Snippet: The decision to move the Raiders to Las Vegas from Oakland presents conflicts for a league that has long opposed gambling.
short_question: ['Move to Las Vegas Exposes N.F.L.’s Paradox on Betting  ']

query: Though better known for ice wines, the regions near Lake Ontario produce gorgeous dry wines, and their potential is only beginning to be explored.
comments: ["I'm an ex-pat who has lived in New York City for 20 years.  I have never, even once, seen an Ontario wine on the shelf of any American wine retailer, except for of course the gimmicky ice wines. Snobbery in wines is nothing new -- it's even the raison d'etre.  But still, why can't Ontario wines get some shelf space?", 'We are sorry that clos jordanne is defunct. We loved their chardonnay..we have had trouble finding any Canadian wine for sale near us in the u s .', 'Too bad because so many are very fine. You should ask your retailers to stock some.', 'We are members of the wine CSA at David and Louise’s winery in Vineland, Ontario called Featherstone. They use natural methods to produce small batch wines: reisling, Chardonnay, Merlot, Cabernet franc, gewurtztraminer, pinot noir, rose and a sparkling wine called Joy. We enjoy the quality and depth of their wines.', 'I absolutely love their Pinots.', "Delightful to see the NYT paying attention to Ontario wine and Canada in general. It is interesting to note that a number of Pearl Morissette wines have been rejected by the Vintners Quality Alliance (a quasi government/industry board)  because they were not 'typical' of the region. They are however, as Francois eloquently points out 'of the place' where they are grown - terroir driven wines, like all great wines of the world. Bravo to Pearl Morissette, Tawes and Norm Hardie.", 'Having lived in Ontario, I am shocked: how could one praise wines, not alw3ays made from native grapes, in a country where wine sales are Provincial government monopoly?', '@ RootsReggae Canada Of course, not the sales regime as such, but the whole atmosphere of how and where wine is produced is affected by the bureaucracy. Besides, there are Ontario wines that use grapes imported from the US: the road to cheating is open.', 'What nonsense is this? "Non-native grapes"? And the grapes of every other great wine region of the world are "native"? What could that even mean considering that grapes have been heavily bred and cultivated for centuries? And as others have noted, the means by which the wine gets from vigneron (in this case) to consumer hardly matters.', 'What? Have you tasted any Ontario wines lately? And what does the monopoly have to do with the wine? Get over your shock and try some. You will be very happy.', "I have had the opportunity to taste quite a few brilliant Ontario wines, however, as our liquor stores tend to favour the big consistent sellers, it's hard to find anything from the little guys. I can often find 12+ SKUs of Robert Mondavi or Masi, but next to nothing from Prince Edward County or the Niagara region.", 'True. I love to support local Ontario wines, wish they were a little bit cheaper.', 'This is true. One sometimes needs to take a weekend trip to try some excellent wines.', 'When I read this yesterday I immediately searched the LCBO site to see if I could buy any of Pearl Morisette wine here at the govt. outlets in Ottawa. Only a single pinot noir was listed - and it was out of stock. Very frustrating.', 'I had the same problem and reaction a while ago when I wanted to get some PM wines specifically. Thankfully, their website is super easy to order from and shipping is incredibly reasonable within the province. Fast too.', 'Merci!', "I first came across Tawse wines at Frank restaurant in the Art Gallery of Ontario on a trip to Toronto several years ago.  Count me as a consumer who wasn't aware of the high quality of wines coming from that area of Ontario, but I was very impressed.", 'Would love to see a similar article on Okanagan Wines from BC Canada. Would volunteer  my favourite winemaker Wild Goose just a 5 minute drive from my  home in Okanagan Falls , BC  as a particularly excellent example. Meyer Family just round the corner are another worthy candidate. There are numerous vineyards and wine makers in the Okanagan valley - probably in excess of 200+ properties.  Obsolete Canadian liquor laws make it difficult for people in western Canada to buy eastern  wines and vice versa.', "I have had some delicious Okanagan wineswhen out in BC visiting, but - they just aren't here  ( NYS).  Didn't know they don't even ship to eastern Canada!", 'The silly reason for this is protectionism.  BC fears that BC wine sales will fall if it allows Ontario wines in and vice versa.  And yet both provinces think their wine dare world class.  How could they be if they are not prepared to compete with one another.  Even beers brewed in NS are considered imports in the rest of Canada.', "andy Morrissey....i'm not a big wine drinker and I live in southern Ontario less than an hour's drive from upstate/western new York. it's been my experience that british Columbians are pretty snotty about Ontario wine. I remember going to Vancouver and decided to have a look at a wine store. I noticed there wasn't anything from Ontario. I asked the employee why this was so, 'because there is no demand for it in BC. we think it's awful.' that was 16-17 years ago. don't know if it's still true."]
summary: Several commenters discuss how difficult it is to find Ontario Wine. One commenter who is a New Yorker even states they "have never, even once" seen Ontario Wine being sold in the USA. A few other commenters discuss their experience drinking Ontario Wine, with one commenter stating they were "very impressed" with the wine and another stating they have had many "brilliant Ontario wines." Another commenter states they hope the writer does another article like this on "Okanagan Wines" in the future.
short_title: Headline: Cool-Climate Wines of Beauty   Keywords: Wines; Morissette, Francois; Pearl Morissette; Grapes; Prince Edward County (Ontario)   Snippet: Though better known for ice wines, the regions near Lake Ontario produce gorgeous dry wines, and their potential is only beginning to be explored.
short_question: ['Cool-Climate Wines of Beauty  ']

query: At a country music concert, my 11-year-old son taught me a lesson about refraining from snap judgments.
comments: ['In my case, it was my teenager that brought me over to the "dark side" of country music and an unacknowledged recognition that the banjo is a wonderful instrument.  We laugh about the lyrics at times - hunting, drinking, loving - both girls and trucks -- but sharing the music (including FGL) provides neutral turf, with no pressure of grades or future plans, on which we can just listen, relax, laugh and enjoy.  And my son can happily take the lead.', "I didn't share my children's fondest for country music (being a NYer, country music just wasn't in our repertoire) until I had to drive my daughter's car for a week. No XM radio, no NPR, no BBC. I left it on her station and I have to say, I liked most of it.  Cheese lyrics, twangy guitar and sometimes really good melodies....shocked even me!", '"So here’s to divorcing expectations from experience. And to the ice you float your beer in."  Excellent sentiment.  I\'m sure that your son will remember this and someday extend the same to his children if he has some.', 'Fantastic observation---and relationship with your son. Kudos. Great for you, and him---both of you.', 'Matt, I expect great things from your son,', 'Great parenting creates individuals who use their brains, experience, and judgement in the real world.  Seems like this youth has plenty to be happy about from his parenting.', 'Besides the good advice, to not be too judgemental and appreciate things better, it was wonderful to read about a parent who was able to be supportive with out criticizing, inhibited a lot of typically parental things to allow their relationship to florish, and trusted his son to figure out the reality of his impressions about the country band at some point in the future, on his own, instead of imposing his opinion on his son. The result? An authentically close, touching lifelong memory of a wonderful experience with his son. So hard to do! Well done!', 'Exactly the same with many new experiences.. I am thinking about the Whitney Biennial -- the art show everyone hates -- the shock of the new and unfamiliar-- which can send our brains to new places.   Now HOLY will mean something else to at least a certain segment of the population.   ONTOH there sometimes are limits!! ;-D', 'I too thought this was mother and son. I am wondering if this good advice would work for our current political situation or is it just plain bad and that will be confirmed.', "It can be humbling and a bit nerve-wracking to notice the power we have to shape our children's tastes, beliefs, and experiences of the world. I periodically hear my children echo back one of my judgments or opinions, and find myself wondering....do I really believe that? enough to pass it along to the next generation as received wisdom? So, congratulations, Dad, on refraining from shutting down your child's enjoyment and, even better, letting him open up the world a bit for you!", 'Sometimes a snap judgement is the right one.   Soon as I started listening to various candidate in our recent election,  I knew what would happen and it did and it has.', 'Yes of course, your bias clouds reality as most zealots do.', 'Why bring in politics to everything?  Does everything has to reference our current political situation?', 'The "sappy,cheesy"  "H.O.L.Y."  lyrics or arguably any other song  lyrics coud ever  compare to 1968\'s: Yummy, Yummy, Yummy I got love in my tummy...', "Let's hope your son avoids the political positions of most country fans.", 'I think country music is such a uniquely American genre, the most lyrical, and speaks to parts of us that other music does not. Not all songs will avoid the saccharine-ness tho.', "I loved Matt's essay. It brought a tear to my eye, and don't be surprised by that.  We all got to share in the special moment when a loving parent realizes he's raised a really great kid.", '"...an acronym for “high on loving you,” in case you, like me, were initially baffled..." Thank you. Me WAS initially baffled. So were Jane and Cheeta.', "Don't sell yourself short, you have a much fuller catalog of experiences to delve through before being burned by a bad experience.  Your son not so much, he's just developing his catalog, but it is good to go back to those younger observations from time to time and glean the meaningful from the sap.", "Maybe this belongs in the Music section. Maybe somewhere else. But I certainly hope it's not a trend putting this in the Health & Wellness part of the paper.", 'Because it was so darn hard to pass it by?', 'This is the Well Family section.', 'Good story, well told. The wisdom of kids; we could learn a lot from them.', "It's amazing what happens when we ditch the preconceptions and open our minds. Sounds like a pretty transformative experience. Thank you for sharing it.", "'modeling a healthier, more life-affirming perspective ... divorcing expectations from experience' I volunteer at after-school childcare - it saddens me when I see a parent walk in to pick up their child - often staring at or talking on a mobile phone - look around for their kid, find them, then command the kid 'let's go' the kid is often in the middle of some engagement, creating some piece of art or construction, watching a movie, playing with friends - and the abrupt interruption just feels wrong - I see the kid 'harrumph!' and bristle - but the parent is usually looking the other way until they turn around the threaten the child if they don't leave NOW. OTOH - more often mothers of new kids - will come in - silently watch their kid from a distance - how are they getting on - are they enjoying it - are they making friends - and respect the kid's interest and wish to stay with a moderate request like 'I'll give you 5 minutes' - after which the kid will have finished, packed up and said their goodbyes to their friends. One tip - if I as an adult twice as tall and weighing 4-5 times as much as a small child sits down beside them and immediately start asking questions, the responses will usually be avoidance-style - a shrug of the shoulders, and evasive 'whatever' you wanted to hear type answer. Yet if I sit silently nearby - without saying anything - after 30 seconds they will typically turn to me - and start talking - telling me their thoughts - and it's delightful !", 'Its the miracle of listening. Much better for relationships than questioning and asking and telling.', 'I don\'t know why but until I got to the "I love my wife too" I assumed this was written by his mom. Imagining it was mom and son was floating my boat. A touching vignette either way, painting the sensitivities between an 11 year old boy and his parent.', 'A Mom named Matt, a boy named Sue. Why not? Country music.', 'I also thought it was written by the mother until that point. Why could it be?', 'I thought it was his Mom, too.']
summary: Many of the commenters mention how special and insightful the author's son is. One commenter in particular states that the author raised "a really great kid." Several commenters bring up some teaching moments from the article, such as that we can learn a lot from "the wisdom of kids." One commenter brings up the fact of how much power adults have to shape "children's tastes, beliefs, and experiences" and how it is important as an adult to take this responsibility seriously. A few of the commenters were a bit more critical of the article, with one commenter asking why politics are brought up and another commenter wondering why this is in the health and wellness section.
short_title: Headline: Here’s to the Good Times, and an Open Mind   Keywords: Country Music; Pop and Rock Music; Families and Family Life; Parenting   Snippet: At a country music concert, my 11-year-old son taught me a lesson about refraining from snap judgments.
subreddit: ['Country Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
short_question: ['Here’s to the Good Times, and an Open Mind  ']

query: Who has had the strongest influence on you when it comes to making choices that will affect your future?
comments: ["I think everybody or at least most people can relate to a degree of what Ms. Mitchell experienced. I for one do feel a lot of pressure to succeed or achieve bigger goals. Mostly this is due to my mom and her wanting me to get into a good college. Part of this can be attributed to the fact that neither of my parents went to college and that some of my cousins have been really successful and are doing/did very good in school and college. Eventually I just started to ignore or pay less attention to these standards being set and just do as well as I can to satisfy myself. I'm sure everyone has been under judgement in some way based on a decision they made but if people are going to judge you there is no point in listening to them.", 'Yes', "Pressure most definitely influenced Ms. Mitchell's decisions despite the fact that her parents' pressure was somewhat light. The fact that she was expected to do well in school and go to college shows the pressure that her parents and society put on her. I feel a pressure to achieve but the pressure is mostly self-inflicted. My parents try to lightly push me because they want me to be successful in life, but have given me the option to do whatever I want in life, whether that be going to college or pursuing a career right out of high school. I think the judgement Ms. Mitchell's peers placed on her when she told them of her decision to go to Spelman was a little unfair and might have been hurtful. In the past I occasionally received judgement for the colleges I plan on applying to or the career path I want to pursue, but I am able to brush it off and not let it influence my decisions.", 'In the community where I live, everyone knows what everyone is doing in high school, college, and who went to what college, and what grades they´re getting. Hearing my parents gossip about other kids can often cause me to be very neurotic and stressed out because I know the same would happen to me if I didn´t meet everyone´s expectation of what constitutes a ¨proper life¨ by attending a ¨good¨ college. I constantly feel pressure to achieve success, not only for my own sake, but for my family and what others would think of me.', "When in comes to choosing a college, of course there's a lot of pressure involved. Everyone feels conflicted about their desires and the desires of others. However, there's nothing wrong with this; it can even be a good thing. In any decision that anyone makes, one has to consider the impact. Yes, I do feel pressured by my parents and my teachers to succeed. Sometimes, It feels as though people hold me on a pedestal of academic excellence that I can't step down from. But this isn't a bad thing. It's just something that I have to take into consideration. I often find the academic pressures from my surrounding environment pushes me to try my hardest - to achieve the most that I can achieve. Though it may seem as though you know the best decision for yourself, sometimes, you just have to acknowledge that others may see things in you that you yourself can't see.", 'I am the first generation in my family to go to college. My mom is always so serious about what college I will go to. Because I am an international student from China, my mom often uses many examples of other Chinese students who got into ivy leigh schools with scholarships to encourage me to work harder.', "My parents put a lot of pressure when it comes to academics. Not only do they care about grades, but they also care about what college I should try to get into and what career I should take. Fortunately, my friends don't judge my decisions since they're more empathetic.", '- I\'m in the midst of narrowing my lists of colleges right now and have found that I find myself leaning towards schools with high diversity rates. I have some HBCU\'s on my list, but at a minimum would not mind attending a PWI as long as I found their diversity rates satisfactory. -I do find myself pressured to achieve at times. Most of the time the pressure is brought on by myself, in relation to what I want my future to look like. My family and peers are incredibly supportive and I\'ve never found them placing unnecessary stress on me when it comes to my future. -I do have certain expectations placed on myself because of what my parents have achieved. They\'re successful and always attempt to take on new opportunities to challenge themselves. This has affected me in a positive manner by inspiring me to go past my "invisible threshold", so I don\'t have any regrets when I look back on what I\'ve accomplished. -When Ms.Mitchell\'s peers gave her that reaction to her attending Spelman it shows people are unaware and may, at times, make assumptions about things they don\'t know. I have been on the receiving end of judgment. When it happens, it\'s just a matter of me knowing what I want for myself and acting on it.', 'Many students, in today\'s world, maintain multiple leadership roles and take on many responsibilities. This often effects the perception students have on their futures, while the students also feel the pressure of being "perfect" in the eyes of their followers. Admissions pushes students towards leadership roles, but not all students can be leaders. So, what now? In turn the leaders of today are put in the limelight as a hopeful model of perfect leadership for other "aspiring" student leaders. The pressure to achieve is often pushed on by the idea that the student is seen as less of a leader when they fail.', "I relate somewhat with her college experience. My parents push me a little bit towards applying to certain colleges, but at the end of the day its my decision. I do feel pressure to achieve because of all the opportunities my parents had available to me. I don't have many expectations with regards to comparison because im the oldest child. I haven't received judgment for my college aspirations.", 'Pressure is a funny thing, it leads to stress and stress leads to infinite amounts of agony and ripping out hair. It feels like all I ever feel is pressure from everybody. My parents say I need to be the best that I can be, friends always want me to act a certain way, and family want a good kid who can do no wrong. For an example my father has been bugging me saying how I am failing my class because i have an 89.2%."Hard work, I was taught, would ensure as many choices as possible."(Doyne,1). I get it you want me to be the best that I can be, but it doesn\'t help when you always in the back of my head saying you\'re not good enough. Friends always want me to act or dress a certain way because society says that\'s what were supposed to do. I always feel like I am letting every living soul down and there\'s nothing i can do about it. I try my hardest and still its not good enough for anyone. I will forever be the second disappointment of the family. So yes I do feel pressure to make decisions in my life, every decision i make will impact everything.', 'My parents sometimes make me make important decisions. Like one time my mom wanted me to go to the school she worked at but I wasn\'t sure if I wanted to leave my friends. So one week I went to the school, tried to make, friends, and went home to think about it. It was weird they didn\'t have enough desk so I had to share desk with someone. When I sat-down in my desk I tried to be friends with the guy sitting next to me. "I was in the eighth grade and my heart was set on the Northeast Ivies"(Skylar Mitchell 1).This is how I felt about my school so I told my mom and she was fine about my decision.', 'Have You Ever Felt pressured by family or others in making an important decision? And my answer to that question is yes. 24-year old had stated that her mom said "you don\'t have to go to this school but you will see It." this is an example of a parent who is giving light pressure. To me this is what some people need and this is also exactly what my parents do. Whether there talking about soccer or school they will push me to my limit, it could be that I can study harder or that I can sprint faster and score more goals. Parents don\'t do this to get on our nerves they do this because they see something in us that can only be brought out with a little push. Hopefully when you succeed you can look back and see how right they were.', "My parents never asked about my grades. Grades were my business, not theirs. Now did they query me about my rather modest career choice. I think they would have been appalled and disappointed, had I told 5hem I wanted to 'succeed' at something. What a vulgar idea.  Life was about being decent to others and good manners. I'm 81.", 'My parents have always pressured me to a limit where I felt like my head was about to explode. They had me checking my grades, maintaining a clean record, looking for job careers. The result in that was me constantly worrying about my grades and me getting in trouble. If I even had a B, even a high B, I would panic and try my best to get it up. Sometimes they would degrade me when I did something wrong. "Do you ever worry you\'ll let people down?"(Lee, 1). If I ever didn\'t meet their expectations I would feel like I let them down. Although I felt pressured I always thanked them for making me be where I am today.', "Parents should be very careful not to pressure their young adult children into careers they don't want. There is a need to have frank conversation about various paths, but I have known many bright young people who were pushed to the brink of despair because they had been forced to go to professional school right after college by ambitious parents. Let them work for a couple of years then decide if that's what they want. If they choose to go then, they will be happier, more motivated and more successful. And they'll be on a path they want, not on the road to clinical depression.", 'I\'m sure that everyone has felt pressure from their family at least once. When Ms. Mitchell talks about how the school she was going to attend shocked her peers reminds me of my family. Every time I go over and talk about what i want to do with my future, my family will tell me that I should really think about going to college, get a bachelors degree and settle down. "Do you ever worry you\'ll let people down?"(Lee, 1).  I do, i want to make my family proud all the time, but they\'re opinions on what I should do with my future is completely against mine. Despite how a person feels about what you should do, don\'t listen, but instead do what you feel is right because at the end of the day, its your life and not theirs.', 'My parents don\'t pressure me to make decision. They just get irritated when i take a long time. I will get the decision, I will think about it for a long time, and then my parents will yell at me to hurry up and make a decision. "Have you ever felt pressured by them when it comes to making big decisions, such as where to go to college, what to study, what jobs you should pursue, and so on?"(Karyn Lee,1). I have my mind set on a college. Have you ever felt pressured by them when it comes to making big decisions, such as where to go to college, what to study, what jobs you should pursue, and so on?ASU is my college, but I still have and open-mind. I would love to take refuge at ASU or any college that i can get in to.', 'My influence was my neighbor, she was like a big sister to me. I looked up to her greatly before she moved away']
summary: Some state that pressure is a good thing, and they don't let it negatively influence them. Others emphasize that pressure and gossip, especially among parents, makes a student's life hard. They state how parents judge and use examples of other students. Some students have expectations for themselves because of what their parents have achieved or the opportunities given to them. A couple say how they do not get pressure from parents.
short_title: Headline: Have You Ever Felt Pressured by Family or Others in Making an Important Decision About Your Future?   Keywords:    Snippet: Who has had the strongest influence on you when it comes to making choices that will affect your future?
short_question: ['Have You Ever Felt Pressured by Family or Others in Making an Important Decision About Your Future?  ']

query: Pasta with peas, a classic combination updated with farro spaghetti, makes for a quick springtime dinner.
comments: ['But i have celiac disease, so how is this good for me?  and my kids, who have it too? Gluten is disgusting stuff anyway.', 'millennia, right? thank you for the recipe!', 'Fargo  As wheat, it contains the gluten protein, which is found in the grains wheat, barley and rye, and is most definitely not gluten-free. "farro is higher in protein and other nutrients and is sometimes tolerated by diners with wheat allergies." What is it, gluten or not ? You should be specify in your answer.  There is no tolerance for those celiac disease.', "Why do these recipes always include PEAS? I don't like PEAS. Is there a substitute? Everything else sounds wonderful/", "It's a classic Italian dish. It's pasta with peas. Make the pasta and put some other green veggie in it that you like. Green beans?", 'It appears delicious and healthy . Tutti a tavola e buon appetito !', 'I particularly love tarragon in pasta and peas.', 'The prospect of this has made a sunny morning in Hove even brighter. Thanks.', 'Though similar to modern wheat, farro is higher in protein and other nutrients and is sometimes tolerated by diners with wheat allergies. Your comment may be misleading and is not needed (sometimes tolerated). Those who have wheat allergies and those who have celiac disease are hard pressed to live normal lives. The term "tolerated" may make others feel that such individuals are in control of their allergies when it is far from the truth.', 'OK but buckwheat sounds like something pushed on us in the early 1970s, but I am intrigued -- I will try because snap peas are amazing.', 'The greens look wonderful. One might prefer the less fatty capicola to pancetta and slightly fried rice to the noodles.', "This pasta sounds quite delicious. Food stories about ancient grains aren't exactly new, but the concept has been slow to catch on.  Here's an interesting piece written by Mimi Sheraton in 1976, where she also highlighted the use of ancient grains in some equally ancient recipes:   http://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/03/archives/dolmas-kebabs-and-pilaf-with-...", 'Mmmmmmm, pasta, peas & anything.', 'Pesto (basil and parsley) would go so well with this!', 'So great !!! giay tay nam']
summary: Most commenters express their support for the recipe, that they would like to try it, and that it appears healthy. One commenter insinuates that it seems old-fashioned, but they would still like to try it. Another commenter says that they do not like peas and wonder if there is a substitute.
short_title: Headline: Three Peas and a Grain, Playing Well Together   Keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks; Pasta; Peas   Snippet: Pasta with peas, a classic combination updated with farro spaghetti, makes for a quick springtime dinner.
short_question: ['Three Peas and a Grain, Playing Well Together  ']

query: Bayou Teche Brewery makes craft beers for only-in-Louisiana celebrations. Its distribution for now is limited to that state, Texas and Quebec.
comments: ["Since the 1980's there seems to be a push to redefine creole cooking and creole specialties as being Cajun--but they are not. Creole food and culture was in Louisiana as early as 1721, while Cajuns (Acadians) did not arrive in Louisiana until after 1764. Upon their arrival in Louisiana, it was the Louisiana's Creoles and other inhabitant who schooled the Cajuns (Arcadian immigrants) in Louisiana's unique foodways! Despite the tendency of some nowadays to label all of Louisiana's specialty dishes as being 'Cajun'; when they are not, The truth is evident as witnessed by Creole food, early creole cookbooks and commercial dishes, which tell quite  another story.", 'This is perhaps the first article I\'ve read in a national publication that accurately describes Cajun life as it is lived. Growing up in Lafayette, I acted as a tour guide for out-of-state reporters and TV crews during Mardi Gras. I was insulted by their questioning which usually began with "Why do you people ..." as if we were a circus act. Thank you Ms. Wharton for a great article and photos!', "One other hyper-local touch made by the brewers in their commitment to place are the boots that the horseman is wearing on the Courir de Mardi Gras label. These are white shrimpers boots (ubiquitous in South Louisiana), not the brewers boots as stated in the article (or atleast that's how I've interpreted the label art) . Just one more of the little things that the folks at Bayou Teche gets exactly right.", 'Bon appétit et laissez les bons temps rouler!', 'Growing up in New Orleans I remember two local beers, Dixie and Jax - made from real Mississippi river water!', 'A bayou is a coastal river or creek whose current is influenced by tidal movements.  It is not simply a "Louisianian term for a waterway smaller than a river."', "A beer with a sense of place! In this globalized world, it's good to know that one must sometimes still travel to experience the essence of the best in local food and drink. Still, I'd love to try one of these brews here in Boston.", "Perhaps the brewery doesn't distribute to Mississippi per se, but I do recall seeing it in grocery stores in that state as recently as 2012. Maybe they have shored up since then.", 'The Expulsion of the Acadians was from (Primarily) Nova Scotia as well as New Brunswick, NOT Quebec as quoted in your photo caption.', 'who sells it in Quebec?', "Was visiting home and my Chicago born and raised husband asked for some homegrown beer.  I picked out several, one being the La 31, which turned out to be his fav.  Meeting two high school friends in Tenn for a little weekend getaway; yep, I'll be asking them to bring a new supply, just for him..  awesome article; maybe its time to move back to Cajun country :-)", "What's wrong with Abita beer, from Abita Springs, LA?", 'Nothing', "A lot of people don't think Abita Beer is very good. Nothing inherently wrong with it. It's big and commercial.", "Been living in New Orleans for a few years and Bayou Teche is by far my favorite local beer, along with Mississippi's Lazy Magnolia and Southern Prohibition, but prefer the more French/Belgian farmhouse ale style of BT.  Craft brewing is growing steadily here.  I'll be sure to make a trip out to Arnaudville one of these Saturdays.  Even if you pretty much skip the boil (like me), the Ecrivesse is still a great craft American saison.", 'Finally not just a pop-up shop "craft" brewer, but one rooted in deep history and culture. Thank you BT! Bring it up here to Brooklyn, we could use a brewery refresh(ment).', "Bayou Teche's standard brew, LA 31, shows up in New York bars and beer stores from time to time.  However, their seasonal brews are truly special and are best enjoyed in Acadiana with Cajun food. Steps from Bayou Teche's brewery is a marvelous Cajun restaurant, Myran's Maison de Manger.  Diners sit at picnic tables with views of the Bayou Teche. Visitors to Acadiana don't want to miss the incredible music scene, with dozens of Cajun and Zydeco dance halls and other venues.  Zydeco brunch at the Cafe des Amis in Breaux Bridge.  Steps from Cafe des Amis is Joie de Vivre Cafe, where regular Cajun music jam sessions take place.  Breaux Bridge is also a good base for exploring the local music scene, including Poussiere's and Whiskey River Landing in nearby Henderson.  The annual crawfish festival in Breaux Bridge and the weekend-long Festival Acadiens et Creoles are wonderful ways to immerse yourself in Cajun and Zydeco music.", 'We are fortunate to be able to visit and experience the beers, food and atmosphere of this gem of a brewery located along the bayou. The beers are great and the Cajun culture is alive and well in this part of Louisiana. Such a unique part of the country. Laissez les bon temps roulez.', "This is as it should be locals drinking local beer. At one time NYC had over 200 brewery's you drank the beer in your neighborhood. I have a brewery 2 blocks from my house here in Nassau county. I get my growlers filled on a regular basis.       Don't miss understand my point I'm all for going elsewhere and trying all types of beers. I just wont be disappointed if something not available in my beer distributor. Saw a photo in the paper recently of people waiting overnight for beer at a brewery in Brooklyn. Are you kidding me?", 'I had the pleasure of visiting Bayou Teche Brewing while visiting Arnaudville with some friends in September 2016. Their beer is great, but so is the Knott family, as is the beautiful, unique, and historic region where they reside.']
summary: Many commenters love Bayou Teche and their beer, applauding its deep history, Cajun culture, and intimate sense of local craftsmanship. While Bayou Teche is advertised as making craft beers for events only in Louisiana and Quebec, one commenter says that they've seen it in New York bars. Several commenters reminisce about their favorite beers from their time living in New Orleans and also recall their favorite memories about Cajun food and culture.
short_title: Headline: Mardi Gras  in a Bottle   Keywords: Beer; Mardi Gras; Bayou Teche Brewing; Arnaudville (La)   Snippet: Bayou Teche Brewery makes craft beers for only-in-Louisiana celebrations. Its distribution for now is limited to that state, Texas and Quebec.
short_question: ['Mardi Gras  in a Bottle  ']

query: If anyone says “stay within the lines,” grab your kid and flee.
comments: ['You could pick a preschool in about a minute if you simply asked the administrators and teachers whom they voted for.   This will work for both sides.', 'Thank you for this article. I must point out that the preschoolers making a pink chair have undoubtedly been inspired by a very wonderful book by the late Vera B. Williams, "A Chair For My Mother." The very fact that they know of this book and have probably heard it read aloud speaks well of the classroom!', "The author has it about right. I would caveat two things. A kid like my daughter who is out there along the Asperger's spectrum would freak out and go fetal in a classroom that is too jumbled and busy and noisy. She couldn't tolerate much external stimulation until about 7 years old. My nephew was in a classroom that believed in teaching knitting instead of letters. It took him many years past kindergarten to begin reading. That's not great either. There should be a healthy balance between coloring with verve and imagination, and trying to challenge one's little self to follow a line so as to get better at fine motor skills. Some of each and encourage the taking of joy in each. A teacher who 'loves' one sort of activity and frowns on the other has much to learn and little to teach.", "I remember visiting two daycare centers thirty years ago for my then 2 year old son. One was dark, quiet and with few children's art projects displayed. When I visited the other, the children were outside wading in puddles in their boots in a neighboring cemetery. I chose the latter. On one memorable day, they had lunch in the boiler room at my son's suggestion, because it was warm and cozy. When people ask my advice about how to choose, I say, go with your gut - how does it feel to be there?", 'This is the best description of "Developmentally Appropriate Activities" I have seen in a long time. Thank you', 'Perhaps those in the GOP who will support Betsy DeVos because they are party devotees should take a day to visit preschools (and, for that matter, some of her Christian schools as well as public schools THAT ARE WELL FUNDED). Our children are our most valuable resource, and they too often get the short end of the stick. Quality teachers, like well built houses or cars or accessories, cost a bit more than the knock-offs, but the payoff is well worth it.  Good article...which comes down to the bottom line the author suggests.  If YOU would like to go there, your child will as well. And if your child likes and feels comfortable in their environment, they will thrive and learn.', "This guy hasn't picked a preschool. You don't know which teacher you will get until after you've picked the school. Schools in NYC have multiple pre-k classrooms, and the teachers can change between Feb (when you have to pick the school) and Sep (when your child will start the school).", "Too many middle-class parents throw the idea of any kind of publicly funded child care program out the window without personally checking it out first. Pre-K should be about socialization and positive reinforcement that gives children a positive attitude towards school and makes them ready for kindergarten. Parents can save thousands of dollars by using public Pre-K; they're more likely to be ethnically diverse and the younger children are when they are exposed to children from different racial and ethnic backgrounds, the better prepared they are to live in a diverse world. Sometimes, public Pre-K isn't the best choice, but parents should at least give it a chance and not arbitrarily dismiss it.", "Thank you. I'm sending article to my young mother relatives", "Not bad, but in fact there's room for compromise. I like to see kids' work on the walls. The kids like looking at their friends' (and their own) stuff. But it's also good for them to see big, beautiful, framed prints -- works that spur their imaginations. In my public school, in the early 1960s, we had -- of course -- replicas of Blue Boy and Washington Crossing the Delaware and other masterpieces gorgeously framed and lined up on corridor walls -- and to this day I remember them very clearly. They awed me. Plants hanging everywhere? Everywhere? Okay. But the slender vase of pussy willows on the window ledge of my first-grade classroom is something I'll never forget.  And you don't want every inch of wall festooned -- that's overload.  Coloring within the lines? Not a bad skill to have.  Yelling at kids? Stupid and counterproductive.  Our country's politics are polarized. Our notions about education have, for far too long, also been. Moderation is a good thing.", 'Good article. The two examples are good, though both are extremes. However, I would be careful to take too literally a passage like this: "What I witnessed should be obvious to any mom or dad. That’s why, even if you are an anxiety-ridden parent, you can rapidly determine whether you want to send your child to a particular preschool. " I am a teacher. What any teacher will tell you is that a parent might see something similar to either of these examples from a particular teacher on different days (though not to the extreme described). The reasons are varied - could be that it\'s been a tiring day, or that something\'s just happened and they are excited. The point is to pay multiple visits and not go by what you see on a particular day.', 'The problem with preschool is...preschool itself.  "Preschool" is what should be taught and learned in the home.  If a family is too busy or too nuclear to raise a child in the most formative years under their tutelage, they should not have children, frankly.  Preschool teachers are glorified babysitters - your child would learn and adapt better by playing lego with a trusted babysitter than with an overworked and detatched romper room monitor.  So-called structured environments?  These autocratic, mind-numbing "methods" are simply scams that soak wealthy and diffident parents who crave anything the masses cannot afford and that cynically exploit decent and fair-minded middle class parents made to fear a world of competition.  Shun these places, abjure the philosophies that extol them.  You will raise better adjusted, intellectually curious children and at the same time save yourseves tens of thousands that could be better spent amassing a home library.  YOU have the responsibility and the power; do not cavalierly squander that.', "More often than not, parents become the sole decision makers for their child's choice of schooling, especially at this tender age. That is why Tiger parents exist. They think they can push their child to learn more and excel and be able to read and write clearly by the time they are ready to enter kindergarten; often using high pressure tactics. And there are schools which charge an exorbitant fee that cater to this consumer base. It is a vicious cycle.  I believe, preschools across the country should adopt a standardized approach to learning, fun and play.  As a mother of a toddler, who is in the process of finding an apt preschool for my child, I know my child's comfort level, excitement and enthusiasm for a new place matters a lot and is the top criterion in choosing the right preschool. And for this reason, I think it is important to take the child along while preschool hunting. Observe how your child takes to the environment in each school you visit, assess their comfort level, see if they are able to mingle with their peers, while simultaneously analyzing the curriculum and daily schedules with the teachers. And then make a call. If you do that, I think you would have made the right choice for your child.", 'This editorial is one of the most cogent, concise, and brief descriptions of an ideal classroom, particularly at the pre-K and primary levels that I\'ve read in a long time. If the classroom is silent most of the day, and if kids are coloring within the lines at 3 to 5 years old, being pushed by a teacher, something is seriously wrong. If the walls of the classrooms are not filled with student work, and if everything is perfectly tidy and in place, you\'re in big trouble. Walk away quickly and take the kids with you. There should be literature filling the classroom, student "writing" everywhere, and kids so engaged in work that they hardly realize someone has entered the room. When the teacher does pull kids together for lessons, they are short, with lots of active involvement, consistent questioning, and follow up that is differentiated for all students.  There should be a quiet buzz going on in the room most of the time, but never does it seem like the classroom is out of control. There should be laughter, joking, and respect by students to each other and to/from the teacher. Betsy DeVos is the epitome of someone who should never, ever get within shouting distance of public school classrooms. She has no clue as to what good teaching looks like, no clue about how to support differentiated instruction, and definitely no clue about how to meet the needs of students with special needs. If  we were all smart, we would grab our children and run for our lives. Scary times!', "Bravo!   Why can't administrators and state departments of education view these thoughts as a standard?    Is that really what NAEYC had in mind?  We need to come together on the importance of preschool.", "Sounds like a good way to pick out a preschool to me. I know which I would rather attend.  PS. Don't forget to look at the teacher/student ratio.", 'Preschool should be primarily about social development. There is plenty of time in the future for academics. Enabling children to cope with the social situations they will soon encounter in Kindergarten will help them succeed in life more than any other information they acquire.', 'I still have the ceramic heart with my name on it that I made in kindergarten.  I wore it proudly without realizing that I had learned a simple lesson in creativity using shapes, color, and spelling.  Those teachers we have in the beginning help determine if we will love school or hate it.  The best teachers find a way to balance learning with fun.', "Until the child is fully 6 years old, everything MUST be play - which means, things he or she would CHOOSE to do. Cramming an older child's routines on a preschooler is like making her or him wear a hat too small. It's got to be play - hopefully verbal, involving other children, cooperation, and more visual things than you'd see in a third grade.", 'Great article.', 'New York City private schools, and perhaps elsewhere, prize "staying within the lines." The kids who do are easier to manage and therefore easier for the teachers. Public schools, with a more varied student body, offer a richer"real  world" educational environment. We need to support and strengthen our public schools so that everyone has the opportunity to excel.']
summary: Several commentators praise both the article and the quality of the class that it describes. Some commentators agree that the class is good, but make a few criticisms of various points. A few commentators espouse their notions of a good education, such as lots of playtime or social development. A few other commentators extoll the value of public education. One commentator suggests asking teachers who they voted for to find a good school.
short_title: Headline: Pick a Preschool in Under an Hour   Keywords: Children and Childhood; Education (Pre-School)   Snippet: If anyone says “stay within the lines,” grab your kid and flee.
short_question: ['Pick a Preschool in Under an Hour  ']

query: Panera Bread appears to be the first major restaurant chain to offer its customers information about the amount of added sugar in the beverages it sells.
comments: ['In the last year or two I\'ve noticed that Panera did not have "sweet ice tea", something of a staple in Southern US restaurants. I hadn\'t been paying much attention as I only choose unsweetened ice tea and I assumed it was a cost-based decision, either cost of sweetener (basic syrup), cost of maintaining dispensers or a combination.  I know that pre-sweetener drinks use a lot more sugar than those sweetener by the customer. It\'s good to know that advocating a more healthy diet was the impetus.', 'Why is Panera doing this...simply put...marketing strategy. Also free press.', "I have been drinking unsweetened iced tea and coffee for ever, and it's only recently that I could rely on getting good, unsweetened tea at fast food, or casual dining places. I was appalled recently when I went into a Subway in West Virginia and had a choice between regular (way too sweet) and 'Sweet' (diabetic coma, her I come) tea. I applaud Panera for its move to awareness and providing more alternatives. Now, if we could only get movie theaters and canned and bottled soft drinks more on board. Snapple used to produce an unsweetened tea line - before they were taken over by Quaker. They should dot that again.", "It seems to me that listing the amount of sugar in soda is stating the obvious; who doesn't know soda is loaded with the stuff? More useful would be listing the sugars added to foods that most consumers don't tend to think of as sweet, such as salad dressing, coleslaw, bread, ketchup, mayonnaise, crackers, soup, tomato sauce, and so on. Greater awareness of the insidiousness of sugar in these and many other processed foods would help consumers make better choices.", "My wish list for Mr. Shaich: 1. A bigger selection of  herbal hot teas.   Try Stash brand. 2.. At least one whole food plant based entree  with no added sugar or oil but with a complex starch. 3.  A true whole grain bread option with no sugar or oil. 4.   Please read The China Study by Campbell and The Starch Solution by Mc Dougall to further understand these requests. 5.  I love Panera and meet friends there often.  There are 3 within 10 minutes of my home. I usually drink water or bring my own teabag.  Thanks for adding the unsweetened drinks. I'd love to be able to eat there too. 6.  You might enjoy checking out the Plant Pure Cafe that just opened in Philly.   You could get way ahead of the restaurant nutrition curve without starting from scratch.  Best of luck, Mr. Shaich.", 'With respect, you seem to believe that restaurants can survive on providing niche services.  I say niche, because as someone who not only has a culinary background (chef/cook for years), but also is hyper-conscious about what I eat, a menu item like #2 is easy enough presuming one is after baked sweet potatoes and steamed veg, etc., and willing to shell out 10-bucks for it. Why the price? Because it will not sell, at least not at Panera. Could it? Sure, but without digging into the debate, it would change what Panera is as a restaurant. Restaurants in general are not good nutritional choices because "good nutrition" does not sell. Or, if it does, it costs a premium (and should - another topic though). Most people will not pay those costs frequently enough to support such a restaurant. Most people really have no idea of the costs associated with running a top notch foodservice that pays staff a true competitive (salaried) wage. I\'d open up a vegetarian spot in a heartbeat if I thought it would be truly supported, but it would not. More to the point, and with respect, many vegetarians are...picky. Some eat honey, some eat shrimp, some drink milk, some scream bloody murder about whole milk cheese, but are upset there\'s no yogurt. I generalize greatly, but again, if someone wants to pay 10 for rice, beans, salad, and whole-wheat (true) bread, I\'m your guy, but you and 2500 others need to visit weekly, for lunch (and that\'s lowball). And don\'t bring your own teabag.', 'Will Panera reveal the amount of sugar in their breads?   Why is it so difficult nowadays to purchase bread - anywhere - that does not contain sugar. If I want sweetened bread, I\'ll order challah. But why must "health" breads like whole wheat, multigrain, etc have sugar? OK, OK it makes the dough rise faster, the bakers say.  But why the rush when it comes to our health – or at least our choices? Mr. Shaich, do the right thing!', "Even Challah doesn't have to be sweet. When I make it, I put in 1 tsp of sugar with the yest to proof it, and then make 2 1.5 lb loaves.", 'Panera Bread does little to serve Type 2 diabetics. A few low carb options would be beneficial along with some no added sugar baked goods.', 'The "pleasure center" in our brain has been trained to demand lots of sugar, salt and fat almost all the time. You can\'t withdraw all at once but hopefully the Panera sugar info will make a difference and over time, they will reduce salt and fat, as well.', 'I\'ve never understood the appeal of Panera. When one opened up near me, I was excited to try it out because it had such a high reputation. Sure their food is all "real" but look at the salt content of their soups. How healthy is that? A sandwich of oven-roasted turkey breast, lettuce, vine-ripened tomatoes and red onions with salt and pepper on Whole Grain with pure mayo and spicy brown mustard has nearly 1200mg of sodium. How does that happen? It\'s nice that they\'ll post the added sugar but how about lowering the salt content of all this "real food."', 'Folks who are seriously trying to eat less sugar, because of a metabolic imbalance should not even go into a Panera.  Make your own soups and salads - go to the Forks Over Knives website for great recipes and inspiration.  I am not a vegan, but the recipes are delicious, affordable and super nutritious.', 'This is wonderful to raise awareness of what we are eating and make more informed choices!  Hopefully other restaurants will follow suit.', 'Bravo to Panera for doing this!  Now if they would just reduce the sugar in their pastries - too sweet!', 'Good for Panera!  I hope others follow their example.  I hope even more that customers ACT on the new information.   Here in Greensboro, Panera provides their day-old bread to Out of the Garden Project, which redistributes it to after school facilities and food banks.  As a volunteer with that project, I have seen Panera make a difference.', "If Ron Shaich is so concerned about sugar intake, why sell drinks that exceed government sugar consumption guidelines?  Beyond that, his pastries are flush with sugar and typically taste like cardboard, to boot.  It's all about marketing and trying to get a step ahead of the competition.", 'Reducing sugar content of soft drinks is like wearing a seat belt.  NothING harmful. Just takes some getting used to.', "Will Panera's also list the amount of sugar added to their other offerings -- such as the pastries mentioned?  It's amazing how many foods have added sugar where it wouldn't be expected:  it could be in the bread, the soup, salad dressing, all kinds of places. btw, I just drink water when I eat at Panera's:  it's cheap!!  Actually, it's free!!  And we skip the pastries.", 'And they seem to use sweetened soymilk in coffee drinks. will they declare?', 'they will regret it in Philly cause of the soda tax that has people up in arms', 'Good to read articles like this. The business community taking a more active role in our health is always a positive. Adding sugar content on the label at least gives the consumer the option to buy or not. Years ago in the 70’s and 80’s we generally made Kool-Aid for the kids in the summer time. Can’t afford sodas when your raising three hungry mouths. What the boys never knew though was, the amount of sugar added to make the Kool-Aid was minuscule. We knew it was bad back then so decided only a little. When they found out years later it was somewhat of a surprise but the unexpected benefit is their all trim and don’t have a craving for soft drinks. Of course wine and beer are ok!', 'Why would you want to sell food that is bad for people and has been proven to lead to serious diseases like diabetes? Oh, yeah, forgot, - money. Perhaps it\'s precautionary - "We warned you" in anticipation to lawsuits that may come down the pike for selling food that made customers sick. I assume it\'s pretty hard to sue tobacco companies these days for making smokers sick, what with the prominent warning labels on the packages. And while nicotine is an addictive substance, so is sugar. Think about your local ice-cream store as a type of crack house and you may not shop there again.', '34 grams of sugar is still 68% of the daily limit.  If you need to add sugar to anything, is it really worth consuming it?', 'Except for chocolate, no. Though even then there are alternatives like Crio Bru.', "The announcement about Panera's new labeling policy should please all the dietetically minded and believers in the presumably damaging effects of sugar, even when taken in moderation. But in reality, I doubt that many clients of the various eateries would carry with them gadgets for calculation of their daily intake of different substances before ordering something that they like.", "I was one of those customers who gave my opinion of what Panera was doing--and I strongly complained about the amount of sugar in their drinks.  I'm so impressed that they changed the formulation of some of their drinks and are now offering drinks with no sugar (one of which I purchased during my last visit). Thanks Panera for listening to your customers.", 'Without posting the cane sugar vs HFCS is a mistake.    We need to know exactly what we are eating.', "Just because its been around for 200 years doesn't mean its not harmful.Sugar is sugar regardless of fructose or glucose it still is bad for the metabolic system.And its not the type of sugar its the AMOUNT of consumption thats lead to all the problems.", 'Your research is long out of date.  See  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2868080/  for example.', 'Your advice is fine unless people decide to get off sugar and switch to aspartame.     Then they just may wind up with a seizure or worse.     We should be asking why it is that 35 countries are healther then we are.']
summary: Most commenters are supportive of restaurants starting to label the sugar content of their food and drinks. All commenters seem to be in favor of big businesses taking an interest in the diet and nutrition of their customers. A few commenters seem to doubt the motives of Mr. Shaich and question if he will add the added sugar info for all of the food sold. One commenter goes on a rant about people not being willing to pay for what they say they want in a  restaurant.
short_title: Headline: Soda or Bear Claw? Panera to Post Added Sugar in Drinks It Sells   Keywords: Sugar; Restaurants; Diet and Nutrition; Soft Drinks; Food; Labeling and Labels (Product)   Snippet: Panera Bread appears to be the first major restaurant chain to offer its customers information about the amount of added sugar in the beverages it sells.
short_question: ['Soda or Bear Claw? Panera to Post Added Sugar in Drinks It Sells  ']

query: What are healthy ways you can express and relieve suffering when facing tragedy?
comments: ["i had to deal with a divorce and death of a parent in a relatively short time period and through that, i have never felt sad about any of them, i have tried for years to let myself grieve and tell myself it is ok, butt nothing seems to come out of it. my whole family wanted to see me grieve as they thought it was unhealthy i wasn't, and i tried so so hard to do so butt yet it never worked. me being the person i am researched grieving so this article wasn't to surprising", "I personally for the longest tried to avoid feeling sad. I didn’t like the feeling it gave me. I was the only kid that was sad during breaks not wanting to talk to anyone else while other went to go do what they did. I felt like the odd man out so I would fake a smile and go with the other kids. I got really good at doing it until one day we were reading a book in class that reminded me of the one I lost and I just started balling tears. No one knew why I started crying on my desk because I didn’t tell anyone what had happened beforehand. Sitting there crying over the two loved ones I lost I realized that it is okay to be sad and feel grief or emotion towards the situation. I never really know if I moved on because to this day I still feel sad but now it is more anger to everything and everyone. People always tell me to talk to someone because it’ll help but I just get angrier because I can’t express my feelings without wanting to cry bringing up the situations. So with friends when they lose a loved one I tell them to talk to someone and accept the grief and that it is okay to be sad because it's normal. That it will get better over time but you need to give it time. I say that because it would probably work for me if I wasn’t so hard headed and a stubborn person.", 'For me, grief is something that never really took hold of me so I can’t properly explain how I cope with something that I haven’t had.  Or maybe my coping is simply ignoring the feelings and putting them in the trash like many emotions of mine, but that’s semantics.  What I want to talk about is how I think it is best to help others with grief (had a bit of experience from having family members of my mother dying every year for the past 3 years).  I agree that when helping someone, don’t try to tell them what to do unless they ask.  Always try to gently coax them into asking the question of what they are going to do in the future after all of this has happened to themselves.  This can help them process what they need to do going forward, but this should only be done after someone has settled down from grieving.  They need to be able to process the past and realize, by themselves, that there is more to do in life.  You can’t force them, but you can plant the seed of the future thoughts in their head.  It has helped for my mom, and a few of my friends when they are grieving.  In essence,  be a shoulder to cry on and someone to point them forward without dragging, pushing, or over encouraging them to move on.  Take it slow and walk just one step ahead of them and help them up if they ever fall.', 'For the longest time, I didn’t cope with grief. I didn’t let myself be sad and instead I just pushed away the emotions and tried to act like I was fine. I didn’t acknowledge the fact that I was grieving, even to myself, and the outcome was I was incredibly stressed and was facing not only grief but anxiety. The article basically says that the way to grieve is to let yourself do so. You shouldn’t push away your emotions because letting yourself feel grief that is a step to feeling better. Like the author Megan Devine’s book, “It’s OK That You’re Not OK”. It is okay to not be okay, and acknowledging that can help you feel better, and even let people around you know so that they can help as well. There is no single way to cope with grief, so even if someone doesn’t outwardly look sad at all, that could be their way of coping.', 'In the past, I never did anything to cope with grief because I felt as if I wasn’t actually feeling grief. Nowadays, I acknowledge the fact that I am most likely feeling grief, and with that realization came the strong desire to live a happier life. Most recently, I have been keeping a notepad that lists how I’m feeling on a scale everyday, and the reasons as to why I feel that way. I think I could try to talk to people who will just listen to me, as mentioned in the article. In the past, I would simply cry with my sister, which would comfort me a lot, and I really think I could try doing that again.', "On December 31, 2017 my grandfather passed away. Ever since his death I have been beating myself up for not crying enough or for not being sad enough. The only time that I truly cried was whenever I got the news that my grandfather was in a coma and that he probably wouldn't come out of it. My grandfather had been sick for a while, during the summer of 2016 he had a brain tumor removed and during his recovery he suffered a major heart attack. He spent 6 months in the hospital and in rehab trying to get better. Even after he came home he still was in pain daily. This article helped me to realize that it is okay that I didn't cry as much as my sister or my grandma. Now I know why I didn't cry, I didn't cry because I was relieved. I was relieved that he wouldn't be suffering anymore. I am sad everyday that I will never see his face again or hear him talking to me but if my sadness means that he feels no more suffering, in the end it is worth it.", 'Last week my aunt had passed away, and yesterday I attended her funeral. The past few days haven\'t been easy for me or my family. My first reaction when I got the news was immediate silence. I didn\'t believe my ears. Then silence turned to tears. When I grieve I tend to just cry until there isn\'t anymore tears. I tend to isolate myself from my friends and shut the world out. After about two to three days, I open up to my friends and want their support and love. The best support I have gotten was when my two best friends just showed up to my house and just held me tightly. They didn\'t need to say anything to me, the hug spoke a thousand words itself. The worst is when I tried to explain how I felt to somebody, and they totally shut me out and made it about them. When I help somebody who is mourning, I try to have empathy. I tell them I am here no matter what, and will do anything I can to make them feel better. What I took most out of this article is that there is no right or wrong way to grieve. I always thought that the \'appropriate\' way to mourn was to just cry and be around your friends and family. Like one of the titles mentioned in the article says, "It\'s OK That You\'re Not OK." Everybody grieves differently, and that is okay.', 'I’ve seen so much grief throughout my life. I’ve seen my mom grief before, and many people in my family grief, but I have never exactly experienced it myself. I don’t think I want to experience it either, but when I do someday, this is what I will do to deal with the sadness. At first when people find out the news of somethings that happened that was important to them, they cry. Crying is their first reaction. I am pretty sure that I will cry because I know that it would be very painful to lose someone that is important to you. After crying for a few hour or days or a few times every day, I think that I would do something to calm me down and help me relax, for example, lying on the bed and watching cheerful things on the TV, and also I could make a hot cocoa for myself and eat some delicious ice cream. Then finally, after a few days or week, I will move past about the situation a little bit and go back to doing what I was doing again. If I don’t move past it, I would never be able to accomplish what a wanted to do. I wouldn’t be able to do anything if all I did was cry about what happened because grief is usually not something that happens only once or twice. Still, there are many ways dealing with grief. Some people just hold it in, and there are even some people that don’t seem like they care. Grief is something I have seen a lot, but I know that no one likes to deal with grief.', 'The loss of a family member or loved one can shatter one\'s soul. There is a multitude of ways for dealing with these sort of situations with none really being the appropriate way. There is dreading and weeping, holding it in and acting like it doesn\'t bother you, or talking and discussing the problem with someone which seems to work the best for most people. Keeping the problem to yourself and acting like it isn\'t reality usually leads to depression and can develop even worse from there. Like one of the title\'s mentioned in the article “It’s OK That You’re Not OK," it is good to feel misery or sorrow from the loss of someone and there are more effective ways of dealing with them. Approaching the situation seeking help and comfort can give the person dealing with the grief support and the idea that someone is there or them. Even though I think communicating with someone else works best, there still isn\'t necessarily a "correct" way of handling the situation.', 'Honestly, I think coping with grief is such a difficult thing I don’t have a strategy I could write down in words. Like the article said, ‘there is no right or wrong in grief’. Luckily, I have not experience grief when it comes to a loved one dying. The times I have I was too little to comprehend the gravity of the situation. It saddened me of course, but I don’t remember it enough to say if I had a strategy. However, I have many friends who I have witnessed experience grief. For me the best strategy for helping them is to give them space. When they wanted to talk they would seek me out. This way they didn’t feel bombarded and had time to process their feelings.', 'Honestly, I think coping with grief is such a difficult thing I don’t have a strategy I could write down in words. Like the article said, ‘there is no right or wrong in grief’. Luckily, I have not experienced grief many times when it comes to a loved one dying. The times I have I was too little to comprehend the gravity of the situation. It saddened me of course, but I don’t remember it enough to say if I had a strategy. However, I have many friends who I have witnessed experience grief. For me, the best strategy for helping them is to give them space. When they wanted to talk they would seek me out. This way they didn’t feel bombarded and had time to process their feelings.', 'As the article states, “grief is the natural reaction to the loss of a loved one.” Everyone experiences it once, if not many times in their lifetime, and coping with grief is anything but easy. It’s different for everyone and there is no right way to deal with it. I think the article said it all when it stated that “pain cannot be “fixed,” that companionship, not correction, is the best way to deal with grief.” Just having someone to be with you or offer their friendship in my opinion is the best way to cope. I think when people bottle up their feelings and close everyone out is when grief is the hardest. Just like the article said, expressing your feelings is one of the best ways to cope with grief; however, everyone is different, and everyone deals with grief differently. Whether it’s talking to someone, or just simply keeping a journal, getting your thoughts out is always beneficial. Some people might rather be left alone and others want the comfort of a friend. For example, when I was in middle school, two of my classmates both lost their mothers to cancer. When it happened, they coped with their grieving in different ways. While one of them wanted the constant comfort of their friends, the other just wanted to be left alone for some time. I think when someone is grieving, the best way to help them is to let them know you’re there for them, but if they need some space, respect it.', "I recently lost one of my grandparents a little over a month ago. It was sudden and was somewhat of a harsh shock when I was told, but there was also a slight sense of relief, like mentioned in the article. My grandmother had been in pain for a long time, being told time and time again that she wouldn't live much longer, and how the pain her lungs caused her seemed to be getting worse and worse. Grief, especially when it pertains to someone in your family, does not have a negative stigma around it.  However, it is something that everyone must encounter eventually. Expressing your feelings is probably one of the best ways to grieve, no matter in what format. The article talks about great ways of doing this. Writing, talking to someone, or even just expressing those feelings aloud to no one are ways to help you get through the grieving process. However, being someone who has a friend who is in mourning, the best thing to do is to give them space. Don't rush them and try to hurry the process along. That can and will cause a negative reaction. Whenever I have been grieving, my friends did just this and I came out of it okay. Overall, this article brings up ideas and concepts that I think are great for treating mourning.", 'There are many ways to cope with grief.  Some usually try to forget and move on while others sit alone away from everyone because they feel like they have no one who will understand.  What I find interesting about the subject of grief is that everyone experiences it from time to time, but we feel as nobody could ever understand us.  It\'s a personal, psychological process that we must conquer in order to obtain the feeling of happiness again.  The only problem is, how do we accomplish this battle?  Many go to counciling to talk about their problems.  Some resort to addiction such as alcohol or drugs which leads to even more pain for themselves and the loved ones who care for their mental and physical health.  Everyone is different which is why I firmly beleive there is no "correct" way to cope with grief.  There is no "deadline" for when all the pain with stop.  It takes our own mind to overcome the challenges and to test our limits to what we can withstand.', "Grief is unbearable. I wouldn't say I have experienced this to its fullest extent, but grief is something that is a long and painful process. When i was 11 years old, one of my family members passed away from lung cancer. My siblings and I were very close to him and he would be with us all the time.
