He was always smiling, always laughing, always telling jokes, I had never seen him without a smile on his face. I tried not to cry at the funeral, but it was impossible to hold back the tears. I believe that from this article I definitely have used some of these strategies. When I was dealing with grief, I used one of the points made in the article. I thought of the loss as a universal experience. I knew my loved one was in a better place, that it was for the best, and he was in terrible pain, and if he was still living, he would be living in pain that would eventually kill him. Everyone deals with loss in a different way. If someone I know is dealing with grief, I think its best that you always stay by their side, but also give them a healthy amount of space. After my loved one passed I wanted more time alone and appreciated it when people didn't ask me a lot of questions about it. I'd say that if someone is experiencing grief, that they should be with their family and friends and surround themselves with joyful people.", 'I don\'t believe people cope with grief, I simply believe that we each find a way of dealing with things. Truly we just either forget it not completely but to the point where it doesn\'t hurt us sustainably every day. That\'s is only in the case that you\'ve said you "coped" with it. so I would simply say I deal with grief and that is the best way and it was I usually do.', 'Well I just cope with grief by not thinking about it, or about the person that had passed away. Also I would just do what I like to do to keep me occupied and to stay happy. I am speaking off of experience because I have had many loss ones so just follow those things and it will help with it.', "How do I cope with grief? In my life a few people have left me and it never gets easier. That first shock of them being gone is hard. You become extremely in denial and you don't want to believe anything. Myself personally when things like this happens, I find it helpful to talk to people rather then staying alone. I think you should get all the love and support you need during this time.", "How do I cope with grief? I have been fortunate enough to have various loved ones in my life. I have never experienced losing a family member of my blood, but I did lose a family member. My dog Stewie, Stewart, Stew; a man's best friend. Stewie was an amazing dog. He was all you wanted in a dog, a friend.  I did not have a lot of grief when he passed. I feel he lived life to his full potential, whether he was humping other dogs on the beach, and pissing off owners, or snatching your pizza right off your plate. He lived his last few months like a stud too; he wore a diaper stylishly around the house.  I guess I cope with grief with humor. It helps me see my dog Stewie lived a incredible life, and it helps me to never forget him. I am not laughing at him; I am laughing with him. And, I know he is having an amazing time in Doggy Heaven.", 'As stated in the article, grief causes many "common pitfalls and misunderstandings." It is quite hard for me to cope with grief. I am the type of person to hold in all of my emotions, rather than expressing it. I do not like to talk about my feelings of sadness when it comes to grief. It takes time to fully heal from grief and the process cannot be rushed. Many emotions come with grief, such as anger and anxiety- those feelings are all common. When I am in the state of constant sadness, I allow myself to be sad, rather than to hide my emotions behind a mask. The best way someone could comfort me is to lend me their shoulder to cry on. No words are required or necessary, the thought of them being there is very comforting.', 'this is about greif and how it is used to people and greif is used for anger', 'Grief. A word so simple yet so complex at the same time. One word that sums up the sorrow one endures. One word that reflects the misery one endures. One word that represents the anguish one endures. Grief. A concept that everyone knows of but not everyone feels. How does one cope? How does one get through the day without breaking into tears? How does one get out of bed every day while feeling such distress? No one has an answer. You have to find your own ways to cope when you feel like all is lost. When you see someone who is grieving, whatever you do, don\'t tell them that "everything is okay" or "things will get better." In their minds, it won\'t "be okay" or "get better", and those words mean nothing to them. Don\'t just feel sorry for them. Put yourself in their shoes and understand their situation personally. How do I cope? I listen to music. Music is how I am able to express myself without inflicting others.', 'Sadly, I have experienced the death of a loved one in my life. This person I knew, and loved ever since I was born and I had a really strong connection with him. I was really sad when he had passed away and I really did miss him. Like many say, grief takes time and I do agree, but time itself will not fix the grief.  The way I handled the death of a loved one is by staying close to my religion. With my religion, I understand that I would be able to see this loved one again. This gave me hope when dealing with the death of my loved one. During that time I surrounded myself with my family and we were able to give each other comfort by providing each other company. It has now been 6 years since the death and I am doing just fine. Life does have some sad times but also its happy times. Of course I am still going to miss this loved one, but I always strive to think of the good times instead of the bad in order to move on.  In my opinion, the best way to handle someone that is grieving is to always be there for them during that moment of time, and to let them know that. By doing this it reminds that person that someone is there for them and loves them. This gives them hope to get through the sad times.', 'In my life so far I have been lucky enough to avoid the grief of losing someone who I was very close with. However, I am often the friend in the situation who becomes the shoulder to cry on. That being said, I still often times make mistakes and say the wrong things in certain situations. Over the past few years, I have learned that it is better to insist that someone is going to be okay rather then asking them if they are. If a person would like to discuss their life, they will on their own. However, your job isn\'t to know what the problem is, it is to simply comfort them until they are ready to accept the issue and/or move on. I\'ve also found that comparing your issues to theirs when they are sad, is a useless tactic, and considerably rude. A person in pain doesn\'t want to hear about that time you went through "almost the exact same thing" 5 years ago, or how they "have it easy" compared to what you had to go through in the past. Letting them know they aren\'t alone is a good route to go, but what I have just described is not the way to do it. Overall, listen to your grieving friends and/or family. If they don\'t want to talk about their problems, don\'t make them. Often times, talking isn\'t necessary. Comforting body language could be all that is needed to make a person feel safe and protected.', 'They tell you the only thing that heals a grieving heart is time. Clearly "they" have not experienced true grief before. I don\'t know if you can truly rid someone of grief. Time only makes it easier to manage the grief. Time makes it easier to push it down inside and try to forget about it. But it will always be there. Grief is a powerful emotion that consumes your whole body. I remember the exact moment when I received the news that would change my outlook on life forever. Those memories will always be with me wherever I go. We wouldn\'t be human if we didn\'t grieve. We all grieve in different ways and it is natural to feel hopeless when consumed by the realization that you have lost someone. If I have learned anything, it is that we shouldn\'t forget the ones we have lost and how it felt to lose them. Grief is a painful experience but in time it helps us appreciate the people around us. I think the best way to cope with grief is to accept it and let the emotions flow over you. After you let your soul wash itself of the initial shock and grief, it is important to celebrate the good memories of your loved one. I lost a classmate that I went to elementary school four years ago. I did not know him very well but the memory I have of him will stay with me. When I heard the tragic news I didn\'t know how to handle it. I was his age and it devastated me to know that he would not have the opportunity to grow up like I would. I still think of him often and use grief to honor his memory.', 'Part 2  The first day I just wanted to be by myself, I spent my days in my room, thinking about all the good memories, but that didn’t last for long. I like to be happy, and when I’m not happy I become stressed and even more unhappy, so I knew I had to move on. I slowly started laughing more and engaging in conversations more until I felt normal again.     Although Mochie was obviously very special to me, I wouldn’t know what to tell someone if they lost a relative. I imagine losing a special person in your life to be a lot harder than losing a pet, but I don’t know for sure. If someone I knew were grieving I would tell them to take their time, and then once they started to feel better, to go out and just do things that will distract them and will eventually make them feel a lot better. My family had already dealt with their grief and had felt better by time I returned and helped me by just letting me take my time and grieve the way I needed to. That would be my suggestion to anyone who had lost someone special to them, but you should let them grieve however they need to. As Julia Samuel said, “There is no right or wrong in grief”.', "Part 1 I haven’t had to deal with a lot of grief in my life. I still have both sets of grandparents and I haven’t lost anyone close to me or my family. The only time I actually remember grieving was when our family dog, Mochie, passed away a few years ago. She was very old and had a lot of medication she had to take because of seizures, but she was still the sweetest dog. Being a German Pointer, she was pretty big and she would come and it in your lap as if she believed she was a lap dog. When she seemed to become weaker and older I knew there wasn't much time left for her, but when she did pass it seemed so unexpected I had just gotten back from an amazing week long trip with my class and when I finally got back to the comfort of my home I didn't see Mochie. I remember my mom saying she was sorry, but they had to put her down while I was away. My mom knew that I would want to see Mochie one last time, but she also knew that I wouldn’t want her to suffer. I had a very hard time dealing with her passing, especially since I never really got the chance to say goodbye.", "Honestly My mother passed away when I was 3 1/2 years old  I honestly didn't handle it right at first but then I went to Grief therapy I learned how to handle it better and it really hurts still"]
summary: All commenters explain grief is a sensitive topic. One talks about how the article makes them understand it is okay not to cry. One commenter agrees, stating that it's okay not to be okay. Being sad is normal behavior. Many commenters also concur that giving space to someone grieving is helpful. At the same time, knowing when to comfort a person is just as useful, especially during times of grievances. Everyone at some point experiences grief, and it is a difficult task to cope with grief.
short_title: Headline: How Do You Cope With Grief?   Keywords:    Snippet: What are healthy ways you can express and relieve suffering when facing tragedy?
short_question: ['How Do You Cope With Grief?  ']

query: Still talking about the rewards of sifting through a pile of scratched-off lottery tickets on a Manhattan-bound F train.
comments: ['A flawless gem!   I hope the New York Times publishes more writing from Ms. Usadi.', "Made me smile...I didn't want this story to end so quickly!  :)", 'It is great to read happy memories of subway trips. The writer made her memory come alive.', 'As I sit here reading this article with my wife of twenty years reading her section of the paper and our children away for the week, those types of memories seem not so long ago. Good times.', 'What a sweet last line!', 'This made me laugh :) subway rides are full of interesting stories', "A 'stooper', a person who picks up discarded gambling tickets particularly at now defunct OTBs.", 'I can still remember reading sometime in the 1960\'s about men who were selling bunches of discarded bet tickets at a racetrack for fifty cents a bunch. (Every dollar was worth a lot more then than now.) The sales pitch was that "You may find a winning ticket".', 'So much for the adage "You can\'t win if you don\'t buy the ticket."', 'U pick up change and metro card too to name a few. A recent picked up metro card had $7!', 'Indeed!  I recently found a Barnes and Noble card worth twenty-five bucks dropped in the street.  You never know.', 'Great story and oh so true!!! want to hear more from this author.', 'Good for you! I have always picked up change (including pennies).']
summary: The commenters overall find this a heartwarming story, with some commenting directly on the author's writing and others sticking to the feelings the article itself evokes. Others talk about similar stories from their own subway-riding days, and one even includes the slang term "stooper" - which describes the behavior the author describes in their article.
short_title: Headline: Memories of a Modest Jackpot   Keywords: Lotteries; New York City   Snippet: Still talking about the rewards of sifting through a pile of scratched-off lottery tickets on a Manhattan-bound F train.
short_question: ['Memories of a Modest Jackpot  ']

query: Mel Taub is back with some head-spinners.
comments: ['TO CAITLIN: On further examination, is it possible that there is an error in the clue list on the site? The given clue is "dine twice", but in your piece you seem to be saying that the clue was: B U R G', 'OK, but the inconsistency is that the website has only "dine twice" as the clue. As the other person explained, the Magazine has only B U R G as the clue. Somebody at the Times goofed somewhere.', 'Because the online software can\'t artificially break lines, like B U R G , ... or do anything typographically unusual, clues for the print edition that involve tricks like this have to be changed for online. The above clue leads to the answer EATS UP, because "grub" = "eats," and "grub" reads upward. For online the clue was changed to "Dine twice," because EATS UP = "eat" + "sup".', 'Eats up is GRUB', 'Maybe the clues gave too much away, but this was relatively easy.', 'Six Packs was something new and different. [SPOILER ALERT] I first incorrectly assumed that the cardiological answer would NOT be from “artery”, because that would be too “fitting” and therefore probably wrong. The hardest answer for me was the one about “piano or accordion”. I searched in vain, but then suddenly realized that it was KEYBOARD INSTRUMENT, from “ardent”.', 'This time I decided to take a stab at the PandA. I got approximately ten words (mostly in the southwest corner), which for me is probably a record when it comes to PandAs or Cryptics. Anyway, after “revealing” the rest of it:  47A: Isn’t BIAS and discrimination essentially the same thing in this context? I don’t get where the pun or anagram is. 10D: “Car finish” is EER. Could anybody please explain these?', 'Do you mean the puzzle in the print magazine? Here it says "dine twice". https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/variety/2018/04/22', "Can't see it without a subscription.  But, the print version in the Magazine does not reflect what you saw.", 'Yes, this is strange! About a half-hour ago I entered a Comment about it that I addressed to Caitlin. It wound up on the top of this column.', 'CAR   EER is CAREER. I liked the puzzle. It solved fairly quickly for me.', "I had trouble following this thread. Yes, [Dines twice] is pretty easy at EATS UP.  And the BIAS question has been answered.  But I'm really lost when you're talking about BURG/GRUB.", 'The mystery finally got cleared up for me. In the online puzzle, the clue was "dine twice". In the print Magazine, the clue was the letters B U R G, printed vertically in that order.', "I'm just putting in a quick thanks! for fixing the links box so that the quick links to recent puzzles appears on this variety puzzle page - I hope it stays this way. Much better for dropping in on recent puzzles. I came to a new understanding while doing this weekend's P&A - I feel about them the way other people feel about rebus puzzles. I never understood how people could feel so negative about rebus puzzles, yet I realized I feel just as negative about P&A. No right or wrong, just what tickles your fancy and floats your boat. P&As never float my boat.", 'How do I access the Variety puzzles on line? Thanks in advance!', 'It took me a moment to realize this was the same puzzle used for the Puns and Anagrams contest at ACPT this year. I wonder if I solved this one faster. :)', 'please explain 5 down\'s answer "rein"', 'The part about "announcement" is unclear. But REIN and RAIN are homonyms, and "check" can have a meaning similar to "rein", as something that stops, controls or limits something.', '"Announcement of" hints at sounding the word "rain" aloud in which case the homonym for "check" is "rein"', 'I liked it a lot as I do all PANDAs. This was relatively easy but still fun and a challenge for those of us who are not pros.  Keep up the PANDAs.', "I can only assume that there is some glitch with the new Comments section, since there seems to be a lot of discussion about stuff that I can't even find in this puzzle. That said, I'm always glad to see something with Mel Taub's byline.  OTOH, I'm not thrilled by those clues that show some expression with blank letters to fill in for the entries. Back to figuring out what y'all are talking about.", "Caitlin, If you're there, the Sunday Wordplay column has not appeared! (The puzzle is up, the column is not.)", 'Apologies Barry et al, I got bitten by a technical issue and the column published late. C']
summary: Commenters generally respond positively to the word puzzles. Most say that they are relatively easy to decipher and give several examples of word plays they found amusing, such as "Car finish" is EER = career. Others bring up that some were difficult, possibly because of misleading clues. One claimed the hardest was "piano or accordion."
short_title: Headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams   Keywords: Crossword Puzzles   Snippet: Mel Taub is back with some head-spinners.
short_question: ['Variety: Puns and Anagrams  ']

query: Christian Borle is the eccentric Willy Wonka in this tentative musical based on the Roald Dahl children’s classic.
comments: ['I guess I see far too many musicals and sometimes, the ones who get the best reviews are the ones I detest the most. That wasn\'t the case for "Charlie Chocolate" as I\'ve shortened it down to, which I found to be pure agitation and no imagination. Yes, the kiddie filled audience was going overwhelmingly bonkers over the whole thing, and my friend and I looked at each other every time the audience erupted as if to ask each other, "Why?" Christian Borle gives a fun performance, but somehow I wonder if he\'s wishing he was still doing "Falsettos" for which he got the Tony nomination. I wasn\'t a fan of "Matilda" either, so I\'m wondering if Ronald Dahl just can\'t be properly musicalized. As usual, the cast is filled with professionals who each get a moment or two to stand out, and I wish that the fantastic Jackie Hoffman would get that part that finally gets her the Tony nomination I thought she has deserved for several parts. At expensive Broadway prices (even TKTS half off or rush/lottery rates), you expect some pizazz, and the dull colorless factory set was an absolute disappointment. I\'ll give it credit for one thing: I did enjoy it somewhat better than "Cats", but that is not saying much.', 'This review is way too kind. The London production certainly had its shortcomings, but overall it was both tuneful and pleasantly eye-popping. The Broadway version has "solved" both those problems. First, several charming, clever songs in the first act are gone - replaced by bland and forgettable numbers. But the greatest abomination is how unbelievably cheap they\'ve made the entire show look. Bare stages, with just a single set piece are the norm. There\'s even one scene in the factory with NOTHING on the stage as the actors mime their way through an invisible obstacle course. Pure imagination, indeed. But two scenes stand out as the most blatant cheapskate-ry I\'ve ever seen on a Broadway stage. First, the fabled Chocolate Room, which in London was passably impressive. On Broadway, however, it has been swapped out with something best described as a Chocolate Terrarium - literally a 10\' x 10\' glass box that looks like a display of Easter candy at your local Duane Reade. The poor actors look ludicrous as they stand around it pretending to be awed. Equally bad is the Great Glass Elevator. In London, it took off to dizzying heights, even soaring out over the audience. On Broadway, it rises ten feet into the air, stops, and then comes back down. That\'s it. The greedy producers should hang their heads in shame, and I can only hope their cynical, calculated contempt for their audience bites them in the wallet. You can help by avoiding this abysmal excuse of a Broadway musical.', 'This is one of the most repulsive things I\'ve ever seen. Walked out in the middle of the second act. Took everything great about the book, and the 1971 movie, and ruined it. There was one line in particular that stood out, "If cabbages were watches, I\'d tell you the time", which is some of the worst lyrics ever made. If your thinking of seeing this play, DON"T!', 'I saw the show in the company of two 7 year olds and they thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the show as did I.  Christian Borle was fantastic and the show was engaging. It is nice to have show options on Broadway that appeal to children; after all they are the next generation of ticket buyers.  Not everything has to be Shakespeare', 'My comment is not on the show, but on a trend I\'ve noted in Mr. Brantley\'s most recent reviews. Just this past week, he\'s referred to actors (not characters) as looking "embarassed",  and suffering from "a lack of conviction", although he sugests it is not on the young actor\'s part.  I find this second-guessing questioning an actor\'s professionalism disturbing. It\'s perfectly acceptable to question the merits of a performance or production without suggesting that an actor would reveal to an audience that he or she was unhappy to be in said production, and would telegraph a lack of commitment to a paying audience.', "I saw this show a couple of weeks ago. Borle, as expected, was great. The rest was a complete and utter disappointment. I left the theatre thinking that a musical that should have felt magical was anything but. Fortunately, I saw Anastasia this past Friday and that feeling I was hoping for with Charlie came in full force and then some. If you're debating between the two, head to the Broadhurst.", "All hail Jackie Hoffman!  No actor is funnier these days than Ms. Hoffman on stage or screen or anywhere else...from the Book of Liz to Puddy Singleton to Mamasita and now Mrs. Teavee.   With all due respect to Donna Murphy or even Tyne Daly, she's the best candidate to take over for Bette Midler in Hello Dolly after the Divine one's contract is up next year.", 'delighted to have discovered her video blog on you tube. the woman is hysterical! i will see anything she is in! her backstage antics while in adams family are side splitting. kudos!', "Johnny Depp was one of my favourite actors until I saw his version of Willy Wonka. The movie did have the necessary darkness of Dahl but it seemed just so ugly and lacking in charm and I've only shown my Dahl-obsessed kids the Gene Wilder version.  We all loved Matilda on Broadway (possibly my favourite Broadway show, ever) so the bar was set high and we were so hoping that this would deliver.  I need to read some more reviews first though; not sold on it yet.", "Sorry, I just can't watch Depp's version...one look at him and you think it should be called A Clockwork Chocolate.", 'Took my visiting 9 yr old niece opening week. The sets were a hugely disappointing. Score not so toe tapping. Needs work. My niece was asleep by the final act.  I mostly agree with this review however the Oompa Loopa\'s "almost" make up for all the faults!  So well done and clever. They should give the Rockets the night off and let this little chorus line take over.! LOl.', "I saw this show in previews with my two nieces and we all loved it.  I thought it could have used some judicious editing and perhaps edits were made.  The production is throughly inventive, we loved the musical numbers and Christian Borle is brilliant.  The reviewer needs to see this musical with young ones in tow.   I'm sure I was influenced by my vicarious joy in watching my nieces howl with laughter over the squirrel ballet.", '"In the second act, these spoiled young things get their just deserts..." um, you would think that a writer of a review describing a chocolate factory would know that dessert is spelled with the double s, not the single.', 'Sorry, but pudding has nothing to do with it; "deserts" are what one deserves, hence the single "s".', 'While it would be quite punny to spell it "desserts", the phrase is "deserts," as in things that are deserved.', 'Saw the show last Wednesday and in my less than High Brow Intellect , I found it to be what I expected and closer to a pleasant Surprise! My 8 and 10 year old grand children Loved it and they should be the ones to write a review.  Satisfying and Delicious', 'Saw it recently with my kids. They loved it, even the darker moments, though some younger children seated near us appeared to be a bit shaken during certain scenes. So it may be plenty "spicy" for the tween set. Christian Borle can do no wrong according to the theater lovers in our household, so it was no surprise that he met and exceeded our expectations with his delightful and nuanced Wonka. So much is demanded of Mr. Borle in the second act, however, one wonders how long any actor might last in the role. We felt there were lots of lively and memorable performances from the entire cast, and plenty of fun new songs (not in the movie versions). The only significant disappointment for us was the choice of a minimalist set design, which was so skimpy that it became, ironically, a distraction. While we did not see the London staging -- and there seems to be a lot of attention paid to comparisons between the two -- we feel there is much to recommend about this terrific new version of the show.', 'Dear Mr. Brantley, You just retroactively ruined my entire childhood.', "Did Ben Brantly pick the title of this review? I read somewhere that there is a totally different person who writes the titles. If so, did the title writer read the review? I don't know if Ben meant that the show should have been spicier. I am going to see it in mid may, and am looking forward it it.", 'It should be "these spoiled young things get their just desserts"', 'See above comments. "deserts" is the proper.', 'It\'s been a while since I\'ve encountered the name "John Rubinstein" in a cast listing.  To be apprised that he\'s now doing grandfather roles fills me with dread of my own mortality.  Yikes!', 'John Rubinstein had two brief scenes with Joan Crawford playing George Cukor in the recent series, "Feud" and did a wonderful job. He also appeared a couple of years ago in the revival of "Pippin" on Broadway and also on the subsequent tour, play King Charles, the father of Pippin, the part he played back in 1972. Yes, we all get older.', "Ye gods and little fishes, Stu, you're right ... if memory serves, he played the lead in the very first B'way musical I ever saw, another manchild-dreamer: Pippin. Yikes indeed."]
summary: About half of the commenters think that other theater goers should skip Charlie and the Chocolate Factory because of the darkness in some of the scenes. The other half say they like the play, even the younger ones in their families. There is some discussion about the various actors in the play, with some focus on John Rubinstein because of his age. One commenter points out that the phrase "just desserts" should be "just deserts" because it refers to what people deserve, not to sweet treats.
short_title: Headline: Some Sugar. Could Use More Spice.   Keywords: Theater; Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (Play); O'Brien, Jack (1939- ); Borle, Christian; Dahl, Roald; Greig, David; Shaiman, Marc; Wittman, Scott   Snippet: Christian Borle is the eccentric Willy Wonka in this tentative musical based on the Roald Dahl children’s classic.
